DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 1, or the 25th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
2001: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issues a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial." ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM NESAT FORMS NEAR GUAM

TEXT.P: A low pressure system near Guam has gained strength to become a tropical storm, and it's still too early to predict whether the "light typhoon" will affect Taiwan in the next couple of days, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Wednesday.

Typhoon Nesat, the fourth typhoon reported in the Pacific this year, was located some 2,700 kilometers away from Taiwan, moving in a west-northwest direction at a speed of 15 kilometers per hour as of 10 a.m. Wednesday, according to CWB meteorologists.
Meanwhile, the Central Weather Bureau forecast thunderstorms for central and southern Taiwan and cloudy skies for the north for Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL SOLICITS FRENCH ART INDUSTRY TO EXPLORE TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of cultural affairs on Tuesday called for the French art and design sectors to make inroads into Taiwan where they may find brand new markets to demonstrate French creativity.

Chen Chi-nan, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Cultural Affairs (CCA) , said that France used to market its industrial products and military equipment to Taiwan, but it is time that the country also known for its modern and contemporary art sell more "cultural" products to Taiwan.

Chen, who arrived in Paris recently to preside over the ninth Taiwan-France Cultural Award presentation ceremony co-sponsored by the CCA and the French Academy (Academie Francaise), made the remarks during his visit at the prestigious Centre Pompidou, one of the most daring modern arts museums in the world.

Noting that currently there are many spaces in Taiwan which have been left idle and are now targeted to be redesigned for public use, Chen extended an invitation to French artists and designers to go to Taiwan to explore new opportunities.

Chen said that the CCA will in the future invite internationally-known design firms to make field trips to Taiwan and give their professional opinions on how Taiwan should redesign and reconstruct these "idle spaces, " adding that the CCA will probably sponsor international open bids for the development of such spaces.

Chen and Pierre Messmer, president of the Academie Francaise, jointly presided over the presentation ceremony for the Taiwan-France Cultural Award, which are aimed at promoting cultural exchanges as well as serving as a bridge to strengthen contact between the two countries.

This year's award was presented to two research groups represented respectively by Chantal Zheng, director of the Institute for Research on Southeast Asia at the University of Provence, and Jean-Pierre Cabestan, a senior research fellow of a Chinese study team at the French National Center for Scientific Research. (By Y.S. Lo and Deborah Kuo) ENDTIME/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA FORMING VOLUNTARY ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION SQUADS

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) is planning to form and dispatch 10-member environmental protection squads to each city and county around the island to reinforce its environmental surveillance operations in local areas, an EPA official said Wednesday.

Last December, the Cabinet-level administration recruited several retired public servants, military personnel and public school teachers to form the first "environmental guard" of the country. Inspired by the guard's efficient performance in assisting the government to promote environmental protection, the EPA has decided to recruit more retired public servants to engage in the volunteer work.
The official said that the planned local environmental squads are expected to be set up by the end of June and soon after kick off their mission of working to prevent pollution.

The guard could help local environmental protection authorities collect evidence, including photos, against suspected polluters and help stop such illegal activities before they expand into major environmental disasters, the official said.
The squads' work will also include publicizing environmental protection regulations and encouraging people not to engage in environmentally-unfriendly behavior, such as littering, the official said.

All retired public servants, public school teachers and service persons aged under 70 are qualified to apply for the volunteer positions, the EPA official said, indicating that applicants will be given tests and professional training before they are certified as members of an environmental squad.
Despite the fact that the work is voluntary in nature, squad members will be awarded with money if they help in cracking major pollution cases under existing regulations, the official added.

Those who are interested in applying can do so at any of the EPA's offices around the island, or phone the EPA hot line at (04) -2252-1718, ext. 163 or visit the bureau's Web site at http://www.epa.gov.tw for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER JUSTIFIES TAX REFORMS

TEXT.P: Tax reform proposals unveiled recently by President Chen Shui-bian should not be construed as an across-the-board tax hike, Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Wednesday.

At a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh said the reforms are aimed at establishing a fair taxation system by expanding the tax base and he instructed the authorities to explain the idea to the public to minimize their resistance to the tax increases.
Hsieh noted that it is difficult to promote tax reforms in any country, especially when the reforms involve tax hikes for the public.

Hsieh pointed out that proposals to expand the tax base have failed on many occasions to win the support of the Legislative Yuan, which, he claimed, is quick to pass proposals on tax cuts and exemptions.
With the tax system having become "distorted" under these circumstances, the continued expansion of social welfare is causing a fiscal gap for the government, Hsieh said.

According to Hsieh, although the tax reform plans will increase the tax burden for certain sectors, they do not mean an across-the-board tax hike, because commodity tax, stamp tax, gift tax and inheritance tax will decrease.
The government will also work out complementary measures to ensure the burden upon the underprivileged will not become heavier, he added.

Meanwhile, commenting on the issue during a trip to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Vice President Annette Lu said the tax reform proposals were put forth by the president after a long period of study and discussion with his economic advisers.
Lu said the reform is necessary because the government's fiscal condition is tight and Taiwan's tax rates are relatively low compared with other countries.
She promised that the government will follow the principles of justice and fairness in promoting the reforms.
Chen said Monday that the reforms are aimed at raising the average national tax rate from the current 13.6 percent to 15 percent in three years and even higher -- to 18 percent -- as a mid-term goal.

The reform proposals unveiled by the president include hiking the business tax by one or two percentage points to 6 percent or 7 percent and levying a capital gains tax on investment in unlisted companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TRAIN FOR KAOHSIUNG MRT SYSTEM UNVEILED
DOC.DATELINE: Vienna, June 1 (CNA) (By S.F. Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The first three-car train for the mass rapid transit (MRT) system currently under construction in Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung was unveiled Wednesday at a ceremony held at a Siemens plant in Vienna.

Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Chou Lie-liung and Sepp Rieder, a deputy mayor of Vienna, jointly presided over the ceremony to mark the building of the first of Kaohsiung's MRT trains.
The train will be transported to Cologne in Germany for tests before being delivered to Kaohsiung in October, said Volker Kefer, president of Siemens Transportation Business Division.

The Kaohsiung MRT Bureau has ordered 42 of the trains from Siemens. The first batch will be used on the R3 line connecting the Hsiaokang International Airport and Santuo Road beginning in October 2006, according to Chou, who coincidentally was the director-general of the Kaohsiung MRT Bureau before assuming his post at the Transportation and Communications Ministry in February this year.

Addressing the ceremony, Rieder lauded Siemens' outstanding expertise and technology in building electrical engineering systems for MRT trains, which have helped create jobs and a better economy for the Austrian capital of Vienna.

For his part, Kefer praised Kaohsiung as a growing and promising city. He particularly offered his admiration for Premier Frank Hsieh, who was the mayor of Kaohsiung City prior to Feb. 1, and was the prime mover behind the development of the Kaohsiung MRT project.

The Siemens-built MRT cars -- in white and green livery and boasting modern interior decor featuring LED display panels and see-through seat partition walls -- are each capable of carrying 750 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN CHILDREN HAVE EYE, DENTAL, WEIGHT PROBLEMS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Most of Taiwan's children aged between six and 15 have problems with their vision, teeth and weight, according to the results of a general health survey conducted by the Ministry of Education and released Wednesday.

The survey, conducted by the Education Ministry for school year 2004, found that 42.7 percent of elementary school children were either too thin or too fat to meet the weight standards set for this age group in Taiwan.

The survey of all children aged between six and 15 nationwide found that 16.4 percent of elementary school children and 24.6 percent of junior high school students are underweight or suffer from a growth disorder but have never obtained medical attention for the condition.
It found that 7.8 percent of first graders are overweight and that the fatness rate increased gradually grade-on-grade to reach an average of 15 percent among sixth graders.
The survey also found that 26.5 percent of elementary school first graders had visual problems, a rate rose to 52.2 percent among sixth graders.

In terms of dental problems, however, elementary school first graders have a higher percentage than their fourth grade counterparts, or 68.17 percent against 49.77 percent, indicating that children have problems with their teeth even before they reach the age of 6, Education Ministry officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOURNALIST GROUP ARRIVES IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, May 31 (CNA) (By C.F. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 13-member journalist mission of reporters from Taiwan arrived in New York Tuesday for a 10-day visit under the leadership of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng.

The delegation will then proceed to Washington, where it will visit Randall G. Schriver, former U. S. deputy assistant secretary of state, and meet members of major think tanks such as the National Committee on U. S. - China Relations, the CATO Institute, the American Enterprise Institute, the Council on Foreign Relations, the Heritage Foundation and a group of pro-Taiwan congressmen.

According to a MAC spokesman, the main purpose of the visit organized by the MAC is to help Taiwan reporters gain an increased understanding of the U. S. government stance and policy-making on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation after Beijing enacted the Anti- Secession Law in the middle of March aimed at containing Taiwan independence.
The Cabinet-level MAC is Taiwan's top agency in charge of China affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

The bourse opened at 6,002.55 and fluctuated between 6,023.34 and 5,962.88 during trading. A total of 3.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.25 billion (US$2.52 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.9 percent, machinery and electronic shares at 0.7 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 472 to 379, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH REAFFIRMS STANCE ON PEACEFUL SOLUTION TO TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, May 31 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush reaffirmed his commitment Tuesday to assist in resolving the Taiwan Strait issue peacefully.
Fielding questions at a White House news conference, Bush said there is tension across the Taiwan Strait and that his position on the issue has been very clear and consistent.

Asked about the nature of U.S.-China ties, Bush said the relationship is very complex. In some fields, such as trade, the two countries are competitors, he said, adding that in other domains, such as the anti-terrorism campaign and the North Korea issue, the two countries are partners.
As far as the Taiwan issue is concerned, Bush said, the relationship is one of helping to solve the cross-strait dispute peacefully.

"Obviously, there's tension about Taiwan that we have to deal with, and I made my position very clear and very consistent about Taiwan. The Taiwanese understand my position. The Chinese understand my position. So in this case, the relationship is one of helping to solve that problem as to keeping stability in the region so that eventually there will be a peaceful solution to that issue, " Bush said.
He also stressed that the United States has an obligation to remind China that economic freedom is not enough to make a hopeful society.

"China is a fascinating country that is significant in its size. Its economy is still small, but growing. But as well, I believe we have an obligation to remind the Chinese that any hopeful society is one in which there's more than just economic freedom; that there's religious freedom and freedom of the press," Bush said.

In his meetings with different Chinese leaders, Bush said, he has always brought up issues such as the Dalai Lama, or the Catholic Church's inability to get a bishop into China, or the need for the country not to fear evangelists, but to understand that religious freedom leads to peace.
"And so I'll continue doing that so long as I'm the president, and at the same time help deal with this very complex relationship, " Bush added.

During his first term, Bush had on two occasions clearly stated his stance on the Taiwan issue. Shortly after he assumed office in 2001, he said the United States will do whatever it can to help Taiwan defend itself.

In December 2003, he told Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao during a meeting at the White House that the United States is opposed to either side of the Taiwan Strait taking unilateral action that could change the Taiwan Strait status quo. He also warned that if China attacks Taiwan, the United States will not sit idly.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET CALLS FOR TALKS WITH CHINA OVER PANDA GIFT

TEXT.P: China's offer to give Taiwan a pair of pandas should be arranged through government-to-government negotiations, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Wednesday.

According to Cho, the delivery of the pandas to Taiwan must comply with international conventions on endangered species conservation, and it requires quarantine and conservation assessments to ensure Taiwan has the ability to care for the animals.
Therefore, it would be best for the authorities and experts from both sides to discuss the issue, Cho said.

He made the remarks after a Chinese official repeated earlier that day Beijing's offer to give Taiwan a pair of pandas and claimed that the gift is a matter between China and Taiwan and does not fall under the jurisdiction of any international conventions.
Beijing first made the offer early last month during opposition Kuomintang Lien Chan's visit to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES SCHOOL BUILDING RECONSTRUCTION PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved Wednesday a NT$21 billion (US$669 million) project to reconstruct decrepit old buildings at elementary and junior high schools nationwide over four years.

According to a Ministry of Education survey, of more than 3,000 elementary and junior high schools around the country, reconstruction is required in 448 of them, affecting a total of 11,375 classrooms.
The reconstruction project is scheduled to run from 2006 to 2009.

At the Cabinet meeting in which the project was discussed, Premier Frank Hsieh instructed the ministry to prioritize the reconstruction of schools in outlying regions and to keep track of the schedule to ensure the project is accomplished on time.
Hsieh said the funding required by the project will be provided through a special budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AFFAIRS COUNCIL TO CREATE 3,500 JOBS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has begun a job creation program in cooperation with local governments, eyeing underprivileged and handicapped job seekers, a CLA spokesman said Wednesday.

According to the CLA official, the council plans to create 3,500 jobs on recommendation by public-run employment agencies for married women, middle-aged and elderly job seekers, mentally and physically challenged people, aborigines and registered workers who remain jobless for more than three months, in collaboration with local governments from now until the end of the month.

The CLA will receive employment boost projects filed by local governments with jobs in the fields of industrial development, social services and medical treatment, community security, the humanities, residential design and environmental protection during the month-long period as part of the government's efforts to help boost employment.

Budget for the CLA's job creation program will be allocated in principle from a special fund of NT$1.5 billion (US$48 million) under its management, the official said, adding that the CLA might also use the money in an employment stabilization fund if local governments come up with too many projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA MAKES EFFORTS TO REDUCE TRADE DEFICIT WITH SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: In an effort to lower Taiwan's big trade deficit with South Korea, the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is inviting local businesses to join a delegation that will visit South Korea in September to seek trade opportunities, a TAITRA official said Wednesday.

South Korea has become the second-largest source of Taiwan's foreign trade deficit behind Japan in recent years. According to Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) statistics, Taiwan's exports to South Korea amounted to US$5.35 billion last year, while imports reached US$11.63 billion.

In the first quarter of this year, Taiwan's exports to South Korea amounted to US$1.22 billion, marking a growth of 1.6 percent over the year-earlier level. However, imports posted a surge of 18.2 percent at US$3.13 billion, the tallies show.

To reduce the deficit, MOFA and TAITRA have mapped out various projects aimed at expanding exports to South Korea, including the September trade-promotion visit, the official said. He noted that local businesses in the sectors of electronics, electrics, machinery, communications, medical treatment equipment, chemicals, construction materials, household and consumer products, textiles, foodstuffs and hand tools are all welcome to have their representatives join the delegation.
Last year, South Korean exports reached over US$200 billion, representing a 30 percent growth, according to TAITRA, creating a trade surplus of US$29 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: EACH HOUSEHOLD IN TAIWAN OWNS 0.9 CARS ON AVERAGE: MOTC

TEXT.P: Official statistics show that at the end of April, every household in Taiwan owned an average 0.9 cars and 1.7 motorcycles or scooters, while there were 6.52 million vehicles, excluding motorbikes, on the roads.
According to statistics of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , at the end of April, every 1,000 households had 901.5 automobiles and 1,789.5 motorbikes or scooters on average.
Of the 6.52 million cars, 2.594 million, or 39.9 percent, were over 10 years old, marking the largest automobile group in the country.
The second-largest group was cars aged between seven years and 10 years, at 1.328 million or 20 percent, the statistics show.

In 2004, there were a total of 11.77 million traffic regulation violations in the country, or an average 32,000 per day. The government collected a total of NT$20.34 billion (US$648 million) in traffic fines, according to the MOTC.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS OPPOSE BUSINESS TAX HIKE

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators said Wednesday that during an upcoming meeting with President Chen Shui-bian they will oppose the government's plan to increase business tax.
The legislators argued that the government should abolish the tax exempt measure for the hi-tech sector instead of increasing the business tax, which they said will affect all consumers.
Chen has since May 18 met with two different groups of DPP legislators to exchange views on various issues. He is scheduled to meet a third group Thursday.

The president unveiled Monday a set of tax reform proposals aimed at raising the average national tax rate from the current 13.6 percent to 15 percent in three years and even higher -- to 18 percent -- as a mid-term goal.
The proposals include hiking the business tax by one or two percentage points to 6 percent or 7 percent and levying a capital gains tax on investment in unlisted companies.

According to DPP Legislator Wang Jung-chang, the tax reforms should not focus mainly on the adjustment of business tax but should address the priority issues of taxation unfairness and the light tax burden on the wealthy.
Wang Shih-chien, another DPP legislator, said the tax hikes should target the people at the top of the wealth pyramid, rather than everyone.

He proposed that the government revise the law to scrap the tax exemption measure for the hi-tech industry, which according to him will give an increase of several hundred billion new Taiwan dollars in tax revenue annually.
He also suggested that the tax hike plans be postponed in light of the rise in consumer prices.
Agreeing with Wang, DPP Legislator Kuo Jung-chung said now is not the right time to hike taxes and make life even harder for the people.

Kuo noted that the hi-tech sector has been able to generate high profits every year mainly because it has enjoyed government protection and various preferential taxation measures for a long time. It is time, he said, for the sector to reciprocate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEGISLATIVE MISSION ARRIVES IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 21-member legislative mission led by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator P. K. Chiang arrived in Tokyo Wednesday for a six-day visit.

The group was met by Koh Se-kai, Taiwan's representative to Japan, at the airport. Accompanied by Koh, the group immediately left for the official residence of Takako Doi, Japan's first female speaker of the House, for a visit.
Doi, who has long been friendly toward Taiwan, stressed the need for increased exchanges between lawmakers of the two countries.

The 21 legislators from Taiwan's various political parties will take part in the third annual meeting with members of the Alliance for Japan-Taiwan Friendship -- a group of pro-Taiwan Japanese lawmakers -- Thursday in Tokyo for discussions on security and economic issues in Asia.

The Taiwanese lawmakers will then proceed to Chibu Prefecture Friday, where some of them will participate in an Asian-Pacific lawmakers' meeting on renewable energy Saturday through Sunday. Chiang is slated to give a speech on the occasion.
They will also visit the 2005 World Exposition being held in Aichi Prefecture Sunday before flying back to Taipei Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ASPIRANTS OUTLINE VISIONS FOR PARTY

TEXT.P: Two hopefuls for the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship laid out their visions for the party Wednesday, touching on the party's line, its strategy for the year-end city and county chief elections, its exchanges with the ruling party, cross-Taiwan Strait policy and its controversial party asset issues.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, both of whom concurrently serve as KMT vice chairmen, were each given 30 minutes to air their views at the KMT Central Standing Committee (CSC) meeting and were then grilled by 20 CSC members befored giving their answers for 10 minutes respectively.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan was positive about the two candidates after listening to their reports, and told them to engage in a "gentleman's battle" in the July 16 chairmanship election.

Wang said the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP) , will take advantage of their majority in the Legislative Yuan and will organize street protests, supposedly to "stop the ruling Democratic Progressive Party from hurting Taiwan through populism."
As long as the DPP will not address its "partial and biased way, " the KMT will not stop its checks and balances, he said, adding that this is an approach to keep "populism at bay."
The party will also formulate legislation and create public service issues so as to carry out a "quasi-ruling" goal and stop a "populist government from having its own way," according to Wang.
Ma for his part said the KMT will safeguard the sovereignty of the Republic of China, its interests and dignity, and will adamantly oppose Taiwan independence.
Also, Taiwan should not engage in a "desinicization" campaign but should admit its cultural and historical roots, Ma said.

Ma said that cross-strait tension has been the major hurdle to Taiwan's development and that it has cast a shadow over East Asian peace. For Taiwan, however, "it is a threat, but also an opportunity," he added.

"Taiwan cannot hinge its hopes on goodwill from the other side and should maintain a credible deterrent force, but it should also take advantage of its concentration on peaceful development at this stage to seek the possibility of co-existence and co-prosperity, " he said.

Ma also spoke of his basic stance -- based on the Constitution and the so-called "1992 consensus" of "one China, different interpretations, " which the ruling Democartic Progressive Party does not recognize the existence of -- to promote cross-strait peace, exchanges and cooperation under the principles of equality and dignity.

The party will also follow through on Lien's five-point agreement with Chinese President Hu Jintao during their April 29 meeting in Beijing to promote cross-strait relations, which includes the promotion of an end to hostility and the establishment of a confidence-building mechanism, opposition to Taiwan independence and a resumption of dialogue as soon as possible, Ma said.
Wang largely echoed Ma's views, saying that he agreed with the insistence on the "1992 consensus" and opposition to Taiwan independence as outlined in the Lien-Hu consensus.

He also said that most people in Taiwan are concerned with five issues, including an end to hostility and a move toward peace, direct cross-strait transportation links, cross-strait economic cooperation, protection of the rights of Taiwan businessmen and Taiwan's participation in international organizations that have few political connotations.
Wang reaffirmed that he will go to China in his capacity as legislative speaker if needed and if the legislature passes a resolution and the visit is based on equal footing.
On the campaign strategy of the year-end elections, Wang said the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP should launch a united campaign in Taipei County and solidify its edge in northern Taiwan.
Taichung, Changhua and Nantou counties have deep rivalry between the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, he said.
Ma said that the KMT and the PFP should step up cooperation and engage in consultation to nominate shared candidates in each city and county.

Ma also said that neighboring cities and counties have increasing number of issues that are shared between them, and that "pan-blue alliance" candidates should unite with their counterparts in neighboring cities and counties for campaigning.

On party assets, Wang advocated that the top priority should be given to retired and incumbent party workers and to keep a substantial amount for the party's sustainable development. In the longer term, the party should use its money frugally and major election expenditures should be financed by soliciting donations, he said.
Ma said that the handling of the party assets should be speeded up and that the party should encourage retirement without forcing party workers to quit.
The proceeds of handling the party assets should be published regularly to avoid accusations of corruption, Ma added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT TAIPEI DIRECTOR TO COMMUNICATE WITH LAWMAKERS ON ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The United States' top envoy to Taiwan will host a luncheon June 9 with members of the National Defense Committee in the Legislative Yuan to communicate with them on the long-stalled major arms procurement package, a committee convener said Wednesday.

Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was referring to the Cabinet's proposal last June to buy six Patriot Pac-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, which has been blocked by the opposition-dominated legislature and had yet to be put on the legislative agenda for review before the first session of the legislature closed Tuesday.
The Executive Yuan and the DPP have listed the major arms procurement project as their top priority in a proposed extra legislative session.

Lee said that with Douglas Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan, Taipei Office, communicating directly with the opposition legislators, it will certainly help the major arms procurement project in the extra legislative session, but he predicted that the effects will be limited.

He said the passage of the bill will have to return to its fundamentals, adding that the triangular relations between President Chen Shui-bian, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will hold the key to its passage.

But PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang said he had already declined the invitation from Paal to avoid any "conflict of interests, " while KMT Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen said that she had not decided whether to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS, EXPERTS SUGGEST LOWERING TAX IN FREE TRADE ZONES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers and experts suggested Wednesday that the government lower business tax for free trade zones to lure manufacturers to such zones.
They made the suggestion during a public hearing on complementary measures for free trade zones sponsored by a group in the Legislative Yuan to promote the tax legislation.

Legislator Christina Y. Liu of the opposition People First Party said the zones should be considered "special zones" in which there should be complete liberalization. She urged a lowering of tax in the zones so as to stay competitive with free trade zones in neighboring countries.
Legislator Kuo Jung-tsung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that the tax rate should reflect the original purpose of setting up free trade zones.
Kuo said that compared with the tax ratios in neighboring countries, Taiwan imposes too high a tax in free trade zones and therefore cannot entice manufacturers to set up there.

Chao Teng-chung, chairman of the Far Glory Group, said the establishment of free trade zones is aimed at luring Taiwan businessmen to return to Taiwan from China, but with a tax ratio of 25 percent, manufacturers will be more likely to consider China or South Korea, both of which have lower tax ratios.
Chao suggested lowering the tax ratio, but said the level of lowering should consider other neighboring countries and should not only be compared to China's level.

Professor Wei Chi-lin of National Taiwan University predicted that if the tax ratio can be lowered, it will lure Taiwan businessmen and foreign manufacturers, which will in turn create higher tax revenues.
Taiwan currently has three free trade zones in Keelung, Kaohsiung and Taichung harbors, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: 'Deep Throat' Unmasks Himself as Ex-No. 2 Official at F.B.I.
Deep Throat, the mystery man who reigned as Washington's best-kept secret source for more than 30 years, was not just any shadowy, cigarette-smoking tipster in a raincoat. He was the No. 2 official of the F.B.I., W. Mark Felt, who helped The Washington Post unravel the Watergate scandal and the presidency of Richard M. Nixon, a feat that he lived to see disclosed on Tuesday, frail but smiling at 91. In a final plot twist worthy of the saga that Felt helped to spawn, Vanity Fair magazine released an article from its July issue reporting that Felt, long a prime suspect to Nixon himself, had in recent years confided to his family and friends, "I'm the guy they used to call 'Deep Throat.' "
Wall Street Journal: Global Dogfight; Airplane Battle Spotlights Power of a Quirky Court.
A three-person panel will soon convene to decide what could be the most expensive trade dispute in history -- a clash between the U.S. and the European Union over tens of billions of dollars in government aid that's gone to the world's two major airplane makers, Chicago-based Boeing Co. and Airbus of Toulouse, France. The U.S. equested that a WTO panel decide the case, saying that months of talks with the EU had led nowhere. European officials im mediately filed a countersuit.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO DEPLOY BOMBER SQUADRON IN GUAM: JAPANESE TV
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States will deploy a bomber squadron in Guam to cope with contingencies or crises in the Asia-Pacific region, Japan's public television station NHK reported Wednesday.
According to the NHK report, the squadron, to be stationed at the Andersen air force base, will be composed of some 70 aircraft, including bombers, jet fighters and unmanned reconnaissance planes.
The report said the squadron will be able to use stealth bombers to enter any enemy country's airspace and destroy its important facilities with sophisticated weapons.

According to the Pentagon plan, the report said, the squadron's 48 jet fighters and six bombers will be based on the U.S. mainland but will fly to Guam at regular intervals. The squadron's three unmanned Global Hawk reconnaissance aircraft and 12 strategic refueling planes will be posted at Andersen permanently.

As part of the new deployment plan, Andersen staff will increase by 2,400 and new facilities will be built at the base. It will take several years to complete the deployment plan, the NHK report said, adding that an environmental impact evaluation survey is already underway. The number of military aircraft to be stationed at the base might also change in terms of the results of the environmental survey.

The NHK report further said the Pentagon is undertaking a worldwide U.S. military re-deployment plan to cope with a reduction of U.S. troops in South Korea and the changing world situation, and that the Andersen bomber squadron deployment is part of that project.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY TO VOTE ON PROPOSED CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS JUNE 7

TEXT.P: Political parties and representative groups at the National Assembly will present their views June 6 on the amendment package to the Constitution and voting will begin the following day, those chairing the assembly decided Wednesday.
The session of the ad hoc National Assembly opened on Monday and will consider constitutional amendments passed by the Legislature last August. The assembly is expected to meet for about two weeks.

Twenty-six delegates have been assigned to deliver speeches that day and each speaker will have seven minutes to state his or her party or group's position. Six of the delegates are from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and six are from the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang.
The People First Party and the Taiwan Solitary Union will each have three delegates give statements, while other parties or groups with fewer then five delegates will each have one person speak.
The National Assembly will start voting on the proposed reforms on June 7.

Items in the constitutional reform package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113, adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE PRESENTS ANTI-DRUG FILMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice presented three anti-drug films Wednesday as part of the government's efforts to fight drug abuse.

According to a ministry official, one of the three films features the stories of drug addicts in Malaysia and Thailand shot by a preacher from Malaysia who was also a drug addict but kicked the habit more than 20 years ago.
At a press conference, the preacher, named Chen, expressed hope that the story of his life with drugs will help other people say no to drugs.
According to Premier Frank Hsieh, crimes related to drug abuse and trafficking have risen significantly in the last three years, with the amount of seized drugs last year reaching a 10-year high.

The Cabinet has set the period from 2005 to 2008 as "national drug-fighting years, " in which the government will launch all-out efforts to fight against drug abuse and trafficking, the premier added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER WITHDRAWS FROM PARTY PRIMARY FOR TAIPEI COUNTY HEAD

TEXT.P: A prospective Kuomintang (KMT) candidate for Taipei County magistrate was shown the door Wednesday after she fared poorly in a party-commissioned public opinion poll.

KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said that she had "misgivings" about the polling procedure and regretted the result, but said she will respect the democratic system within the party and will withdraw from the next stage of the primary -- which will be the voting among KMT members.
Hung noted that she had insisted on not soliciting donations at this stage and so she did not have the financial power that other prospective candidates have.
She said that the poll will account for 70 percent of the result of the party's primary, and if someone leads by a large margin, then it is clear who the candidate will be.
Saying that she didn't have the money to carry on, Hung said, "I have fought a good battle."

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei, who returned to the fold of the KMT from the People First Party (PFP) to boost his chance of winning the bitterly contested Taipei County magistrate race, said that Hung "has set a good example" of integrating the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP.

Chou said that he believes the polls are fair mechanism, and will respect the procedure of the primary, adding that he is confident of integrating the "pan-blue alliance" forces to run against the ruling "pan-green" camp candidate.

Huang Teh-fu, director of the KMT's Taipei County branch, said that the public polling company commissioned by the party is very professional and was agreed upon by all the would-be candidates from the outset.
The official results of the public opinion poll will be released after the vote by party members is completed, Huang said.

Meanwhile, Sanchung City Mayor Lee Chien-lung said that in fact only himself, Hung and another woman hopeful are qualified to run for the party's candidate, adding that if the actual selected candidate is not one of these three, he will not support this individual.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM SUPPORTS SIGNING OF U.S.-TAIWAN FTA: CEPD OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Officials of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei will support the signing of a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement (FTA) at their upcoming meetings with U.S. government officials, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

In AmCham's 2005 Taiwan White Paper released Tuesday, the trade organization recognized Taiwan's progress in the protection of intellectual property rights and the cooperation between the island's executive and legislative branches in several aspects, such as the completion of an amendment to the IPR Law.

According to the CEPD, several high-ranking AmCham officials had said that they will support the signing of a U.S.-Taiwan free trade agreement during their upcoming "doorknocking" trip to Washington, D.C. slated for June 12-18, which is aimed at visiting U.S. trade officials and members of Congress to discuss issues brought up in the 2005 Taiwan White Paper.

Unlike previous years, the 2005 Taiwan White Paper does not give priority to cross-Taiwan Strait issues, as AmCham President Tom Johnson said he was happy to see that there has been increased dialogue between the two sides in the last few years.
Johnson noted that although there has not been substantial progress in cross-strait economic and trade ties, he feels optimistic on the future of cross-strait relations.

Instead, AmCham expresses more concern on several practical issues this year, such as too much fake pesticides and medicines being circulated in the market and punishments for forgers that are too light.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGE OF KMT CHAIRMAN WILL NOT ALTER POLITICAL LANDSCAPE: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: If President Chen Shui-bian thinks that the political climate will change after opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan steps down from the post he is "very mistaken, " KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen quoted the party chairman as saying Wednesday.
Cheng said that Lien made the remark following the party's weekly Central Standing Committee meeting.
According to Cheng, Lien's rationale was that since the KMT is a party coherent and consistent in assuming a task, the party's stance will not be different simply because of a change in leadership.

Lien also warned the president to stay on the alert in August, when many issues of major public concern are expected to further pressure him, pointing to the potential for fruit overproduction and the possible failure to honor the government's promise to allow Chinese citizens to sightsee in Taiwan, as examples.

Lien's comments came after the president said over the last weekend during a gathering with lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that Taiwan's political situation will improve in the middle of July after Lien quits the KMT's chairmanship when his term expires.

According to a DPP source, Chen was optimistic that Lien's departure will create an improved political situation, which in turn will help important bills clear the Legislative Yuan, such as a major military procurement bill and approval of the list of presidential nominees for Control Yuan members.

Moreover, the president also contended that the KMT will stop trying to investigate the March 19 shooting of himself and Vice President Annette Lu by that time after a KMT chairman is produced following a vote by party members set for July 16, the source added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-MINISTERIAL MEETING TO BE HELD TO ADDRESS MANPOWER SHORTAGES

TEXT.P: An inter-ministerial roundtable will be held early next month to address issues regarding domestic manpower shortages, a senior official said Wednesday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , made the remarks a day after the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei urged the ROC government to set up a supra-ministerial panel to review its manpower planning policy and regulations to remove barriers to the upgrading of Taiwan's competitiveness in the global market.
AmCham made the call in its 2005 White Paper on Taiwan's economic environment.

In response, Hu said the CEPD is drafting proposals to ease manpower shortages faced by certain industrial sectors and to further speed up processing of applications by multinational corporations to allow their Chinese employees to work in Taiwan.

Moreover, Hu said, the CEPD will organize a ministerial-level roundtable meeting in July to discuss manpower planning issues, with the participation of senior officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Council of Labor Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council and other relevant government agencies.
Hu said the Executive Yuan has formed a manpower cultivation panel which will serve as a platform for communications and consultations with AmCham on human resources-related topics.
In the face of globalization, Hu said the CEPD has given priority to human resources development in recent years.

"We have assisted many local universities to open master's programs to cultivate talented people needed by high-tech industries, " Hu said, adding that the government has also adopted many measures in the past couple of years to open the door wider for Chinese professionals to work in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND HAS NO COMMENT ON CHINA'S DETENTION OF SINGAPORE JOURNALIST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense has no comment on the detention of a Singapore journalist by Chinese authorities on suspicion of spying for Taiwan, defense ministry spokesman Liu Chih-chien said Wednesday.

The Chinese Foreign Ministry has confirmed that their national security authorities have detained Ching Cheong from Singapore's Straits Times newspaper, with spokesman Kung Quan saying that Ching had done something related to spying.
Another Chinese official said Ching was detained while "collecting intelligence for Taiwan."
Asked by a group of local journalists, Liu said the ministry usually has no comment on issues related to intelligence collection.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC INSISTS ON FARM TALKS WITH CHINA VIA WTO FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reiterated its stance Wednesday that Taiwan and China discuss Taiwan's farm exports under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Pointing out that the WTO mechanisms provide a secure platform for Taiwan and China to conduct sound and effective agricultural exchanges, an MAC spokesman said that Taiwan and China, both WTO member states, should negotiate customs tariffs, customs clearance, quarantines and certification issues under the WTO's framework to best protect the interests of Taiwan's farmers.

Although China is willing to offer preferential treatment to Taiwan's farm exports, the MAC official said that such an approach would produce only short-term benefits for Taiwan farmers and that business risks would largely increase over the long term due to a variety of uncertainties.
China's hope that Taiwan would also remove its restrictions on more than 800 Chinese agricultural products is a clear indication of its long-term strategy in bilateral exchanges, he pointed out.

Taiwan's farm exports to China reached around US$890,000 last year, he said. Combining the outbound shipments to Hong Kong, the value totaled US$7.54 million, accoutring for 1.07 percent of Taiwan's agricultural exports and only 0.16 percent of the domestic industry's overall production value, he added.

The MAC spokesman's remarks came after officials of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council told a news conference earlier the same day that China is poised to provide Taiwan fruit imports with preferential treatment through private-sector negotiations.
The MAC is Taiwan's top agency in charge of China affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR-END ELECTIONS RESULTS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF KMT CHIEF: WANG

TEXT.P: Responsibility for the performance of the Kuomintang (KMT) in the year-end elections for county and city chiefs will rest with whomever is elected as the party's new chairman, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng was quoted as saying Wednesday.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said that Wang, who is one of the KMT's vice chairmen and is competing against Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou for the chairmanship, told the KMT Central Standing Committee that the year-end elections will determine to a great extent how the party will fare in the 2008 presidential election.

Therefore, the new party chief to be elected on June 16 will be held responsible for the results of the party, even if the candidates were chosen under the watch of current party Chairman Lien Chan, Wang said.
Wang made the remarks while giving a briefing to the Central Standing Committee about his vision for the party, Cheng said.

The spokeswoman also said Wang listed five priorities for the new party chief, including pressing forward with reforms within the party, solving the thorny problem of the party's assets that are alleged by political rivals to have been acquired illegally, laying off the party's redundant workers, and dealing with the competition of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
If elected KMT chief, Wang said, his roles as both speaker of the legislature and KMT chief will put him in good stead for leading the party to victory in its political struggle with the DPP.

He also said that his experience as legislature speaker for three consecutive terms bears witness to his capability to command the support of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) , which is vital for the KMT to win the 2008 presidential election.

Although the party chairman is very likely to bear the party standard in the 2008 presidential race, Wang suggested that he may not necessarily run on the KMT ticket; rather, he said the party chief should choose a pair of candidates with the best chance for victory in the 2008 election.

Instead of being the party's candidate-apparent for the 2008 presidential race, the KMT chairman should be a person who devotes himself to uniting the KMT, the PFP and other political allies to rally behind the party's presidential candidate.
Wang's remarks were apparently directed at Ma, who has been touted as the party's best hope for the presidency in 2008 and who is trying to win the chairmanship before bidding for presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL URGES E.U. NOT TO TILT MILITARY BALANCE WITH CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs R. Nicholas Burns has recently urged the European Union not to unduly affect in a negative way the military balance between the United States and China, particularly concerning the Taiwan Strait.
Burns made the call in a speech delivered at the Translatic Democracy Network Conference held in Brussels May 26. The State Department issued text of the speech Tuesday.
In his speech, Burns said that managing relationship with a rising China and continuing to ensure stability and peace in East Asia is a major American preoccupation.

Since the European Union announced that it was going to lift its arms ban on China, imposed for human rights reasons just following the Tiananmen Square Massacre in June 1989, Burns said, there has been a very vigorous debate between the United States and the E.U. about that.
The core of the American argument has been that Europe needs to understand that not only did America have security commitments in Europe over the last 60 years, it has the same commitments in Asia.

"We are the guarantor of stability in Asia. In the Taiwan Straits and in the entire Asia Pacific region, through our treaty relationships with Japan and South Korea, Australia, and our security commitments to the Philippines and Thailand, an American naval and air presence in Asia has been the single greatest factor. That has meant there has been no major regional war in Asia since the 2nd World War. Certainly no conflict that would directly pit the interests of the great powers in Asia itself," Burns said.

Against this backdrop, Burns said, Europe had to und erstand how important it was that Europe not unduly affect in a negative way the military balance between China and the United States, particularly concerning the Taiwan Straits as well as the wider responsibilities.

"We're very pleased now that the European Parliament has spoken out so clearly on this arms sales issue. It's a difficult one. We understand the motivations of the European Union, but we cannot accept that Europe would move forward when we are alliance partners and we have such profound security interests in East Asia itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 2 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, June 2:
10: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will visit the 2005 National Fair of Vocational Schools and Colleges at Southern Taiwan University of Technology in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.
10: 00, The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters on constitutional reforms.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Taipei Guest House.
15:45, The Philadelphia Orchestra will hold a news conference at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
17: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S FIXED POLICY ON TAIWAN PRECLUDES TALKS FOR NOW: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Beginning dialogue with China on political issues would be difficult now since Beijing has not changed its policy toward Taiwan, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by National Chengchi University on the challenges facing Taiwan, Wu said when Beijing officials talk about a possible peace agreement with Taiwan, they predicate this on their "one China" principle, " and they term any opening of direct transportation links with Taiwan a "domestic affairs." The fact is, Taiwanese don't want to unite with China under Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, he said.

Wu said that China has not changed one iota of its strategy of "uniting its minor enemies to fight its major ones, " and has not slowed down its deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan - about 700 altogether currently - and is aggressively building up its submarine fleet of 50 vessels, which is powerful enough to pose a serious threat even against Japan.
However, Wu said, negotiations with China on non-political issues is possible.

The view of the chief of the Mainland Affairs Council is contrary to that of Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who called for dialogue with China in his speech on the same occasion, saying that dialogue will promote peace across the Taiwan Strait while stalemate serves the interest of no one.
Wednesday's seminar brought together more than 200 political, economic and academic leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE TRADE ORGANIZATIONS SIGN MEMORANDUM

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) signed a memorandum with the Singapore Business Federation Wednesday, with both sides promising to strengthen bilateral economic and trade ties.

The signing of the cooperation memorandum was conducted at the 9th Taiwan-Singapore Economic Conference held in Taipei, in which more than 100 industrial and business representatives from Taiwan and Singapore participated, including Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming.
The Taiwan-Singapore Economic Conference was held for the first time in 1994, and the conference has played an active role in creating cooperative projects between the two countries over the years.

The main theme of this year's conference was "strengthening competitiveness in the new economic age, " in which the participants exchanged opinions and gave lectures about the economic situation and on the technologies surrounding the semiconductor, information technology and telecommunications industries of both countries.
According to the CIECA, trade between Taiwan and Singapore reached US$10.63 billion last year, with Singapore being Taiwan's sixth-largest trading partner.

Taiwan exports to Singapore totalled US$6.34 billion in 2004, an annual growth of 27.2 percent over 2003, while its imports reached US$4.29 billion, an increase of 11.2 percent over 2003, the CIECA statistics showed.
Taiwan and Singapore signed an investment guarantee agreement in April 2004. As of December 2004, Taiwanese entrepreneurs have launched 402 investment projects in Singapore worth US$264.4 billion.

In 2004 alone, Taiwan enterprises have 18 investment projects in Singapore with a total value of US$822 million, mainly in the financial and insurance, electronic and electrical, transport, and textile sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 7 MEDALS IN WORLDSKILLS COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Taiwan won seven medals -- one gold, two silver and four bronze -- in the 38th WorldSkills Competition held May 26-29 in Helsinki, Finland, officials of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Wednesday.
Taiwan sent a delegation to competing in 31 of the 48 categories of the biennial international competition which brought together over 2,000 participants from 40 countries, the officials said.
In addition to the seven medallist, five other Taiwan representatives won recognition for their excellent performances, they added.

Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA Vocational Training Bureau, said that the Taiwan delegates had done excellent jobs in the competitions although they obtained fewer medals than in previous competitions.
He said that the vocational training authorities will meet in the near future to go over the experiences obtained by the delegation in the competition for future reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CAUTIONS EUROPE AGAINST LIFTING ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Undersecretary of State Nicholas Burns urged Europe last week not to affect the military balance between China and the United States, particularly concerning the Taiwan Strait, in a negative way by lifting its arms embargo on China.
Burns made the remarks at the Transatlantic Democracy Network Conference in Brussels, Belgium on May 26. The text of his remarks was released by the State Department in Washington, D. C., Tuesday.

Burns said the United States has an interest in maintaining a peaceful relationship with China, but it also has a competitive relationship, certainly in trade with China, and the United States also has major grievances concerning human rights with China itself and a lack of democratization in that country.

Noting that managing its relationship with a rising China and continuing to ensure stability and peace in East Asia is a major American preoccupation, the U.S. undersecretary said at the center of the U.S. argument against Europe's lifting of the arms ban on China is that America has security commitments in Asia just as it has in Europe, and Europe's lifting of the arms embargo would unduly affect in a negative way the military balance in Asia.

Burns said his country understands the motivations of the European Union, but the United States cannot accept that Europe would move forward when they are allied partners and they have such profound security interests in East Asia.

The U.S. official said the United States would like to see a more outward-looking Europe that will work with the United States in the promotion of democracy in Asia, and in trying to ensure stability in Asia.
The Europe Union, which mulled the possibility of ending the arms embargo, decided to shelf the idea for the time being because of Washington's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 2, or the 26th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
2001: The Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Mongolian Olympic Committee sign a sports cooperation and exchange agreement in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP ASKS FOR CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION ON NA DELEGATES' LEGITIMACY

TEXT.P: The legislative and National Assembly caucuses of the opposition People First Party (PFP) on Thursday formally applied for a constitutional interpretation by the Council of Grand Justices on whether the delegates of the ad hoc National Assembly can vote on a constitutional amendment package.
Citing the low 23.35 percent voter turnout in the May 14 National Assembly election, the petition said the delegates can hardly be seen as representing the will of the people.

Of the 3,913,338 people who did turn out to vote, only 3,224,240 voted for parties or groups that support the constitution reform package, or not even 20 percent of the country's eligible voters, raising serious doubts about the legitimacy of the delegates to vote on the constitutional amendment package, according to the petition.
Fan Kuang-chun, secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan, said the grand justices will handle the request according to the law.
The ad hoc National Assembly, which convened for the first time Monday, is set to vote on the constitutional amendment package June 7.
A total of 300 National Assembly seats were allotted among the 12 political parties and civic groups taking part in the election in proportion to the number of votes they garnered.
The key mission of the ad hoc National Assembly is to review and vote on a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last August.

The amendment proposals include reducing the number of seats in the legislature from 225 to 113, extending the tenure of legislators from three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF INSURANCE POLICIES PER CAPITA IN TAIWAN HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The number of insurance policies owned by people in Taiwan reached a per capita record high in 2004, with each person owning an average of 1.7 insurance policies, according to a report released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The number of valid life and pension insurance contracts totalled 166.3 percent of the island's population as of the end of last year, with average coverage being 3.1 times that of Taiwan's average national income, representing another record high, according to the DGBAS report.

In terms of personal insurance, the number of valid life insurance contracts rose to 33.63 million as of the end of 2004, up 4.9 percent over the amount at the end of the previous year; injury insurance contracts increased 0.3 percent to 32.89 million; and health insurance contracts climbed 4.3 percent to 42.8 million.
The number of valid pension insurance contracts totalled more than 280,000 as of the end of 2004.

In terms of group insurance, the number of life and health insurance contracts registered an annual growth rate of 1.7 percent and 9.1 percent, respectively, in 2004, while that of injury insurance contracts was down 3.6 percent.

Meanwhile, the number of new contracts for all the various types of insurance fell last year, with the exception of that for personal pension insurance, which rose 1.2-fold over the previous year's figure.
The coverage amount for personal life insurance averaged NT$783,000 (US$24,944) in 2004, almost double that of the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO ASK FOR CONSTITUTIONAL INTERPRETATION OF NATIONAL ASSEMBLY LAW

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) official said Thursday that an article in the National Assembly Operation Law is in gross violation of the Constitution and that the TSU caucus in the ad hoc National Assembly will request a constitutional interpretation from the Council of Grand Justices Friday.

TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming was referring to Article 9 which stipulates that the National Assembly must vote on the Legislative Yuan-approved constitutional reform package as a whole instead of item by item.

Noting that Article 25 of the Constitution states that the National Assembly "shall exercise political powers on behalf of the whole body of the citizens, " Chen said it is not appropriate for the Legislative Yuan to put limitations on the exercise of this power unless through a constitutional amendment.
Chen expressed the hope that before the grand justices hand down their ruling on the matter, the National Assembly will vote on the constitutional reform package item by item instead of as a whole.

The amendment proposals include reducing the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan from the current 225 to 113, extending the tenure of legislators from the present three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.

Chen said that the low turnout rate of 23.35 percent for the May 14 National Assembly election has created serious doubts about the legitimacy of the 300 National Assembly delegates in representing the people and voting on the constitutional reform package. The 300 seats were allotted to the 12 political parties and civic groups taking part in the election based on the proportion of votes they each garnered.

Chen stressed that the TSU respects the result of the election, but the party advocates that when the 300 delegates vote on the constitutional amendment proposals, they should stick to the principle of procedural justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONDEMNS CHINA'S ATTEMPT TO SHORTEN U.N. MANDATE IN HAITI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) condemned China Thursday over its pressuring the United Nations to reduce a recommended one-year extension of the U.N. peacekeeping mission in Haiti which maintains diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan recommended in May that the U.N. peacekeeping mission in Haiti be extended for one year after its mandate expired June 1.

However, China insisted that U.N. peacekeepers would be needed in Haiti for no longer than six more months. A Chinese official in Haiti was quoted as having said a six-month timeframe would allow the United Nations time to reevaluate its mission and extend it again if necessary.
The U.N. Security Council on May 31 extended the mandate of the 7,400-member peacekeeping mission to June 24, giving it more time to settle the dispute with China.
Lu said China's attempt to shorten the U.N. peacekeeping mission in Haiti was part of its efforts to sabotage Haiti's longtime diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
According to Lu, China was also angered by plans for Haiti's interim President Boniface Alexandre to visit Taiwan in July.

Stressing that Haiti's relations with Taiwan and its interim president's Taiwan travel plan have nothing to do with the U.N. peacekeeping mission in the Caribbean nation, Lu said China was trying to abuse its clout in the U.N. Security Council to interfere with Haiti's internal affairs.
"We condemn this gross act by China," Lu said.

It wasn't clear when the 15-member Security Council would vote on the extension of the peacekeeping mandate in Haiti. China, as one of the five permanent members, has veto power over the council's decisions.

A U.S.-backed interim government and U.N. peacekeepers have taken over in Haiti since an armed rebellion led to the ouster of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in February 2004. Elections have been scheduled for October and November. Haiti forged diplomatic ties with the ROC in 1956.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 67.86 points to close at 6,039.48.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 6,008.9 and hit a high of 6,065.23 during trading. A total of 4.11 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$92.35 billion (US$2.94 billion).
