Gainers outnumbered losers 670 to 202, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S CURRENT TAIWAN POLICY MORE FLEXIBLE THAN BEFORE: MAC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 1 (CNA) (By C.F. Lee and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Republic of China official for mainland China affairs said Wednesday in New York that Beijing is currently adopting a flexible policy toward Taiwan rather than a rigid one as it did before.

Huang Wei-feng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan, made the comments while meeting with members of local think tanks at a seminar to exchange views on issues regarding current cross-strait policy in Taiwan and in the United States, Taiwan-U.S.-China relations and Taiwan's constitutional amendments.
The official, at the head of a delegation of Taiwan reporters, said that China's Taiwan policy is currently showing signs of flexibility rather than rigidity.

In order to calm down the negative feelings of the Taiwan people after the passage of the Anti-Secession Law in March, China not only invited two leaders of Taiwan's opposition parties -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- to visit the mainland, but also made some proposals aimed at resolving cross-strait differences, he further said.
Nevertheless, Huang also questioned the proposals, saying that Beijing's precondition of making such proposals is that Taiwan must accept the "one China" principle.

Urging the United States to support Taiwan and push Beijing to engage in dialogue with the island, Huang said that by doing this, both sides of the Strait can then move forward toward further exchanges and cooperation.
The participants at the gathering also agreed that Beijing has become more flexible in dealing with Taiwan since Hu Jintao took over as president of China.

Meanwhile, a scholar said at the conclusion of a conference held by three U.S. think tanks last Wednesday in Washington, D. C. that the Bush administration's current cross-strait policy, which attaches great importance to maintaining the status quo, is workable and functions properly. He added that the policy hopes to make Taipei and Beijing realize that the United States will never accept a unilateral change to the status quo by either side.

According to the scholar, more than 30 U.S. officials and members of think tanks, including former U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Randall Shriver, attended the conference in which some participants said that they believe that the Bush administration's cross-strait policy has six key points. They are: A. Regardless of unification or independence, the U.S. insists that
cross-strait problems should be resolved peacefully and that the
resolution should be accepted by the people of both sides. B. The U.S. will continue to warn China not to use force against
Taiwan, while the island should not provoke the mainland into
conflict. C. The U.S. security concept is "residual security value" -- Taiwan
must determine to defend herself first and the U.S. will then be
able to protect the island's security. D. The U.S. will continue to recognize the Beijing government and
respect the existing "one China" policy. E. The U.S. will continue to strengthen its trade, economic and
cultural relations with China. F. The U.S. refuses to play a mediator role between the two sides of
the Strait and cross-strait problems should be resolved by Taipei
and Beijing themselves.

The participants at the conference also felt that Taipei and Beijing will eventually have the means to resolve their differences, noting that the both sides will certainly be able to find room in President Shui-bian's so-called "foundation laid by the results of the 1992 Hong Kong talks" and Beijing's so-called "1992 consensus" to solve any problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVERE ENTEROVIRAL INFECTIONS ON THE RISE: CDC

TEXT.P: Twelve new cases of severe enteroviral infections have been reported in Taiwan over the past eight days, bringing the total number of severe infections to 47 so far this year, according to the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health on Thursday.
All the victims are children below five years old, four of whom have died from complications caused by the infections, CDC officials said.
While the number of medical visits for enteroviral infections has been rising for 10 consecutive weeks in the country, the outbreak may peak in the next couple of weeks, the officials said.
The enteroviral outbreak has so far resulted in 36 school closures, mainly in daycare centers and kindergartens, with 25 cases occurring in northern Taiwan and 11 in the central part, they said.
Most of the severe infections have been reported in central Taiwan, with 31 cases, while there have been nine cases in the south, six in the north and one in the east, they added.

The officials urged parents to watch closely if their children develop any symptoms of severe illness in the five days since symptoms of enteroviral infection start to appear and send them to a hospital.

These symptoms include excessive sleepiness, decreased responsiveness, weakness and paralysis of the extremities, muscle pain, vomiting, fever, irritability, coma, shortness of breath, increased or irregular heartbeat.
While the symptoms of enteroviral infections can be similar to that of flu, some patients may develop blisters on their hands, feet and mouths and even pneumonia, myocarditis and encephalitis.

As enteroviruses are transmissible via direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with contaminated surfaces or objects, practicing good personal hygiene is crucial to preventing infections, according to the CDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO IN NEW YORK TO GET NEW OFFICE IN AUGUST
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 1 (CNA) (By C. F. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York will move to a new location in August in the city's prime district, director Andrew L. Y. Hsia said Wednesday.
Hsia made the remarks while briefing a group of journalists from Taiwan led by Mainland Affairs (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng.

The new TECO office will be located in a building on the intersection of 5th Avenue and 42th Street, in which about 10 outposts of relevant government agencies in New York, such as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Education, the Council for Cultural Affairs and the Financial Supervisory Commission, will also be relocated, Hsia said.
According to Hsia, the government spent NT$1.7 billion (about US$54 million) to purchase and refurbish the building, which has 16 floors and two basement floors.

As to the question of whether the building would be named the "Taiwan Building" or "Taiwan Plaza, " Hsia said that his office has not received any order from the representative office in Washington regarding the issue. He added that his office will continue operations at the new office under the name of "TECO" following a grand opening slated for early August.
At the head of a 13-member delegation composed of Taiwan reporters, Huang arrived in New York Tuesday for a 10-day visit to the United States.

The delegation paid a visit to the United Nations and met a group of reporters stationed at the U.N. later the same day. It will also meet members of major think tanks, such as the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations and the Council on Foreign Relations.

It will proceed to Washington, where the delegation will meet Randall G. Shriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state, and representatives stationed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition Kuomintang, as well as U.S. congressmen and members of the Heritage Foundation, the American Enterprise Institute and the CATO Institute.

The MAC organized the visit to help Taiwan reporters familiarize themselves with the U. S. government's stance and policymaking on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and to increase bilateral exchanges and mutual understanding with U. S. scholars. The Cabinet-level MAC is Taiwan's top agency in charge of China affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC RECOMMENDS HOLDING THREE LOCAL ELECTIONS SIMULTANEOUSLY ON DEC. 3

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has recommended that three local elections be held simultaneously on Dec. 3 to save costs, CEC officials said Thursday.
These elections include those for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors as well as township and village heads.

The CEC officially notified the electoral committees of the concerned cities and counties of its recommendation on Wednesday to hear their opinions, with most of the respondents agreeing to hold the three elections at the same time, the officials said.
The CEC will communicate with cities and counties that are hesitant about the idea and will help them resolve any problems that they may have, they said.

Also on Thursday, lawmakers across party lines expressed their support for the CEC's plan but urged the government to step up its crackdown on vote-buying that is expected to become prevalent in the year-end, three-in-one elections.

Chen Chieh, a whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, said although holding the three elections simultaneously may not be favorable to the party's campaign strategy, the KMT supports the plan because it will help save costs.

Chen Chih-pin, convener of the opposition People First Party legislative caucus, predicted that vote-buying activities will increase during the upcoming elections in light of the large number of candidates participating in the races, which he said requires more intensive efforts to bring lawbreakers to justice.

Agreeing with Chen, Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus convener Lo Chih-ming said the government must take precautions against interference by local factions and gangsters in the elections as well as guarding against any outbreaks of violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASE STILL OPEN ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Prosecutors are not about to end their investigations into the March 19, 2004 presidential election-eve shooting of the president and vice president in spite of a media report to the contrary, Kuo Jen-ni, the chief prosecutor of the Tainan Prosecutor's Office, said Thursday.

Kuo was responding to a United Daily News article that the investigative team will indict their prime suspect, Chen Yi-hsiung, on the charge of attempted murder, but since Chen apparently committed suicide shortly after the shooting, the court will dismiss the case.
Kuo said that officials were surprised by the report, adding that the task force still meets regularly.
The gun used in the shooting has yet to be recovered and Kuo said that law enforcement officials are still looking for it in the hope that it will turn up at some point.

The task force in the meantime is sorting out information compiled over the past year, and there is no timetable for closing the case, she said, adding that the task force will make an announcement when this happens.

Meanwhile, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Thursday that after the identification of the lone gunman in early March, most CIB agents of the task force have returned to their original posts and Hou Yu-ih, the CIB's commissioner, is now working on a report of the case.
It is initially estimated that the more than 100,000-character report will be divided into two parts on forensics and investigation, and will address the areas of the case still in question.

Some people wonder if Chen really did drown himself after the shooting and are unconvinced about the case since the weapon used has never been found. However, the police have confirmed that Chen was in fact standing in the "hot zone" of the crime scene because he was filmed by a video surveillance camera.
The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that the party will respect the judicial ruling on the shooting.

William C. T. Lai, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that any parties or individuals who can bring fresh evidence to the case are encouraged to do so, but people coming forward to be critical for no purpose will only hinder the investigation and create divisiveness in society.
The legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, said police should continue to search for the homemade gun used against the president or the whole case will be flawed.
Chang Jung-kung, a spokesman for the Kuomintang (KMT), said that closing the case now would be an attempt by the government to cover the truth.

Chang said that president won re-election by a slim margin thanks to two bullets. The government has tried to come out the shadow of the shooting, but if there is no full accounting to the world and the Taiwan people, then Chen Shui-bian will never shake off the title of the "two-bullet president," he added.
Lee Yung-ping, caucus whip of the People First Party (PFP), said that if the case is closed rashly, it will result in political discordance and bring new crises to the legality of the government.

Lee said the shooting is not an ordinary criminal case, but is a national security issue with the lives of the president and the vice president at stake, and it shouldn't be closed without any evidence having been produced.

Lee urged those in the national security system who know the truth and who have a clear conscience to come forward and expose the truth courageously, just like the secret source "deep throat" in the Watergate scandal, which brought down U.S. President Richard Nixon.

She said that if the case ends abruptly, it will only prove the need to form another "319 truth commission, " and the PFP caucus will actively promote the formation of such a commission in the next legislative session.

The opposition-controlled fifth Legislative Yuan passed a special statute authorizing the establishment of an independent "319 truth commission" last year to investigate the case in which President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu were shot and slightly wounded. However, the statute was later ruled to be unconstitutional by the Council of Grand Justices.

President Chen and Vice President Lu were injured on the eve of the presidential election when two homemade bullets grazed them as they campaigned in an open jeep in the southern city of Tainan. After the Chen-Lu ticket narrowly won re-election the following day, the sole challenging ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong accused the president of having staged the shooting to win sympathy votes and filed two lawsuits to challenge the election result. The lawsuits were rejected by the court.

The special police team investigating the incident identified Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, as the key suspect in the shooting shortly before the first anniversary of the shooting. Chen Yi-hsiung was found dead in Anping Harbor in Tainan March 29 last year -- 10 days after the shooting -- in what police have said was an apparent suicide.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ARREST MAN FOR ATTEMPTING TO BLACKMAIL BEVERAGE COMPANY

TEXT.P: Police in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, reported the arrest of a man Thursday for attempting to blackmail a famous beverage company with the threat of lacing their products with poison.

Police said that Chien Heng-wen, 36, who was previously convicted of fraud, apparently tried to ride on the coattails of the panic triggered by the recent case of a man who put cyanide in several bottles of an energy drink called "bullwild" produced by the Paolita Company, another famous beverage company.
Chien was targeting the well-known Sanyo Whisbih drink.
Chien reached the Whisbih company through its toll-free number for consumers and demanded that NT$20 million (US$634,920) be transferred to a designated account, or face the same fate as Paolita.

Police arrested Chien in downtown Kaohsiung in the early hours Thursday, and in a search of his home later found that before he targeted Whisbih, he had already blackmailed several medical institutions as well as extorted money from owners of luxury cars.

Chien said that he located luxury cars parking illegally and would then call police to tow them away. After the cars were towed away, he would change the phone numbers left on the scene by traffic police to his own. When the owners called, Chien would then extort money out of them.
Meanwhile, a famous but yet unidentified manufacturer of snacks reported to police that they have been receiving blackmail threats via telephone and e-mail.
Police said the company received unidentified calls May 31 to try to extort NT$1 million, and later received threatening e-mails from China.
Police said that three extortion calls were made and they are now checking whether they were real or pranks.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUST ALMOST SETTLED ON DPP CANDIDATES FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The dust over the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidacy for the year-end city and county chief elections has largely settled, party officials said Thursday.
The DPP held party primaries (including a vote by party members and public opinion polls) in six cities and counties to determine its candidates.

According to the results of the primaries, the DPP will nominate former Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan to run for Ilan county magistrate -- a post in which Chen has served two previous terms; Hsinchu City Councilor Chen Kuei-yuan for the Hsinchu city mayorship; former Legislator Su Chih-fen for Yunlin county magistrate; incumbent Chiayi Mayor Chen Li-chen to run for a second term; former Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san for Taichung county magistrate; and incumbent Legislator Tsai Huang-liang for Nantou county magistrate.
As competition in three counties -- Taichung, Nantou and Yunlin -- was fierce and bitter, party officials said the DPP headquarters must step up fence-mending efforts to consolidate party unity.

Former Legislator Lin Feng-hsi, who lost to Chiu in the Taichung County primary, issued a statement earlier in the day that he would not accept the outcome of the primary because he believes the opinion survey was not fairly handled. He urged the party headquarters to review its opinion survey regulations for the sake of protecting all party members' rights. He also claimed that he was a victim of factional strife within the party.

Meanwhile, incumbent Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-yung had refused to concede his defeat in the primary and it remained unclear whether he would mount a maverick bid to compete with the party's nominee in the year-end election.

DPP candidates for some districts with no need to hold primaries have also been determined, with five incumbents -- Changhua County Magistrate Weng Chin-chu, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih, Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tian-tsair and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing -- to run for second terms.

In addition, former Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Lo Wen-jia will be nominated to run for Taipei county magistrate; Taiwan Salt Co. Chairman Cheng Pao-ching for Taoyuan county magistrate; former Government Information Office Minister Lin Chia-lung for Taichung city mayor; and Chen Kuang-fu, head of the DPP's Penghu County chapter, for Penghu county magistrate.

The DPP has also decided to draft suitable candidates to run for Keelung city mayor as well as Hsinchu and Miaoli county magistrates. These three districts have traditionally been strongholds of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP). Party officials said the DPP headquarters will step up a search for candidates after the ongoing ad hoc National Assembly session concludes.

As several hopefuls are interested in the Keelung mayoral post, the party might conduct an opinion poll to determine who to draft. The party will also consult with its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which has decided to nominate TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming to run for the post.

In Hsinchu County, party sources said, the DPP will evaluate the feasibility of cooperating with incumbent Legislator Chiu Ching-chun, who withdrew from the KMT after the party decided to support incumbent Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin to run for a second term.
In Miaoli County, the DPP will give priority to drafting a Hakka hopeful to join the race with a view to expanding the party's support base in the Hakka community there.

Meanwhile, party sources said, the DPP is almost certain not to name its own candidate in Taitung County, which is also a pan-blue bastion, and will throw its support behind incumbent Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan, an independent who is friendly toward the DPP.

In the three other pan-blue strongholds -- Hualien County and the two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, the DPP will not make a final decision on its nomination strategies until after further consultations with influential figures and opinion leaders there, party sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS SEEK THE DEATH PENALTY FOR DRINK POISONING SUSPECT

TEXT.P: The man allegedly responsible for spiking energy drinks with cyanide which resulted in the death of one person and the poisoning of three others in central Taichung City was indicted on charges of murder on Thursday.
The Taichung District Prosecutors' Office is seeking the death penalty for Wang Chin-chang and the deprivation of his civil rights for life.
According to the indictment, Wang allegedly placed Bullwild energy drinks tainted with cyanide, a poisonous chemical, on shelves of nine convenience stores and two drug stores in Taichung on May 17.
One of the consumers, Chou Yi-kuei, died shortly after drinking the poisoned beverage, while three others including Chao Shih-fang, Ho Han-sen and Li Feng-ming suffered cyanide poisoning.
Wang was arrested on May 27 in Taipei County, and he confessed that he was responsible for the crime.

Prosecutor Chang Hung-mao said in addition to Wang's confession, other evidence gathered by prosecution include the autopsy report and medical records of the victims, nine bottles of Bullwild and two bottles of Paolyta B drink tainted with cyanide, a plan to use cyanide to commit crimes found on Wang's computer, and surveillance video tapes collected near the crime scenes.
Wang faces 11 counts of poisoning, one count of murder and 10 counts of attempted murder, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET HOPES TO PASS 3 BILLS ON GOVERNMENT RESTRUCTURING

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is hoping that three bills concerning the restructuring of the government can be passed in an extra session of the Legislative Yuan, Yeh Jiunn-rong, director of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan, said Thursday.

Yeh said that the bills concerning an amendment to the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan, a draft bill on the total number of employees of central government agencies, and a draft bill on the adjustment of the function, operation and organization of the Executive Yuan are crucial to upgrading the government's efficiency.
He said the three bills are included in the six top priority bills that the Cabinet hopes to pass in the extra session.

Yeh said that the opposition parties are concerned about the integration of the central government agencies, citing as an example that the legislative caucuses of the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party are hoping that the Veterans Affairs Commission and the Mainland Affairs Council will not be integrated with any other agencies.

The legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union is hoping for the establishment of an ocean commission, Yeh said, adding that the executive arm will display the maximum goodwill to make flexible adjustments and will consult with the legislative caucuses.
Premier Frank Hsieh has said he hopes an extra session of the Legislative Yuan can be held in late July.

The priority bills include those related to a long-stalled arms procurement package, the tax laws, a review of a list of Control Yuan members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian and a statute on the establishment of a pension fund supervisory commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO MANY QUALIFIED TEACHERS BANE OF EDUCATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Colleges and universities around Taiwan are churning out qualified teachers, but with 180 graduates this year for each opening, the number of unemployed teachers is growing, prompting some to take to the streets June 12 to vent their frustrations.

According to Chen Chun-hao, convener of the Saving Compulsory Education Alliance, there are currently about 60,000 college graduates and masters degree holders who have a teaching license, but there are fewer than 100 openings nationwide for teachers in elementary and junior high schools this year.

Since many colleges and universities in Taiwan have education and teaching courses in their curriculums, about 18,000 individuals qualified to be teachers at elementary or junior high schools matriculate each year, said Chen, adding that the number of these potential teachers has been snowballing on a yearly basis, posing an increasingly serious problem in the education sector.

The potential teachers, most of them having never had the opportunity to teach after graduation, will walk the streets of Taipei June 12 to ask the Ministry of Education to consider increasing the number of teachers in elementary and junior high schools and implementing small-class programs to create more openings for the jobless who are qualified to teach, Chen said.

Chen noted that the Saving Compulsory Education Alliance has collected signatures from more than 10,000 potential teachers islandwide in a short six-day period for the June 12 rally, although the alliance has no idea yet exactly how many of them will turn out to march.
Prior to June 12, the alliance will ally with the National Teachers' Association June 4, which will help magnify the alliance's outcry against injustice in the nation's education policy, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT URGED TO GET READY FOR CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: In view of the government's imminent opening to tourists from China, the Taipei city government has been urged to iron out a comprehensive program in time to brace for an anticipated influx of visitors.
A group of city councilors of the opposition People First Party (PFP) made the proposal Tuesday to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou during an interpellation session at the city council.

Citing the results of a recent public opinion survey on visitors from China, PFP city councilman Tai Hsi-chin said there is an urgent need for the municipal authorities to quickly upgrade the city's tourist facilities and service quality.

Should some 10,000 Chinese tourists be allowed to enter Taiwan per day, it would be extremely difficult for the city to accommodate such a large number of visitors with its current establishments, including hotels and popular tourist spots, according to Tai.

According to the poll results, Chinese visitors make an average stay of 8.6 days in Taiwan, spending nearly two nights in Taipei, Taiwan's largest city, he reported. Based on an average per-head spending of NT$38,000 (US$1,210) by Chinese visitors in Taiwan, this would generate roughly NT$2.5 billion in tourist dollars for Taipei each month and some NT$30 billion each year, he said.
The Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, the National Palace Museum and the Taipei 101 Building are the most popular sightseeing spots in Taipei among Chinese visitors, PFP City Councilor Lin Tin-yung said.

Despite the fact that 84.4 percent of the Chinese tourists questioned said that they would like to visit Taiwan again and that they gave an average score of 83.5 points (out of a full scale of 100 points) to Taiwan, traffic disorder and currency exchange inconvenience are some of Taipei's major shortcomings for them, PFP City Councilor Lin Ting-yung said.

Wang Chih-ping, a PFP city councilwoman, claimed that the government's opening would create a boon for businesses in Taipei. However, she expressed doubt as to whether the city is ready for the change and called on the municipal authorities to respond swiftly.

In response to Beijing's offer to allow the Chinese general public to make pleasure trips to Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said last week that bilateral negotiations on the issue could begin this year after necessary coordination and arrangements have been put in place.
But it added that residents of Fujian Province will not be included in the government's opening measure in the initial stage, due to their bad record of absconding en masse upon arrival in Taiwan.

MAC officials expressed the hope that the Chinese authorities will cooperate in scrutinizing the backgrounds and financial situations of prospective tourists to Taiwan to help prevent illegal overstays of their citizens here.

Premier Frank Hsieh has made it clear that the government is poised to open up to Chinese tourists, but on condition that only a maximum of 1,000 visitors, from various selected Chinese cities, will be permitted to enter each day under a quota control management system.
The government will not allow full unfettered opening out of grave concern of the many possible consequences if complementary measures are not imposed, MAC officials noted.
The Cabinet-level MAC is Taiwan's highest government agency responsible for China affairs.

Meanwhile, operators of tourism agencies in China told the Central News Agency that public response to sightseeing in Taiwan has been enthusiastic. Some agencies have even started taking reservations from potential tourists, they said.

Most of the Chinese tourism agencies are very optimistic about the business prospects of the opening, saying that Taiwan has a special appeal for Chinese people and expressing hope for direct flights across the Taiwan Strait.
For the time being, Taiwan only allows Chinese people residing overseas or those traveling from a third country to visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CLARIFIES GIST OF HIS TAX REFORM PLANS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his recent proposal to raise the domestic tax rate should not be interpreted as a measure to increase everybody's tax burden.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a group of legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Taipei Guest House for wide-ranging talks.

Chen's six-point tax reform plan, which was unveiled after a meeting of the Presidential Office Economic Advisory Panel last week, has drawn broadsides not only from the opposition camp but also from his own party.

Chen took advantage of the meeting with DPP lawmakers to explain in detail the rationale behind his proposals, stressing that the reform will focus on expanding the tax base, restructuring and simplifying the tax system and eradicating tax evasion.
Noting that the DPP is a reform-oriented party, Chen said he will not allow the fear of losing the popular vote to dissuade him from carrying out the tax reforms.

"The DPP came to power because of support from various levels of people, including a lot of impoverished people. We should always give priority to taking care of the disadvantaged and siding with the poor. Our tax reform program will absolutely not increase the tax burden on low-income families and will instead lessen or even exempt their tax payments while levying more taxes on well-to-do families, " he claimed.

Touching on the details of his reform plan, Chen said the proposal to raise the tax rate is not a scheme to raise everybody's taxes. Instead, he argued, the plan has been drafted with an aim of making the rich pay more while reducing the burden on the poor in line with the principle of social justice and fairness.

At present, Taiwan's average tax rate is 13.6 percent, ranking among the world's lowest. Chen said he is hopeful that the ratio can be raised to 15 percent in three years and to 18 percent in the long run.
In 1990, when the opposition Kuomintang was in power, Chen said, Taiwan's average taxation rate was 20.6 percent. Between 1992 and 1994, the ratio also surpassed 15 percent.

"We are just trying to return to that level, " he said, adding that the average tax rate in member countries of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, also known as the "Rich Men's Club," reaches a high of 27 percent.

Chen said he will direct relevant government agencies to restructure and simplify the income tax scale with a view to cutting low-income wage earners' tax burden while increasing the wealthy's tax payments.
"I feel regret that opposition parties and some news media have deliberately distorted my tax reform plan as a plot to increase everybody's tax burden," he said.
As to a proposal to raise the business tax by 1 percent or 2 percent, Chen said it would be a complementary measure for overhauling the consumer tax system.

"Our current consumption tax system is not completely reasonable. We will make an overall review and adopt measures to avoid double taxation. While the business tax may be increased, the commodity taxes may be reduced or even completely canceled," Chen explained.
In comparison, he said, Taiwan's business tax is too low. China's business tax reaches a high of 17 percent, he noted.
Chen further said the ultimate goal of the plan to establish a minimum tax mechanism is to uphold fairness and justice in the taxation system.

Noting that Taiwan's inheritance tax is relatively high, Chen said he has proposed to gradually lower the ceiling on such tax to 40 percent to equal the maximum income tax rate. High inheritance tax only prompts local rich people to remit their money abroad, he added.

With a view to raising the capital gains tax ratio in the government's total tax revenues, Chen said he has called for a feasibility study on levying capital gain taxes on transactions of unlisted stocks.

"This reform proposal is aimed at expanding our tax base to make our tax system more reasonable and fairer. At present, wage earners contribute three-quarters of the country's tax revenue, while capital gains tax account for only one-quarter of the total tax revenue. Under the current system, wealthy people are often exempt from capital gains tax," he said.

As many people have criticized the government's current measures to encourage investment in high-tech industries, Chen said his six-point tax reform plan will also require relevant agencies to review tax incentives and financial subsidies for various industries annually and to make necessary updates or adjustments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO YOUNG WHALE SHARKS FROM HUALIEN TRANSPORTED TO U.S. FOR RESEARCH
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, June 2 (CNA) (By C.T. Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Two young whale sharks were transported by air Thursday to an aquarium in Georgia in the United States for research, according to the Hualien Fishermen's Association.

The two sharks, captured by Hualien fishing boats in February and April, respectively, passed health and quarantine examinations prior to their shipment, said Wang Ming-chang, director-general of the association.

According to Wang, authorities of the privately-run Georgia Aquarium contacted the association in April upon learning of the capture of the sharks and offered NT$250,000 (US$8,000) each for the animals.
Although the whale shark is easily recognized, zoologists know little about them.

The whale shark is the biggest shark and the biggest fish in the world. With distinctive light-yellow markings of random stripes and dots on its very thick dark gray skin, the whale shark is a filter feeder, although it has about 3,000 very tiny teeth. Adult whale sharks can be up to 14 meters long and can weigh up to 15 tons, although the average size is 7.6 meters.

The Hualien Fishermen's Association first packed the whale sharks into a container specially designed for transporting live fish and then took them to the Hualien airport, where the container was put aboard a charter flight bound for the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport before heading for the United States.
The two sharks, weighing 470 kg and 520 kg, respectively, are each about 4 meters long.

According to Wang, a Hualien-based fisherman also captured another young whale shark in February 2004, which was later bought by the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in Pingtung, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEMENS TO BID FOR KAOHSIUNG LIGHT-RAIL STREETCAR PROJECT
DOC.DATELINE: Vienna, June 2 (CNA) (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Siemens AG will bid for Taiwan's first light-rail streetcar system to be built in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, a Siemens executive said Thursday.

Volker Kefer, the Germany-based firm's transportation division chief, made the remarks a day after the first three-car train for Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit (MRT) system was unveiled Wednesday at a Siemens' plant in Vienna.

With the concerted efforts of the Kaohsiung city government and Siemens, Kerfer said Kaohsiung's MRT system is a success. The first Kaohsiung MRT line connecting the Hsiaokang International Airport and Santuo Road is scheduled to begin operations next year.
Kaohsiung has also decided to build a light-rail streetcar system to complement its MRT system, a project that has been approved by the Cabinet.
It will be Taiwan's first light-rail streetcar system and will require an outlay of NT$13.3 billion, with NT$5 billion for land acquisition. Private investors are welcome to take part in the project.
The 15.2-km streetcar system, which will have 26 stations, is scheduled for completion by June 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS AIMED AT BOOSTING EMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: The government has plans to invest some NT$7.5 billion (US$240 million) to finance a community development program nationwide over a span of three years from this year, aimed at creating 37,000 jobs, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday.

Community leaders and authorities from cities, counties and townships around the country are welcome to offer their respective development plans to the Executive Yuan as part of the program, which is titled the "Six Stars Program," Wu said.
He added that to help lower the unemployment rate among the aborigines, aboriginal rural townships are also welcome to apply to join the program.

It is hoped that some 8,000 jobs will be reserved exclusively for aboriginal people over the three-year span, an effort that might contribute to lowering the unemployment rate among aborigines to 4 percent-4.75 percent from the current 5.5 percent-6.25 percent, Wu noted.

The unemployment rate among the aboriginal people stood at 5.76 percent in May 2004, marking a significant decline from 9.64 percent posted in May 2003, thanks to the administration's promotion of an employment program via public service over the past several years, Wu added.
The 5.76 percent unemployment, however, is still relatively much higher than the average of 4.41 percent posted in Taiwan's non-aboriginal sectors in May 2004, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFERS NT$50 MILLION FOR 'DEEP THROAT' IN 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) offered NT$50 million (US$1.59 million) Thursday for information leading to the arrest of the man who shot President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu March 19 last year.

Encouraged by the news that former FBI Deputy Director Mark Felt confirmed Tuesday that he was the source of the Washington Post, dubbed "deep throat" by the paper when it broke the news about the Watergate scandal in 1972, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said his party will give NT$50 million for Taiwan's "deep throat" who can come out with information leading to the discovery of the truth of the 319 shooting.
The Watergate scandal brought down U.S. President Richard Nixon in 1974.

The spokesman for the KMT, which suspects the shooting to be a politically-motivated scheme coined to help Chen win re-election, said his party is worried that the "truth" of the shooting will never come out after the United Daily News said Thursday that a police task force charged with investigating the incident is ready to wrap up its probe.
Chang said his party will start collecting public donations for the rewards and announced Post Office account 19839620 for receiving donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CHINA ENERGY ECONOMIC SEMINAR TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A symposium on energy economics in Taiwan and China will be held in Taipei on June 5, according to its organizer, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER).

The symposium hopes to enhance the level of studies in the field of energy economics and will feature a speech by Yeh Hui-ching, director of the Energy Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and a speech by Zhou Dadi, director-general of the Energy Research Institute under China's National Development and Reform Commission, according to a news release issued by the CIER.
Yeh's speech will focus on Taiwan's energy demand and its prospects, while Zhou's will focus on China's energy demand in developing a fairly well-off society.

Other experts will be invite to discuss weather changes and China's response, the impact of Taiwan's nuclear-free policy and how to develop new sources of power, and challenges facing China in the fields of energy and environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY TO BE CHINA'S FINAL DESTINY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he believes that no matter how China develops politically, democracy will be its final destiny.
Chen made the remarks in an article carried in an online weekly bearing his nickname "A-bian."
With the 16th anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen Massacre approaching, Chen said it is time to review political developments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1989.
While the Tiananmen Massacre stymied China's democratic development, Chen said Taiwan has since accelerated its democratic reform and has emerged as one of the most vibrant democracies in Asia.
Judging from Taiwan's experience, Chen said, he is convinced that repressive rule only restricts humans temporarily and cannot constrain them for ever.
To the best of his understanding, Chen went on, although the shadow of Tiananmen might gradually fade away, the "sun" of democracy is dawning quietly in various corners of China.

"I believe that no matter how bumpy China's political development will be, democracy will be its final destiny. I earnestly hope that China's leaders can respect and protect the people's rights to free choice and that the universal values of freedom and democracy will blossom in China eventually," Chen wrote in his article.
The Tiananmen Massacre refers to a tragedy in which Chinese troops crushed pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing on June 4, 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, June 3:
09: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the 2005 National Anti-Drug Conference at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
09: 00, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will visit the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
09:20, New York Times publisher Arthur Ochs Sulzberger will meet readers of the Taiwan-based United Daily News at the Far Eastern Plaza hotel in Taipei.
09: 30, The Fourth International Conference on Internet Chinese Language Education will open at the National Taiwan Science Education Center in Taipei.
10: 00, The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
11: 00, Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the inauguration of a new plant of Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. in the Hsinchu Science-based Park.
15: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Kids Alive International Chairwoman Sherry J. Schaub at the Presidential Office.
16:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive members and experts of UNESCO's World Heritage Committee at the Presidential Office.
16: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend an activity to promote domestic agricultural products at RT-Mart in Neihu, Taipei.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 20, The Central Bank of China will issue reports on Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves at the bank's headquarters.
18: 30, The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy will hold a rally in memory of the 18th anniversary of the June-4 democracy movement in China at No. 4, Lane 17, Alley 147, Hsinyi Rd. Sec. 3, Taipei.
19:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a dinner party in honor of New York Times Publisher Arthur Ochs Sulzberger at the Taipei World Trade Center Club.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN LAWMAKERS MEET IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Sixteen legislators from Taiwan exchanged views with their Japanese counterparts in an annual meeting of bilateral lawmakers Thursday and reached consensus on many issues of mutual concern.
The Taiwan lawmakers, led by opposition Kuomintang lawmaker P.K. Chiang, meet with 50 members of the Dietmen's Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship, a pro-Taiwan group.

During the meeting, Takeo Hiranuma, who is the head of the Dietmen's pro-Taiwan group, promised to push the Tokyo authorities to perpetuate visa-free privileges granted to Taiwan tourists during the duration of the Expo 2005 Aichi, and to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly as an observer.

Citing China's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan, its tapping of natural gas in the East China Sea without consulting Japan's opinion, and intrusion by Chinese submarines into Japan's waters, the former Japanese minister of international trade and industry condemned China for pursuing hegemony in the region.
He also said Japan shares Taiwan's interest in peace across the Taiwan Strait.

For his part, Chiang expressed thanks to Hiranuma's group, which, he said, has contributed a great deal to the substantial exchanges between Taiwan and Japan since the two countries broke diplomatic ties in 1972.
Although Taiwan has been squeezed out of many international groups by China, Chiang said, it has come a long way in economic development, and attaches great importance to peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan's representative to Japan Koh Se-kai said the annual meeting has become a vital channel of exchange between the two countries.

He made a pitch for Taiwan's participation in the East Asian community, claiming that it will promote regional peace. He also urged Japan to review its "one China" policy with an eye to improving ties with Taiwan.
Chiang and his delegation arrived in Tokyo Wednesday for a six-day visit.
They paid a call Tuesday on Oogi Chikage, speaker of the House of Councillors, and on Wednesday visited Kansei Nakano, vice speaker of the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER NOMINATES TWO NEW CABINET MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has decided to promote Hakka Affairs Commission Vice Chairman Lee Yung-teh to the chairmanship and to nominate Huang Kuo-lung to head the Environmental Protection Administration, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Thursday.
Cho Jung-tai said that Hsieh had reported to President Chen Shui-bian on the two nominations, which form part of Hsieh's efforts to fill vacancies in his Cabinet.

Lee is to fill the vacancy left by Lo Wen-jia, who quit the chairmanship in March to run in the year-end Taipei county magistrate election, while Huang is to succeed Chang Ju-en, who quit in April to return to teaching.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILLING TO TALK WITH CHINA'S LEADER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is willing to talk with Chinese President Hu Jintao but not in June or July as had been claimed by some local media.

Chatting with a group of lawmakers from his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at a tea party, the president was quoted as saying that he has not forsaken the hope of peace talks with China and would like to meet with Hu if the talks are held somewhere other than Taiwan or China and with no other prerequisites.
Chen was quoted as telling the lawmakers that Taiwan will be half-lost if he goes to China for talks but will get a free hand in negotiating with China if they take place elsewhere.

He defended his February meeting with James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, claiming that it paved the way for reconciliation between the ruling DPP and the opposition at the Legislative Yuan.
"There is nothing wrong with contacting the opposition, as long as we stand firmly by our advocacy of Taiwan's sovereignty." Chen was quoted as saying.

He reiterated his prediction that the domestic political landscape will change dramatically after mid-July, when a new leader takes the reins of the main opposition Kuomintang and the constitutional amendments crafted to reshape the legislature have been approved by the National Assembly.
Opposition lawmakers will stop their unreasonable filibustering at the Legislative Yuan and the ties between the executive and legislative branches will become more stable, the president forecast.
He also defended his announcement last week of tax hikes, which has caused an outcry among taxpayers, saying it is part of his administration's efforts to revamp the tax system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 3, or the 27th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King" and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium in Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories include "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus" and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American sweetheart, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The U.S. Navy launches an attack against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treason. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution, with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for U.S. Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of the state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: An earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: A train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen visits the offshore islands of Tungyin and Matsu, his first visit to the frontline islands since he assumed the post on May 20.
2001: Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, says that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square is a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being forward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN ANTI-NUCLEAR ACTIVIST NAMED ENVIRONMENT MINISTER

TEXT.P: Professor Chang Kow-lung, a veteran environmental protection activist who has been nicknamed Taiwan's "anti-nuclear godfather, " was confirmed Friday by the Executive Yuan as the new Environment Protection Administration (EPA) minister.

Chang, formerly a political vice minister of the Ministry of Examination and a National Taiwan University professor of physics, is filling the vacancy created when Chang Juu-en stepped down more than a month ago to return to his teaching career at National Cheng Kung University.
Chang, 68, who holds a doctoral degree in physics from Yale University, has been an environmental protection activist in Taiwan for 37 years, particularly in anti-nuclear power efforts.
The nomination of Chang as the new EPA minister has generally been welcomed by environmental protection groups in Taiwan.

Chen Shu-hua, chairwoman of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, welcomed Chang's new posting, saying that given his long-term experience in the environmental protection movement in Taiwan, Chang is capable of pushing for major environment policies to make the island a better place in which to live.

Liu Ming-lung, secretary-general of the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation, also received the news favorably, saying that given Chang's professional expertise and his resolve to defend Taiwan's environment, there is no doubt that Chang will bring about a new era in Taiwan in its environmental protection efforts.

Liu, however, called for Chang to stick to his guns after resumes his new post. Liu also expressed hopes that Chang not to be compromised like many of his predecessors who were replaced under pressure from the business and industrial sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE FIRM AT COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2005 HAS HAD DISPLAY BOOTH SHUT DOWN

TEXT.P: A Chinese manufacturer using Taiwan counterpart's license to take part in Computex Taipei 2005 has had its display booth shut down after an opposition lawmaker pointed out the illegal practice.

The Taipei Computer Association (TCA), sponsor of the world's second largest computer exhibition, made the announcement after Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Liao Pen-yen pointed out earlier in the day that several Chinese manufacturers have colluded with their Taiwan counterparts to take part in the Computex Taipei 2005, and urged the government to deal with them rigorously according to the law.
The Taiwan company that colluded with the Chinese manufacturer has been barred from the computer exhibition for the next two years as a penalty, TCA officials said.

Liao said that current regulations stipulate that Chinese manufacturers can take part in local exhibitions with specific themes if they come and go in groups. Chinese manufacturers can take part in international exhibitions in Taipei if they pass screening by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, he added.

Three individual Chinese companies, which applied under the cover of Taiwan manufactures, are currently attending the Computex Taipei 2005, the world's second largest computer exhibition, in total disregard of Taiwan's regulations, Liao claimed.
Liao disclosed the name of one of the Chinese company, but withheld the names of the other two until more information is gathered.

Liao said that he is not against having Chinese manufacturers come to Taiwan to take part in exhibitions legally, but he is opposed to these companies undermining the rights of local manufacturers by colluding with "rogue" Taiwan manufacturers to evade screening and take part in the Computex Taipei 2005 at which it is difficult to get a display booth because of high demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE MAYORS PROTEST TAIWAN MAYORS' PARTICIPATION IN WED EVENTS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 2 (CNA) (By C. Chiang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Seventeen mayors from China on Thursday rejected invitations to the United Nations' World Environment Day (WED) 2005 activities being held June 1-5 in San Francisco in protest against Taiwan mayors' participation in the events.

World Environment Day, while falls on June 5 each year, is one of the principal vehicles through which the United Nations tries to raise global awareness of the environment and enhance political attention and action.
The theme of this year's World Environment Day is "Green Cities," and the slogan is "Plan for the Planet." San Francisco has been selected to host to main activities marking World Environment Day.

During the five days of activities, city leaders attending the events are expected to trade ideas on issues that will create a better environment for people to enjoy a safer and more prosperous future.

The organizers of the WED 2005 activities, including the Bureau of Environment of the City of San Francisco and the United Nations, have invited a total of 250 mayors from cities around the world, including 17 mayors from China and two mayors from Taiwan, to participate in the activities.

Hsu Tain-Tsair, mayor of Tainan City, who is attending at the head of a delegation from the city, met with California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger and San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom at the opening ceremony of the activities.

Meanwhile, Yeh Ching-chuan, deputy mayor of Taipei City, is expected to represent Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is currently vying for the chairmanship of the opposition Kuomintang, in participating in some activities marking this year's WED.
The 17 Chinese mayors have decided to boycott the activities because of the invitations extended by the organizers of the activities to the two mayors from Taiwan.

Tainan Mayor Hsu said that his city's outstanding performance in the fields of environmental and natural resources protection and in waste management over the past few years are some of the reasons that he was invited to attend the WED activities in San Francisco.
Hsu also said that he will join the other 61 mayors attending the activities to sign a "Green Cities Declaration" June 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER RETURNS TO KMT FOLD AFTER 12 YEARS

TEXT.P: Legislator Lee Ching-hua on Friday announced his return to the main opposition Kuomintang fold after leaving the party some 12 years ago.

Lee, who quit the People First Party (PFP) May 18 because he was disappointed by the party's cooperation with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) initiated by PFP Chairman James Soong, who has met with President Chen Shui-bian twice so far this year, said he has a"feeling like coming home" at a welcome press conference presided over by Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Policy Committee
Lee said that he met with KMT Chairman Lien Chan two weeks ago and that Lien extended a welcome.

Lee said that during his visits to grass-roots supporters, the people expressed the hope that he would return to the KMT. He also said that he supports Lien's advocacy of a merger of the KMT and the PFP as well as of cross-strait peace. All these factors contributed to his decision to return to the party, Lee noted.

Lee, who is serving his fifth consecutive term as a legislator, joined the KMT in 1966 but left the party in 1994 for the New Party, a splinter party of the KMT formed by KMT members disgruntled with then President Lee Teng-hui's policies. He later joined the PFP in 2000.

Lee is the second lawmaker to leave the PFP and return to the KMT fold in the past two months. Legislator Chou Hsi-wei did so in April. The PFP is still the third-largest party in the Legislative Yuan.
Tseng said that Lee's legislator sister, Lee Ching-an, remains in the PFP, while Legislator Chiu Yi, who recently quit the PFP, has yet to contact the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S SON TO ENTER KMT DELEGATES ELECTION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's son, Lien Sheng-wen, decided Friday to enter the election for KMT delegates to formally join in political affairs of the main opposition party in Taiwan.

Lien is scheduled to register June 6 for the delegates election, which is slated for July 16 when a new KMT chairman and 1,000-odd KMT delegates will be elected by some 1 million KMT members nationwide, a source from the party's Organization and Development Department said.

The KMT is scheduled to convene a national congress Aug. 19, during which a total of 210 delegates will be elected to the new KMT Central Committee as members by the 1,000-odd newly-elected KMT delegates. About 200 candidates for the Central Committee members will be produced via endorsement by the newly-elected KMT delegates, and another 200 candidates will be nominated by the newly-elected KMT chairman, according to the KMT official.

After the 210 new Central Committee members are elected, the new KMT chairman will nominate some of the Central Committee members and the Central Committee members will endorse some of the members for the election for new KMT Central Standing Committee members, numbering 31, the official said.
Lien's aides declined to confirm whether the chairman's son will seek to be elected as a KMT Central Committee member.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRUS VIRUS HAS ENTERED PEAK FOR THIS YEAR: CDC

TEXT.P: The enterovirus outbreak in Taiwan has entered its peak this year, with a total of 49 severe infections reported so far, including four deaths, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Friday.
CDC Deputy Director General Chou Chi-hao said that among the four deaths, three were caused by the EV71 virus, while the cause of the fourth has yet to be determined.
Chou said that EV71 virus is usually the cause of severe enterovirus infection, but he added that three of the 49 cases are due to the CoxB3 virus.
CoxB3 virus usually hits newborns, and this is exactly the cause of the mass infection of newborns at a hospital in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Chou said.
He noted that one female infant and two male infants at the Taoyuan hospital have been infected with CoxB3 virus, and the hospital has evacuated its infant ward to control the situation.
CDC officials said that all the enterovirus victims are children under five years old, and most of the severe infections have been reported in central Taiwan.

The officials urged parents to watch closely whether their children develop any symptoms of severe illness in the five days after the appearance of symptoms similar to those of enteroviral infection, and if they do, to send the children to hospital immediately.

These symptoms include excessive sleepiness, decreased responsiveness, weakness and paralysis of the extremities, muscle pain, vomiting, fever, irritability, coma, shortness of breath, and increased or irregular heartbeat.

While the symptoms of enteroviral infections can be similar to those of the flu, some patients may also develop blisters on their hands, feet and mouth and even pneumonia, myocarditis and encephalitis.

As enteroviruses are transmitted via direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with contaminated surfaces or objects, practicing good personal hygiene is crucial to preventing infections, according to the CDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW RULES GOVERNING CAT AND DOG IMPORTS TO GO INTO EFFECT MONDAY

TEXT.P: New regulations governing the inspection and quarantine of imported cats and dogs will be put into practice from next Monday to prevent rabies from entering Taiwan, the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture said Friday.

Rabies affects both humans and animals. With recent reports of rabies around the world, the bureau revised the operations governing the inspection and quarantine of imported cats and dogs in February this year.
The new regulations stipulate that cats and dogs imported from infected areas must have blood samples examined by certified laboratories at least 180 days before their entry.

Bureau officials said that Taiwan has had no documented cases of rabies since 1961 and urged the public to follow the regulations when bringing cats and dogs in and out of Taiwan and not to buy animals and related products from unidentified sources.
The public were also encouraged to report smuggling activities through the hotline 0800-039131.

Rabies is an acute, infectious, often fatal viral disease of most warm-blooded animals, especially wolves, cats and dogs, which attacks the central nervous system and is transmitted by the bite of an infected animal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TO FEEL TENSION OF FREE ECONOMY, TIGHT POLITICS: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) (By George Liu and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld said Wednesday that China will feel the tension caused by its free economy and tight politics in the coming years.

According to Rumsfeld, China is going to reach a fork in the road as it wants to boost its economy -- to do that it has to have a relatively free economic system -- and to maintain strong political control, which he said is inconsistent with having a free economic system.
"So they're going to feel that tension, that stress, in the years ahead," he said during an interview.
He noted that the U.S. government will soon release a report on the People's Republic of China that recognizes that the PRC is increasing its military capability on land, sea and air.
"We know it's been investing in double digits in its military capabilities [and] that it's been buying a great deal of weaponry from Russia," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 68.47 points to close at 6,107.95.
The bourse opened at 6,062.78 and fluctuated between 6,113.49 and 6,051.27 during trading. A total of 4.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$102.53 billion (US$3.26 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 5.6 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, cement stocks and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.8 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 654 to 202, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPORTERS WITNESS CHINA'S OBSTRUCTION OF PRESS FREEDOM
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 2 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese reporter Thursday witnessed several of China's obstructions in preventing the nation's journalists from doing their jobs and said the obstructions have made Taiwan media face more difficulties in covering the news.

Chiu Yu Tzu, a reporter of the Taipei Times, bore witness at a press conference held by the International Society for Human Rights (ISGHR) on the eve of 16th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre to condemn the violence of the Beijing government's trampling of human rights.

Criticizing the United Nations for its second consecutive refusal to allow Taiwan reporters to cover this year's annual meeting of the World Health Assembly, the executive arm of the World Health Organization, which was held May 6-14 in Geneva, Chiu said that although Taiwan is a democratic country, its journalists abroad have encountered more difficulties than their counterparts from other countries in doing their jobs.

Saying that she experienced unfair treatment from the United Nations, which refused to allow her to cover a "U.N. Conference for Sustainable Development" held in Johannesburg in 2002, the reporter said that the only reason given by the U.N. was that it does not recognize Taiwan.

Describing Chiu's experience as "unbelievable, " a former reporter of the Xinhua News Agency and Radio France International, who was also attending the conference, said that the U.N.'s discrimination against Taiwan journalists is an injustice that will eventually be judged by historians and media experts in the future.

Wei Jinsheng, a renowned Chinese dissident now living in the United States, also said at the gathering that Chinese embassies in various countries around the world still press foreign media to report only the news that is believed to be beneficial to the Beijing government.

ISFHR spokesman Martin Lessenthin issued a statement at the press conference saying that the freedom of discussion is a precondition of political and economic development and that paying proper heed to human rights can create a more stable society.
He further said that the continuous obstructions of the Chinese government in the freedom of the press and against political dissidents can only cause resistance and instability.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN FILES DEFAMATION SUIT AGAINST PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong filed a defamation suit against President Chen Shui-bian Friday over Chen's claim that Soong met with a Chinese official secretly in the United States.
Soong demanded a symbolic NT$1 in compensation and a published apology in major newspapers for three consecutive days.
Presidential Office officials declined to comment on the case but said the president will continue to seek reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties.

According to a petition submitted by Soong's attorney to the Taipei District Court, Chen claimed during an interview with a local TV network May 8 that he had intelligence showing that Soong met with Chen Yunlin, head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, in the United States in February this year.

The president also claimed that Soong promised during the meeting to oppose a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments in exchange for Beijing's approval for him to visit China, the petition says.
It notes that Chen has refused to apologize or offer any explanation, despite Soong's strong protest and the National Security Bureau's denial of having the intelligence that Chen mentioned.
Soong alleged that Chen was obviously attacking his political reputation with the unfactual account.

PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said the party believes it is right to follow a path of political reconciliation with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) but that it will not tolerate the president's defamation of an opposition leader.
Chen Chih-pin, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, expressed his support for Soong's move.

As to whether the incident will affect cooperation between the PFP and the DPP, Chen said the cooperation is based on national interests rather than partisan gain, but he stressed that such cooperation must not be conducted at the expense of the PFP's dignity.
Meanwhile, Ker Chien-ming, head of the DPP's policy committee, said he did not think Chen and Soong will become enemies because of the incident.
Ker said Chen and Soong share similar views on promoting political stability and cross-Taiwan Strait reconciliation and that there is still room for them to work together.
William C.T. Lai, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, expressed regret at Soong's decision to sue the president.

Lai said he hopes the PFP will continue to pursue political reconciliation based on the spirit of a Feb. 24 Chen-Soong meeting and cooperate with the DPP to push through priority bills during the upcoming special legislative session.
