DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MODEL INVITED TO PROMOTE JAPAN TOURISM

TEXT.P: Japan's Ministry of Land Infrastructure and Transport (MLIT) has once again invited Chiling Lin, a fashion model from Taiwan, to serve as a goodwill ambassador for its tourism-boosting "Visit Japan Campaign (VJC)."

Lin, dressed in a traditional Japanese kimono, called on Katzuo Kitagawa, head of the MLIT, at his office Friday. During the meeting, Kitagawa presented a certificate of assignment to Lin, who was also the "VJC Taiwan goodwill ambassador" last year.

Kitagawa said that thanks to Lin, some 1.08 million tourists from Taiwan visited Japan in 2004, the highest number in history. The MLIT wants to borrow the celebrity's charm one more time to lure more Taiwanese visitors to the country, the minister added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO THROW FULL WEIGHT BEHIND DOMESTIC ENTERPRISES: PM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the government will throw its full weight behind enterprises that are willing to invest heavily in Taiwan.
Hsieh made the remarks when he attended the inauguration of the second 12-inch wafer plant of Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. in the Hsinchu Science-based Park in northern Taiwan.
Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. Chairman Frank C. Huang reaffirmed his determination to keep the company's roots in Taiwan.
He said that 95 percent of the company's investment is currently in Taiwan and that it will remain here.

No matter what changes take place in the economy, the company's plan to build a new 12-inch wafer plant in Taiwan every two years will remain unchanged. It is estimated that the investment in Taiwan will eventually reach NT$200 billion (US$6.34 billion).

Hsieh said that in addition to the Hsinchu Science-based park, the science parks in central and southern Taiwan are also growing rapidly, moving toward the goal of "high-tech silicon valley island" espoused by President Chen Shui-bian.

Vice President Annette Lu, speaking on the same occasion, said that Taiwan is a beautiful high-tech island and that its importance to high-tech industry is like the supply of oil of the Middle East countries to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO HELP LIFT CHINESE FARMERS FROM POVERTY: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to extend its experience and expertise in the development of agricultural economy to Chinese farmers to help them shake off poverty, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.

Noting that Taiwan's agricultural achievements are world renowned and that Taiwan has helped Third World countries develop agriculture for decades, MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said Taiwan is capable and willing to help alleviate the poverty of Chinese farmers, who number roughly 900 million.
You called for authorities of China's agricultural sector to contact Taiwan for talks on efforts to provide timely and effective assistance to their farmers.

At a regular press meeting, he quoted United Nations and World Bank tallies as indicating that nearly 200 million farmers in China are unemployed without any regular income, the bane of China's economy.

About seven out of 10 people in China live in rural areas, You said, quoting information released by the Chinese authorities as indicating that the Chinese farmers' annual income currently averages 2,900 renminbi (US$362.5) , representing a daily income of about 8 renminbi.
However, You said, according to a survey conducted by a private group in China, the average daily income is actually less than one-tenth of the official figure.
Despite the prevailing poverty, China's farmers have to pay various taxes, You added.

The Chinese authorities have also announced that the unemployment rate in the agricultural sector stood at 7 percent as of early this year, representing about 20 million farmers are out of work, a dubious figure compared with the figure released by the United Nations and the World Bank of nearly 200 million, You said.

Quoting a recent saying in China: "The farmers are bitter, rural villages are poor and the agriculture sector is endangered, " You reiterated that Taiwan, in its capacity as a member of the international community, is more than willing to help lift China's farmers out of poverty.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS SUPPORT U.S.-BASED TV BROADCAST TO CHINA

TEXT.P: A total of 45 Taiwan lawmakers released a joint letter Friday urging the European satellite operator Eutelsat to continue leasing its satellite to a U.S.-based Chinese-language television station so that it can broadcast pro-democracy programs into China.

At a press conference held in the Legislative Yuan, Liu Ying-chuan, a representative of the New Tang Dynasty Television (NTDTV) station, urged Eutelsat to continue leasing its satellite to his company so that it can continue broadcasting free television programs in China.

Liu claimed that NTDTV's programs, designed at unveiling "the realities in China, " are being hindered by the Chinese authorities and that Eutelsat is planning to suspend leasing its satellite to the NTDTV under pressure from China.
NTDTV has been broadcasting uncensored programs into China via the Eutelsat satellite since March 2004.

The television company has so far gained support from 93 American congressmen, 73 lawmakers from the European Union and other European countries, as well as 25 members of the Canadian Parliament, who have urged Eutelsat to renew its contract with NTDTV before June 6.

Meanwhile, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao sent a representative to the press conference to show his recognition of NTDTV's contribution in broadcasting "the real situation in China."

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUME OF DRUG BUSTS, NUMBER OF DRUG ADDICTS ON THE RISE: DOH

TEXT.P: Both the volume of drug busts and the number of drug addicts in Taiwan have surged noticeably over the past seven years, while the age of people coming into their first contact with narcotics has lowered, sources from the Department of Health (DOH) said Friday.

Speaking at a national anti-narcotics conference, Li Jih-heng, director-general of the DOH National Bureau of Controlled Drugs, said that about 1,000 kg of illicit drugs were apprehended by law enforcement authorities in 1998, a figure that had soared eight-fold to some 8,000 kg by 2004.
Meanwhile, Li said, the number of drug addicts checking into DOH psychiatric centers and related institutions to get rid of addiction has also surged from 1,000 to 12,000 people.

Officials from the Taoyuan Psychiatric Center also reported at the conference, saying that the age of drug abusers coming into contact with narcotics for the first time averaged 17.3 years in 2004, much younger than the average age of 20 posted a decade ago.
Among all narcotics, heroin is the most difficult to kick, according to Li, while heroin addicts are also most vulnerable to AIDS infection.
To help these addicts get rid of their habit, the DOH has decided to choose 50 heroin addicts who are also HIV positive to be candidates for medication with buprenorphine from July, Li noted.
Buprenorphine is currently one of the most effective medicines capable of helping AIDS patients quit heroin addiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP CALLS FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF MINIMUM TAX SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The private Alliance of Fairness and Justice urged the government Friday to implement by the end of this year a minimum tax system that targets very high income earners to ensure the fairness of the country's tax system.
In addition, the alliance demanded that the government lift the income tax exemption for military servicemen and teachers.

The group proposed setting the minimum tax rate at 15 percent and announced that it will launch a campaign to unseat any legislators who boycott the tax reforms and those who lobby for tax cuts for the business sector.
According to Tseng Chu-wei, a professor of public finance at National Chengchi University, the targets of the minimum tax should include corporations and individuals.
The government should reform the income tax system before adjusting the business tax rate, Tseng added.

President Chen Shui-bian unveiled Monday a set of tax reform proposals that are aimed at raising the average national tax rate from the current 13.6 percent to 15 percent in three years and even higher -- to 18 percent -- as a mid-term goal.
The proposals include hiking the business tax by one or two percentage points to 6 percent or 7 percent and levying a capital gains tax on investment in unlisted companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC ATTENDANCE IRRELEVANT TO CHEN-HU MEETING: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's desire to attend the annual summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum has nothing to do with the proposal of a meeting between him and Chinese President Hu Jintao, an official said Friday.

Chou Chun-ying, deputy director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, was responding to a media report that Chen is striving to attend the 2005 APEC informal leadership meeting to be held in South Korea later this year so that he can meet with Hu on that international occasion.

The 21-member APEC forum is one of the few major international organizations that admit both Taiwan and China. Because of China's opposition, Taiwan's top leader has been barred from attending the annual APEC informal leadership meeting in person and has to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

Over the years, Chou said, the Presidential Office has always hoped that Chen can attend the APEC summit in person. However, she went on, such a desire is completely irrelevant to the proposal for a summit meeting across the Taiwan Strait.
If Chen is able to attend the APEC summit, Chou said, he would interact with his counterparts from all APEC member economies, not just with the top leader from any specific member economy.
As to the topics of a cross-strait summit, Chou noted that this is another issue entirely.

Chen was quoted as having said during a tea party with a group of lawmakers from his ruling Democratic Progressive Party Thursday that he is willing to talk with Hu but not in June or July as had been claimed by some local media.

Chen further said he has not forsaken the hope of peace talks with China and would like to meet with Hu if the talks are held somewhere other than Taiwan or China, on an equal footing and with no prerequisites other than those.
In his view, Chen said Taiwan would be half-lost if he were to go to China for talks but would get a free hand in negotiating with China if the talks were to take place elsewhere.
A local newspaper speculated that Chen's "third place" proposal refers to the APEC meeting scheduled for late this year in South Korea, but Chou dismissed the speculation as "off base."
Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that whether a Chen-Hu meeting can become a reality hinges on China's attitude.

For years, MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said, the DPP administration has on numerous occasions extended olive branches in an effort to push for cross-strait "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation and permanent peace."

Noting that the longstanding disputes across the Taiwan Strait could have profound impact, You said the two sides should have meaningful dialogue and consultations with a view to resolving all those critical disputes.

In the pursuit of cross-strait peaceful development, You said, the MAC and other relevant government agencies have made extensive preparations for cross-strait talks. However, he went on, it takes two to tango and high-level cross-strait talks will take place only when China shows interest or willingness.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW STRAITS EXCHANGE FOUNDATION HEAD RECOMMENDED

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh recommended Friday Chang Chun-hsiung, a former premier and former secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which handles daily affairs in Taiwan's exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) spokesman Yu Ying-lung said the naming will strengthen the government's "rapprochement- and cooperation-oriented" China policy because Chang has long called for "cooperation rather than confrontation" with China.
Yu said Chang is the "best choice" for the critical and symbolic post.

The post has been vacant since the death of Koo Chen-fu Jan. 3. It had long been rumored that President Chen Shui-bian wanted Chang to take over the post and Hsieh finally made it official, as the SEF board is to meet next week to formally endorse Hsieh's recommendation.

Chang, 67, graduated from National Taiwan University with a law degree. After becoming a lawyer, he joined the legal corps defending opposition activists arrested during the 1979 Formosa Magazine incident. He then entered politics, serving as an opposition lawmaker for 17 years.

During the 2000 presidential election, Chang served as DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian's campaign manager. After winning the election, he worked as deputy premier, premier and the president's secretary-general before becoming the DPP's secretary-general. He is currently a senior adviser to the president.

William C.T. Lai, DPP legislative caucus secretary-general, said that with his rich political experience, Chang will be able to win the trust of the people in Taiwan and protect Taiwan's interests in the handling of cross-strait affairs.
The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said it expects Chang to "shed his ideology" and do more in promoting pragmatic exchanges with China.

Chen Chieh, secretary-general of the KMT's legislative caucus, said that during his time as premier, Chang did not made too many pro-Taiwan independence statements and that the party hopes "he will promote cross-strait exchanges and not be bound by his party's ideology."

However, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen accused Chang's appointment of being "political cronyism" as he does not have any special knowledge or experience or even interest in cross-strait affairs and therefore will not help improve Taiwan-China relations.
The opposition People First Party (PFP) said it does not expect too much from Chang on the grounds that it is Chen who makes China policy and who must explain it in clear terms.

Chen Chih-pin, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, said that if the president does not explain clearly to the people his China policy, "it does not matter who is in charge of the Straits Exchange Foundation" because cross-strait relations simply will not change.

The minor opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's secretary-general, Chen Chien-ming, expressed hope that Chang will be able to "reopen the door of negotiation" between the SEF and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMAGE MUSEUM INAUGURATED IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: An image museum long planned by the Government Information Office (GIO) to collect documentary films and other images was inaugurated Friday in Taichung, central Taiwan.

GIO Minister Pasuya Yao presided over the inauguration of the museum, called Taiwan Images on the Blog. Also on hand were former GIO head Lin Chia-lung, who quit his job earlier to run for the Taichung mayorship in the year-end elections.

Yao noted that it was Lin who made the decision to establish the museum in Taichung and that the name has its inspiration from web-logs (usually shortened to blogs) , a form of online personal journals.
The museum collects the most comprehensive contemporary documentary films in Taiwan, Yao said, adding that he hopes it will also become an interchange and discussion center for central Taiwan.

Yao noted that the GIO has had a series of pieces of good news recently. The GIO-assisted documentary film "Jump! Boys, " depicting gymnasts undergoing gruelling training made more than NT$2.5 million (US$79,365) at the box office because of good reviews. Another documentary film "Let it Be" depicting the lives of rice farmers also made more than NT$2 million.
"The Wayward Cloud," an award-winning film at the Berlin Festival this year, also set a box office record of more than NT$20 million, Yao added.
He praised Lin for his measures and policy of assisting domestic film workers when he was GIO head.
Lin for his part said there is a national movie center in northern Taiwan, but it mainly collects feature films, while the central museum will focus on collecting documentary films.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO SEEK CROSS-STRAIT RAPPROCHEMENT: PROSPECTIVE SEF HEAD

TEXT.P: The prospective new chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Chang Chun-hsiung, said Friday that the government's China policy will focus on maintaining Taiwan's identity and seeking rapprochement and symbiosis with China.

Premier Frank Hsieh formally recommended Chang as SEF chairman to replace Dr. Koo Chen-fu, who died in January. The recommendation is expected to win approval next week from the board of directors of the SEF, the quasi-official body that handles day-to-day cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.
Chang immediately pledged that he will show his utmost sincerity and patience in seeking to resume cross-strait dialogue.
He said it is a great pity that the governments on the two sides of the strait are currently stuck in a squabble over the definition of the so-called "1992 consensus."

He said the "1992 consensus" comes from the Hong Kong negotiations of that year, which he claimed resulted in both parties agreeing not to deal with controversial issues but to respect each other and talk about ways and means of solving practical problems.
"If the two sides can try to solve all issues based on that 'Hong Kong spirit, ' I believe it will be a good start (to a resumption of dialogue)," he told a press conference.

Turning to domestic squabbles over the direction of Taiwan's China policy, Chang said a consensus needs to be reached for the sake of national interest, as consensus is the "most critical support" of policy.
The success of the SEF depends on reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties as well as the consensus of the people, he said.
Hsieh said he recommended Chang because the government wants to usher in a new era for cross-strait relations.
Chang has rich experience in politics; he knows political changes and cross-strait relations well; further, he knows President Chen Shui-bian's basic stance with regard to China, Hsieh said.
He said he expects Chang, with his wide experience and moderate style, to open up a new situation and work for the well-being of the people on both sides of the strait.
Observers said Chang has always been a "vanguard" in the governing team, sometimes acting as a firefighter but more often as a moderator.

His appointment to the SEF position is an indication that Chen wants to have direct dialogue with China's top leader, and Chang will play the role of "ice breaker" in that regard, according to the observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH NATIONAL ASSEMBLY DEPUTIES TO VISIT TAIWAN JUNE 5

TEXT.P: A five-member French political group headed by Christian Bataille, the chair of a Taiwan-friendly group in the French National Assembly, will arrive in Taiwan for a six-day visit June 5, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

The group of French parliamentarians and a provincial councilor will visit David J.C. Chung, vice president of the Legislative Yuan, Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen and Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, as well as other officials, during their stay. They will also tour economic and cultural establishments such as the No. 1 Nuclear Power Plant and the National Palace Museum.
Bataille, a socialist, visited Taiwan in January 2003 to attend an international conference on Asia-Pacific security.

The other members of the group will be three of Bataille's colleagues in the National Assembly -- Michel Voisin, Albert Facon and Jacques Houssin -- as well as Delphine Bataille, a provincial councilor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IT SERVICE MARKET REACHES US$1.8 BILLION

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's information technology (IT) service market reached NT$58.1 billion (US$1.8 billion) last year, according to statistics compiled by the International Data Corporation (IDC).

Tsao Yung-hui, a Taiwanese analyst at the IDC, noted that the market for IT services in Taiwan has been fierce in the last few years, affected by slow economic growth, forcing local entrepreneurs to become more and more prudent in their purchase of information products and services.
Although the market for software maintenance is stable, profits are dropping, with the market for system integration in big enterprises almost saturated, Tsao added.

Despite this, Tsao predicted that IT service companies will enjoy a lucrative market by offering core system software, tools and applications for new banks in the next five years, with the banks' annual investment in this respect expected to total more than NT$10 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT BE ABSENT FROM `GLOBAL CHINESE LANGUAGE FEVER': OCAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan will do its best to play a leadership role in promoting Chinese language and culture around the world, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei said Friday.
Chang made the remarks in a speech at the opening of the 4th International Conference on Internet Chinese Education being held at the National Taiwan Science Education Center through Sunday.

Describing that the traditional characters used in Taiwan as the "orthodox" writing form of Chinese, Chang expressed her hope of helping the people of Taiwan and those in the rest of the world to gain a better understanding of what she claimed is "a Chinese fever sweeping the entire world."

Chang dismissed a recent media report that China has gained the upper hand over Taiwan in the global advocacy of Chinese language, saying that Taiwan's digital technology is far above China's levels and that the OCAC will also kick off various programs to lure more Chinese learners.
She also denied that the United States has shifted from Taiwan's traditional characters to China's simplified characters, claiming that the information is incorrect.

According to a recent newspaper report, China is attracting increasing numbers of foreign Chinese learning students with its use of simplified characters and a strong cultural promotion campaign -- setting up more than 100 "Confucius institutes" worldwide.

The OCAC chairwoman said her council has been preparing to launch various e-learning programs on its Web site in the hope of creating a network of 3,600 Chinese language-teaching centers around the world.

Quoting a recent report by Newsweek, around 2,400 high schools in the United States will begin opening Chinese classes in 2007, she said, adding that this is a clear indication that Chinese language and culture will be incorporated into the U. S. higher and secondary education systems, as a large number of U.S. colleges and universities will also open Chinese courses from 2006.

To catch up with the new trend, the OCAC and the Ministry of Education will jointly generate US$300,000 to help finance a project to create teaching materials and related matters, she said, noting that relevant government agencies have agreed to consolidate resources and policymaking mechanisms to make Taiwan a global hub and think tank for Chinese language teaching and learning.

The Global Chinese Language and Culture Center run by the OCAC provides an E-school for Chinese teaching and learning through the Internet, she said. In the future, the E-school will be developed into a portal and platform responsible for online enrollment, learning, testing and certification for overseas Chinese and foreigners, she explained.

Emphasizing that Taiwan is determined to play a constructive role in the Chinese learning enthusiasm worldwide, she said that the government has been assisting more than 3,000 Chinese schools offshore and has been maintaining close links with about 1,800 of them.
She expressed the hope of turning the 1,800 Chinese schools abroad into the OCAC's strongholds abroad, where Chinese learners can enjoy high-quality software and hardware facilities.

Meanwhile, domestic and foreign experts are slated to make public a total of 85 papers at the three-day conference on building a digital environment for Chinese learning and teaching through e-learning.

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRD ROUND TAIWAN-GUATEMALA FTA TALKS TO KICK OFF ON JUNE 6

TEXT.P: The third round of negotiations concerning the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and Guatemala is slated for June 6-10 in Los Angeles, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.

According to MOEA officials, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will head Taiwan's negotiation team, with Chen's Guatemalan counterpart, Enrique Lacs, being the main negotiator for Guatemala.
Other officials from the ministries of foreign affairs, finance, transportation and communications, as well as agriculture from both countries will also participate in the talks.
MOEA officials noted that representatives will be divided into several divisions, including market access, service and investments, as well as legal review of regulations.

The two sides are expected to focus on topics that were not agreed upon at the second round of talks, including national treatment, rule of origin, dispute settlements, safeguard measures, unfair trade measures, and technical trade barriers.

As the previous rounds of talks have been conducted smoothly, MOEA officials showed confidence that both sides will reach consensus at the third round of negotiations in regulations, the list of agricultural and industrial products that may enjoy tariff cuts, the negative list for the opening of the service industry, aviation and marine transport agreements, and the rule of origin.
The officials expressed hope that the free trade agreement can be signed before the end of this year.
Taiwan's first FTA was signed with Panama, with the pact coming into effect in January 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION CONFERENCE OPENS IN YUNLIN
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, Central Taiwan, June 3 (CNA) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-Southeast Asia International Conference on Technological and Professional Higher Education opened Friday at National Yunlin University of Science and Technology (NYUST).
The two-day event drew more than 300 educators from Taiwan, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam and the Philippines.

Addressing the opening of the conference, NYUST President Lin Tsong-ming said globalization is the trend of the 21st century and that technological and vocational education should also follow this trend.
Lin proposed that educational institutions in Taiwan and Southeast Asia enhance their academic exchanges and promote multi-dimensional cooperation.

According to Chang Kuo-pao, head of the Department of Technological and Vocational Education under the Ministry of Education, it is the ministry's policy to promote academic-corporate collaboration and international exchanges.
The ministry will hold exhibitions on technological and vocational education in various Southeast Asian countries in the future to attract students to study in Taiwan, Chang said.

In a keynote speech on technological talent in Taiwan's high-tech firms, Chang Ping-heng, a human resources official at the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., pointed out that Taiwan has faced manpower shortages in recent years because students are interested only in getting academic degrees rather than pursuing academic quality.

To cope with the demand of corporations, personnel should be well-trained in terms of their linguistic ability, international perspective, professional skills, emotional management and communicative ability, Chang said.

Topics on the agenda of the conference include faculty and student exchanges, mutual curriculum accreditation, development and accreditation of Internet curricula and instruction, and international research collaboration.
An exhibition of technological research achievements is being held as a sideline event of the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN TO ARRIVE JUNE 4 FOR THREE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: U. S. Representative Mark R. Kennedy will arrive in Taipei Saturday for a three-day visit, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
Kennedy is slated to meet President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and hear a briefing by officials of the American Institute in Taiwan, the MOFA official said.

He will also pay visits to the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research and the Far East Air Transport Corp. to better understand Taiwan's economic and political developments, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and issues related to a Taiwan-U.S. free trade agreement.
It is Kennedy's first visit to Taiwan as a U.S. congressman, and is part of his Asian tour that will also take him to China, South Korea and Thailand under the arrangement of the U. S. government.

Kennedy, a staunch supporter of Taiwan since assuming his post in 2001, voted in favor of adopting resolutions to back Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, to oppose Beijing's Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan, and to urge the European Union not to remove its ban on weapons exports to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall Shriver said Thursday he is scheduled to visit Taiwan in July and will meet with ROC President Chen Shui-bian.

Shriver made the remarks while meeting with a group of journalists from Taiwan. The press group, headed by Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, discussed with Shriver issues regarding relations across the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan-U.S.-China relations.

Shriver, who just stepped down as deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs, said he had met with President Chen on many occasions in the past few years. Shriver said he believes that Chen fully understands the cross-strait situation.

When he visits Taiwan in July, Shriver said he would not take the initiative to offer any advice about cross-strait issues. "But if President Chen asks me, I would take pleasure in offering my own opinions," he added.

Touching on the meeting in September between U.S. President George W. Bush and Chinese President Hu Jintao, Shriver said he believes they will focus their discussions on U.S.-China trade and the North Korean issue. Shriver said he doesn't think anything new regarding the Taiwan issue will be forthcoming.

Shriver further said although China shows some "creativity" in dealing with the Taiwan issue, it has so far not demonstrated any "flexibility" in its stance. Since both the United States and China have their own fundamental stances, Shriver said, they are unlikely to come up with any new overture about the Taiwan issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES REACH US$253.17 billion

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit US$253.17 billion as of the end of May, an historical high, according to statistics released Friday by the Taiwan's Central Bank of China.

The amount represented an increase of US$530 million over the April figure, and a growth of US$11.43 billion over the end of last year due largely to profits gained by investments made from foreign exchange reserves, the statistics show.
The figure made Taiwan the third-largest holder of foreign reserves in the world, after Japan's US$824.2 billion and mainland China's US$670.77 billion posted in April, officials of the bank said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REMAINS FIRM ON RAPPROCHEMENT PLAN: YU SHYI-KUN

TEXT.P: Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that President Chen Shui-bian remains firm in his plan to seek rapprochement with opposition parties.

However, Yu would not comment on opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong's lawsuit against the president. The suit originated from Chen's statement that Soong had met with China's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin in the United States early this year.
Yu said the president has many sources of information; when he made that statement, he did not mean to hurt anybody or make anybody uncomfortable.
Even though Soong has filed a civil lawsuit against the president, the Presidential Office respects Soong and the legal process, and will not make any further comment, Yu said.

Asked if Chen will meet with Soong again, or with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Yu said the atmosphere surrounding the relations between the ruling party and the opposition parties has changed somewhat after the May 14 National Assembly election since contacts have been less frequent than before.
Still, he stressed, the president is standing firm on the "road to rapprochement" and will continue to create harmony and induce cooperation among political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR TO ATTEND CITY CONFERENCE IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu has won Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) approval to attend a city and local government conference in Beijing, the first Taiwan mayor or magistrate to visit China with government permission.

The executive and board meeting of United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG) , scheduled for June 8-10, rotates in different cities around the world every year. As Taichung has been elected a board member in Asia, Hu has been invited to attend this year's meeting in Beijing.
The Beijing conference will discuss two major topics: How cities should cope with an emergency, and how cities should define themselves in the years after 2000.
Hu said he had not expected to win government approval to attend the meeting in Beijing as he did not hear from the MAC until Thursday.

Although he will be the first mayor or county magistrate from Taiwan to attend the meeting in China, he will not make any political statement while there because it is a purely civilian activity, he said.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is busy running for the chairmanship of the Kuomintang, has said he will not attend the meeting. He may assign a deputy to go in his place.

Mayors and local government representatives from around the world embarked on a new era of international cooperation with the launching of a new body called United Cities and Local Governments in Paris May 2-5, 2004. UCLG is a merger of the International Local Governments Alliance and the International Cities Alliance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FIFTH IN BERI'S INVESTMENT CLIMATE EVALUATION FOR 2005

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment environment was ranked fifth among 50 major economies by the Swiss-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) market research firm in its 2005 investment climate risk evaluation report.

Citing BERI statistics, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Taiwan's investment climate ranking was behind that of Switzerland, Singapore, the Netherlands and Japan. In Asia, the island enjoyed the third-best investment climate, only after Singapore and Japan.
Taiwan was classified at the 1A category as a country with low risk for investments.
BERI evaluates a country's investment climate based on three major indicators -- business risk index, political risk index and currency exchange risk index.

Taiwan's business risk index and currency exchange risk index remained at last year's level -- both at third place; however, its political risk index dropped two places to 15th in this year's evaluation.
BERI considered Taiwan's business risk as stable, suggesting that the island may improve its image in the world community by continuing its reform programs.
Regarding the currency exchange risk index, BERI hailed Taiwan's progress in the legal structure governing foreign exchange reserves and the island's ability to earn these reserves.
The Swiss company also classified Taiwan's political risk as stable, predicting that there will be no military conflicts between the two sides of Taiwan Strait before 2008.

Although China enacted the Anti-Secession Law with Taiwan as its target, which caused some concern, in fact it might turn out to be a turning point for the island, BERI experts noted, estimating that cross-strait relations will improve over the next five years.
BERI experts concluded that Taiwan political risk dropped due largely to the political struggles among different parties within the country.

Meanwhile, according to the BERI report, Taiwan can claim the third-best workforce in the world, only after that of Singapore and the United States, as the attitude of its laborers, skill level, labor regulations and relative productivity all scored high.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. COULD BE BEST BRIDGE FOR CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he thinks that the United States probably could be the best bridge and platform for an historic meeting between the top leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with New York Times Chairman Arthur O. Sulzberger, Jr., who is currently on a three-day visit in Taiwan at the invitation of the United Daily News Group.

Even though the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have different political systems and lifestyles, Chen said he is more than willing to develop contacts, dialogue and consultations with China. Nevertheless, he stressed that cross-strait talks should be conducted without violation of the principles of "sovereignty, dignity, security and popular wellbeing."
Chen further said he looks forward to an historic handshake and peace talks with the Chinese leader on an equal footing and with no preconditions.
"I hope this 'first meeting' can take place in a third country and the United States could probably be the best bridge and platform for such a rendezvous," Chen said.

Touching on the recent China visits by two Taiwan opposition leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, Chen said he didn't think that their visits could help pave the way for him to visit the mainland.

"In reality, I took their visits as a litmus test for the Chinese leadership's sincerity toward improving cross-strait relations. My observation is that the Chinese leader didn't make any concessions. Even so, I would not forsake the hope of forging cross-strait rapprochement and dialogue while insisting on Taiwan's separate identity," Chen said.
The president further said he feels regret that China didn't seize the "window of opportunity" for cross-strait detente when he first came to power in 2000.

"I believe that the years of 2005 and 2006 could be another 'window of opportunity' for improving cross-strait ties. If China misses it, the next such opportunity is not expected to come until after 2008 or even 2010," he claimed.

While he is willing to talk with Chinese President Hu Jintao in a third country with no political strings or preconditions, Chen said he doesn't expect that the first such meeting would result in a conclusion to longstanding cross-strait disputes.
"I believe it would take time to work out a viable solution. We may need many rounds of difficult talks to find a solution, " Chen said.

In U.S. President George W. Bush's telephone conversations with Hu on May 5, Bush urged Hu to hold talks with Taiwan's duly-elected leader, referring to President Chen. Chen said he looks forward to such a moment.

As the top national leader, Chen said, he is obligated to defend Taiwan's sovereignty and protect the country from being invaded or annexed. While China addresses the sovereignty issue from the Chinese nationalistic perspective, Chen said his administration is dealing with the issue based on the principle of democracy. His belief is that Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to its 23 million people. Against this backdrop, Chen said he doesn't think the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resolve this dispute any time soon. Therefore, he said, a Chen-Hu meeting could take place only if both sides agree to talk without any political string or prerequisites.

For his part, Sulzberger said if a Chen-Hu meeting indeed takes place, it would certainly make headlines around the world. Sulzberger presented a collection of New York Times news clippings regarding the 911 terrorist attacks to Chen as a gift.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO EASE REGULATIONS ON BUSINESSES IN FREE TRADE HABOR ZONES

TEXT.P: Regulations governing orders for outbound processing within Taiwan's free trade habor zones have been relaxed to attract more international distribution and logistics businesses to set up operational lines there, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPC) said Friday.

Under the Statute Governing the Establishment and Management of Free Trade Habor Zones, only two sectors in the compounds -- manufacturing and processing -- are currently permitted to place orders on manufacturers or processors outside the zones.
However, according to some corporate sources, the official said, logistics and transportation sectors are also expected to open operational lines in the free trade zones in the future.

If the zones want international logistics enterprises to move in, they should give the businesses the right to seek outbound processors to allow them enjoying sufficient sources of supplies, corporate sources have suggested.

Vice CEPD Chairman Thomas M.F. Yeh indicated that regulations were changed to allow non-manufacturing and processing businesses in the free trade zones to file orders to outbound processors. If their ordered products are transported back to the free trade zones in six months after the order is released, the goods are tax free, he noted.
There are currently free-trade zones operating in Keelung, Taoyuan and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 4 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, June 4:
08:30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend the opening ceremony of the 2005 International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE) conference at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
09: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the commencement of National Taiwan University's 2004 academic year at the university's gym.

10: 30, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will attend the opening ceremony of an agricultural products show at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
14: 30, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a fundraising luncheon for the Democratic Pacific Union at the "New York, New York" shopping mall in Taipei.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive foreign participants of the 2005 IAEE conference at the Presidential Office.
19:40, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh will return home from South Korea via the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending the APEC trade ministers meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN'S DEFENSE UNCHANGED: FORMER U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: U.S President George W. Bush's 2001 promise that he will do whatever it takes to defend Taiwan remains unchanged, former U.S Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Randall G. Schriver said Friday.

During a meeting with a group of journalists from Taiwan, Schriver said Washington tried through both private and public channels to dissuade China from enacting its Anti-Secession Law early this year, calling it a wrong step unhelpful for China's ties with Taiwan.

The backlash the law produced in the international community has born out Washington's prediction, and the European Union has therefore postponed a decision to lift an arms embargo against China, Schriver went on.

He denied that Washington's response to China's enactment of the law was not as harsh as its anger over Taiwan's first national referendum in 2004, claiming that the United States was unable to frame its response to China's Anti-Secession Law before China made public its contents.

He dismissed concerns that the U.S. might withdraw its offer to sell a package of arms to Taiwan if Taiwan's opposition parties keep blocking passage of the budget for it, but warned that the foot-dragging might drive up the price of the weapons because of arms manufacturers' cost in re-launching their production lines.

When Taiwan criticizes the United States for what it felt was a weak response by Washington to China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, it should ask itself why it drags its feet on clinching the arms sale, Schriver said.

Schriver said he is not certain whether Chinese President Hu Jintao is amenable to the idea mulled by his predecessor Jiang Zemin of withdrawing its missiles targeting Taiwan in exchange for a U.S. promise to stop arms sales to Taiwan, but Washington's position on this issue is very clear: Such an offer should be made to Taiwan rather than to the United States, as would be Beijing's offer to build a military mutual-trust mechanism.
He dismissed the idea that China is more flexible now toward Taiwan, pointing out that Beijing hasn't stopped trying to win over Taiwan's diplomatic allies.
But he admitted that Beijing has been more creative in engaging Taiwan, citing its contacts with two of Taiwan's opposition parties as an example.
He also warned Taiwan to guard against China's trick of calling Taiwan a troublemaker while casting itself as a troubleshooter who bends over backwards to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Schriver suggested that Taiwan enhance its international profile by contributing generously to international relief operations and supporting the U.S. battle against terrorism rather than offering grants to other countries in exchange for their diplomatic recognition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ENERGY CONSUMPTION INCREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's domestic energy consumption was 25.96 million kiloliters of oil equivalent (KLOEs) in the first quarter of this year, up 2.5 percent from the previous year's level, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The industrial sector was the largest domestic energy consumer by sectors with 13.58 million KLOEs during the first three months of this year, up 1.5 percent year-on-year, while the residential sector posted the largest annual growth rate of 7 percent, the tallies showed.
Taiwan's domestic energy supply totaled 32.02 million KLOEs during the January to March period, down 0.3 percent from the figure recorded a year ago.
Of the total domestic energy supply, 98 percent was imported, DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIGIL HELD TO MARK 16TH ANNIVERSARY OF TIANANMEN MASSACRE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy organized a vigil and seminar Friday to mark the 16th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre in which Chinese troops crushed a pro-democracy demonstration in Beijing on June 4, 1989.

Addressing the seminar, Wang Dan, one of the leaders of the 1989 pro-democracy demonstration at Beijing's Tiananmen Square, who was forced into exile in the United States after having been jailed for several years in the wake of the massacre, said he hopes the June 4 tragedy can be portrayed in its real light.

"I also hope that the spirits of those who were killed in the notorious Tiananmen Massacre can find rest in heaven, and that China can move toward democratic reforms and permanent peace will prevail across the Taiwan Strait, " said Wang, who traveled from the United States to attend the seminar.
Wang said he believes that unless the names of the Tiananmen Massacre victims are cleared, China's democratization cannot get started.
"Only when China is democratized, can cross-strait peace be achieved," Wang added.
He also urged Taiwan people to continue supporting democratic development in China because "when your neighbors are not free, you can't enjoy real freedom."

DOC.HEADLINE: IAEE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE) conference will open in Taipei Saturday with more than 500 government officials and experts from 32 countries participating, the organizers of the event said Friday.
The theme of the meeting is "Globalization of Energy: Markets, Technology and Sustainability."

The meeting, which will run through June 6, will be chaired by Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, and Vice President Annette Lu will be invited to address the opening ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREEDOM OF PRESS MORE VALUABLE THAN NATIONAL SECURITY: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: Press freedoms are more valuable than national security, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday in a meeting with Arthur O. Sulzberger, Jr., the publisher of the New York Times.
The president said newspapers are politicians' mirrors, and while their stories might not always be palatable, politicians have to accept them humbly.
The more closely the media keeps its eye on politicians, and the more scathingly are the criticisms, the better work lawmakers do, Chen said.
When it comes to press freedoms, Chen said it is better to err on the side of accommodating them too much than too little.

Noting that the 16th anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre in which the Chinese military put down a student-led pro-democracy demonstration with force will fall on Saturday, the president said China's human record has not shown any improvement and this was proved by the European Union's recent decision to maintain its arms embargo against China.

Furthermore, the president said, the Beijing authorities arrested a New York Times' Beijing correspondent last September and a Singapore Straits Times' correspondent in April, both on the vague charge of espionage.

The president said he is pleased that Taiwan, along with the United States and other advanced countries, was considered to have good press freedoms and ranked 44th among 194 countries by the New York-based Liberty House in May, far ahead of China, which came in at 177th place.

The president said he himself was a publisher before he entered into politics and was known as a vociferous defender of the freedom of the press when he worked as a lawyer, but he paid dearly for his fight and had to spend eight months behind bars.
The president said the experience convinced him that press freedoms are more valuable than national security.
Sulzberger arrived in Taipei Thursday at the invitation of a local newspaper, the United Daily News, for a three-day visit. He is scheduled to leave on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP: LEADERS OF TAIWAN AND CHINA COULD MEET IN APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: When the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum holds its annual summit in Busan, South Korea in November it will be agood opportunity for President Chen Shui-bian to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao on the sidelines, Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

Echoing the president's claim the previous day that any meeting between himself and Hu should be held in a place other than China or Taiwan, Lu said Busan would be an ideal place, if Chen could take part in the APEC summit in person.

Because of China's reluctance to rub shoulders with Taiwan leaders, the Republic of China (ROC) president has in the past been forced to refrain from participating in the summit. The ROC has traditionally had a senior official attend the summit.

Besides, the vice president said, China still has to accept Chen's prerequisite for such a meeting, which is that the ROC is a sovereign state owned by its 23 million people who have the final say in deciding the country's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 4, or the 28th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the French coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with U.S. Gen. Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1982: U.S. Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
2000: An ROC Navy goodwill flotilla reaches the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles.
2001: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- kicks off at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting a record high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad to take part in the five-day event.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR CONTINUES TO ATTEND WED EVENTS DESPITE CHINA'S PROTEST
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 3 (CNA) (By C. Chiang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair said Friday that he will continue to participate in the United Nations' World Environment Day (WED) activities despite China's protest against his presence at the events.

Hsu, who is attending the June 1-5 WED activities in San Francisco at the head of a delegation from his city, made the remarks in response to a statement by the China consulate that representatives from Chinese cities will boycott the activities.
The statement said that Chinese city representatives will not attend WED activities since the host city has not dealt appropriately with matters regarding Taiwan city mayors' participation.
Seventeen mayors from China who were invited to participate decided to boycott the events because of the invitations extended by the organizers to Hsu and to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Yeh ching-chuan, the deputy mayor of Taipei City, is expected to represent Ma, who is currently vying for the chairmanship of the opposition Kuomintang.

Saying that he and his city delegation's presence at the event has nothing to do with politics, Hsu pointed out that environmental protection is a universal value and that it is his city's "outstanding performance" in the field that led to the invitation from the organizers, which include the United Nations and the Bureau of Environment of the City of San Francisco.
Commenting on China's protest, Hsu said it is not wise for China to do such things. "We just want to attend WED activities and exchange views with mayors from other countries, " he added.

Meanwhile, San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom expressed regret that mayors from both sides of the Taiwan Strait are unable to jointly attend the events and said the WED activities are issues among cities and that he has no authority to deal with affairs related to international relations.
WED, which falls on June 5 each year, is one of the principal vehicles through which the United Nations tries to raise global awareness of the environment and enhance political attention and action.
The theme of this year's WED is "Green cities, " and the slogan is "Plan for the Plant."
During the five-day activities, city leaders are expected to trade ideas on issues that will create a better environment. They will also sign a "Green cities Declaration" June 5.

Opposition political leaders call for President Lahoud, a Damascus ally, to resign.

The Japan Times: Don't visit Yasukuni:Nakasone to Koizumi
Former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, whose visit to Yasukuni Shrine two decades ago sparked huge Chinese protests, urged Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi on Friday to stop his annual trips there.
