DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA names 3 Monetary Board Members
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday named former Finance Secretary Juanita D. Amatong and two other government officials as new members of the Monetary Board, the policymaking body of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP).
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo: I feel your pain, too
Speaking yesterday in Tublay, Benguet, where she inaugurated new road and irrigation systems funded by the Japanese and Australian governments, Ms Arroyo again called on the people to bear the "pain" that would result from her administration's economic reforms. She said, "I feel pain when people feel pain."
The Philippine Star: GMA: Unpopular measures needed
President Arroyo reiterated yesterday her willingness to pay the political price for her "tough decisions to save the economy" from collapse as her popularity ratings slumped to a record low for any Philippine leader amid rising prices, higher taxes and an illegal gambling scandal hounding her family.
The Manila Times: House backs Con-con
The House of Representatives will support President Arroyo's renewed call to start initiatives for a Charter change through a constitutional convention next year, Speaker Jose de Venecia said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO RAISE REUSABLE ENERGY GENERATION RATIO TO 10% BY 2010

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that the government is planning to raise the ratio of reusable energy generation to 10 percent of total power generation by 2010.

Lu made the remarks while speaking at the opening ceremony of the 2005 International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE), which was attended by more than 500 government officials and experts from 32 countries.
It is the first time Taiwan has sponsored the international meeting, whose theme is "Globalization of Energy: Markets, Technology and Sustainability."
The meeting, to run through June 6, is chaired by Vincent Siew, chairman of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.
The vice president noted that the Kyoto Protocol went into effect Feb. 16 to regulate the emission of greenhouse gases.
Although Taiwan is not a signatory of the protocol, it has to address the issue seriously as one of the members of the global village, Lu said.
As Taiwan currently relies on imported fuel for up to 97 percent of its energy needs, the government's top energy strategy will be to develop reusable energy, she said.

To learn more about the effects on various sectors of the Kyoto Protocol and other environmental protection pacts, as well as to contribute more to international energy, Lu said a national energy conference will be held June 20-21.

The conference will be attended by business and environmental groups as well as think tanks and related government officials, who will discuss related strategies to deal with the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions for use as a reference by the government in the formulation of policy concerning cutting reliance on energy imports and promoting energy independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC APPROVES TAICHUNG MAYOR'S CHINA TRIP FOR UCLG MEETINGS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has approved Taichung Mayor Jason Hu's application to visit China for the United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG) World Council meetings, MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung confirmed Saturday.
You said the MAC has no reason to restrict the mayor's participation in an international event and believes that Hu, who is a former foreign minister, will behave with propriety while in China.

You said Hu is not the first local government chief to have obtained the government's permission to visit China, pointing out that then-Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien was permitted to go to China in 2000 to take part in a world technology conference held in Nanjing.

The UCLG World Council meetings are scheduled for June 8-10 in Beijing. Over 300 mayors and councilors will meet with representatives from the World Bank and the United Nations in a World Mayors Forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES FOR POLITICAL HARMONY IN ADDRESS AT NTU CAMPUS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that he hopes there will be a joint effort to push for harmonious interaction between the ruling and opposition parties.
Hsieh made the remarks while addressing a National Taiwan University (NTU) graduation ceremony. He was invited to be present as an alumnus of the school.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jing-pyng took part in the ceremony as father of an NTU graduate.

The premier said that NTU has cultivated numerous distinguished leaders and experts in a wide range of fields since its founding in 1928. Its alumni include former and incumbent presidents, Lee Teng-hui and Chen Shui-bian, as well as Vice President Annette Lu.
Even opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who also serves as the KMT vice chairman and is vying for the chairmanship, were NTU graduates, he noted.
"I think I should consider seeking the assistance of the NTU presidet or the NTU alumni association in resolving inter-party rifts in the future," Hsieh said.

He added, apparently jokingly, that since the legislative speaker's two children are NTU students, there is no reason for the two major government branches -- the Executive Yuan and Legislative Yuan -- not to get along with each other more harmoniously.
Hsieh graduated from the NTU department of law.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NUKES ASIA FORUM BEGINS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The "No Nuke Asia Forum 2005" continued Saturday in Taipei, with participants from around the world exchanging opinions on the development of renewable energy and the anti-nuclear campaigns in their countries.

The forum from June 2-8, organized by the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU) , has attracted representatives of environmental protection groups from Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia, India, Vietnam, Australia, Germany, Netherlands, Russia and the United States.
The participants visited several nuclear plants Friday and had talks with residents near the plants.

TEPU Chairman Shih Shin-min noted that the Cabinet convened a national energy conference in 1998, setting a goal that renewable energy should account for 1 percent to 3 percent of the country's total energy capacity. At that time, the government did not have the idea of promoting a nuclear-free country.
In 2003, the government began anti-nuclear campaigns, setting its new goal in which renewable energy should account for 10 percent of the total by 2010.
Expressing hope that the government can fulfill its promise, Shih complained that even the 10 percent goal will still lag behind that of advanced countries.

Citing the example of Denmark, which has efficiently developed renewable energy such as hydro, wind, geothermal and biomass power, Shih noted that the European country's renewable energy accounts for 40 percent of its total.

With the Kyoto Protocol taking effect in February, which aims to limit the global emission of greenhouse gases, the European Union hopes that renewable energy can account for 22 percent of each country's total by 2020.
However, Taiwan can only reach 12 percent goal by that time, Shih added.
According to Shih, Taiwan has been promoting hydro, wind, solar, geothermal and biomass power, but with low efficiency.
He urged the government and the people to show more concern for the environment and to focus on renewable energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LOOKS FORWARD TO CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian looks forward to dialogue and consultations between the leaders on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the president's chief of staff said Saturday.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, made the remarks while attending the opening ceremony of an agricultural product show at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
Asked whether the United States will play the role of a bridge in cross-strait dialogue, Yu said Taiwan has not discussed the matter with the United States.

Chen said Friday during a meeting with New York Times Chairman Arthur Sulzberger that the United States is probably the best bridge and platform for a historic meeting between the leaders on either side of the strait.

Yu noted that since Chen assumed office in 2000, he has continued to extend a series of olive branches to the other side of the strait, hoping for a cross-strait reconciliation to promote peace in the Asia-Pacific region.
Regrettably, Yu said, Beijing has failed to seize these opportunities over the past five years and Taiwan has yet to see China willing to come to the negotiating table.

Meanwhile, as the ad hoc National Assembly will vote on a constitutional amendment package June 7, Yu also said that if the National Assembly invites Chen to the conference, the president will attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS 64,000-PLUS VOLUNTEERS: MOI

TEXT.P: Taiwan had more than 64,000 volunteers in 2004, with women accounting for 70 percent, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Saturday.

Since the Volunteer Service Law was promulgated January 2001, the governments of all special municipalities, cities and counties around the country have been required to form social welfare volunteer service corps.
At the end of 2004, MOI officials said, there were 1,169 volunteer service corps, up 17.1 percent from the year-earlier level.
In terms of numbers, the service corps had a total of 64,822 volunteers, marking a 10.5 percent increase from the 2003 level.
On average, each volunteer worked 1.6 hours in two installments per week.

Female volunteers far outnumbered their male counterparts, 70 percent to 30 percent. In terms of education, graduates of senior high schools and vocational schools formed the bulk, accounting for 40 percent of the total.

By occupation, homemakers accounted for 30 percent of all formally registered volunteers, followed by those working in the commercial and industrial community with 24 percent and students at 16 percent.
By area, Kaohsiung County boasted the largest number of volunteers with more than 6,300, followed by Taichung City with 5,700 and Taipei City with 5,500.

However, Hualien County had the highest volunteer participation rate, with 88 volunteers out of every 10,000 residents. Nantou County came in second with 72 volunteers out of every 10,000 residents, followed by Penghu County with 61 volunteers per 10,000 residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-HU MEETING IN U.S. AN EXPECTATION OF ILLUSION: KMT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's wishes for a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao in the United States will not come true, a spokesman of opposition Kuomintang claimed Saturday.

The president said Friday that 2005 and 2006 might be another "window of opportunity" for holding cross-Taiwan Strait talks and that if both sides miss that opportunity they might have to await until 2008 or even after 2010 to hold negotiations. He expressed the hope that he and Hu's first contact can be made in a "third country" and said the United States would serve as the best bridge and platform for such contact.

But Chang, who is also director of the KMT's Department for Mainland Affairs, claimed while responding to media question that both Taipei and Beijing can create opportunities for resuming talks at any time. He further claimed that "nobody knows" why Chen chose 2005 and 2006 as the best time to hold talks with China.
"President Chen has said about 20 times that cross-strait leaders should hold talks, but to no avail, " he added.

Chen has said three times that he and Hu can meet with each other in a third place after KMT Chairman Lien Chan's China visit, and this time he clearly pointed to the United States as the place for his first contact with his Chinese counterpart, the spokesman said, claiming that Chen's purpose is to show that "he and the United States are bound together closely" rather than promoting a meeting with Hu.
At Hu's invitation, Lien visited China from April 26 to May 3.

The U.S. government is well aware of the Beijing government's policy and bottom line and will not help arrange Chen to meet with Hu in the United States, since they know such an arrangement would be rejected by China, Chang speculated.

Commenting on what he described as Chen's current "soft" attitude in dealing with cross-strait issues, the spokesman claimed it is society's hopes for better relations between the two sides of the strait since Lien's visit that has pressed the president to keep a low key.
He further speculated that Washington's stance of encouraging Chen to work on improving relations with Beijing is also a factor that has made the president keep a low profile.

He also claimed that fierce opposition by the fundamentalists in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union to a visit to China by Chen is behind the president's wish for a meeting in a third place.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SUPPORTS HIKE IN DEFENSE SPENDING TO 3% OF GDP

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker expressed his support Saturday for a proposal to increase the country's annual defense spending to 3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP).

Ho Min-hao, deputy convener of the TSU legislative caucus and a member of the legislature's National Defense Committee, pointed out that Taiwan's annual defense spending now accounts for 2.4 percent of GDP, which he said is lower than the 4-5 percent of Japan, the United States and European Union nations.
Ho said it is unreasonable that Taiwan is spending less on defense when it is facing the military threat from China.

By raising the ratio of defense spending, the government will be able to show the world its resolve to defend Taiwan and will facilitate the passage of its NT$480 billion (US$15.33 billion) arms procurement package from the United States, Ho said.

Objecting to the Cabinet's plan to finance the procurement by a special budget, lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) have proposed hiking the defense spending ratio in the hope that the arms procurement package can be accommodated in the government's annual budget.
Items in the package include a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and eight diesel-electric submarines.

The KMT and PFP, which between them enjoy a slim majority in the legislature, have blocked the special budget proposal for the procurement package for two legislative sessions, mainly because of disagreement with the Cabinet over the budgeting method and the amount of the procurement.

Concerned about the progress of the procurement, Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, has invited co-conveners and certain members of the legislature's National Defense Committee for a gathering June 9.
However, only Lee Wen-chung from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , one of the co-conveners, and committee member Shen Fa-hui, also from the DPP, have accepted the invitation so far.

Lu Shiow-yen, a co-convener from the KMT, said she will consult her supporters' opinions before deciding whether to attend, while Lin Yu-fang, a co-convener from the PFP, said he has turned down the invitation to "avoid causing any misunderstanding." He did not elaborate.
Ho from the TSU, meanwhile, said he will not attend the gathering because his party has already offered firm support for the arms procurement package.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO GIVE `MORAL SUPPORT' TO NA DELEGATES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will meet the party's National Assembly delegates Monday to give them moral support and demonstrate the party's determination to pursue constitutional reforms, according to Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's central policy coordination committee.
The presidium of the ad hoc National Assembly has decided to allow for representatives of each political party to explain their respective positions concerning constitutional amendments June 6.

On June 7, the assembly will vote on the package of constitutional amendment proposals passed by the legislature last August, which include reducing the number of seats in the legislature from 225 to 113, extending the tenure of legislators from three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.

Both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT are in favor of the package of amendment proposals. However, the package can only be approved if they are supported by three-quarters of the total delegates.

The DPP won the lion's share of the votes in the May 14 National Assembly election, gaining 42.52 percent of the ballots, or 127 out of the total 300 seats, while the KMT garnered 38.92 percent of the votes, or 117 seats. Three other pro-reform parties won another five seats.
Altogether, the pro-reform parties have gained 249 seats in the National Assembly.
The KMT will mobilize its senior officials June 7 to "supervise" the voting process of its party members to ensure that they vote along with party lines, Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOLD PRIMARIES IN TAIPEI, ILAN, CHANGHUA COUNTIES

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will hold party primaries in three counties, including the bitterly contested Taipei County, Sunday to choose its candidates for the year-end city and county chief elections.
The KMT's Organization and Development Committee said the party hopes to retain its present seats in the cities and counties, and aims to regain seats in Taipei, Nantou and Changhua counties.
As for southern Taiwan, which is a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the KMT is targeting Chiayi City and Kaohsiung County.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said that the three-stage candidate nomination operations are expected to be completed by June 22 at the earliest.

Under the party's nomination procedures, the party will first coordinate a party candidate, and if coordination fails to produce a candidate, then a primary will be held, which will include a vote by party members coupled with public opinion polls, with the former accounting for 30 percent and the latter accounting for 70 percent in an overall assessment.

In Taipei County, Legislator Chou Hsi-wei, who quit the People First Party to join the KMT in April to boost his chances of winning, Sanchung Mayor Lee Chien-lung, former Justice Minister Liao Cheng-hao and Taiwan Provincial Education Association Secretary-General Wang Ling-hwei are vying for the party's candidacy.

As Taipei County is considered a key battleground for the ruling and the opposition parties, and victory in the county will be crucial for the presidential election in 2008, the result of Sunday's primary is raising a high degree of concern.

In Ilan County, Ilan Mayor Lu Kuo-hua and Ilan County Speaker Chang Chien-jung are rivals, while in Changhua County, Deputy Speaker Hsiao Chin-tien and Legislator Cho Po-yuan are vying for the candidacy. After the party member vote, the KMT will also unveil the results of the public opinion polls.
Under the second-stage nomination procedures, Tainan City and Yunlin counties have no vote by members, but only public opinion polls.

Chen Jung-sheng, director of the KMT's Tainan chapter, emerged as the party candidate in Tainan City, while in Yunlin, four hopefuls -- Legislator Hsu Shu-po, County Council Speaker Chen Chin-hsiu, former deputy County Magistrate Chang Ching-liang, and Bureau of Public Works Director Chang Tsung-ming -- are competing for the candidacy.
Chang Ching-liang announced his decision to quit the party primary earlier in the day. He said however that he will definately run in the year-end election.
Incumbent Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin and Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Sheng-shan are poised to be nominated by the KMT again.
Once its candidates are decided by the end of the month, the KMT will begin a consultation process with its allies -- the People First Party and the New Party.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said the year-end elections are crucial to the political landscape, but with a "fair mechanism" and "cooperation among the allies," the party is confident of winning the support of the majority of people.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL FAIR KICKS OFF IN FRONT OF PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: An agricultural fair aimed at demonstrating Taiwan's premium agricultural products and the government's results in the promotion of agricultural upgrading, kicked off Saturday at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.

Yu Shyi-kun, the chief of staff to President Chen Shui-bian, and Council of Agriculture Minister Lee Chin-lung, jointly opened the fair and encouraged the public to visit the two-day open-air activity to give their support to Taiwan's agricultural development.
Addressing the opening, Yu, who was born in a rural village, said he has special feelings for agriculture and that he believes the sector is one of Taiwan's most valuable assets.

Since Chen assumed office five years ago, efforts have been made to push for agricultural upgrading and transformation. The government has been promoting agricultural research and development, assisting farmers and traders to create brand names to boost sales, and reducing the impact of Taiwan's market opening after joining the World Trade Organization, said Yu.

At the same time, it has also combined agricultural, cultural and artistic resources in an effort to lift the country's agriculture from the basic level of food supply to include tourism and leisure, he noted, adding his belief that some day, Taiwan's agriculture will enjoy stronger competitiveness than that of that industrial sector in global markets.

The fair has 275 booths divided into 11 districts, featuring themes including biotech, agricultural security, premium farm environment, disease control and quarantine, fishery, leisure-oriented agriculture, the tea industry and rice.
The activity is open from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Saturday and from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITATIONS BY EPA FOR PROMOTING ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) cited individuals and groups Saturday for promoting environmental protection.
Acting EPA Minister Tsai Ting-kui presided over the citation ceremony, held at the Sheraton Taipei hotel.
A total of 77 medals were awarded to individuals and groups for their longstanding efforts.

A group of the mentally challenged were awarded for making their living environment more pleasant by recycling discarded items, Tsai said, adding that a senior citizen aged 85 got a medal for his efforts to instil respect for the earth into young people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION RESUME SYSTEM NEW TREND: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's top aide said Saturday that the "production curriculum vitae" system is becoming a new trend in the international community and should be listed as one of the major administration policies.

Yu Shyi-kun made the remarks while addressing the opening ceremony of the two-day "Health Taiwan, Premium Agriculture" fair held by the Council of Agriculture at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.

Since more and more consumers around the globe pay close attention to food safety, ensuring that they have the right to know about the food they buy has become a key topic, Yu said. He noted that because of this, major economies such as the European Union, the United States, Canada and Japan have already made efforts to promote the so-called production resume system.

The system, an operating base for the traceability of foodstuffs, is widely taken as a key method in the management of foodstuff security, said the official, who was a farmer before embarking on a political career.
He suggested that the government should adopt the system in its efforts to promote "safe agriculture" and expand agricultural exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOW IS NOT OPPORTUNE TIME FOR CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT: U.S. ACADEMICS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 4 (CNA) (By Lee Chia-fei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Now is not an opportune time for the top leaders on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in dialogue, two noted U.S. think tank scholars said Friday.

Gary Schmitt, executive director of the Project for the New American Century, and Dan Blumenthal, a research fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, made the remarks while meeting with a group of Taiwan journalists.

Their comments came a day after President Chen Shui-bian said he would be willing to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao in a third country with no prerequisites and added that the United States could be a possible bridge or platform for such a cross-strait summit.

To the best of his understanding, Schmitt said, the U.S. administration will not get involved in concrete cross-strait affairs and instead looks forward to seeing direct engagements between the Taiwan and China governments.

Even though dialogue can help ease tension, Schmitt said Taiwan should be very cautious and prudent in dealing with China. From a long-term perspective, he said, Taiwan should wait until after China has engaged in political reform. Before that, he predicted, cross-strait dialogue will not achieve any major breakthroughs.
Blumenthal echoed Schmitt's view, saying that cross-strait talks, even high-level ones, can hardly achieve substantive results because of the different political systems on either side.

He further said it would be "tough and dangerous" if the United States were to get involved in a proposed cross-strait summit meeting. The pitfall could lie in the possibility that the United States would pressure Taiwan to compromise in the course of cross-strait dialogue in exchange for China's cooperation in other fields, Blumenthal said, adding that if such a scenario does happen, Taiwan could suffer setbacks.

No matter whether a cross-strait summit could become a reality, Blumenthal said, the United States must face up squarely to China's ever-growing military build-up. In addition to pushing China to dismantle its missiles targeting Taiwan, he said, the United States should also demand that China consider Chen's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait forge a military mutual trust mechanism.
Given the imbalance in the two sides' military strength, Blumenthal said the right time has yet to come for Taiwan to hold a summit meeting with China.
The Taiwan press group, headed by Mainland Affairs Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, is on a U.S. visit aimed at exploring major U.S. think tanks' views on the development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRONG TIME FOR MEETING BETWEEN CROSS-STRAIT LEADERS: ACTIVIST

TEXT.P: Exiled Chinese pro-democracy activist Wang Dan said Saturday in Taipei that the conditions are not right for a meeting between leaders from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Wang, who is visiting Taiwan from his home-in-exile in the United States, made the comment in a seminar held in Taipei about the democratic situation and development in Taiwan and China.

Wang was responding to remarks by President Chen Shui-bian Friday that he would like to have talks with China's President Hu Jintao in a "third country" without any preconditions, with the United States as possibly be the best bridge for such a meeting. Chen made the remarks at a meeting with New York Times Chairman Arthur Sulzberger, who is in Taiwan on a three-day visit.
The Chinese dissident said he is glad to see the goodwill shown by each side of the Taiwan Strait and that he can see Taiwan's eagerness to break the political impasse between the two sides.
However, he reminded Chen that the results of the proposed talks between Chen and Hu may result in uncertainty without any guarantee if China does not first implement full democracy.

Wang stressed that there is no mutual trust between the two sides of the strait and that with the huge differences in their political systems, he doubts whether the talks will lead to any concrete breakthrough in cross-strait ties.
"Even if they really talk, it will be just for show," Wang predicted.

Due to the lack of press freedom in China, the Chinese people do not have a full understanding of Taiwan, Wang said, stressing that China's democratization will absolutely be the crucial boost to cross-strait relations.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang said on another occasion that if the Chen administration still refuses to recognize the so-called "1992 consensus" between the two sides of the strait, he sees little chance of a Chen-Hu meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. INFORMED OF DETAILS OF CHINA VISITS BY TAIWAN'S OPPOSITION HEADS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 4 (CNA) (By C.F. Lee and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A representative of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) in the United States said Saturday that he has delivered "the most precise briefing" to Washington on details of the recent visits to China by the leaders of the two parties.
Jason Yuan made the remarks while receiving a group of Taiwanese journalists who are visiting the United States under the leadership of Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng.

Yuan said Washington has maintained close contact with the KMT and PFP since last December's legislative elections and such contact became even closer during last month's China visits by KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong.

According to Yuan, Washington approached his office for Lien's itinerary before Lien's departure for China, and after his return to Taiwan, Washington further requested details of Lien's meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao to serve as background material for U.S. President George W. Bush's May 5 phone talks with Hu.

Yuan said he briefed Washington officials on everything he knew, which includes that Lien and Hu discussed the issue of removing China's missiles targeting Taiwan but did not touch upon Taiwan's arms procurements from the United States.

On a joint letter addressed by 33 members of U.S. House of Representatives to Lien urging him to help expedite the passage of the budget for a NT$480 billion arms procurement package, Yuan said the letter has not been delivered to him yet.
Yuan said the move was not activated by the administrative branch and that he doubts if the letter represents the majority opinion of the U.S. Congress, which has a total of 535 members.

However, during a meeting with the visiting Taiwanese journalists, Gary Schmitt, executive director of the Project for the New American Century (PNAC) , a Washington-based think tank, said Washington is concerned about the delay of the arms procurement package by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan and that the joint letter by the 33 congressmen represents only this concern.

American Enterprise Institute (AEI) resident fellow Dan Blumenthal noted that the KMT used to support arms procurements from the United States when it was in power and he said it is ironic that the KMT has changed its attitude just because it is now in the opposition.

Blumenthal said it is only the KMT's hostility toward President Chen Shui-bian that has prompted the party to block the arms procurement package, which he said is not something a responsible opposition party would do.
Although the procurement will not immediately reverse the military imbalance across the Taiwan Strait, it will help deter a Chinese invasion of Taiwan, he said.
Meanwhile, on Chen's claim that Soong met secretly with Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, in the United States, Yuan described it as absolutely untrue.
Yuan said it was impossible for them to meet each other because Chen Yunlin left Washington, D.C. in early January, while Soong arrived there Jan. 15.

Chen has claimed that during his meeting with Chen Yunlin, Soong promised to oppose a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments in exchange for Beijing's approval for him to visit China.
Soong filed a defamation suit Friday against Chen over the allegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK FAILS TO PLAY INTERMEDIARY ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 4 (CNA) (By C.F. Lee and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has failed to play an intermediary role between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a scholar of a U.S. think tank said Friday.

Ellen Bork, deputy director of the Project for the New American Century, made the remarks when she met with Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, who is leading a group of journalists on a visit to the U.S.

Huang also called on two other think tanks -- the American Enterprise Institute (AEI) and the Cato Institute -- to exchange views with its researchers on such issues as Taiwan's proposed arms procurement from the United States, U.S. policy toward Taiwan and how to view the rising economic clout of China.

Bork noted that when Hong Kong was returned to China in 1997, China proposed a flexible approach of rule under the "one country, two systems," which the U.S. seemed to think might serve as an option for future cross-strait relations.
Due to China's lack of freedom and democracy, however, the democratic prospects of the former British colony under the formula have grown dimmer in recent years, she said.

The international community's aspiration that Hong Kong could play an intermediary role between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has fallen through and the experiment of "one country, two systems" in Hong Kong has proved it is not a feasible model.
After seeing what has happened in Hong Kong, the U.S. would change its views that the model could be applied to Taiwan, Borg predicted.
Dan Blumenthal, an AEI research fellow, said that the U.S. has grown impatient with China on such issues as North Korea and military modernization, and will probably adopt a harsher approach.
The U.S. hopes Taiwan will not take provocative action against China, but it also hopes that the nation will not give up its principles and bow to China's pressure, Blumenthal said.

Christopher Preble, director of Foreign Policy Studies of the Cato Institute, said the U.S. and China do not necessarily have to confront each other with the emergence of China's economic clout, adding that its impact on U.S. security interests is limited.
The focus should be on how to inject more economic freedom into China's system to prompt change and allow exchanges between the two countries moving toward stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT COMES BEFORE HIGH-TECH DEVELOPMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Saturday that the building of Taiwan into a "green silicon island" has the country's sustainable development as its basis.

Chen also said that "green" should take precedence over "silicon island" and that "if there is a conflict between the two, then I would rather choose green, as there is only one earth and only one Taiwan."

The president made the remarks when he received delegates to the 2005 International Association for Energy Economics (IAEE) , which kicked off a three-day meeting in Taipei earlier in the day, attracting more than 500 government officials and experts from 32 countries.
Chen also exchanged views with the delegates on such issues as energy policies, economic development and environmental protection.
The president said that amid rising global demands for energy, Taiwan will convene a national energy conference at the end of this month.

He noted that the Kyoto Protocol went into effect in February to regulate greenhouse gas emissions and said that although Taiwan is not a signatory of the protocol, it will nevertheless address the issue seriously as a member of the global village.

He said the upcoming energy conference will be attended by business and environmental groups as well as think tanks and related government officials, who will discuss related strategies to deal with the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions.
The president also expressed the hope that a more visionary energy policy can be formulated to underscore Taiwan's determination to work in line with the trends of international energy development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NOT SENT GROUP TO CHINA OVER PANDA GIFT: MAC

TEXT.P: The government has not sent any group to China to inquire about a proposed gift of pandas from Beijing as had been claimed by Chinese media, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said Saturday.
The officials were responding to Chinese media reports that a Taiwan group is conducting a fact-finding visit in Sichuan to pave the way for importing pandas from China.
The Chinese government said after opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan visited China in April that it would offer two pandas as gifts to Taiwan.

However, President Chen Shui-bian noted that pandas are protected by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) and that the issue should be handled prudently.

MAC officials said the government will be glad to see the pandas come to Taiwan if the procedures are in accordance with related international and domestic laws and there is somewhere in the country that is capable of taking care of the animals.
The officials stressed that the government is considering the issue purely from the conservation point of view and not from any other angles.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY STUDENTS MARK 16th ANNIVERSARY OF TIANANMEN MASSACRE

TEXT.P: A group of university students held a rally Saturday outside the National Taiwan University campus in Taipei City to mark the 16th anniversary of Beijing's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy activists in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

The activists of an inter-school organization called the "Ching Liu" democratic alliance urged the public to be more concerned about the Communist Party of China's (CPC's) persecution of dissidents and the lack of press freedom.

Holding placards reading "stop red terrorism from expanding," the students claimed that the CPC is the source of "worldwide conflicts" and said that only when the party vanishes will it be possible for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to have peace.
They urged all political parties in Taiwan to overcome their "blue and green" complexes and to form a joint frontline to block the CPC's "red" invasion.
The Ching Liu alliance was organized by students of universities including NTU, National Central University, National Yang Ming University and Soochow University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTENARIAN BUDDHIST MASTER DIES

TEXT.P: Respected Buddhist Master Yin Shun died at the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation's Jing Si Abode in the eastern county of Hualien Saturday at the age of 100.
Yin Shun, known as the pioneer of humanistic Buddhism, celebrated his 100th birthday in April. He was found dead early this morning.
His widely known disciple Master Cheng Yen said Yin Shun had inspired her to dedicate herself to glorifying Buddhism by serving the people.
Cheng Yen, founder of the Tzu Chi foundation which is Taiwan's largest charity organization, said it was a great blessing for her to be able to meet Yin Shun in her pursuit of Buddhist enlightenment.

With Yin Shun's inspiration, Cheng Yen said, the Tzu Chi foundation has managed to accomplish many projects in four major fields -- charity, medical service and health care, education and cultural development -- over the past four decades. She said she is more than grateful for her mentor's teaching.
The Tzu Chi foundation will organize a memorial service for Yin Shun later this month, a spokesman said.
Yin shun was born in Haining, Zhejiang province in China in 1906. He was determined to pursue Buddhahood in his adolescence after reading a Buddhist book. He became a monk at the age of 25.

After the Chinese Communists took control of the mainland, Yin Shun came to Taiwan to continue promoting humanistic Buddhism. He was one of the most prolific Buddhist monks of the modern world. He had written many books introducing Buddhist scriptures and teachings. Throughout his life he had also inspired numerous Buddhist followers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR VOWS NO CONTACTS WITH CHINESE OFFICIALS DURING BEIJING VISIT

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Saturday he will not have any contacts with Chinese officials in private during his upcoming visit to Beijing to attend an international conference.
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has approved Hu's application to visit China for the United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG) World Council meetings.
Hu said he is scheduled to leave for Beijing Tuesday as the UCLG meetings will kick off June 8.

"The main purpose of my attendance at the UCLG activities is to introduce Taichung's major industries, cultural development and tourist attractions, " said Hu, who once served as the Republic of China's minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States.

Hu ruled out the possibility of contacting Chinese officials in private during his stay in Beijing. As a city mayor, Hu said he will not touch on any political issues or topics related to the relations across the Taiwan Strait during his visit.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said earlier in the day that the MAC has no reason to ban Hu's participation in an international event like the UCLG meetings. You said Hu is not the first local government chief to have obtained the government's permission to visit China, pointing out that then-Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien was permitted to go to China in 2000 to take part in a world technology conference held in Nanjing.

The UCLG World Council meetings are scheduled for June 8-10 in Beijing. Over 300 mayors and city councilors will meet with representatives from the World Bank and the United Nations in a World Mayors Forum. The agenda will include how Asia-Pacific cities will cope with contingencies or crises and the status of city in the new millennium.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND INVESTMENT DECLINES: MOEA

TEXT.P: Direct inbound investment in Taiwan amounted to US$736 million in the first four months of this year, marking a 37.97 percent decline from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Saturday.

Ou Chia-jui, director of the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center, attributed the drop to a combination of factors, including changes in investment types and a global economic slowdown.

A comprehensive analysis of investment activities showed that during the four-month period, many foreign and overseas Taiwan companies adopted indirect investment methods, such as issuing ADR or GDR, to enter the local market, Ou said, adding that indirect investment figures were usually not included from the MOEA's direct inbound investment statistics.

Amid the current worldwide economic downturn, Ou said, corporate owners have become more cautious and conservative toward business expansion, leading to a decline in the inbound investment. Likewise, he said, Taiwan's outbound investment, including China-bound investment, also dropped in the January-April period.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRUS INFECTIONS UNDER CONTROL: DOH

TEXT.P: The current enterovirus outbreak, which has infected 50 children and claimed five lives, has been brought under control, Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mao said Saturday during an inspection tour in the central city of Taichung.

"Although the enterovirus infections are at a peak, the general situation has been well controlled, " Hou said after inspecting Taichung Veterans General Hospital to get a better understanding of the outbreak in the central Taiwan area.
An encouraging development was that none of the enterovirus strains have mutated significantly, Hou said.
As the outbreak is expected to peak in two week's time, Hou urged medical personnel and parents with young children to keep alert to prevent any further spread of the disease.

Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted via direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with contaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene is critical to preventing infections.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS SUPPORTS CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT AT THIRD PLACE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday it supports President Chen Shui-bian's proposal that the top leaders from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait hold a summit meeting in a third place.

DPP legislative whip William Lai was responding to Chen's remarks a day earlier that he would be willing to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao in a third country with no prerequisites and added that the United States could be a possible bridge or platform for such a cross-strait summit.

As cross-strait issues are closely related to Asia-Pacific regional security and peace, Lai said, they have been major international concerns. Therefore, he said, a cross-strait summit had better take place at a destination other than Taiwan and China.
Moreover, Lai said such an option can help avoid the thorny cross-strait dispute over Taiwan's sovereign status.

Responding to the main opposition Kuomintang's claim that a Chen-Hu summit meeting in the United States is just a pipe dream, Lai said the president's statement was mainly aimed at telling the world Taiwan's basic stance toward negotiations with China.

"President Chen was reiterating our stance on cross-strait talks. He was telling the world that Taiwan is willing to talk with China so long as the dialogue is conducted on an equal footing and with no premises and no preconditions. Chen's remarks can help prevent the international community from misunderstanding that Taiwan rejects China's offer for talks," Lai said.

Singapore has urged the United States to make more use of its 'soft power' to win over international opinion and build trust, especially in the Muslim world.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, June 5:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 5, or the 29th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1723: Adam Smith, the Scottish political economist and philosopher, is born. His "Wealth of Nations" was the foundation of classical free-market economic theory.
1883: British economist John Maynard Keynes is born. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces in China.
1945: The supreme commanders from the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union sign a statement in Berlin that divides Germany into four occupation zones under their respective controls.
1947: An Outer Mongolian cavalry battalion, aided by planes with Soviet insignia, attack Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang.
1947: U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall announces his plan to help Europe recover financially from the effects of World War II.
1963: King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand arrive in the Republic of China for a state visit.
1967: The Six-Day War, which lasts for 132 hours and 30 minutes, breaks out between Israel and the neighboring countries of Egypt, Jordan, and Syria.
1968: Five years after the assassination of his brother, President John Kennedy, Senator Robert Kennedy is shot in the head and shoulder and dies at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Greece.
1976: A joint communique pledging close cooperation between Lesotho and the ROC is issued as Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan ends a five-day visit to Taipei.
1976: Gen. Carlos Manuel Arana Osorio, former president of the Republic of Guatemala, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1988: Kay Cottee sails into Sydney harbor, becoming the first woman to sail nonstop around the world alone.
1989: The Solidarity party defeats the communists in the first free Polish elections since World War I.
1989: U.S. President George Bush suspends government sales and private military exports to mainland China to protest the Chinese army's crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui appoints Vice President Lien Chan to serve concurrently as ROC premier. The Cabinet is reshuffled three days later.
1999: Yugoslav and NATO officers meet in Macedonia to discuss the withdrawal of Serb forces from Kosovo.
2000: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew turns down an offer of a job as a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: Chen Poh-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says that in addition to financial aid, the Republic of China is to offer economic advice to its allies in the same way the United States helped the island some 50 years ago.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a wise and good man holds in awe. He holds in awe the Laws of God, persons in authority, and the words of wisdom of holy men. A fool, on the other hand, does not know that there are Laws of God; he, therefore, has no reverence for them; he is disrespectful to persons in authority, and condemns the words of wisdom of holy men."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Separation of war criminals 'will never happen': Yasukuni
Yasukuni Shrine will not separate Class-A war criminals from the ranks of Japan's war dead honored there, because the outcome of the Tokyo war crimes tribunal that convicted them remains controversial, officials from the Shinto shrine have said in a written statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP FAVORS SUB PURCHASE FROM U.S. BUT NOT AT CURRENT PRICE: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) is not opposed to the purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines from the United States, but the current price of US$1 billion each is exorbitant, PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang said Sunday.
Lin, a member of the Legislative Yuan National Defense Committee, said that India bought six submarines from France at a total cost of only US$2 billion.
He added that the price was particularly out of line since the U.S. shipbuilding industry is in a slump.
Opposition legislators have continued to block a bill on major arms procurements initiated by the Democratic Progressive Party administration and have threatened to cut the budget for the purchase.
The bill covers three items to be purchased from the United States -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Chinese Arms Threaten Asia, Rumsfeld Says. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said that
the rapid development of China's missile capabilities, air force and navy put Asia's military balance at risk and that the Pentagon believed Beijing's buildup had been far more extensive than its leaders had admitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Report Presses Easy Ways to Fix Airline Security.
Significant gaps in security at the United States airports could be curtailed even at a time of rising passenger traffic by quickly making a wide range of relatively modest changes in screening people and bags, a confidential report by the Department of Homeland Security has concluded. The proposed fine-tuning of airport security includes expanding the use of devices that can detect trace amounts of explosives and stationing more armed guards in secure areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLLEGE STUDENTS ON WORLD ENVIRONMENT DAY: WE WANT TO SURVIVE

TEXT.P: Chanting "No pollution! We want to survive!" a group of college and university students led a march in downtown Taipei hoping to enhance the public's attention to environmental issues Sunday on World Environment Day.

The students from National Taiwan University, Tung Hai University and other universities or colleges gathered at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, some of them naked from the waist up, to show their determination to protect Taiwan's environment.

Wu Hung-chun of Transworld Institute of Technology, wearing a banner reading "We want to survive! " on his bare chest, said more than 200 students were marching to arouse society's awareness of the importance of the government's environmental policy.

Wu and schoolmate Chang Chia-sheng, also shirtless, called on the people not to focus on their bodies. Instead, people should pay attention to environmental issues that have long been ignored, they said.
As the students marched toward the Presidential Office, members of the public joined them. They hoped the activity would draw 1,000 participants.

They appealed for "environmentally friendly policies, " "clean water sources, " "safe food and water, " "recyclable energy, " "primitive mountains and forests, " and "values fashioned through self-awareness."
World Environment Day is one of the principle vehicles through which the United Nations stimulates awareness of the environment and enhances political attention and action.

This year's World Environment Day theme is "Green Cities" with the slogan "Plan for the Planet." The United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) said World Environment Day is an event for the people, with colorful activities such as street rallies, bicycle parades, green concerts, essay and poster competitions in schools, tree planting, as well as recycling and clean-up campaigns.
The main international celebrations of World Environment Day 2005 will be held in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHOWS NO SIGNS OF STOPPING BULLYING TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: China's bullying of Taiwan in a present security meeting serves as a clear indication that the Chinese communist regime has never altered its hegemonic designs against Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Sunday.
Lu was referring to the Fourth Asian Security Conference being held in Singapore under the sponsorship by the U. S. - based International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS) since 2000.

He called it a hard evidence that the names of the participants from Taiwan, some academics, are listed at the end of the meeting's booklets which are very likely to be ignored by others and claimed that China has been using a two-pronged tactic in its dealings with Taiwan by repeatedly displaying goodwill to the island while seeking every means to suppress it.

Under a mounting pressure from China, it is increasingly difficult for Taiwan to send ranking officials to take part in the annual conference, sources said, pointing out that Taiwan was still able to dispatch ranking national security officials to the meeting in 2001.

U. S. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Saturday in the conference that China's authoritarian regime will hobble its booming economy and decrease its influence across the world should it hesitate to launch a political reform.
Rumsfeld also question China why dose it deploy hundreds of missiles aimed at Taiwan.
The IISS is an independent think tank focusing on research, discussions and studies on military strategy, arms control, regional security and conflict resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE:This is to replace item CEP0009.CHINA SHOWS NO SIGNS OF STOPPING BULLYING TAIWAN: MOFA
DOC.TEXT:
China was behind efforts to minimize the presence of delegates from Taiwan at a security conference in Singapore and shows that the Chinese communist regime has never altered its hegemonic designs against Taiwan, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Sunday.
Lu was referring to the Fourth Asian Security Conference being held in Singapore under the sponsorship by the U.S.-based International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS).
The names of the participants from Taiwan, some of whom are academics, were listed at the end of the meeting's booklets, a move that Lu claimed would likely result in the Taiwan representatives being ignored. He said this was a part of a two-faced strategy used by China whereby offers of goodwill are tendered while at the same time Beijing does all it can to suppress Taiwan's presence in the international community.
Under mounting pressure from China, it is increasingly difficult for Taiwan to send ranking officials to take part in the annual conference, sources said, pointing out that Taiwan was still able to dispatch ranking national security officials to the meeting in 2001.
U. S. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said Saturday at the conference that China's authoritarian regime will hobble its booming economy and decrease its influence across the world should it hesitate to launch political reforms.
Rumsfeld also questioned why China as to why it has hundreds of missiles aimed at Taiwan.
The IISS is an independent think tank focusing on research, discussions and studies on military strategy, arms control, regional security and conflict resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PUSH FOR CLEAN ENERGY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government will push for the development and application of clean, recycled energy to alleviate Taiwan's reliance on fossil fuels, 98 percent of which is imported from abroad, Bureau of Energy Chairman Yeh Hui-ching said Sunday.

The Executive Yuan plans to allocate NT$3 billion (US$96.77 million) each year beginning fiscal year 2006 to finance the research, development and application of clean, recycled energy, which includes solar power, biomass energy, wind power and marine energy, Yeh said.

Yeh made the remarks during a speech on energy policy at the opening of the Academic Workshop on Energy Economics Across the Taiwan Strait sponsored by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research.
Yeh said reducing reliance on imported fossil fuels is the only way to lessen the risks regarding import sources and price fluctuations.

Yeh said that as Taiwan's self-produced energy resources are scarce, the country's imports of fuels have increased noticeably over the past 20 years as the domestic economy has expanded, from 88.8 percent in 1984 to 97.9 percent in 2004.
In the same period, per capita electricity consumption also surged, from 2,595 kwh in 1984 to 9,131 kwh in 2004, marking an increase of 3.52 fold, Yeh said.

One of the reasons why Taiwan's energy consumption has increased over the past 20 years is probably because energy prices have been relatively lower than most of the other major economies in Asia, Yeh said, adding that the lack of economic incentives to encourage energy saving was another reason.

Pointing out that currently the country still lacks mandatory measures to reduce energy consumption while manufacturing industries requiring high amounts of energy remain the backbone of Taiwan's industrial sector, Yeh said the government and the private sector must work in concert to increase energy resources and promote conservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOSPEL'S 140-YEAR HISTORY IN TAIWAN PROOF OF GOD'S LOVE: REVEREND

TEXT.P: Christian priests introduced Western culture to Taiwan 140 years ago, contributing to Taiwan's modernization and proving that God loves Taiwan, a leading Presbyterian reverend said Sunday.

Rev. Lo Jung-kuang, secretary-general of Taiwan's Presbyterian Church, said in the face of moral deterioration and the dissolution of values, Christians should work harder to spread the Gospel as a means of averting Taiwan's moral crisis.
Lo was speaking at a service worshiping God for His grace to Taiwan over the past 140 years. The service was held simultaneously in six cities, including Taipei, Changhua, Kaohsiung and Hualien.
Taipei's service was held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall with more than 10,000 people participating, including former president Lee Teng-hui.

Lo said since Beijing took over Taipei's seat at the United Nations in 1971, Taiwan has become an international orphan. It was from that time on that the Presbyterian Church devoted itself to promoting Taiwan's democratization.
He called on church-goers to cooperate with civilian groups and the government to spread God's justice and build a relationship between Taiwan and China based on justice and peace.

In 1856, Scottish Dr. James L. Maxwell landed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, the first Western priest with medical skills to preach in Taiwan. He formally started his preaching career in Taiwan when he moved to Tainan on June 16.
Six years later, Canadian Rev. George Leslie Mackay arrived in Taiwan to open another chapter in Taiwan's Christian history. Both Maxwell and Mackay were Presbyterian priests.
There are now 1,218 Presbyterian churches across Taiwan, with 230,000 believers worshiping God in 16 languages.
