DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS OF CHINESE LANGUAGE TO GET BOOST WITH NEW WEB SITE

TEXT.P: Foreigners leaning Mandarin will have a new tool at their disposal soon when a new Web site opens with special tonal-recognition software to aid in pronunciation, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
According to a news release issued by the ministry's Department of Industrial Technology, the Web site will be set up by L Labs, Inc.
The automatic speech analysis system developed by L Labs can recognize and analyze the voices of those learning Chinese and report on whether or not their pronunciation is correct.

Building the Web site will cost between NT$8 million and NT$10 million ( US$255,918 to US$319,898) is expected to create after-market revenues of around NT$800 million (US$25.6 million) for Taiwan's publishers of Chinese- language study books, the department said.

With globalization and the emergence of China as an economic powerhouse, the department said Mandarin has become a popular second language for foreign students, not to mention the 1.3 billion people who use it as a native language. The Web site will help the country earn a leading position in the Chinese-language learning industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ASKS CHINA TO GIVE PEOPLE FREEDOMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 4 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of State called on China Saturday to give its people the ability to flourish by allowing them to think, speak, assemble and worship freely.
In a message on the 16th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square Massacre, the department said there are as many as 250 people still languishing in prison for Tiananmen-related activities.
"Sixteen years after the brutal and tragic events of Tiananmen Square, we still remember the many Chinese citizens killed, detained or missing in connection with the protests," the message said.
The State Department urged the Chinese government to fully account for the thousands killed, detained or missing in the massacre and to release those unjustly imprisoned in connection with it.
The message said the family members of the victims and other citizens who urge their government to undertake a reassessment of what happened June 4, 1989 should be free from harassment and detention.
"We continue to urge China to bring its human rights practices into conformity with international standards and law," the State Department said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LIGHT EARTHQUAKES JOLT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three moderate earthquakes hit Taiwan Sunday with the largest having a preliminary magnitude of 4.8 on the Richter scale, according to the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center.

The first quake occurred at 8: 33 a.m. and had a preliminary magnitude of 4.1. It was centered 3.2 kilometers east of a seismic station in Hualien City, eastern Taiwan, at a depth of 6.1 kilometers beneath the surface.
The temblor had an intensity of 4 in Jian and Hualien City and 1 in Nanao in the northeastern county of Ilan, officials of the center said.

The second earthquake hit one minute later and had a preliminary a magnitude of 4.3 with its epicenter 4.3 kilometers southwest of the Hualien City seismic station at a depth of 7.4 kilometers. It was felt with an intensity 5 of in Hualien City, 4 in Jian and 2 in Nanao.

The third quake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 4.8 on the Richter scale, came at 9: 16 a.m. with its epicenter located 14.8 kilometers southeast of the Gukeng seismic station in the central Taiwan county of Yunlin and was at a depth of 8.2 kilometers. It had an intensity of 4 in Touliu City; 2 in Changhua and Tainan counties; and 1 in Taichung, Miaoli, Hualien, Taitung and the outlying island county of Penghu.
There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 17-YEAR-OLD PRODIGY LEAVING FOR U.S. TO PURSUE PH.D.

TEXT.P: The 17-year-old prodigy from National Taiwan University (NTU) who became an NTU freshman at the age of 13 is scheduled to leave for the United States later this month to pursue a doctorate, education sources said Sunday.

Lin Chien-yi from Kaohsiung County, the youngest university freshman in memory in Taiwan, decided to pursue a Ph.D. from the Georgia Institute of Technology because he said that Georgia Tech has the graduate program that he likes the most. He has also been accepted by Stanford University, Texas University at Austin and Purdue University.

Lin graduated from NTU's Electrical Engineering Department at a commencement ceremony held in Taipei Saturday after studying at the "top choice" department for four years -- a long time for a whiz-kid who only spent seven years finishing his elementary through high school education, which usually takes at least 12 years.

Lin's classmates at the NTU Electrical Engineering Department did not consider him "childish" at all. On the contrary, all of his NTU friends said that Lin is more sophisticated than most of his university peers, at least mentally, despite his age.

Besides, according to his friends, Lin is an independent man who has seldom relied on his parents, both of them teachers at junior high schools in Kaohsiung, for their opinions or important decisions.
Lin, however, is just like every 17-year-old in Taiwan and is obsessed with video games in addition to his two other hobbies: playing the game "go" and sleeping.

Lin, one year shy of completing his three-year course at Tainan First Senior High School, was allowed to take the Joint University Entrance Examination, receiving a remarkable score of 451.7 and earning himself entrance to NTU's Electrical Engineering Department in July 2001, becoming the youngest university freshman in Taiwan in the island's 48-year history of the highly competitive joint university entrance examinations.
At that time, he said that the secret to his success in his studies was "preparing before class, concentrating during class and reviewing after class."

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES CHINA TO DESTROY MISSILES, HOLD PEACE TALKS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China should destroy its missiles aimed at Taiwan and open peace talks with the island as the first step toward a peaceful solution to cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmaker Lo Chih-ming said Sunday.

Lo, a caucus whip of the pro-independence TSU at the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks when answering questions from reporters after U. S. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said a day earlier in the Fourth Asian Security Conference held in Singapore that China's military expansion will not only hurt the interests of Taiwan and the United States, but it will also affect China's other trading partners in Asia.
In recent years, China has been building its military at a two-digit annual growth rate, Lo warned, adding that China is rising as a military power.

In the face of China's fast military buildup, Taiwan should ask the country to renounce its military threats against Taiwan by fully destroying its hundreds of missiles targeting the island, in an event to be observed by the United Nations or the United States to protect security and prosperity in the strait and the rest of the Asia-Pacific region.
The arms destruction precedence set up by the United States and the former Soviet Union can serve as a good example for Taiwan and China, he proposed.

Meanwhile, former President Lee Teng-hui, who is the spiritual leader of the TSU, advocated a new constitution for Taiwan, describing it as an urgent need for Taiwan in its efforts to become a truly independent, free and democratic nation.

The Republic of China, Taiwan's current formal designation, is a laggard name for the country and the international community, Lee said, claiming that the country must be renamed to effectively reach out to the world.
"Taiwan is the promised land from God for the people in Taiwan, and we should treasure this land and make it a nation ruled by justice and peace and full of joy," he said.
Lee issued the call during an activity held by the Presbyterian Church at the plaza of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei to mark the 140th anniversary of Christianity in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST FAMILY ATTENDS DAUGHTER'S GRADUATION CEREMONY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his family were all smiles when his daughter Chen Hsing-yu had the tassel moved from one side of her black cap to the other in a special ceremony marking her graduation from National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Clinical Dentistry Sunday.
Chen Hsing-yu, along with 41 others, completed their master's program. They were joined by 40 who finished their undergraduate studies and were awarded a bachelor's degree.

President Chen, his wife Wu Shu-jen, son-in-law Chao Chien-ming and two grandchildren sat in the front row as they witnessed Hsing-yu receiving a blessing from her professors. Chao videotaped the event.
The president and first lady left immediately after the ceremony without making any remarks.

The president later told an American visitor at the Presidential Office that his whole family was delighted, and his wife and he were especially pleased to see their child having grown up with her own academic achievement.

Chen Hsing-yu majored in dental palate correction, meeting course requirements in three years. Institute Director Lan Wan-hung said she was a hard-working student who loved to read. He said she had published a paper on palate correction and two more were on the way, all written in English.
"She certainly has had some pressure as we [NTU] do give students pressure. However, she surmounted all the difficulties," Lan said.

Chen Hsing-yu and her husband Chao held up their two young sons while being interviewed by the media. Asked about her future plans, she replied, "Haven't thought about that yet. Don't ask me this before any other question!"

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY TO ACT ON CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS ON MONDAY

TEXT.P: The National Assembly will gather to act on a package of constitutional amendments on Monday, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which control 244 out of the 300 seats between them, vowing to ensure that their representatives vote in favor of the amendments.

Beginning from 2 p.m. Monday, the National Assembly deputies will gather to receive a briefing from the presidium about the rules of order, following by a discussion in which representatives of various parties will give presentations of their parties' view on the amendments.

Chen Ta-chun, who is leader of the DPP National Assembly members, said these discussions are not provided for by law but it wouldn't go amiss to give the opponents of the amendments, mainly minor parties, an opportunity to air their grievances.

During the discussions, Chen said six deputies of his party will make a strong case for the amendments which will half the number of lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan, change the electoral system through which lawmakers are chosen, allow for a popular referendum on constitutional amendments, and do away with the National Assembly, which is tasked only with voting of the constitutional amendments.

Claiming that all these amendments were developed from the DPP's ideas over the past decades, Chen said the discussions will allow the opponents to vent their anger about the proposals and thereby prevent them from filibustering the vote the following day, which will be the highlight of the session.

In order to ensure that all 127 DPP deputies are present to vote for the amendments, Chen said that party authorities have booked a hotel near the venue to accommodate all of them on Monday and DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang will show up at the venue of the National Assembly Tuesday morning to see that party deputies have abided by the party's policy in casting their votes.
Any DPP deputies who fail to show up at the venue by 8: 50 a.m. Tuesday will be fired and replaced by alternate party candidates, Chen warned.
The KMT, which has 117 seats, will have its secretary-general, Lin Fong-cheng, see that every party deputies follows the party's line in voting Tuesday, said a KMT official.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which is the biggest party opposing the amendments, commanding 21 seats, said they won't filibuster to stop the vote since it would be useless to do so.
Chien Lin Whei-jun, the convener of the TSU deputies, said her party representatives will vote against the amendments and let the people judge which party is right on these issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT GRANTS SCHOLARSHIPS TO ABORIGINAL FEMALE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu granted scholarships Sunday to 15 aboriginal female students and encouraged them to continue to study hard and to become excellent professionals in the future.
In a ceremony held at the Presidential Office, Lu said that the scholarships, which she personally established, are aimed at stimulating aboriginal female students to develop their talents.

She expressed the hope that the scholarship winners will make good use of the money they earn to improve their studies and future professionalism and to become the pride of Taiwan's aboriginal peoples.

Lu also urged the scholarship winners to write her at least once every three months and to obtain a professional license through national examinations or achieve a particular achievement in their career by May 19, 2008, the eve of when she leaves office.

Cheng Chuan-ju, a student who is studying at the University of Washington for a Ph. D., thanked the vice president in representation of the scholarship winners for her attention and assistance extended to aboriginal peoples. She promised they would do their best in developing their careers as well as serving their tribes and the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP POISED TO VIE FOR CITY MAYORS, COUNTY HEADS IN PROMISING AREAS

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) will field candidates for December's city mayors and county magistrates elections in various constituencies where the party stands a good chance of winning, PFP lawmaker Lin Yu-fang said Sunday.

Lin made the comments during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency after he met PFP Chairman James Soong a day earlier for more than an hour to exchange opinions on various key political issues, including the party's future line.

Despite the fact that it is an undeniable fact that there is a big overlapping between the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in their public support base, Lin stressed that his party is set to put forth its own hopefuls in ares such as Keelung City and Nantou County. "The PFP will no longer bow to pressure from our ally, the KMT, this time," he claimed.

He also made it clear that the PFP will stand pat on its resolve to "walk its own way" to achieve its two major goals -- political reconciliation and ethnic harmony amid wide speculation over its future course -- continuing cooperating with the main opposition KMT or aligning with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) based on the Feb. 24 meeting between Soong and President Chen Shui-bian.

The KMT, the PFP and the New Party form the pro-unification "pan blue" alliance in a polarized political wrangle against the pro-independence "pan-green" camp of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

In the meantime, Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Organization Development Committee, said that the year-end elections for city mayors and county magistrates will be a race dominated by a competition between the "pan-blue" and the "pan-green" camps.

The KMT and the PFP must collaborate and field candidates jointly to win over the "pan-green" competitors. Liao said, adding that such a KMT-PFP cooperation must be across the board and not limited to just several constituencies.
However, Liao was skeptical of the PFP's stance and urged the PFP to clarify its party line to help lead to cooperation between the two parties.

Political observers said that the PFP will face a thorny issue as to the question of whether it should side with the KMT or the DPP, and predicted that the PFP will have to show its hole card as the elections approach or risk becoming an outcast.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECOLOGICAL RESOURCES LAGGING IN SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been doing fine in terms of reducing social and economic pressures, but this is not the case when it comes to dealing with pollution and managing its ecological resources, according to a government report released Sunday on World Environment Day.

"The 2004 Sustainable Development Indicators of Taiwan, " issued by the Cabinet's National Sustainable Development Commission, tracked the nation's performance in six areas and found that it can take pride in only two -- institutional response and urban development.

The indicators show the country has done poorly in preventing or tackling pollution, as well as in the management of ecological resources. To improve the situation, the government has enacted a land rehabilitation law, the report noted.

It urged the nation to pay special attention to several issues that have been "worsening fast, " including carbon dioxide emission, arable land, cancer death rate, passenger car ownership in urban areas, and the share of high energy-consuming industry output in the total production of manufacturing industry.

Yeh Chun-jung, chief executive officer of the commission, said Taiwan is one of the few countries releasing such reports in response to a United Nations request. Even the United States has not released its sustainable development indicators.
The indicators are good for "comparing with ourselves, " he said, adding that the report serves as a data bank for reviewing government policies and shows "where we should be going," he said.
This was the second yearly report, which also aims to invite public interest and participation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCHERS DEMAND STOP TO ENDLESS GROWTH & DEVELOPMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 environmentalists, including 30-odd foreigners, marched in downtown Taipei Sunday as part of an World Environment Day campaign calling for an immediate stop to the endless economic growth and development policy.

The activity culminated when all the marchers lied down on the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, chanting "We want to survive! " and demanding the government to take environmental protection seriously and to stop all inappropriate development projects.

Chen Shu-hua, president of Taiwan Environmental Protection Federation and one of the organizers, said the participants were "environmental refugees" from across the country who did not oppose economic development per se but wanted the government to realize that too many ill-advised development projects and destructions of land resources are making it increasingly difficult for people to survive.

A Canadian artist, dressed in traditional Chinese dresses and wearing wooden slippers, said Taiwan's environmental degradation is much more serious than many other countries, and yet the people do not seem to care very much.

A Scottish woman who was working as a volunteer in Taiwan warned that Taiwan was getting close to ecological collapse and running out of natural resources. She called on the people to stop wasting and unnecessary shopping.

The marchers appealed for "environmentally friendly policies, " "clean water sources, " "safe food and water, " "recyclable energy, " "primitive mountains and forests, " and "values fashioned through self-awareness."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 6, or the 30th day of the fouth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
2001: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County is quarantined after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis the previous day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR CALLS FOR INCREASED CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 5 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) said Sunday that only by maintaining the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and increasing cross-strait bilateral exchanges can Taiwan and China solve their differences peacefully.

Addressing the annual meeting of the Asia Society in a keynote speech entitled "A Rising China," Feinstein said that China's rapidly expanding military strength and the Democratic Progressive Party's taking power in Taiwan have impacted cross-Taiwan Strait stability.

Feinstein said that China has accelerated its arms build-up in recent years, with its reported military spending rising by 16 percent over the past two years. She added that the actual figure could be three times higher. She also pointed to the some 700 Chinese missiles targeting Taiwan. Feinstein said that all this is upsetting the delicate balance that has been in place in the Taiwan Strait for decades.
In Taiwan, meanwhile, landmark visits to China by opposition leaders Lien Chan and James Soong have left President Chen Shui-bian little option to avoid the "China issue," Feinstein said.

Noting that time is on China's side, Feinstein claimed that China will soon gain the upper hand in military and economic influence across the Taiwan Strait. In light of this, she added, Washington should continue its "status quo" policy in the Taiwan Strait while at the same time intensifying communications with both China and Taiwan to prevent any undesirable situation from occurring.
Feinstein said that China is expected to have huge influence in Asia in the future, and the United States has monitored related developments closely.

She called for Washington to pay equally close attention to Asia as it does to Europe, saying that the United States should establish a U.S.-China crisis management mechanism to enable the United States to effectively handle any crises that might arise.
Feinstein said that the United States should increase high-level military visits with China to reduce misunderstanding and as a way to help solve cross-strait issues peacefully.

She also said she foresees increasingly closer exchanges between China and Taiwan in the commercial and cultural sectors in the years to come and that China's booming economy will help push for democratization within the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOUNDATION DENIES REPORT OF CONTROLLING 'BEIJING SPRING'

TEXT.P: An official of the government-funded Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD) denied over the weekend a report that the foundation has financed a journal launched by Chinese democracy activists overseas in exchange for their support for Taiwan independence.

According to the report published by a Beijing-based newspaper on Friday, the Beijing Spring monthly receives a US$50,000 subsidy fund per year from the Taiwan foundation under a contract established between the two sides.

The report claimed that under this arrangement, members of the journal's editorial committee are assigned by Taiwan's National Security Bureau, and any personnel adjustments require the bureau's approval.
Chou Yi-cheng, an official with the TFD, dismissed the report as unfactual.

Chou said that the foundation did subsidize Beijing Spring last year but that it has not done so this year, noting that the journal has also sought donations from other organizations including the U.S-based National Endowment for Democracy.
He said it is impossible that Taiwan will be allowed to dominate the editorial committee of the journal, which is run by a number of heavyweight Chinese intellectuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO EXPLAIN OPPOSITION TO PROPOSED CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the mission-oriented National Assembly said Monday that it will explain clearly why it is determined to vote against the proposed package of amendments to the Constitution in the upcoming NA general session later in the day.

NA deputies are gathering Monday afternoon to act on the Legislative Yuan-approved constitutional amendment package. They will first receive a briefing from the presidium about the procedual rules, and then start a discussion in which representatives of the various parties and groups will give presentations of their views and positions on the reform package.

Chien-Lin Whei-jun, the convener of the TSU caucus in the National Assembly; Chen Wen-kuei, secretary general of the caucus; and Chen Yi-shen, the spokesman for the caucus, will represent the party in speaking at the gathering.
The TSU, the biggest party opposing the amendments, commands only 21 seats in the 300-seat ad hoc National Assembly whose only mission is to vote on the constitutional amendment package.

The amendment proposals include reducing the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan from the current 225 to 113, extending the tenure of legislators from the present three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.

Pointing out that the National Assembly is obligated to vote on the package of the proposed amendments as a whole instead of item by item, Chien said that while presenting the party's view in the upcoming discussion, they will try to make clear how unreasonable they feel this is.

She and the other two TSU representatives will make clear the party's consistent opposition to the constitutional reforms and explain why the proposed "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system will damage Taiwan's democracy.
She stressed that her party's representatives will vote against the amendments and let the people judge which party is right on these issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIVERSIFICATION HELPS TFT-LCD INDUSTRY FLOURISH FURTHER: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's TFT-LCD industry's production line diversification policy is moving in the right direction amid cut-throat international competition and should make operations more profitable, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.

Noting that Taiwan cannot afford to repeatedly go down the road of " dominating the world market but making no money, " Ho said diversifying production variety and marketing will not only help Taiwan's TFT-LCD industry survive global competition, it will also sharpen the industry's competitiveness on the world market.
Ho made the remarks while addressing the 2005 Flat Panel Display Prototype Technology Awards sponsored by the Industrial Technology and Research Institute.

Companies that received an award included Chunghwa Picture Tubes, Toppoly FPD, AU Optronics, Chi Mei Optoelectronics and Ritdisplay Tech for outstanding business operations or technological developments.

Products and technologies that were cited at the ceremony included OLED, LCoS, wide-angle view and low color shift technology, active matrix full color OLED display, and low temperature poly silicon technology.

Takeyasu Murayama, head consultant to the Japanese-invested Asahi Glass Fine Techno Taiwan, which was cited as a role model in cross-border joint-ventures, said that Taiwan's development of LCD technology and production has been amazing.

According to Murayama, Taiwan industry's consumption of LCD glass panels exceeded that of South Korea last year to become the world's largest in this field and similar usage is expected to grow further this year.

The following two or three years will be crucial to find out whether Taiwan will remain the world's No. 1 LCD country with severe competition from South Korea, Murayama added. According to tallies compiled by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan's output of TFT-LCDs and related products totaled NT$715 billion (US$23.06 billion) last year and the figure is expected to exceed the NT$1.37 trillion mark in 2006.

Ho estimated that Taiwan's production of TFT-LCDs and related products will exceed NT$1 trillion this year with research and development as well as manufacturing operations in these companies continuing to flourish.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PUSH FOR SECOND PHASE OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will push for a second phase of constitutional reforms after the first stage of reforms is accomplished, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Monday.

According to Su, the next phase of constitutional reforms will be aimed at creating a "timely, relevant and viable" constitution that will enhance the country's efficiency as President Chen Shui-bian has promised.

Su said the president will invite representatives of various political parties and sectors to join a constitutional reform committee to discuss reform issues such as government efficiency, human rights and labor rights protection as well as the inclusion of a special chapter on the well-being of aboriginal citizens in the Constitution.
Su made the remarks during a meeting of the DPP's National Assembly caucus.
The National Assembly is scheduled to vote Tuesday on a constitutional amendment package adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August.

Major items in the package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.

A three-quarters majority vote is required for the passage of any amendments. The DPP and the opposition Kuomintang, which are in favor of the package, together control 80 percent of the seats in the National Assembly.

William C.T. Lai, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said the second phase of constitutional reforms will not involve controversial issues such as changes to the country's sovereignty, territorial boundaries or official designation.

The constitutional reform committee will seek a national consensus on the reforms to smooth their passage, which requires the endorsement of at least three-quarters of legislators and over 50 percent of eligible voters in a popular referendum, Lai said.

While the existing Constitution, which was enacted decades ago in China, provides insufficient human rights protection, improvements are also required in the Constitution in terms of the country's political system, which is neither a presidential system nor a parliamentary system, he pointed out.

However, opposition People First Party Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, who also serves as director of the party's Policy Research Center, said he does not see any possibility or necessity to carry out a second stage of constitutional reforms in light of the inter-party differences over the current proposed reforms.

Chang said the current proposed constitutional reforms were adopted by the Legislative Yuan without adequate discussion in society, adding that it is very unreasonable that the National Assembly, whose delegates were determined in an election that saw a voter turnout rate of only 23 percent, has the power to amend the Constitution.
On the constitutional reform committee proposed by President Chen, Chang said the president has no power to form such a committee because he is not empowered to amend the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR REGISTERS FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou registered Monday to run in the Kuomintang's (KMT's) chairmanship election set for July 16.

Accompanied by Taipei City Council spokeswoman Pearl Wu Bi-chu and KMT Legislator Chen Chieh, Ma, currently a vice chairman of the main opposition party, completed the registration at the KMT headquarters after presenting an endorsement signed by more than 82,000 KMT members, far more than the required 32,000 signatures, and relevant documents.

Ma expressed the hope that the chairmanship election will be a "gentlemen's race" between himself and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, another KMT vice chairman who is also keen for the party's top post through a direct vote among party members.
No matter who wins, party unity must be maintained following the race, he stressed.
Wang has yet to complete his registration with the KMT to take part in the race.
Incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan is slated to step down from the post in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: TINY HAKKA VILLAGE BLESSED WITH 67 COUPLES WITH 60 YEARS OF MARRIAGE

TEXT.P: The tiny, serene Hakka rural township of Hengshan in Hsinchu County seems to have Cupid's blessing as 67 couples living there have celebrated their diamond wedding anniversary, photographer Chen Yu-shu said Monday.

Compared with Hsinchu City, where there are only 20-odd couples out of a population of 380,000 who have been married for over 60 years, the Hengshan rural township boasts of 67 such couples out of a population of 14,000, Chen said. Chen has spent six months in rural areas around Hsinchu as an artist-in-residence.
The Hakka seniors are intriguing and they made superb models, Chen said.
Chen has been photographing around the rural areas for the Hsinchu Railway Art Village and he found the Hengshan seniors the most adorable, particularly with vintage railway systems as backgrounds.

Although Hengshan is located only about 40 minutes' drive away from Hsinchu City, many of the seniors have not visited "the town" for one or two decades. "They apparently are happy with their lives and environment," Chen said.
One couple was asked whether they quarreled during their extraordinarily long marriage, and even their answers were an identical, "No. "
Chen's photographs are currently on display at the Hsinchu Railway Art Village located in Hsinchu City. The same collection of pictures will be exhibited in Hengshan Aug. 2-21.

The 10 commissioners will present a letter within days to Andrew H. Card Jr., President Bush's chief of staff, asking the White House to allow the group to gather detailed information from the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Pentagon, the State Department and other agencies about the government's recent performance in dealing with terrorist threats.
Wall Street Journal: Promotion Track Fades for Those Starting at Bottom
Outsourcing and aggressive outside hiring have made many enterprises more efficient and profitable. But these trends raise the risk of workers in low-wage jobs getting trapped there. Annette Bernhardt, a sociologist at New York University Law School, studied the salaries of thousands of workers over nearly 40 years. She found that 12 percent of workers who started in the labor market in the late 1960s and early 1970s remained stuck in low-wage jobs 10 to 15 years into their careers. But for workers who entered the labor market in the 1980s and early 1990s, that percentage had more than doubled, to 28 percent. African-Americans have extra difficulty making it out of poverty, according to a 2003 study by American University economist Tom Hertz.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON WARNS AGAINST CHINA'S MILITARY BUILDUP: JAPANESE DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States is increasingly growing uneasy with China's military buildup, with the Pentagon positioning it as one of the worst threats together with international terrorism in an annual assessment, the Sankei Shimbun reported Monday.

In a report datelined Washington, the Japanese daily newspaper said that in its annual assessment of China's military capabilities that will be published soon, the Pentagon lists China's fast military expansion and international terrorist attacks as being on the same level under "worst threats."

According to the report, the Pentagon made the assessment based on the following arguments: China increased the number of short-range missiles aimed at Taiwan in the Nanjing military region, purchased more advanced jet fighters from Russia, deployed a larger number of fast-response troops to deal with contingencies in the Taiwan Strait, and stepped up military drills to counter U. S. military planes and ballistic missiles.

China's military capabilities are expanding at a rate that exceeds the tolerance of the U. S., the report said, adding that U. S. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld told a group of U. S. reporters June 1 that it is imperative to pay close attention to China's military buildup.

Rumsfeld said that the Pentagon's annual assessment of China's capabilities shows that China is spending more than its leaders acknowledge, expanding its missile capabilities and developing advanced military technology, according to an Associated Press (AP) report June 4.
The AP story quoted Rumsfeld as saying that China now has the world's third-largest military budget, behind the U. S. and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE, PARITY BEDROCK FOR CROSS-STRAIT ENGAGEMENTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that peace and parity are Taiwan's top guidelines for promoting engagements across the Taiwan Strait.
Hsieh made the remarks while meeting with Tadashi Ikeda, who as head of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) is Japan's de facto ambassador to Taiwan.

"Our basic attitude toward China has been that cross-strait issues should be dealt with in accordance with the principles of peace and parity, " Hsieh said, adding that Taiwan is more than willing to promote peaceful cross-strait engagements under the premise that Taiwan's present status quo is maintained and its independent sovereign status remains intact.

The premier further said the so-called "China fever" in Taiwan fueled by media reports about two opposition leaders' controversial visits to China was short-lived as proved by the results of the May 14 National Assembly election.

In his view, Hsieh said, China's invitations to Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong were part of its efforts to draw attention away from the backlash that China's anti-secession law created in Taiwan.

This strategy has proved to be ineffective in swaying Taiwan people's determination to safeguard their democratic way of life and Taiwan's separate identity since the KMT and the PFP failed to do well in the National Assembly election held after their leaders' high-profile China visits, Hsieh said.
Hsieh further said he hopes China's rise as a world power can be peaceful and democratic. Otherwise, he said, its emergence could pose a threat to the world.
Noting that both Taiwan and Japan are liberal democracies, Hsieh said he is hopeful that the two countries can strengthen cooperation based on their shared values of peace, democracy and rule of law.

Hsieh said he is pleased to see Japan offer visa-free privileges to prospective Taiwan visitors during the ongoing world exposition in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi, which will last through September this year.
"I'm hopeful that the visa-free privileges for Taiwan citizens can become permanent, " said Hsieh, who has a master's degree in law from Japan's Kyodo University.
Japan has been the biggest source of foreign tourists to Taiwan. Hsieh said Taiwan expects to attract one million Japanese visitors this year.
For his part, Ikeda, a retired career diplomat, said he will do his utmost to promote bilateral exchanges and cooperation in various fields during his tenure.
Ikeda used to be Japanese ambassador to Holland and Brazil. He also once served as chief of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs's Asian Affairs Bureau and the ministry's secretary-general.
JIA is a quasi-official body authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP LAWMAKER GRANTED PAROLE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice on Monday paroled former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chou Po-lun, who was jailed in 2003 for corruption.
Vice Minister of Justice Tang Chin-chuan said the ministry believes Chou has repented his crime and that the likelihood is low that he will commit the same crime again.

Tang pointed out that Chou has served 46.1 percent of his jail time and that over the past five years, most people convicted of corruption in Taiwan have been granted parole after serving 43.1 to 48.7 percent of their terms.

Chou was convicted of corruption by the Supreme Court on Jan. 29, 2003 for accepting bribes from the contractor of Taipei's Junghsing Park development project during his term as a Taipei City councilor in 1988.

The lawmaker was sentenced to six years in prison and was deprived of his civil rights for four years. His prison term was to have run from Feb. 17, 2003 to Oct. 26, 2008 after deducting 82 days during which he was kept in custody by the court, according to the ministry.
He was also sentenced to five months for obstruction of official duties in the same case, but the term was converted into a fine and paid.
Chou first petitioned for parole in December 2004 but was turned down by the ministry in January this year.

According to Tang, although Chou had one violation last year while incarcerated, he received two credits this year for his active participation in community service and the arrangement of a Lunar New Year party for prison inmates.
Tang said it is still uncertain if Chou can be released before the Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on June 11 this year, because authorities still need some time to process the paperwork.

District prosecutors in eastern Hualien County, where Chou is imprisoned, need to report the case to the Hualien District Court for parole supervision arrangements, Tang noted, adding that the processing time usually takes 10 days to one month.

The Moscow Times: Putin Dresses Down Chubais.
President Vladimir Putin on Saturday gave Anatoly Chubais a public dressing down over last month's power outage, accused Unified Energy Systems management of incompetence, and called for an investigation into the electricity monopoly's tax payments and spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEPERS RESISTING RELOCATION TO NEWER FACILITY PETITION HEALTH DEPT.

TEXT.P: A group of leprosy patients petitioned the Department of Health Monday not to evict them from the sanatorium they call home even though officials say that they will be relocated to a newer and medically more sophisticated facility.

The lepers and a number of their supporters say that the 75-year-old Leseng Sanatorium in Hsinchuang, Taipei County is the best place for the patients to live and that the health department has forsaken them to make way for construction of part of the Hsinchuang mass rapid transit system.

Health officials say that other departments were instrumental in deciding the fate of the Leseng Sanatorium, but added that the new facility, located nearby, will be more modern and can provide the more than 300 leper patients with up-to-date treatments and facilities.

However, the Leseng residents dispute this, claiming that it was the health department that turned over the matter to the Taipei Department of Rapid Transit Systems, which will demolish the buildings next month.

Activists of a youth organization for Leseng patients' rights said that under the Executive Yuan's newly revised regulations governing the implementation of the Cultural Heritage Preservation Law, the Leseng Sanatorium should be an historic site which is protected. They say that the authorities are reluctant to put the regulations into effect because they want to clear the way for the MRT project.

Representatives of the lepers petitioned the health department many times in May, asking the government to refurbish the old facility to allow its occupants to stay where they feel is home. The health department maintains that it is only trying to give the patients the best possible treatment.

Lending support to the lepers' cause, a Japanese activist said that if the Taiwan government does not care about the Leseng lepers' rights, he will try to bring the issue to the attention of the international community by publishing articles and reporting the situation to Japanese representatives who assist the United Nations Human Rights Commission in its survey on lepers' human rights around the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONVENE OR NOT, N.A. DELEGATES TO BE PAID FOR FULL SESSION

TEXT.P: Delegates to the National Assembly will be paid for as long as the session lasts, even on days that no meetings are scheduled, Yeh Junn-rong, secretary-general of the National Assembly, said Monday.
Yeh said that the session has been defined as starting on May 30 and will end when the assembly votes on the constitutional amendment package on June 7.
He said that according to the law governing the operations of the National Assembly, delegates will be paid for each of the nine days even if the assembly was in recess.
As of June 6, the delegates had only met twice. Delegates will receive a transportation allowance and unconfirmed reports have said that they will be paid NT$7,000 (US$220.8) in total for each day.

Yeh stressed that the National Assembly has shortened its session from the original plan of one month, and the public should focus more on whether the delegates have carried out their duties in voting on the constitutional amendment package and not just dwell on how much the delegates are making from the assembly.

However, the public will have nothing to speculate about regarding the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) since its National Assembly leaders passed a resolution Monday stating that DPP participants in the assembly will not accept payment for simply doing their duty

Chen Ta-chun, DPP caucus whip, said that some media reports have alleged that some delegates are trying to line their pockets by taking part in the assembly and the DPP wants nothing to do with this sort of thing; therefore, it will be requesting that an auditing team publish the details of pay and stipends to assuage any public misgivings.

The National Assembly convened at 2 p.m. Monday and after a report on the convening procedures, various political parties and groups sent representatives to explain their stances on the constitutional amendments, and the DPP, which has the most seats at 127 out of 300, decided not to deliver a report to save time, although it will respect the wishes of minor political parties or groups who want to elaborate on their stances.

The mission of the convening delegates will be to vote on such constitutional amendment proposals as reducing the 225 seats in the legislature to 113, extending the tenure of legislators from the current three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: N.A. DELEGATE DRIVES POINT HOME BY ATTENDING SESSION ON A CRANE

TEXT.P: Trying to drive home his opposition to the package of constitutional amendments, one National Assembly delegate came to Monday's session behind the wheel of a crane.

Yen Kun-chuan, a delegate of the 150-person union led by Zhang Ya-jhung, drove the vehicle with professors Zhang and Hsieh Ta-ning as well as eight volunteers of the union to Chungshan Hall in Yangmingshan.

The crane was adorned with banners that read: "Halve the number of legislative seats and the underprivileged groups will go under, " "The dominance of the big parties bodes ill for the people, " and "Reckless constitutional amendments and counter-democracy."
Police on the scene finally convinced the protesters to hand over the banners after they were displayed in front of the Chungshan Hall for some time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO CONTINUE CAMPAIGN AGAINST PIRACY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday his administration will continue its all-out campaign against commercial piracy even though the country has registered the world's fastest rates in lowering music and software piracy.

Chen made the pledge while meeting with executives of a local copyright owner association and organizers of a just-concluded pop concert aimed at raising public awareness of the importance of intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.
Thanks to concerted efforts of relevant government agencies, Chen said, Taiwan's commercial piracy rates have declined significantly over the past year.

Among others, Taiwan's videogame software piracy rate dropped to 42 percent last year from a high of 56 percent in 2002. The music recording piracy rate fell to 42 percent from 47 percent in 2002 and commercial software piracy rate declined to 43 percent from 53 percent.

"All these rates were the world's fastest. In recognition of our anti-piracy achievements, the United States has removed Taiwan from its Special 301 'priority watch' list of countries for copyright violation monitoring and instead included Taiwan on the less serious 'watch' list this year," Chen said.
He added that the government will not be complacent about the accomplishments and will continue stepping up the crackdown on commercial piracy.

During this era of knowledge-based economy, Chen said, knowledge has replaced commodities as the most important niche for economic development and creativity has replaced efficiency as the key to industrial upgrading.
Against this backdrop, Chen went on, IPR protection is no longer just a commercial issue but rather a pivotal event crucial to overall national competitiveness.
As a member of the Global Village, Chen added, Taiwan is obligated to boost IPR protection and fight piracy. He urged the public not to buy, sell or produce pirated products.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, DPP SET FOR TAIPEI COUNTRY MAGISTRATE SHOWDOWN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chou Hsi-wei will face a showdown against Lou Wen-jia, the candidate nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , in the race for Taipei county magistrate in December's city mayor and county magistrate elections.
Chou gained the candidacy after beating three other contesters in the party primary Sunday.

Although Chou won the support of the largest number of KMT members, observers predicted that he will have to first overcome difficulties in forging unity within the party and mending differences with the People First Party (PFP) , an ally in the "pan blue alliance" led by the KMT, if he is to secure a win over Lou in the year-end election in the Taiwan's largest county.

It will be a difficult task for Chou to repair relations with KMT competitors that have complained about what they claim was the primary's unfairness and reach a comprise with the PFP, which has said it will also put forth an aspirant to run in the election, political analysts said.

The situation will be made even more difficult when weighing the key fact that Taipei county has been under DPP rule since 1989 due to a split in the "pan blue alliance" in the last elections, they noted.

December's election for Taipei county magistrate will be a similar race -- one that the analysts said will be dominated by a keen competition between the "pan blue alliance" and the "pan green camp" of the ruling DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
Only a united "pan blue alliance" will be able to counter a strong "pan green camp, " they said, adding that neither camp can afford to lose the support of their allies.

Although it seems that Lou has gained the high ground in the campaign, sources close to the DPP said that Lou is also facing pressure in his party due to dissatisfaction among the supporters of Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, who was also trying hard to gain the party's nomination. Lou was a former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs.

Meanwhile, the KMT will present the name list of five primary winners, including Chou, for approval by the party's policy-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) in its weekly meeting Wednesday. The CSC is scheduled to wrap up the KMT's nomination for the December elections Aug. 1.

Legislator Huang Teh-fu, head of the KMT's Taipei county committee, said he will do his best to negotiate with the PFP and seek its support on fielding a common candidate that is approved by the "pan blue alliance."

In the meantime, the PFP's stance has been the focal point in the domestic political spectrum with regard to whether it will continue to line up with the KMT or align with the DPP, based on a foundation built upon a meeting between PFP Chairman James Soong and President Chen Shui-bian, or whether it will opt to take its own path by fielding candidates at the cost of "pan blue" unity.

Lin Yu-fang, a well-known PFP lawmaker, said Sunday that the party is poised to put forth its own candidates in promising constituencies regardless of pressure from the KMT and despite the fact that there is a big overlap in public backing between the two parties.

According to Lin, the PFP stands a good chance of wining in Keelung city, Changhua county, Nantou county, Taoyuan county and Kaohsiung county. The party is expected to announce its nominees for some of these constituencies in the coming days.

December's elections are expected to serve as a turning point for the PFP to determine its future course -- siding with either the KMT or the DPP or risking being marginalized for insisting on walking the middle road amid fierce political wrangling between the "pan blue" and the "pan green" forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN IN WASTE WATER RECYCLING EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recently achieved a breakthrough in ecological engineering technology developed to control river and lake pollution, with the completion of the country's first underground "soil absorption" system in a military base in Taipei County.

The system, built based on the theory of biodegradation, has proved to be able to recycle around 260 tons of waste water produced by 1,200 servicemen in the military base in Yingge township every day, officials of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Monday.

The purifying rate reached over 77 percent, allowing the military compound to recycle its daily waste water, including that flowing from kitchens and septic tanks, for cleaning use, the officials said, explaining that the water purified by the system has already proved to be good for car-washing, cleaning and watering.
The underground soil absorption system works very well, according to Wei Wen-yi of the EPA department of water quality protection.

Moreover, unlike the normal wetlands used in waste water treatment, the new pollution control-oriented facility can also offer greenland for other public establishments because it is constructed underground, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR MUM ON WHETHER TAIWAN IS PART OF CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 6 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A former U.S. White House official said recently he could not answer the question of whether Taiwan is part of China.

Kenneth Lieberthal, a University of Michigan professor who once served as senior director of Asian affairs under the White House National Security Council during the Clinton administration, took the question after delivering a speech on the Taiwan Strait issue at the Atlantic Council, a Washington-based think tank, last week.
A young audience member said during the question-and-answer session that he was baffled about whether Taiwan is part of China.
Lieberthal said he could not answer such a question because he is not a historian.

Noting that there have been a myriad of discourses about this issue politically and academically, Lieberthal said he could not provide an answer, since he primarily deals with "political reality" rather than historical analyses.

In his speech, Lieberthal continued to advocate that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait shelve their sovereignty disputes and sign a long-term agreement on "no pursuit of independence by Taiwan and no use of force by China against Taiwan" to facilitate the maintenance of the present status quo for 20 years, 30 years, 50 years or even longer.

Lieberthal reminded Taiwan and China that time is limited for them to work out a viable framework for peaceful interaction and said 2007 could be the best timing for the two sides to complete the establishment of a mechanism for peaceful engagements.
As to whether the two sides can resume dialogue, Lieberthal said the next six or 12 months will be an important period for any possible developments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO PREPARE FOR 2ND PHASE OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: After the ad hoc National Assembly votes to pass a constitutional amendment package Tuesday, the Presidential Office will embark on preparations for the second phase of constitutional reforms, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

Yu made the remarks as the mission-oriented National Assembly started to convene for the day and was scheduled to vote Tuesday on a constitutional amendment package adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August.

Yu said that in the past, constitutional reforms were conducted without the direct involvement of the public and that after the passage of the constitutional amendment package, the public will be directly involved in future constitutional amendments, which he said is significant.

Major items in the package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.

A 75 percent majority vote is required for the passage of any amendments and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang, which are in favor of the package, together control 80 percent of the seats in the National Assembly.
If the package passes smoothly, Chen will invite the DPP delegates to the National Assembly to a luncheon to express his appreciation for their efforts, Yu said.

He said that Chen has mentioned several times that the second phase of constitutional reforms will involve such issues as whether to have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power; whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government; reform of the national legislature and relevant articles; whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government; lowering of the minimum voting age; modification of compulsory military service requirements; human rights and labor rights protection; and the inclusion of a special chapter on the well-being of aboriginal citizens in the Constitution.
On the timetable for the second stage of constitutional reforms, Yu said that Chen wishes to hand over a "timely, relevant and viable" constitution when he steps down in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR DEPARTS FOR HONG KONG EN ROUTE TO BEIJING FOR UCLG MEETING

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu left for Hong Kong Monday for an overnight layover on his way to Beijing to attend the United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG) World Council meetings.
Hu said prior to his departure that the UCLG meetings are inter-city conferences aimed at promoting mutual cooperation in urban affairs.

The mayor said he will refrain from any contact with Chinese officials in private during his stay in Beijing and will also not accept any arrangements that would denigrate the Republic of China's status as an independent sovereign state.

"The main purpose of my attendance at the UCLG activities is to introduce Taichung's major industries, cultural development and tourist attractions, " said Hu, who once served as minister of foreign affairs and as representative to the United States.
As a local government chief, Hu said, he will not touch on any political issues or topics related to relations across the Taiwan Strait during his visit.
Hu further said the central government has not given him any directives nor has asked him to convey any message to China.
"Promoting city-to-city exchanges and upgrading Taichung's international image and profile will be my only mission, " Hu stressed.
Hu said he has brought with him a large amount of two of Taichung's delicacies -- Sun cakes and pineapple pastries -- to be distributed to other conference-goers and Chinese journalists.

"I'll catch this rare opportunity to introduce Taichung's unique features and development potential to Chinese people, " Hu said, adding that the UCLG meetings have offered him a rare opportunity for exposure to the Chinese media.

The UCLG World Council meetings are scheduled for June 8-10 in Beijing. Over 300 mayors and city councilors will meet with representatives from the World Bank and the United Nations in a World Mayors Forum. The agenda will include how Asia-Pacific cities plan to cope with contingencies or crises and the status of the city in the new millennium.

Hu is the second ROC local government chief to have obtained the government's permission to visit China. In 2000, then-Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien was permitted to go to China to take part in a world technology conference held in Nanjing.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ENERGY CONSERVATION SEASON' KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: An "Energy Conservation Season" sponsored by the Energy Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs kicked off Monday with the slogan of "saving one unit of electricity per person per day."

Minister of the Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said in a ceremony marking the start of the season that the cutting of greenhouse gas emissions has become a cause of great public concern since the Kyoto Protocol on climate change took effect in February.

Ho said cutting the consumption of electricity is the most effective way of reducing greenhouse gas emissions because most electricity is generated by burning fossil fuel, which produces carbon dioxide, the major component of the so-called greenhouse gases.

This is all the more pressing during the summer, when the consumption of electricity peaks, which is why the Energy Bureau came up with the idea of the "Energy Conservation Season" from June to August, the minister said.

By saving only unit of electricity per day per capita, Ho said, the country will save 8.4 billion units in one year, which is worth NT$21 billion and 2.3 times the total electricity produced in a year by the country's Linkou Thermo Power Station. This will thereby reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 5.8 million tons, an amount that would take 390,000 hectares of trees a whole year to process.

The MOEA Energy Bureau offered some tips for saving electricity, for example turning up the temperature of the air conditioners by one degree Celsius, switching off the electric hot drinking water suppliers in the summer, turning off lights when leaving a room, not riding elevators when going up or down within three floors, and buying electrical appliances with energy saving marks.
A copy of the tips will be sent by the Taiwan Power Company to their customers along with their next electricity bills.

In order to encourage the public to cut their electricity consumption, the power company will offer prizes to winners chosen through a raffle for consumers who use less electricity in August and September than they did in the same months of last year.

Other activities include road racing, a trade fair of energy-conserving products, public speeches on energy conservation, a competition for energy conservation songs and the spread of energy-conserving technology, according to Ho.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEASIBILITY OF SETTING UP PRIMATE RESEARCH CENTER UNDER ASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: An assessment report on the feasibility of establishing a primate research center in Taiwan will be submitted in July, a director of the nation's highest academic body said Monday.

Yu Cheng-po, director of the Institute of Cellular and Organism Biology of Academia Sinica, said that former National Science Council (NSC) Chairman Wei Tze-ho commissioned him to conduct the feasibility study and that he has invited experts from the Council of Agriculture and other related government agencies to help with the study, as well as such a center's purpose and mission.
"The assessment report will be submitted to the NSC by the end of the month," he said.

Yu noted that if the research center is to be established, it will have to meet world standards. He said that as Taiwan has a dearth of basic research in this field, there is a lot of work that could be done in the areas of information collection, conservation and biomedicine.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO FORM PANEL TO FLESH OUT TAX REFORM MEASURES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has ordered the formation of a special task force to flesh out tax reform measures in line with President Chen Shui-bian's recent directives regarding taxation reform, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Monday.
According to Cho, Hsieh will personally head the panel with relevant department chiefs as its members.
The panel will work out a timetable for implementing Chen's six-point tax reform program, Cho said, adding that the package will also include detailed tax rates and complementary measures.
Operational rules for the panel will be announced later this week, Cho added.
President Chen announced his six-point tax reform plan May 30 after presiding over a meeting of the Presidential Office Economic Advisory Panel.
Chen said the reform program will focus on expanding the taxation base, restructuring and simplifying the tax system and eradicating tax evasion.
According to Chen's proposals, Taiwan's average tax rate should be raise from the current 13.6
percent to 15 percent in three years; the business tax rate should be raise by 1-to-2-percent in the near future; the ceilings on the inheritance and gift taxes should be adjusted to 40 percent.
Chen also called for a feasibility study on the levy of capital gain taxes on unlisted stock trading and offering tax deductions on educational expenditures.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER'S DEGREE PROGRAM TO BE OPENED ON KINMEN FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: An Executive Master of Business Administration (EMBA) program for Taiwanese executives working in China will open on the frontline island of Kinmen in September, an education official said Monday.

Chen Teh-hua, director of the Higher Education Department at the Ministry of Education, said his office has given the greenlight to the program, to be conducted jointly by National Kaohsiung University in southern Taiwan and the National Kinmen Technology College.

Huang Ying-chung, president of National Kaohsiung University, said the program, targeting Taiwan businessmen working in China's Fujian Province, just across the Taiwan Strait from Kinmen, will begin to take in students from September.
In addition to 30 placements for China-based Taiwan businessmen, the program will reserve 10 placements for senior officials from the Kinmen county government and local people. according to Huang.

Noting that there are more than 3,000 Taiwan firms based in Xiamen and Chuangzhou -- the two cities directly across the strait from Kinmen, Huang said he expects the program will easily find enough students.

Huang said one quarter of the classes under the program will be conducted on the campus of National Kaohsiung University, half will be on the campus of the Kinmen Technology College and the other quarter will be in China in the form of field trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 7, or the first day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."
