DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA USING EVERY MEANS TO BLOCK TAIWAN'S ENTRY INTO OAS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that China, based on its "zero-sum" mentality, is using every possible means to block Taiwan from entering the Organization of American States (OAS).

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks following the release of a U.S. Congressional Research Service (CRS) report that since China became an observer in the OAS last year, it has vehemently opposed Taiwan joining the organization as an observer. Beijing has also taken the opportunity to develop relations with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the organization and to continue to suppress Taiwan internationally, according to the CRS report.
Lu noted that 12 of the 34 members of the OAS are diplomatic allies of Taiwan and that the other members have maintained substantial relations with Taiwan.
Taiwan has been actively trying to become an observer in the OAS, and the United States is supporting its bid, but China is doing everything possible to block the island's entry, Lu added.
China's "zero-sum" mentality has led Beijing to attempt to marginalize Taiwan in every possible way, Lu said, adding that this has posed a great challenge to Taiwan.

Lu expressed the hope that the public will understand the situation and that domestic businesses will come out in force to invest in central America to help the nation cement ties with its diplomatic allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY PASSES CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT PACKAGE

TEXT.P: The ad hoc National Assembly passed a constitutional amendment package by a vote of 249-48 early Tuesday afternoon.

The delegates from the two major parties -- 127 delegates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and 117 delegates from the main opposition Kuomintang -- toed their respective party lines and voted in favor of the amendment package. A three-quarters majority, or 225 votes in favor, was required to endorse the package.

The amendment proposals, adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August, include reducing the number of seats in the legislature from the current 225 to 113, extending the terms for legislators from the current three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 31.78 points to close at 6,105.78.
The bourse opened at 6,144.25 and fluctuated between 6,146.94 and 6,096.84 during trading. A total of 3.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.46 billion (US$2.45 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent, and construction issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 621 to 230, with 152 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved down nine points to close at 6,060, with 17,739 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July moved down four points to end at 5,953, with 1,174 contracts traded, while September futures lost four points to finish at 5,873, with 699 contracts traded. December futures moved down four points to close at 5,864, with one contract traded, while March futures moved up seven points to close at 5,854, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,069 for June, 5,957 for July, 5,877 for September, 5,868 for December and 5,847 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

June TE futures moved down 0.65 points to close at 244.3, with 3,958 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 0.5 points to finish at 241.2, with 174 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down one points to end at 236.25, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

June TF futures lost one point to finish at 943, with 2,535 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures moved up 0.6 points to end at 930, with 243 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down three points to finish at 915, with 61 contract transactions, while December TF futures moved up 1.2 points to close at 910, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Customer Data Lost, Citigroup Unit Says; 3.9 Million Affected As Firms' Security Lapses Add Up.
A unit of financial services giant Citigroup Inc. said yesterday that a box of computer tapes with account information for 3.9 million customers had been lost in shipment, exposing a vast new swath of Americans to the increased possibility of identity theft, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER REMAINS TAIWAN'S TOP KILLER FOR 23RD STRAIGHT YEAR

TEXT.P: Cancer kept its title as Taiwan's top killer in 2004, remaining as the leading cause of death in the country for the 23rd year in a row, the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

Heart disease, stroke, diabetes, accidents, pneumonia, chronic liver disease, kidney disease, suicide and hypertension rounded out the top 10 list in that order last year, according to DOH statistics released Thursday.

Generally speaking, DOH officials said, the order of the top 10 did not change much from the previous year. The only changes were that heart disease and stroke switched places, while pneumonia and chronic liver disease switched spots.

More than 133,000 Taiwan people died in 2004, marking a 2.9-percent increase over the figure for the previous year. Seventy-five percent of the deaths were caused by one of the top 10 killers, according to the DOH statistics.

Huang Hsu-ming, chief of the DOH's statistics department, said that the number of the people dying from hypertension has been gradually declining over the past ten years, with the death rate dropping from 10.96 per 100,000 people in 1994 to 7.97 per 100,000 people last year.
Over the same period, the number of suicides has been steadily increasing, from a rate of 6.24 out of every 100,000 people in 1994 to 15.31 per 100,000 people last year, Huang said.
As for the top killer, Huang said, cancer claimed one life in Taiwan every 14 minutes and 27 seconds on average last year.

A total of 36,357 Taiwan people died of cancer last year, with liver cancer and lung cancer claiming about 40 percent of those lives, according to the DOH tallies. Colo-rectal cancer, breast cancer, gastric cancer, oral cancer, cervical cancer, prostate cancer, cancer of the esophagus, and pancreatic cancer rounded out the top 10 list of deadliest forms of cancer.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO SENSITIVE POLITICAL ISSUES FOR NEXT CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS: YU

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's plan to introduce additional constitutional reforms will not touch on sensitive political issues; rather it will deal with issues that are of major concern to society, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday.

Yu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters at the Chungshan Building in Yangmingshan, where the members of an ad-hoc National Assembly were voting on a package of constitutional amendments that include the adoption of "a single seat, two votes" electoral system, reducing the number of seats at the Legislative Yuan by almost half and granting referendum power to the public to decide constitutional amendments proposed by the Legislative Yuan.
According to Yu, the president hopes to promote a new round of constitutional reforms soon after the National Assembly completes its current session which is expected to end later in the day.

Instead of controversial political issues, such as changing Taiwan's official designation, an option for independence or unification and a redefinition of national sovereignty or territory, issues related to the governmental system, lowering the voting age and reforming the military conscription system will be the centerpieces of the planned new constitutional reforms, he said.

The president will do his best to seek comprehensive understanding and communication with the opposition parties and will fully respect their opinions to forge a consensus, the top presidential aide said.
Lin Fong-cheng, secretary-general of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , criticized the second phase of constitutional reforms proposed by Chen as impractical.

Stressing that the people of Taiwan are looking forward to better livelihoods, Lin urged the government to focus on improving Taiwan's economy and cross-Taiwan Strait ties. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must not rashly start a fresh round of constitutional reforms only to win political capital without having gained a national consensus, he said.

Shieh Kung-ping, spokesman for the People First Party (PFP) , quoted PFP Chairman James Soong as accusing Chen of violating the Constitution by pushing for a new phase of constitutional reforms since doing so goes against the principles in a democratic nation.

According to Soong, the president and the ruling DPP must abide by and take the lead to implement the Constitution instead of repeatedly violating it, Shieh said. He added that the PFP will never agree to a new round of constitutional revisions.

Soong was quoted by Hsieh as saying that the president's initiative to amend the Constitution is in violation of the law, as constitutional amendments proposals should be put forth by the Legislative Yuan, not the Presidential Office.

The Presidential Office's proposal to set up a constitutional amending committee under its jurisdiction is totally illegal, Hsieh cited Soong as saying and pointing out that the PFP is firmly opposed to the DPP's scheme to play with popularism in disguise of its inability to effectively rule the country.

The issues that the president wants to include in the next round of constitutional reforms can be improved through the regular process of legislation or by coordination in execution by related government agencies, Hsieh said, claiming that it is not necessary to resort to amending the Constitution.

Su Ching-chiang, chairman of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , blasted the current round of constitutional revisions as suicide that will kill the lifeline of Taiwan's democracy, referring to the high three-fourths majority vote by the lawmakers jointly supported by the DPP and the KMT for future referendums on constitutional amendments.
Although the TSU's wish to create a new constitution for Taiwan remains far off, Su said that the party will not give up its dream.
The DPP and the KMT together hold 244 seats at the 300-member National Assembly, that will be immediately dissolved and pass into history following the current session.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.001 to close at NT$31.226.
A total of US$734 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.225 and fluctuated between NT$31.148 and NT$31.226.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAX RESTRUCTURING WILL MAKE THE SYSTEM FAIRER: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: If President Chen Shui-bian's administration has its way, overhauling the tax system will level the playing field for taxpayers and will certainly not make poor people poorer as former President Lee Teng-hui has alleged, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.
Hsieh made the remarks while addressing a ceremony to install new caucus leaders of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) at the Legislative Yuan. Lee is the TSU's spiritual leader.

A day earlier, the premier ordered the formation of a special task force to work out tax reform measures in line with President Chen's directive. He said in his address to TSU legislators that reforms will be conducted in three major directions -- making taxes fair, expanding the tax base and increasing the sources of tax revenues.

He said the reason the government hopes to reform the tax system is so that everyone can share in the benefits of the nation's economic growth, referring to the national health insurance system and social welfare.
Hsieh said that the new panel, which will be headed by himself, will meet this week and begin discussing ways to define the lowest tax rate for ordinary taxpayers.

President Chen announced a six-point tax reform plan on May 30 after presiding over a meeting of the Presidential Office Economic Advisory Panel. He said that the reform program will focus on expanding the tax base, restructuring and simplifying the tax system and eradicating tax evasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER REGISTERS FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP RACE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who also serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , registered Tuesday to run for party chairman in the July 16 election.
Accompanied by his family and supporters, Wang completed the procedure by turning in 100,000 signatures endorsing his candidacy.
Wang said the encouragement of current KMT Chairman Lien Chan as well as his sense of responsibility and mission prompted him to run.

Wang pledged to rejuvenate the century-old KMT and bring about a more optimistic future for the Republic of China, which he said has been put to a real test over the past five years since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power.

Saying cross-Taiwan Strait tensions have escalated and that society in Taiwan has become divided, Wang said his goal after becoming the next KMT chairman will be to push for a second transition of power so that the KMT can once again lead the country.

He said the KMT should play a positive role in the Legislative Yuan to block any improper legislative and budget bills and he proposed that the party focus on proposals that will serve the public and endorse bills that are beneficial to the country and its people.
Also, he promised to integrate the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party to help the party win the presidency in 2008.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, another KMT vice chairman who has also registered to run for chairman, said he expects that the campaigning on both sides will be fair.

Calling it an "epoch-making development" in the KMT's history for two vice chairmen to vie for the chairmanship, Ma said he expects party workers in charge of electoral affairs to remain neutral in the election.
Ma said he believes the outcome of the election will be acceptable to everybody as long as it is carried out in an open, fair and just manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS PAVE WAY FOR POLITICAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The constitutional amendments passed by the National Assembly on Tuesday has set the stage for major political reforms in Taiwan, which include the abolition of the National Assembly, the introduction of constitutional referendums and a "single district, two votes" electoral system as well as reducing the number of legislative seats from 225 to 113.
National Assembly Secretary-General Yeh Jiunn-rong said within three days the assembly will request the president to promulgate the amendments.

Under the amendments, the National Assembly, which had powers to vote on constitutional amendments, territorial boundary changes and the impeachment of the president and vice president proposed by the Legislative Yuan, ceases to exist.

Future constitutional amendments and territorial boundary changes proposed by the Legislative Yuan will be put to a popular referendum within three months after they have been publicized for six months. The amendments or changes will be passed if over 50 percent of the eligible voters vote in favor of them.

A proposal to impeach the president or vice president that is initiated by over 50 percent of legislators and endorsed by over two-thirds of the legislators will be transferred to the Grand Justices for consideration. The president or vice president will be removed from duty if the impeachment is determined valid by the constitutional court.

Starting from the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, the Legislative Yuan will have only 113 seats and will be elected every four years. While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

The regional seats will be distributed among special municipalities, counties and cities according to their populations, with each locality enjoying at least one seat and one legislator elected from each district. The at-large and overseas expatriate seats will be allocated to political parties that win at least 5 percent of the votes, according to the proportion of votes they garner, with each party required to reserve at least 50 percent of the seats for women.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, TSU TO FEEL IMPACT OF NEW ELECTORAL SYSTEM: OBSERVERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's smaller political parties are set to encounter survival difficulties in future elections now that the National Assembly has approved a "single seat, two votes" electoral system in a constitutional revision session that took place Tuesday, according to political analysts.
Under the new system, only 113 lawmakers will be elected to the next Legislative Yuan, a sharp reduction from the 225 seats in the current 6th Legislative Yuan that will end early 2008.

As the new system is widely viewed as more favorable to larger parties -- namely the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- due to fiercer competition for fewer seats in smaller constituencies, candidates of the People First Party (PFP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) are very likely to be crowded out in future elections, analysts predicted.
However, they expressed worry that in the future, legislative committees, which will be controlled by just a few lawmakers, will invite intervention by vested interest groups.

The analysts also expressed concern that the "one seat, two votes" system will fuel competition between the pro-independence DPP and the pro-unification KMT, further aggravating the polarized political wrangling dominated by the "pan green camp" led by the DPP and the "pan blue alliance" led by the KMT.
Currently, the "pan green camp" enjoys wider public support in southern Taiwan, while the "pan blue alliance" enjoys a noticeable advantage in the north.

PFP Legislator Huang Yi-jiau said candidates of smaller parties must be devoted to serving the public to gain votes amid the aggressive competition that will arise from the changes in the electoral system and from a legislature that will be cut by nearly half.
PFP Legislator Chung Shao-ho said a leaner Legislative Yuan will create stronger pressure on both the KMT and the PFP to consolidate to secure "pan blue" victory in coming elections.

Meanwhile, Cheng Cheng-long, secretary-general of the TSU, the ally of the ruling DPP in the "pan green camp, " was not so pessimistic about the party's prospects, although he did not deny the fact that a streamlined legislature will represent a smaller slice of the pie for all the competitors.

Saying he does not think the TSU will become a "burst bubble" in the short term, Cheng added that the party must cement and broaden its public support base through enhanced organization and in-depth theoretical discourse to expound its stance and attract new blood.

Various other TSU lawmakers were of the view that the KMT will benefit the most from the electoral system changes and they called for negotiations with the DPP as soon as possible to jointly take on the challenges in December's city mayor and county magistrate elections.
Neither party in the "pan green camp" can afford a split if they want to win in the year-end elections, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO START SECOND PHASE OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he will formally start the next phase of amending the ROC Constitution now that the mission-oriented National Assembly voted earlier in the day to pass a constitutional amendment package.
President Chen made the remarks while receiving members of the Asian Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce at the Presidential Office.

The president noted that the Legislative Yuan, responding to the aspiration of the people, adopted the constitutional amendment package across the party spectrum last August and that he was glad to see the ad hoc National Assembly pass the package 249-48 so that they could formally became part of the Constitution.

The proposals include reducing the number of seats in the legislature from the current 225 to 113, extending the terms for legislators from the current three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.
"This is not the end of constitutional reform, but a new start," the president said, adding that after the completion of the first stage, the second phase of constitutional re-engineering will begin.
He reiterated that he wants to hand over a "timely, relevant and viable" constitution to Taiwan when he steps down in 2008.
The president also said that he will base subsequent amendments on "fairness and neutrality."
He said that constitutional reform will not only be a reform of the system, but will be the best democratic and constitutional reform education for the people.

He pointed out that he will speed up the formation of a constitutional reform committee, inviting all political parties as well as people from all walks of life to participate to allow the public to be fully engaged in the constitutional reform discussion, forge a national consensus and form a new collective sense of the nation.

Chen has mentioned several times that the second phase of constitutional reform will involve such issues as whether to have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power; whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government; reform of the national legislature and relevant articles; whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government; lowering of the minimum voting age; modification of compulsory military service requirements; human rights and labor rights protection; and the inclusion of a special chapter on the well-being of aboriginal citizens in the Constitution.

Meanwhile, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, who went to the Chungshan Building on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei to ask DPP delegates to the National Assembly to toe the party line and vote in favor of the package, said though various parties had different views, the result was perfect.

President Chen will host a dinner for all DPP delegates to express his appreciation for their efforts. Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang also said that all 127 DPP delegates strictly toed the party line and delivered on the party's promise of reform to the people.
Su also expressed appreciation for the Kuomintang, whose 117 delegates also voted "yes" unanimously on the package, adding that the DPP will continue working for democratic reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAYORS SIGN ENVIRONMENT ACCORDS IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 6 (CNA) (By C. Chiang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two mayors from Taiwan, along with over 200 heads of cities around the world, committed themselves to making more efforts to green the Earth by signing a "green cities declaration" before the United Nation-sponsored World Environment Day (WED) 2005 activities ended in San Francisco Sunday.

Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair and Deputy Taipei Mayor Yeh Ching-chuan signed the "Urban Environment Accords," which designate a number of concrete goals in the development of ecologically sustainable urban centers.

The goals include reducing their respective jurisdictions' emissions of greenhouse gases by 25 percent by 2030, achieving zero waste added to landfills and incinerators by 2040, ensuring there is an accessible public park or recreational open space within half-a-kilometer of every city resident by 2015, and increasing adequate access to safe drinking water, aiming at access for all by 2015.

World Environment Day, which falls on June 5 each year, is one of the principal vehicles through which the U.N. tries to raise global awareness of the environment and enhance political attention and action in environmental protection affairs.
The 2005 WED activities, hosted by San Francisco, was held June 1-5, with a total of 250 mayors from cities around the world, including 17 mayors from China and two from Taiwan, invited to attend.
However, all the Chinese mayors boycotted the event because of the invitations extended by the organizers to Taiwan.

Regarding China's protest, both Hsu and Yeh said that they came to San Francisco to trade ideas with other cities on issues that will create a better living environment for people, and that they had no intention to raise political tension.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNTIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Olympic Bid Hurt as New York Fails in West Side Stadium Quest.
New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's nearly four-year quest to build a Manhattan football stadium that could spark the redevelopment of the West Side and lure the Olympic Games to New York was defeated yesterday when City Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, refused to approve the US$2.2 billion projec. The decision by the state's Public Authorities Control Board, makes it far more difficult, if not impossible, for the city to guarantee the construction of an Olympic stadium, a prerequisite to its bid. Just hours earlier, the International Olympic Committee released a report generally praising New York's bid, but calling attention to the stadium's uncertainty. Paris's proposal drew unqualified praise. In less than four weeks, the Olympic committee plans to pick Paris, London, Madrid, Moscow or New York for the site of the Summer Games.
Wall Street Journal: Virtual Battle, How a Global Web of Activists Gives Coke Problems in India.
Amit Srivastava who runs a nonprofit, activist organization in California has been helping shake up one of the world's biggest corporations, Coca-Cola Co., thousands of miles away in India. Srivastava is rallying college stude ntsin the U.S. and Europe to take up the NGOs'cause. Under pressure from student protesters, at least a half-dozen colleges have decided not to renew contracts with Coke or boycott it, and other campuses are considering similar action. Even though he lives in Northern California, Srivastava has emerged as a key figure in Coke's travails in India. That a one- man NGO armed with just a laptop computer, a Web site and a telephone calling card can, with his allies, influence a huge multinational corporation illustrates the role social activists can play in a world that's going increasingly online.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR ARRIVES IN BEIJING FOR INTERNATIONAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 7 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu arrived in Beijing Tuesday to attend the United Cities and Local Governments (UCLG) World Council meetings slated for June 8-10.
Upon arrival, Hu said the main purpose of his attending the UCLG activities is to promote Taichung City.

It is an opportunity for Taichung to show the world its unique features and development potentials, Hu said, adding that he hopes to hold a news conference in Beijing to promote city-to-city exchanges.
Hu said, however, that he had not arranged to meet any Chinese government officials during his stay in Beijing.

Hu is the second Taiwan local government chief to have obtained the central government's permission to visit China. In 2000, then-Hsinchu Mayor Tsai Jen-chien was permitted to go to China to take part in a world technology conference held in Nanjing.

The UCLG World Council meetings are the first to take place since the organization's founding congress in Paris in May 2004. The agenda will include discussions on the key role of local governments in meeting the millennium development goals and managing the aftermath of disasters.

During the meetings, over 300 mayors and city councilors will also meet with representatives from the World Bank and the United Nations in a World Mayors Forum, in preparation for the Millennium Summit review in New York in September, where UCLG will be advocating the creation of an officially recognized advisory role for local governments within the U.N.

DOC.HEADLINE: `PEOPLE POWER' WILL ENSURE SUCCESS OF NEW CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that as long as "people show their power," the second phase of constitutional reforms can succeed.

Chen Chin-jun, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, made the remarks after the opposition parties responded in a lukewarm fashion to President Chen Shui-bian's advocacy of formally starting the next stage of constitutional reform after the ad hoc National Assembly passed a constitutional amendment package 249-48 earlier in the day.

The package includes reducing the number of seats in the legislature from the current 225 to 113, extending the terms for legislators from the current three years to four years, adopting a "single seat, two ballots" legislative electoral system, phasing out the National Assembly, holding popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, and empowering the Council of Grand Justices to screen presidential and vice presidential impeachment proposals.
The legislator claimed that despite the lukewarm response from the opposition parties, it is "urgent" to start the second phase of reforms so that Taiwan can become a "normal and great country."

He said that under the present constitutional system, Taiwan has neither a presidential nor a cabinet system. The issue of compulsory military service, as well as the inclusion of a special chapter in the Constitution on the well-being of aboriginal citizens also requires discussion, he added.

"Economic issues are important, but so is the sustainable development of Constitution," he said, referring to criticism by the main opposition Kuomintang that people are more concerned about improving the economy.
He said the DPP legislative caucus fully supports the president's promotion of the second phase of constitutional amendment.

"The opposition parties should come to terms with reality and not try to boycott the reforms," he said, adding that Chen is resolved to embark on the reforms and that the people will also display their power, which the opposition should not underestimate.

The president has said several time that the next phase of constitutional reform will involve such issues as whether to have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power; whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government; reform of the national legislature and relevant articles; whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government; lowering of the minimum voting age; modification of compulsory military service requirements; human rights and labor rights protection.
He also promised to hand the nation a "timely, relevant, and viable" constitution before he steps down from his second term in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS TAX REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accentuated again Tuesday what he described as the urgency and necessity of tax reforms, saying that the reform proposals he unveiled recently are aimed at broadening the tax base, establishing a fair taxation system, achieving effective use of resources and promoting investment.
Chen said the reforms will require high-income earners to shoulder a heavier tax burden, which he said is consistent with social justice and fairness.
The president made the remarks during a meeting with representatives of the Asia Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce.

Chen pointed out that although Taiwan is ranked the world's 11th most competitive country in the World Competitiveness Yearbook 2005 released last month by the Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD), its ranking in the "public finance" criterion has fallen.
This situation shows that financial reforms are imperative, Chen said.

He noted that fiscal imbalance of the government has continued for a long time and that to tackle the problem, the Cabinet finalized in 2003 a financial reform package intended to achieve fiscal balance in five to 10 years.
The tax reform proposals that he unveiled last week are also designed to exhibit the government's resolve to carry out financial reforms, he said.

These include raising the national tax rate to 15 percent in three years from the current 13.6 percent and further to 18 percent as a mid-term goal; reviewing the rates of commodity tax, stamp tax, business tax, inheritance tax and gift tax; establishing a minimum tax system targeting high-income earners; and simplifying the tax system.
According to Chen, these proposals were worked out after taking into consideration the advantages and disadvantages they involve.
He said the government should continue to try to increase government and corporate investment to expand its revenue instead of focusing the reforms on tax cuts and tax hikes.

He predicted that a backlash and differences over the tax reforms will be inevitable during the remaining three years of his term, but he said he will endure the pressure and take the challenge in order to fulfill his responsibility and obligations as the nation's leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAICHUNG MAYOR NAMED VICE INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has decided to name former Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying as vice minister of the interior and to appoint former Legislator Chiu Yi-ying as a deputy chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council for Hakka Affairs, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

Cho Jung-tai said that Hsieh will officially announce the nominations of Chang and Chiu together with those of Hakka Affairs Council Chairman Lee Yung-teh and Environmental Protection Administration Director-General Huang Kuo-lung at Wednesday's Cabinet meeting.

Lee is to fill the vacancy left by Lo Wen-jia, who quit the chairmanship in March to run in the year-end Taipei county magistrate election, while Huang is to succeed Chang Ju-en, who quit in April to return to teaching.

A handover ceremony for outgoing and upcoming heads of the Council for Hakka Affairs and the Environmental Protection Administration will be held at the Government Information Office later Wednesday, Cho added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO REVISE LAWS IN STEP WITH AMENDED CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan promised Tuesday to revise related laws in step with the amended Constitution after the National Assembly passed a package of constitutional amendments earlier in the day.

Cho Jung-tai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said the constitutional amendments, which include halving the number of lawmakers and switching the lawmakers' electoral system to a "single-seat, two ballots" system, entail the redrawing of voting districts and revisions to the election rules.
Another amendment giving the people the right to approve constitutional amendments through referendum requires changes in the referendum law to be put into practice.

With the amended Constitution in place, Cho claimed, the legislature will be revamped and the sharp confrontations between the legislative and executive branches will be "gone, " which he said is in the country's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAUDS PERFORMANCE OF PARTY NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan praised the performance of the party's National Assembly members after the National Assembly approved as expected a package of constitutional amendments Tuesday.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng told a news conference at the Chungshan Building on Yangmingshan, venue of the National Assembly, that Lien was pleased that all 117 of the party's National Assembly members had toed the party line by voting for the amendments.

Although some parties had backed away from promises they made last August to support the amendments, Lin said his party has stuck to its guns, which he claimed shows that the KMT is a responsible party.

Calling the revisions of the Constitution only the beginning of a long process of political reform, Lin said a lot remains to be done and that the KMT will try to unite the followers of the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party to present a united front.

After the numerous twists and turns involved in the process of altering the Constitution, Lin said the people need to take a break and redirect their attention to improving their livelihoods. Therefore, he went on, the party will not support the president's idea of starting preparations for another phase of constitutional reforms in 2007.

KMT convener in the National Assembly Chen Chin-jang said at the news conference that the rapid approval of the amendments proves that the National Assembly has done what it was mandated to do and he claimed that the media's criticism of the ad hoc group as being inefficient and greedy is "unfair."

In a related development Tuesday, KMT Legislator Cheng Yung-chuan, who is the director of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, said the KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan will make the enactment of the organic law of the Central Election Commission a priority in the next legislative session now that the commission is set to redraw the voting districts for lawmakers after the revised Constitution cut the number of lawmakers by half.
In order to ensure that the commission does not gerrymander while redrawing the constituencies, it is vital to shield the commission from political influence in its organic law.

KMT Legislator Huang Teh-fu said the party is trying to make the commission a mirror of the legislature by having its members nominated by various political parties in proportion to their legislative seats.
Also, Huang said, the constituencies redrawn by the Central Election Commission should be subject to the approval of the Legislative Yuan.

He claimed that the commission was downgraded into a rubber stamp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in 2004 when it agreed to hold a national referendum along with the presidential election and to set the legislative election day on December 11, 2004, which he claimed favored the DPP.

Under the existing law, the redivision of voting districts should take effect only one year after being promulgated. Since the next legislative election is due by the end of 2007, the new boundaries of the various voting district must be made public before the end of 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN EXPERT CALLS FOR REVIEW OF U.S. 'ONE CHINA' POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 6 (CNA) (By C.F. Lee and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission Chairman Richard D'Amato urged Washington Monday to review its "one China" policy based on the new developments across the Taiwan Strait.
He made the call while meeting a group of Taiwanese journalists who are visiting the United States under the leadership of Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng.
D'Amato said it is "unwise and mistaken" for China's leaders to bypass the duly elected government in Taiwan and discuss cross-strait affairs with the opposition parties.

However, Beijing, which insists on making the "one China" principle a precondition for government-to-government cross-strait talks, is obviously not ready to resume official dialogue with Taipei, D'Amato observed.

He said the United States should play a more active role to help the resumption of cross-strait dialogue and review its vague "one China" policy to avoid misunderstandings and reduce cross-strait tension.
According to Heritage Foundation research fellow John J. Tkacik, Washington has never recognized Taiwan as part of China, although it "acknowledges" Beijing's claim to the contrary.

Tkacik proposed that the U.S. government specify openly that its "one China" policy does not mean it recognizes Taiwan as part of China and said he believes China will reconsider its policy toward Taiwan if this stand of Washington is made clear to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, June 8:
09: 00, The weekly Cabinet meeting will be held at the Executive Yuan.
09: 00, The opposition Kuomintang will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
09:30, Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei will hold a news conference at the Legislative Yuan on her planned visit to Japan.
09: 30, The inauguration of an alliance for research and development of the cosmetics industry will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
10: 20, The inauguration of an alliance for customized service industry development will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center.
10: 30, The opening ceremony of the 2005 Taipei Opto-electronic Week activities will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center.
14:00, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will receive representatives of the Asia Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce at the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN REPRESENTATIVE ARRIVES IN SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 7 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new representative to Singapore, Hu Wei-jen, arrived in the Southeast Asian city state Tuesday to assume his new post.
Upon arrival, Hu said he is pleased to work in Singapore, which he described as a "respectful" country. He did not elaborate.
He pledged to do his best to further promote Taiwan-Singapore relations.
Hu, a former deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council and former deputy director of the National Security Bureau, previously served as Taiwan's representative to Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S OBU ASSETS INCREASE

TEXT.P: The assets of Taiwan's offshore banking units (OBUs) totalled US$69.4 billion as of the end of April, up US$529 million from the figure recorded a year ago, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Central Bank of China.
The capital coming from Asia occupied the lion's share of 63 percent, the tallies show.
In terms of capital destinations, Asia was the major destination, accounting for 68 percent, it adds.
Of the total assets of OBU operations, those of the domestic banks accounted for 69 percent, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISION OF REFERENDUM LAW UNDER CONSIDERATION

TEXT.P: Encouraged by the passage of a package of constitutional amendments by the National Assembly Tuesday, the Executive Yuan is speeding up its studies on revising the Referendum Law, which has to be changed to be in conformity with the amendments.
Under the preliminary studies, the number of people needed to initiate a call for referendum should be lowered from 0.5 percent of the electorate of the latest presidential election to 0.03 percent.
In the present situation, that means a reduction from 80,000 people to 4,800.
Meanwhile, the number of sponsors for any such call will be lowered from 5 percent of the presidential electorate to 1.5 percent, representing a reduction from 800,000 to 200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS SET STAGE FOR FURTHER REFORM

TEXT.P: The just-passed constitutional amendments have set the stage for another and more radical phase of constitutional reform, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

In a dinner party hosted by the president for National Assembly members of his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chen said his administration takes heart from the success of the first phase of constitutional reforms that ended with the passage of five amendments Tuesday, and vowed to speed up the next phase of reforms with the purpose of giving the country a constitution tailored to its needs.
When his term expires in 2008, Chen said, he hopes a constitution suitable for the country will be in place along with a new president, new administration, a new legislature and a new era.

Chen said the first constitutional reforms, especially the abolition of the National Assembly, has destroyed the myth that the the Constitution, as well as the five-branch government provided for therein, is a vital and untouchable part of the country's legacy.

By doing away with this myth, Chen said, the National Assembly has removed a political taboo against revamping the Constitution thoroughly, and has prepared the public for more radical changes to the Constitution, Chen claimed.
"It has convinced people that the Constitution should serve their interests rather than maintain a fictitious legacy," he said.

Furthermore, he went on, the amendments also give people the final say in future constitutional amendments through referendum and thereby make them the real masters of the country, which is unprecedented in the country's history.
He thanked the opposition Kuomintang for its support for the amendments and promised to give the country a more active leadership in the second phase of constitutional reforms.

The president's exuberance was shared by his guests at the dinner party, with Vice President Annette Lu admiring him as "the engineer of constitutional reform" and Chen's chief of staff Yu Shyi-kun saying the passage of the amendments is a success for the DPP and the Taiwan people.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said at the party that Taiwan's democracy takes a big jump forward with the passage of the amendments and will be even better when the president finishes his second phase of constitutional reforms in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO EXPAND SEWAGE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior plans to expand Taiwan's sewage system, increasing the ratio of the country's households that are connected to a public sewage system from the present 11 percent to 23 percent by 2008, agency officials said Tuesday.
The agency will appropriate NT$20 billion (US$637 million) in the next two years for related construction projects and the establishment of asewage system construction office, they said.
Taiwan is sorely lacking in terms of its public sewage system in light of the 70 percent to 90 percent seen in Western European countries and North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 8, or the second day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army when his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 U.S. troops from Vietnam.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the U.S. National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The ROC-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first Chinese-American astronaut.
1987: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Mainland China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
2000: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung carry out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation, giving Wu Feng-ying, 50, a section of liver donated by her son, Lin Yun-ju, 24.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: Such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard." "But men who live in retirement in order to study their aims and who practice righteousness in order to carry out their principles: The expression of such principles I have heard, but I have not seen such men."
