DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER TO SEEK APOLOGY, COMPENSATION IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei is scheduled to lead a Taiwan group to Japan next Monday to seek an apology and compensation from the Japanese government for the Taiwanese aborigines who were killed during World War II in combat as drafted Japanese Imperial Army soldiers.

At a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Kao Chin, a member of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, said she will travel to Japan with a group of 60 aborigines who are offspring of members of the Taiwanese Kaosha Warriors Group who were forced to fight for the Japanese army during World War II.

Kao Chin and her group will primarily demand that the Japanese government remove the tablets for the Kaosha Warriors Group from the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo. Discounting Yasukuni authorities' earlier statements that the Taiwanese aboriginal warriors have already become "gods" and nobody has the right to decide their fate, Kao Chin said that the Kaosha warriors are not Japanese and their "confined souls should be released and allowed to return to their home in Taiwan."

Calling the "shackling of the warriors' souls" in Japan the "saddest event in the history of Taiwan's aboriginal people, " Kao Chin said that her people will travel to Japan one group after another in a bid to "release" their ancestors' souls in their own way.

Kao Chin and her group will also demand an open apology from the Japanese government for Japan's atrocities committed in Taiwan during the war as well as compensation for the Taiwanese aborigines who were killed in battles during the war.
Documentaries showing Taiwanese telling of how Taiwan's aborigines were slaughtered or tortured by the Japanese during the period of Japanese colonial rule were also shown at the press conference.

The Yasukuni Shrine, situated in central Tokyo just outside the moat to the Imperial Palace, is dedicated to the some 2.46 million people who died in battle for Japan between 1853 and 1945, including 1,068 convicted war criminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS ARMORED BRIGADE IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reviewed an armored military unit at an Army base in the southern county of Kaohsiung Wednesday.
Chen was accompanied by Vice President Annette Lu, Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of the General Staff Gen. Lee Tien-yu and Army Commander-in-Chief Chu Kai-sheng on the inspection tour.

After observing a tank drill, Chen lunched with officers and soldiers of the 564th Armored Brigade based in Kaohsiung County's A-lien Village as part of celebrations for the Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on June 11 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STANCE TOWARDS TAIWAN REMAINS UNCHANGED: PRESIDENT BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush on Tuesday reiterated that his administration's stance towards Taiwan remains unchanged.
The president made the reiteration while meeting with a Chinese National People's Congress delegation which is currently visiting Washington, D.C. at the invitation of Senator Ted Stevens (R-AK).

According to White House spokesman Scott McClellan, Bush received the members of the delegation at the request of the senator who "thought it would be great if the president could sit down and meet with them."
McClellan said that the president talked about three sets of issues, including the economy and trade, North Korea, and the Taiwan Strait, with the Chinese legislators during the meeting.
"And the president reiterated that our position remains the same, that nothing has changed when it comes to Taiwan, " the spokesman further said at a daily press briefing.

Bush already reaffirmed his stance on issues related to Taiwan at a White House press conference held May 31 by saying: "I made my position very clear and very consistent about Taiwan. The Taiwanese understand my position. The Chinese understand my position."
The president's position is "maintaining the status quo and resolving the Taiwan issue peacefully."
Bush also emphasized the importance of fair trade during his meeting with the Chinese lawmakers, expressing the hope that China can respect the international trade rules, McClellan also said.
Touching on the North Korea issue, McClellan said that the president also told Chinese lawmakers that he wants China to use its influence to urge North Korea to return to the six-party talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S WIFE DEPARTS FOR SHANGHAI VISIT

TEXT.P: Lien Fang Yu, wife of main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, left Taipei for Shanghai via Hong Kong Wednesday to attend the christening ceremony for a vessel there.
Mrs. Lien, accompanied by her two daughters, is keeping a low profile at the CKS International Airport on her private trip. Her two sons joined the trio in Hong Kong.
She has been invited to co-preside at the christening ceremony for the "China Peace, " which was built at a Shanghai shipyard at the commission of the Taipei-based Chinese Maritime Transport (CMT).

Mrs. Lien's last trip to China was April 26-May 3 when she accompanied her husband for a visit to Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai. During that visit, Lien Chan met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, marking the first meeting between the leaders of the KMT and the Communist Party (CPC) of China since the KMT fled the mainland after being defeated by the CPC in 1949. Hu doubles as CPC general secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Justices Rule U.S. Can Ban Medical Pot. The Supreme Court upheld the federal government's power to seize and destroy marijuana that is used as medicine by seriously ill patients, ruling that strict federal drug laws trump California's liberalized policy on pot.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Tobacco Escapes Huge Penalty; U.S. Seeks $10 Billion Instead of $130 Billion.
After eight months of courtroom argument, Justice Department lawyers abruptly upset a landmark civil racketeering case against the tobacco industry yesterday by asking for less than 8 percent of the expected penalty, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Govt okays youths' ideas for change.
Singapore's youths yesterday got a pat on the back from their minister, who made it clear to them: You can make your ideas work in this country.
Dr Vivian Balakrishnan sent out this strong signal when he said the Government had accepted some 55 of the 91 proposals for shaping Singapore's future which a group of young people submitted.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Oman invests $25B to build a deep blue tourism city.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Japas's UNSC bid dealt blow by U.S.
Japan will probably postpone submitting a resolution to expand the U.N. Security Council in light of an objection aired last week by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Foreign Ministry sources said Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: No destabilization - opposition
The opposition in the Senate yesterday dismissed charges by Malacanang that they are planning to overthrow the Arroyo administration. Also, several opposition senators denied Palace allegations that an alleged taped phone conversation between President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo and a Commission on Elections (Comelec) official came from them.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: PNP vows to quell any coup attempt
ECHOING an earlier warning by the Armed Forces, the Philippine National Police yesterday said the controversies and scandals rocking the administration of President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo were but a prelude to a larger scheme to overthrow it.
The Philippine Star: GMA: Erap on tape: Don't look at us
Saying only the government possesses the equipment to eavesdrop on telephone conversations, deposed President Joseph Estrada laughed off allegations by Malacanang yesterday that the opposition had engaged in illegal wiretapping.
The Manila Times: Palace: Erap lawyer claims he edited GMA tape
A former lawyer of deposed President Joseph Estrada said Tuesday he edited the tape of conversations between President Arroyo and a still unidentified person in which they discussed rigging the 2004 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES 2 VICE CHAIRMEN TO ENGAGE IN 'GENTLEMEN'S BATTLE'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Wednesday urged the two KMT vice chairmen who have registered to run for the party chairmanship in the July 16 election to engage in a "gentlemen's battle."
Lien made the remarks during a regular KMT Central Standing Committee meeting a day after Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng formally registered. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou registered Monday.

Despite strenuous efforts by many in the KMT to persuade Lien to stay on to lead the party, especially in view of the upcoming "three-in-one elections" -- or the simultaneous holding of city and county chief, city and county councilor, and village and township chief elections -- at the end of the year, Lien is determined to step down from the post. Wang had earlier said that if Lien wants to enter the race, then he will not run.
At Wednesday's meeting, Lien called for Ma and Wang to engage in a "gentlemen's race" and help usher in a new era for the nearly 110-year-old party.
July's election will mark the first time in the KMT's history that more than one candidate vie for the party's top post.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF BOARD TO MEET JUNE 10 TO SELECT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Board directors and supervisors of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) are scheduled to meet Friday, mainly to select a new chairman of the quasi-official intermediary body, SEF sources said Wednesday.
The SEF chairmanship post has been vacant since the death of its founding chairman, Koo Chen-fu, Jan. 3.

Chang Chun-hsiung, a former premier and former secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , is expected to be elected smoothly at Friday's board meeting as the new chairman of the SEF, which handles Taiwan's exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.
Actually, Friday's meeting is seen as merely a ceremonial occasion to formally endorse a recommendation that Premier Frank Hsieh has made.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman and spokesman You Ying-lung said that Chang is the "best choice" for the critical and symbolic post as Chang was the first DPP heavyweight who espoused the "replacing confrontation with cooperation" strategy toward China and as Chang's nomination will strengthen the government's "rapprochement- and cooperation-oriented" China policy.

Chang, 67, holds a law degree from National Taiwan University. After becoming a lawyer, he joined the legal corps defending opposition activists arrested during the 1979 Formosa Incident. He later entered politics, serving as an opposition lawmaker for 17 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. VOICES CONCERNS OVER CHINA'S MILITARY BUILDUP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Bush administration is very concerned about China's military buildup, White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Tuesday.

The spokesman made the comments at a press briefing in response to a reporter's question about whether U.S. President George W. Bush shares the concerns expressed in Singapore recently by Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld that China's military buildup could pose a threat to stability.
McClellan said that Rumsfeld's remarks clearly reflect the U.S. stance and its commitment to promoting stability and peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

"We are a nation at war on terrorism, " the spokesman said, adding that "there are serious threats that we face when it comes to proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and those weapons getting into the hands of terrorists."

Referring to Rumsfeld's remarks at the Fourth Asian Security Conference at the end of last month in Singapore, McClellan said that "the secretary spelled out some of the concerns we had and asked why it was necessary that this (China's military buildup) needed to be done."

"Peace and stability in the region is a priority for this administration. And we have concerns when a country is taking the steps that China is, and the secretary was simply expressing those concerns, " the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXPECTS CEC TO DEMARCATE CONSTITUENCIES FAIRLY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh expressed the hope Wednesday that the Central Election Commission will demarcate the new constituencies fairly.

Hsieh made the remarks in an Executive Yuan floor meeting while commenting on the constitutional amendments passed by the National Assembly a day earlier, which include changing the electoral system from the current multiple seats in one constituency to a "single seat, two votes" format, as well as reducing the number of legislative seats from 225 to 113.

Starting from the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, the Legislative Yuan will have only 113 seats and will be elected every four years. While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

Hsieh noted that the passing of the constitutional amendments marked the first step of reform and that the follow-up task will be for the Executive Yuan to amend the laws and redraw the constituency boundaries.
He described the demarcation of constituencies as "a politically charged task" and said the issue has been controversial in the experience of many other countries.
He expressed the hope that the CEC will solicit views from all sides on the demarcation of the new constituencies so that the task can be carried out in a "fair and objective" manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER WELCOME TO OFFER '319 SHOOTING' CLUES: CIB HEAD

TEXT.P: Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) Commissioner Hou You-yi urged independent Legislator Li Ao Wednesday to provide the police with a copy of an intelligence document that Li claims to have acquired from the United States to help solve the March 19, 2004 presidential election-eve shooting.

Li claimed earlier in the day that he holds intelligence information obtained from the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency indicating that the real shooter in the 319 shooting is a man surnamed Lee who remains at large even though Taiwan law enforcement authorities have left no stone unturned in their investigations since March 20 last year.

Hou urged Li to provide relevant information to the CIB, saying that the police hold no prerequisites or assumptions of any kind regarding the case and that his bureau would welcome any information that could lead to solving the case.
Li also said that he will mail Vice President Annette Lu a copy of the CIA intelligence information, which he said shows that the shooter was targeting Lu alone in an attempt to wound her.

A "319 truth investigation commission" was formed last October under a statute passed by the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan, but the commission got nowhere because it encountered heavy criticism and the Council of Grand Justices ruled the all-powerful commission unconstitutional and the administration refused to cooperate with it.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" claims that the shooting and the ensuing activation of a national security mechanism barred many police and military servicemen -- traditionally supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" -- from leaving their posts to vote, unfairly swaying the election in Chen's favor. The alliance filed two lawsuits to challenge the election and the result of the election, both of which were thrown out by the courts because the plaintiffs failed to provide any evidence to support their allegations.

A grueling full recount of the votes demanded by the "pan-blue alliance" confirmed that Chen won the election by a margin of a little more than 25,000 votes, instead of the original figure of 29,518 votes, out of more than 13 million ballots cast.
Although a number of people were questioned and investigated, and even though the CIB claimed earlier this year that "major progress" had been made, the shooting case remains unsolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE PRAISED FOR UNCOVERING FAKE CLAIM BY TAIPEI POLITICIAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh commended the police Wednesday for laying bare a false claim by a Taipei politician that food offerings at funerals are being resold in the city for human consumption.
Speaking at the Cabinet's weekly meeting, Hsieh said the incident is one involving the credibility of a politician and has resulted in widespread public distrust in the government and media.
The efficient action taken by the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) has rebuilt public confidence in the government and has been very helpful to social stability, Hsieh said.

Taipei City Councilor Wang Yu-cheng of the opposition People First Party (PFP) released filmed images last week that he claimed support his claim that workers at city government-run funeral parlors are reselling funeral offerings to certain restaurants in the city and that rice offered to the deceased is also being reused to process preserved tofu.
The claim triggered a public scare and reportedly affected the business of many restaurants located at places insinuated by Wang as where the funeral offerings ended up.

However, CIB agents found out Tuesday that the alleged funeral offering collectors appearing in the film were just actors, prompting Wang to admit that the images were "simulated" and staged by his hirelings. He apologized to the public for his sham.
According to lawyer Kao Yung-cheng, the affected restaurants can demand compensation from Wang if they can prove they have suffered business losses as a result of the incident.
Wang might also face criminal charges for making false allegations, Kao said.
Taipei city government spokesman Yu Tzu-hsiang said the city government will not file a defamation suit against Wang because the truth has been clarified.

On offenses such as forgery and humiliating civil servants and a government agency, in which Wang is also allegedly involved, Yu pointed out that these are offenses subject to public prosecution and that it will be up to prosecutors to determine if an indictment is warranted.
Also Wednesday, the PFP caucus at the Taipei city council recommended that the party expel Wang over the incident. It also apologized to the public for the panic and disturbance caused by Wang.

Caucus convener Wang Hsin-yi said using simulated images as if they are true evidence is a serious offense that has not only destroyed Wang's credibility but has also damaged the image of the PFP, and that the caucus will not tolerate such behavior.

A tearful Wang Yu-cheng said losing his PFP membership is "the severest punishment" for what he claimed was his "failure to properly supervise his assistants" and that he will consider resigning from the post of Taipei city councilor to assume his "political responsibility."
Meanwhile, on behalf of the Taipei city council, speaker Wu Pi-chu also apologized to the public for the uproar.
Wu said she will advise councilors to be more careful about their speeches and behavior in the future.
Liu Yao-jen, a whip of the Democratic Progressive Party caucus at the city council, said Wang should assume total responsibility because his behavior has damaged the image of the city council.
The councilors will discuss whether to refer Wang to the disciplinary committee for punishment, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: C.I.A. Is Reviewing Its Security Policy for Recruiting Translators.
The Central Intelligence Agency of the Unites States is reviewing security procedures that have led the agency to turn away large numbers of Arabic-language linguists and other potential recruits with skills avidly sought by the agency since the attacks of 2001, Congressional and intelligence officials say. Many of those rejected, the officials say, have been first-generation Americans who bring the linguistic facility and cultural knowledge that the C.I.A. has been trying to develop in seeking to improve its performance in penetrating terrorist organizations and otherwise gathering intelligence in the Middle East and South Asia. Among the possibilities under review are revised standards for background checks and the creation of new job categories subject to less stringent requirements. But the C.I.A. is likely to resist anything that would be perceived as a scaling back of security restrictions.
Wall Street Journal: GM Plans to Cut 25,000 Jobs By '08 in Restructuring.
General Motors Corp., struggling with highcosts and declining sales, unveiled plans to cut its North American work force by about 25,000 workers by 2008 as part of a broader restructuring, but the plan drew mixed reviews from analysts and investors and skepticism from the company's biggest union. GM's North American op erations, which posted a loss of US$1.3 billion for the first quarter, already have been eliminating about 8,000 jobs a year through a combination of attrition and early-retirement programs since 2002, part of a gradual decline in the size of its work force.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Secret Police Directive Assailed.
An independent investigation into a police crackdown in Blagoveshchensk late last year has brought to light a secret Interior Ministry document that allows police to place suspects in "filtration stations" and expands their authority to use firearm s in violation of the law, human rights activists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE FEMALE POLITICIANS JOIN ADMINISTRATIVE TEAM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday he has decided to name three women politicians to join his administrative team as part of the government's efforts to promote gender equality in political participation.

The three new Cabinet members are former Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying, who will serve as a vice minister of the interior, and two former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators -- Chiu Yi-ying, who will serve as vice chairman of the Council for Hakka Affairs and Chou Ya-shu, who will be a commissioner of the Fair Trade Commission.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh noted that women account for a mere 15 percent of the Cabinet at present and that major women's rights groups have been pushing the government to recruit more outstanding women into the administration.
"The trio's recruitment is part of our response to this appeal, " Hsieh said, adding that the government will continue to promote competent women politicians into decision-making ranks.
During the meeting, Hsieh also introduced two new department heads -- Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Chang Kuo-lung and Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Minister Lee Yung-teh.
Both Chang, an anti-nuclear pioneer in Taiwan, and Lee, who was promoted from CHA vice chairman, attended Wednesday's Cabinet meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT UNVEILS 10 MORE NOMINEES FOR CITY, COUNTY CHIEF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) unveiled 10 nominees for the year-end city and county chief elections Wednesday, bringing to 16 the number of its nominees for the 23 city and county chief positions up for grabs.
The nominees for the remaining seven cities and counties are expected to be passed by the KMT Central Standing Committee June 22.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said that after deciding the nominees in the primaries, the KMT will consult with its allies, the People First Party and New Party, hoping to set up a mechanism among them to decide upon final candidates to represent all three opposition parties.

KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said the KMT Central Standing Committee had approved the results of the just-concluded second-stage primaries to nominate Legislator Chou Hsi-wei in Taipei County, Ilan Mayor Lu Kuo-hua in Ilan County, Legislator Cho Po-yuan in Changhua County, Legislator Hsu Shu-po in Yunlin County, and former Legislator Chen Jung-sheng in Tainan City.

The nominees in five other cities and counties are incumbent Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, Legislator Huang Ming-hui in Chiayi City, Legislator Kuo Tien-tsai in Tainan County, Makung Mayor Wang Chien-fa in Penghu and incumbent Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Sheng-shan.
The KMT has completed its nominations in Keelung and Taichung cities, and Taichung, Nantou, Kaohsiung, and Pingtung counties in its first-stage nomination operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 55.87 points to close at 6,161.66.
The bourse opened at 6,121.34 and fluctuated between 6,170.47 and 6,121.21 during trading. A total of 3.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.46 billion (US$2.64 billion).

All but one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up 0.7 percent, foodstuff issues up 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares up 0.3 percent, cement stocks up 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares up 1.3 percent, construction issues up 1.8 percent and banking and financial shares up 0.6 percent. Pulp and paper issues lost 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 550 to 264, with 185 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA'S YOUNGER BROTHER ON LOW-PROFILE VISIT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The younger brother of the Dalai Lama is making a low-profile visit to Taiwan, a local cable television channel reported Wednesday.

Tendzin Choegyal, who at the age of four was recognized as the 15th Ngari Rinpoche, a title that is passed through reincarnation, is one of the top aides of Tibet's spiritual leader at the Tibetan Buddhism headquarters-in-exile in Dharamsala, India.

Ngari Rinpoche, who was elected to the Tibetan parliament-in-exile, where he served until 1995, is in Taipei mainly to attend the June 10 commencement of a bodyguard of the Dalai Lama, who has been attending the Central Police University.
Ngari Rinpoche has intentionally kept his visit low-profile and he will not meet any Taiwan officials during his stay, according to the TV report.

Interviewed by the same TV channel, the Dalai Lama's bodyguard said he has learned a lot at Central Police University over the past few years, particularly affairs pertaining to national security and anti-terrorism efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY FAIL TO BUY KEY WEAPONS FROM U.S. DUE TO PROCRASTINATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that procrastination in the legislature might jeopardize Taiwan's chances of purchasing important U.S. weapon systems and consequently cause the armed forces to miss an opportunity to upgrade its defensive capabilities.
Speaking during a lunch at the headquarters of the 564th Armored Brigade based in the A-lien rural township in the southern county of

Kaohsiung, Chen said the opposition lawmakers' continued blockage of the passage of a bill on major arms procurements initiated by the Democratic Progressive Party administration has worried him tremendously, as it will further aggravate the military imbalance across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen stressed that the procurement plan, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, will neither crowd out the overall government budget plans nor affect spending related to the people's wellbeing.

The president reviewed a tank drill at the 564th Armored Brigade before lunching with officers and soldiers of the brigade as part of celebrations for the Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on June 11 this year.
Chen was accompanied by Vice President Annette Lu, Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of the General Staff Gen. Lee Tien-yu and Army Commander-in-Chief Chu Kai-sheng on the inspection tour.

The window of opportunity is closing for the Republic of China to purchase a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said at the Legislative Yuan May 24, adding that the U.S. has given Taiwan till the end of May to buy the planes, otherwise they will be sold elsewhere.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 93 PERCENT OF POLLUTED FARMLAND CLEANED: EPA

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Wednesday that 93 percent of polluted farmland has been cleaned and removed from a watch list over the past three years.
EPA officials also said that it is expected that the farmland can be regenerated in one year at the earliest.

The officials said that as of the end of 2002, farmland polluted by excessive heavy metals totaled 261 hectares. Changhua County accounted for the most at 183 hectares, followed by Hsinchu City at 32.7 hectares and Taoyuan County at 11.4 hectares.

They noted that to protect the safety of the public, crops grown on the polluted farmland have been rooted out and destroyed. Farmers have also been prohibited from growing crops for human consumption and more than NT$40 million (US$1.269 million) in reimbursement for farmers during the fallow period was issued during the two-and-a-half-year period.

The officials said that the main cause of the farmland pollution is polluted irrigation water. To avoid similar incidents from happening again, they are targeting Taoyuan, Changhua and Kaohsiung counties for improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS REFUSE TO MEET AIT OFFICIAL OVER ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: No opposition legislators are expected to show up for a Thursday luncheon hosted by an American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) official to discuss Taiwan's latest arms procurement plan from the United States.

Douglas Paal, director of the AIT's Taipei office, who is the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan, invited the leaders and various members of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee to the luncheon at his official residence after the Cabinet-proposed budget for the NT$480 billion (US$15.33 billion) arms procurement package was blocked by the opposition-controlled legislature for two legislative sessions.

Those invited include Lee Wen-chung, Lu Shiow-yen and Lin Yu-fang, committee co-conveners from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), opposition Kuomintang and opposition People First Party, respectively. Other committee members invited are Shen Fa-hui from the DPP and Ho Min-hao from the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
While Ho is set to leave for Vietnam Thursday for an investment fact-finding tour and cannot attend the luncheon, Lu and Lin have turned down the invitation, citing a conflict of interests.

Expressing regret at the decisions by the opposition legislators, Lee said the opposition should not have over- exaggerated the consequences of such a meeting because it is "very normal" for a representative of the U.S. government to exchange views with Taiwan legislators and even lobby for their support for the arms procurement package.
Although the KMT and PFP claim they are not against arms procurements, they are doing just the opposite and are sacrificing Taiwan's security for the sake of political wrangling, Lee alleged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.043 to close at NT$31.269.
A total of US$801 million changed hands during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.226 and was traded between NT$31.173 and NT$31.273.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WARNS AGAINST TRAVEL TO HAITI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged the public Wednesday to refrain from traveling to the Caribbean nation of Haiti for the time being because of its political instability and deteriorating public order.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the ministry has raised its travel alert for Haiti from orange, or elevated, to red, or the highest level on its alert system.

Even though the United Nations has sent peacekeeping forces to Haiti, Lu said, the political situation there has yet to completely stabilize and its public order has shown signs of further deterioration.
Just last week, Lu said, unknown armed men attacked a market and a police station in the Haitian capital of Port-au-Prince, killing at least 10 people.
For security concerns, Lu said, local citizens should avoid traveling there at the moment.
Meanwhile, Lu went on, no Taiwan citizens were injured in a tour bus traffic accident the previous day in British Columbia, Canada.

Two Taiwan citizens were aboard the tour bus when the accident occurred, and 15 passengers were injured, Lu said, adding that Taiwan's representative office in Vancouver will offer the two Taiwan passengers necessary assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUAO FISHERMEN TO PROTEST AGAINST JAPANESE PATROL SHIPS

TEXT.P: Fishermen in Suao, northeastern Taiwan, will mobilize between 60 and 70 fishing boats to an area off the coast of northern Taiwan Thursday to stage a protest against Japanese patrol ships.

Suao fishery official Lin Kuang-hui noted that Taiwan's economic zone overlaps that of Japan's and that when Taiwan fishing ships are operating in waters off northern or northeastern Taiwan, they are often chased away by Japanese patrol ships.

A large number of Taiwan fishing boats have been seized by the Japanese authorities and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have to pay for their release, seriously undermining the operating rights of the fishermen, Lin pointed out.
Lin said the government has yet to address the problem of the overlapping economic zones.

To express their anger, he said, a large contingent of fishing boats will converge in waters between the Tiaoyutais, a tiny group of islets lying about 75 nautical miles northeast of Keelung, and Pengchiayu, about 25 nautical miles off Keelung harbor, and he did not rule out the possibility that the vessels will deliberately go into the overlapping part of the economic zones to confront the Japanese patrol boats.
Coast guard authorities in Suao said that to prevent conflicts between Taiwan fishermen and Japanese patrol ships, they will send a ship to escort the protest ships.

Meanwhile, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported Wednesday that it has sent three ships to handle the situation after receiving reports that four Taiwanese fishing ships were being chased away by Japanese patrol boats while operating in waters 60 nautical miles northeast of Suao that day.
CGA officials stressed that to protect the rights of Taiwan's exclusive economic zone and the safety of its fishermen, they send ships regularly to waters north, east and south of Taiwan.
As long as the fishermen operate within the legal boundaries, their safety and rights will be fully protected, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June gained 71 points to close at 6,131, with 29,611 contracts traded.

TAIEX Index futures for July rose 74 points to close at 6,027, with 2,615 contracts changing hands, while September futures gained 56 points to close at 5,929, with 786 contracts traded. December futures moved up 57 points to end at 5,920, with 11 contract transactions, while March futures moved up 66 points to close at 5,920, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,052 for June, 5,953 for July, 5,861 for September, 5,888 for December and 5,899 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly up.

June TE futures moved up 4.3 points to close at 248.6, with 5,956 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 4.05 points to close at 245.25, with 720 contracts changing hands. September TE futures grew 4.1 points to finish at 241.25, with eight contract transactions, while December TE futures went up 4.25 points to close at 240.8, with two contracts traded.
March TE futures lost 0.5 points to close at 237.4, with 10 contracts changing hands.

June TF futures gained five points to close at 948, with 2,721 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures moved up 4.6 points to close at 934.6, with 483 contracts traded. September TF futures rose 5 points to close at 920, with 24 contracts traded, while December TF futures were up 9.8 points to close at 919.8, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL BIOTECH PARK IN PINGTUNG TO BE COMPLETED IN MARCH

TEXT.P: The construction of an agricultural biotech industrial park in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, is expected to be completed in March next year, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.
COA officials said that 21 manufacturers have passed the screening and will enter the park, with three others still being assessed.

To cope with the impact on agriculture caused by Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2002, the COA, the Council for Economic Planning and Development and other related government agencies have been heavily promoting the agricultural biotech park.

Agriculture-heavy Pingtung County was chosen as the location of the park because its agricultural, forestry, fishery and poultry production sectors have ranked among the top among the 23 cities and counties in Taiwan.
The park will cover around 233 hectares and the total cost of construction will be around NT$2.46 billion (US$78.09 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED NOT TO MISREAD TAIWAN'S CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) (By C.F. Lee and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: An American scholar urged China Tuesday not to misinterpret the constitutional reforms in Taiwan as representing a move toward independence.

Richard C. Bush, senior fellow and director of the Center for Northeast Asia Policy Studies at the Brookings Institution, told a group of visiting Taiwanese journalists that Beijing's attitude and reaction to Taiwan's constitutional reforms are important signals that will indicate China's bottom line.
Bush said the U.S. government has no reason to oppose constitutional amendments that are aimed at enhancing government efficiency in Taiwan and strengthening the country's democratic development.

Taiwan's National Assembly passed a constitutional amendment package Tuesday to abolish the assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, to reduce the number of legislative seat from the present 225 to 113 and to adopt a "single seat, two votes" electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007.

President Chen Shui-bian said the success of the constitutional reforms has paved the way for a second phase of reforms, which officials said will be designed to enhance government efficiency and will not involve sensitive issues such as changes to the country's sovereignty, territorial boundaries or official designation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLUEPRINT FOR 2ND CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS DUE IN A WEEK: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office will hammer out a blueprint for the second phase of constitutional reforms in one week, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

The conclusion of a week-long constitutional amendment session by the ad-hoc National Assembly Tuesday means that the second phase reforms can kick off immediately, and the Presidential Office has been working on a blueprint detailing its form and the steps that can be taken, Yu said.

As the Constitution represents the fundamentals of a nation's laws, a new round of constitution revision needs to be conducted based on a national consensus obtained through comprehensive participation by people from all walks of life, the top presidential aide said, adding that this will be a time-consuming task.

To honor the promise made by President Chen Shui-bian to put forward a new constitution before he steps down in May 2008, the constitutional amendment proposals must be approved by the Legislative Yuan before the end of the first half of 2007 to allow for a public referendum to decide the fate of the issues, Chen's aides said.

The results of various public opinion surveys carried out by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) show that most of the people in Taiwan favor amending the Constitution, which is widely viewed as out of date, they claimed, adding that it is why the DPP feels it necessary to introduce a second phase of constitution reforms.
Chen said a day earlier that he hopes to create a "timely, appropriate and tailor-made" constitution for Taiwan in 2008 and that he will invite the opposition leaders to join forces in the task.

Chen said that he had already asked Yu to quickly form a constitution amending committee under the Presidential Office to promote public awareness and understanding of the course of Taiwan's democratization.
Despite the president's claim that he hopes for across the board participation by the opposition camp and the whole of society, various opposition parties have voiced disagreement with his plan.

Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the Central Policy Committee of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Chen should not seek a new round of constitutional revision at present, since the latest round has just ended. The government should instead concentrate on creating a better livelihood for the people, he said.
He made it clear that the KMT is opposed to a new phase of constitutional amendments or any attempts to write a new constitution.

Chin Ching-sheng, secretary-general of the second-largest opposition People First Party (PFP) blamed the DPP and the KMT for adding new uncertainties to the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and for putting Taiwan's future at greater risk by endorsing the package of the just-concluded round of constitutional amendments.

Chin was referring to one of the amendments that grants the right of referendum to the public to decide constitutional amendments proposed by the Legislative Yuan. The PFP views it as an approach that could invite moves toward "de jure" Taiwan independence, a situation that he claimed will lead to a catastrophe for the country.

Chien Lin Whei-jun, a former legislator and a National Assembly member of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) questioned the possibilities of a second round of constitutional reform that the DPP wants.

The amendment that requires a three-quarters majority vote by the Legislative Yuan has actually killed the chances for any new constitutional revisions in the future, she claimed, pointing out that under these circumstances, the TSU will continue to advocate a new constitution for Taiwan through a public referendum that requires a lower approval threshold.

The mission-oriented 300-member National Assembly was automatically dissolved and passed into history Tuesday after deputies voted 249 to 48 in favor of a package of constitutional amendments put forward by the Legislative Yuan last August.

Reducing the number of seats at the Legislative Yuan to 113 from 225, adopting a "one seat, two votes" electoral system and providing the public with the right of referendum to decide future constitutional amendment proposals raised by the Legislative Yuan were among the key issues in the package.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING HAKKA WILL ENRICH TAIWAN'S CULTURE: HAKKA AFFAIRS CHIEF

TEXT.P: Lee Yung-teh officially took the helm of the Council for Hakka Affairs Wednesday, saying that he will highlight Hakka culture so that the entire cultural spectrum in Taiwan can be enriched.

At a news conference, Lee, who has been acting chairman of the council for the past three months, said because of the efforts of the council over the last four years, Hakka culture, which was on the wane, has rebounded.
Citing a survey conducted by the council, Lee said the number of people using the Hakka dialect has fallen by 2 percent every year because of the "unfavorable political climate."

In 2002, Lee said, only 11.6 percent of Hakka children under the age of 13 could speak their mother tongue, but in 2004 the percentage rose to 13.8 percent, thanks to the establishment of the Council of Hakka Affairs and the launch of a TV channel that exclusively uses Hakka.
People concerned with the preservation of Hakka culture have been delighted by this change because if Hakkas cannot speak their own dialect they will lose their unique cultural identity, Lee said.
Lee promised to keep promoting Hakka culture by encouraging not only Hakkas but also other people to learn the Hakka dialect to enrich the country's diverse culture.
Lee, who was the council's vice chairman, took the place of former chairman Lo Wen-chia in March when Lo quit to assembly a campaign for the year-end Taipei County magistrate election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WANTS TO SHARE JOYS OF HIS SON'S WEDDING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian looks forward to sharing with the public his joy at his son's upcoming wedding, a Presidential Office spokesman said Wednesday.

Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, made the remarks at a news conference where he released a collection of seven of Chen Chih-chung's wedding photos and a copy of the wedding invitation.
According to Chen Wen-tsung, President Chen asked his department to assist in unveiling the photos to meet the media's demand and share with the public the first family's delight.
Chen Chih-chung, who obtained a master's degree in law from the University of California at Berkeley in May, will be married June 18.
Chen Wen-tsung stressed that the president has kept a low-profile toward his son's engagement and wedding.
"President Chen will not use public resources for his son's marriage. Only the first family's relatives and friends have assisted in preparatory work," Chen Wen-tsung said.

Meanwhile, President Chen wrote in an article to be published Thursday in an online weekly bearing his nickname A-bian that he hopes his two children can learn to adopt a business-as-usual attitude toward the limelight shone on them due to their status as members of the first family.
In the article, the president also expressed his hope that his two children and all other local young people can learn to "be yourself and be responsible."
The president's daughter, Chen Hsing-yu, a mother of two young sons, just obtained a master's degree from National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Clinical Dentistry last Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTORS CONFIDENT OF DOING WELL AT PITTSBURGH SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 7 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A group of inventors from Taiwan led by Taiwan Inventors Association President Chen Chung-tai said Tuesday in New York that they are confident that they will do well at the annual INPEX, America's largest invention trade show that will be held June 8-11 in Pittsburgh.
The 20 Taiwanese inventors made the remarks at a news conference held at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York.

Chen, who also led a Taiwan mission to take part in the 33rd International Exhibition of Inventions, New Techniques and Products of Geneva in early April, said that he and the other members are confident of grabbing a good number of medals at this year's INPEX with their 20 original ideas.

According to Chen, the 23 products presented by the Taiwan inventors in the Geneva show were all given medals -- 13 gold medals, seven silvers and three bronzes. In the 2004 INPEX show, Taiwan seized five gold medals, three silvers and four bronzes, he noted.
Since 2000, Taiwanese inventors have gained more than 4,000 U.S. patents, ranking fourth in the world after their counterparts from the United States, Japan and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, June 9:
10:30, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will attend the opening ceremony of the 2005 World Digital Audio Broadcasting (DAB) Forum at the Splendor Hotel in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.

12: 30, The National Science Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
13: 00, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
13:30, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will visit the detention center of illegal immigrants from China in Tungshan village in Ilan County.
14: 00, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh will attend the launch at Hanhsien International Hotel in Kaohsiung City of a program for narrowing the digital gap.
14: 30, The Chinese Institute of Engineers will hold its annual congress at the Chinese Petroleum Corp. Building in Taipei.
15: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Taipei Guest House.

17: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
19:00, The diplomatic corps will host a dinner party at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei to entertain Premier Frank Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S PLANNED LEGISLATION WOULD FURTHER HURT TIES: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Relations across the Taiwan Strait will suffer yet another setback if China goes ahead with its reported plan to legislate a so-called "emergency law" in connection with its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, an official said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a visiting delegation of state legislatures from the U.S. Mid-Atlantic region, which covers Delaware, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Washington, D.C.

According to media reports, Wu said, China will work on its so-called "emergency law" this year. If the planned legislation is indeed a complementary act to its anti-secession law enacted in March of this year, Wu said, the move would definitely deal yet another severe blow to cross-strait relations.
Such an act would also have a grave impact on Taiwan's policy toward cross-strait ties, Wu added.

China's anti-secession legislation, which codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, has drawn a strong backlash from the people of Taiwan and serious concerns in the international community.
Wu told his guests that cross-strait relations have remained grim because China has continued to increase the number of its missiles and has added new types of submarines.
"China's accelerated military buildup has not only escalated cross-strait tensions but has also made Japan feel uneasy," Wu said.

Moreover, Wu said, China has continued its efforts to squeeze Taiwan out of the international arena. In May, he recalled that China used its diplomatic clout to block Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the governing body of the World Health Organization -- as an observer.
For their part, the leading state assembly members from the Mid-Atlantic region said they will continue to speak for Taiwan's cause to join the WHA and other major international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WELCOMES CHINESE TOURISTS: CITY OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 8 (CNA) (By H. M. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei City keenly welcomes Chinese tourists and is doing its best to improve its services and facilities to serve that end, a ranking official of the Taipei City Government in charge of tourism affairs said Wednesday.

Speaking in a new conference held in Hong Kong, Taipei Tourism Commission CEO Kang Ping-cheng said that the city will be very happy to receive visitors from China and expressed his hope to lead a municipal delegation to China next year to help promote Taiwan to Chinese tourists, as Taiwan is expected to open in the near future.

Kang said that he fervently hopes for direct flights between Taipei's Sung Shan Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao Airport and he pointed out that more than 70 percent of tourists from Hong Kong and Macau that travel to Taiwan will pay a visit to Taipei. Over 136,000 tourists from the two areas visited Taiwan during the first four months of this year, he noted.
Taipei, Taiwan's largest city, is a place where traditional culture and modern elements are delicately blended, he said, assuring that visitors would not get tired of it easily.
According to Kang, hotels in Taipei are able to provide around 20,000 rooms for visitors and various new hotels are being built to accommodate an additional 3,000 to 5,000 visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE WITHOUT PRECONDITIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 7 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States looks forward to seeing the two sides of the Taiwan Strait engage in any for of dialogue with no political strings or preconditions, a State Department official said Tuesday.

Christopher R. Hill, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks during a hearing on the "Emergence of China Throughout Asia: Security and Economic Consequences for the U.S., " organized by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations Subcommittee on East Asia and the Pacific.
"We believe that recently stated positions on both sides of the Strait incorporate elements of flexibility that could form the basis of substantive dialogue," Hill said.

While the recent trips to Beijing by Taiwan's two opposition leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong -- have the potential to be helpful, Hill said it is crucial that China take the important next step of reaching out to duly elected representatives on Taiwan.

"We encourage any form of cross-Strait dialogue and believe that the unofficial KMT and PFP visits have the potential to serve as an important first step in the resumption of a dialogue between Beijing and Taipei. It is crucial, however, that China take the important next step of reaching out to elected representatives on Taiwan, " he added.

Hill also pointed out that Beijing's strategy on Taiwan is based on a refusal to renounce the use of force while simultaneously encouraging economic integration by making itself attractive to Taiwan investors.

"China also seeks to leverage its economic influence with countries of the Asia-Pacific region and beyond to generate support for the PRC's stand on Taiwan. We saw this recently when a number of countries like Burma, Cambodia and Laos issued statements in March welcoming China's unhelpful Anti-secession Law," Hill said.

He further said the longstanding U.S. position, based on its one- China policy and commitments under the three U.S.-China joint communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act, has been that cross-Strait differences must be resolved peacefully through dialogue in a manner that meets the aspirations of people on both sides of the Strait.

To that end, Hill said the U.S. government strongly encourages cross-Strait dialogue of all forms. He added that the anti-secession legislation adopted by China's National People's Congress was an unfortunate and unhelpful step that did not contribute to cross-Strait stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU TO ADDRESS DEMOCRACY MEETING IN JAPAN VIA TELECONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that she will address the Asia-Pacific regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to be held June 10 in Tokyo.

Speaking at a tea party she hosted at the Presidential Office to entertain journalists, Lu said that the meeting will be jointly organized by the Taiwan-based DPU Coordinating Office and the Japan-Taiwan Parliamentarian Amity Association.

More than 100 lawmakers and representatives from Taiwan, South Korea, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Australia and host Japan will take part in the meeting which will be jointly chaired by herself and Takeo Hiranuma, head of the Japanese pro-Taiwan parliamentary group.
The main topics of the meeting will be Asian civilization and technological developments in Asia.
Lu said that she will address the meeting via teleconference instead of traveling to Japan in person to chair the conference so as not to put undue pressure on the Japanese government.
"It is a great breakthrough for the meeting be held in Japan, " Lu stressed, adding that Huang Mao-hsiung, vice chairman of the DPU Coordinating Office, will attend the meeting.
The DPU, an international organization founded by Lu, is aimed at serving as a platform for personnel and resources exchanges around the Pacific Rim.

The organization will be officially established Aug. 14 in Taipei, Lu said, adding that at least two heads of state, vice presidents of various other countries, lawmakers, leaders of political and academic fields and civic groups from more than 20 countries will attend the DPU inauguration.
In her speech to be delivered at the Tokyo meeting, Lu went on, she will explain the DPU's main concept and the core values of democracy, peace and freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IS USING ECONOMIC STRENGTH AS LEVERAGE AGAINST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: China is using its growing trade and investment ties to achieve its political ends, which includes continuing to isolate Taiwan, Christopher R. Hill, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs warned Tuesday.

Giving testimony at the Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs under the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate, Hill said China's strategy on Taiwan is based on a refusal to renounce the use of force while simultaneously encouraging economic integration by making itself attractive to Taiwan investors.
China also seeks to leverage its economic influence with countries in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond to generate support for its stand on Taiwan, Hill went on.
Citing as an example, Hill said a number of countries like Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos have issued statements in March welcoming China's unhelpful Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: REDRAWING VOTING DISTRICTS PITS RULING PARTY AGAINST OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: One day after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the major opposition party of Kuomintang (KMT) working together to railroad through the National Assembly a package of constitutional amendments, the two has pit against each other Wednesday on how to redistrict the constituencies of lawmakers in conformity with the amendments.

The DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang spoke out against the KMT's idea of having an independent agency other than the Central Election Commission redraw the election districts with the approval of the legislature.
The KMT claimed the Central Election Commission has debased itself into a rubber stamp of the DPP and could not be expected to do the job impartially.
Lee said the redistricting will redraw the country's political map and therefore has to be done by the Central Election Commission or an ad hoc agency free of political influence.

If an ad hoc agency is set up to do this, Lee said political parties should refrain from interfering with its work by having as few as possible party representatives in it, and members of the agency appointed by political parties should not exceed half of the total.
As the lawmakers will bear the brunt of the redistricting, the legislature should not be given the right to approve it, Lee argued.

DPP caucus whip William Lai said that legislators can hardly be expected not to interfere with the process and giving them the right to approve the redistricting is to give them the power to pull the strings behind the scenes.

KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, who is the chief of the party's Policy Coordination Committee, said his party's idea is negotiable; the first thing to do is to enact a law governing the organization of the Central Election Commission to ensure its independence from political influence.

But the KMT's proposal to give the Legislative Yuan the final say in reforming voting districts has won applause from the People First Party (PFP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , the two other opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan.
Legislator Lee Yung-ping of the PFP said the Central Election Commission has already been controlled by the ruling DPP and could not be trusted to do redistricting without bias.
She suggested the Legislative Yuan form a commission to do the work by itself.

TSU Legislator Huang Shih-cho shared Lee's view of having the Legislative Yuan preside over the redistricting, saying that the Central Election Commission is sure to gerrymander to give the ruling party an unfair advantage in elections.
Only the Legislative Yuan, which keep its fingers on the pulse of the people, can redraw the constituencies to the public's satisfaction, Huang claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 9, or the third day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," "Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned by the Nuremberg tribunal to hang for "crimes against humanity." In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Richard M. Hoban, vice-commander of the US Air Force Logistics Command, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the mainland Chinese communist regime.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Mainland China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew appoints Yang Chao-hsiang, former vice minister of education and current chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin Ching-chiang as education minister.
1999: The Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China is formally inaugurated in Taipei to facilitate bilateral exchanges.
2000: Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung confers a medal upon Oleg Lobov, head of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, in recognition of his contributions to Taipei-Moscow relations.
2001: The Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand and the Republic of China's Taipei Zoo signs a memorandum to promote the exchange of animals between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you do not study poetry, you cannot make yourself agreeable in conversation. If you do not study the arts, you will lack judgment and taste."

DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI WON'T CUT DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 8 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Haiti will not cut its longstanding diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, ROC Ambassador to Haiti Yang Cheng-da said Wednesday.

Yang made the remarks after the Washington Times reported that China has been pushing the Haitian interim government to sever diplomatic ties with Taiwan in exchange for its consent to extend the mandate for the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Haiti.

Even though China has been pressuring Haiti to cut its diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Yang said, the Haitian Foreign Affairs Ministry has on many occasions announced that the Caribbean country is unlikely to change its diplomatic policy.
Moreover, Yang said, senior Haitian officials have also reaffirmed that Haitian interim President Boniface Alexandre's plan to visit Taiwan in mid-July remains unchanged.
Despite China's pressure, Yang said he is convinced that Haiti's interim government will not switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERMEN MOBILIZE NEARLY 50 VESSELS IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: Suao fisherman mobilized nearly 50 Taiwan fishing boats to stage a protest against Japanese patrol vessels in waters off northeastern Taiwan Thursday.
The fishermen mobilized fishing boats operating off Suao, northeastern Taiwan at 4 a.m. to stage the protest.
White banners that read "Are fishermen second-rate citizens? " "Encroachment on our traditional fishing grounds! " and "Attach importance to the rights of fishermen!" were tied on the boats.
To avoid possible confrontation between the fishing boats and Japanese patrol boats, the Coast Guard Administration sent seven ships, led by a 917-ton vessel, to escort the Taiwan fishing boats.
The fishermen wanted to confront Japanese patrol ships, which are often in the area to chase them away, so as to arouse international attention, but no patrol ships showed up.
Japan only sent several reconnaissance planes to monitor the situation, and the protest ended peacefully at 6:30 a.m.

As Taiwan's economic zone overlaps that of Japan's, the Ministry of the Interior at the end of 2003 drew a provisional line within the Republic of China's 200-mile exclusive economic zone at the mid-point between the overlapping zones.

Taiwan fishermen generally stay within this boundary, but Japanese patrol boats have chased away Taiwan fishing boats several times recently, leading the fishermen to complain that their legal fishing grounds are being encroached upon.

In addition, a total of 13 Suao fishing boats have been seized by Japan while operating in Taiwan's economic zone since 2001, and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.
Suao fishery official Lin Kuang-hui noted that the fishermen staged the "spontaneous" protest to vent their long-term anger and misgivings.

Lin said the fishermen hope that the large-scale protest will drive home their call that the government step up protection of fishermen that stay within the legal boundaries, and that the government embark on negotiations with Japan on the problem of overlapping economic zones.

Another fishery official, Chen Chien-chung, said overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon have been long-term problems, and if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASKS OLYMPIC COMMITTEE TO CORRECT NAME
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 9 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan asked the International Olympic Committee (IOC) on Thursday to correct the mistaken designation of Taiwan as "Taiwan, Province of China" appearing on an IOC Web page.

Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee President Huang Ta-chou said that his committee protested to the IOC and asked for a correction as soon as it discovered the error and that the IOC has promised to change the name to "Chinese Taipei" -- the one Taiwan registered with the IOC -- as soon as possible.
Huang said he believes the matter to be a simple technical error that is not related to politics.
According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu, this is not the first time that the IOC has made similar errors.
The error in question appears in the country list of the on-line registration form for the 117th IOC session, which is set for July 6-9 in Singapore.

In Geneva, an IOC spokeswoman, Sandrine Chappuis, told the CNA that the error is the result of the IOC using the standard country names established by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO).
Chappuis stressed this is a purely technical problem and does not represent any changes in the IOC's decision or position.

She said that she understands this is a very sensitive issue for Taiwan and that the IOC will deal with the matter, but added that it is still uncertain when the correction will be made as most IOC personnel are now busy preparing for the Singapore session.

The ISO country name codes are established according to the United Nations' format. Despite its opposition, Taiwan, which is not a member of the United Nations or ISO, can do nothing about being called "a province of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME WILL HEAL CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE: BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush said Wednesday he believes that time will heal the political dispute between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"My attitude is that time will heal this issue. And therefore we're trying to make sure that neither side provokes the other through unilateral action, " Bush said in an interview with Fox News TV Channel.
Asked whether the United States would uphold its promise to defend Taiwan if the island were ever invaded, Bush said: "Yes, we do. It's called the Taiwan Relations Act."
Bush explained that the the U.S. stance is that it supports a "one China" policy based on the three Washington-Beijing communiques.
Moreover, Bush said, the United States adheres to the Taiwan Relations Act, which means it is against either side of the Taiwan Strait unilaterally changing the status quo.

"In other words, neither side will make a decision that steps outside the bounds of that statement I just made to you. If China were to invade unilaterally, we would rise up in the spirit of Taiwan Relations Act. If Taiwan were to declare independence, it would be a unilateral decision that would then change the U.S. equation, " Bush added.

Asked about his views on U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's recent criticism of China's rapid military buildup despite not facing any threats in the region, Bush said the U.S.-China relationship is a complex one.
"It is complex because we deal with each other on a variety of fronts. One front, of course, is our defense posture," Bush said.
When asked whether he trusts China, Bush said: "So far, I do. We'll see."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO WORK WITH PFP ON MECHANISM TO PRODUCE ELECTION CANDIDATES

TEXT.P: The largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT) , hopes to work closely with its ally the People First Party (PFP) to set up a mechanism to produce candidates agreed upon between them to run in the year-end city and county elections, a KMT official said Thursday.

Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, made the remarks one day after PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng said that consultations between the two parties on cooperation in the year-end elections is scheduled to start after June 22, when both parties will have decided upon their nominees.

The PFP is suggesting that a "coalition government" be created as a way of cooperation, and that the mechanism of producing candidates will "be mainly based on consultations and public opinion polls as complementary measures, " Chin said. The PFP also wants to have a cooperative agreement signed between the two parties, he added.

Liao noted that the KMT has prepared its own integration mechanism for the two parties, and will consider whether to conduct public and party opinion polls or consult opinion leaders. The top leaders of the two parties will decide on this matter.
Meanwhile, the PFP held a press conference Thursday to drum up support for the party's first group of seven nominees for the city and county chief elections.

Most of the seven nominees -- Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung for Keelung mayor, Legislator Sun Ta-chien for Taoyung County magistrate, Shen Chi-hui for Taichung mayor, former Legislator Hsieh Chang-chieh for Changhua County magistrate, Legislator Chen Chih-ping for Nantou County magistrate, incumbent Lienchiang County Magistrate Chen Hsueh-sheng and PFP Police Center Deputy Director Lee Yun-chieh for Chiayi mayor -- said a victory of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP is the goal.

But they also pointed out that "the KMT is not equal to the 'pan-blue alliance, '" and that the two parties should consult to produce a "fair and transparent" mechanism in finalizing only one "pan-blue" candidate for each city and county.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CLARIFIES CIECA INVITATIONS OF U. S. LAWMAKERS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The visits of U. S. Congressmen to Taiwan at the invitation of the Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) were aimed at booting two-way trade ties, activities that have nothing to do with political lobbying, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

Lu's comments came after the Washington-based Capitol Update, a weekly review of the newest legislative and regulatory news, reported in an edition published earlier the same day that from 2000 to 2004, a total of 34 U. S. Congressmen were treated by two Taiwan-based trade organizations -- the CIECA and the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) -- to trips to Taiwan.

According to the weekly, the two trade organizations that maintain good relations with the Taiwan government failed to abide by the U. S. law that stipulates that lobbying groups must register with the U. S. Congress and the Department of Justice.

Pointing out that the CIECA is a non-profit group engaged exclusively in strengthening Taiwan's economic links with the rest of the world, Lu said that its invitations to U. S. lawmakers to visit Taiwan were not in violation of the law either in Taiwan or in the United States as the visits were not involved with any lobbying or political activities.
Lu further dismissed the notion that it was not the CIECA that had issued the invitations. The CIECA was called the CNAIC prior to 2002, he elaborated.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW TO BE REVISED IN LINE WITH NEW ELECTORAL SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will work out its draft revisions to an election law soon to pave the way for the implementation of a "single seat, two votes" electoral system in Taiwan, an MOI official said Thursday.

Lin Ching-chi, deputy director of the MOI's Department of Civil Affairs, said during a seminar hosted by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao that the ministry plans to submit its draft revisions to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law to the Cabinet in July and send the draft to the Legislative Yuan for review in the next legislative session set to start in September.

The National Assembly passed on Tuesday a constitutional amendment package under which the number of legislative seats will be reduced to 113 and a "single seat, two votes" system will be adopted starting with the next legislature to be elected in 2007.
While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

The regional seats will be distributed among special municipalities, counties and cities according to their populations, with each locality enjoying at least one seat and one legislator elected from each district. The at-large and overseas expatriate seats will be allocated to political parties that win at least 5 percent of the votes, according to the proportion of votes they garner.

Yu Ming-hsien, an official at the Central Election Commission (CEC) , said the CEC will maintain the integrity of administrative regions while re-demarcating the constituencies in line with the new electoral system.
Meanwhile, Lai proposed that a CEC organic law be enacted to ensure the CEC's impartiality in conducting constituency re-demarcation.

According to Lai, the members of CEC should be appointed by proportional representation, and a constituency demarcation review committee should be set up under the CEC to protect its independence and objectivity.
