DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED TO NEGOTIATE WITH TAIWAN ON OVERLAPPING ECONOMIC ZONES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday urged Japan to negotiate with Taiwan as soon as possible on the problem of overlapping economic zones of the two countries.

Lin Song-huann, director of MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks after nearly 50 Taiwan fishing boats converged in waters between the Tiaoyutais, a tiny group of islets lying about 75 nautical miles northeast of Keelung, and Pengchiayu, about 25 nautical miles off Keelung harbor earlier in the day to protest against Japanese patrol ships, which are often in the area to chase them away.
The fishermen wanted to confront Japanese patrol boats, but the protest ended peacefully as no patrol boats showed up, only several Japanese reconnaissance planes were monitoring the situation.
Lin noted that at issue was the formulation of a law regarding its exclusive economic zone and continental shelf by Japan in 1996, which includes Taiwan and Matsu into its 200-mile economic zone.
Because of the unreasonable demarcation, both countries started negotiations in 1996.

Both sides have conducted 14 rounds of fishery negotiations as of the end of last year, but couldn't reach consensus, Lin said. He urged Japan to attach importance to the long-term friendship between the two countries and deal with the problem pragmatically.

The government has asked its representative office in Japan to convey the fishermen's anger and exasperation, hoping that Japan could address the issue squarely and conduct the 15th round of negotiations with Taiwan as soon as possible.

He said the government can understand the feelings of the fishermen, but he urged rationality, saying that the issue involves the sovereignty and laws of the two countries, and protesting will not solve the problem.

He expressed the hope that the fishermen will provide related information of being unfairly treated, such as where their ships were being chased away and seized, so as to be used in future negotiations with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC ZONE ISSUE SHOULD BE SOLVED DIPLOMATICALLY: CGA HEAD

TEXT.P: Controversial economic zone issue should be solved diplomatically and international fishing disputes should be settled via fishery talks, Syu Huei-you, minister of the Coast Guard Administration (CGA), said Thursday.

Syu reiterated that the CGA is resolutely firm in protecting the safety and interests of the country's fishermen, particularly in light of the fact that four Taiwanese fishing boats were driven away by Japanese patrol boats while operating in waters 43 nautical miles northeastern of Keelung Wednesday.

Syu stressed that while doing its best to safeguard fishermen's safety and rights when Taiwanese fishing boats are operating within the Republic of China territorial waters, the CGA believes firmly that controversies arising from disputed economic zones, such as the area in the East China Sea and south of Okinawa, where China, Taiwan and Japan all claim sovereignty, should be redressed via diplomatic means or through negotiations.
According to CGA authorities, another nine Taiwanese fishing boats were facing off against Japanese patrol boats in the area around 7 p.m. Wednesday.

Wednesday's incidents -- only the latest two of many -- prompted more than 40 fishing boats from Suao, northeastern Taiwan, to sail out in concert Thursday to the area to stage a protest against the Japanese patrol ships' bullying.
To avoid possible confrontation between the fishing boats and Japanese patrol ships, the CGA dispatched seven ships, led by a 917-ton vessel, to escort the Taiwan fishing boats.

As Taiwan's economic zone overlaps that of Japan's, the Ministry of the Interior at the end of 2003 drew a provisional line within the ROC's 200-mile exclusive economic zone at the mid-point between the overlapping zones.

Taiwan fishermen generally stay within this boundary, but Japanese patrol boats have driven away Taiwan fishing boats several times recently, leading the fishermen to complain that their legal fishing grounds are being encroached upon.

A total of 13 Suao fishing boats have reportedly been seized by Japan while operating in Taiwan's economic zone since 2001, and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.

A Suao Fishermen's Association official said Thursday that overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon have been long-term problems, and if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROPOSES TALKS WITH JAPAN OVER FISHERY DISPUTES

TEXT.P: The government has requested Japan to speed up bilateral talks with Taiwan to seek a resolution to fishery disputes triggered by an overlap of the exclusive economic zones of both countries, Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday.
Hsieh proposed that both countries refrain from taking expulsion actions against fishing boats from the other side before the negotiations come to any conclusions.

The premier was responding to a conflict breaking out a day earlier off Taiwan's northeast coast between Taiwanese fishing boats and the Japanese coast guard following an expulsion by the Japanese side.
Hsieh pointed out that the problem exists because both Taiwan and Japan claim that their exclusive economic zones extend 200 nautical miles out from their coasts, which overlap at some points.

The premier said the process of negotiations with Japan involves much difficulty because Taiwan maintains no diplomatic relations with Japan, but he promised that the government will make an all-out effort to protect the country's sovereignty and the rights of Taiwanese fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PAVILION IN VENICE BIENNIAL TO OPEN FRIDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Venice, June 9 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The 51st Venice Biennial opened Thursday with the Taipei Fine Arts Museum submitting works to the prestigious exhibition for the sixth time.
The Taiwan pavilion, still set in the bustling Plazzo Delle Prigioni, features four contemporary artists who display their installations surrounding the theme of "The Spectre of Freedom."

Chen Chi-nan, minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, and Liao Hsien-hao, director of the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of the Taipei City Government, will preside over an official public opening party Friday.

A total of 105 pavilions with 419 artists are taking part in this year's exhibition, which will last until November 6. The exhibition has become a major forum for Taiwan to have exchanges with international artistic establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO FOLLOW GRAND JUSTICES' ORDER ON FINGERPRINTING POLICY

TEXT.P: Responding to a report that the Council of Grand Justices might order a moratorium on the government's fingerprinting policy, Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that the Cabinet will abide by the council's order is one is forthcoming.
The government plans to require everyone to be fingerprinted when they apply for the new national identification cards to be issued from July 1.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators have filed for a constitutional interpretation from the Council of Grand Justices in the wake of concern expressed by human rights groups over the policy.
A local daily said Thursday that in light of the limited time available, the council might order a moratorium on the policy before its interpretation is released.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND U.S. WILL TEAM UP TO PROBE ECSTASY AND THE BRAIN

TEXT.P: The United States will cooperate with Taiwan in studying whether the use of ecstasy, also known as MDMA, damages the brain, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Thursday.

Under the cooperative program, the U.S. government will provide US$300,000 over two years for the DOH's National Bureau of Controlled Drugs (NBCD) and the Tri-Service General Hospital to study the impact of MDMA on the human brain.

NBCD Director Lee Chih-heng said the cooperative research program has just begun. Under the program, researchers will collect cases involving people who have used MDMA more than five times. Fifty MDMA users in the study will receive magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examinations so that researchers can look into whether their brain cells have undergone any changes after using the drug.

Barry Hoffer, director of the U.S. National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) , who is currently in Taipei to attend an international conference on neural transplantation and regeneration, said the NIDA has initiated the cooperative program mainly because both Taiwan and the United States face MDMA abuse problems.

As the United States is a multiracial country, Hoffer said, hereditary factors may hinder the study of MDMA's possible damage to the brain. In comparison, he said, Taiwan people's genetic backgrounds are believed to be simpler and thus helpful to the study.

In Taiwan, Lee said some local physicians have reported cases involving MDMA users suffering from strokes or dementia. However, he said, those reports lacked MRI support. Moreover, he said, local addicts usually like to use a mix of ecstasy and other drugs, making it hard for researchers to judge whether their symptoms or mind disorders were caused purely by MDMA.
Against this backdrop, Lee said the ongoing Taiwan-U.S. cooperative research program will require looking into the addicts' drug abuse history.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN REMITTANCE TOTALS US$3.361 BILLION IN MAY

TEXT.P: Net foreign remittance to Taiwan's stock market totaled US$3.361 billion in May, or the second-largest amount in a single month, next only to February's US$3.748 billion, officials from the Securities and Futures Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission said Thursday.
The officials said that since the government allowed foreigners to invest in the Taiwan stock market in December 1990, net foreign remittance has reached US$91.034 billion.
Foreign remittance in the first three days of this month totaled US$430 million, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER CAUTIOUSLY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT 4 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday that he is cautiously optimistic about Taiwan reaching an economic growth of more than 4 percent this year.
Wu made the remarks while commenting on the current economic situation and strategies when he attended a congress of the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei.
To achieve this goal, he said that government needs to use a two-pronged approach.
The first is to relax regulations and he thinks that it is most helpful to economic growth if the spending of the private sector can grow.

The second is to expand government spending, Wu said, adding that the budget for the 10 New Major Construction Projects only passed the Legislative Yuan last month, although the Executive Yuan proposed it last year and is hoping to use it this year.
Wu said that businesses should pressure legislators so that urgent bills could be passed soon.
He said world economic growth should reach over 3 percent this year, compared with 4 percent last year.

Though the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics recently adjusted Taiwan's economic growth downward to 3.6 percent, Wu said Taiwan's economy has been quite resilient, and it could rebound quickly.

In addition, the government is usually conservative in its predictions, citing the figures by such institutions as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund which have predicted that Taiwan will have no problem in reaching an economic growth of 4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS UP CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT ASSESSMENT TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) decided Thursday to set up a constitutional amendment assessment unit in its weekly Central Standing Committee (CSC) meeting to compliment President Chen Shui-bian's call for a second round of amendments.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang will serve as convener of the 15-member task force, with the 14 others coming from the government, the party and representatives from the academic sector, such as Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, lawmakers Trong Chai and Chao Yung-ching and various scholars.

Su hailed the latest round of constitutional amendments that concluded Tuesday and expressed his belief that the constitutional changes will help Taiwan develop into a sound country, where politics can become more even-handed over the long term.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the DPP's culture and communications department, said earlier the same day that the party will begin to craft a blueprint for the second phase of constitutional reforms after an assessment panel has been set up.

The DPP will invite representatives from a wide spectrum to take part in the panel to forge a consensus based on popular support, Cheng said, adding that the panel may consider setting a timetable for the second round of constitutional reforms and include certain key amendment proposals in the blueprint.

In response to the opposition parties' cold shoulder to the DPP's plan to conduct a second round of constitutional revisions, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang claimed that a second phase of constitutional reforms will not hobble the government's efforts to improve Taiwan's economy.

Working out a "tailor-made, timely and appropriate" constitution for Taiwan will help sharpen the country's competitiveness and the opposition parties should fully throw their support behind the DPP instead of standing in the way, Lee said.

According to Lee, the next round of constitutional amendments will focus on revisions regarding the governmental system and the fate of the now vestigial Taiwan Provincial Government, among other issues.

The latest round of a weeklong constitutional revisions session ended Tuesday, with ad hoc National Assembly deputies voting 249 to 48 in favor of a package of amendments approved by the Legislative Yuan last August.

While the ruling DPP and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) fully endorsed the amendments contained in the package, smaller parties such as the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said that it would spell disaster for Taiwan's democracy.

The PFP and TSU will face even more aggressive competition in future elections, as the amendments will allow for the adoption of a "one seat, two votes" electoral system in newly demarcated but smaller constituencies and with the seats at the next legislature to be cut by nearly half to 113 from 225 when it opens in early 2008.

Although the KMT is widely assumed to benefit the most from the new electoral system, the party has made it clear that it would be a big mistake for the DPP to initiate a new round of constitutional reforms at a time when the people in Taiwan are looking forward to a better livelihood.

KMT officials urged the ruling party to focus its energy on issues of major public concern, such as improving the economy and social order, and accused it of intending to shift public attention from its inability to rule the country by a new wave of political moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER PLEDGES TO NARROW INTER-SECTOR DIGITAL GAP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs launched a project Thursday that is aimed at helping small- and medium-sized businesses improve their digital capabilities to narrow the digital gap between industrial sectors.

Under the project, which will be implemented in collaboration with local Internet firms and is scheduled to run from 2005 to 2008, the ministry plans to help 100,000 small- and medium-sized businesses establish broadband networking and 150,000 others employ e-commerce, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said during the launching ceremony held in the southern city of Kaohsiung.
The project is expected to create business opportunities worth NT$7.3 billion (US$233.22 million) a year and will enhance the competitiveness of small- and medium-sized businesses, according to Ho.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Award Limit in Tobacco Case Sets Off a Strenuous Protest.
A U.S. Justice Department decision to seek US$10 billion for a stop-smoking program in its suit against the country's leading tobacco companies, instead of the US$130 billion suggested by one of its expert witnesses, set off a firestorm on Wednesday. Several Democratic lawmakers with a longtime interest in smoking and health issues attacked the department for what they said was a politically motivated decision, as did public health groups. The payments are intended to finance a stop-smoking program that a government witness said would cost US$130 billion over 25 years.
Wall Street Journal: Side Effects, In Treating U.S. After Bubble, Fed Helped Create New Threats.
By many yardsticks, the Federal Reserve's response to the bursting of the stock and tech- spending bubbles in 2000 has been a remarkable success. The 2001 recession was mild and economic growth since has been brisk. Employment is up and inflation remains within the Fed's hallowed zone of price stability. But five years after the s tock market's peak, the economy faces other threatening imbalances: a potential housing bubble, rock-bottom personal saving rates and a gargantuan trade deficit. And the Fed's post-bubble prescription bears some responsibility for all three. By slashing short-term interest rates to 45-year lows, the Fed encouraged Americans to borrow more, gave them little reward for saving and helped ignite a surge in housing prices. President Bush and Co ngress joined in with steep tax cuts that boosted household purchasing power. All that spending contributed to a growing U.S. economy, a steady increase in imports and -- given that Americans are so eager to borrow and foreigners so eager to lend -- a mountain of foreign debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT REITERATES U.S. RESOLVE TO HELP TAIWAN DEFEND ITSELF

TEXT.P: The U.S. government is resolute in its desire to help Taiwan beef up its self-defense capabilities but Washington is also concerned as to whether Taiwan is determined to protecting itself militarily, an American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) official said Thursday.

David J. Keegan, deputy director of the Taipei office of the AIT, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations, expressed U.S. concerns over the fate of an arms procurement budget bill that has been stuck in Taiwan's opposition-controlled legislature for two legislative sessions.
Keegan made the remarks during a lunch with two legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the official residence of Douglas Paal, director of the AIT's Taipei office.

According to Shen Fa-hui, one of the legislators who attended the luncheon, Keegan expressed serious concern over Taiwan lawmakers' attitudes toward the arms procurement bill, which involves the purchase of important weapons systems including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
Keegan, however, did not say anything about the U.S. bottom line on the deadline for these orders, according to Shen.

On May 24, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said at the Legislative Yuan that the window of opportunity is closing for Taiwan to purchase a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States, claiming that the U.S. "has given Taiwan till the end of May to buy the planes, otherwise they will be sold elsewhere."

Keegan also said that the U.S. will pay close attention on how the constitutional amendment package passed by Taiwan's National Assembly Tuesday will impact the outcome of the year-end mayoral and county chief elections.
Paal was absent from the luncheon because he had another appointment, according to Keegan.

Paal extended an invitation at the end of May to the leaders and various members of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee to the luncheon after the Cabinet-proposed budget for the NT$480 billion (US$15.33 billion) arms procurement package was blocked again by the opposition-controlled legislature.
None of the opposition legislators bothered to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUPS CLARIFY ROLES IN REPORT ON U. S. LAWMAKERS' TAIWAN TRIPS

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan-based groups clarified their role Thursday in a report by a Washington-based weekly alleging that they treated over 30 U. S. lawmakers to visit Taiwan over the past four years and said there was nothing illegal in the matter.

Lin Tien-kuei, deputy secretary-general of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC), said that his group has nothing to do with the story published by the Capitol Update that same day and added that it has never invited any U.S. lawmaker to Taiwan since 2002, when incumbent chairman Huang Mao-hsiung assumed the post.

Capitol Update reported that a total of 34 U. S. congressmen, including some who have been involved in political contribution scandals, were invited to Taiwan from 2000 to 2004 by two trade groups that maintain good relations with the Taiwan government.

The report alleged that spending on the trips totaled more than US$230,000 and that the congressmen who accepted the invitations might have violated U. S. law, as the two Taiwan groups failed to register with the U. S. Congress and the Department of Justice.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the non-profit Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) , a splinter group of the CNAIC, said that the CIECA is not a political lobbying body and claimed that it has never done any political lobbying in the United States.

According to CIECA Deputy Secretary-General Lin Chi-sung, the group invited some U. S. congressmen to visit Taiwan to help them better understand Taiwan's democratic and economic development. Private sector exchanges are very important in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, he added.

As to the claim that the U. S. congressmen might have broken U. S. law if they did not report their Taiwan trips to Congress prior to departure, Lin said that the CIECA is unaware of U. S. legal restrictions.
The CIECA was established in 2000 to take charge of CNAIC's international exchange affairs, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LODGES PROTEST WITH JAPAN OVER FISHING DISPUTE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy representative to Japan lodged a formal protest with the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) Thursday over a fishing dispute.

Chen Hung-chi, deputy head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Japan, presented the protest letter to the JIA, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
A senior JIA official accepted the petition and promised to relay it to the relevant Japanese authorities.

Chen told the official that four ROC fishing vessels were dispersed by Japanese patrol ships Wednesday while they were operating in the overlapping area of the two countries' 200-mile exclusive economic zones.
"We solemnly protest such an act, " Chen said, adding that Japan should exercise self-restraint toward Taiwan fishermen's operations in disputed waters.
He also urged Japan to hold a new round of bilateral fishery talks as soon as possible to resolve longstanding disputes over fishing operations in the overlapping economic zones.

Also Thursday, about 60 Taiwanese trawlers converged in waters about 80 nautical miles east of northern Taiwan, near a number of small, uninhabited islands known as the Tiaoyutais, which are claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China.

Fish abound in the waters surround the Tiaoyutais and Japan often impounds Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter the waters, fining their owners. The absence of formal diplomatic ties has made it difficult to resolve the disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S WIFE ARRIVES IN SHANGHAI FOR SHIP CHRISTENING
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, June 9 (CNA) (By Chao Yen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Lien Fang Yu, the wife of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, arrived in Shanghai via Hong Kong Thursday to witness the christening of a Taiwan bulk carrier built by the Taipei-based Chinese Maritime Transport (CMT).
Lien, accompanied by her sons and daughters, kept a low-profile and was whisked away in a limousine motorcade driven by officials from the Shanghai city government and public security authorities.
She has been invited to co-preside at the christening ceremony slated for Friday for the "China Peace, " which was commissioned by the CMT and built at the Waigaoqiao Shipyard in Pudong, Shanghai.
The 75,000-ton "China Peace" is a Cape-sized bulk carrier designed to carry coal, iron ore, or wheat across oceans, according to a CMT spokesman.
Cape-sized is a term that denotes a vessel that is too large to navigate the Panama or Suez canals and must therefore sail around Cape Horn or the Cape of Good Hope, respectively.

Lien's last trip to China was April 26-May 3 when she accompanied her husband on a visit to Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai. During that visit, the KMT chairman met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, marking the first meeting between the leaders of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) since the KMT fled China after being defeated by the CPC in 1949. Hu doubles as CPC general secretary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN LIVE 5.8 YEARS LONGER THAN MALE COUNTERPARTS: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The average lifespan among Taiwan women was 5.8 years longer than that of their male counterparts in 2004, according to tallies released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The DGBAS statistics show that life expectancy among Taiwan women reached an average of 79.4 years in 2004, compared to 73.6 years for the nation's men.
Women's 2004 average life span increased 0.2 years from the year-earlier level and men's average life expectancy registered a 0.1 year rise.
In 2004, 133,679 people died, up 2.9 percent from the 2003 level.
Cancer continued to be the top killer, claiming 36,357 lives or 27.2 percent of the total.

Meanwhile, 12,861 people died from heart disease, 5,536 died from pneumonia and 4,680 died from renal disease. These three death categories increased by 9.1 percent, 8.6 percent and 8.7 percent, respectively.
In contrast, deaths from diabetes, hypertension and stroke declined by 8.2 percent, 2.1 percent and 0.5 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE INCREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade amounted to US$149.07 billion in the first five months of this year, up 10.5 percent from the previous year's level, according to customs statistics released Thursday by the Ministry of Finance.

During the January-May period, the tallies show, Taiwan exported goods worth US$74.81 billion and imported goods worth US$74.26 billion, up 7.6 percent and 13.5 percent over the figures recorded a year ago, respectively, leaving a trade surplus of US$550 million in Taiwan's favor.

In May alone, foreign trade increased by 7.5 percent year-on-year to US$32.46 billion, of which exports totaled US$16.32 billion and imports accounted for US$16.14 billion, leaving a trade surplus of US$180 million in the country's favor.

Bureau of Foreign Trade officials said the foreign trade surplus has been dwindling since the beginning of this year due to the sharp increase of oil prices and the slowdown of global economic growth.
They said, however, that economic performance remained strong in light of export orders received in May, worth US$20.81 billion.

Also, they went on, export reliance on China has been alleviated as exports to China and Hong Kong accounted for 36.3 percent of the total in May, down 1.6 percentage points from the previous year's level.
The officials said the government will continue to help exporters diversify their overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IC INDUSTRY OUTPUT DECLINES

TEXT.P: The overall output from Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) manufacturing industry totaled NT$235.8 billion (US$7.6 billion) in the first quarter of this year, the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA) reported Thursday.
The NT$235.8 billion figure represented a decline of 3 percent from the production posted in the same quarter of last year and a decline of 16.4 percent from Q4 of 2004, TSIA officials said.

In the IC industry, the design and manufacturing sectors posted first-quarter production of NT$57.5 billion and NT$127.7 billion, down by 4.8 percent and 6.7 percent, respectively, over that posted in Q1 of 2004 and an even greater decline of 13.5 percent and 18.1 percent, respectively, compared with that posted in Q4 of 2004.

Meanwhile, output from the packaging and testing sectors managed to secure growth of 8.1 percent and 17.9 percent, respectively, over that registered in Q1 of 2004. The two figures, however, represented a decline of 15.5 percent and 14.7 percent, respectively, when compared with that posted in Q4 of 2004, TSIA officials noted.
They attributed the production decline in the first quarter mainly to stagnant demand in the domestic and foreign markets due to excessive inventory accumulated from last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: The government's policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait is to maintain the peaceful status quo and resolve any cross-strait dispute by no other than peaceful means, the Presidential Office said Thursday.

The Presidential Office issued the statement after U.S. President George W. Bush said in an interview with Fox News TV Channel a day earlier that his administration is working to make sure that neither Taiwan nor China "provokes the other through unilateral action" but expressed confidence that "time will heal this issue."
China has said it will attack Taiwan if the self-governing island tries to declare formal independence.
The Presidential Office said in a press statement that the government's stance on peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes is in full compliance with that of the United States.

The statement further says that the international community should pay more heed to whether China will use "non-peaceful means" to alter the Taiwan Strait status quo since it enacted its anti-secession law in March this year. The legislation codifies the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVERS COULD BE FINED NT$24,000 IN SHUEISHAN TUNNEL

TEXT.P: Traffic violators in the Shueishan Tunnel caught on all eight of the tunnel's cameras could be fined a total of NT$24,000 (US$774) , sources from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Friday.

The 12.9-km long Shueishan Tunnel -- part of the Peiyi Freeway connecting Taipei and Ilan City in the east and scheduled to open at the end of this year -- will not only be the longest tunnel in Taiwan, it will also be one of the five longest of its kind in the world, MOTC officials said.
Due to its long distance, maintaining safety in the tunnel is vital, said the transportation officials.
The eight cameras installed on each side of the tunnel will catch drivers who violate any of the three tunnel "nos" -- no lane changing, no speeding and no tailgating.
Drivers snapped by all eight cameras could be fined NT$24,000 in total, making the tunnel potentially one of the most expensive stretches of road in the world, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S REMARKS EXPECTED TO HAVE DETERRENT EFFECT: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The government is grateful for U.S. President George W. Bush's reaffirming his commitment to helping defend Taiwan if the country is invaded, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

Lu's remarks came after Bush said in an interview with Fox News TV Channel Wednesday that the United States adheres to the Taiwan Relations Act, which means it is against either side of the Taiwan Strait unilaterally changing the status quo.
Asked whether the United States would uphold its promise to defend Taiwan if the island were to suffer an invasion, Bush said: "Yes, we [would]. It's called the Taiwan Relations Act."

Responding to Bush's statement, Lu said Taiwan has no intention of altering the Taiwan Strait status quo. On the contrary, he said, Taiwan has been a staunch supporter and defender of the peaceful status quo in the region.

Lu said President Chen Shui-bian has on numerous occasions announced that Taiwan will continue to uphold the universal values of peace, freedom and democracy and is willing to dialogue with China under the principles of "peace, democracy and parity."

Meanwhile, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the government is hopeful that Bush's reaffirmation of the U.S. commitment to help defend Taiwan in the event of an invasion could help deter any attempt to use "non-peaceful means" to alter the Taiwan Strait status quo.

Asked whether Bush's remarks reflect closer Taiwan-U.S. ties, Cho said that since China enacted its anti-secession law in March, codifying the use of "non-peaceful means" against the nation, Taiwan-U.S. ties have "become an important integral part of international relations."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT OF SUCCESS OF 2ND ROUND OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed confidence Thursday in getting success in the second round of constitutional reforms.

In a meeting with a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators at the Taipei Guest House, Chen said the second round of reforms is aimed at increasing the government's efficiency, which he said is part of the government's efforts to improve the economy, according to William Lai, DPP legislative caucus whip, who was present in the meeting.
Lai quoted Chen as saying that the constitutional reforms do not contradict the opposition camp demand that the government should focus its efforts on improving the economy.

Many issues related to the people's livelihood will be involved in the second phase of revisions, particularly issues with regard to the interests of laborers, youth, women and aboriginal people, Chen went on.

The reforms will be successful because they will forge a national consensus, the president claimed while rebutting concerns about a high threshold imposed by the now-defunct National Assembly for future constitutional amendments.
According to the revised Constitution, future constitutional amendments will require a three-quarters majority vote by the Legislative Yuan and be endorsed by a referendum.

Chen announced Tuesday the start of the second phase of constitutional reforms shortly after the National Assembly approved a package of constitutional amendments adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August.

Referring to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chen said it is clear Taiwan should take its own path, given that Beijing still insists on its "one China" principle after Lien Chan, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, and James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, visited China last month and claimed there are different interpretations of "one China" by the two sides of the strait -- the so-called "1992 consensus."
"There is no consensus," Chen reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 10, or the fourth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1922: American singer and actress Judy Garland is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet Me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," as well as "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: U.S. marines invade the Japanese Ryukyu islands, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins a decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors and expands its territory by 200 percent.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1972: Chang Feng-hsu assumes office as the new mayor of Taipei, succeeding Henry Kao.
1975: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, addressing the Kuomintang, pledges to carry out Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the late President Chiang Kai-shek's anti-communist policy.
1976: Lin Yang-kang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Reconstruction Department, is appointed mayor of Taipei City by the Executive Yuan.
1980: The Ninth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens at the International Hall of the Civic Aeronautic Administration in Taipei with 109 Chinese and American scholars and experts participating.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern mainland China, defects at the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for copyright infringements.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and reaffirms the ROC's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperation programs with Macedonia.
2000: The 2000 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race kicks off at Tachia Park, located alongside the Keelung River, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening ceremony.
2001: The Chinese version of "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," a new book by the Japanese historian and novelist Fuyuko Kamisaka, has been released in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSE COMMITTEE SUPPORTS VISITS TO U.S. BY HIGH-LEVEL TAIWAN OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday passed the Foreign Relations Authorization Act (H.R. 2601) with an amendment (Section 806) in support of high-level visits to the United States by Taiwan's elected leaders.
The House International Relations Subcommittee on Africa, Global Human Rights and International Operations earlier passed the amendment May 26.

"It is in the national interests of the United States to communicate directly with democratically elected and appointed officials of Taiwan, including the president of Taiwan, the vice president of Taiwan, the foreign minister of Taiwan and the defense minister of Taiwan, " according to the amendment.

It also says that "the Department of State should, in accordance with Public Law 103-416, admit such high level officials of Taiwan to the United States to discuss issues of mutual concern with United States officials."

In cooperation with Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the State Department is also urged to "facilitate high level meetings between such high level officials of Taiwan and their counterparts in the United States," according to the amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS' VISITS TO U.S. CONDUCIVE TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: PFP

TEXT.P: Visits to the United States by Taiwan's democratically elected leaders would be conducive to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, an opposition People First Party (PFP) whip said Friday.

Chen Chih-pin, convener of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, made the comments when expressing welcome to the passage by the International Relations Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives Thursday of the Foreign Relations Authorization Act for 2006 and 2007 (H.R. 2601) with an amendment (Section 806) in support of high-level visits to the United States by Taiwan's elected leaders.

Chen said that Taiwan leaders being allowed to make official visits to the United States will also help the Taiwan people grasp their leaders' ideas and the government's policy on cross-strait relations.
"At least the president wouldn't dare lie to the U.S. president during such a visit, and what he would say would count, even if he lies to the people and lawmakers back home," Chen said mockingly.

Chen added that since the United States is committed to protecting Taiwan based on its Taiwan Relations Act, it is essential and imperative for the president of the Republic of China on Taiwan to visit the United States.

The amendment that the International Relations Committee passed on Thursday was submitted by the House International Relations Subcommittee on Africa, Global Human Rights and International Operations on May 26 this year.

The proposed amendment says that "it is in the national interests of the United States to communicate directly with democratically elected and appointed officials of Taiwan, including the president of Taiwan, the vice president of Taiwan, the foreign minister of Taiwan, and the defense minister of Taiwan."

"The Department of State should, in accordance with Public Law 103-416, admit such high level officials of Taiwan to the United States to discuss issues of mutual concern with the U.S. officials, " the amendment further says.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING PROFESSOR NAMED NEW NTU PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A screening committee of the Ministry of Education has chosen National Taiwan University (NTU) electrical engineering professor Lee Si-chen as the new president of the university.
Lee will take over the post from Chen Wei-jao, who is set to step down at the end of this month after serving for 12 years.
Lee, 53, who holds a doctoral degree from Stanford University, served as head of NTU's Department of Electrical Engineering from 1988-1992.

During his term as dean of academic affairs of NTU from 1996-2002, Lee helped set up an evaluation system of various departments and colleges of the university and worked out a mechanism to allow college entrance through multiple channels.

The screening process for a new NTU president lasted for about seven months. The university first selected six professors for the first round of voting March 20. Only Yang Yeong-bin, dean of NTU's College of Engineering, received more than half of the ballots, or 201 ballots. According to the rules, a second round of voting was then held, and Lee received 178 votes.

The university then sent the two names to a screening committee of the Ministry of Education for review. The committee invited the two candidates to elaborate their views on running the school last week.

Chen was held on bail of S$2 million, but he can't afforded it and keeping himself in jail.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENNSYLVANIA HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WHA BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 9 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The House of Representatives of the U.S. state of Pennsylvania passed a resolution June 7 in support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization, as an observer.
The resolution was unanimously passed by the more than 200 lawmakers after Andrew L.Y. Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, delivered a speech on the house floor.
While emphasizing the existing close relationship between Taiwan and Pennsylvania, the director expressed the hope that both sides could further strengthen their economic and trade cooperation.
Taiwan is Pennsylvania's 15th largest trade partner.

The island's science and technology sectors and their counterparts in the Pennsylvania have interacted well with each other as the state authorities attach great importance to science and technology development.

It is expected that minister without portfolio Lin Ferng-ching, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang and Industrial Technology Research Institute President Lee John-see will attend a biotechnology exhibition to be held in Philadelphia later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO OPEN TALKS WITH TAIWAN UNCONDITIONALLY

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official called on China Friday to heed the suggestions of the United States and open dialogue with the government of Taiwan without setting any preconditions.

According to MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung, the source of cross-Taiwan Strait deadlock lies with the Chinese side, and the deadlock will continue if Beijing insists on setting preconditions on opening official dialogue with Taipei, which is a situation unwelcome by Taiwan and the international community.

You said the recent remarks by high-level U.S. officials on the cross-strait situation are "extremely significant, " especially after the enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan and the recent China visits by two of Taiwan's opposition leaders.

While U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld expressed his concern over China's continued military buildup and increased military deployments targeting Taiwan during the Fourth Asian Security Conference held last week in Singapore, U.S. President George W. Bush reaffirmed Washington's commitment to defend Taiwan in the event of a Chinese invasion during a June 8 TV interview, You noted.

Also, during a hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on East Asia and the Pacific on June 7, Christopher R. Hill, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, called on China to reach out to the duly elected leaders of Taiwan and engage in any form of dialogue with Taiwan with no political strings or preconditions, You pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO FACILITATE REPATRIATION OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council official called on China Friday to speed up its transportation arrangements to facilitate the repatriation of more than 2,000 illegal Chinese immigrants in Taiwan.
MAC Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng made the remarks during a visit to a Hsinchu detention center for illegal Chinese immigrants.

Huang pointed out that the repatriation process has been too slow to cope with the rapid increase in the number of illegal Chinese immigrants arrested in Taiwan, prompting the government to expand its detention facilities to cope with the situation.
Out of humanitarian considerations, Huang asked China to prioritize the repatriation of those who are seriously ill, underage or pregnant.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU CALLS FOR CROSS-PACIFIC GROUPING TO PROMOTE DEMOCRACY, PROSPERITY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that the development of a regional, cross-Pacific organization to promote the values of democracy, peace and prosperity is not only an urgent present matter, it is also important in terms of helping secure long-term stability in the world.

Addressing via teleconference the Asia-Pacific Regional Meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) held in Tokyo Friday, Lu, the founder of the union and chair of its International Preparatory Committee, said that although she was not able to attend the meeting in person, she still feels privileged to join the meeting via teleconference and meet so many distinguished leaders from countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region gathered in Tokyo to build a better future for the world.

Quoting a line from Charles Dickson's "The Tale of Two Cities, " namely "it was the best of times; it was the worst of times," Lu said the 21st century is certainly "a century of paradox, a time marked by incredible peace and serious conflict, where contentions and compromises coexist."
"It is a time of hope and a time of crisis. It is also a time when we must soberly examine the past while we plan our future course with enthusiasm and optimism," she said.

While the dual forces of globalization and the information revolution have resulted in much prosperity and economic success, these forces have also deepened the economic divide between the North and the South, Lu continued.

She said that the integration of the East and the West is not only a strategic alliance, but also a fusion of cultures and values -- resulting in a new "Blue Civilization focused on the development of the ocean as well as the land."

The integration of the North and the South is not just an economic partnership, but also an effort to promote prosperity by sharing development experiences among the members and to foster understanding through the inclusion of South Pacific cultures in the formation of the "Blue Civilization," Lu noted.

Lu said that globalization and the information revolution have also posed new challenges for the Pacific Rim area, prompting her to initiate the concept of a Democratic Pacific Union, which started in 2001 with the preparatory meeting of a Democratic Pacific Assembly.
The goal of the DPU is to gather the democracies around the Pacific Rim region to promote democracy, ensure peace and spread prosperity throughout the Pacific Rim region, she added.

Lu stressed that in the DPU Asia-Pacific Regional Meeting, the topics of civilization and technology are especially important. "This region contains a diverse group of civilizations that are both ancient and modern. Yet it is also a region that has the most communist states in the world. The region has the fastest growing economy in the world today, primarily driven by technological progress and world-renowned information technology industries, " she said.
"Yet it is also a region that faces old and new threats, ranging from the remnants of conflicts during the Cold War to the rise of terrorist groups."

"Through the discussion and presentation today, I hope that the participating countries will have a better understanding of each other as well as the issues that face the Asia Pacific community, " she added.

Lu said that in March of this year, the DPU held its first regional meeting in the Americas, where delegates from 12 countries gathered in Guatemala to discuss the issues of development. Delegates from Taiwan shared Taiwan's economic, technological and agricultural development experiences with the participants from the Americas. The panel sessions, titled "The Taiwan Experience," received overwhelming responses from those participating. The success of the first regional meeting also laid a solid foundation for the Asia-Pacific Regional Meeting today, she said.

Lu also noted that the DPU International Preparatory Committee and the International Secretariat have started some initial projects for the DPU operations, including the Taiwan Scholarship and a Visiting Fellowship Program.

The Taiwan Scholarship program is aimed at developing future leaders by promoting academic exchanges between Taiwan and other members of the DPU. Recipients of the scholarship are given three years to study in Taiwan and to learn about the Taiwan economic development and democratization experiences.

The Visiting Fellowship Program provides prominent leaders in the political, academic, non-profit and private sectors a chance to visit Taiwan. It is designed to strengthen the ties among DPU members and to provide a platform for professional exchanges, she noted.

In addition to these two programs, she said, the DPU International Secretariat is also planning three institutes: the Institute for Democracy, the Institute for Peace, and the Institute for Prosperity; and three centers: the Center for Women's Development, the Center for Marine Development, and the Center for Disaster Prevention; as well as a Pacific Internet University.
More than 100 distinguished leaders from countries around the Asia-Pacific region participated in Friday's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE JAPAN TO HOLD TALKS WITH TAIWAN ON FISHING RIGHTS ASAP

TEXT.P: Two legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday urged Japan to conduct talks with Taiwan over fishing rights in the disputed overlapping economic zones as soon as possible.

DPP Legislators Wang Tuoh and Hsu Kuo-yung made the appeal one day after Taiwan fishermen mobilized nearly 50 fishing vessels to stage a protest in waters off northeastern Taiwan against Japanese patrol boats, which are often in the area to chase them away.

Wang said that the fishermen's move shows that they can no longer tolerate "the pirate acts of the Japanese patrol boats" and that they have become desperate regarding the government's lack of resolve to protect them.

Wang said that he has asked the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture to resort to confrontation with Japanese patrol boats as a way to pressure Japan to come to the negotiation table.
If Japan still won't talk in goodwill, Wang said, he will not rule out the possibility of mobilizing fishermen to stage a protest at the Interchange Association, Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan.
Legislator Hsu stressed that Taiwan and Japan could consult over the overlapping economic zones, but Japan has turned a deaf ear to Taiwan's appeal for talks for fear of pressure from China.
Hsu asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Coast Guard Administration and the Fisheries Administration to form a task force to review the issue.
Coast Guard Administration Vice Minister Chung Tung-sheng said the administration will protect the fishing boats based on the principles of sovereignty and peaceful means.

Sha Chi-i, deputy head of the Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture, said Taiwan and Japan have conducted 14 rounds of talks since Japan in 1996 demarcated its 200-nautical mile economic zone, which includes parts of Taiwan's exclusive economic zone.

Sha said the issue of the overlapping economic zones involves sovereignty and the distribution of interests, which he termed as highly complex issues. He added that the 14 rounds of talks focused on the development and regeneration of the fisheries stocks in the zones.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said that the government should study the overlapping economic zones based on the facts, history, and the international situation to work out the government's stance and then express that stance firmly to the international community.

Lee Sheng-feng, secretary-general of the opposition New Party, said that the government should rigorously enforce its authority in protecting the fishermen, and only by doing so can Japan be pressured to come to the negotiation table.

Legislator Tsao Shou-ming of the opposition Kuomintang said countries should deal with bilateral issues based on the principles of equality and mutual benefits. If Japanese patrol boats chase away or seize Taiwan fishing vessels, then the Taiwan government should do the same to Japanese vessels, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES JAPAN TO AGREE TO NEW ROUND OF FISHERY TALKS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) hopes to convene a 15th round of fishery negotiations with Japan to resolve the problems incurred as a result of their overlapping exclusive economic zones, a foreign ministry official said Friday.

Lin Song-huann, director of MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks one day after nearly 50 Taiwan fishing boats converged in waters northeast of Taiwan to protest against Japanese patrol ships, which chase them away from the disputed area.

The fishermen initially wanted to confront the Japanese patrol boats but the protest fizzled out when no patrol boats showed up and only several Japanese reconnaissance planes monitored the situation.
Lin said that before Taiwan and Japan negotiate a provisional boundary, Taiwan fishermen should stay within the patrol line of Taiwan's Coast Guard Administration patrol boats.

He said that following the protest, the ministry has on one hand lodged a protest with the Japanese authorities urging them to exercise self-restraint, while on the other hand asking for a 15th round of talks.

At issue is the formulation of a law regarding its exclusive economic zone and continental shelf by Japan in 1996, which includes parts of Taiwan's exclusive economic zone within its 200-mile economic zone.
Because of this demarcation, which Taiwan feels is unreasonable, the two countries have conducted 14 rounds of talks on the issue since 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 46.43 points to close at 6,192.35.
The bourse opened at 6,188.1 and fluctuated between 6,198.3 and 6,158.13 during trading. A total of 3.87 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.61 billion (US$2.83 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks both at 0.6 percent and construction issues at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 529 to 302, with 170 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES CHINESE MEDIA POSTED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) welcomes more media from around China to station staff in Taiwan to help improve bilateral understanding across the Taiwan Strait, MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said Friday.

The MAC is at present assessing the possibility of allowing Taiwan press accreditation for two Chinese local dailies -- the First Financial Daily of Shanghai and the Guangdong Nanfang Daily -- You said at a regular press meeting.
Taiwan would like to see more local Chinese media stationed in Taiwan so long as the Beijing authorities do not "interfere intentionally," You said.

You reiterated that the MAC is opening Taiwan's doors wider to more local Chinese media, mainly out of consideration that more and more local media around China have shown dynamism and professionalism since China's opening and reform policies have taken root.

Saying that the MAC's opening policy has no ulterior motives, You added that as long as Beijing does not interfere "on purpose, " it will be no problem allowing both central- and local-level Chinese media to cover news in Taiwan in the near future.

The MAC halted press accreditation for China's official Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper in April this year on the grounds that "their coverage of Taiwan was not conducive to enhancing understanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait."

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said at that time that the purpose of allowing Chinese media organizations to station staff in Taiwan -- a practice that began in 2000 -- was to help the two sides better understand each other.

Unfortunately, Wu said, some Chinese media groups have focused only on the most extreme or radical opinions in Taiwan's political spectrum, which is not helpful to efforts to strengthen cross-strait understanding.

In addition, Wu said, the Chinese authorities have blocked news reports about Taiwan in all media channels, including Websites, another move that does not help Chinese people to gain better understanding of Taiwan society.

Meanwhile, Wu noted that the government will not cease media exchanges with China across the board and that other unofficial Chinese news media organizations will still have the opportunity to come to Taiwan to cover news.
Nevertheless, he added, any media, cultural or educational exchanges should be strictly assessed if they are found unhelpful to efforts to cement cross-strait relations.

At least five Chinese media organizations, including Xinhua, People's Daily, China National Radio, China Central Television and China News Service, have stationed journalists in Taiwan since the country first allowed Chinese news media organizations entry to Taiwan Nov. 10, 2000.
All these arrangements have been on a trial basis, with each visit lasting for only two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 50 points to close at 6,175, with 23,085 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for July moved up 53 points to end at 6,065, with 3,839 contracts traded, while September futures gained 52 points to finish at 5,962, with 322 contracts traded. December futures moved up 54 points to close at 5,960, with nine contracts traded.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

No transactions were recorded for March.
