A total of US$559 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.330 and hit a low of NT$31.290.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL LEADERS PAY HOMAGE TO LATE DHARMA MASTER YIN SHUN
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu City, northern Taiwan, June 10 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and other government officials traveled to Hsinchu Friday to pay homage respectively to the late Dharma Master Yin Shun, who passed away June 4 at the age of 100.

They offered incense to a picture of Yin Shun and paid their last respects to his remains in a ceremony held at the Fu Yan Monastery, where Yin Shun had resided for several decades and where his ashes will be kept permanently.

Born in Haining, in China's Zhejiang Province in 1906, Yin Shun became a Buddhist monk at the age of 24. As one of the most venerable Dharma masters in the Buddhist world, Yin Shun is remembered the most for his core philosophy of "humanizing Buddhism and bringing bodhisattvas into the world."
Known to his followers as the "savior of the world, " Yin Shun's teachings include the espousal of "benefiting others is the priority of all deeds and thoughts."
Yin Shun received an doctorate from Japan's Taisho University for one of his many books, named "The Zen History of China," published in Taipei in 1971.

His concept of "humanized Buddhism" has been devoutly undertaken by Master Cheng Yen, founder of Taiwan's largest charity organization the Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation, and her millions of followers.
Like her mentor, Master Cheng Yen is also a practitioner of Buddhism who encourages her disciples to take what they have learned from Buddhist philosophy and practice it in daily life.
Yin Shun had a simple and spartan lifestyle, so his disciples decided to keep his funeral simple but solemn, said a Fu Yan Monastery spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP OFFICE IN JAPAN HELPS WITH SEARCH FOR MISSING WOMAN

TEXT.P: Two staff members at Taiwan's representative office in Japan have arrived in the northern Japanese city of Asahigawa to help with the search for a Taiwan woman who went missing while on a mountain-climbing trip, an official said Friday.

Lin Song-huann, director of the Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , said Tsai Wan-ting, a Taiwan citizen in her 20s, was reported missing during a recent climbing vacation on the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido.
Japanese police have launched an all-out search over the past few days, but have so far not discovered Tsai's whereabouts, Lin said.

In Hokkaido, Lin said, this is the season when snow is thawing and bears come out of hibernation in search of food. Japanese police have not ruled out the possibility of Tsai having been attacked by one, Lin said, adding it is also possible that Tsai has accidentally fallen into a ravine.
Lin said Japanese police authorities have informed his department of their search and rescue operations. To date, he said, no clues to Tsai's whereabouts have been found.
With MOFA's assistance, Lin said, Tsai's family members have arrived in Asahigawa to handle relevant affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POLICE CONTRIBUTE TO ARREST OF GREEK FUGITIVE

TEXT.P: When Greek fugitive Apostolos Vavilis was arrested April in Italy after a 10-week international manhunt, most people might not have been aware that the Taiwan police played a crucial role in the operation leading to his arrest.

It was the first time the Taiwan police had taken part in a operation jointly launched by Interpol and the Greek and Italian authorities. It was also its first participation in the hunt for a criminal wanted by the European Police Office (Europol).

According to the International Criminal Affairs Section of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) , the representative of Greek police to Interpol, George Vanikiotis, requested Taiwan police in late February to assist in tracing Vavilis.
A key figure in a string of scandals involving the Orthodox Church of Greece, Vavilis was believed to have fled to Taiwan or another country with the help of his Taiwanese friends.
The CIB was told that Vavilis maintained close links with the church and political communities in Greece, Europe and the Middle East and used at least six different identities.
Based on information provided by Greek police, the CIB discovered that Vavilis had departed for Thailand and had made hundreds of flight reservations to try to shake off the police.

After an analysis of the flight information, the CIB concluded that Vavilis could have headed for Rome via Bangkok and Athens using one of his aliases, Antonios Aivaliotis, and passed the information to Greek police.

Greek police later spotted him in Italy by monitoring his e-mail and credit card use, and he was arrested in the Italian city of Bologna April 22, holding a fake Greek passport under the name of Antonios Aivaliotis.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO ASSIST FLOWER WHOLESALES TO TAP OVERSEAS MARKETS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Friday that it will continue to help local flower wholesalers to market their products overseas.

COA officials said that they are helping flower wholesalers in Changhua County, as well as in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, to promote cut flowers such as chrysanthemums and potted plants such as money trees for export to Malaysia, Hong Kong and Singapore.
The officials said the flower growing areas in Taiwan cover about 12,000 hectares, with a production value of more than NT$11.1 billion (US$352.38 million).

They said the flower sector in Taiwan is growing rapidly, with five flower wholesale markets set up in Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung cities and Changhua County, respectively. In addition, there is the Taipei flower and tree wholesale market, focusing mainly on potted plants.
They said that 76.21 million bouquets of flowers were sold in the wholesale market in 2004, accounting for 70 percent of the total cut flowers produced, while 5.95 million potted flowers were sold.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO OFFER AID TO JAPAN-BOUND ABORIGINAL PROTESTERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will offer all necessary assistance to an aboriginal delegation that will travel to Japan June 13 to protest Japan's atrocities during World War II, a senior official said Friday.
Lin Song-huann, director of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department, made the remarks after meeting with aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei, who will head the delegation.

In response to Kao Chin's complaint that the nation's representative office in Tokyo has asked her delegation to keep a low profile during the visit, Lin said the MOFA has already directed the representative office to offer all necessary aid to ensure her group's safety.

Kao Chin said her delegation will mainly be composed of offspring of the Kaosha Warrior Group, a band of indigenous Taiwan people drafted by the Japanese authorities to fight for Japan during World War II, when Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule.

The lawmaker from the opposition Non-Partisan Solidarity Union said her mission will demand a Japanese apology for its forcing Taiwan aborigines into war and compensation for bereaved members of the Kaosha Warrior Group.
Another major purpose of the visit is to push Japan to remove tablets dedicated to Kaosha warriors' souls from its controversial Yasukuni Shrine in downtown Tokyo, Kao Chin said.

The Yasukuni Shrine commemorates and worships those who died in war for Japan. However, the shrine has become a symbol of Japan's militant past, since the tablets of more than 1,000 convicted war criminals, including 14 Class-A war criminals, were installed there in the 1980s.
Kao Chin said the offspring of the Kaosha Warrior Group do not want to see their ancestors' souls worshipped at the controversial shrine any longer.
During Kao Chin's visit to the MOFA office, Lin promised her that the representative office in Japan will offer her group technical assistance to ensure their trip is a safe and smooth one.

"We have directed our representative office in Tokyo to keep close contact with the Japanese police to ensure that your delegation will not be harassed by any Japanese rightwing nationalistic groups during its stay in Japan," Lin told the actress-turned-lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES FREEZE APPLICATION OF FINGERPRINTING ON NEW ID CARDS

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices passed a provisional ruling to temporarily freeze the application of an article of the Household Registration Law that requires fingerprinting when claiming national identification cards.

The Council of Grand Justices announced the provisional ruling after discussing a request filed by the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) May 30 to invalidate the fingerprinting provision in the Household Registration Law.
Article 8 of the law stipulates that people claiming new national identification cards must be fingerprinted, which critics say encroaches upon their basic human rights.

The ruling states that establishing files on fingerprinting will consume a large amount of human and material costs and that if the files later have to be destroyed because of the unconstitutionality of the law upon which such files are built, it will be a tremendous waste of administrative resources.
In addition, whether or not the fingerprinting encroaches on the basic rights of the public enshrined in the Constitution is a controversial issue.
For this reason, the provision requiring fingerprinting will be suspended, the justices said in the provisional ruling.

The provisional ruling will only be invalidated when the grand justices make a constitutional interpretation on Article 8 of the Household Registration Law or six months after the promulgation of the temporary ruling at the latest.

Meanwhile, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said the Cabinet will work with the provisional ruling of the grand justices, and that the renewal of ID cards, which was scheduled to begin July 1 for one year, will be put on hold.

Cho Jung-tai said that people over the age of 14 claiming their ID cards for the first time will be issued the old type of ID cards and will not be fingerprinted. After the grand justices make their interpretation, these people will have to go through the entire process again for new ID cards.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER SUGGESTS GOVERNMENT HELP IN FISHERY DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Joanna Lei urged the government Friday to seek to participate in relevant world bodies as "an entity" in order to speak for the people in Taiwan in fishery disputes and other international issues.

Addressing a recent fishery dispute between Taiwan and Japan, Lei said that it is extremely important for the government to seek participation in international organizations to voice the interests of the Taiwan people and she called on the government to clearly underline Taiwan's stance on the issue in order to protect the interests of Taiwan fishermen.

Although Taiwan is unable to join the United Nations and other international organizations as a result of pressure from Beijing, Lei prodded the government to do so as "an entity" on the grounds that protecting the people's interests is the top and the most urgent issue for the government.

Citing a notion advocated by Myres S. McDougal, a renowned authority on international law and the co-founder of the New Haven School, the KMT lawmaker explained that McDougal's method is oriented toward an attainable policy that respects human dignity, in contrast to the purely analytical forms that preceded it.

She contended that the government must seek a greater international presence to help the people of Taiwan reach out when facing difficulties in the international arena, despite the country's diplomatic isolation.

Taiwan has already joined several regional fishery organizations thanks to its key role in the international deep-sea fishing industry, she noted, but added that it is worth noting whether the matter will develop into an international incident.

Nearly 50 Taiwan fishing vessels from Suao tried Thursday to encircle a Japanese petrol boat which had chased Taiwan vessels out of an area about 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast where the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

In the last two years, Taiwan fishing ships operating in the area have been dispersed or detained by Japanese patrol vessels, fanning resentment among the Taiwan fishermen whose livelihoods have been seriously affected.

Lin Yueh-ying, a chief delegate of the Suao Fishermen's Association in Ilan County, pointed out that the interests of domestic fishermen were greatly hurt after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and Hualien counties.
"Japan has gone too far and has been detestable, " Lin said, complaining that "Taiwan fishermen are so unfairly treated that they do not want to keep silent and swallow their anger any more."

In the face of the fishery dispute arising from the overlap in the exclusive economic zones of the two countries, the government must send more patrol ships to step up protection of Taiwan fishermen in the short term, industry sources said, arguing that on the other hand, Taiwan must try to ink a mutually recognized accord with Japan to secure the long-term interests of Taiwan fishermen.
Resolving the issue through diplomatic approaches may be a time-consuming task, but it is a more practical and secure way to achieve the aim, the sources said.
Taiwan's fishery authorities have actually held unsuccessful negotiations with Japan 14 times in the hope of settling the dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH COMMISSION INVITES YOUTHS TO SPEND SUMMER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: To encourage local youths to get a deeper affinity with their nation during the approaching summer vacation, the National Youth Commission (NYC) has organized a series of Taiwan study tour packages to allow young people to see, feel and touch the land where they live.

A total of 13 theme camps are included in the NYC "Youth Study-Travel Taiwan" project. The camps are designed with an itinerary including tourist visits, physical training, public discussions, tours to national establishments and experience-oriented learning, according to the NYC.

Of the theme camps, perhaps the weirdest is what the NYC is calling an "experience camp in jail" in Chiayi, southern Taiwan. Participants will be handcuffed, chained and fed prison food in jail to "let them feel what it's like if a person loses freedom, " an official said.
Besides the jail camp, there is also a baseball camp in which participants will visit a series of baseball fields around the country, as well as learn about the sport and play.

NYC Chairwoman Chen Li-chun noted that study tours do not have to be in a foreign country. The innovative "Youth Study-Travel Taiwan" program could not only allow students to travel, but also gain an in-depth knowledge of Taiwan, she claimed.
Meanwhile, to make Taiwan a tourist destination for foreign youths, the theme camps will also be open for them. According to the NYC, each theme camp will have three vacancies for foreign students.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE TO SET STRATEGY FOR 2ND-PHASE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office will set up a special task force to review the steps, method and strategy to promote a second phase of constitutional reforms, a top presidential aide said Friday.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said the review will be completed in a week and that the task force will consult public opinion before deciding upon whether a cross-partisan constitutional reform committee should be established to facilitate the reforms.
According to Yu, President Chen Shui-bian is very happy about the successful passage of a constitutional amendment package early this week, which has made possible a second phase of reforms.

Yu said it remains the government's goal to upgrade the country's competitiveness through the reforms and to have a new constitution implemented in 2008 together with the inauguration of the new president, legislature and administration.

Issues to be addressed in the second phase of reforms will include the introduction of a voluntary military service system, civil rights, labor rights and human rights protection, as well as the enhancement of welfare for the country's aboriginal population.

The mission-oriented National Assembly passed on Tueday a constitutional amendment package to scrap the assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments, to reduce the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and to adopt a "single seat, two votes" electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007.
Officials have promised that the next phase of reforms will not involve sensitive issues such as changes to the country's sovereignty, territorial boundaries or official designation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPU ASIA-PACIFIC CONFERENCE HELD IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Asia-Pacific regional conference of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) was held Friday in Tokyo, with 170 representatives from eight countries taking part.
Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu, who initiated the DPU, gave a 30-minute keynote speech on democratic values that was transmitted from Taipei via teleconference to the attendees in Tokyo.

The conference was jointly sponsored by the DPU International Preparatory Committee, the Japan-ROC Diet Members' Consultative Council, a pro-Taiwan group in the Japanese Diet, and the Japanese Federation of Economic Organizations.

Takeo Hiranuma, who is a former Japanese economics minister and is now chairman of the Diet council, and Koh Se-kai, Taiwan's top representative to Japan, also gave speeches at the conference, endorsing Lu's calls for democracy, peace and human rights in the region and the rest of the world.
The DPU will be formally inaugurated in August in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP TO HONG KONG BANNED FROM ENTERING AIRPORT OFF-LIMITS AREA

TEXT.P: The Repulic of China's (ROC's) representative to Hong Kong confirmed Friday that the Hong Kong government has begun to deny him access to a restricted area of the Hong Kong airport.

Pao Cheng-kang, head of the Bureau of Hong Kong Affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council, told CNA in a telephone interview that his exclusion began on April 18 when he was not allowed to enter the off-limits area to welcome opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan. The incident was described at the time by Hong Kong authorities as a case of poor coordination.
His application to enter the same area to welcome Taichung Mayor Jason Hu on June 6 was also rejected, Pao said.
It is uncertain if the measure is temporary or permanent, but political analysts said if it is permanent, it will be a major setback to Taiwan-Hong Kong relations since 1997.

The representative of the ROC did not enjoy the privilege of entering the restricted area of the airport until the handover of Hong Kong from the British colonial government to China in 1997. In the event of a need to enter the off-limits area, an application must be submitted beforehand through China Airlines (CAL), and the escort of CAL staff is required while in the area.

The Moscow Times: Moscow Puts Its Bets on a Rally

The Washington Post: Pre-9/11 Missteps By FBI Detailed; Report Tells of Missed Chances To Find Hijackers.
The inability to detect the Sept. 11, 2001, hijacking plot amounts to a "significant failure" by the FBI and was caused in large part by "widespread and longstanding deficiencies" in the way the agency handled terrorism and intelligence cases, according to a report released yesterday, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PROMULGATES CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT PACKAGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian issued a decree Friday promulgating a package of constitutional amendments passed by the ad hoc National Assembly Tuesday.
The package comprises amendments to Articles 1, 2, 4, 5 and 8 of the Additional Articles of the ROC Constitution plus adding Article 12, the presidential decree said.
The new amendments will affect five aspects of the government:

-- Legislative downsizing: Beginning with the next Legislative Yuan to be elected in 2007, the number of legislators will be cut to 113 from the current 225 and their terms will be extended from three years to four years.

-- Legislative electoral system: The next legislature will be elected through a "single-seat constituency, two ballots" system instead of the current "single vote, multiple-seat constituency" system. Voters will cast two ballots, one for the constituency and another for political parties in at-large proportional representation.

-- Abolishment of the National Assembly: The National Assembly's powers to ratify future constitutional amendments and impeach the president or vice president will be transferred to other institutions.

-- Ratification by referendum: Future proposals to amend the Constitution that have received the consent of at least three-quarters of lawmakers or to change the national territory will be put to a popular referendum.
-- Impeachment by Grand Justices: The Council of Grand Justices will act as a Constitutional Court to decide on moves approved by the legislature to impeach the president or vice president.
Political pundits said this round of constitutional amendments will definitely have a far-reaching impact on Taiwan's future political development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HISTORY NOW IN BILINGUAL COMIC BOOKS AND ONLINE

TEXT.P: A 10-volume collection of color comic books in English and Chinese on the history of Taiwan was published Friday, with an online version also released.

The collection called, "A History of Taiwan in Comics, " was published by Third Nature Publishing Company under the commission of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) and the Council for Cultural Affairs.
A number of historians double-checked the accuracy of the information in the comics, said the editor in chief of the project, Wu Mi-cha, a professor of history at National Taiwan University.
The collection took two years and more than NT$10 million (US$320,000) to finish. It features the changes that have occurred in politics, culture and society in Taiwan.

Wu said that although they may only be comic books, the set contains more information than current history textbooks, adding that the books provide an insight into the fascinating lifestyles and values of the numerous ethnic groups that have lived in Taiwan over the years.
Since the collection is also in English, it can help foreigners and overseas Chinese better understand Taiwan, OCAC Minister Chang Fu-mei said.
The Internet version of the collection of comic books can be seen at: edu. ocac.gov.tw, and then clicking the "Taiwan History" link.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY HAS PRODUCED MOST UNIVERSITY CHIEFS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University has the distinction of having produced more university presidents than any other university in Taiwan, according to a university official Friday.

An alumnus of National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City, Wu Ming-yang, was inaugurated as president of the Kaohsiung Municipal Air University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, in March, bringing the number of Cheng Kung alumni who currently serve as heads of universities in Taiwan to 25, in addition to three other alumni who serve as university heads overseas.
The number is 45 if the 17 ex-heads of universities are included. Cheng Kung is unrivalled in Taiwan in terms of producing university chiefs, the university official said.
Founded in 1941 as an industrial school, it was developed into a general university in 1956 and was renamed National Cheng Kung University.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LOOKING FORWARD TO TAIWAN-U.S. FREE TRADE PACT BY NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday he is looking forward to entering into a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States by the end of next year.

At a meeting in his office with Tom Johnson, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, the premier said negotiations on the FTA, which began in 2002, have had some bumpy patches because of the complexity of the issues involved.
However, since an FTA between Taiwan and the United States would boost bilateral trade, especially U.S. exports to Taiwan, it would be beneficial for both sides, Hsieh said.
Furthermore, the premier said, such an agreement would encourage other nations to follow the lead of the U.S. in signing similar agreements with Taiwan, Hsieh said.
He thanked the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei for its backing of an FTA and for its sound advice, which was spelled out in its 2005 White Paper on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LI AO'S SMOKING GUN DOCUMENT SHOOTS BLANKS: PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: The alleged CIA report that independent Legislator Li Ao says is the smoking gun that shows that the president set up his own assassination attempt is a dud, prosecution authorities said Friday.

The document that Li produced as genuine to back his claim that the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on March 19, 2004 was staged is in the hands of the Tainan Prosecutors' Office in southern Taiwan.
Prosecutors who have examined the document said that it is riddled with errors -- including calling the vice president by the surname of Lee -- and is written entirely in Chinese.
Li claimed Wednesday that the document is a bone fide intelligence report from the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA).

Initial examinations indicated that the source of the document is unlikely to be the CIA, officials said, adding that the task force investigating the presidential election-eve shooting will check the authenticity of the document via normal channels.

Li claimed earlier this week that he had obtained a CIA report saying that President Chen staged his own election-eve shooting to win sympathy and ensure his re-election. Quoting the document, Li alleged that Chen employed two snipers to kill or injure Lu so that he would get sympathy votes.
The alleged CIA document identified one sniper as Chen Yi-hsiung and the other as someone surnamed Lee.

The investigative team announced earlier this year that it had discovered that the likely shooter was Chen Yi-hsiung, who allegedly committed suicide by drowning himself in a canal in the southern city of Tainan shortly after the March 20 presidential election in which the Chen-Lu ticket won by a slim margin.
A spokesman for the task force said the document in question did not give additional details on the full name of the person surnamed Lee and gave no supporting evidence for any of the other claims.
Meanwhile, a Presidential Office official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the document uses a great deal of emotionally charged and biased phraseology.

To the best of his understanding, the official said, CIA reports are known for their objectivity, neutrality and cautiousness. It would be out of character for a CIA report to use emotional or radical wording, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE BARS ENTRY TO FALUN GONG PRACTITIONER FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 10 (CNA) (By Charles Kang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan Falun Gong practitioner, Nie Shuwen, was blocked by Singapore immigration officials Friday from entering the city-state and was repatriated.
Nie, 72, arrived here along with 13 other Taiwan Falun Gong practitioners. They were invited by the Singapore branch of the New York-based Epoch Times to attend a new book-launching in the country.

Nie, a former director of the pediatrics department of the Shanghai Hospital, is the first mainland Chinese who declared her withdrawal from the Communist Party of China (CPC) while in Taiwan. She now lives in Taiwan.

Besides repatriating Nie by claiming she violated immigration laws, the officials also confiscated 600 copies of a book criticizing the CPC, according to members of the group who carried in this books.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA SHIPS COULD SAIL TO 'OVERLAPPING AREAS' TO PROTECT FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has ordered coast guard patrol ships to sail, if necessary, to the overlapping areas of Taiwan's and Japan's exclusive economic zones to protect local fishermen's legitimate fishing rights, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Friday.

Cho made the remarks a day after about 60 Taiwanese trawlers converged in waters about 80 nautical miles east of northern Taiwan to protest Japanese coast guard ships' chasing them from their traditional fishing grounds on many occasions.

The waters near a number of small, uninhabited islands known as the Tiaoyutais, which are claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China, have been Taiwan's traditional fishing grounds. However, Japan demarcated the area as part of its 200-mile economic zone in 1996 and has since often impounded Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter the region and have fined their owners. The absence of formal diplomatic ties has made it difficult to resolve the disputes.

Stressing that Premier Hsieh is concerned about local fishermen's well-being, Cho said the premier has demanded that the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) take necessary steps at appropriate time to defend the nation's sovereignty and fishing rights.
"The premier has asked that CGA patrol ships, if necessary, to sail to the overlapping areas of the economic zones to protect our fishermen's fishing rights," Cho said.
Nevertheless, Cho said, the government will endeavor to prevent the issue from becoming an international dispute.
Meanwhile, Cho said, the premier has directed diplomatic agencies to work closely with fishery authorities in negotiating with Japan over the issue.

Fishery officials from Taiwan and Japan have held 14 rounds of talks on the Tiaoyutai fishing rights issue, but have failed to reach an agreement because of the sovereignty dispute. Taiwan is pushing Japan to open a 15th round of talks as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER SWORN IN AS NEW CHIEF OF STRAITS EXCHANGE FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung was sworn in Friday as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) which is charged with the country's dealings with China in the absence of formal ties between the two sides.

Chang, who had served as premier between 2000 and 2002, called for resumption of exchanges with the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF's Beijing counterpart, after his new post was approved by the board of SEF directors, saying that exchanges should not stop because of the controversy over whether or not there is a consensus between the two sides about the meaning of "one China" in their meeting in 1992.
Beijing, which believes there was a consensus reached on the issue in its favor at the time, refused to resume exchanges after Taiwan said no such consensus was reached.

Claiming that the spirit of 1992 meeting between SEF and ARATS is "sidestepping controversies, respecting each other, talking and negotiating", the new SEF chief said it will bode well for bilateral ties if both sides of the strait can engage with the other based on this spirit.
However, he admitted the resumption of exchanges between the SEF and ARATS involving a lot of factors, many of which are beyond the control of the SEF.
Before the resumption of exchanges, Chang said the SEF will focus its attention on serving Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland especially those who are embroiled in legal disputes there.

He disputed critics' challenges about the legality of his double role as a lawmaker and the SEF chief, arguing that he is not the only legislator who serves concurrently as head of a non-governmental organization, and in any case, he is not being paid for working with the SEF.
Chang will serve out the remaining term of his predecessor, Koo Chen-fu, who died on Jan. 3 before his term ends on Dec. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. and Britain Agree on Relief for Poor Nations
The United States and Britain have reached an agreement on how the billions of dollars that the world's poorest nations owe to international lenders can be erased, removing the last impediment to an accord long sought by the richest nations. Treasury Secretary John W. Snow and his British counterpart, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, will present their proposal to a meeting of the finance ministers of seven of the Group of 8 industrial nations on Friday in London. The plan would free 18 countries, most of which are in Africa, from any obligation to repay the estimated US$16.7 billion they owe the international lenders. chairman.
Wall Street Journal: New Orders, After Four Years in the Rear, Boeing Is Set to Jet Past Airbus
The European jet maker Airbus had already surpassed Boeing Co. as the No. 1 builder of jetliners. Last year, it trounced Boeing in every key sales campaign. Since Boeing replaced its chief salesman, Boeing is on track this year to win more new orders than Airbus after four years in second place, both companies say. At the heart of today's race is the market for the industry's workhorses: the midsize planes used on transcontinental and transoceanic flights. Propelling Boeing back into the lead is the 787, the first plane to be designed from scratch since the 9/11 terrorist attacks and the first to fully take into account the industry's dramatic transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 11, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a U.S. House of Representatives and was the only legislator to oppose American involvement in both world wars.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director-general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River" and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada with two gold and four bronze medals.
2000: Officials from 30 Asian-Pacific cities reach an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.
2000: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale hits the central Taiwan county of Nantou, injuring 16 people.
2004: The Legislative Yuan passes amendments to the Labor Standard Law to allow laborers to open portable pension account.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH OFFICIALS DENY REPORTS ON SELF-PAYMENT RATIO HIKES

TEXT.P: Top health officials on Saturday denied reports that the self-payment ratio for outpatients and emergency patients under the national health insurance system will be raised July 16.
Both Department of Health Deputy Minister Chen Tzay-jinn and Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) President Liu Chien-hsiang denied the reports.

Chen said that although the DOH and the BNHI are hoping for a hike in the self-payment ratio, they will respect the decision of a national health insurance supervisory committee on when to put it into effect.
Chen noted that the committee still has misgivings about the proposed self-payment hike for outpatients and emergency patients.
Liu said that if the self-payment ratio is raised, it is estimated that about 20 percent of patients will be affected.

Liu said that most of the patients will not feel the extra burden if they are transferred to other hospitals, adding that chronic disease patients may have to change their habits of visiting regional or medical centers.

According to the fee hike plan envisaged by the BNHI, the self-payment amount for outpatients for district, regional and national medical center hospitals will be raised to NT$80 (US$2.54) , NT$240 and NT$360, respectively, from the present NT$50, NT$140 and NT$210, while the self-payment amount for emergency patients for regional and national medical center hospitals will be raised to NT$300 and NT$450, respectively, from the current NT$210 and NT$420.
A double hike of health insurance premiums and the self-payment ratio was put into effect in September 2003 despite opposition from the national health insurance supervisory committee and the public.
