DOC.HEADLINE: DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL ACTIVITIES HELD AT TACHIA RIVERSIDE PARK

TEXT.P: A series of activities kicked off Saturday morning at the Tachia Riverside Park along the Keelung River in celebration of the Dragon Boat Festival, Taipei City Government officials said.
The main event will be a dragon boat race with 3,000 participants forming 111 teams from around the world. The race will start in the evening.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will lead a team of high-ranking city government officials to compete with a team which is half made up of visually-impaired people.

According to Chinese tradition, the Dragon Boat Festival falls on the fifth day of the fifth month of the Chinese lunar calendar, with dragon boat races being held and glutinous rice wrapped in bamboo leaves being eaten in remembrance of Chu Yuan, a famous poet and official (343-290 B.C.) of the Warring States Period, who drowned himself after failing to convince the king of Chu to guard the kingdom against an enemy.
After a dragon boat show with teams from Japan, France and local visually-impaired people, Ma will preside over a glutinous rice dumpling making show, in which more than 1,000 people will take part.
The finished dumplings will be presented as gifts to physically and mentally challenged people as well as elderly people in the care of social welfare organizations.

In addition to the dragon boat races, a series of performance activities, including a water show, a Japanese drum show, and a traditional Chinese orchestra performance, will also be held at the Tachia Riverside Park at night to mark the Dragon Boat Festival, one of the most important Chinese festivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MEET WITH DPP MAYORS, MAGISTRATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will invite mayors and magistrates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as well as the heads of the DPP chapters in cities and counties around the country to a tea party next Tuesday, a lawmaker said Saturday.
William Lai, a DPP legislative whip, said the informal meeting at the Taipei Guest House is aimed at forging intraparty consensus on strategy for the year-end local government chiefs elections.
President Chen has organized four similar meetings with DPP legislators since May 18 to explore lawmakers' views on major policy issues.

"All those meetings have proved effective in forging intraparty consensus on important public issues, " Lai said, adding that President Chen attaches great importance to opinions and counseling offered by DPP lawmakers at those closed-door meetings.

As the year-end local government chiefs elections are expected to have a great impact on the future domestic political development and the DPP administration's power base, Lai said, President Chen wants to learn more about incumbent DPP mayors and magistrates' opinions on the party's platform and campaign strategy for the year-end elections.
Lai said Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and the DPP legislative caucus' three whips, including Lai himself, will also attend the June 14 meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES REPORT OF CONTACT WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: A Presidential Office spokesman denied Saturday a media report that some Beijing messengers have offered to help establish direct contact between Chinese President Hu Jintao and President Chen Shui-bian to pave the way for a cross-Taiwan Strait summit.

Dismissing the report as mere speculation, Chen Wen-tzung, director of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs, said the Presidential Office has never received any such information and has no plan to assign any presidential aides for the mission.

Chen pointed out that President Chen has mentioned on many occasions that cross-strait differences must be resolved through dialogue and that a government-to-government format is inevitable in conducting such talks.

The president welcomes a meeting with Hu as long as it is not subject to any preconditions and believes cross-strait talks must be based on a national consensus and the best interests of the Taiwan people, Chen said.
Also, Chen said the Hong Kong visit by Presidential Office official Chao Lin from May 18-20 was only a private trip.

According to the report, the Beijing messengers have proposed that contact be established through presidential aides of both sides, with the possible choices being Hu's premier aide, Ling Jihua, and Chen's close aide, Ma Yung-cheng.
The report said that Chao might have been assigned with the mission of meeting with some Beijing representatives during his Hong Kong visit.
Also commenting on the report, William C.T. Lai, a whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus, urged the media to stop circulating rumors that are not based on facts.

Lai noted that President Chen has said he is not afraid to negotiate with China provided that Taiwan's sovereignty, democracy and peace are secured and that he is willing to meet Hu in a third country.

But this scenario will only be possible through the mediation of the international community, and the visits to China by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong have proven futile in changing Beijing's mind concerning its desire to annex Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEMENS FACTORY WORKERS CONCERNED ABOUT BENQ'S RECENT ACQUISITION

TEXT.P: Many of the more than 1,800 employees working at the mobile phone factory of Siemens AG in Kamp-Lintfort, a small town of just over 40,000 people in Germany, have expressed concerns about their fate following BenQ's recent acquisition of the factory.

The Taiwan-based BenQ Group announced June 7 the acquisition of Siemens AG's Mobile Devices Business and said that the acquisition will create the world's fourth largest handset maker as well as the largest mobile phone technology company in Greater China, bringing BenQ's combined annual revenue to US$10.9 billion.

However, George Nassauer, president of the Union of Siemens AG, told the Central News Agency bluntly in a telephone interview that the workers do not want to join BenQ Group because they do not know the new owner of the factory. The workers are also worried about job security, he added.

Despite the fact that BenQ Group is currently comprised of ten companies and five main business groups and units to produce various products in the fields of display and imaging, networking and communications, digital computer and storage business, and so on, in the eyes of German consumers, the group is only a LCD panel maker and is not a familiar brand to them.

Under these circumstances, many Germans expressed surprise at hearing that the renowned Siemens AG's mobile phone device business had been acquired by an unknown company from Taiwan as they take great pride in Siemens-made mobile phones, just like Leica cameras and Agfa films.

Nevertheless, Michael Leuker, president of the factory's union, also criticized Siemens AG's executives, saying that they are all inexperienced in running the factory and admitting that under Siemens leadership, there will be no future for the factory's employees.

The headquarters of Siemens AG had planned earlier to move the factory to Hungary due to high labor costs in Germany. In order to prevent it from doing so, the factory employees agreed to an increase in work hours from 35 hours per week to 40 hours without a corresponding salary increase.

However, the factory's average daily losses of 1.5 million euros in the first quarter of this year led Siemens Group to decide to sell the factory in order to avoid harming the group's reputation, ignoring the union's appeals that the group first try to save the factory with its partners.
A German weekly reported recently that the factory is brimming with an atmosphere of fear, anger and sadness over news of the sale to BenQ.
Pointing out that the factory workers no longer trust their old bosses, Leuker said that the urgent need for Benq Group is to eliminate the employees' feelings of fears and uncertainty.
He also said that the group should not only establish mutual trust with their German employees, it should also work on boosting German consumers' confidence in Siemens-made mobile phones.
Statistics show that despite an increase of 9 percent in global mobile phone production in the first quarter of this year, Siemens-made mobile phone market share registered a decline of 2.5 percent.

Another concern of the factory employees is that German media have reported that BenQ just wants to use the Siemens AG's brand to gain a foothold in markets in Europe and Russia and that mobile phone products with the Siemens brand will eventually disappear once the Taiwanese group achieves its goal.

A German daily also revealed recently that the name of Siemens AG's Mobile Devices Business will be changed to BenQ Mobile Devices in the future, showing that the Taiwanese group is not interested in the German electronics giant's brand name.

As to questions regarding the future of the factory, many believe that it all depends on whether the new owner can reduce production costs and that it is unavoidable for BenQ Group to lay off employees.

Declining to give a response to a question relating to the possibility of the new owner laying off workers at the factory with severance pay, Leuker said that his union is planning to take the necessary steps to deal with this possibility. "You can imagine our feelings," he added.
Siemens AG is a global powerhouse in electrical engineering and electronics and has roughly 440,000 employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE MINISTER WELCOMES PROPOSED TAX CUT

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Lee Chin-lung on Saturday welcomed the premier's announcement Friday that the business tax on household, medical and agricultural products will be reduced in the future.

Lee said that the council will be happy to see the proposed tax cut implemented, saying it will not only lower the burden of taxation on farmers and fishermen, but also encourage consumers to purchase domestically-produced farm goods.

Premier Frank Hsieh announced the policy after he ordered the formation of a special task force June 5 to flesh out tax reform measures in line with President Shui-bian's directives for taxation reform last week.
Hsieh also said that some of the items in the three major categories will not be subject to business taxation in order to help disadvantaged people.
Lee noted that the tax cut will help farmers and fishermen, whose earnings are normally less than those employed in other sectors.

Meanwhile, David Huang, the convener of the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, praised the new policy as the right way to go, saying that taxes on items concerning people's basic needs should be lowered, while those on luxury or other consumer products should be hiked to properly reflect economic growth.

Huang added that all details concerning the tax reform plan should be put on table to allow all relevant parties to discuss them and give their input. A national consensus on the tax reform proposals is definitely needed before the government implements them, he stressed.

At the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's caucus office at the Legislative Yuan, a party whip, Chen Chin-jun, urged the public to "have a healthier attitude" toward the government's tax reform proposals, which include raising the national tax rate to 15 percent from the current 13.6 percent, as well as hiking business tax rates and those of some other categories.
Many critics misinterpreted the proposal as an across-the-board tax hike.

Defending the president's six-point tax reform plan unveiled last week, the legislator explained that the plan is aimed at broadening the tax base and establishing a taxation system that is based on the principles of fairness and social justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELF-PAYMENT HIKE FOR OUTPATIENTS TO BE ANNOUNCED JUNE 15

TEXT.P: A senior Department of Health (DOH) official said Saturday that a self-payment ratio hike for outpatients and emergency patients is scheduled to be announced June 15.
DOH Secretary-General Lai Chin-hsiang also said the hike is expected to be put into effect July 16.
His words came after Department of Health Deputy Minister Chen Tzay-jinn and Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) President Liu Chien-hsiang earlier in the day denied such reports.

Chen said that although the DOH and the BNHI are hoping for a hike in the self-payment ratio, they will respect the decision of a national health insurance supervisory committee on when to put it into effect.

However, Lai said that the self-payment amount for outpatients and emergency patients will be raised, while the self-payment amount for those visiting Chinese medicine doctors or dentists will not be raised.
Lai said a national health insurance supervisory committee is not opposed to the hike, but it has expressed the hope that the DOH will prepare complementary measures.

According to the fee hike plan envisaged by the BNHI, the self-payment amount for outpatients for district, regional and national medical center hospitals will be raised to NT$80 (US$2.54) , NT$240 and NT$360, respectively, from the present NT$50, NT$140 and NT$210, while the self-payment amount for emergency patients for regional and national medical center hospitals will be raised to NT$300 and NT$450, respectively, from the current NT$210 and NT$420.
A double hike of health insurance premiums and the self-payment ratio was put into effect in September 2003 despite opposition from the national health insurance supervisory committee and the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP NOMINEES URGED TO COORDINATE AMONG THEMSELVES IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang (KMT) official suggested Saturday that the nominees of the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally People First Party (PFP) for the year-end city and county chief elections first coordinate among themselves to produce only one joint candidate for each city and county.
Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, made the suggestion when he spoke on how to coordinate the candidates of the KMT and the PFP.
Both parties have decided to start to talk about cooperation in the year-end elections on June 22, when the two parties will have decided their candidates for the elections.

Liao said that the KMT has prepared its own integration mechanism for the two parties and that it will consider whether to conduct public and party opinion polls or consult opinion leaders among the candidates of the two parties. The top leaders of the two parties will decide on this matter, he added.
He said the city and county chief elections concern local affairs and that if the matter can be sorted out locally, then there is no need for the party central to step in.
He cited Nantou County as an example, saying that P. K. Chiang, a KMT vice chairman from Nantou, is now actively coordinating between KMT nominee Lee Chao-chin and PFP nominee Chen Chih-ping.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LAUDS LUKANG DRAGON BOAT FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh lauded the Lukang Dragon Boat Festival race Saturday as one of the oldest and most colorful races on the island.

Hsieh made the remarks when he was invited to attend the dragon boat race in Lukang, Changhua County. Also attending were Chunghua County Magistrate Wong Chin-chu, National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports Minister Chen Chuan-show, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai, and Legislator Wei Ming-ku.

Hsieh noted that there are about a dozen dragon boat races being held around the island to celebrate Dragon Boat Festival Saturday and that he has chosen Lukang because it is famous for traditional culture.

He said that if Taiwan wants to attract foreign tourists to Taiwan, it has to work to promote its distinctive features, adding that Lukang, with its rich traditional cultural heritage, could work toward this direction.
He added that there has been a record high number of foreign tourists to Taiwan this year.

Magistrate Wong said that the Lukang dragon boat race has become one of the most important activities in Lukang every Dragon Boat Festival. She expressed appreciation for the subsidy provided by the central government for the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PROPOSES EXPANDING FUNCTION OF 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday proposed that the government expand the function of the "mini three links" as an interchange between Taiwan and China before direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links are opened up.

Ma, who also serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and is a candidate in the party's upcoming chairmanship election, put forth the proposal during a campaign stop on the frontline island of Kinmen, which has maintained ferry service to China's Xiamen port since 2001.

Ma pointed out that while only around 20,000 people took trips between Taiwan and China via Kinmen in 2001, the figure is expected to top 500,000 this year, which he said shows that Kinmen can play a more positive role as a cross-strait interchange to enhance exchanges of people between both sides.
Ma said related facilities in Kinmen should be improved to make it more convenient for people, especially China-based Taiwanese businesspeople, to use Kinmen as a transit to travel across the strait.
With the Kinmen airport enjoying a tourist capacity of five million a year, Kinmen should have no problem becoming a transit alternative to Hong Kong and Macau for cross-strait travelers, Ma said.

On his KMT chairmanship bid, Ma pledged that if he is elected, he will integrate the "pan-blue alliance, " stabilize cross-strait relations, reject Taiwan independence as a possible option for Taiwan's future and lead the party back to power in 2008.
Ma said he will also fight for the rights of Kinmen residents in order to reciprocate for their sacrifices over the past decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSIONS SHOULD ONLY BE HELD FOR URGENT BILLS: KMT

TEXT.P: Facing the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's call for an extra legislative session, the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday that extra sessions should only be held to deal with urgent bills for the benefit of the people.

Chen Chieh, the KMT legislative caucus whip, told reporters that he is willing to hold talks with his counterparts of other parties on the issue of holding an extra session. However, he stressed that extra sessions should only be held to deal with urgent bills that concern the well-being of the people.
He said that if the DPP wants the extra session simply to address bills for its own benefit, then the KMT is against it.

Referring to a special budget bill for the Executive Yuan's long-stalled arms procurement plan, the lawmaker suggested that the Ministry of National Defense rearrange the planned spending for the procurement by including it in its annual budgets, instead of calling for an extra budget bill.

Meanwhile, Tzeng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Coordinating Commission, claimed that the ruling DPP sees the holding of extra sessions as part of the Legislative Yuan's normal operations, warning that such an attitude could damage the system.

Besides, he added, the Legislature has just concluded its first session and there are still five to go before it finishes its current term in 2007. The KMT doesn't believe it is urgent at present for the Legislative Yuan to call an extra session, Tzeng said, adding that if the DPP legislative caucus proposes an extra session, then the KMT may oppose it.

Upon the end of the last legislative session May 31, Premier Frank Hsieh expressed the hope that an extra session would be called to screen bills that he described as "critical, " which include those related to the arms procurement package and Executive Yuan restructuring, revisions to the liquor and tobacco taxation law, a special statute on flood control, and a statute on the establishment of a labor pension fund supervisory commission, as well as to review President Chen Shui-bian's list of Control Yuan member nominees.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 500 TAIWAN ENTREPRENEURS ATTEND BUSINESS MEETING IN JIANGSU
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 11 (CNA) (By K.F. Lo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 500 Taiwan entrepreneurs attended a business meeting held in Xuzhou in the southeastern mainland Chinese province of Jiangsu Saturday.
Taiwan National Federation of Industries Chairman Hou Chen-hsiung, Taiwan Cement Group Chairman Leslie Koo and other prominent figures from Taiwan's business sector attended the meeting.

China, attaching great importance to the meeting, sent Li Bingcai, executive director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, to attend the meeting. Jiangsu Provincial Governor Liang Baohua and representatives from 14 Taiwan businesspeople's associations in Jiangsu also attended.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG RELEASES FIRST WAVE OF ADS FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, one of the two candidates in the upcoming main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship election, presented his first round of campaign ads in the print media Saturday in search of support from KMT members.
Wang is running against Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in the election slated for July 16. Both Wang and Ma are KMT vice chairmen.
In the ads, Wang stressed his capability to integrate the opposition "pan-blue alliance" to win the 2008 presidential election.

Wang has said that the new KMT chairmen should strengthen reforms, resolve problems within the party, such as the party's assets and the retirement of its cadres, and integrate the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, People First Party and New Party in order to present a single ticket for the 2008 presidential election.

Noting that the year-end city and county elections will play a pivotal role in determining who will win the 2008 presidential election, Wang said the new KMT chairman should assume all the responsibility for how the party performs in the year-end elections.

Wang said he has been supportive of using the "pan-blue alliance's" majority clout in the legislature and even some rational street protests as ways to fight against what he claimed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's frequent resorting to populism, stressing that "special times require special measures."

He stressed that he does not consider the KMT chairmanship as a bridge to the presidency, but instead sees it as an opportunity to help the KMT and the "pan-blue alliance" to win the 2008 presidential election.
Wang on Saturday began his "around the island" tour to seek support, with his first stops being in the counties of Tainan, Chiayi and Kaohsiung.

During a stop in his home county of Kaoshiung, Wang expressed gratitude to Kaohsiung residents who mobilized some 18,000 KMT members to endorse his registration as a candidate for the party chairmanship.
Although admitting that it is still too early to tell whether he will win the election, Wang said that he is becoming more and more confident.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR DHARMA MASTER YIN SHUN HELD SATURDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, Northern Taiwan, June 11 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A memorial service was held Saturday in Hsinchu County for the late Dharma Master Yin Shun, who passed away on June 4 at the age of 100.

Venerable Yin Shun, one of the most respected contemporary Buddhist masters in world and mentor of Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, was a great Buddhist scholar and an advocate of humanizing Buddhism.

Led by Master Cheng Yen, several thousand Tzu Chi followers attended the memorial service organized by the foundation, while an additional 60,000 or so Tzu Chi members scattered around the world participated in simultaneous memorial services held in Tzu Chi offices around the globe.
Several top political figures, including President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Fran Hsieh, and other government officials traveled to Hsinchu Friday to pay their respects to the late Dharma Master.
Master Yin Shun, born in 1906 in Zhejiang Province, put most of his efforts into "searching for what the ultimate and core teachings in Buddhism are.

His disciple, Master Tzu Chi, who has set up a huge foundation dedicated to humanitarian aid, charitable service, medical service and education, and promoting Buddhism around the globe, told Venerable Yin Shun a few minutes before his death that she and her followers would continue his efforts in promoting the humanizing of Buddhism.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER TO DEMAND REMOVAL OF SHRINE TABLETS FOR ABORIGINAL SOLDIERS

TEXT.P: Aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei said Saturday that she will leave for Japan next week to demand the removal of tablets for a group of Taiwan aboriginal soldiers forced to fight for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II from a controversial shrine for war dead in Tokyo.

Kao Chin from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union said she will also demand an apology and compensation from the Japanese government for the persecution of indigenous residents during its colonial rule in Taiwan. She will lead a 60-member delegation made up of family members of the deceased aboriginal soldiers.
Kao Chin said it is absurd that the aboriginal soldiers, whom she calls victims of Japanese persecution, are honored together with their persecutors at the Yasukuni Shrine.

Although the protesters will not be allowed to enter the shrine, they will perform rites of their respective tribes outside the shrine and sing songs to comfort the spirits of their ancestors, she said.
The Yasukuni Shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan.

Kao Chin sued Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi two years ago for violating Japan's constitution by paying a visit to the shrine, but the suit was rejected by an Osaka district court. Kao later appealed, and the high court of Osaka is expected to announce its ruling on the appeal June 17, according to the lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WANTS DPP COOPERATION IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: If the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) cannot cooperate with its smaller "pan-green camp" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , then the TSU will not rule out the possibility of asking former President Lee Teng-hui's daughter to run for Taipei County magistrate in the year-end election.
Cheng Cheng-lung, TSU secretary-general, made the remarks while commenting on possible cooperation in the "pan-green camp" in the year-end city and county chief elections.

Cheng stressed that the party "absolutely has the sincerity to cooperate, " but if the DPP refuses "to budge any inch," the TSU will consider inviting Lee An-ni, daughter of the former president, who is the spiritual leader of the TSU, to run for Taipei County magistrate.

Taipei County is generally considered a big prize as the party whose candidate wins the heavily-populated county is expected to have a better chance of winning the presidential election in 2008. The DPP has held the Taipei County magistracy for the last 16 years.

Cheng noted that DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang held a meeting recently during which neither touched on matters of substantial cooperation, but they promised to keep in touch via hot line. The DPP also said that it would respond to the TSU on the extent of cooperation after sorting out the matter, Cheng added.

TSU Chairman Su has suggested a model of cooperation for the year-end "three-in-one elections, " namely the elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors, and village and township chiefs.

Under the model, the TSU would support the DPP's candidates in certain cities and counties, while the DPP would support the TSU candidates for village and township chiefs, according to Su. In other cities and counties, the DPP would support the TSU's candidates, he added.

Cheng said that the two parties could target city and county chief, and village and township chief elections for cooperation, and that both sides could talk about city and county chief cooperation first.

He said that the TSU has already nominated its former Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming to run for Keelung City mayor, while the DPP has yet to choose a candidate, and the TSU couldn't possibly withdraw from the Keelung mayoral election.

The DPP also has yet to name a candidate in Hualien County, which is also a county where both parties could cooperate. In Tainan County, incumbent DPP mayor Hsu Tien-tsai is seeking a new term, and the TSU is mulling whether to put forward its own candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT JUBILANT AT SON'S ENGAGEMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he has no more personal worries now that his son has become engaged and will soon marry.
"From now on, I'll concentrate my full energy on reinvigorating our economy and accelerating political reform, " Chen said at his son's engagement party held in the central city of Taichung.
Chen further said he is very pleased that his son Chen Chih-chung will soon marry a pianist who he believes will bring music into his family life.
Chen's daughter-in-law-to-be, Huang Jui-ching, has a master's degree in piano performance from the Taipei National University of the Arts.

Chen Chih-chung, who obtained a master's degree in law from the University of California at Berkeley in May, will marry his fiancee June 18. The couple will then travel to the United States to continue their studies.

The engagement ceremony took place at Huang Jui-ching's home in Taichung City, while the engagement party was held at Evergreen Laurel Hotel. Most of the party guests were Huang's relatives and family friends. Only a few political figures were invited to the party, including Changhua County Magistrate Wong Chin-chu, Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi and Cabinet Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan.

Expressing his feelings about his son's marriage, President Chen wrote in an article published in an online weekly bearing his nickname A-bian earlier this week that he hopes his two children can learn to adopt a business-as-usual attitude toward the limelight shone on them due to their status as members of the first family.
In the article, the president also expressed his hope that his two children and all other local young people can learn to "be themselves and be responsible."
The president's daughter, Chen Hsing-yu, a mother of two young sons, just obtained a master's degree from National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Clinical Dentistry last Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED ABOUT DELAY IN TAIWAN'S ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The United States has expressed a high degree of concern over the delay in Taiwan's latest arms procurement plan and the challenge posed by this situation to Taiwan's security.

During recent meetings with a group of visiting Taiwanese journalists, most of the U.S. officials, members of Congress and scholars raised similar questions regarding what they see as Taiwan's inability to reach a consensus on the arms procurement plan to show the United States its resolve to defend itself while at the same time expecting U.S. soldiers to fight for the island in the event of an invasion by China.

The Cabinet-proposed NT$480 billion arms procurement package to buy a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and eight diesel-electric submarines has been blocked by the opposition-controlled legislature for two consecutive sessions.
The opposition Kuomintang and People First Party have picked at the high price tag of the procurement and the way the procurement is budgeted.

Washington officials have pointed to what they call the absurdity of the fact that Taiwan is decreasing its annual defense spending, which now accounts for only 2.5 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) , despite the rapid yearly increase in China's military spending.
The officials have also warned that the continued delay of the procurement package might draw a negative response from the U.S. Congress and cost Taiwan the chance to acquire the weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTAMINATED DUCK EGGS NOT ENTERING MARKET: COA

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said Saturday that all dioxin-contaminated duck eggs in Changhua County are destroyed as soon as they are confirmed to be contaminated and that no such eggs are circulating in the market.
The officials made the reaffirmation after reports that some of the contaminated eggs may have entered the market.
Duck eggs produced in Changhua County's Hsienhsi village were confirmed in March by National Cheng Kung University to have been contaminated by dioxin

According to COA and Department of Health (DOH) officials, they have destroyed more than 2 million ducks and 93.34 tons of duck eggs contaminated by dioxin since March, and have been conducting tests to determine the source of the contamination.

Huang Hung-yiao, Hsienhsi village chief, noted that the villagers suspect that the village's approximation to the Changhua Coastal Industrial Park may be the reason behind the duck eggs' being contaminated with dioxin.
They suspect that dust from metal products burned in the park settles on nearby land and water and eventually makes its way into the stomachs of the ducks.
They urged the DOH to determine as soon as possible the source of the contamination so that they won't have to live in worry any longer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSPEOPLE URGED TO INVEST IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 11 (CNA) (By H.C. Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Professor Ko Chen-en of National Taiwan University said Saturday that Taiwan businesspeople have concentrated on mainland China too much and that they should consider Southeast Asia as a place to invest.
Ko made the remarks while attending a seminar on the situation in the Asia-Pacific region which was sponsored by the Thailand chapter of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace.
Ko noted that Taiwan businesspeople flock to the mainland mainly because of language and geographic proximity, adding that their investment in the mainland has exceeded US$100 billion.
However, he said, the economy in Southeast Asia is developing rapidly, and Taiwan businesspeople shouldn't overlook this point.

He stressed that an international company should not only look at language factors when considering where to expand and that Taiwan businesspeople should not confine themselves to China and hinder their becoming internationalized.

Although Taiwan has been unable to join the Association of Southeast Asian Nations because of political factors, he suggested that Taiwan, based on its model of using the "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu" to enter the World Trade Organization in January 2002, join a proposed common market of the Southeast Asian countries.
Also attending the seminar were Lo Fu-chuan, president of the East Asia Relations Commission, and Lai I-chung, director of Foreign Policy Studies of Taiwan Thinktank.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZONGTZE WORLD RECORD

TEXT.P: Residents in the central Taiwan city of Taichung set a new Guinness world record Saturday by making 30,000 glutinous rice dumplings, known locally as "tzongtze, " in one hour.

The Taichung City Government mobilized 3,000 citizens to make "tzongtze, " a Chinese festive food made of glutinous rice and other ingredients wrapped in bamboo leaves, as part of Dragon Boat Festival celebrations.
The only tzongtze-related event in the Guinness Book of World Records was a stack of 13,192 tzongtzes exhibited in Singapore's Orchard Road park in 2003.

Guinness Book Co. staff members videotaped the record-setting tzongtze-making process in Taichung. At the end, two truck-mounted cranes lifted the 30,000 glutinous rice dumplings simultaneously to set a new Guinness world record.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and his wife joined the tzongtze making immediately after their return from a 72-hour visit to Beijing to attend an international meeting. Hu hung the final tzongtze on the crane to set the world record.
Hu said the event was part of the city government's efforts to promote Taichung's image and international profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN, STARBUCKS COOPERATE IN SUPPORTING ABORIGINAL KIDS

TEXT.P: In its seventh straight year of cooperation with World Vision Taiwan (WVT) in supporting education for aboriginal children, Starbuck Coffee has recently kicked off a three-month charity sale at all its coffee shops around the island to raise money to subsidize needy kids' school fees.

Mugs and pen holders with the picture of an "A-nai" doll on them are on sale at the coffee shops for the fund-raising drive. Customers can also donate directly by placing cash in the charity fund boxes set up at the coffee shops.

The annual WVT-Starbuck charity drive was first held in 1999 with the goal of providing disadvantaged indigenous children living in remote mountainous areas with access to knowledge and facilities for learning. The latest campaign, which will run through Aug. 31, aims to raise NT$5.5 million (US$176,000) to support 1,500 needy children living in the Jenai, Hsinyi and Hopin townships in Nantou County, according to WVT.
WVT hosted a party in Taipei on Saturday for 20 children from Honghsiang village in Jenai Township to celebrate the Dragon Boat Festival.

A volunteer worker for the international organization, which has been supporting disadvantaged children around the world, said that access to the remote village has been blocked on many occassions in recent years due to heavy downpours. The rainy season, which started last month, has led to the closure of the only road leading into the village for two weeks.

This not only affects the transport of supplies to the mountainous village, but also impacts key businesses, such as tourism, resulting in economic losses to the residents of the village. With most of the families in the village struggling just to make enough to eat, there are few resources left over to support the education of children, the WVT worker said.
Statistics show that about half of the children in the village come from poor or broken families that are unable to provide for their education, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES CONDUCIVE TO POLITICAL STABILITY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday increased exchanges across the Taiwan Strait will be conducive to domestic political stability and reduce risks for business people with interests in China.

Addressing a meeting of a business association in the central city of Taichung, Hsieh said he doesn't think that increased cross-strait exchanges would adversely affect Taiwan's separate identity distinct from that of China.

"The results of a series of public opinion polls show that more than 60 people of the respondents identify themselves as Taiwanese. Therefore, cross-strait civilian exchanges will not affect Taiwan's national identity," Hsieh said.
He also took the opportunity to clarify some misunderstandings of the government's tax reform plans.
The premier said the tax reform proposals unveiled by President Chen Shui-bian recently will by no means lead to an across-the-board tax hike.
"The reform plan is aimed at establishing a fairer, healthier and more balanced taxation system," Hsieh explained.

For instance, he said, the proposed minimum taxation measure is targeted at those who earn more than NT$10 million annually. At present, many rich families could legally avoid tax payment. Under the minimum tax scheme, high-income taxpayers will have to pay a minimum percentage of income tax. At any rate, Hsieh said the proposed new tax scheme is not aimed at increasing everybody's tax burden.

Touching on public order, Hsieh said the government has decided to recruit more police officers to maintain law and order and fight crime. With a national junior police college resuming recruiting students this year, he said, the police manpower shortage problems will be resolved gradually.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFGHAN ARTIST WINS TAIWAN AWARD AT VENICE BIENNALE
DOC.DATELINE: Venice, June 10 (CNA) (By Tong Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Linda Abdul, an Afghan artist, has won the first Taiwan Award to be presented in connection with the 2005 Venice Biennale, one of the most significant contemporary visual arts festival.

Tchen Yu-chiou, chairwoman of Taiwan's National Culture Association, will present the award to the Afghan artist at a presentation ceremony to be held in Venice Saturday. The Taiwan Award is sponsored by the National Culture Association.
Abdul will receive US$20,000 in prize money. The amount is even higher than the top award to be presented by the Venice Biennale organizing committee.
Tchen said this is the first time that the association has sponsored the competition with a view to upgrading Taiwan's international profile.
"We hope to expand the Taiwan Award's international recognition and clout through creative works presented by young artists who took part in the competition," Tchen explained.
According to Tchen, Abdul has won the prize because her work reflects Afghanistan's past and present and demonstrates profound cultural backgrounds.
The 2005 Venice Biennale will open Sunday and run through Nov. 6. The Taiwan pavilion is located at Pligioni palace, one of Italy's noted historical sites.

The Taiwan pavilion, named the Museum of Taiwan, opened Friday, attracting many art critics and lovers. In addition to Tchen, other Taiwan cultural officials, including Chen Chi-nan, chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, also traveled to Venice to attend the ceremony. Lin Ki-Tseng, ROC representative to Italy, and Umberto Vattani, secretary-general of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, were among the well-wishers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC PACIFIC UNION TO BE INAUGURATED IN TAIPEI IN AUGUST: LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday an international organization to be dedicated to promoting democracy and human rights will be inaugurated in Taipei in August.

Addressing a graduation ceremony at National Taiwan Ocean University, Lu said the Democracy Pacific Union (DPU) to be inaugurated Aug. 14 will be the first Taipei-led international organization since the Republic of China was forced out of the United Nations in 1971.
Lu said the DPU will serve as a conduit for Taiwan to share with the world its experience in promoting democracy, human rights, love, technology and peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER URGED TO APOLOGIZE FOR PRODUCING FAKE DOCUMENT

TEXT.P: Independent Legislator Li Ao should make a public apology for producing a fake document allegedly from the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) , a ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker said Saturday.
William Lai, a DPP legislative whip, said prosecutors have proved that Li's document is a dud.

Li claimed earlier this week that he had obtained a CIA report saying that President Chen Shui-bian staged his own election-eve shooting to win sympathy and ensure his re-election. Quoting the document, Li alleged that Chen employed two snipers to kill or injure Lu so that he would get sympathy votes.

Prosecutors investigating the March 19, 2004 shooting have examined the alleged CIA report that Li said the smoking gun that showed that Chen set up his own assassination attempt, Lai said, adding that the document has been proved a dud.

"Prosecutors who have examined the document said that it is riddled with errors -- including calling the vice president by the surname of Lee, " Lai said, adding that Li should apologize for producing such a document.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Hurricane-Battered Floridians Huddle in Home Sweet Fortress
Two weeks into a new hurricane season - with the first official tempest of 2005, Tropical Storm Arlene, already churning toward the Florida Panhandle on Friday - homeowners across the state are taking defensive measures to guard against a repetition of the calamities they suffered last year. With Florida still recovering from more than US$20 billion in property damage from four consecutive hurricanes last summer, with wrecked shingles, roof beams, siding and pool screens still piled up from Pensacola to Palm Beach, and with more than 10,000 families still in temporary shelter, no one wants to gamble this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 12, or the sixth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before being taken to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1938: China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: A strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human-powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohammed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabic.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of British prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served in the post for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other British prime minister in the 20th century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti-Communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members from both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
2000: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology kicks off its three-day session in Taipei with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.
2001: The Republic of China opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan gives a speech at Oxford University in the United Kingdom in which he focuses on Taiwan's economic and political situations and the future of his party.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS OF UNEMPLOYED TEACHERS TAKE TO THE STREETS

TEXT.P: About 3,000 unemployed teachers were expected to turn out in a march Sunday to vent their frustrations caused by their long-term unemployment.

Some of the marchers were expected to come from Kaohsiung and Pingtung cities in southern Taiwan, said Chen Chun-hao, convener of the private Saving Compulsory Education Alliance, which has collected signatures from some 10,000 teachers islandwide in the six-day period from June 1.

The teachers, who hold official teaching licenses, but most of whom have never had the opportunity to teach since graduating, were to walk the streets of Taipei to demand that the Ministry of Education face squarely the issue of licensed teachers' right to teach, Chen said.

The unemployed teachers will also ask the Ministry of Education to consider increasing the number of teachers in elementary and junior high schools and to implement small-class programs to create more openings for qualified teachers, Chen said.

The rally-goers will also express their opinion that elementary school and junior high school teachers should be taxed and that the revenues collected should be used for education; that the Ministry of Education should promulgate standards for teachers pedagogical performance and ethical principles so that bad teachers or those who have constantly exhibited "uncalled for behavior or remarks" during their careers can be replaced; and that the number of openings for elementary school and junior high school teachers should be published in each year's general regulations bulletin for the teacher's examinations, Chen added.
According to Chen, colleges and universities around Taiwan are churning out qualified teachers, but with 180 graduates this year for each opening, the number of unemployed teachers is growing.

There are currently about 60,000 college graduates and masters degree holders who have a teaching license, but fewer than 100 openings nationwide for teachers in elementary and junior high schools this year.

Since many colleges and universities in Taiwan have education and teaching courses in their curriculums, about 18,000 individuals qualified teach elementary or junior high matriculate each year, said Chen, adding that the number has been snowballing for several years, posing an increasingly serious problem in the education sector.
Taking Taipei City as an example, he said, more than 1,000 licensed teachers are vying for only 30-odd openings this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AWARD PRESENTED IN VENICE
DOC.DATELINE: Venice, Italy, June 11 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Two artists from Afghanistan were chosen by a panel of five Taiwan judges from among the contestants in the Venice Bienniale International Art Exhibition as winners of the first Taiwan Award Saturday.

Linda Abdul and Rahim Walizada were each awarded a trophy made out of a brick produced in Taiwan 200 years ago and a cash prize of US$20,000 by Tchen Yu-chiou, secretary-general of Taiwan's National Cultural Association.
Abdul, who is an Afghan refugee, had to choke back tears when she accepted the prize from Tchen.

She told the 50-odd audience at the award ceremony that she loves her country's culture, which was seriously damaged during the civil war, and would like to draw the world's attention through her art to the disaster facing the Afghan people and their culture.

Tchen said at the ceremony in Venice on the eve of the Venice Bienniale that the award was initiated by a group of young Taiwan artists and sponsored by her association to highlight Taiwan's aesthetic views on the international stage.
Tchen said the launch of the award is part of her country's efforts to enrich world culture with Taiwan's unique perspectives and to enhance Taiwan's profile in the art world.
Tchen said Taiwan wants to contribute to the globalization of art by offering its own aesthetic values.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Memo: U.S. Lacked Full Postwar Iraq Plan; Advisers to Blair Predicted Instability.
A briefing paper prepared for British Prime Minister Tony Blair and his top advisers eight months before the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq concluded that the U.S. military was not preparing adequately for what the British memo predicted would be a "protracted and costly" postwar occupation of that country, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH WATCHING U.S. MAD COW REPORTS CLOSELY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is watching carefully reports that an older animal on a U.S. ranch is suspected of having mad cow disease and that tests in Britain may take up to two weeks to confirm the disease, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.

Chen Lu-hung, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Safety, said that the suspect animal, the species of which was not disclosed and which was first tested in November, did not enter the human food or livestock feed supply because it was unable to walk when delivered for slaughter.
It did not have any chance of entering the Taiwan market, Chen added.

Chen noted, however, that if the animal is confirmed to have the brain-wasting bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , also known as mad cow disease, Taiwan will suspend imports of U.S. beef immediately.

If that is the case, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) will have to produce epidemiological documents proving that no such cases existing in the United States before Taiwan will reconsider reopening its doors to U.S. beef, Chen added.
U.S. beef just arrived back on the menu in Taiwan in April after being banned for a year and a half because of the discovery of a single case of mad cow disease in Washington State in 2003.
The DOH announced in late March that Taiwan would conditionally reopen its market to U.S. boneless beef from cattle under 30 months old beginning April 16.

Meat from U.S. cattle under 30 months old that is clear of bones, offal and specific risk materials, including brains, trigeminal ganglia, dorsal root ganglia and spinal marrow, and with certificates issued by the USDA, can now be imported into Taiwan. Ground beef is not included in the opening list, bureau officials added.

The DOH Bureau of Food Safety, meanwhile, has asked the USDA to provide Taiwan with a list of the names of legal, contracted U.S. slaughterhouses to be used as a reference to compare with the sources of the newly imported beef.

Taiwan health and agriculture officials have traveled to the U.S. to conduct on-site inspections of the implementation of U.S. safeguards against mad cow disease and have recently completed the necessary reviews for resuming the beef trade.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million-worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before Taiwan imposed the ban in December 2003. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, banned U.S. beef in the aftermath of the mad cow disease scare, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER CAMPAIGNS FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng visited the frontline island of Kinmen Sunday and vowed to build Kinmen into an "island of gold," using its huge potential for tourism and direct flights with China.

Wang made the remarks while giving a speech during a ceremony to mark the establishment of the Kinmen chapter of Wang's supporters endorsing his bid for the chairmanship of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) through a direct vote by party members set for July 16.

Saying he has an idea of opening a "Kinmen policy study center" if he is elected KMT chairman to help push for relevant legislation at the Legislative Yuan, Wang said that Kinmen has huge potential for tourism and cross-Taiwan Strait transport and added that he hopes to develop the island into a tourist resort and transit hub to help improve its economy.

Should he be elected KMT chairman, Wang went on, he will do his best to make Kinmen a cargo and passenger transport center, turning it into an exchange area and interaction platform for Taiwan businessmen operating on the two sides of the strait.

Cargo transport links between Kinmen and the Chinese cities of Xiamen, Quanzhou and Zhangzhou in nearby Fujian province should be set up before passenger services in a blueprint for a cross-strait transport network, according to a press release made public by Wang's office.

In efforts to implement the consensus obtained by incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan during a landmark "journey of peace" to China from April 26 to May 3, Wang firmly supports direct flights between Kinmen and Fujian so as to attract Chinese tourists to Taiwan and help Taiwan farm produce to be sold in China, the press release said.

Kinmen has maintained shipping services with Xiamen since the beginning of 2001, commonly known as the "mini three links" that also sees ferry links between the Taiwan-controlled island of Matsu and the port of Mawei in Fujian.

Meanwhile, Wang Chih-kang, a former minister of economic affairs who serves as the chief delegate in Wang's campaign team, claimed that Wang's chairmanship will help the KMT boost its chances in the 2008 presidential election.

Wang Chih-kang called on the KMT members to back Wang on the grounds that it is "necessary" to vote for Wang for the sake of the KMT and the 2008 presidential race to secure the maximum interests of the Republic of China.

Stressing that Wang will follow Lien's anti-independence line in terms of cross-strait relations, Wang Chih-kang said that the KMT needs Wang to help resolve the many problems facing the party, adding that "helping the KMT win is to help the ROC win."

The legislative speaker ran a prominent ad in print media Saturday soliciting support from KMT members and describing himself as the "right person" to lead the KMT at a juncture when the party has to consolidate the "pan blue alliance" to counter the "pan green camp" in December's city mayo and county chief elections.
Wang is set to compete against Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in the KMT chairmanship election. Both Wang and Ma are party vice chairmen.
Wang said Saturday in his native Kaohsiung County in an endorsement campaign that he is confident of winning the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC PLANNING, FINANCE OFFICIALS TO VISIT EUROPE

TEXT.P: A group of economic planning and finance officials will leave for Europe and Singapore Monday to explore opportunities for bilateral economic and financial cooperation, according to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The group, which will be composed of officials from the CEPD and the Ministry of Finance, will be headed by CEPD Vice Chairman Yeh Ming-feng during its two-week visit to the Netherlands, Germany and Singapore.

They are scheduled to tour Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport, the Port of Rotterdam, the Port of Bremen, the Port of Hamburg, the Frankfurt Airport and Singapore's Changi Airport during the trip that will run through June 25, Yeh said.

Also, he added, the group will meet with officials of central banks and financial authorities, as well as private financial institutions, to explain Taiwan's programs and vision for developing the country into a regional financial hub.

The main purpose of the visit is to learn about the experiences of these countries in the planning, development, operation and management of free trade zones, while seeking bilateral cooperation with related government agencies and private institutions, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES AT ODDS OVER EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The four political parties in the Legislative Yuan were at odds Sunday over whether the Legislative Yuan should gather for an extraordinary session to work on bills considered urgent by the government.

Legislator William Lai, the legislative whip of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said he hopes the legislature will gather for an extra session after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has chosen its new chairman July 16.

Citing a special budget for arms purchases and the confirmation of the president's nominees for members of the Control Yuan as examples, Lai said several bills and proposed revisions to some existing laws are urgently needed by the Executive Yuan and have to be enacted immediately.

Lai said his caucus will move before July 16 for an extra legislative session after July 16 and he expressed hope that Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is running for the KMT chairmanship, will convene inter-party negotiations to decide the exact date.
His opinion was supported by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which is a political ally of the ruling party.

Legislator Huang Shih-cho, the TSU deputy convener at the Legislative Yuan, said the just-concluded session that ran from February to May enacted 46 bills, which is the lowest number since 1999 and has seriously hindered the administration's agenda.

In order to address the problem, Huang said, an extra legislative session is needed, with the bills to be debated not necessarily limited to the budget for arms purchase and the confirmation of the Control Yuan nominees.
The KMT and its political ally the People First Party (PFP) , however, do not see the necessity for any extra legislative meeting.

Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, the KMT whip at the legislature, said his party believes an extraordinary session should be called only for dealing with constitutional issues, of which none are pending in the legislature.
Ordinary bills can be dealt with during regular sessions, Tseng said.

The PFP concurred with the KMT, with its legislative convener, Legislator Chen Chih-ping, claiming that the arms purchase has already been rejected by voters in a national referendum March 20, 2004. He added that he does not see any urgency which would require the legislature to deal with it during an extra session.
As to the president's nominees for the Control Yuan, Tseng went on, their names were presented to the previous legislature that was dissolved when the terms of its members ended in January.

The current legislature has not been asked by the president to confirm his nominees for the Control Yuan, so the legislature is not in a position to exercise its right to approve these nominees, whether or not there is an extra session.
The president presented his 29 nominees to the legislature in December 2004 but was asked to withdraw the list on the grounds that some of those nominated did not live up to public expectations.

The president refused to retract his list and the legislature refused to act on it. The political impasse continued after the new legislature gathered for its first session in February and has made the Control Yuan be without members after the terms of its original members expired at the end of January.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES' PSYCHOLOGICAL WARFARE WEEK TO KICK OFF MONDAY

TEXT.P: An armed forces' psychological warfare drill week is scheduled to kick off Monday to help the military better understand the threats from enemies and allow the armed forces to know more about modern warfare and strengthen their ability to discern China's non-military warfare.

The psychological warfare week, primarily to be conducted via television, will feature the following themes: Identifying the threats from enemies; knowing the various types of warfare; upgrading military intelligence security; boosting patriotic morale; and streamlining military discipline, said Hu Chen-pu, director of the General Political Warfare Bureau (GPWB) under the Ministry of National Defense.

The psychological warfare week, the first of its kind in Taiwan in seven years, will also for the first time introduce China's armed conflict law to allowed Republic of China military personnel to gain a better understanding of the war strategies and combat methods of the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA), Hu noted.

During the week, attention will be paid in particular to China's "double-handed" strategy and its three-pronged non-military warfare toward Taiwan, said Wang Ming-wuo, chief of the GPWB Department of Publicity and Political Education.
The PLA's three-pronged non-military warfare refers to psychological warfare, media warfare and legal warfare, Wang added.
Minister of National Defense Lee Jye will address the opening of the activities, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYED TEACHERS DEMAND MOE RESPONSE IN THREE DAYS

TEXT.P: About 1,800 unemployed teachers turned out in a march Sunday to vent their frustrations caused by their long-term unemployment, according to Ministry of Education (MOE) officials.

The teachers, who hold official teaching licenses but most of whom have never had the opportunity to teach since graduating, walked the streets of Taipei to demand that the Ministry of Education face squarely the issue of licensed teachers' right to teach.

They made a six-point appeal and demanded that the Education Ministry deliver on them, including that the MOE should consider increasing the number of teachers in elementary and junior high schools; that the MOE should implement small-class programs to create more openings for qualified teachers; that the number of professional teachers trained should be cut at least by 50 percent on a yearly basis; that elementary school and junior high school teachers should be taxed; that the MOE should promulgate pedagogical standards for teachers and ethical principles to regulate bad teachers; and that the number of openings for elementary school and junior high school teachers should be published in each year's general regulations bulletin for the teacher's examinations.

Responding to the teachers' requests, Chen Yi-hsing, director of the MOE Department of Secondary Education, said the ministry will see to it that the number of professional teachers trained each year will be reduced by 51.2 percent in three years.
Chen, however, stressed that the ministry's determination to maintain a diverse source of teacher cultivation will not change.

Dissatisfied with Chen's response, the marchers gave the MOE three days to provide a response they like better. Otherwise, they said, more unemployed teachers will be mobilized to launch a sit-in in front of the MOE.

According to Chen Chun-hao, convener of the private Saving Compulsory Education Alliance, colleges and universities around Taiwan are churning out qualified teachers, but with 180 graduates this year for each opening, the number of unemployed teachers is growing.

There are currently about 60,000 college graduates and masters degree holders who have a teaching license, but fewer than 100 openings nationwide for teachers in elementary and junior high schools this year.

Since many colleges and universities in Taiwan have education and teaching courses in their curriculums, about 18,000 individuals qualified teach elementary or junior high matriculate each year, said Chen, adding that the number has been snowballing for several years, posing an increasingly serious problem in the education sector.
Taking Taipei City as an example, he said, more than 1,000 licensed teachers are vying for only 30-odd openings this year.

In response to the teachers' rally, William Lai, a convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan, said that the teachers' appeal is "constructive" and he called for the MOE to respond favorably.

Lai said taxing elementary school and junior high school teachers would enlarge the base on which the government can impose more taxes and it is also a policy for which the Executive Yuan is planning.

The demonstrators' demand that the MOE should promulgate standards for teachers so that bad teachers or those who have constantly exhibited "uncalled for behavior or remarks" during their careers can be replaced is also commendable, Lai said, adding that by doing so, the standards of the country's teachers can be raised.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT CALLS FOR LAW ON SENSITIVE TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: An expert called on the government Sunday to work out a law to protect sensitive technology.

Tai Chao-yang, a researcher at the Taiwan Research Institute, said the Executive Yuan should take the initiative in enacting this law to prevent the country's high technology, which is the lifeline of the country's economy, from being exported.
Protecting the country's edge in technology is vital to its ability to hold its own against competition from overseas, Tai said.
This risk is all the more real when it comes to China and other countries that are eager to outpace Taiwan in the information industry, Tai added.
He urged the Executive Yuan to follow the examples of advanced countries in crafting laws to control the exports of high technology.

Tai's recommendation came days after Robert Tsao, founder of the semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , was questioned by prosecutors over allegations that he invested illegally in Hejian Technologies, a Chinese semiconductor manufacturer, and provided it with his company's technology to the detriment of UMC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS ALLIANCE FORUM TO BE HELD IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan Business Alliance Forum will be held Sept. 22 in Taipei to introduce Taiwan's nanotechnology development to the international business sector and to solicit foreign investors, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Sunday.

More than 400 representatives from domestic and foreign industrial and academic sectors are expected to attend the discussions, which will cover four main topics on the application of nanotechnology in traditional industry, energy, opto-electronics and biomedicine, the officials said.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh will explain Taiwan's nanotechnology development and business opportunities to the participants of the forum, which will form part of a government-organized "International Nanotechnology Week" to be held in Taipei Sept. 21-25.

Meanwhile, they added, Matthew Nordan, vice president of Lux Research, a leading research and advisory firm focusing on the business and economic impact of nanotechnology, will give a keynote speech on capital venture strategies for nanotechnology development.

In addition to the forum, they went on, the International Nanotechnology Week activities will include an exhibition on achievements made during the first phase of Taiwan's nanotechnology development program, an international seminar on nanotechnology and a panel discussion on the exploration of nanotechnology business opportunities.
The officials estimated that the output of Taiwan's nanotechnology industry will top US$13 billion by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO SHOW SELF-DEFENSE RESOLVE IN ARMS DEALS WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: U. S. experts have shown grave concern over Taiwan's procrastination in a major arms deal with the United States and have urged the Taiwan government to display self-defense resolve in the face of China's increased military buildup by quickly deciding on the procurement plan.

The U. S. experts voiced their worry recently to a visiting journalist group from Taiwan led by Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, saying that Taiwan's national security will be put at great risk if Taiwan fails to purchase the necessary weapons in time.

Donald S. Zagoria, director of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy's Project on U. S.- China- Taiwan Relations, said that Taiwan has to display its own determination before moving to seek U. S. protection, underlining the U. S. notion of "residual security value."

Gary Schmitt, executive director of the Project for a New American Century, pointed out that they have found the procrastination over the procurement bill in Taiwan's parliament is a result of domestic political wrangling.

For instance, Schmitt said, the opposition People First Party (PFP) has vowed to block the bill at the legislature unless President Chen Shui-bian apologizes for an allegation against PFP Chairman James Soong

Soong sued Chen June 4 for defamation after Chen alleged that the PFP chairman had met Chen Yunlin -- director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council -- in the U. S. to seek permission for a visit to China in early May.
Adequate screening by the parliament is necessary, but such a boycott is rather a product of political strife, Schmitt said.

Dan Blumenthal, a researcher at the American Enterprise Institute, described the Kuomintang's (KMT's) opposition to the arms purchase bill as "absurd, " pointing out that the party was very supportive of such bills when it was Taiwan's ruling party.

The KMT's turnaround in attitude toward the issue is very cynical, Blumenthal said, noting that such a change only represents the KMT's hostility toward Chen and that it is something in which a responsible opposition party would not engage.

Richard D'amato, chairman of the U. S.- China Economic and Security Review Commission, and John J. Tkacik, Jr., a senior researcher at the Heritage Foundation, contended that the U. S. is not expected to take countermeasures against Taiwan, despite the bill's failure to clear the legislature.
But they expressed the view that Taiwan must stage a firm determination to safeguard itself before turning to the U. S. for help.

Some U. S. government officials have warned that Taiwan might lose the opportunity to purchase the weapons if it continues to remain indecisive, now that some other countries have emerged as potential buyers for the equipment in question.

If the issue remains unresolved in the coming months, it might upset support for Taiwan within the U. S. Congress, the officials said, arguing that Taiwan's decreased military spending -- only about 2.5 percent of its GDP (gross domestic product) -- is extremely low compared to China's continued military expansion.

Randall G. Schriver, a former U. S. deputy assistant secretary of state, said that the U. S. is not very likely to rescind its approval for selling the weapons to Taiwan, but he urged the Taiwan authorities to view the matter more practically, such as the possibility that production lines might close.

In view of the grave concern from the U. S., the Executive Yuan has called on the Legislative Yuan to open an extraordinary session in July to exclusively screen the major military procurement bill, stalled during the last two legislative sessions and now valued at NT$480 billion (US$15.4 billion) after being cut by the opposition camp from its original estimate of NT$610.8 billion.
