DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 13, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1994: The Foreign Ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit U.N. nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
2000: The United States Senate passes a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, for his distinguished service.
2000: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates praises Taiwan's companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES PSYCHOLOGICAL WARFARE DRILL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: An armed forces' psychological warfare drill week kicked off Monday to help the military better understand the threats from enemies, allow the armed forces to know more about modern warfare and strengthen their ability to discern China's non-military warfare.

The psychological warfare week, primarily to be conducted via television, is featuring the following themes: Identifying the threats from enemies; knowing the various types of warfare; upgrading military intelligence security; boosting patriotic morale; and streamlining military discipline, said Wang Ming-wuo, a section chief with the General Political Warfare Bureau (GPWB) under the Ministry of National Defense.

The psychological warfare week, the first in Taiwan in seven years, will also for the first time introduce China's "armed conflict law" to allowed Republic of China military personnel to gain a better understanding of the war strategies and combat methods of the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA), according to Wang, who is the chief of the GPWB Department of Publicity and Political Education.

During the week, Wang said, attention will be paid in particular to China's "double-handed" strategy and its three-pronged non-military warfare -- psychological warfare, media warfare and legal warfare -- against Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINES HEAD TO JAPAN FOR PROTEST

TEXT.P: Some 60 indigenous people from Taiwan, led by aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei, departed Monday for Japan to demand the removal of tablets for a group of Taiwan aboriginal soldiers forced to fight for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II from a controversial shrine for war dead in Tokyo.
Kao Chin's group is made up of 60 Taiwan indigenous residents who are offspring or family members of the deceased aboriginal soldiers, known as the Taiwanese Kaosha Warriors Group.

Kao Chin, who is from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, said that while in Japan, her group will also demand an apology and compensation from the Japanese government for the persecution of indigenous residents during its colonial rule in Taiwan.
The legislator said it is absurd that the aboriginal soldiers, whom she calls victims of Japanese persecution, are honored together with their persecutors at the Yasukuni Shrine.

Although the protesters will not be allowed to enter the shrine, they will perform rites of their respective tribes outside the shrine and sing aboriginal songs to comfort the spirits of their ancestors, she said.
The Yasukuni Shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan and 1,068 convicted war criminals.

Kao Chin sued Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi two years ago for violating Japan's constitution by paying a visit to the shrine, but the suit was rejected by an Osaka district court. Kao Chin later appealed, and the high court of Osaka is expected to announce its ruling on the appeal June 17. The ruling will be final as no further appeals are allowed according to Japanese law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA FORECASTS TAIWAN'S 2005 GDP GROWTH AT 3.74%

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica researchers forecast Monday that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow by 3.74 percent for 2005, lower than the 4.05 percent figure that was previously predicted for the year.

Researchers from Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics said that Taiwan's economic performance for the first half of this year will not be as brilliant as previously predicted mainly as a result of high crude oil prices and the rapid appreciation of Taiwan's currency against the U.S. dollar.

Wu Chung-shu, one of the institute's researchers, said that the global economy has turned sluggish since the last quarter of 2004 mainly as a result of rising bank interest rates. At the same time, he said, crude oil prices have not declined to reflect the slowing economy, creating a further drag on economic growth.

Taiwan's exports of goods and services rose by only 1.23 percent in the first quarter due to the double pressures of a stagnant world economy and an appreciating New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, Wu said, adding that GDP growth for Q1 was consequently only 2.54 percent.

Wu forecast that this flagging trend will continue into the third quarter before things start to turn around. GDP growth is expected to hit 4.83 percent for Q3 and 5.05 percent for Q4, for a growth of 3.74 percent for the whole of 2005, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PINEAPPLES HIT MACAU MARKET IN RECORD TIME

TEXT.P: A shipment of fresh, mature Taiwan pineapples was delivered to Macau Monday in a record-breaking 13 hours, trade sources reported.

It took only 13 hours to allow fresh and tasty pineapples to be put on a Taiwan Agricultural Products Exposition table in Macau around 9 a.m. Monday after farmers in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan began to pick and pack the fruit around 8 p.m. Sunday upon receiving a telephone order from the Macau expo authorities, said Wu Wen-hsiung, vice president of the Taipei-based China Times Evening News, one of the private organizations co-sponsoring the expo.

According to the Taiwan Agricultural Products Expo authorities in Macau, the Taiwan pineapples on display were all sold out on the first day of the expo Sunday. They placed another order with the Chiayi pineapple farmers around 4 p.m. the same day in the hope that a new shipment could make it when the expo reopened the next day at 9 a.m.

The Chiayi farmers did not fail them -- they began to pick and pack the pineapples around 8 p.m. Sunday and delivered the cartons at 4 a.m. Sunday, enabling the shipment to reach the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 7 a.m. the same morning.

The transportation companies as well as the Macau customs authorities have also been cooperative -- the pineapples were flown over the Taiwan Strait and passed Macau's customs and quarantine checks to hit the expo table in two hours, Wu said.

Normal transportation of agricultural products from Taiwan to Macau takes at least 20 hours if the products are transported by air. It usually takes three to seven days if the shipments are delivered by sea, Wu added.
(By C.H. Jen and Deborah Kuo)/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULATION WHITE PAPER HAS YET TO BE FLESHED OUT: MOI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has yet to flesh out a white paper on the government's future population policy, a ministry official said Monday.

Su Ching-chao, deputy director of the MOI's Population Administration Department, was responding to a newspaper report that the government will offer tax incentives to encourage childbirth, including offering tax deductions for children born out of wedlock.
According to the media report, the decision was made during an interministerial meeting called by the MOI last week.

Su said the MOI indeed invited officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) and other relevant government agencies as well as representatives of private associations to discuss the contents of a proposed white paper on population policy last Thursday.
"The meeting focused discussions on general policy directions regarding population quality, number and distribution and has yet to touch on specific measures for encouraging childbirth," Su said.
He acknowledged that the meeting was held with a view to addressing worsening population trends, including declining birth rates and a greying population.
Nevertheless, Su said, no consensus has yet been reached on any specific measures.
"The media report about an initial consensus on offering tax deductions for children born to unmarried women was not correct, " Su said.
He stressed that the MOI is still working on the contents of the population white paper and will do its utmost to finalize a package of population policy guidelines as soon as possible.

According to the media report, some government officials voiced support at the June 9 meeting for the proposed tax deductions for children born out of wedlock. They said the measure probably could encourage women unwilling to marry but willing to have children to go ahead and do so, thereby helping increase Taiwan's birth rate.
Statistics compiled by the MOI show that the number of Taiwan adults who have never been married is approaching 25 percent of the total population.

A study released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) also showed that more than 50 percent of local women aged between 25 and 29 remained unmarried last year and that the ratio of local women responding to a DGBAS survey who said they would not have children has increased to 2.45 percent from 1.2 percent recorded in a previous survey.

Meanwhile, officials from the Department of Health said the number of fetuses aborted annually in Taiwan has been estimated at 280,000 to 300,000, with more than half of these belonging to unmarried women.

Some MOI officials said the proposed tax deductions for children born to unmarried women are not aimed at encouraging childbirth out of wedlock. The proposed measure could only serve as part of the efforts to raise the birth rate, the officials said, adding that many other measures are needed to realize that goal.

According to the media report, other measures to be adopted to encourage local married couples to have children will include improving in vitro reproductive technology to help infertile married couples have children and offering tax exemptions for underage children and providing better day care and welfare services for working mothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY DOWNPOURS CAUSE HEAVY AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Torrential rains in Taiwan's southern areas over the past few days have caused heavy agricultural damage, with the latest official tallies showing that as of 11: 00 a.m. Monday, a total of NT$26.38 million (US$840,500) in agricultural losses has been reported.

Kaohsiung County has suffered the most, with NT$17.2 million worth of agricultural losses, according to the Council of Agriculture (COA) tallies. The council also reported that leafy vegetables and melons have born the brunt of the devastation.
An estimated 493 hectares of crop fields have been flooded as a result of the torrential rains, with 38 percent of these fields having there crops completely destroyed, according to the COA.

After Kaohsiung County, Pingtung County has suffered the most in terms of agricultural losses, at NT$3.97 million, followed by Tainan City, at NT$2.77 million, and Tainan County, at NT$2.44 million, the COA tallies showed.

However, despite the heavy agricultural losses, the supply of fruits and vegetables to wholesale markets in Taipei has not been significantly affected as these markets are mainly supplied by producers in Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi.
These counties have not been seriously affected by the recent torrential rains, the officials noted, adding however that prices in the markets could move up in the near future.

Meanwhile, in anticipation of continuing torrential rains, the COA Soil and Water Conservation Bureau on Monday issued a red alert against possible landslides and mudflows for 40 creeks in Pingtung, Tainan and Kaohsiung counties that are vulnerable to flooding.

Thirty-six of the creeks are located in 24 villages in eight townships in Pingtung. Under the red alert, local authorities have the power to forcibly evacuate residents living near the creeks in certain situations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG BAKERS THANK MAYOR FOR PROMOTING SUNCAKES IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu got a tip of the hat from the chairman of the Taichung Pastry Industry Association Monday for his excellent job as a pitchman for suncakes in Beijing last week.

Yiu Yiu-yi, chairman of the Taichung Pastry Industry Association, said that Taichung City's pastry business could grow five times over if Hu continued being a spokesman for the Taichung-originating dessert.

Yiu thanked Hu for his presenting suncakes, a popular Taiwanese cake made of flaky pastry with sweet fillings, in Beijing while attending the United Cities and Local Governments World Council meeting, which was held June 8-10.
At present, the annual turnover of the pastry business in the central Taiwan city reaches about NT$1 billion (US$31.87 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, GUATEMALA FTA TALKS GOING SMOOTHLY

TEXT.P: The third round of negotiations concerning the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and Guatemala has concluded smoothly, and it is expected that both countries could sign the FTA in mid-August, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

The officials said that both sides made progress in tariff concessions for agricultural and industrial products and regulations concerning the role of the origin of certain products in the just-concluded negotiations in Los Angeles.
The officials said that both countries are scheduled to hold the fourth round of negotiations in Taipei July 11, and Guatemala will organize a high-level delegation to come to Taiwan.
If everything goes well, Taiwan and Guatemala will sign the FTA as scheduled in mid-August.
Taiwan's first FTA was with Panama, and came into effect in January 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE CONSUMPTION, INVESTMENT TO CONTINUE TO EXPAND: RESEARCHER

TEXT.P: Consumption and investment in Taiwan's private sector are both expected to expand throughout this year despite a slowing in the overall economic growth in Taiwan, an Academia Sinica researcher forecast Monday.

Private consumption and investments are expected to expand by 3.26 percent and 17.47 percent, respectively, in 2005 over the 2004 levels, thanks to the brisk domestic real estate market, which has gained momentum since late last year, and the improved unemployment situation, said Wu Chung-shu, a researcher with Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics.

Noting that Taiwan's economic performance for the first half of this year will not be as brilliant as previously predicted mainly as a result of high crude oil prices and the rapid appreciation of Taiwan's currency against the U.S. dollar, Wu said that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow by 3.74 percent for 2005, lower than the 4.05 percent figure that was previously predicted for the year.

Government investment, one of the factors making up the GDP figure, totaled NT$372 billion (US$12 billion) in 2005, marking a paltry annual growth of 0.69 percent over the year-earlier level because many of the major development projects that the government had announced would be carried out islandwide have not begun yet, Wu said.
However, Wu noted, the booming real estate market and lower unemployment rate should jump-start consumption growth in the private sector.

Private investment, meanwhile, should also pick up steam this year, hopefully up by 17.47 percent, to continue the dynamic rise from last year, when private investment posted a whopping annual growth of 28.2 percent, Wu added.

Meanwhile, Wu forecast, Taiwan's exports of goods and services will grow about 5.04 percent this year, down noticeably from last year's 15.27 percent as a result of the double pressures of a flagging world economy and an appreciating New Taiwan dollar against the greenback.
The annual growth of Taiwan's imports of goods and services are also seen to slow down this year, down from last year's 18.56 percent to 6.71 percent, Wu forecast.

The global economy has turned sluggish since the last quarter of 2004 mainly as a result of rising bank interest rates. At the same time, he said, crude oil prices have not declined to reflect the slowing economy, creating a further drag on economic growth.

Wu forecast that this flagging trend will continue into the third quarter before things start to turn around. GDP growth is expected to hit 4.83 percent for Q3 and 5.05 percent for Q4, for a growth of 3.74 percent for the whole of 2005, he said.

How Taiwan's economy will fare in the following months will be directly impacted by several factors, including crude oil and raw materials' prices on the international markets; exchange rates among the greenback, the NT dollar and the Chinese renminbi; the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the fluctuation of bank interests rates at home and abroad, Wu concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DELEGATION HEADED TO EASTERN EUROPE

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade delegation will go to Eastern Europe in September.

The government-funded Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will organize a delegation to go from Sept. 24 to Oct. 9 which will stop in Sofia, Bulgaria; Bucharest, Romania; Budapest, Hungary; as well as Bratislava, in the Slovak Republic.
TAITRA officials said Monday that these are markets with strong consuming power in the region.

The Slovak Republic, with a stable economy, joined the European Union last May, while Bulgaria is scheduled to join the economic bloc in 2007 and enjoys good foreign investment, according to the TAITRA Kaohsiung branch.

At every destination during the planned trip the delegation will hold a meeting with local businesses to seek trade opportunities, while it will also visit local shopping malls and wholesale stores to study their marketing, TAITRA officials said.

Businesses in the fields of information and communications, electronics parts and components, household electronics equipment, auto parts and components, textiles, sports gear, stationary and machinery are all welcome to contribute representatives to the delegation, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISSUE OF JOBLESS TEACHERS TO BE SORTED OUT IN ECONOMICAL WAY

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said Monday that the issue of jobless teachers will be sorted out taking economics into account.

Tu made the remarks while inspecting dilapidated school buildings at a Kaohsiung elementary school in southern Taiwan, one day after more than 2,000 jobless teachers assembled in a street protest to ask that the Ministry of Education raise the ratio of teachers to students, and cut the number of students in a class to allow more employment opportunities for them.
Tu said that those who protested were intern teachers, and that their unemployment has structural problems.

He noted that currently, the number of students in elementary and junior high schools is decreasing, and that the supply and demand question needs an overall review before creating more job opportunities.
Tu noted that the number of students has been cut to 38 in a junior high school class and 35 in an elementary school class, which has created more than 10,000 jobs.

He stressed that the supply and demand in schools should be handled as an economic problem, and that the ministry will work out its strategy and ratio of teachers to students based on the possible population changes over the next decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES LAWMAKERS PASS 8-YEAR, NT$80 B. FLOOD-CONTROL PROJECT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday he hopes that the Legislative Yuan will prioritize the bill for an eight-year, NT$80 billion ( US$2.539 billion) flood-control project if it convenes an extra session next month.

Hsieh made the remarks while attending the annual conference of the Chinese Institute of Engineers. He was referring specifically to his just-concluded tour of southern Taiwan a day earlier to see first hand the damage brought about in recent days by flash flooding.

Hsieh, who was Kaohsiung mayor before assuming the post of premier this February, said that southern Taiwan has been plagued by flooding for more than 10 years and the government is sympathetic to the plight of the people.

The problem can be solved, the premier said, noting that some parts of Kaohsiung used to be inundated three or four times a year, but after the installment of flood-control ponds, no more flooding was reported.

Currently, a lot of areas in Taiwan still are inundated whenever there are downpours, Hsieh said, adding that under the proposed NT$80 billion flood-control project, flooding problems in population-dense areas could be resolved in the first two years.

The premier also mapped out the policy of his government based on an "equilateral triangle" theory, with the top angle being economic development, and social justice and ecological sustainability occupying the other two sides, saying that the government's budget will take into consideration economic development and upgrading the quality of life.
He said that the government will step up advocacy of build-operate- transfer models, promote new communities and rebuild dilapidated classrooms in rural areas within four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUILD THE NATION WITH THE ENVIRONMENT IN MIND: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan must be built with ecological conservation in mind, President Chen Shui-bian told a group of engineers Monday.

In a written statement read at the annual conference of the Taipei-based Chinese Institute of Engineers, the president urged members of the institute to develop engineering technologies that are environmentally friendly and which can sustain development.
The institute's annual conference coincided with a forum on engineering technology between Taiwan and Japan.
Founded in 1912, the Chinese Institute of Engineers has 6,151 individual members and 79 institute members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN FISHERY TALKS DUE IN LATE JUNE, EARLY JULY: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan are expected to hold talks in about half a month to address their recent fishery disputes in the overlapping water of the two countries' exclusive economic zones, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

Gary Lin Sung-huann, director-general of MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said that Japan has responded to the ministry's request to conduct bilateral negotiations to settle the dispute as soon as possible by agreeing to hold the talks in late June or early July.

According to Lin, MOFA has set the fishery negotiations as the top issue in its dealings with Japan, and the Executive Yuan will call an inter-ministerial meeting later the same day to discuss the issue.
The opposition People First Party (PFP) held a seminar in the morning at the Legislative Yuan, with fishermen and officials from MOFA and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) taking part.

Sha Chih-i, deputy director of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that Taiwan will emulate the China-Japan and Japan-South Korea models to conduct the negotiations with Japan.

To meet the precondition not to affect future demarcation of each other's economic zones, Taiwan will discuss with Japan on first drawing up a joint operations area in the disputed water where fishing boats from the two countries are allowed to catch fish under adequate management.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao, in the eastern Taiwan county of Ilan, staged a protest last Friday in water 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships out of an area in which the 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Chen Chih-pin, a PFP caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan, accused the MND of negligence for having not dispatched vessels to protect the Taiwan fishermen and for trying to pass the buck to the Coast Guard Administration (CGA).

Chen opined that the Ministry of the Interior and the Fisheries Administration should allocate funds in national compensation to those Taiwan fishing boats that were dispersed or detained by Japan due to the government's inability to protect its nationals.

An MND official defended the ministry's stance by clarifying that the CGA is the government agency that is designated to deal with such incidents and that the MND will offer assistance when the CGA needs help.

Fishermen attending the seminar were angry with the government's poor handling of the issue, claiming that if the government fails to do them justice within 15 days, they will converge fishing boats from across Taiwan to encircle Japanese patrol vessels and stage a protest before the Interchange Association in Taipei -- Japan's representative office in Taiwan.

Taiwan fishing ships have been repeatedly expelled or arrested by Japanese patrol vessels over the past two years after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and neighboring Hualien counties.

According to a Fisheries Administration official who commented over the weekend, Taiwan and Japan will seek to resolve their fishing disputes through dialogue in line with international law after the government filed a strong protest to Japan.

Before the talks start and during the negotiation process, Taiwan fishermen will be asked to operate within an area temporarily demarcated by the government and the CGA will send patrol ships to fully protect them, the official said.

For the time being, Taiwan and Japan have reached consensus in designating a joint operations and conservation area in the disputed waters for fishing boats of both sides, but the two countries remain divided on the issue regarding joint management, he noted.
Taiwan and Japan have unsuccessfully had 14 rounds of talks in the hope of settling the dispute since 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOVE THE EARTH FOR TAIWAN'S SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday one must learn to "respect the heaven and the earth and love one another" for the sustainable development of Taiwan.
Lu was addressing the annual conference of the Chinese Institute of Engineers.

The vice president noted that it is a given that the world will face a number of problems in the 21st century, such as the growing world population, the climate changes, the increase of waste and the depletion of energy resources.
She said that in the past decade, the average temperature of Taiwan has risen, rainfall has dropped by 20 percent over the past century and mudslides have become more frequent.
Water consumption per person in Taiwan is 350 liters, which is higher than the world average of 250 liters, she continued.
People must respect nature she said so that "life, ecology and production" will continue to develop on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE YAKUZA RINGLEADERS DECLARED PERSONA NON GRATA

TEXT.P: Five Japanese yakuza criminal ringleaders have been declared persona non grata and banned from entering Taiwan, police said Monday.
The announcement is part of a new crackdown on domestic organized crime launched by the National Police Administration (NPA) late last month, police said.

The five yakuza figures, including Matsuo Maki, deputy head of the Tokyo-based underworld ring known as Sumiyoshikai, traveled to Taiwan in late May to attend the funeral of Hsu Hai-ching, a local mob godfather nicknamed "Mosquito."

With the assistance of the immigration authorities and Taiwan's representative office in Japan, the NPA's Criminal Investigation Bureau discovered that the five yakuza figures used pseudonyms to visit Taiwan in May to attend the funeral.
NPA officials said they decided to ban the yakuza members from visiting Taiwan in the future in an attempt to prevent them from colluding with local criminal rings in committing cross-border crimes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES ENGINEERING AWARD WINNERS, JAPANESE DELEGATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received award winners of the Chinese Institute of Engineers (CIE) and Japanese delegates to the 25th Sino-Japanese Modern Engineering Technology Seminar at the Presidential Office Monday.
Chen congratulated the winners in the 26 categories of awards bestowed by the CIE, saying they have each played a role in the development of the nation.

He also welcomed the Japanese scholars and experts from the engineering sector, noting that they have come to Taiwan to share the latest high-tech information and engineering technology, which will be a valuable exchange opportunity for both sides.
The award winners and Japanese delegates were accompanied by CIE President Yu Chun-yen. Also on hand was James Huang, vice secretary-general to the Presidential Office.
A joint conference of the CIE and the 25th Sino-Japanese Modern Engineering Technology Seminar was held that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: A Report by U.S., Criticizing U.N., Urges Reform.
A U.S. Congressionally mandated panel will report this week that the United Nations suffers from poor management, " dismal" staff morale and lack of accountability and professional ethics but will acknowledge the broad changes proposed for the organization by Secretary General Kofi Annan and urge the United States to support them. Newt Gingrich, a Republican former speaker of the House of Representatives, and George J. Mitchell, a Democratic former majority Senate leader, are co-chairmen of the bipartisan task force created last December. It includes former diplomats, military and intelligence officials and leaders of conservative and liberal political institutes. The United States is the biggest donor to the United Nations, contributing 22 percent of the regular operating budget and nearly 27 percent of the peacekeeping budget.
Wall Street Journal: With Italy in the Doldrums, Many Point Fingers at the Euro.
Many manufacturers across Italy say the Euro's sharp rise against the dollar inflated the price of their products and made them defenseless against Asian rivals. In the past, Italy would devalue its old currency, the lira, to help businesspeople claw back to competitiveness against other countries. But since Rome gave up control of currency policy to join the Euro in 1999, manufacturers have watched their fortunes slide. Having the Euro Six years ago, 11 European nations made a bold bet that a common currency would unify and fortify the continent from Sicily to Helsinki. Now, as many of the nations in what is known as the Euro zone slog through an economic funk, the experiment is helping to drive countries further apart -- and fueling a growing resentment of the wider European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: 78% OF HK CITIZENS FAVOR DONALD TSANG AS HONG KONG CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 13 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Among the three candidates for the leadership of the Hong Kong Special Administration Region of China, civil service veteran Donald Tsang has gained the support of 78 percent of polled citizens, leaving the other two far behind, according to the poll results released Monday by Hong Kong University.

In the survey, conducted last week among more than 1,000 citizens, only 3 percent gave their support to opposition Democratic Party leader Lee Wing-tat, while less than 1 percent tipped lawmaker Chim Pui-chung as their choice, according to the poll.

The survey also shows that 63 percent of the respondents said they do not want Chim elected as chief executive, while 51 percent voted against Lee. Only 4 percent of the respondents did not favor Tsang, who is now the acting chief executive.

Among Tsang's supporters, however, only 9 percent said they know Tsang's campaign ideas well, while 34 percent said they have little knowledge of his political ideas and plans and other 29 percent said they only know a little about Tsang's ideas.
According to a survey researcher, the figures show that Tsang won the largest popularity for his administrative performance rather than by his campaign promises.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO REINSTATE BAN ON U.S. BEEF IF BSE CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will reinstate a ban on U.S. beef imports if the United States confirms it has found a new case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cow disease, a food sanitation official said Monday.
Chen Lu-hung, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the announcement while attending a news conference jointly organized by a group of lawmakers from across the political spectrum.
During the news conference, lawmakers from both ruling and opposition parties urged the DOH to immediately reinstate a ban on U.S. beef imports that was lifted barely two months ago.
When the DOH lifted the U.S. beef import ban April 16, Chen said, it set a condition that allows for an immediate halt of further imports if a new case of BSE is found.
"The United States has sent samples to Britain for further testing. If the results are positive, we will immediately suspend U.S. beef imports," Chen said.
Taiwan first banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case.
On April 16, Taiwan began to allow imports of U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age.

Quoting data provided by the World Health Organization (WHO) , Chen said boneless beef, particularly that from young cattle, is no longer capable of spreading BSE due to improvements in feed and slaughtering methods.

Chen said the World Organization for Animal Health has stipulated that "boneless beef with no other specific dangerous substances" from animals under 30 months of age can be exported even from BSE-infected areas.
Nevertheless, Chen said the DOH is determined to reinstate the U.S. beef import ban if the new case is confirmed as BSE.
Meanwhile, the Consumers' Foundation urged local people not to buy U.S. beef for the time being.

Jason Lee, chairman of the foundation, said he shares lawmakers' views that the DOH should immediately ban U.S. beef imports. He also advised local consumers to refrain from purchasing U.S. beef until after the British testing proves that the suspected case is not BSE.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES INSTRUCTED TO MAINTAIN GUARD

TEXT.P: National Defense Minister Lee Jye instruct the armed forces Monday to maintain their guard and strengthen their will to fight, saying that China now possesses a more resilient "two-pronged" strategy against Taiwan.
Lee gave the pep-talk in a written statement as an armed forces' psychological warfare drill week kicked off.

He noted that Beijing has heightened its military intimidation of Taiwan through the enactment of its Anti-secession Law March 14, which codifies the use of force should the island move toward formal independence.

But Beijing has also on other hand tried to create an ambience of peace through cross-Taiwan Strait private exchanges, showing that its "double-handed" strategy has become ever more resilient and flexible, Lee added.
He said that since Beijing has broached its warfare on Taiwan on three fronts -- legal, media and psychological -- more than one year ago, it has continued to use one or another approach.

Beijing has hoped that this "soft" offensive will undermine the morale of the Taiwan public and drive a wedge into a "unified" Taiwan, he said, pointing out that the armed forces and the public must remain vigilant against China's united front strategy and must realize the true colors behind what he described as a "charm offensive."

He pointed out that Beijing has been promoting military buildup in terms of quality, quantity and high-tech enhancement and that it has consistently strengthened its military deployment targeting Taiwan along its southeast coastal areas.

For this reason, the armed forces should not be fooled by the surface goodwill from the other side and relax its vigilance, as that would put a crack in national security and cause the government to lose its bargaining chips to counter or negotiate.

He also said that the Hankuang No. 21 drill recently completed its computer simulation exercise and reached several consensuses, including that the nucleus of defending Taiwan should be to upgrade its self-defense capability.
He said the ministry is planning to buy advanced weaponry and to step up its military buildup, because upgraded military personnel will need more advanced weaponry systems.

The psychological warfare week, the first in Taiwan in seven years, will also for the first time introduce China's "armed conflict law" to allow Republic of China military personnel to gain a better understanding of the war strategies and combat methods of the People's Liberation Army.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN TAIWAN RAVAGED BY TORRENTIAL RAIN

TEXT.P: Three days of torrential rain brought by a cold front have flooded low-lying areas in southern Taiwan, ravaging agriculture and bringing highway and rail traffic in some areas to a standstill.
In Machia rural township in the southernmost county of Pingtung, 818 mm of precipitation was recorded in the previous 24 hours, according to meteorologists Monday.
As a result, much of that county has been inundated and bridges on many rivers have been closed as water levels reached dangerous heights.
Agricultural authorities said the rain has caused damage worth about NT$171 million (US$5.46 million) to agriculture in southern Taiwan, especially in Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties.

The Council of Agriculture said the damage suffered by farmers growing sesame, watermelon and leafy vegetables in Tainan is so serious that some farmers there are eligible for government cash relief, while the other farmers in the three counties can apply for soft loans provided by the government.
The council is also asking farmer's associations to market stockpiled refrigerated vegetables to prevent shortages of vegetables on the market.
Many fish farms and livestock farms in the three counties have been completely washed away by the flooding.
The rain has caused landslides in mountainous areas, disrupting traffics on the southern cross-island highway.

Rail traffic between Taitung and Kaohsiung was disrupted briefly Monday morning after the water under the Linbian Bridge in Pingtung County surged beyond dangerous levels. The railway reopened that afternoon when the water in the river receded a little.

A total of 49 schools in the three counties have suffered damage in the flooding and four people have been reported killed in the flooding, including one washed away by water in Kaohsiung and three others killed in flood-related accidents -- two in Pingtung and one in Tainan.
In order to cope with the unexpected rain, the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center has been opened to coordinate relief operations.
Noting that the front is not expected to move out of Taiwan before June 18, weather forecasters warned the public to be on guard against the torrential rain until then.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MORE FLEXIBLE IN DEALINGS WITH TAIWAN, BUT HARDER ON STANCE

TEXT.P: Since the beginning of this year, observers said Monday, China seems to have adopted a softened approach toward Taiwan, although the Beijing leadership led by President Hu Jintao has shown little flexibility in its stance toward Taiwan.

Chang Wu-ueh, a professor at Tamkang University specializing in China affairs, said that the current Beijing leadership differs a lot from its predecessors in its decision-making and strategic deployment in its dealings with Taiwan.

According to Chang, Beijing is using a two-pronged strategy centered on its "one China" principle and the so-called "1992 consensus" to deal with Taiwan's ruling and opposition camps after last December's legislative elections.

The win by the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) over the pro-independence "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union by grabbing more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan led to the changes, Chang pointed out.

On one side, Beijing seeks to build a friendly atmosphere in its exchanges with Taiwan by inviting opposition leaders -- KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- to visit China in late April and early May and by holding bilateral talks on the special charter flights over the Chinese new year holiday for Taiwan businessmen working in China, he said.
On the other side, it came up with its Anti-Secession Law in March, threatening to use "non-peaceful means" to contain Taiwan, he noted.

At a time when Taiwan and the entire world was lashing out at Beijing for the Anti-Secession Law, Hu's meetings with Lien and Soong successfully shifted the global attention from Beijing's hegemonic attitude to wide speculation over a possible new breakthrough in Taiwan-China relations, leading the outside world to ponder on Hu's strategy toward Taiwan, according to analysts.

Although some people think it is Hu who took the initiative to improve China's relations with Taiwan -- daring to show greater flexibility following so many years of up-and-down in bilateral ties -- the analysts said that Hu stands by his principles.

Randall G. Schriver, a former U. S. deputy assistant secretary of state, recently told a visiting group of journalists from Taiwan that China has increasingly got to know of the aggressive competition among Taiwan's political parties and that Hu is also quite good at using the situation to set traps to gain advantages in political moves against Taiwan.
At the same time, many watchers are of the view that Beijing is also fully aware of the fact that its rival is the governing DPP and that it needs to deal with it.

But due to the political divergences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and a lack of mutual trust, Beijing has only been able to try to forge an atmosphere conducive to rekindling substantive talks with Taiwan for the time being, watchers said.
Hsu Chih-chia, a professor at Ming Chuang University, contended that a compromise by the two sides over "one China" and the "1992 consensus" disputes will be the key to reopening two-way talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EARNS US$2.26 BILLION FROM FOREIGN TRADE IN FIVE MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan earned US$2.26 billion from its foreign trade in the first five months of this year, according to statistics released Monday by the Central Bank of China.
During the January-May period, the tallies show, Taiwan earned US$87.41 billion from exports while spending US$85.143 billion on imports, up 10.1 percent and 19.1 percent year-on year, respectively.

In May alone, Taiwan earned US$17.88 billion in foreign exchange from exports, while spending US$17.6 billion on imports, up 11.4 percent and 20.1 percent from the figures recorded a year ago, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 14 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 14:
09:30, A seminar on the management of electronic archives will be held at the National Central Library.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a group of Latin American envoys to the Organization of American States and to the United States at the Presidential Office.
10:20, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will attend a meeting of Taiwan businessmen operating in China at the Howard Hotel in Taichung, central Taiwan.
10: 30, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao will attend the 2005 National Youth Conference at the Red Theater in Taipei.
11: 00, President Chen shui-bian will receive members of the Taiwan delegation to the WorldSkills Competition Helsinki 2005 at the Presidential Office.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
17: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES EARLY CONSULTATION ON TOURISTS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged China Monday to respond with goodwill and negotiate with Taiwan as soon as possible on matters concerning Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan.

The premier made the remarks while elaborating on the government's stance on opening the country to tourists from China to more than 100 Taiwan businessmen operating in China at a dinner party held in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Hsieh noted that the government announced a plan to allow Chinese people to visit Taiwan as tourists in November 2001, but as China has yet to list Taiwan as a destination for tourism, the number of such tourists coming to Taiwan amounted to only 44,500.
In the meantime, the arrival of Chinese tourists also highlighted problems such as groups of "tourists" disappearing en masse upon arriving in Taiwan in July and August last year, he added.

To allow more Chinese tourists to have high quality trips to Taiwan, the Executive Yuan has, under the premise of effective management, studied the establishment of a passenger personal guarantee system and renewed regulations for travel agents so as to upgrade management efficiency.

The premier said Taiwan hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can consult on such matters as identity verification, repatriation for overstayers, cooperation and regulations for cross-strait travel agents, and mediation of travel disputes.

He said the Executive Yuan has instructed the Mainland Affairs Council, as well as the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, to work out plans for consultation and to arrange for bilateral talks in the hope that China will respond favorably.
This will help tourists from China to have better travel quality, while Taiwan will have an effective management mechanism to cut the unease of local people and help boost local tourism, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES NEW STEPS TO BOOST CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced three key policy measures to promote civilian and commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait Monday, including authorizing the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) to negotiate with its Chinese counterpart on the opening of direct cross-strait charter cargo flights.

Hsieh made the announcement while attending a seminar with executives of major Taiwanese trade associations in China, who returned to Taiwan over the weekend for the Dragon Boat Festival celebrations.

The premier told the 100-plus executives that the government is determined to authorize private organizations to assist in fleshing out technical details for opening cross-strait charter cargo flights, exporting Taiwan agricultural products to China and allowing Chinese residents to sightsee in Taiwan.
"We are hopeful that the Chinese authorities will understand our goodwill and open substantive talks with Taiwan to resolve bilateral issues in a realistic manner," Hsieh claimed.

In addition to commissioning the TAA to negotiate the charter cargo flight issue, Hsieh said the government has decided to authorize the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to talk with relevant Chinese authorities on the shipment of Taiwanese agricultural products to China.
As to the opening of Taiwan's doors to Chinese tourists, Hsieh said the government will commission an "appropriate organization" to assist in setting the stage for bilateral talks on related issues.

Hsieh's announcement marked the first time the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has unveiled concrete steps to promote cross-strait exchanges since China enacted its anti-secession law in mid-March that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.

Despite the fact that the Chinese legislation marked a grave setback in the development of cross-strait relations, Hsieh said the government will continue to deal with cross-strait issues in line with the principle of "reconciliation without retreat and steadfastness without confrontation."

"Even though the cross-strait situation remains grim, the government will continue promoting cross-strait exchanges in consideration of people's well-being, including the interests of those with investments in China, " Hsieh said. To help Taiwanese businessmen cut transportation costs, Hsieh said the government is willing to open direct cross-strait charter cargo flights based on the formula set forth in the Lunar New Year charter passenger flight arrangements earlier this year.

Hsieh said he has directed the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to work with the TAA in preparation for negotiations with China on opening direct charter cargo flights. As for agricultural exports to China, Hsieh said that even though China recently announced preferential treatment for Taiwan-produced fresh fruit, Taiwan's agricultural shipments to China have been limited. In 2004, Taiwan exported only US$890,000-worth of farm produce to China, accounting for a marginal 1.06 percent of Taiwan's total agricultural exports, or 0.16 percent of its total agricultural production.

Over the years, Hsieh said, China has deliberately attracted Taiwan farmers and businesses to invest in agricultural production in China, leading to an exodus of Taiwan's farming experts, fine grain and fruit strains and core farming expertise.

In the future, he went on, the government will rein in cross-strait agricultural trade in accordance with the principles of "active opening, effective management" with a view to establishing an cross-strait agricultural market and guiding Taiwan's agriculture to develop in a healthier direction.

Hsieh said the Cabinet has instructed the Council of Agriculture to coordinate with the MAC and local farmer's associations in organizing a professional negotiating team. In addition, he said, the government has commissioned TAITRA to assist in arranging for talks with its Chinese counterparts regarding customs clearance, quarantine and inspection and other technical issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULATION TO REGISTER NEGATIVE GROWTH FROM 2117: MOI

TEXT.P: Taiwan faces an urgent need to enhance its birth rate because the total population might begin to register negative growth from 2117, Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang said Monday.

Taiwan's birth rate was 1.18 per woman of childbearing age in 2004, far lower than the average of 1.6 registered in member states of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) , Chien said.
To address the declining birth rate issue, Chien said, former Premier Yu Shyi-kun directed the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to draft a white paper on population policy.
"In line with Yu's directive, the MOI has drafted a white paper which outlines suggestions for encouraging childbirth from economic and non-economic perspectives," Chien said.

As population policy involves a broad range of issues, Chien said, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan directed at an inter-ministerial meeting last week that the white paper should not be presented to the Cabinet for discussion at present and should be subject to further debate by officials from different departments and experts from relevant social groups.

Instead, Chien went on, the MOI will present a package of policy guidelines to the Cabinet later this month for approval. The MOI will then further flesh out the population policy white paper based on the guidelines.

According to a study by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, 20 percent of local women of child-bearing age have never given birth. At present, about two breadwinners support one non-breadwinners (referring to those aged under 15 and older than 65) . If the current low birth rate trend continues, the ratio will become one to one in 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT OPPOSES TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng expressed his opposition to Taiwan independence Monday, claiming that he has long insisted that the official title of the Republic of China and of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) cannot be changed nor the ROC Constitution abolished.
Wang, who is a vice chairman of the KMT, made the remarks in a meeting with party members in Taichung, central Taiwan, to solicit support for his party chairmanship bid.

Taiwan's situation has been worsening since the political power transfer five years ago, Wang claimed, adding that the country is now facing four major crises -- a hollowing out of the national treasury, the marginalization of the economy, the sharpening of rivalry among ethnic groups and the heightening cross-strait crisis.
Taiwan can only get out of this plight when cross-strait relations are peaceful, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN CAUTIOUSLY WELCOME PREMIER'S REACH-OUT TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Leaders of Taiwan businessmen working on the mainland cautiously welcome Premier Frank Hsieh's announcement Monday to have private groups negotiate on behalf of government with China on three bilateral issues.
The three issues mentioned by Hsieh are the start of direct chartered cargo flight across the strait, the exports of Taiwan's fruit to China and allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.
Cheng Jung-wen, a Taiwan business leader in Shenzhen, Guangdong province said this is a step forward, and is better than paying lip service.

Yeh Hui-teh, a Taiwan business leader in Shanghai said this is the most concrete step the government has ever taken on the three issues, but he doubted these negotiations could be finished by private groups alone.
Kuomintang greeted the premier's assertion with suspect. Its lawmaker Yang Chiung-ying said she hoped the premier's response is not lip service.

People First Party official Chang Hsien-yao said the premier was making a virtue of necessity, adding that under the public pressure, the premier can't help but make the decision to meet people's desire.
Taiwan Solidarity Union whip at the Legislative Yuan Huang Shih-cho said his party worries about the premier's decision which he said bodes ill for the country's future.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's whip at the Legislative Yuan William Lai said the ball now is in the court of China, and people can see how Beijing will response to Taiwan's initiatives, especially its request for starting direct cargo flight across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM TOUTS POLICY TOWARD CHINA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen touted Taiwan's policy toward China while leading a group of foreign representatives to Taiwan on a tour of the outlying island county of Kinmen Monday.

Tan told them that the development of ties between Taiwan and China takes time and that the key to improving ties lies in a "live and let live" approach by both sides, with any bilateral negotiations conducted at government level.

Accompanied by Huang Wei-feng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, Tan took his guests to the Shuitou Wharf to see the ferry service between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's Fujian Province, which is the center piece of the so-called "mini-three-links."
Chen said the success of the mini-three-links vindicates the county's claims that its policy of improving ties with China in steps in a pragmatic way is correct.

Huang told the foreign representatives that the launch of the direct ferry services has demonstrated Taiwan's desire to end hostility across the Taiwan Strait and to bring in a new era of peace and stability with China.
Also, Huang said, the mini-three-links has given Kinmen and Matsu -- another outlying county with direct ferry services with China -- important roles as Taiwan gateways.
Besides the Shuitou Wharf, the group of 17 foreign envoys also visited other tourist sites around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 14, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1838: Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894: After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Colombian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900: The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920: In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936: Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940: German troops march into Paris, and the flag of Nazi Germany, bearing the swastika, is hoisted up the Eiffel Tower.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943: The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949: Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952: The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is put on public display in the United States.
1955: The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964: In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: A 10-member Chinese national judo team headed by Mao Ming-chu leaves for Lausanne to take part in the 8th world championships.
1974: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung and Deputy Premier Cuthbert Edwy Talma of the Barbados sign a joint communique in Taipei announcing the extension of the Sino-Barbados agricultural technical cooperation agreement.
1975: More than 500 Chinese poets and Dr. Jeno Platthy, chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Third World Congress of Poets, gathered in Taipei to celebrate Chinese Poets Day and pay homage to poet Chu Yuan of the period of Spring and Autumn Annals.
1978: A technical cooperation agreement between Saudi Arabia and the Republic of China is signed.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Huang Shao-ku and Hung Shou-nan as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, respectively, following unanimous approval by the Control Yuan.
1982: Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo visits the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Taipei to extend his condolences over the passing of King Khalid ibn abdul Aziz.
1989: Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
1992: Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton sends his greetings to the participants in the 24th annual Joint Business Conference of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-U.S.A. Business Councils, which kicks off in Taipei.
2001: A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrives in Taipei to take part in an unprecedented cross-Taiwan Strait long-distance race as part of a campaign for mainland China's bid to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TROOPS MOBILIZED TO HELP WITH POST-FLOODING RELIEF WORK

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) sent 300 military service members and seven armored personnel carriers to help with post-flooding relief work in the southernmost county of Pingtung Tuesday.
Some 200 officers and enlisted men assisted in cleaning up flooded streets in Hsinyuan village, one of the areas hit hardest by flash floods brought by heavy rains over the past few days.

The armored personnel carriers assisted in evacuating stranded residents to temporary shelters in addition to transporting relief goods, including bread, boxed lunches, mineral water and sleeping bags.
An additional 100 service members were mobilized to help in clearing away mud and rocks in the county's mountainous Machia village which was struck by heavy mudslides caused by torrential rains.
As intermittent rains continue to batter the county, water levels in the Kaoping River remain unstable. Weather forecasters have urged residents in low-lying areas to remain on alert.

OFFICIALS of San Carlos Seminary in Guadalupe, Makati City, evicted the whistleblower Samuel Ong Monday night for violating an agreement with his hosts that he would not grant media interviews.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIOTECH GROUP TO ATTEND CONVENTION IN PHILADELPHIA

TEXT.P: A group composed of government officials and executives of biotechnology businesses in Taiwan will attend the 2005 annual international convention of the Biotechnology Industry Organization (BIO) to be held at the Philadelphia Convention Center in Philadelphia June 19-22.

More than 18,000 biotech executives, investors, journalists, policy makers and scientists from more than 60 countries are expected to attend the convention which will feature exhibitions as well as academic sessions and workshops on topics ranging from nanotechnology applications, the mapping of the human genome, and personalized medicine, to pharmacogenomics and other cutting-edge technologies.

Members of the Taiwan delegation will include Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching; Vice Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang; Johnsee Lee, president of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) ; specialists from the Council of Agriculture, the Department of Health, and the National Science Council under the Cabinet; as well as executives of several pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.

Minister Lin, Vice Minister Shih and ITRI President Lee will give a report on Taiwan's biotechnology development at a briefing luncheon on June 21. Later in the afternoon, the Taiwan delegation will hold a wine and cheese party at the Taiwan pavilion.

Biotechnology has been a priority sector in Taiwan enjoying government incentives, with more than 1,000 companies engaging in biotechnology research and development, pharmaceutical production, and manufacturing of medical devices.

Government statistics indicate that in 2003, the Taiwan biotechnology sector's production totalled approximately NT$131.6 billion, with pharmaceutical production accounting for NT$61.4 billion of that total, or 0.4 percent of the global total, and medical device output hitting NT$40.6 billion, or 0.6 percent of the global total.
The Taiwan biotechnology sector's research and development spending totalled about NT$29.6 billion, or about 0.9 percent of the global total, for the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Jury Acquits Jackson on All Charges; Pop Singer's Molestation Trial Ends as Evidence Fails to 'Add Up,' Juror Says.
Michael Jackson left the courthouse here Monday just as he entered it, a free but somber man waving to fans and blowing a kiss, after a jury rejected charges that he repeatedly molested a 13-year-old boy, gave him alcohol and held him and his family captive at Neverland ranch, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR QUITS TO DEVOTE HIMSELF TO LOCAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislator Tsai Huang-liang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Tuesday he is quitting his at-large legislative seat in order to devote himself to the year-end Nantou county magistrate election.

Tsai, who is set to be approved by the DPP Central Executive Committee to be the party's candidate in the Nantou county election, said that he will step down and work as the service office chief for Hsu Jung-hsu, who will fill the vacancy left by his departure.
Before Tsai was elected a legislator, he worked as a volunteer in Hsu's service office when Hsu was a legislator.

Tsai said that he has learned a lot during his 10 years in the Legislative Yuan and that he feels sorry leaving. But he said he will now dedicate himself to meeting with grass-roots supporters, hoping to "shake hands with every resident in Nantou and touch their hearts."
He vowed that if elected, he will build Nantou into a tourism county.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS ASK FOR REINSTATEMENT OF U.S. BEEF IMPORT BAN

TEXT.P: Several legislators from across the political spectrum called Tuesday for Department of Health (DOH) Minister Ho Sheng-mao to remove U.S. beef products from store shelves and to reinstate the U.S. beef import ban that was lifted barely two months ago.
The legislators were Lai Shin-yuan and David Huang of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, Lai Shyh-bao of the Kuomintang, and Huang Wei-cher of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Lai Shin-yuan noted that although there are around 60 countries that currently import U.S. beef, quite a few of these countries are affected areas of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.
She noted that Taiwan is not one of the BSE-affected countries, but it rashly decided to lift the ban.

She pointed out that although a suspected BSE case was detected in the United States June 10, Chen Lu-hung, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said Monday that the DOH will only decide on the matter after a further test in Britain on the U.S. sample.

Lai Shyh-bao criticized the DOH for not adequately protecting public health and demanded that the department suspend U.S. beef imports, remove U.S. beef products from store shelves, discipline negligent officials, and convene a hearing to make transparent its decision-making process on allowing the U.S. beef imports.
Ho said that the matter will be handled strictly on considerations of professionalism.

He quoted World Organization for Animal Health guidelines as stating that boneless beef with no other specific dangerous substances from animals under 30 months of age can be exported even from BSE-infected areas.

He also said that DOH's decision to remove the U.S. beef import ban in April was arrived at after careful consideration and that the department invites BSE experts to review its decision-making process.
He stressed that the DOH's policy has nothing to do with instructions from the Presidential Office or the Executive Yuan.
Taiwan first banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case.
On April 16 this year, Taiwan began to allow imports of U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE GROUP TO VISIT EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: A legislative delegation composed of 12 lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties will leave Taipei this weekend for a visit to Europe to promote parliamentary exchanges, legislative sources said Tuesday.

Legislator You Ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who concurrently heads a legislative subgroup dedicated to promoting amity with European lawmakers, said the delegation will visit the European Parliament -- the legislative arm of the 25-member European Union -- and the French and German parliaments.
The delegation will also meet with French and German think tank scholars and researchers during the upcoming visit, You said.

According to You, the delegation will brief European lawmakers on the gist of Taiwan's newly passed constitutional amendments and the adverse impact of China's anti-secession law on Taiwan and security in the Asia-Pacific region.

"Europe has played an increasingly important role in the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait. We hope our visit can help European lawmakers and scholars better understand our basic stance on cross-strait relations. We want them to know that our constitutional amendments are not aimed at changing the present cross-strait status quo," You said.

"We'll also take the opportunity to express our gratitude for the European Union's support for our bid to join the World Health Organization, " You further said, adding that he is hopeful that the visit can help win more European support for Taiwan's cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH, TAIWAN RECORD BUSINESSES TO MEET FOR COOPERATION TALKS

TEXT.P: The French Institute, France's liaison office in Taiwan, is working with two French industry associations to hold a business meeting with Taiwanese record companies on June 20 in Taipei in an effort to arrange France-Taiwan cooperation in the music industry.

Ten French record companies, including Bleu Regard, Discograph, ELLA, EMD, Fair Play, Harmonia Mundi, Night & Day, Productions Speciales, Toujours Plus, and Vicious Circle, have been invited to attend the meeting, while on the Taiwan side, more than 20 businesses will attend, French Institute officials said Tuesday.

One of the meeting's goals is to forge cooperative ties between the French and Taiwanese record industries in the fields of music production, record publishing and concert arrangement, the officials said, adding that the French side also hopes to introduce its music performers to Taiwan.

The event is also a prelude to the grand international music fair in France called the MIDEM -- an annual international music marketing festival. This year's festival is slated to be held Jan. 20-26 in Cannes.

Each year, the MIDEM festival attracts independent and major record companies, music publishers, online and traditional distributors, festival programmers, import/exporters, manufacturers, service companies, retailers, attorneys, and rights organizations from every music genre around the world. This quality of participants makes it a magnet for music buyers from other fields and industries, including advertisers, video game companies, and film and TV producers.

Rubin Lee, secretary-general of the non-profit International Federation of Phonographic Industry in Taiwan, and Yu Kuang of the Yu Kuang Music Magazine will deliver key-note speeches at the upcoming record business meeting, according to the French Institute officials.
