The Moscow Times: Putin Backs Blair's Agenda for the G8.
British Prime Minister Tony Blair won President Vladimir Putin's support Monday at the start of a mission to pave the way for agreements on tackling African poverty and climate change at the Group of Eight summit. But Putin, who often miscues publicly by using exotic language, reacted sharply when a reporter linked human rights abuses and corruption in Africa with the situation in Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 25.29 points to close at 6,205.76.
The bourse opened at 6,244.56 and fluctuated between 6,266.25 and 6,205.76 during trading. A total of 3.76 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.03 billion (US$2.89 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up at 1.3 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks and construction issues both moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1 percent, foodstuff issues, machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares all at 0.8 percent and textile stocks at 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 595 to 261, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA READY TO TALK WITH CHINA ON AGRICULTURAL PRODUCT EXPORTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is ready to take on the task of paving the way for the direct export of fruits from Taiwan to China given the council's extensive experience over the past 34 years, the council's top official said Tuesday.

Chao Yung-chuan, TAITRA secretary-general, made the remarks one day after Premier Frank Hsieh said the government has decided to authorize TAITRA to talk with relevant Chinese authorities on exporting Taiwanese agricultural products to China.
"TAITRA will do all it can to be the best conduit," Chao said.

Chao said that TAITRA is only an intermediary agency and the Council of Agriculture and the Mainland Affairs Council have to do the main planning. Once they have completed this, the council will open discussions with the Chinese side, he added.
He noted that since 2002, the council has invited big Chinese buyers, such as large supermarkets and agricultural products companies, to take part in exhibitions and buy from Taiwan.
TAITRA has also sponsored Taiwan agricultural festivals in big cities and organized delegations to take part in agricultural exhibitions in China, Chao said.
The council plans to set up footholds in Beijing and Shanghai this year, he added.

He said that Taiwan exported US$3.4 billion of agricultural products last year, and fruits accounted for 2.5 percent (US$86 million) of these. Among them, fruit processed products, such as dehydrated products and fruit juices exports totaled US$53 million, while fresh fruits totaled US$33 million, or only 1 percent.

The main markets for Taiwan's fresh fruits are Japan (accounting for 50 percent), followed by the United States (25 percent) and Hong Kong (25 percent.) Direct exports to China only totaled US$340,000.

Chao noted that the biggest challenge for Taiwan fruits will be their high cost, saying that China has only given 18 Taiwan fruits tariff-free treatment. Fruits from Vietnam and Thailand also enjoy the same treatment, but they have far lower production costs.
In addition, the biggest worry is that Chinese consumers may only buy Taiwan fruits once out of curiosity and will not buy them again.
He said that Taiwan fruits should target high-end department stores in Shanghai, Beijing and Shenzhen.
Only when there is a bumper year for certain fruits, such as citrus, will the council promote them in wholesale shops.

Meanwhile, Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the policy committee of the opposition Kuomintang, wondered if the government had chosen TAITRA out of political considerations since it has close relations with the industrial and business sectors, instead of the provincial agricultural association, which is familiar with the marketing of agricultural products, in handling the exports.
Tseng said that the government should be responsible if the interests of the farmers are undermined.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN, UC BERKELEY SIGN MEMORANDUM ON INFORMATION SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 13 (CNA) (By C. Chiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching on Monday signed a memorandum of agreement with the Berkeley branch of the University of California to promote exchanges and cooperation in the field of information security.

Lin, who doubles as the deputy convener of the Executive Yuan's Science and Technology Advisory Group, is leading a four-member delegation on a visit to San Francisco, California. He signed the deal with Paul R. Gray, executive vice chancellor and provost of UC Berkeley, in an effort to enhance Taiwan's manpower and technological capability in the information security sector.
Lin explained that the memorandum covers three categories: technological research and transfer, personnel exchanges, and consultations. The exchanges will involve government and academia.

Besides the UC Berkeley links, the delegation, organized to seek cross-national information security technological cooperation, will also sign a cooperative memorandum with Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) during its U.S. visit.

The two universities enjoy great prestige in the fields of information technology and information communication security. UC Berkeley is a leading institute on the research of computer security in the United States, while CMU has been presiding over the U.S. government's information security projects for years. Taiwan can learn from their expertise and knowledge in dealing with information security incidents, a member of the delegation said.

Chen Ju-fen, the executive director of the Cabinet's technological consultant group, explained that information security is a big field, which covers governmental administration, corporate operations, and personal confidential information.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET URGES LEGISLATURE TO CONVENE EXTRA SESSION ON FLOOD CONTROL

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan Spokesman Cho Jung-tai on Tuesday urged the Legislative Yuan to convene an extra session late next month on urgent bills such as an eight-year NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project.
Cho made the appeal after heavy flooding that caused tremendous losses to people living in southern areas of Taiwan.
According to Cho, the central government and a dozen local governments, as well as the Ministry of National Defense have set up emergency centers for rescue and relief efforts.

Premier Frank Hsieh has ordered the Department of Health and the Environmental Protection Administration to watch closely the post-disaster situation in order to prevent contagious diseases from breaking out, Cho said. Hsieh also instructed Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Ching-lung to present an agricultural loss report to subsidize farmers suffering from the inundation, Cho added.

The Cabinet presented the flood-control budget bill to the legislature for approval on May 18; however, the bill has not been passed although it was put on the agenda on May 24. The Legislative Yuan has been in recess since late May.

Cho noted that many areas of Taiwan suffer from inundation due to lowered surface levels as a result of excessive use of groundwater from wells; therefore, the flood-control project requires huge efforts from both the government and the people, and the work is urgent.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said earlier in the day that the Cabinet can first use the reserves of its budget to deal with the flooding, while the NT$80 billion flood-control project needs to be discussed between the different political parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROTESTERS BARRED FROM CONTROVERSIAL JAPANESE SHRINE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 14 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan aboriginal protesters led by Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei were barred Tuesday from approaching a controversial shrine for war dead in Tokyo, where their ancestors who were forced to fight for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II are honored.

The protesters had originally planned to stage a demonstration outside the Yasukuni Shrine to demand the removal of the deceased aboriginal soldiers' tablets so that their spirits could be escorted back to Taiwan. But they were stopped by Japanese police around 200 meters away from the shrine and prohibited from getting off their buses.
With the help of officials from Taiwan's representative office in Japan, Kao Chin finally was allowed to get off her bus to talk to the media.
Lashing out at Japanese police over their actions, the aboriginal lawmaker from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union said she will keep coming back until she achieves her goal.
Kao Chin stressed that the spirits of the aboriginal soldiers cannot rest in peace at the Yasukuni Shrine because they were forced into military service and were not Japanese.

Dozens of Japanese right-wingers had gathered at main entrances of the shrine before the Taiwan protesters arrived in an attempt to disturb their planned demonstration, prompting the dispatch of hundreds of policemen to the scene to maintain order for fear that the situation might lead to violence.

The Yasukuni Shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million soldiers who died fighting for Japan, including more than 28,000 from Taiwan. It has drawn controversy mainly because a group of war criminals are also enshrined there.

Kao Chin sued Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi two years ago for violating Japan's constitution by paying a visit to the shrine, but the suit was rejected by an Osaka district court. Kao later appealed, and the high court of Osaka is expected to announce its ruling on the appeal on June 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60% IN HALF OF TAIWAN'S CITIES, COUNTIES SATISFIED WITH SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: The average approval rating for social order in Taiwan's 23 cities and counties is 55.86 percent, although over half of the cities and counties have an approval rating of more than 60 percent, a poll showed Tuesday.
The poll was conducted by the Ministry of the Interior May 20-28 and asked about social order between March and May. A total of 23,596 effective samples were collected.
The top three counties that have the highest approval ratings are Penghu, Taitung and Ilan in that order, while the lowest approval ratings are in Taichung City, Taipei County, and Taichung County.

The poll also showed that 5.74 percent of residents have been burglarized over the past three months, and the highest burglary ratio was reported in Kaohsiung and Pingtung at 6.46 percent. Just over 77 percent of residents have received fraud messages over the past three months to try to swindle them, and 1.28 percent were taken in.

Meanwhile, 25.9 percent attributed poor social order to the deteriorating economy and high unemployment, followed by the government's failure to uphold public authority or political instability (13.21 percent), and decadent ethics and morality (10.95 percent).

The Executive Yuan invited local chiefs early this year to meet to join in a campaign to improve social order on the island and the poll was one of the results of the efforts put forth by various cities and counties.
Other factors were that judicial authorities have been too lenient on perpetrators (8.72 percent) , media over-reporting of criminal cases (8.66 percent) , and educational failures (8.29 percent).

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY DOWNPOURS CAUSE NEARLY US$10 MILLION IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by torrential rains in southern Taiwan reached NT$296.6 million (US$9.44 million) , the latest official statistics showed Tuesday.
Tainan City sustained the largest agricultural damage, with every farmer and fishery operator qualifying for government cash aid, said officials of the Council of Agriculture (COA).

Meanwhile, farmers who grow melons, scallions and leafy vegetables in Kaohsiung County, as well as those who grow green beans in Tainan County are all qualified to apply for government relief, low-interest loans, they added.

According to COA statistics, the island saw a total of NT$112.54 million in crop losses, while 2,791 hectares of fields have been flooded as a result of heavy rainfall, with 26 percent of the fields having their crops completely destroyed.
In terms of fishery production, there was NT$174.4 million in losses, mostly reported from fish ponds in Tainan City and Pingtung County, the tallies showed.
Torrential rains have also caused NT$450,000 worth of facility damage in the fishery sector, as well as NT$9.1 million in livestock losses, according to the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG GROUPS ASK FOR RELEASE OF DETAINED JOURNALIST
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 14 (CNA) (By Semy Chen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong Journalists Association (HKJA) and a group of University of Hong Kong (HKU) alumni each published open letters to Chinese President Hu Jintao in local newspapers on Tuesday asking for the release of a journalist detained by China.

Ching Cheong, a Hong Kong resident who works as chief China correspondent for the Singapore-based Straits Times, has been detained in Guangzhou since April on charges of spying for foreign intelligence agencies.
In an open letter signed by 770 current and former journalists, the HKJA requested Beijing authorities deal with Ching's case justly, openly and legally.
More than 300 alumni of the HKU, Ching's alma mater, also urged Beijing authorities to consider the case justly and comprehensively in light of what they called Ching's patriotism.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES WORLD SKILLS COMPETITION DELEGATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday received Taiwan delegates who participated in this year's WorldSkills Competition in May and braved opposition from the organizer to wave Republic of China national flags at the opening ceremony.

Under pressure from Beijing, Finland, the organizer of the 38th WorldSkills Competition, sent in anticipation a formal letter to the Taiwan delegation that it would not allow Taiwanese delegates to carry ROC national flags at any occasion during the competition.
However, Taiwanese delegates managed, at many occasions including the opening and closing ceremonies, to carry and wave their flags to the audience from around the world.

Although their actions have pushed the International Vocational Training Organization (IVTO) to consider reviewing its rules to prevent a reoccurrence, President Chen hailed the patriotism of the delegates, saying that they are the pride of the country.
Taiwan joined the IVTO in 1970, with its delegates getting good results in almost every skill competition.
Taiwan delegates brought home one gold, two silver and four bronze medals, as well as 10 other prizes among 678 top competitors from 38 countries.

Chen stressed that under great pressure from the international community, Taiwan people should strengthen their competitiveness, and he urged the public to dedicate themselves to life-long learning to boost the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO NAME GROUPS FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai urged China Tuesday to appoint intermediary bodies to negotiate with parallel Taiwan organizations for opening direct charter cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait and other issues of mutual concern.

Cho made the call a day after Premier Frank Hsieh announced that the Republic of China government will take positive steps to boost cross-strait exchanges, including ordering the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to cooperate with other relevant government agencies to flesh out details for direct cross-strait charter cargo flights, sales of Taiwan farm produce to China and sightseeing trips to Taiwan by Chinese citizens.

While dining with a group of Taiwan businessmen operating in China who returned over the weekend for the Dragon Boat Festival celebrations, Hsieh also said the government will commission the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) to negotiate cross-strait charter cargo flights with China and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to negotiate sales of Taiwan farm produce to China.

"Now that the premier has outlined options acceptable to us, we hope China can make a goodwill response by appointing its parallel organizations for bilateral negotiations on the cargo flights and farm trade issues, " Cho said, adding that Beijing is welcome to announce its intermediary bodies at a news conference to be held by its Taiwan Affairs Office Wednesday.
"Should that be the case, cross-strait consultations on direct charter cargo flights and farm trade could begin very soon, " Cho said.

As to opening the door for Chinese residents to sightsee in Taiwan, Cho said the government has yet to choose a suitable body to negotiate with China because the issue involves more complicated technical details related to the exercise of public authorities.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said earlier in the day that he looks forward to the participation of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in the negotiations for opening sightseeing trips to Taiwan by Chinese residents.

The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges with China in the absence of official contacts. However, Beijing has unilaterally suspended the institutionalized interaction between the SEF and its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- since mid-1999 over then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui's definition of bilateral ties as being state-to-state in nature.

If China still does not allow ARATS officials to talk with their SEF counterparts over the tourist issue, Wu said the government would not rule out commissioning other appropriate body to negotiate the issue. But he added whatever the body, the negotiating team should include officials from the Immigration Bureau, the Tourism Bureau and the SEF.
Noting that the SEF has a long history of dealing with China, Wu said its officials should have a role in the negotiations for opening the door to Chinese tourists.
The nation's top mainland policy planner further said the ROC government has been pragmatic and flexible in managing cross-strait affairs while adhering to its fundamental stance and core values.

"Anything involving state authority must be negotiated by government officials or in a way acceptable to us. Nevertheless, we are willing to exercise flexibility toward the setting in order to achieve concrete results," Wu said.
Take the opening of direct cross-strait charter passenger flights during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday earlier this year as an example, he said.
"Regardless of the title used in the negotiations in Macau for the temporary holiday charter flights, our civil aviation chief presided over the negotiations in person on that occasion," Wu said.

Wu was referring to Civil Aeronautics Administration Director Chang Kuo-cheng, who took part in the cross-strait charter passenger flights negotiations in Macau with Chinese officials as an adviser to the private Taipei Airlines Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT-YEAR, NT$80 BILLION PROPOSAL CAN SOLVE FLOOD PROBLEMS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that his proposal for an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project will solve the flooding problems of the entire nation.

The premier said the project was not "absurd" as opposition parties have alleged, saying that those who have not suffered from serious flooding cannot know the misery of those who have gone through such an ordeal.

Hsieh pointed out at the headquarters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party that the government has appropriated NT$1 billion every year for flood control, but if the problems have to be addressed year by year, it may take 80 years to completely fix the problems.

He noted that the flooding problems in Shertze and Hsichi in Taipei and Kaohsiung have been solved, and the key is whether the government is willing to take the problem seriously for the rest of the country.

Hsieh said that the government spent more than NT$40 billion to solve the Hsichi flooding problems, and nobody said that that was too much. The proposed NT$80 billion will solve the flooding problems of the entire nation, and he asked, "How can that be too much?"
Because Taipei is a metropolitan city, its flooding problems were solved early, but can the problem in other places wait 80 years? he asked.

He said that before he assumed the premiership, he was Kaohsiung mayor, and the city had serious flooding problems. But when visiting Kaohsiung Sunday, he found an installed pond had caught 110,000 tons of waters after flash flooding and had prevented serious problems for local residents.

On Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's remarks that the government's emergency fund could be used, the premier said that the fund can indeed be used in emergency situations, but that the money available is limited.

He said that if the Legislative Yuan can pass the eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-control project, it would mean that there will be NT$20 billion available in the first two years, and the flooding problems in most of the population-dense areas, such as Hsinchuang and Hsulin in Taipei county, can be solved.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN HOPEFUL: NEW CHIEF SHOULD LEAD PARTY TO WIN PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is running for the Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship, said in Taitung, eastern Taiwan Tuesday that the new party leader must be capable of leading the opposition party to winning back the presidency.

At a campaign meeting with KMT leaders in Taitung, Wang said five years after the Democratic Progressive Party took power, the country is still beset by financial problems, stagnant ties with China and confrontations among various ethnic groups.
The only way for the country to weather these problems, Wang said, is for the KMT to win back power.
However, Wang said, for the KMT to win in the 2008 presidential election, the party will need a leader who can deliver on five urgent tasks.

He said the five tasks are pressing on with party reforms, handling the thorny issue of the party's assets, commanding the support of the People First Party and the New Party -- which are KMT spin-offs -- leading the KMT to control at least half of the 23 counties and cities in the year-end elections for county and city chiefs, and finding a candidate who can win the 2008 presidential election.
Although he was not specific, the KMT vice chairman is suggesting that he can do all of these and is therefore the best man to take up the reins of the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA UNDECIDED ON STAND TOWARD JAPAN FOR BARRING TAIWAN PROTESTERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will decide whether to protest to Japan for blocking a planned demonstration by family members of a group of deceased Taiwan aboriginal soldiers who fought for the Japanese after gathering more information on the incident, a ministry official said Tuesday.

The protesters led by aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei had planned to demonstrate Tuesday outside the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, where their ancestors who fought for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II are honored. They are demanding the removal of the aboriginal soldiers' tablets from the shrine "so that their spirits can be escorted back to Taiwan."

But they were stopped about 200 meters from the shrine and prohibited from getting off their buses by Japanese police for fear that they might clash with a group of Japanese right-wingers who had gathered at the scene ahead of their arrival.

According to Liao Ching-pang, an official in charge of Taiwan-Japan relations at the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, the ministry does not approve of the behavior of the right-wingers and will look into the case to see if the action taken by the police exceeded their authority.
The ministry has hired lawyers to assist the family members with their bid to have tablets of the aboriginal soldiers removed from the Yasukuni Shrine, Liao said.
Liao made the remarks in response to a request by opposition Kuomintang aboriginal Legislator Kung Wen-chi that the government lodge a serious protest to Japan over the incident.

Kung accused the Japanese government of discriminating against the aborigines by shutting them in their buses in favor of the Japanese right-wingers, which he said reminds him of the brutalities of Japanese militarism and what he described as "high-handed governance" during the former Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
He urged the government to offer as much assistance as possible to the family members of the deceased aboriginal soldiers to protect their safety and dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT COMMISSION EXPLAINS REGULATIONS ON INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday that the Taiwanese investor who owns "dominating power" over a company situated in an overseas area outside Taiwan or China must apply for government permission before investing in China.

A report of a controversial plan by Taiwan's semiconductor giant, the United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , to invest in the Suzhou-based He Jian Technology in China via its Japanese subsidiary has recently raised debate among local businessmen on the legality of investment projects of this kind.

Explaining the existing regulations in terms of investment in China, officials said that individuals and enterprises in Taiwan are allowed to invest there directly or indirectly -- making such investments through corporate operations in "third areas" outside Taiwan and China -- after they are granted permission by the Investment Commission.

If a company in a "third place" acts to invest in China and their Taiwanese investors are the "dominating power" in the firm, such a plan is considered by the Taiwan government as indirect investment, which requires government permission, the officials said.

The commission defines the "dominating power" as holding over 5 percent of stocks or being the leading stockholder of a company in a third place, or investing over US$200,000 in such a company, or serving as general manager or a member of the board of the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Michael Jackson Cleared After 14-Week Child Molesting Trial.
Michael Jackson was acquitted on Monday of all charges against him by a jury that absorbed three months of often lurid testimony about his life and relationships with young boys but rejected a teenager's claim that Jackson plied him with liquor and sexually molested him. A Santa Maria jury found Jackson not guilty of four charges of child molesting, one charge of attempted child molesting, one conspiracy charge and eight possible counts of providing alcohol to minors. The eight women and four men of the jury deliberated for about 30 hours over seven days before saying shortly after noon that they had reached a decision.
Wall Street Journal: Exxon Chief Makes A Cold Calculation on Global Warming.
At Exxon Mobil Corp.'s laboratories, scientists are trying to perfect an oil that could sell to companies operating wind turbines. Oil giants such as BP PLC and Royal Dutch/Shell Group are trumpeting abetter-safe-than-sorry approach to global warming. They accept a growing scientific consensus that fossil fuels are a main contributor to the problem and endorse the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, which caps emissions from developed nations that have ratified it. BP and Shell also have begun to invest in alternatives to fossil fuels. Exxon publicly predicts that solar and wind energy will continue to provide less than 1 percent of the world's energy supply in 2025, a subject that others shy away from. Even if fossil fuels are the chief global-warming culprit, Exxon argues, the sensible response is to figure out how to burn them more efficiently.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CRITICIZES CHINA AS 'HAVEN FOR CRIMINALS'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu described China Tuesday as a "haven for criminals" because so many Taiwanese criminals have fled there to evade punishment.

At a meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Central Executive Committee, in which Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan presented a report on social order, Lu expressed her preoccupation with the country's deteriorating social order and said the DPP administration should offer the people a living environment free of worry.
Noting that China has apparently become a refuge for Taiwanese gangsters, Lu said the government should lodge fierce protests with the Chinese authorities.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said the improvement of social order has been a big concern for the public and that the government also has put the issue at its top priority, claiming that an action plan to improve social order launched by the government in early March has seen some results.
Meanwhile, Su Jia-chyuan urged the joint efforts of the public, the media, the judicial authorities and the education sector to improve the social order.

Legislator Trong Tsai, who is a member of the committee, claimed that the heavy coverage of a mobster's high-profile funeral by the media has sent the "wrong message" to the public and will thus affect social morals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON TO DONATE NT$2 MILLION TO MARK WEDDING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son will donate a total of NT$2 million (US$63,694) in cash to three charitable organizations in the southern county of Tainan to mark his wedding this weekend, a Presidential Office spokesman said Tuesday.
"Chen Chih-chung will follow the example set by his elder sister four years ago in donating money to social welfare groups to mark his wedding," the spokesman said.

The president's daughter, Chen Hsing-yu, donated NT$2 million to low-income families when she married four years ago. Of the money, NT$1.5 million was the dowry given by her father and the remaining NT$500,000 came from her own savings.

"Chen Chih-chung and his fiancee will donate the same amount of money to three charitable organizations, including the Tainan County LifeLine Association, in the president's home county, with the money coming from their parents and their own savings, " the spokesman explained.
Chen Chih-chung was engaged to his fiancee Huang Jui-ching in Taichung City last weekend and they will get married in Taipei this week.

The president originally asked the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs to assist in calling a news conference to brief the media on procedures of Chen Chih-chung's wedding. However, the first family decided to cancel the news conference after flash floods brought by heavy rain in the past few days wreaked havoc in the three southern counties of Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan.
The Presidential Office spokesman said the first family will not accept any money or gifts for Chen Chih-chung's wedding.
"The first family will only accept good wishes from relatives and friends," the spokesman added.

Chen Chih-chung, who obtained a master's degree in law from the University of California at Berkeley in May, will travel to the United States with his pianist wife, where they will continue their studies. Huang Jui-ching has a master's in piano performance from the Taipei National University of the Arts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES FOR OBSERVER STATUS FOR TAIWAN AT OAS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the Organization of American States (OAS) Tuesday to give a fair consideration to Taiwan's application to become an observer.
Chen made the call during a meeting with a visiting delegation comprising ambassadors of Republic of China diplomatic allies to the OAS and the United States.

After China obtained observer status in the OAS last month, Taiwan also filed an application with the OAS for the same status May 20 in the hope that the country could take a more positive part in the international community, according to Chen.
Chen claimed that the OAS is the most important political regional organization in the western hemisphere and that one-third of its member nations maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
While Taiwan participated in the rehabilitation program in the aftermath of Hurricane Mitch in 1998, it has also sponsored an OAS project aimed at training young entrepreneurs since 2003, Chen noted.
The president said he hopes that a Taiwan fund can be established in the OAS to let Taiwan contribute in a more substantive way to OAS affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S RECOGNIZES TAIWAN'S FIGHT AGAINST DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan has lived up to "world standards" in the fight against illicit drug trafficking, the deputy head of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Tuesday.

David Keegan, deputy director of the AIT Taipei Office, made the remarks while addressing the opening of an anti-drug trafficking workshop at the headquarters of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) in suburban Taipei.
The workshop was co-sponsored by the MJIB and the United States' Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) . Similar seminars were held in Taipei in 2002 and 2004.

Keegan said that even though Taiwan is not a signatory to the United Nation's Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, its anti-drug trafficking mechanism and legislation fully meet the U.N.-set standards.

Taiwan used to be a major transshipment stop for illicit drugs delivered to the United States, Keegan noted, adding that the situation improved after Taiwan stepped up the fight against illegal drug trafficking and crafted a world-class anti-drug trafficking system.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Taiwan has made significant progress in the crackdown on illicit drug trafficking and abuse. In 2004, he said, 3,000 kg of amphetamine were seized, accounting for 60 percent of the total drug seizures for that year. Law enforcement officers seized 551 kg of raw materials for producing amphetamine, indicating that plants that moved abroad a few years ago might have been moved back, Shih said, adding that the MJIB will strengthen cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) to rein in the flow of relevant raw materials.

The DEA has sent instructors to teach local law enforcement officers, including MJIB investigators, prosecutors, coast guard officers, IDB officials and health care staff, how to detect illicit drug trafficking and controlled chemicals that could be used to produce illicit drugs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD PROMOTES DEVELOPMENT OF RENEWABLE ENERGY

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) officials said Tuesday that renewable energy has great market potential in the next decade, as its electricity-generating costs have been falling.

Citing a report from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) of the United States, CEPD officials said the cost of electricity-generating from wind, geothermal, solar and biomass power has been reducing since 1980, with the electricity-generating cost from wind power dropping to between four and six cents per unit in 2004.
According to U.S.-based Business Communications Co. Inc, the global production of renewable energy totalled US$26.64 billion in 2003, with the figure expected to reach US$41.62 billion in 2008.
In that year, the top three forms of renewable energy will be wind, hydro and solar power, in that order, researchers said.

Meanwhile, experts from American research firm Clean Edge, which helps investors to understand and reap profit from emerging clean-energy markets, said clean energy will focus on solar, wind power and fuel cells in the next decade, with production value reaching US$39.2 billion, US$48.1 billion and US$15.1 billion, respectively, in 2014 from US$7.2 billion, US$8 billion, and US$900 million in 2004, respectively.

CEPD officials said Taiwan should develop renewable energy to reduce its heavy energy dependence on other countries, adding that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has plans to increase the percentage of renewable energy in the country's total energy capacity to 10 percent in 2010 from the 5.5 percent in 2004.

By doing so, the officials said, it is expected to significantly reduce carbon dioxide emissions and save energy imports by NT$113 billion (US$3.6 billion) , while generating production value of related industries by NT$44 billion.
The officials urged the early legislation of renewable energy development regulations to eliminate barriers to its development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 15 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, June 15:
09: 00, The weekly Cabinet meeting will be held at the Executive Yuan.
09: 00, The opposition Kuomintang will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
10: 00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10: 20, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a ceremony at the Council of Agriculture marking the first shipment of Taiwan papayas to Japan.
11: 00, President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh will attend celebrations marking Police Day at the National Police Administration.
14: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will watch a documentary on Taiwan farming titled "Let It Be" at the Presidential Office along with farmers' representatives and journalists.
14: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a rescue dog donation ceremony by Samsung Group of South Korea at the Kaohsiung Municipal Rescue Dog Training Center, in Nantze, Kaohsiung City.
15: 45, Premier Frank Hsieh will inspect flood-control ponds in Kaohsiung City.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
18: 55, Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang will attend a meeting of the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace at Sheraton Hotel in Taipei.
19: 30, Taiwan Think Tank Chairman Chen Poh-chih will give a lecture at the Ketagalan Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BEEF SAFE, AIT OFFICIAL CLAIMS

TEXT.P: An American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) official claimed Tuesday that U.S. beef will remain safe, regardless of the results of a possible second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.

According to Scott S. Sindelar, chief of the Agricultural Section at the AIT's Taipei office, this is not a new case but a re-test of an old sample taken during an extensive cattle herd surveillance program prior to December 2004.

As an enhanced surveillance program started in June 2004, the U.S. Department of Agriculture has tested more than 375,000 animals from the targeted cattle population using a rapid test, three of which tested inconclusive, Sindelar said.
The three samples tested negative in subsequent immunohistochemistry testing, but one of them was positive using the Western blot test, Sindelar said.
He said the sample was sent to England for further testing and that the results are expected in two weeks.

Although the targeted animals account for only 0.5 percent of the entire cattle population in the United States, they are considered a high-risk group that has been banned from the human food supply chain, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. STATE SECRETARY: POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 14 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged and President George Bush is expected to carry on this policy, which recognizes only one China and does not support Taiwan independence, former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell said here Tuesday.

Speaking to delegates at a Pacific Basin Economic Council business conference, Powell admitted that there is a trade dispute between China and the United States over China's textile exports, saying it will be sorted out eventually as long as both sides face up to their differences pragmatically.

He played down the significance of trade disputes, arguing that they are common between countries. Citing examples to support his stance, Powell pointed out that the U.S. also has trade disputes with Canada, Mexico and the European Union.
"It is not so much that you have these disputes, but the question is, do you resolve them?" he said.

As to the exchange rate for China's renminbi, Powell said that instead of pressuring China into appreciating its currency, Beijing leaders should be given time and room to exercise their own judgment, claiming that they will eventually do on their own what the rest of the world believes is right.

The former U.S. secretary of state said he does not see any threat to Washington from China's increase in weapons spending, noting that China is at least 10 years behind the United States in military strength.
However, Powell said, China should increase the transparency in its arms purchase programs to increase the trust of other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO SET UP TEAM TO PROMOTE EXCHANGES WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will set up a team to promote opposition exchanges with China, and might send a delegation to Beijing in July, a PFP official said Tuesday.
Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP Policy Coordination Center, said his party will exchange views with the Kuomintang (KMT) on cooperation between the two parties on issues concerning China.

Noting that PFP Chairman James Soong said during his tour of China in May that his party is a strategic partner of the KMT when it comes to Taiwan-China issues, Chang said the PFP will seek the KMT's opinion on cooperation in improving opposition ties with China.
The PFP will also negotiate with the Communist Party of China (CPC) on ways to conduct exchanges, Chang went on.
The team, to be led by PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, will be made up mainly of PFP lawmakers.

The party will send a delegation to China, probably in July, to negotiate with Beijing officials on ways to realize the six-point consensus worked out by Soong and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PARLIAMENT SPEAKER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Marshall Islands Parliament Speaker Litokwa Tomeing will arrive in Taiwan at the head of a parliamentary delegation Wednesday for a four-day visit, according to a news release issued Tuesday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

During the visit, Tomeing will meet with President Chen Shui-bian, Legislative Yuan Vice President Chung Jung-chi, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kau Ying-mao, International Cooperation and Development Fund Secretary-General Chen Cheng-chung and officials of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, MOFA officials said.
Tomeing and his delegation will also visit various economic and cultural establishments before departing Taiwan June 18, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAMAGE CAUSED BY DOWNPOUR EXPANDS

TEXT.P: Damage caused by downpours that have entered a fourth day expanded Tuesday, with the agriculture sector bearing the brunt, suffering damage worth an estimated NT$389.6 million (US$12.42 million) , Council of Agriculture officials said Tuesday.
Most of the damage was centered in southern Taiwan, especially Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Tainan counties where low-lying areas were inundated by floodwater.
In order to prevent a possible outbreak of disease after the flooding, health authorities are scrambling to ship disinfectant to the flooded areas to spray when the water recedes.
The Environmental Protection Administration said it has 15,000 liters of disinfectant in stock.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 15, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border west of the Great Lakes.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down in Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1944: U.S. forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the U.S. envoy to China notifies the Chinese government of the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the U.S., Great Britain and the USSR agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The People's Daily, a Chinese Communist Party newspaper, publishes its first issue.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastics raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1975: Chang Pao-shu, secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, and four other members leave for Tokyo to attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Eikaku Sato.
1976: Maj. Gen. Kin Sang Tao, chief of the South Korean Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1981: Sun I-suan, chairman of the Taipei Bankers Association, announces an increase in the highest deposit interest rate to 15 percent and in the top loan rate to 18 percent.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries -- Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest level ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
1999: South Korea sinks one North Korean gunboat and heavily damages others in the Yellow Sea.
2000: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Exhibition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with exhibitors from more than 10 countries participating.
2001: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says the information technology (IT) industry will remain be the top player among all industries in the next 10 years.
2004: The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union is inaugurated with former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya as its founding chairwoman.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To preach in the public streets the commonplaces which you have picked up on the way is to throw away all your finer feelings."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The China Times:
Hon Hai chairman voices opposition to the government's plan to levy more taxes on rich men.
The United Daily News:

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY CALLS FOR UPHOLDING OF NATIONAL DIGNITY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education called Wednesday for those in Taiwan's education sector to uphold the Republic of China's national dignity while engaging in academic exchanges with their counterparts from China.

Chang Kuo-pao, director of the Ministry of Education's Department of Technological Vocational Education, said that it is the ministry's set policy that the ROC's national dignity and soverignty "should not be dented or infringed upon" during cross-strait academic exchanges or related activities.

Chang was referring to a newspaper report Wednesday that said authorities from the Hsiuping Institute of Technology had removed the ROC national flag and the picture of the ROC founding father, Sun Yat-sen, for a commencement ceremony held at the institute's stadium a couple of days ago to "please several mainland Chinese guests who were attending the graduation ceremony."
Chang said that the move was "extremely inappropriate" because it represented a "denting of the ROC's national dignity."

Meanwhile, Su Tseng-chang, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, called for the administration to immediately discipline the Hsiuping Institute in accordance with the law for impairing the ROC's national dignity.

Su said that the institute had "dwarfed" the ROC's sovereignty by removing the national flag in front of the mainland Chinese visitors. "This is absolutely unacceptable and should be dealt with squarely, " he added.
Meanwhile, the Hsiuping authorities said that the news report's claim that the national flag and the picture of Sun Yat-sen were removed to please the mainland guests was untrue and unfounded.

Hsiuping President Lin Pao-tsong said that the flag and picture were removed to cope with the needs of stage design for the commencement ceremony and that the same thing has been done for years for graduation ceremonies at the institute.

Lin noted that there were a great number of ROC national flags along the roads leading to the stadium and around the campus and that "the last thing the institute would do would be to remove the national flag to please anyone from China."
According to the report, some parents of the graduates informed the daily about the national flag removal incident.

Lin noted that if those parents had attended previous commencement ceremonies held by the institute, then they would know that the removal of the flag and picture was just a regular part of setting up the graduation ceremony stage and that it was in no way related to the fact that a few people from China happened to be attending this year's ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO ADOPT MINIMUM TAX SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reaffirmed the government's determination Wednesday to impose a minimum tax system by the end of this year as part of its tax reform plan.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh said local society has a high degree of consensus on implementing a minimum tax system. Even though some business tycoons have voiced opposition to the proposed minimum tax scheme, he said, the government will not waver its stance on this reform plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REQUESTS EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO PASS FLOOD-CONTROL BUDGET

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Wednesday again called for the Legislative Yuan to convene an extraordinary session so as to pass the Executive Yuan's proposed special flood-control statute and its eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) budget as soon as possible.
The 6th Legislative Yuan went into recess at the end of May after concluding its first session.

The premier noted that torrential rains over the past few days have inundated many areas in southern Taiwan. He attributed the serious flooding in these areas to three factors -- climate change which leads to heavy rainfall, clogged sewage systems, and insufficient flood-fighting facilities.

He pointed to the success of the flood-control projects in Kaohsiung City and for the Keelung River in Taipei City as examples, noting that neither municipality has reported flooding during the recent heavy downpours. However, he stressed that flood-fighting projects require funding, saying that this is why his Cabinet has proposed the special flood-control budget.

Noting that the government has spent NT$70 billion (US$2.22 billion) on the flood-control system for the Keelung River, Yu said that "spending NT$80 billion on flood-control for the entire nation is not a huge sum."

Lai Ching-te, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the legislature, said the premier will call on the DPP caucus Friday to communicate with it on his hope that the legislature will convene a special session and pass the flood-fighting budget.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a DPP ally, has been lukewarm toward the premier's proposal, urging instead that the government use a special fund reserved for emergency use.

Legislator Ho Min-hao, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, urged the government to use the fund for residents in the flood-affected areas immediately, and not to resort to asking the legislature to convene a special session to review the special budget proposal which he said will be "too late for dealing with the current disaster."
Ho also said that he is worried that "flood-fighting" could turn into an excuse for local governments to ask for more money from the central government.
However, Lai said that money from the special fund is limited and is not sufficient for the flood-fighting.
Meanwhile, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) criticized the Cabinet's proposed special budget.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan said the appropriation of special budgets must meet stringent preconditions, lamenting that in recent years, the appropriation of special budgets has become common practice.

Local governments have funds reserved for disasters, and the government "should not resort to populism to try to ram through its special budget proposal" via an extraordinary session of the legislature, which he termed as a "very irresponsible approach."
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the Executive Yuan has at least NT$19.3 billion at its disposal, which he said is more than enough to deal with the flooding in southern Taiwan.

The Executive Yuan should use this money for post-disaster relief, Wang said, adding that whether the legislature holds a special session as requested by the premier to pass the flood-control budget will depend on the results of inter-party consultations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT CHIEF SHOULD LEAD PARTY TO WIN YEAR-END ELECTIONS: MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said Wednesday that the new chairman of the party must be capable of leading the KMT to win back its dominance in the year-end mayoral and county chief elections.

Ma, a candidate for the KMT chairmanship, said that regardless of who wins the chairmanship election slated for July 16, that person must be capable of first leading the KMT to winning at least half of the 23 counties and cities in the year-end elections for county and city chiefs.
"This is a prerequisite to becoming a KMT chairman hopeful, " Ma said, adding that if the hopeful cannot do it, he should not run.

Ma also noted that the 2005 mayoral and county chief elections are only some of the many elections that will be held in the years leading up to the 2008 presidential election, saying that the KMT should win every election over the following three years, including the presidential election in 2008 and the legislative elections in 2007.

Ma's opponent in the race for the KMT chairmanship, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, said a day earlier that the new party leader must be capable of leading the KMT to win back the presidency.

At a campaign meeting with KMT leaders in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Wang said that five years after the Democratic Progressive Party took power, the country is still beset by financial problems, stagnant ties with China, and confrontation among the various ethnic groups.
The only way for the country to weather these problems, Wang said, is for the KMT to win back power.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY HAS NO PLANS TO SEND KNOX-CLASS FRIGATE NEAR DISPUTED WATERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense turned down Wednesday a request by an opposition lawmaker that the military send a Knox-class frigate on June 17 to waters near a disputed part of the East China Sea to flex Taiwan's muscle against Japan.
Ministry spokesman Liu Chih-chien said the military has no plans to do so because most available military forces have been deployed to take part in the "Hankuang 21" exercises.
Liu said the three frigates already deployed by the military near the disputed waters should be sufficient to serve the purpose.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang, a co-convener of the legislature's National Defense Committee, made the request in the wake of a serious conflict breaking out last week in waters off Taiwan's northeast coast between Taiwanese fishermen and the Japanese coast guard following the latest expulsion of Taiwanese fishermen from the area.
The incident occurred in an area of the East China Sea where the exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.
Lin claimed that Japan is "much more polite" to Chinese and South Korean fishermen operating in the same waters and doesn't dare arbitrarily expel them.

Blaming the situation on the "long-time cowardice" of the government of Taiwan, Lin urged the military to get tough with Japan to boost Taiwan's leverage, especially when both countries are set to open a new round of fishery talks in July.

Lin said he will go ahead with his fact-finding sail to an area near the disputed waters on June 17 regardless of the Ministry of National Defense's request for him to postpone the trip on the grounds that the timing is too sensitive.

He also threatened to block the ministry's NT$480 billion U.S. arms procurement package and cut the ministry's annual budget by at least NT$50 billion if the ministry refuses to send a Knox-class frigate to accompany him on the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM TAX SYSTEM TO BE IN PLACE BY YEAR'S END: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reaffirmed the government's determination Wednesday to impose a minimum tax system by the end of this year as part of its tax reform plan.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh said there is a high degree of consensus in Taiwan society on implementing a minimum tax system. Even though some business tycoons have voiced opposition to the proposed minimum tax scheme, he said, the government will not waver in its stance on this reform plan.

"The proposed minimum tax scheme must be in place by year's end because it is closely related to fairness in our taxation system, " Hsieh said, adding that this round of tax reform will focus on introducing a minimum tax mechanism.
Referring to Hon Hai Precision Industry Chairman Terry Kuo's scathing criticism of the government's minimum tax reform plan, Hsieh said Kuo is not alone in opposing this new tax measure.

"Kuo is just more outspoken in expressing his own feelings. The government recognizes Kuo's contributions to Taiwan's industrial development. I hope Kuo and other business magnates can understand the government's ultimate goals in tax reform. We will not waiver in our determination to craft a fairer and more complete taxation system despite opposition from business quarters," Hsieh said.
Under the current taxation system, Hsieh said, many wealthy people are not required to pay income taxes because of deficiencies or flaws in existing tax laws.

"The government is now determined to plug holes and deficiencies in our taxation system by introducing a minimum tax scheme which would require high-income earners' to pay a minimum amount of taxes," Hsieh said.
According to finance ministry data, eight of the nation's 40 richest people didn't pay a dime of income tax last year, and 15 others paid less than 1 percent of their annual income.
Noting that tax reform plans tend to draw opposition from various social quarters, Hsieh said the Ministry of Finance should focus its efforts on fleshing out a minimum tax scheme at the moment.

"At this stage of tax reform, we should give priority to introducing a minimum tax system while suspending debate on other reform measures in order to minimize possible backlash, " Hsieh said, adding that other reform plans aimed at expanding the taxation base should be discussed in the later stage of reform.
Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said after the Cabinet meeting that the government has set two goals for this round of tax reform -- fairness and expansion of taxation base.

To realize the goal of tax fairness, Cho said, the government will introduce a minimum tax scheme. As for the goal of expanding tax base, he said, the priority is to cancel the income tax exemption privilege to elementary and junior high school teachers and military personnel. The proposed levy of income taxes on overseas earnings will not be considered at this stage of tax reform, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ACTIVATES MEDICAL CARE CONTINGENCY MECHANISM IN WAKE OF FLOODING

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday that it has activated a medical care contingency mechanism in central and southern Taiwan in the wake of days of torrential rain that has caused serious flooding in several areas.

DOH officials noted that some residents are still trapped in mountainous or remote areas in central and southern Taiwan and that medical teams provided by local health authorities are on standby to provide assistance.
If the trapped residents need emergency hospital care, the DOH will also ask the Ministry of the Interior to organize helicopter airlifts to get them out.
To avoid outbreaks of infectious disease in the flood-affected areas, the DOH urged the public to pay special attention to dietary and environmental hygiene.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NOT TO EXPAND U.S. BEEF IMPORTS BEFORE DOUBTS CLEARED

TEXT.P: The government will not expand imports of U.S. beef before any doubts about its safety are cleared, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Cho Jung-tai made the remarks in the wake of a report earlier this month of a suspected case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, in the United States. THe case passed all but one of a battery of BSE tests and was sent to Britain for further testing. The results are expected in two weeks.

Several legislators from across the party spectrum have demanded that the Department of Health (DOH) remove U.S. beef from store shelves and a reinstatement of a ban on U.S. beef, but Chen Lu-hung, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said Monday that the department will only decide on the matter after the British tests have been completed.

Cho quoted an instruction from Premier Frank Hsieh that day that the government will deal with the matter cautiously and that before the doubts are clarified, the government will not expand U.S. beef imports.
The DOH has asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture and other related government agencies to send related information concerning U.S. beef to Taiwan, Cho added.

He also said that at present, Taiwan imports boneless beef from animals under 30 months old that has passed stringent security examinations, quoting World Organization for Animal Health guidelines as stating that boneless beef with no other specific dangerous substances from animals under 30 months of age can be exported even from BSE-infected areas.
But he also urged big stores to clearly mark the origin of the beef sold so that the public can have the option of not choosing it.
Taiwan first banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case.
On April 16 this year, Taiwan began to allow imports of U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN URGED NOT TO TAKE RADICAL ACTION OVER DISPUTES

TEXT.P: A government spokesman urged Taiwan's fishermen Wednesday not to take radical action over fishery disputes with Japan.

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Taiwan and Japan are expected to hold a 15th round of fishery talks in late June or early July to address recent fishery disputes in the overlapping waters of the two countries' exclusive economic zones.
Both sides have shown sincerity in resolving the disputes through the bilateral negotiations, Cho noted.
He reiterated the administration's unwavering determination to protect fishermen's rights and interests and to safeguard the nation's economic zone and sovereignty.

He discouraged the fishermen from taking radical or unhelpful action such as flying the five-star People's Republic of China banner or converging to encircle Japanese patrol vessels in disputed waters.

To meet the precondition of not affecting the future demarcation of each other's economic zones, Taiwan and Japan will discuss first drawing up a joint operations area in the disputed waters in which fishing boats from the two countries would be allowed to catch fish under adequate management, according to Cho.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao, in the eastern Taiwan county of Ilan, staged a protest June 10 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships out of an area in which the 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Taiwan fishing ships have been repeatedly expelled or detained by Japanese patrol vessels over the past two years after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and neighboring Hualien counties.

Cho noted that the Executive Yuan has filed a strong protest against Japan over the controversy via Taiwan's liaison office in Tokyo and has asked that Taiwan and Japan seek to resolve their fishing disputes through dialogue in line with international law.

Quoting tallies from the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration, Cho said that over the past several years, 11 Taiwan fishing boats have been detained by Japan's Fisheries Agency, all of which were caught beyond Taiwan's "temporarily demarcated line."
By comparison, Cho said, 38 Chinese fishing boats were nabbed during the same period, while 120-odd South Korean fishing boats were detained.

Cho added that it is a bad idea that Taiwan fishing boats choose to fly PRC flag to evade the Japanese patrol boats' crackdown because more PRC vessels have been busted than those from Taiwan and it would make it even more difficult for the government to protect the Taiwan fishing boats.

Before the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks begin, Taiwanese fishermen should operate within the area temporarily demarcated by the government and the Coast Guard Administration will send patrol ships to fully protect them, Cho added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 46.34 points to close at 6,252.10.
The bourse opened at 6,219.80 and fluctuated between 6,215.73 and 6,252.10 during trading. A total of 3.38 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.30 billion (US$2.43 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by textile and cement issues at 1.5 percent each, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, construction issues at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, and foodstuff and plastics shares both at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 571 to 253, with 173 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPSU PROTESTS TO JAPAN FOR BARRING TOKYO DEMO BY TAIWAN ABORIGINES

TEXT.P: A group of Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) politicians lodged a protest Wednesday with the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan over what they called "rude and unreasonable" treatment received by a group of Taiwan aboriginal demonstrators in Japan a day earlier.

The protesters, led by aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei of the NPSU, had planned to demonstrate outside the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, where their ancestors who fought for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II are honored. They are demanding the removal of the aboriginal soldiers' tablets from the shrine so that their "spirits can be escorted back to Taiwan."
They were stopped by Japanese police about 200 meters from the shrine and prohibited from getting out of their buses.
To show their support for Kao Chin, NPSU Chairwoman Chang Po-ya, Legislators Chen Chin-ting and Tsai Hao submitted a letter of protest to the Taipei office of the Interchange Association of Japan.

In the letter, the NPSU said the "rude and unreasonable" method employed by Japanese police in dealing with the matter reminds people of Japanese colonial rule in Taiwan more than 100 years ago and the "bullying" endured by the Taiwan people at that time.

The NPSU also demanded that the Japanese prime minister stop paying yearly visits to the Yasukuni Shrine and approve the family members' request to perform rites at the shrine to transfer the spirits of the aboriginal soldiers back to Taiwan.
During the meeting with the NPSU representatives, Interchange Association officials said the actions taken by the police Tuesday were based on "traffic safety" considerations, according to Chang.
But Chang claimed the reason is not convincing because the protesters had only planned to stage a demonstration and were not going to march.

Tsai claimed that the way Japan handled the matter has seriously undermined the dignity of Taiwan and its legislators, and urged the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to step in to negotiate with Japan for a proper settlement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June moved up 45 points to close at 6,266, with 13,629 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose 28 points to close at 6,148, with 17,158 contracts traded, while September futures gained 46 points to finish at 6,056, with 739 contracts traded.
December futures moved up 30 points to close at 6,039, with nine contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,221 for June, 6,120 for July, 6,010 for September, 6,009 for December and 6,005 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
June TE futures moved up 1.85 points to close at 253.85, with 2,290 contracts traded, while July TE futures gained 1.65 points to finish at 251.15 with 2,465 contract transactions.
September TE futures rose 1.05 points to close at 248.1, with five contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 2.1 points to close at 248.1, with two contract contractions.
March TE futures moved up 3.5 points to close at 247.1, with one contract traded.
June TF futures rose 3.0 points to finish at 964.6, with 1,669 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures moved up 1.8 points to close at 950.8, with 2,155 contracts traded.
September TF futures moved up 4.4 points to finish at 937.8, with 10 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELEASED SEX OFFENDERS TO BE ELECTRONICALLY TAGGED

TEXT.P: Sex offenders released on parole will be electronically tagged with a tracking device disguised as a wrist watch to monitor their whereabouts, Ministry of Justice authorities said Wednesday.
Surveillance equipment will be installed in their residences to further monitor their behavior, ministry officials said.

Meanwhile, the officials added, the Ministry of Justice will also tag major financial criminals with specially designed bracelets or leg chains to prevent them from fleeing the country after they are released on parole.

The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.478 and hit a high of NT$31.506.
