DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS PERFORMANCE OF POLICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his gratitude to the police Wednesday, hailing their dedication and performance.

At the nation's Police Day celebrated at the National Police Administration, Chen bestowed medals on outstanding policemen around the country and said the improvement of social order is the government's top priority.

Chen claimed that an action plan to improve social order launched Feb. 1 has seen handsome results, mentioning in particular the capture of suspects who assaulted policemen and the capture of an individual who poisoned brand name beverages sold at convenient stores.
Chen encouraged the policemen to continue their efforts and said the government will serve as their shield, offering complementary measures and better training.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR LINKS, TOUTS FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN CITY

TEXT.P: Taipei has huge potential for becoming a regional and global business operations hub and opening direct transport links between Taiwan and China is vital to this aim, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou claimed Wednesday.

Speaking in a seminar sponsored by a financial magazine, Ma encouraged the government to set up direct trade, transport and postal links with China as soon as possible, to help Taipei develop into a business operation center in the Asia-Pacific region for foreign investors and an international business operations hub for Taiwan businessmen.

Once direct three links are established between Taipei and Shanghai, businessmen will be able to travel between the two sides in one day and Taiwan will be given a boost to turn the city into a hub for the entertainment business and the publishing and manufacturing industries in East Asia, thanks to Taiwan's central location in the region, according to Ma.

He also delivered a report on the city's present development and its prospects, pointing out that the municipal authorities have created many business opportunities through cost-effective build-operate-transfer (BOT) joint ventures with the private sector.

According to Ma, the Neihu technology park racked up an annual revenue of more than NT$1.67 trillion (US$53.53 billion) in 2003, while the figure for 2004 is expected to reach NT$1.5 trillion, a level that has exceeded the scale of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- Taiwan's most representative facility for hi-tech companies.

The Taipei City Government has a plan to develop a hi-tech corridor along the Keelung river and to further promote cultural activities, he said, adding that around 2,600 booths will be added to an exhibition hall in the Nankang software park next year to attract a larger number of foreign businessmen.

Meanwhile, Taipei is continuing to expand its mass rapid transit system and improving its sewerage system, Ma said, voicing the hope of making the city a free-travel space in which citizens and visitors can easily get to any corner via public transport, and a wireless communication network with 10,000 service spots through which users can connect to the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS EXPRESSES CONCERN ON TAIWAN FLOODING

TEXT.P: The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) expressed concern Wednesday over the recent heavy flooding in southern Taiwan.

In a letter to its Taiwan counterpart -- the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- ARATS officials said they were informed by the media that people in southern Taiwan were suffering from torrential rain that has claimed the lives of several people and caused heavy agricultural losses.
ARATS officials expressed hope that people living in affected areas can weather the disaster.
The SEF sent a letter to the ARATS June 7 expressing its sympathy on the tremendous human and property losses suffered in China's 16 provinces and cities due to heavy flooding.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS TO FILE FOR CGJ RULING OVER OMBUDSMEN APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will file for a Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) judgment on the constitutionality of the legislature's refusal to screen a Control Yuan nomination list, a caucus whip said Wednesday.

"The application will be filed Thursday, " William Lai said, adding that the CGJ will be asked to judge whether the opposition-controlled Legislative Procedure Committee is eligible to block a bill from being placed on the legislative agenda without any "legitimate" reasons.

President Chen Shui-bian referred a list of nominees for the 29 Control Yuan seats, including the supreme watchdog body's presidency and vice presidency, late last year. The list has so far not been discussed at the legislative floor because the Legislative Procedure Committee has refused to put it on the legislative agenda.
Lai said the legislature's powers should rest in its plenary session, not any auxiliary committees like the Procedure Committee.

If the Procedure Committee is allowed to "randomly" block a bill from being put on the legislative agenda, Lai said, it is tantamount to allowing the committee to usurp the powers and functions of the legislative plenary session.

"By refusing to put a bill on the legislative work agenda, the Procedure Committee has actually deprived legislators who do not sit on the Procedure Committee of the right to exchange their views about the bill at the legislative plenary session, " Lai said, adding that such a practice would lead to the manipulation of legislative operations by a few lawmakers and eventually result in an erosion of the power of the legislature.
Due to the opposition-controlled legislature's boycott, the Control Yuan has been moribund since the six-year tenure of the previous Control Yuan members expired Jan. 31.

Without new ombudsmen, Lai said the public cannot receive timely assistance from the Control Yuan when they file petitions. According to Lai, the Control Yuan has received more than 4,000 appeals in the past four months, but no ombudsmen are available to handle them, undermining the rights of the people.

Under the current political system, Lai said, Control Yuan members are also required to monitor national examinations. "Their absence has affected the rights of a number of participants in various national examinations," he added.

With the aim of safeguarding the nation's constitutional order, Lai said the DPP legislative caucus was forced to seek a CGJ ruling on the constitutionality of the Procedure Committee's repeated rejection of the Control Yuan nomination list.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Demand for Natural Gas Brings Big Import Plans, and Objections.
Just as the 19th century was shaped by coal and the 20th century by oil, people in the energy industry say, this century will belong to natural gas. International energy companies, the Bush administration and governments in gas-rich countries are aggressively championing the creation of a global market for natural gas, with the United States at its center as the largest importer. They are promoting the fuel as more plentiful and less polluting than oil and needed to sustain economic growth. While the United States is already running low on its own production of natural gas and need to import. Competition for gas projects has prompted a frenetic race among international oil companies. However, officials in some states where energy companies plan to build terminals that would receive the gas tankers - including Alabama, California, Maine, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York and Rhode Island - say they could fall victim to a catastrophic explosion, either accidental or set by terrorists.
Wall Street Journal: Fast-Aging Japan Keeps Its Elders On the Job Longer.
With Japan's birth rate declining fast for decades, the pool of young workers was shrinking. Some manufacturers tried out a source of labor it had never considered before: the elderly. These manufacturers are dealing with a problem that's just starting to sweep the world -- an aging population combined with a shrinking work force. The problem is unprecedented in modern times, and its most predictable effect would be to sap economic growth: If a country's work force declines and higher production per worker doesn't make up for this, its economy will shrink. Though Japan will run into this quagmire first, other nations are going to have to deal with it soon as well. Unlike the U.S., Japan is reluctant to rely on large-scale immigration to bolster the work force. Instead, it is trying another strategy: enticing the elderly to work longer before receiving retirement benefits, effectively dealing with old age by making it start later.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMANY TO TRIAL IMPORT SELECT TAIWAN FRUITS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will send a sample shipment of produce to Germany June 16 which will include papayas, pineapples, lychees, mangoes, limes and guavas, an official of the Kaohsiung Agricultural Development Company said Wednesday.
It is the first such shipment to Germany by the development company, which mostly deals with orders from Hong Kong, the United States, Canada and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY PLEDGES TO PROTECT TAIWANESE FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Ministry of National Defense (MND) officials said Wednesday the military will cooperate with the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) to protect Taiwanese fishermen based on what they called a "non-provocation principle."
They pointed out that maintaining sea traffic order and protecting fishery activities are mainly the duties of the CGA and that the navy plays only a backup role in this regard.

While the CGA dispatched six patrol boats to support Taiwanese fishermen during a conflict June 9 with Japanese authorities in a disputed part of the East China Sea following the latest expulsion of fishermen from the area, the navy did not step in because the CGA did not ask, they explained.
According to navy official Lee Hao, two Knox-class frigates were on standby 25 nautical miles off the coast on that day and could have reached the scene in one hour if necessary.
In addition, three Jin Chiang-class vessels were also available in Keelung and could have provided rapid backup, Lee said.

Ministry officials said naval forces are responsible for assisting the CGA with the protection of Taiwanese fishermen and that the navy also assigns three battleships, six complementary frigates and two anti-submarine planes to patrol in specific areas on a daily basis to protect the security of the country's territorial waters.
The patrol scope of the navy's battleships extends beyond 60 nautical miles from the coast, they said.
However, they continued, it is not appropriate for the military to position itself on the frontline of international fishery disputes because this could easily lead to military conflict.

Earlier in the day, opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang requested that the military send a Knox-class frigate to accompany him on a fact-finding trip to an area near the disputed waters June 17 to flex Taiwan's muscle against Japan. The MND brushed aside his request.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV MOST TRUSTWORTHY MEDIA IN TAIWAN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Television tops the five major media branches in terms of access, importance, news sources and credibility among the public, according to the results of a survey conducted by a local university and released Wednesday.
The survey was conducted by Shih Hsin University, targeting the television, newspaper, Internet, magazine and broadcast media.
The survey found that the public trust television most (78 percent) , followed by newspapers (63 percent) , the Internet (48 percent), radio (43 percent) and magazines (40 percent).
In terms of importance, television topped 0 he results at 87.8 percent, followed by newspapers (69.7 percent) , the Internet (55.2 percent), radio (49.7 percent) and magazines (45.6 percent).

In terms of access, most people watch television (91 percent) , followed by reading newspapers (68.9 percent) , surfing the Internet (59.3 percent) and reading magazines (48 percent) . Radio was at the bottom at 46.2 percent, the survey found.
In terms of news resources, television was top again at 71 percent, followed by newspapers at 14.7 percent, the Internet at 7 percent, mouth-to-mouth communication and radio at 2 percent each.
Only 0.2 percent described magazines as a major news source.
The survey was conducted at random among 1,100 people aged 15-64 around the island, with a margin of error of 2.95 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA ONLY PART OF TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURAL PRODUCE MARKET: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian noted Wednesday that China is only part of the global marketing strategy for Taiwan's agricultural produce.
Chen made the remarks while attending a ceremony held at the Council of Agriculture (COA) to mark the first shipment of Taiwan papayas to Japan.
Chen said the government's attitude toward agricultural produce exports to China will comprise "one principle and three arrangements."
He said the government will promote agricultural exports not only to China but also to other parts of the world.

He also said the first arrangement will be that the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will be designated as a window integrating the exports, while local farmers' associations will coordinate in supplying produce, with TAITRA in charge of global marketing.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , the COA and related government agencies will also form negotiation teams and commission TAITRA to assist them in consulting with China on matters related to quarantine, tariffs, inspection and customs clearance for agricultural produce.

To ensure the quality of Taiwan's high-priced fresh fruit and speedy transportation, Chen said that it is necessary to speed up direct cross-strait charter cargo flights based on the "two-way and non-stop" formula of Chinese New Year charter flights for Taiwan businessmen operating in China.

He pointed out that in the wake of China's recent announcement that it will impose zero tariffs on some Taiwan fruit, the issue has become a hot topic, although many discussions have not been from the economic and agricultural perspective but mere political rhetoric.

He cited COA statistics showing that Taiwan exported only US$890,000-worth of fresh fruit to China last year. If exports to Hong Kong were also included, the amount would come to US$7.54 million, or only 1.78 percent of Taiwan's total production value.

In terms of volume, fresh fruit to China amounted to only 629 tons, although if exports to Hong Kong were included, it would amount to 16,000 tons, still only 0.6 percent of Taiwan's total production.
In terms of export price per kilo, Taiwan mangoes exported to Japan averaged US$3.97 per kilo, compared with only US$0.72 to China.
"Viewed from every angle, one can see that the importance of the China market for Taiwan agricultural produce is quite limited, " Chen said.

He said that because of China's deliberate manipulation and "some Taiwanese political figures singing duets" with Beijing's leaders, the potential of the China market has been exaggerated, which he claimed is not only misleading but could also disrupt Taiwan's efforts to transform and upgrade its agriculture.
If Taiwan's agriculture wants to shine in the world, it has to pursue "four highs" -- high quality, high value-added, high price and high return agriculture, he said.
A sharp increase of low- and medium-priced agricultural produce to China could be a "short-term plus, but a long-term minus" to the long-term development of Taiwan's agriculture, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERY TALKS WITH JAPAN IN PIPELINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to start fishery talks with Japan soon and the controversy over the overlapping of bilateral economic zones will be raised, an Executive Yuan spokesman said Wednesday.

Cho Jung-tai urged fishermen who are angry at being chased out of their traditional fishing grounds northeast of Taiwan by Japanese patrol vessels to refrain from violent responses and rally behind the government when it is dealing with Japan.

His statement was in line with Premier Frank Hsieh's earlier assertion that his administration will do "whatever it takes" to defend the country's economic waters and to ensure fishermen's rights to operate.

Meanwhile, an official from the Fishery Bureau under the Council of Agriculture said a consensus has taken shape in previous fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan on the necessity for demarcation of their economic zones.
This consensus will serve as a basis for the upcoming fishery talks which will be the 15th of their kind, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL MARKETS OPEN TO TAIWAN PRODUCE IF QUALITY IS HIGH: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: All global markets are open to Taiwan produce if they are of superior quality, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.
Chen made the remarks after viewing the documentary film, "Let It Be, " which analyzes the impact on Taiwan's farmers after the country entered the World Trade Organization in 2002.
Although hailing the decades-long contribution of farmers to Taiwan's economy, Chen stressed that new strategies are needed in this era of globalization.

"Taiwan is an island country, and we cannot cut ourselves off from outside world, " Chen said, adding that being a member of the WTO means that Taiwan's markets are now open to the world and vice versa.
Noting that Taiwan's global agricultural exports were US$3.5 billion last year, Chen said that exporters have nothing to fear as long as their products are of high quality.
Citing the example of Taiwan mangoes, which are selling in Japan at US$4 per kilo, Chen said that Japan, the United States and Singapore are solid markets for locally grown produce.
Chen told domestic farmers that the government will listen carefully to their opinions, and he urged them come forth unabashedly to say what is on their mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WITNESSES CEREMONY OF PAPAYA EXPORTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan papayas entering the Japanese market shows that Taiwan can sell its produce to any country in the world.

Chen made the remarks when attending a ceremony sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) at its headquarters to mark the sale of Taiwan papayas in Japan -- one of the most stringent and quality conscious markets in the world -- after eight years of negotiations.
Papayas from Taiwan were not allowed to enter the Japanese market in the past due to the fact that domestically planted papayas were plagued by a parasitic insect.

But Japan eventually decided last December to permit imports from Taiwan that are treated with insecticide at home after Taiwan authorities proved that they had been successful in developing a new quarantine technique.
Japanese buyers ordered 500 metric tons of Taiwan papayas valued at NT$65 million (US$2.1 million) for the whole of this year as the peak production season approaches in Taiwan.

Describing Japan as a major barometer for the quality of fruits and vegetables from Taiwan, the president asserted that the quality, flavor, sanitation and safety of domestically grown produce has reached international standards.

As long as Taiwan is able to sell its products to Japan, it means that Taiwan can market its goods in any country across the world, Chen said, stressing that Taiwan farmers must upgrade and transform to overcome the impact of the domestic market opening to foreign competition following Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2002.
Chen proposed that Taiwan's agriculture sector target both the domestic and overseas markets to widen its profits.
During the ceremony, a Taiwan farmer presented a basket of papayas to the president, and a Japanese executive handed him a copy of the purchase order from Japan.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung said that his council is doing its utmost to help Taiwan growers of guavas, bell fruits and grapefruits to meet Japanese quarantine requirements in the hope of exploring new markets for Taiwan's produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER ASKS HON HAI TO REVEAL FINANCIAL STATEMENTS FOR TAX PURPOSES

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. Chairman Terry Kuo should follow the lead of such prestigious American companies as IBM and Intel to make public his company's earnings and tax returns annually, a lawmaker said Wednesday.

William Lai, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , made the call after Kuo criticized the DPP administration's plan to implement a system whereby each taxpayer, including the very wealthy, would have to pay a certain established percent of their income so that loopholes for the rich can be closed.

Kuo was quoted as having said at a Hon Hai shareholders' meeting earlier this week that the government should mull how to enhance administrative efficiency instead of just considering how to levy more taxes on rich people.
"Being rich is not a sin, " Kuo was quoted as having said, adding that if the government divides the people into rich and poor categories, the result would be something like a communist regime.
Commenting on Kuo's remarks, Lai said the proposed "minimum" tax measure is mainly aimed at making the nation's tax system fairer and more reasonable.
In recent years, Lai said, 75 percent of income tax revenues have come from wage earners with a few high-tech industries enjoying significant exemptions and deductions.
Quoting finance ministry data, Lai said eight of the nation's 40 richest people didn't pay one NT dollar of income tax last year, and 15 others paid less than 1 percent of their annual income.

"The proposed 'minimum' tax scheme should correct this unfair and unjust practice in line with the principle of social justice, " Lai said, adding that the planned tax reform would not require rich people like Kuo to pay more taxes than others but would only require the rich to pay a reasonable percentage of what they earn.
Noting that many noted American companies, such as IBM and Intel, have made public their earnings and tax payments annually, Lai said he hopes Kuo can follow such a good example.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WON'T ENCOURAGE TAIWAN CITIZENS TO WORK IN CHINA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government will not encourage local citizens to find jobs in China, a senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Wednesday.

Fu Don-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, made the remarks after Beijing official announced earlier in the day that Chinese authorities are working on law revisions to offer easier access for Taiwan people to the Chinese job market.

The Chinese official said China will ease restrictions on the conditions or qualifications for Taiwan people to land jobs and that red tape will also be cut for Taiwanese job applicants. The new measures are scheduled to come into effect Oct. 1.

Fu said the MAC has yet to fully understand the motivation behind China's decision to open its job market to Taiwan people. But anyway, he said, the government does not encourage local citizens to take jobs in China.
"The government has consistently spared no efforts to retain talent at home," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EACH CHINESE TOURIST WILL CREATE TWO JOB OPPORTUNITES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The entry of 365,000 mainland Chinese visitors to Taiwan a year is expected to create some 700,000 jobs in the country, secretary-general Hsu Kao-ching of the Travel Agents Association of the Republic of China said Wednesday.

Hsu made the estimate in response to China's offer to lift the ban on its citizens coming to sightsee in Taiwan, and the estimate was made based on the ROC Cabinet's plan to allow 1,000 Chinese tourists into Taiwan each day.

Judging from the increase of air flights, hotel personnel, travel buses, restaurants, entertainment parks, tourist agencies and tour guides resulting from the visits of mainland travelers, Hsu estimated that each mainland tourist could equate to two job opportunities for Taiwanese.
Meanwhile, a survey from Manpower Taiwan showed that the service industry will be the booming sector for personnel demand in the third quarter of this year.

Among the industry, almost 70 percent of local tourist enterprises need new employees, which also means more opportunities for people working in air transport companies, restaurants and entertainment parks.
The number of overseas visits by Taiwan people is estimated to top eight million this year, while the number of visits by foreigners to Taiwan will reach 3.2 million, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SITS THE FENCE ON ABORIGINAL PROTESTS AT YASUKUNI SHRINE

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese aboriginal legislator had the right to try to protest at Japan's controversial Yasukuni Shrine Tuesday, and it was the prerogative of the Japanese police to stop them, Premier Frank Hsieh said in Kaohsiung Wednesday.

The premier was commenting on aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei's attempt to bring back the tablets of the deceased Taiwan aboriginal conscripts who died fighting for the Japanese Imperial Army in World War II from the temple dedicated to Japanese war dead.
Kao Chin asked authorities in Taiwan on Wednesday to complain to the Japanese for the "rude treatment" that her group received at the shrine the previous day.
Hsieh was in Kaohsiung inspecting the damage caused by torrential rains that drenched the area over the last four days when he remarked on the incident.

Kao Chin and her followers, mostly aborigines, claimed that the aborigines who are listed in the shrine were forced to serve in the Japanese Imperial Army against their will when Taiwan was ruled by Japan. She said it is disgraceful for Taiwan aborigines to have their ancestors honored in a temple set up by a country that invaded Taiwan.

A number of countries in Asia consider the Yasukuni Shrine a testament to past Japanese imperialism and it is controversial because 14 class A war criminals were included in 1978 among the 2.5 million people enshrined at Yasukuni. Compounding the matter is the fact that various Japanese leaders, including numerous Japanese prime ministers, have gone to the shrine to pay homage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSPECTS PINGTUNG AMID FLOODING, PROMISES MONETARY AID

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh toured flood devastation in southern Pingtung County Wednesday and said that if a flood-control project is approved by the Legislative Yuan, the situation will improve in the coming years.

Hsieh was briefed by county officials at the hardest hit Shinyuan township on the worst inundation in 30 years in southern Taiwan. He was accompanied by Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan and officials from other government agencies.

Hsieh promised to fully finance local flood-control projects over the next three years with a central government, eight-year, flood-control program worth NT$80 billion (US$2.6 billion) after various township chiefs decried local authorities' failure to finish the construction of a revetment along the Tungkang Stream because the central government budget had run dry.

According to Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, 136 colleges and elementary and middle schools in southern Taiwan have closed due to the heavy rainfall brought by a front which is still lingering in the region.

Tu expressed grave concern over the possibility of serious mudslides and rock slides if the front moves northward to Nantou and Taichung counties, which were devastated by the Sept. 21 earthquake in 1999 -- the worst quake to hit Taiwan in a century.
The education ministry will closely monitor the situation in central Taiwan and offer assistance to local schools to help protect students, Tu said.

Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) showed that as of Wednesday evening, losses in the agricultural, fishing and farming sectors in central and southern Taiwan amounted to NT$652 million (US$20.9 million) , with Tainan, Pingtung and Kaohsiung counties suffering the most damage.
At least five people have been killed in the flooding.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS NOT TO COMPROMISE ON FISHING RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday the government is firm on protecting local fishermen's rights and safety in the nation's exclusive economic zone.

Hsieh made the remarks after some critics accused the government of failing to effectively protect local fishermen from being chasing by Japanese patrol ships from a disputed part of the East China Sea near the Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.
Hsieh said the government's determination to protect local fishermen's rights and safety is beyond question.
"The government will never evade its duty of protecting our fishermen's rights and safety as well as defending our national sovereignty and exclusive economic zone," Hsieh said.

Meanwhile, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Shu Hwei-you said the administration has sent large patrol ships to police a temporarily demarcated divide line which was agreed upon in previous rounds of talks with Japan.

"The CGA patrol ships have consistently done their utmost to protect local fishing boats operating within that line. Before we reach a final agreement with Japan over the disputed overlapping parts of the two countries' economic zones, local fishing boats should refrain from operating beyond the temporary demarcation line to avoid unnecessary risks," Shu said.

Quoting tallies compiled by the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency, Shu said only 11 Taiwan fishing boats have been impounded by Japanese coast guard patrol vessels since 2000, while 38 Chinese fishing boats and 102 South Korean fishing ships have been impounded by Japan during the same period.
According to CGA investigations, Shu said all of the 11 Taiwan ships were impounded while operating in waters outside the temporary demarcation line.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO PRESENT 7 DRAFT BILLS TO LEGISLATIVE YUAN'S EXTRA SESSION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet has drawn up seven priority draft bills to be presented to an extra session of the Legislative Yuan for screening, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Cho Jung-tai said that the seven draft bills include a special budget for a flood-control project, the endorsement of nominees for the Control Yuan, upping the excise tax on tobacco products, a major arms procurement, the amendment to the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan, the disposition of wireless television station shares held by the government and the regulations on digital wireless television development.
Cho urged Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to help the Executive Yuan push the bills through the legislature for the sake of the national interest and the people.
The Cabinet has asked the Legislative Yuan to hold an extraordinary session in late July to screen urgent bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CALLS CHINA'S RESPONSE TO ITS INITIATIVES 'FRIENDLY'

TEXT.P: Taiwan considers China's response to its initiatives for bilateral talks on two issues "friendly," Cho Jung-tai, the spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Cho said Beijing didn't turn down Taiwan's initiatives out of hand; that means the two private organizations asked by the Taiwan authorities to negotiate with Beijing on two different issues may now approach their Chinese counterparts.

Premier Frank Hsieh said on Monday that his administration has asked the Taipei Airlines Association and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to talk with Beijing on possible direct charter cargo flights between the two sides and the export of Taiwan's fruits to the mainland.
The two private groups were asked to act on behalf of the government because of Beijing's refusal to have any official contacts with Taiwan, which would lend credit to Taiwan's claim to be a state.

A Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs said earlier that day in Beijing that China would like to exchange views with Taiwan on charter cargo flights although it believes that direct passenger flights are more urgently needed.
As to the negotiations on import of Taiwan fruits, the official said Beijing prefers to talk with the Taiwan Farmers' Association.
Cho said TAITRA, which has succeeded in selling the first batch of 500 tons of Taiwan papaya to Japan Wednesday, is capable of marketing Taiwan's agriculture products.
The premier also promised on Monday to pick appropriate private group to talk with China on the issue of allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MONGOLIA ECONOMIC MEETING HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-Mongolia economic meeting was held Wednesday in Taipei with some 100 business leaders from the two countries participating.

The fourth joint meeting of the Mongolian National Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MNCCI) and the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) was jointly presided over by MNCCI President S. Demberel and Chao Yung-chuan, chairman of the CIECA's Mongolia Committee who doubles as secretary general of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council.
Huang Hua, president of the Taiwan-Mongolia Exchange Association, and Dagva Batmunkh, representative of the Ulaanbaatar Economic Office in Taipei, were invited to address the opening ceremony.

During the meeting, the participants discussed on the economic situation of Mongolia and the role that Taiwan businessmen can play in the Mongolia economic development, the bilateral trade potential, policies and incentives for foreign investment in Mongolia and the investment opportunities in Mongolia for Taiwan businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 16, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: American comedian Stan Laurel is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of the talking film era. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: China's Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at China's Whampoa Military Academy, presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling America's severe economic problems.
1941: Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided to the Republic of China by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad Ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, a British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.
1972: Guatemalan President Carlos Arana Osorio arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Gen. John W. Voge Jr., commander-in-chief of the U.S. Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: China Airlines inaugurates a Boeing 747 jumbo jet service to Los Angeles.
1976: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo inspects cadets of the Military Academy on its 52nd anniversary.
1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, a German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the U.S. Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.
1982: The 11-member ROC Goodwill Mission of Mayors, led by Mayor Jackson C.T. Yang of Taipei, leaves for a 20-day visit to the United States.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of regulations governing foreign exchange, authorizing the Executive Yuan to suspend all foreign exchange controls. Resumption of controls would require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin agree in a summit meeting in Washington to slash their strategic weapons arsenals by about two-thirds by 2003.
1999: Thabo Mbeki becomes president of South Africa, succeeding Nelson Mandela.
2000: A new shortened work-week program, allowing Taiwan's workers and employers to work 84 hours every two weeks instead of the former 96 hours, is passed overwhelmingly at the legislature.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."
