DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DONATES NT$1 MILLION TO HELP FLOOD VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui donated NT$1 million (US$31,847) Thursday to help people affected by the recent flooding in southern Taiwan.
Su Chin-chiang, chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), said Lee, the TSU's spiritual leader, has also directed the TSU to do whatever it can to assist in post-disaster relief work.
Su said the TSU's headquarters and its southern Taiwan office will also donate NT$1 million each for post-flooding aid programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: USING TECHNOLOGICAL POWER TO MAINTAIN TAIWAN STRAIT PEACE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he is hopeful that science and technology can bring new vitality to Taiwan's economy and become the buttress for its national security.
Chen made the remarks at a meeting of the Presidential Office's Science and Technology Advisory Commission.

Noting that science and technology has been the driving force behind economic development, Chen said progress in the science and technology field has helped Taiwan ward off a possible industrial hollowing-out in the face of economic globalization and China's "magnetic effect" in attracting foreign investment.

In the future, Chen said, Taiwan should devote even more efforts to science and technology development because achievements in this field can serve as ammunition to break the China-imposed diplomatic embargo and to better safeguard peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
"We should use technological power to defend regional peace, stability and prosperity," Chen said.

He asked members of the advisory commission to offer counseling on how to boost self-sufficiency in national defense technology, encourage industrial technological innovation, establish world-class brands and construct an index park for creative industries.

The president also urged all science and technology advisory panelists to present counseling on measures to cope with the possible impact on future industrial development of the Kyoto Protocol, a multilateral agreement on reducing greenhouse gas emmissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Lakers Turn to Hire Power. Phil Jackson stepped back into the Laker soap opera, agreeing to return after a year's hiatus in which he caught lobsters off the coast of Australia, built a lakefront home in Montana and wrote a memoir in which he bared his ill feelings about the organization that dumped him.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO STUDY STRATEGY IN FISHERY TALKS WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: Related government agencies will convene a coordination meeting soon to study its strategy in the upcoming negotiations and how best to protect fishermen's interests, a spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
Michel Lu said that the time of the 15th Taiwan-Japan fishery talks will be announced.
Lu made the remarks after Japanese government agreed to convene a new round of fishery talks with Taiwan over disputes resulting from overlapping economic zones between the two countries,

MOFA officials noted that four Taiwanese fishing ships were operating in waters off northeastern Taiwan within the legal boundary set by the government June 8 when they were chased away by Japanese patrol ships. Around 50 Taiwan fishing ships later converged in the nearby waters to stage a protest against Japanese patrol boats.

The ministry lodged a serious protest June 8. The following day, the Republic of China deputy representative to Japan, Chen Hung-chi, delivered a letter of protest to the Interchange Association, which represents the interests of Japan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries, and ROC Representative Koh Se-kai also expressed the government's stance to the Interchange Association that evening, the officials said.

The Interchange Association conveyed the protest to the Japanese government, and Japan agreed to handle the fishery disputes in a peaceful and rational way and instructed its patrol boats to exercise caution so as not to heighten tensions and to avoid conformation.
At issue was the formulation of a Japanese law regarding its exclusive economic zone and continental shelf in 1996, which includes part of Taiwan in its 200-mile economic zone.

Because of complaints by Taiwan about the "unreasonable" demarcation, the two countries began negotiations in 1996. A total of 14 rounds of fishery negotiations have been conducted as of the end of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times:Older laid-off workers get jobs faster.
Older retrenched workers are finding it easier to land jobs, and even nudging ahead of younger ones in getting re-employed. The latest employment figures charted this trend, prompting questions on whether it signals a real change in attitudes of employers and other workers or is just a temporary blip. Still, their better showing pulled re-employment levels to an 18-month high, with 68 percent of workers laid off in the last quarter of 2004 finding new jobs within six months. The figure for the previous quarter was 57 percent.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Nearly 70% of laid-off workers get jobs in six months.
The re-employment rate of laid-off workers in the first three months of this year is 68%. This rate was the highest in over a year. This was mainly due to an improvement in the re-hiring of mature workers, according to the Manpower Ministry's Labour Market First Quarter Report.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Transneft Accused of Illegal Logging.
The government body overseeing the use of natural resources said Wednesday it was demanding a criminal investigation into what it says is illegal logging in protected forests around Lake Baikal ordered by Transneft, the state-owned oil pipeline monopoly. The logging is part of survey work by Transneft for the construction of an oil pipeline designed to connect largely untapped eastern Siberian oil fields with Russia's Pacific coast. Transneft on Wednesday denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Indon, Gambia Presidents arriving.
Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono is arriving in Manila on Monday afternoon for a two-aday state visit to boost economic and security relations with the Philippine government, Malacanang announced yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: House asks Arroyo: Comment on tape.
THE SCANDAL of the tape yesterday went into higher gear with the House of Representatives, the religious and youth sectors, and retired military officials beefing up the clamor for President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo to speak up on the matter.
The Philippine Star: House panels to GMA, Garci: Are you the ones on tape?
Five House committees tasked to look into the controversial Arroyo tapes voted yesterday to ask President Arroyo and Commissioner Virgilio Garcillano of the Commission on Elections (Comelec) to confirm or deny if they were the ones heard on recordings talking about rigging the results of the May 2004 elections.
The Manila Times: House to question GMA on wiretaps.
President Arroyo, her husband, Jose Miguel "Mike"Arroyo, and other personalities who were allegedly tapped discussing plans to rig the election last year will be asked to confirm or deny if the recorded voices are indeed theirs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER REAFFIRMS MILITARY'S COMMITMENT TO PROTECT FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: The military will continue to support the Coast Guard Administration's (CGA's) efforts to protect Taiwanese fishermen and will respond immediately to any situations requiring military backup, National Defense Minister Lee Jye said Thursday.
Lee said the Ministry of National Defense will focus its work on maintaining security on the seas and will dispatch monitoring naval frigates to operate within sight of the fishermen in the future.

Lee pointed out that the responsibility of protecting fishermen was transferred from the Navy to the CGA in 2000 and that the military is now in charge of monitoring and providing backup if necessary.

During last week's confrontations between Taiwanese fishermen and the Japanese coast guard in a disputed part of the East China Sea where the exclusive economic zones of the two countries overlap, the Navy was instructed to make the necessary preparations and dispatched two frigates to nearby waters to monitor the situation there, Lee said.
The minister made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan, where he met with speaker Wang Jin-pyng to discuss the issue of fishermen's protection.

Also at the meeting, CGA Director-General Shi Hwei-yow said the CGA will definitely protect the fishermen if they are operating within the tentative line dividing the two countries' overlapping economic zones.
If the fishermen plan to operate beyond this line, they can apply for CGA protection and escort through a fishermen's association, Shi said.

However, Shi pointed out that the CGA currently only owns 186 patrol ships, with only 13 of these being large-size vessels, which he said is hardly enough to cope with the CGA's law-enforcement missions in territorial waters extending 540,000 square kilometers.

Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau pointed out that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has asked Japan to arrange for the 15th round of bilateral fishery talks as soon as possible, which he said hopefully can take place some time between late June and early July.
Kau said the ministry also hopes that higher level officials will be allowed to take part in the talks and that he himself will participate if necessary.

Before beginning the talks, the ministry will meet with representatives of related authorities, fishermen's associations and the legislature to gather their opinions, he said, adding that the ministry will take a firm stand to protect the rights and interests of Taiwanese fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG, MA TO HOLD TELEVISED PLATFORM PRESENTATIONS ON KMT CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, both vice chairmen of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), will hold two televised platform presentations next month to explain how they would lead the party if elected chairman, an aide of Ma said Thursday.
KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng, one of Ma's chief campaign aides, made the remarks after agreeing on the terms of the presentations the same day with representatives of Wang's camp at KMT headquarters.

There will be no debating or question-and-answer sections during their encounters on television, although Ma had hoped to be able to debate with Wang to allow KMT members to gain a detailed understanding of their ideas, Wu said.

According to Wu, the two sides agreed to hold two televised platform presentations July 2 and July 9, in which each Ma and Wang will be given an hour to elaborate on their policies and how to guide the party if elected. The vote for chairman will be made through a direct vote among party members and is set for July 16.

There will be more than 580 polling stations for KMT members to cast their ballots, Wu said. The winner will take over the post from incumbent Chairman Lien Chan, who is slated to step down in August.
Meanwhile, Wang launched a new publicity campaign targeting around 180,000 members of the KMT's Huangfushing Chapter -- most of whom are retired military veterans and their families.

A new booklet that Wang said he will mail to every Huangfushing member stresses Wang's firm stance against Taiwan independence and his opposition to a change of Taiwan's official designation of the Republic of China and to the abolishment of the ROC Constitution.

Wang told a group of reporters that he must make his stance clearly known to the rest of the KMT members in the face of rampant speculation over his links to former President Lee Teng-hui, who also served as a KMT chairman but who now is the spiritual leader of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS URGES EARLY CROSS-STRAIT TALKS ON DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus on Thursday called for the government to engage in early talks with China on cross-strait charter cargo and passenger flights.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of KMT's Policy Committee and KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao made the appeal one day after a spokesman of the Taiwan Affairs Office said in Beijing that Taiwan should agree to designate private organizations to communicate and arrange for direct cross-strait charter passenger flights. China is also willing to exchange views on cross-strait charter cargo flights, the spokesman added.

Tseng said that since President Chen Shui-bian first came to power in 2000, he has made direct cross-strait transportation links a major policy goal, but he has been unable to make headway on the issue.

Now that governments of both sides of the Strait have extended goodwill toward each other, the government on Taiwan should seize the opportunity to bring about cross-strait charter passenger and cargo flights, Tseng said.

Using three million visits across the Taiwan Strait each year as an estimate, Tseng said that direct passenger flights could save NT$50 billion (US$1.58 billion) , while charter cargo flights could save NT$30 billion each year.
In addition to direct transportation links, Tseng also urged early cross-strait talks on matters concerning Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan and Taiwan fruit exports to China.
Meanwhile, a KMT spokesman said Thursday the party hopes that cross-strait charter passenger and cargo flights will not only be a slogan, but will be translated into action.

Chang Jung-kung said that China favors cross-strait charter passenger flights, while Taiwan has put the emphasis on charter cargo flights, and if both sides stick to their guns, then consultations will not be possible.
Saying that KMT Chairman Lien Chan has advocated direct cross-strait charter passenger and cargo flights, he said that the party is willing to help promote the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 30.31 points to close at 6,282.41.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,298.35 and hit a low of 6,249 during trading. A total of 3.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$82.16 billion (US$2.61 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent, cement stocks and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.1 percent.

Three of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 492 to 345, with 163 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES OPPOSITION TO SUPPORT SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers called on opposition parties on Thursday to support the party's proposal to hold a special legislative session in late July to review several priority items including an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project.

The DPP also hopes to put on the agenda the budget for a NT$480 billion arms procurement package from the United States, Control Yuan nominations and proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, pointed out that the flood-control project was put forth by Premier Frank Hsieh soon after his inauguration in February and is not targeted only at the recent flooding in southern Taiwan.
The project is aimed at resolving the flooding problem at the source by improving regional flood-prevention facilities, Chao said.

Taking the opportunity of the recent flooding, Hsieh repeated a day earlier his call for the legislature to hold a special session to pass the special statute so that the project could start in January next year.

However, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng has expressed his disapproval of Hsieh's proposal and said there is still at least NT$19.3 billion at the Cabinet's disposal for flood aid and prevention.
Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party have also objected the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: House Votes To Curb Patriot Act; FBI's Power to Seize Library Records Would Be Halted.
The House handed President Bush the first defeat in his effort to preserve the broad powers of the USA Patriot Act, voting yesterday to curtail the FBI's ability to seize library and bookstore records for terrorism investigations, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 32 points to close at 6,180, with 33,246 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August moved up 21 points to end at 6,120, with 698 contracts traded, while September futures gained 31 points to finish at 6,087, with 471 contracts traded. December futures moved up 25 points to close at 6,080, with four contracts traded, while March futures moved up 20 points to close at 6,070, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,148 for July, 6,099 for August, 6,056 for September, 6,055 for December and 6,050 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

July TE futures moved up 1.75 points to close at 252.9, with 5,521 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 1.25 points to finish at 250.8, with 117 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 1.55 points to end at 249.5, with nine contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 1.9 points to close at 245.05, with one contract traded. March TE future lost 0.85 points to end at 245.65, with one contract transaction.

July TF futures lost 0.4 points to finish at 950.4, with 2,212 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures moved down 3.2 points to end at 940.8, with 94 contracts traded. September TF futures remained unchanged at 938, with 11 contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 17.2 points to end at 910.2, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.030 to close at NT$31.415.
A total of US$626 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.385 and fluctuated between NT$31.353 and NT$31.415.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TAKE PART IN LICENSING 2005 INTERNATIONAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan is preparing to take part in the Licensing 2005 International, slated to be held in New York June 21-23, to showcase original works done by Taiwan's artists, illustrators, graphic designers and photographers, a source from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

Over 100 pieces of original works will be on display in the Taiwan pavilion, dubbed "Art in Taiwan, " along with 400-odd exhibitors from around the world at the Licensing 2005 International, the 25th of its kind, to be held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York City, said Huang Kuo-chun, director of the MOEA Digital Content Industry Promotion Office.
The "Art in Taiwan" pavilion will feature works from the National Palace Museum, Taiwan classical pieces and works from Taiwan's avant-garde artists, said Huang.

Taking part in the Licensing International exhibition, the largest of its kind in the world -- where consumer product manufacturers and licensees, retailers and marketers come to secure intellectual property rights, forge merchandising and promotional partnerships, and learn about and preview trends that impact consumer spending -- will allow Taiwan artists and designers to showcase their new and existing properties to the thousands of U.S. and international attendees eager for original content.

Taking part in the exhibition, where the Taiwan exhibitors will meet TV programmers, publishers, animators and other content providers from around the world, can also allow Taiwan's artists and designers to learn how licensing and pop culture is reflected in today's marketplace, Huang noted.
The event is also expected to help Taiwan's artists and designers secure business opportunities on a global scale, Huang added.
According to the International Licensing Industry Merchandisers' Association, the global licensing market was worth US$172.70 billion in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: METAL MANUFACTURERS EYE EQUIPMENT FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY

TEXT.P: Metal manufacturers are eager to launch production lines for equipment used in generating electricity from wind power to cash in on the emerging market for renewable energy, according to the Metal Industries Research and Development Center (MIRDC).

MIRDC officials said Thursday that with the Kyoto Protocol having gone into effect in February and which aims to limit the global emission of greenhouse gases, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is adjusting the country's energy structure and promoting actively the development of renewable energy, such as wind, water, solar and geothermal.
Among these, wind power is the one with the largest potential and could account for 35 percent of the total renewable energy of the country in 2010, the officials added.

The MIRDC experts estimated that the domestic demand for equipment used for generating electricity from wind power will reach NT$70 billion (US$2.23 billion) in 2010, and the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau has approved a plan for the promotion of equipment used in generating electricity from renewable energy, with the MIRDC being in charge of the research and development of equipment for wind power.
Due to its complexity and large size, most of the equipment for electricity-generation from wind power is currently imported from abroad, mainly from Denmark and Germany, the officials said.
To reduce dependence on foreign countries, the MIRDC plans to invite domestic machinery and electrical manufacturers to jointly develop related components for this kind of equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIES MADE OF VIETNAM PEANUTS CONTAIN EXCESSIVE AFLATOXINS: DOH

TEXT.P: Several peanut candy products made of Vietnam-exported peanuts have been found to contain excessive amounts of aflatoxins, Department of Health officials said Thursday.

The health department has requested the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to conduct a thorough inspection of peanuts and related products from Vietnam, the officials said.

The health department discovered the problem after a recent survey of 67 peanut candy products sold in Taiwan, five of which were found to contain excessive amounts of aflatoxins, a toxic contamination of mold. In one case, the amount was 34 times above the acceptable level.

According to Chen Shu-kung, head of the health department's Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis, a health department investigation found that all the contaminated products were made from peanuts from Vietnam, which presumably is the source of the contamination.
Chen said all the contaminated candies have been recalled and destroyed and that health authorities will continue to trace other products that might also have been contaminated.
Aflatoxins can cause liver damage in human after long-time consumption and lead to liver cancer or death in the worst case.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET WAITS FOR CHINA'S RESPONSE ON PRODUCE EXPORTS: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that his Cabinet has appointed the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to discuss with China exports of Taiwan's produce, and he hopes that China will respond with goodwill.
Hsieh made the remarks while attending the opening of Food Taipei 2005, an international food exhibition, which will run until June 19.
The premier said that he has faith in the professionalism of TAITRA, and hopes that China can accept it as a contact party so that there will be another outlet for marketing Taiwan's produce.

On China's announcement that it will relax regulations governing the conditions and qualifications of Taiwan residents working in China, he said that the sense of Taiwan's identity will only be higher with increased cross-strait exchanges.

The premier said this is a time when "talented people are looking for the right place to work, " not the other way around, adding that increased cross-strait exchanges will reinforce the people's happiness at being in Taiwan.

On criticism by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) of his proposed eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project, he said that this may be because of some misunderstanding on KMT Chairman Lien Chan's part.
He said he hoped to meet with Lien to explain the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFESSIONAL DELEGATION TO HELP TAIWAN TEXTILE-MAKERS IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: A deluge of low-priced cloth and apparel from China to the rest of the world has affected the textile industry in Africa, and the government will send a professional group to help Taiwan textile makers there overcome their business difficulties, a government official said Thursday.

Wu Teh-yang, deputy director-general of the African Affairs Department under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, told a news conference that a delegation composed of experts recommended by government agencies will visit textile makers from Taiwan operating in Lesotho, Malawi, South Africa and Swaziland in early July and provide them with suggestions on how to take on China's challenge.

According to Wu, the ministry will approve the name list of the specialists to be fielded by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Bureau of Foreign Trade and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council.

The removal of a world quota system on textile products early this year has led to a surge of cheaper textile exports from China to the European Union and the United States -- prompting its two major trading partners to impose limits on Chinese exports.
The textile industry in Africa, where many investors from Taiwan are operating, has also been dealt a blow indirectly, Wu said.

Compared with the E. U. and the U. S., it is much more difficult for African countries to resist the situation due to their more primitive technologies, he explained. But he pointed out that many countries on the continent have begun to address the issue out of a strong fear that foreign investment might flow out of their hard-earned textile industry.
For instance, he said, the South African government has sought to talk over the issue with China after coming under fire from its trade and textile associations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS FILES FOR GRAND JUSTICES' RULING ON OMBUDSMEN APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took the Control Yuan problem to the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) Thursday, asking for a judgment on the constitutionality of the legislature's repeated refusal to screen the president's list of nominees for the supreme watchdog body.
Legislator Chao Yung-ching, who concurrently heads the DPP legislative caucus, filed the petition with the CGJ in the company of several other DPP lawmakers.
Judicial Yuan Secretary-General Fan Kuang-chun said after accepting the petition that the CGJ will give its ruling in accordance with the Constitution.

Chao said the legislative caucuses of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) have abused their majority status in the Legislative Procedure Committee to block the nomination list from being placed on the legislative work agenda for more than half a year.

President Chen Shui-bian referred a list of nominees for the 29 Control Yuan seats, including the supreme watchdog body's presidency and vice presidency, late last year. The list has so far not been discussed at the legislative floor because the Legislative Procedure Committee has refused to put it on the legislative agenda.

"We are forced to file for a CGJ ruling in an effort to safeguard the sanctity of our constitutional order and highlight the absurdity of the opposition-controlled Legislative Procedure Committee's manipulation of legislative operations," Chao said.
DPP Legislator William Lai said the legislature's powers should rest in its plenary session, not any auxiliary committees like the Procedure Committee.

If the Procedure Committee is allowed to "randomly" block a bill from being put on the legislative agenda, Lai said, it is tantamount to allowing the committee to usurp the powers and functions of the legislative plenary session.

"By refusing to put a bill on the legislative work agenda, the Procedure Committee has actually deprived legislators who do not sit on the Procedure Committee of the right to exchange their views about the bill at the legislative plenary session, " Lai said, adding that such a practice would lead to the manipulation of legislative operations by a few lawmakers and eventually result in an erosion of the power of the legislature as well as hindrances to overall government functions.
Due to the opposition-controlled legislature's boycott, the Control Yuan has been moribund since the six-year tenure of the previous Control Yuan members expired Jan. 31.

Without new ombudsmen, Lai said the public cannot receive timely assistance from the Control Yuan when they file petitions. According to Lai, the Control Yuan has received more than 4,000 appeals in the past four months, but no ombudsmen are available to handle them, undermining the rights of the people.

Under the current political system, Lai said, Control Yuan members are also required to monitor national examinations. "Their absence has affected the rights of a number of participants in various national examinations," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS GOVERNMENT'S RESOLVE TO PROTECT FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reaffirmed Thursday the government's resolve to protect Taiwanese fishermen operating in the country's territorial waters.

Hsieh said the government will soon open a new round of fishery talks with Japan to try to resolve the disputes between the two countries, and he urged fishermen to trust the government and avoid any direct confrontation with Japanese authorities.

A group of furious Taiwanese fishermen confronted the Japanese coast guard last week in a disputed part of the East China Sea where the exclusive economic zones of both countries overlap, following the latest expulsion of fishermen from the area.

Earlier in the day, Coast Guard Administration Director-General Shi Hwei-yow pledged that the coast guard would protect the fishermen if they are operating within the tentative line dividing the two countries' overlapping economic zones.
If the fishermen plan to operate beyond this line, they can apply for coast guard protection and escort through a fishermen's association, Shi said.
Also, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said the military will support the coast guard's efforts to protect the fishermen and will respond immediately to any situations requiring military backup.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES DOMESTIC ENTERPRISES TO FIND OWN COMPETITIVE EDGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that as long as Taiwan enterprises can find their own niche and core competitive edge, they are bound to shine internationally.
The president made the remarks while attending the 2005 National Excellence Awards ceremony held at the Taipei International Convention center.

President Chen said that he was happy to see the outstanding results of domestic enterprises, adding that he admired and appreciated their contributions in upgrading the overall image and international competitiveness of Taiwan products.

He said that with the efforts of the enterprises and the government's campaign over the last decade to upgrade the image of Taiwan products, goods made in Taiwan have leapt into the ranks of international brands.
He noted that the Geneva-based World Economic Forum ranked Taiwan's global competitiveness fifth, and likened the island to a strong innovator.
He also said that the international community thinks that Taiwan's importance in the global information industry is equal to the influence of Middle East oil on the world economy.

"We must have confidence in ourselves, and in Taiwan, " he said, adding that as long as an enterprise can find the core competitive edge and build up a solid foundation, it is bound to proposer in the international arena.
The president urged the government and the private sector to work together to make Taiwan the paradigm of global research and development, investment return and value-added products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO PARTICIPATE IN BIO 2005 IN U.S.

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese biotechnology delegation will participate in the BIO 2005 Annual International Convention to be held June 19-22 in Philadelphia, according to officials from the Cabinet-level Science and Technology Advisory Group (STAG).

Under the coordination of Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching, the Taiwan delegation will for the first time cooperate with 15 other countries at the "Bio 2005 International Seminar" in which Chen Chao-yih, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and Johnsee Lee, president of the Industrial Technology Research Institute, will report on Taiwan's biotechnology development and perspectives to representatives from more than 60 countries.

At the event, the STAG will arrange meetings between Taiwan entrepreneurs and their counterparts from other countries including France, Canada and the United States in search of cooperation opportunities.

The Taiwan delegation is composed of 150 biotechnology representatives, and the delegates will exhibit the country's diverse biotechnology development, such as gene technology, the development of new medicines, clinical experiments, biotechnology for agriculture, nanotechnology, and traditional Chinese medicine research.

Taiwan delegates will also visit the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and the National Institute of Health after the exhibition to see for themselves how these two American organizations promote medical and sanitary research as a reference in Taiwan's bid to develop itself as a clinical research center in the Asian and Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DONATES FUNDS FOR POST-FLOODING RELIEF

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui donated NT$1 million (US$31,847) Thursday to help people affected by the recent flooding in southern Taiwan.

Su Chin-chiang, chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), said Lee, the TSU's spiritual leader, is concerned about the devastation caused by torrential rains in the southern parts of the island over the past few days, particularly the impact on farmers and fishermen in Yunlin and Pingtung counties.
According to Su, Lee has directed the TSU to do whatever it can to assist in post-disaster relief work.

"Lee once worked in Yunlin County's Mailiao-Kohu area and is fully aware of the region's land sinking problems. He has asked us to organize a team to help with emergency rescue and relief aid, " Su said.
He added that the TSU's headquarters and its southern Taiwan office will also donate NT$1 million each for post-flood aid programs.

Earlier in the day, the TSU donated all of the attendance fees received by the party's National Assembly delegates during a constitutional amendment session from May 30 through June 7 to five public-interest groups.

The money totaled about NT$1 million, a TSU spokesman said at a news conference, adding that the five groups will use the funds to help victims of domestic violence and promote workplace gender equality and welfare services for the disadvantaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DONALD TSANG DECLARED WINNER OF HK CHIEF EXECUTIVE RACE BY DEFAULT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 16 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Acting Hong Kong chief executive Donald Tsang was Thursday declared the winner of the special administrative region's leadership race.
Electoral officials said the nomination of Tsang was supported by 674 members of the 796-member election committee. He was the only valid candidate among six who had hoped to enter the race.
Under these circumstances, Tsang was automatically elected the new chief executive, making the election originally set for July 10 unnecessary, they said.
Tsang will be inaugurated on July 1, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERY DISPUTE IS NOT AFFECTING ROC-JAPAN TIES: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The latest fishery dispute between Taiwan and Japan has not had an adverse impact on the two countries' close bilateral ties, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.
Chen said that the recent disputes over fishing operations in the overlapping economic zones of the two countries has become a high-profile issue among Taiwan's official, private and media sectors.
As a result, he said, a new strength has emerged in the country, a development which has forced Japan to face the issue and return to the negotiating table with Taiwan, Chen noted.

Chen said that Taiwan and Japan are expected to hold a 15th round of fishery talks in Tokyo in late June or early July to address the disputes through bilateral negotiations in a peaceful and rational manner.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture will be representing Taiwan at the fishery talks, while the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will sign a new fishery agreement with Japan on behalf of the Republic of China government if consensus is reached at the meeting, Chen added.

Noting that the Taiwan-Japan fishery talks would be a complicated endeavor involving affairs governed by the Coast Guard Administration, the Ministry of National Defense and the Council of Agriculture, Chen said that the issue is not expected to be tackled alone by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Meanwhile, he noted that controversies arising from disputed economic zones, such as the area in the East China Sea and south of Okinawa, and the sovereignty issue over the Tiaoyutai Islands, known in Japan as the Senkaku Islands, where China, Taiwan and Japan all claim sovereignty, have been discussed in all the past 14 rounds of fishery talks with Japan.

During all of the fishery talks, he added, Taiwan insisted that the Tiaoyutais are part of the sovereign territory of the Republic of China on Taiwan, that Taiwan fishermen's rights and interests must not be compromised, that controversies must be addressed through peaceful and rational negotiations, and that Taiwan will not collaborate with China for any settlement over such disputes.

Taiwan will remain firm over these resolutions in the upcoming 15th round of fishery talks with Japan, Chen said. Nevertheless, he added, it is indeed hard to foresee how these controversies will be settled and he would not speculate as to whether more discussions would be needed in the future.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao, in the eastern Taiwan county of Ilan, protested June 10 in waters 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships out of an area in which the 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Taiwan fishing ships have been repeatedly expelled or detained by Japanese patrol vessels over the past two years after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and neighboring Hualien counties.

The Executive Yuan has filed a strong protest against Japan over the controversy via Taiwan's liaison office in Tokyo and has asked that Taiwan and Japan seek to resolve their fishing disputes through dialogue in line with international law.

According to tallies from the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration, 11 Taiwan fishing boats have been detained by Japan's Fisheries Agency over the past two years, all of which were caught beyond Taiwan's "temporarily demarcated line."
By comparison, CGA officials said, 38 Chinese fishing boats were nabbed during the same period, while 120-odd South Korean fishing boats were detained.
Before the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks begin, Taiwanese fishermen have been asked by the coast guard to operate within the area temporarily demarcated by the government.

Meanwhile, the Suao Fishermen's Association reported last week that a total of 13 Suao fishing boats have been seized by Japan while operating in Taiwan's economic zone since 2001, and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.

An association official said that overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon are long-standing problems, and if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Laywers Fought U.S. Move to Curb Tobacco Penalty.
Senior U.S. Justice Department officials overrode the objections of career lawyers running the government's tobacco racketeering trial and ordered them to reduce the penalties sought at the close of the nine-month trial by US$120 billion. The trial team argued that the mov e would be seen as politically motivated and legally groundless. Two top lawyers for the tria l team, Sharon Y. Eubanks and Stephen D. Brody, wrote in a memorandum on May 30 to Associate Attorney General Robert D. McCallum that the lower penalty recommendation ordered by McCallum would weaken the department's position in any possible settlement with the industry and "create an incentive for defendants to engage in future misconduct by making the misconduct profitable."
Wall Street Journal: Chain Reaction, North Korea Sparks Proliferation Fears Throughout Asia.
If all goes as planned, the the Rokkasho project, facility within sight of Japan's northern Pacific coast, will begin separating plutonium from highly radioactive spent nuclear fuel. At full capacity, the plant will produce about nine tons of plutonium a year. That's enough to meet 10 percent of Japan's civilian nuclear-fuel needs -- or to make 1,000 nuclear warheads. In a region already fearful of North Korea's nuclear-weapons ambitions, the Rokkasho project is adding to the anxiety. Arms-control experts and some U.S. officials warn that if North Korea tests an atomic bomb, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan might reconsider their pledges not to develop nuclear weapons. This trio of American allies possesses more than enough technical expertise, and Asian history supplies considerable mistrust.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND PHASE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS IN PIPELINE: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stands by his determination to put forth a constitution that fits Taiwan by 2008 and the second phase of constitutional reforms will be launched when conditions are ripe, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Yu made the remarks during a tea party with reporters in which he detailed the direction and steps of the task set by the president.

Stressing that the president stands firm on his promise to create a "timely, adequate and tailor-made" constitution for Taiwan by 2008 before he steps down from the presidency, Yu said that a constitution amending committee will be set up under the Presidential Office.

But there will be no fixed timetable for its establishment and the panel will be set up only when the opposition parties are willing to throw their full support behind the task, he explained, adding that its formation requires the participation of all walks of life.

To obtain this aim, a task force under the Presidential Office will be devoted to the founding of a constitutional amendment alliance in the private sector, the cultivating of talent and the setting up of groups committed to study and research on constitutional reform, he said.

He called on the opposition parties not to overlook the significance of the second phase of constitutional revisions to Taiwan's long-term development and sustainable growth as a democratic nation and reminded them of their obligations to the people and to history.

He expressed the hope that a constitution suited to Taiwan will be put in place by 2008 through democratic participation by the whole of society, and urged the public to have vision and in-depth thinking on a new round of constitutional reforms to make Taiwan a great country.
Chen announced his ambition to introduce a new round of constitutional reforms after the last and now-abolished National Assembly approved a package of constitutional amendments June 7.

Yu said last week that the second round of constitutional reforms will not touch on sensitive political issues but will deal with more practical issues, such as the government system and the military conscription system.

But the opposition camp, including the main opposition Kuomintang, the People First Party and even the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, have all voiced disagreement with Chen's idea, on the grounds that the government should focus on improving Taiwan's economy and the people's livelihoods instead of engaging in political mobilization.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONGRATULATES NEW HONG KONG CHIEF EXECUTIVE

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials congratulated Donald Tsang Thursday upon his election as Hong Kong's new chief executive earlier that day.

Tsang, whose nomination was supported by 674 members of the 796-member election committee, was the only candidate, as five potential rivals had not obtained support from at least 100 members of the election committee for their nominations. Tsang was automatically elected and the leadership race originally set for July 10 was canceled.

MAC officials expressed hope that Tsang will promote relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong based on "new thinking" and materialize his campaign promise of promoting political harmony and the welfare of the people.

Noting that Hong Kong, which is a special administrative region of China, plays an intermediary role in cross-Taiwan Strait ties, the officials said the Hong Kong government is welcome to set up a representative office in Taiwan and contribute to promoting peace and stability between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA `ZEROING' IN ON U.S.: EXPERT

TEXT.P: China is using every way other than military means to zero in on the United States "like in a game of go," a China hand and strategic expert claimed Thursday.

Lin Chong-pin, a professor at Tamkang University and executive director of the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies, made the remarks in the wake of recent remarks by U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld that China's increased military expenditure has raised tensions over Taiwan and concern about its longer term implications for U.S. forces in the Western Pacific.

Lin said, echoing former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell, that although China's military is growing rapidly, it lags 10 years behind the United States and cannot possibly threaten the U.S. in the short term.
He said the United States should take heed instead that China has adopted economic, cultural and diplomatic methods to boost its international influence.
He said that Beijing's strategy is to promote in stages domestic, diplomatic and defense policy and its policy toward Taiwan.
China might not have swayed the U.S. status globally but it will change the whole situation in its "final move, " Lin claimed, using the ancient strategy game go as an analogy.

Lin, who has served as vice national defense minister and vice Mainland Affairs Council chairman, said that China's People's Liberation Army has in recent years attached greater importance to the "wisdom of the ancestors" and has taken cues from the strategy classic "The Art of War" by Sun Zu.

To prove its claim of "peaceful emergence, " China is using its stunning economic strength accumulated over the past decade to generously invest in other countries or provide economic assistance, gradually accumulating more and more diplomatic clout.

He cited as examples that the tourism markets of Pacific island states, in which European and American tourists used to predominate, are now taken over by Chinese tourists with spending power. "China fever" has taken over from "China fear" in Southeast Asian countries and long-term allies of the United States such as the European Union and Australia are at odds with the U.S. because they do not see eye-to-eye with the U.S. on lifting an arms embargo on China or policy toward Taiwan, he went on.
This, he claimed, shows that China's economic might is gradually undermining U.S. influence over other countries.

Beijing has also pulled out all the stops to promote Chinese culture, he said, adding that it is systematically promoting Chinese learning in other countries and that its missions in the U.S. are contacting high school principles to offer free Chinese teaching materials.

Such efforts have borne fruit, Lin said, claiming that Chinese has become the priority choice of students learning foreign languages and that simplified Chinese characters have taken over from traditional Chinese characters as the language medium.

At the same time, China also has a "resource diplomacy" ace up its sleeve, which is to buy large amounts of resources, using "oil diplomacy," "mineral diplomacy" and "timber diplomacy" to woo African countries and Latin American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: VANDALS SPRAY ASPHALT EMULSION AT JIA OFFICE

TEXT.P: Police said Thursday they had stepped up patrols around the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) office in Taipei after unknown vandals sprayed asphalt emulsion at its entrance.
The JIA is a quasi-official organization authorized by the Japanese government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Initial investigations show that four unidentified persons arrived at the JIA office early that morning, sprayed asphalt emulsion at the JIA's main gate and ran off.

The incident came at a sensitive time when local fishermen are protesting the Japanese coast guard's frequent chasing them away from a disputed area of the East China Sea north of Taiwan, while a group of Taiwan Aborigines, headed by aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei, was forced to cancel a protest in Tokyo Tuesday over the enshrinement of their relatives at the controversial Yasukuni Shrine after being blocked by police outside the shrine.
Police said they will trace the vandals' identities and ascertain their motivation for their actions.
To ensure the JIA's security, police said they will strengthen patrols in the region from late night through the early morning hours.

Earlier in the day, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Taiwan's representative office in Japan is checking with Japanese authorities as to whether Japanese police exceeded their authority by barring Kao Chin's group and accompanying Taiwan journalists from getting off their tour bus near the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo.

The police wanted to avoid violence between the Taiwanese and a group of Japanese right-wingers who went to the shrine to confront them, but if the police indeed exceeded their authority, Lu said, the government will lodge a protest with the Japanese authorities.

Kao Chi's mission, composed of about 50 relatives of the Taiwanese Aborigines who were drafted into the Japanese army and died during World War II, want the names of the deceased removed from memorial plaques at the shrine because it also honors convicted Japanese war criminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL DAMAGE DUE TO DOWNPOUR EXCEEDS NT$1.4 BILLION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh Thursday promised farmers in Yunlin County who have sustained tremendous damage caused by downpours that have entered a sixth day that compensation and subsidies will be paid in 10 days to help tide them over their difficulties.
Hsieh also renewed calls for the Legislative Yuan to prioritize a bill for an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.539 billion) flood-control project if it convenes an extra session next month.
Hsieh made the remarks when he made an inspection tour of the south-central county of Yunlin to see at first hand the damage brought about in recent days by flash flooding.

Several legislators from across the political spectrum who traveled with the premier on the fact-finding tour expressed worry over the government's resolve to help the flood victims, saying that if the government did not deliver on its promise in 10 days, they will give Hsieh and relevant agencies a hard time.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) reported that damage caused by flash floods around the country have continued to expand, with the agriculture sector bearing the brunt, suffering damage worth over NT$1.4 billion (US$45.16 million) as of Thursday afternoon.
Most of the damage was centered in southern Taiwan, especially Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan, Chiayi and Yunlin counties, where low-lying areas have been inundated.

Of the damage, crops had sustained damage exceeding NT$600 million, with some 34,790 hectares of rice paddies and peanut, green vegetable, watermelon, corn and papaya plantations inundated, COA officials reported.
The husbandry sector had suffered damage worth about NT$180 million, with over 10,000 head of pigs, 143,000 chickens and many other animals and poultry killed.
In the southern county of Tainan, about half of its townships and rural townships had been inundated, with floodwater about 1 meter high in Yukang, Chinghu and Kunchiang villages in Peimen township.
Soldiers have been sent to help evacuate or rescue affected residents in six rural townships around Tainan County, where 28 bridges had become impassable, according to COA authorities.
Meanwhile, the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center reported that as of midnight Wednesday, 433 people had been rescued and 2,297 people evacuated islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER FLOODING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has expressed great concern over human and property losses caused by the recent flooding in southern Taiwan, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Yu revealed that at a regular Thursday meeting, Premier Frank Hsieh reported to Chen on the progress of post-disaster rescue efforts.
According to Yu, Chen expressed deep concern and Hsieh promised to make an eight-year NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project into an urgent bill.
The flood-control budget bill is the product of thorough consideration of the Cabinet and he dismissed opposition claims that it is a rushed plan, Yu said.
The flooding had claimed the lives of several people in southern area and had caused NT$1.4 billion-worth agricultural losses as of Thursday.

According to Cabinet Spokesman Cho Jung-tai, the central government and a dozen local governments, as well as the Ministry of National Defense, have set up emergency centers for rescue and relief efforts.
Hsieh has ordered the Department of Health and the Environmental Protection Administration to monitor the situation in order to prevent contagious diseases from breaking out, Cho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY FRIGATE TO FERRY LAWMAKERS TO INSPECT ROC FISHING GROUNDS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) agreed Thursday to send a frigate June 21 to waters near a disputed part of the East China Sea to allow lawmakers to inspect first hand how the administration is protecting Taiwan fishermen there, according to a military spokesman.

Liu Chih-chien confirmed that after a closed-door meeting among Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye and opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang, it was decided that the navy will deploy a frigate on an inspection voyage, with Wang, Lee and Lin aboard, to show support for the country's fishermen as well as proclaim Republic of China sovereignty over its 200-nautical mile economic zone.

The MND turned down a day earlier a request by Lin that the navy send a Knox-class frigate June 17 to the disputed area of the East China Sea where the exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap, to flex Taiwan's muscle against Japan.
Liu said Wednesday that the military had no plans to do that because most available military forces have been deployed to take part in the "Hankuang 21" exercises.
Liu said the three frigates already deployed by the military near the disputed waters should be sufficient to serve the purpose.

Lin, a co-convener of the legislature's National Defense Committee, made the request in the wake of a conflict last week in waters off Taiwan's northeast coast between Taiwanese fishermen and the Japanese coast guard following the latest expulsion of Taiwanese fishermen from the area.
Lin claimed that Japan is "much more polite" to Chinese and South Korean fishermen operating in the same waters and does not dare arbitrarily expel them.

Blaming the situation on what he claimed is the "long-time cowardice" of the government, Lin urged the military to get tough with Japan to boost Taiwan's leverage, especially when both countries are set to open a new round of fishery talks in July.

Lin also threatened to continue to block the ministry's NT$480 billion U.S. arms procurement package and to cut the ministry's annual budget by at least NT$50 billion if the MND refused to provide him with a Knox-class frigate for the trip.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao, in the eastern Taiwan county of Ilan, protested June 10 in waters 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships from the disputed area.

The Suao Fishermen's Association reported last week that a total of 13 Suao fishing boats have been seized by Japan while operating in Taiwan's economic zone since 2001 and that the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.

An association official said that overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon are long-standing problems, and that if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TAKES CHINA'S RESPONSE AS HARBINGER OF RESUMED TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to regard China's initial response to its initiatives for bilateral talks on two matters of mutual concern as a harbinger of China's willingness to return to the negotiating table, a senior official said Thursday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a visiting delegation from the Czech Republic's Senate foreign affairs and defense committees.
"As Beijing didn't turn down our initiatives outright, we would like to consider its response a harbinger of Beijing's willingness to resume dialogue across the Taiwan Strait," Wu told his guests.

Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that the government has asked the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to talk with Beijing on the opening of direct cross-strait charter cargo flights and the sale of Taiwan fruit to China.

The two private groups were asked to act on behalf of the government because of Beijing's refusal to have any official contacts with Taiwan, which would lend credit to Taiwan's claim to be an independent sovereign state.

A Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs said Wednesday in Beijing that China would like to exchange views with Taiwan on charter cargo flights even though it believes direct passenger flights are more urgently needed.

As to the negotiations on imports of Taiwan fruit, the official said Beijing would prefer to talk with the Taiwan Provincial Farmer's Association. But he did not rule out the possibility of accepting TAITRA as an intermediary.
"We hope China can make a clearer and more definite response so that the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue can start soon, " Wu said.
During their talks, the Czech parliamentarians said they look forward to seeing China move toward democracy after achieving an economic boom.

In response, Wu said the government-funded Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, which was established two years ago, is cooperating with non-government organizations in the United States and European countries to promote democratic development around the world.

Wu said he hopes China can lift its ban on Taiwan media outlets' online versions. Should that be the case, he said, those online newspapers could become the best channels for Chinese citizens to understand Taiwan.
The nation's top mainland policy planner further said he is hopeful that China can negotiate with Taiwan on technical details for Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.
"We are willing to open our doors to Chinese people so that they can experience Taiwan's democratic way of life, sowing the seeds of liberal democracy in their minds," Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAGANO PREFECTURE GOVERNOR TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR TOURISM PROMOTION
DOC.DATELINE: Nagano, Japan, June 16 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The governor of the Japanese prefecture of Nagano said Thursday he will lead a delegation to Taiwan in November to promote tourism.
At a meeting with Taiwanese reporters, Yasuo Tanaka noted that he met with President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui during previous visits to Taiwan.
Describing his views on Taiwan, Tanaka hailed both Chen and Lee as leaders with vision, and praised Taiwan fruit such as mangoes.
Recalling his previous visits to Taiwan, Tanaka said that every time he returned from Taiwan, he got fat due to the delicious food.
He also expressed pride in the food, wine and hot springs in Nagano Prefecture and said he would also promote Nagano apples during his November visit.
He said he also plans to promote direct flights between Taiwan and Nagano and is in discussions with Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines on this issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN BEEF '100 PERCENT SAFE': AIT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The top U.S. representative in Taipei assured Taiwan consumers Thursday that American beef is very safe and free from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , also known as mad cow disease.

Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, tucked into a dish of American beef at the opening of a four-day international food show at the Taipei World Trade Center, insisting that American beef is completely safe to eat.

"While there has been a lot of media attention on the safety of (U.S.) beef this week, the simple fact is that American beef exported to Taiwan has been and continues to be 100 percent safe," Paal said.
The de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan said he was pleased that American beef is back on the menu in Taiwan.

"The return of American beef after a 15-month absence from the Taiwan market demonstrates the excellent working relationship and cooperation that exists between Taiwan authorities and the U.S. Department of Agriculture," Paal said.

Noting that agricultural and food trade between Taiwan and the United States has a long history, Paal said the United States has been Taiwan's largest agricultural import source and one of Taiwan's most important farm produce export outlets. The United States accounted for 10 percent of Taiwan's total food exports last year.
According to Paal, the American pavilion at the 2005 Food Taipei trade fair features 84 exhibition booths displaying a wide variety of foodstuffs, including beef.
Paal gave a thumbs-up after tucking into his beef before the cameras, saying: "American beef is very very safe, 100 percent safe and delicious."

Taiwan banned U.S. beef imports in December 2003 after the United States reported its first case of BSE, which has been linked to a variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, a disease that has claimed more than 140 lives worldwide, mostly in Britain.

On April 16 this year, Taiwan began to allow imports of U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age, but the Department of Health said Monday it will reinstate a ban on U.S. beef imports if the United States confirms it has found a second BSE case.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT TO RULE ON APPEAL TO NULLIFY PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Supreme Count will give a ruling Friday on an appeal filed by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong to nullify the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, court officials said Thursday.
Lien and Soong appealed to the Supreme Court after their lawsuit to contest the results of the election was rejected by the Taiwan High Court Nov. 4 last year.

They alleged that the results of last year's March 20 election were swayed by various electoral scandals, a referendum held on the same day of the election and the activation of a national security mechanism following the election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu that they claim barred a number of police and military servicemen from going to the polls. They have provided no evidence to support their claims.

The Chen-Lu ticket won over the Lien-Soong ticket by a margin of 29,518 ballots, or 0.228 percent of the more-than 13 million ballots cast. A later vote recount reduced the margin by nearly 4,000 to 25,563 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODS IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN CLAIM 10 LIVES

TEXT.P: Floods caused by torrential rain over the past five days in southern Taiwan have claimed 10 lives, with two persons missing, according to a report released Thursday by the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center.
Meanwhile, the center reported that as of midnight Wednesday, 433 people had been rescued and 2,297 people evacuated around the nation.

The flooding that has affected southern Taiwan since June 12 has also caused tremendous damage to the agriculture sector, which had suffered damage worth over NT$1.4 billion (US$45.16 million) as of Thursday afternoon, according to a report by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 17, or the 11th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1703: British religious leader John Wesley is born. He founded Methodism in 1738, while his brother, Charles, wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing."
1775: The second battle of the American Revolution commences at Bunker Hill and Breed's Hill, just north of Boston, Massachusetts. The Americans lost around 400 men, the British 1,000.
1925: A total of 29 countries sign the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940: Red Army forces occupy Latvia and Estonia and pro-Soviet administrations are installed.
1950: The first kidney transplant is performed by Dr. Richard Lawler in Chicago.
1960: The Chinese communists launch 85,965 shells toward the island of Kinmen on the eve of US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's visit to the Republic of China.
1967: Communist China detonates its first hydrogen bomb.
1971: The United States and Japan sign an agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: Five men are caught snooping around the Washington apartment-hotel complex known as The Watergate, currently being used by the Democratic Party as their headquarters during the US election campaign.
1974: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun leaves for Seoul to attend the 9th Sino-Korean Ministerial Level Economic Cooperation Conference.
1976: Hsu Li-teh is appointed vice minister of finance by the ROC Executive Yuan.
1978: More than 4.5 million eligible ROC voters go to the polls to elect 3,786 representatives of townships and villages as well as 6,417 urban and rural district chiefs.
1979: Charles Cross, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1982: Raymond Perodin, Haiti's new ambassador to the ROC, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1982: Fourteen generals meet at an army base in Buenos Aires and vote unanimously to fire Leopoldo Galtieri, the president who led Argentina into the Falklands War against Britain.
1982: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung, as President Chiang Ching-kuo's special envoy, leaves for Saudi Arabia to offer Taiwan's condolences for the passing of King Fahd ibn Abdul Aziz.
1986: Nineteen mainland Chinese youths defect across the Yellow Sea aboard a small wooden boat to South Korea to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Some 400,000 Parisians and tourists from all over the world celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower.
1990: President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay arrives in Taipei to sign a joint communique calling for closer bilateral relations with the ROC.
1992: Lin Yang-kang, president of the Judicial Yuan of the ROC, leaves for the United States for a three-week visit.
1996: The United States and mainland China reach a deal to stamp out rampant Chinese copyright piracy.
1999: The International Labor Organization adopts a treaty banning the worst forms of child labor, including slavery and forced military recruitment.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweights at an extraordinary session of the party's 15th National Congress call for party unity while protesters outside the session's venue call for the expulsion of former party chairman Lee Teng-hui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I hate the way scarlet dims the perception of vermilion. I hate the way the modern popular airs are liable to spoil the taste for good music. Finally, I hate the way smartness of speech in men is liable to destroy kingdoms and ruin families."

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA vows to finish economic reforms
Facing the toughest ordeal of her four-year-old administration, President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday acknowledged that "agents of destabilization" are exploiting her sagging popularity in a last-ditch effort to grab power because "it is now or never for them."
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo: 'They are going too far'
BUOYED by a positive report on the economic front, President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo yesterday went on the offensive against her political opponents, accusing them of making a last-ditch effort to derail her development goals now that she is on the verge of achieving them and vowing she would not be deterred.
The Philippine Star: GMA won't face House probe
President Arroyo said yesterday she will not appear before any congressional probe into the controversial recordings that purportedly document her attempts to rig the results of last year's presidential election.
