A shipment of high-powered firearms, ammunition and gun parts believed to be intended for groups planning to overthrow the government was intercepted Thursday by Customs agents at the Manila International Container Port.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Gazprom Stake to Go for

$7.1Bln The 10.7 percent stake the state needs to own a majority of Gazprom will be bough t for 203.5 billion rubles ($7.1 billion) , the gas giant announced Thursday after its board approved the price tag set earlier by the government.

Despite some confusion over when the decision was actually reached -- some reports suggested that Gazprom's board may have met Wednesday as initially planned -- the price itself came as no surprise to anyone. The board accepted the government's offer, despite reports that Gazprom had wanted at least $8 billion for the stake.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Tsutsumi accepts guilt as trial starts Seibu don 'unaware ' of illegalities
Former real estate and resort tycoon Yoshiaki Tsutsumi pleaded guilty Thursday to insider trading and falsification of financial reports concerning Seibu Railway Co. shareholdings.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S FIERCE OPPOSITION PREVENTS VISIT TO TAIWAN: THE DALAI LAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 16 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama said Thursday in Berlin that China's fierce opposition has led him not to visit Taiwan during the past few years.
The exiled Tibetan spiritual leader made the comments while responding to questions raised by Taiwanese reporters at a press conference.
He told more than 100 journalists attending the press gathering that he visited Taiwan twice before and that the island has made remarkable cultural and economic achievements.

Expressing his admiration for Taiwan's efforts in preserving the tradition of Chinese Buddhism, the Dalai Lama said that maintaining the island's democracy and freedom is a responsibility of the international community.

Revealing that Beijing has fiercely opposed any visits by him to Taiwan, the Dalai Lama said that as he represents the 6 million people of Tibet and in order to continue to be able to hold talks with Beijing, he cannot visit the island.
Saying that China has experienced rapid economic development, the Dalai Lama admitted that even though its political progress has been very slow, he is still optimistic about his talks with Beijing.

At an awards ceremony held in the German city the same day, the Dalai Lama presented awards to former Czech President Vaclav Havel, as well as to a German political figure and a leader of a German pro-Tibet organization for their outstanding contributions to human rights in Tibet.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDISH LAWMAKERS OPPOSE A LIFTING OF E.U. ARMS BAN ON CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 16 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Swedish Parliament on Thursday adopted a statement by a vote of 198-102 to express its opposition to a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China.
The E.U. imposed the arms sales ban shortly after the Tiannmen Square Massacre in 1989.

Emphasizing in the statement that maintaining the ban can express the E.U.'s concern about China's human rights, the Swedish lawmakers said a lifting of the ban would be against Europe's strategic interests. Furthermore, the statement said, there is currently no reliable way to prevent China from transferring advanced weapons technology to "irresponsible regimes."

China's continuous intimidation and threats toward Taiwan and the recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by the Chinese National People's Congress have made the E.U., the United States and Japan worry about stability in the Asia-Pacific region, the statement also said, adding that therefore, the E.U. should not lift the ban at the present time.

The E.U. must enact a stricter "Code of Conduct" to regulate its member states' arms exports to third countries in order to achieve the goal of protecting human rights and regional stability as well as strengthening relations with friendly nations. it also said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT REJECTS APPEAL TO NULLIFY RE-ELECTION OF PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court rejected Friday an appeal filed by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong to nullify the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Lien and Soong appealed to the Supreme Court after their lawsuit to contest the results of the election was rejected by the Taiwan High Court Nov. 4 last year.

They alleged that the outcome of last year's March 20 election was influenced by various electoral scandals, a referendum held on the day of the election, and the activation of a national security mechanism following the election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu that Lien and Soong claimed prevented a significant number of members of the police and military forces from going to the polls. They provided no evidence to support their claims.

The Chen-Lu ticket won the election by a slim margin of only 29,518 votes, or 0.228 percent of the more than 13 million ballots cast. A later vote recount reduced the margin by nearly 4,000 to 25,563 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: HDB shopowners offered aid.
Almost 200 shopowners from seven HDB estates are the first to be offered the means to bail out of their ailing businesses under a new government scheme.
This first group, with a total of 193 shops, comes under a pilot project that will give each showonwer S$60,000 if he decides to close shop and leave-- a sum that is S$12,000 more than a previous payout considered insufficient.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 193 shops from 7 HDB estes attended RPS.
The Housing Development Board (HDB) has identified 193 shops from seven HDB estates for the pilot Restructuring Programme for Shops (RPS) scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AND FIRST LADY DONATE NT$2 MILLION FOR FLOOD-RELIEF EFFORTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and first lady Wu Shu-jen are concerned about the serious flooding in areas of central and southern Taiwan and have decided to donate NT$2 million (US$63,490) for post-flood relief efforts, Presidential Office officials said Friday.

The officials said that President Chen, who is also the honorary president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, decided to donate the money to the society which has been active in providing various forms of assistance to residents badly affected by days of torrential rains.

In addition, the president also extended his appreciation to the military personnel, police officers and firefighters who have pitched in to provide assistance and relief to flood-affected residents, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.15 points to close at 6,293.56.
The bourse opened at 6,304.24 and fluctuated between 6,357.39 and 6,293.23 during trading. A total of 4.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$111.05 billion (US$3.54 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up at 0.5 percent and machinery and electronics shares gaining 0.3 percent.

The other six major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 469 to 329, with 207 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up nine points to close at 6,189, with 39,792 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August moved up 10 points to end at 6,130, with 339 contracts traded, while September futures gained nine points to finish at 6,096, with 416 contracts traded. December futures moved up eight points to close at 6,088, with five contracts traded, while March futures moved up 50 points to close at 6,107, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,180 for July, 6,120 for August, 6,087 for September, 6,080 for December and 6,057 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

July TE futures moved up 1.2 points to close at 254.1, with 6,263 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 1.2 points to finish at 252, with 98 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 1.65 points to end at 251.2, with 11 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 5.35 points to close at 251, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

July TF futures gained three points to finish at 953.4, with 3,145 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures moved up 1.2 points to end at 942, with 69 contracts traded. September TF futures gained one point to close at 939, with 29 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.092 to close at NT$31.323.
A total of US$666 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.415 and hit a low of NT$31.320.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION'S CLAIM AGAINST PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT INVALID: JUDGE

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court has rejected an appeal by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong to nullify the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu because the plaintiffs have failed to substantiate their claim, the presiding judge said Friday.

Lien and Soong alleged that the outcome of last year's March 20 election was influenced by various electoral scandals, a referendum held on the day of the election and the activation of a "national security mechanism" following the election-eve shooting of Chen and Lu that Lien and Soong claimed prevented a number of police and military servicemen from going to the polls.

According to Hsu Chao-hsiung, presiding judge of the case, it was the Central Election Commission rather than the president that had the authority to decide whether the referendum was to be held alongside the presidential election.

On the activation of the "national security mechanism, " Hsu said the Ministry of National Defense was only exercising its duty and that even if extra military servicemen were asked to stay at their posts, there is no evidence showing that this was ordered by Chen and Lu.

While Lien and Soong could not prove that the March 19 shooting was set up by Chen and Lu to give them an advantage in the election, Chen and Lu were not the operators of underground radio stations that Lien and Soong alleged had falsely accused the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of being responsible for the shooting, Hsu noted.
Also, the results of a recount ordered by the Taiwan High Court last year supported the re-election of Chen and Lu, he added.
The Chen-Lu ticket won the election by a slim margin of only 29,518 votes, or 0.228 percent of the more than 13 million ballots cast. The recount reduced the margin by nearly 4,000 to 25,563 votes.
Lien and Soong appealed to the Supreme Court after their claim was rejected by the Taiwan High Court Nov. 4 last year.
The other case filed by Lien and Soong to annul the presidential election was also rejected by the Taiwan High Court Dec. 30. The Supreme Court has yet to rule on that case.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT RULING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION DISPUTE DRAWS MIXED RESPONSES

TEXT.P: The Supreme Court's rejection of an appeal by defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong to nullify the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu triggered mixed responses from the two camps Friday.
Presidential Office officials said Chen and Lu fully respect the ruling and hope their opponents and the general public will also respect the judiciary.
However, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), which Lien and Soong represent, called the outcome regrettable and disappointing.
Accusing the Supreme Court of yielding to political interference and considerations, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed the ruling was made in the absence of justice and conscience.

Chang urged Chen to support the "truth investigation commission" aimed at probing the election-eve shooting of the president and vice president, to clarify opposition "pan-blue alliance" doubts over the outcome of last year's March 20 election.

Lien and Soong alleged that the election outcome was swayed by various electoral scandals, a referendum held on the same day of the election and the activation of a "national security mechanism" following the shooting that they claimed prevented a number of police and military servicemen from going to the polls. They have provided no evidence to support their claims.

Lai Shyh-bao, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, claimed the ruling was foreseeable because the Supreme Court did not conduct a comprehensive recount, while the government has refused to cooperate with the "truth investigation commission."
Agreeing with Lai, PFP legislators said the ruling is very unconvincing and proposed that Lien and Soong file for an extraordinary appeal on the case.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang called on the KMT and PFP to respect the court decision, put an end to the year-long dispute and reconcile with the ruling party.

Lee said the dispute has been clarified and social justice upheld in the process of the trial, which involved the first recount in Taiwan's history and the testimony by the Presidential Office, the National Security Council and electoral, military and police officials.

He said the country has paid a heavy price because of the irrational action taken by the KMT and PFP over the past year, which includes circulating false accounts of the election-eve shooting to damage the democratic image of Taiwan, mobilizing supporters to a series of massive demonstrations and blocking a number of crucial bills in the Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, the Central Election Commission released a statement saying that it respects the ruling of the Supreme Court, which it said has proven the impartiality of electoral workers in exercising their duties.
The CEC said it will continue to follow the principle of fairness and objectivity in future elections and it urged the public to offer their encouragement to all electoral workers.

Lawyer Kao Yung-cheng, who is executive director of the Judicial Reform Foundation, pointed out that the judiciary is the last institutional resort to resolve disputes and he urged the losers to respect the final ruling and avoid making any further unfounded accusations to damage the credibility of the judiciary.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE SERVICE GROUP CALLS FOR CARE FOR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: The non-governmental Taipei Overseas Peace Service (TOPS) is preparing a series of activities to mark World Refugee Day, the group's convener said Friday.

The United Nations designated June 20 as the World Refugee Day in 2000 as part of its efforts to call on the international community to help refugees around the world. This year, the U.N. will hold various activities under the theme "Courage of Refugees" to mark the annual event.
TOPS project convener Ting Wen-ching said the theme is to underline that every refugee needs courage to overcome fear and the difficulties they face.

Many countries and private organizations offer shelter and aid to refugees, while they also stage various activities regularly to feature the plight of war victims. Taiwan will join in the activities this year, Ting noted.

Planned activities include a photo exhibition marking the 25th anniversary of TOPS overseas services, a speech to be given by Dr. Cynthia Maung, a physician dedicated to refugee camps in Myanmar, a music concert and seminars regarding refugee affairs.
Details of the events are available at the TOPS Web site at "www.tops.org.tw, " or by calling 02-23933676, ext. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP URGES CHINA TO DISMANTLE MISSILES TARGETING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A civic group urged China to dismantle its military buildup targeting Taiwan and to understand that military force cannot resolve the problems between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the PEACETIME Foundation of Taiwan, made the appeal at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

Quoting statistics released by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) , Chien said China has been the largest importer of traditional arms in the world for the fifth year in a row.
Although stressing its "peaceful rise, " China has increased its military spending by a double-digit rate each year, according to Chien.
With hundreds of missiles aimed at Taiwan, threatening the security of the Taiwan people, Chien said he doubts the Chinese claims of "peaceful rise."

He claimed China's rapid military buildup and modernization have caused preoccupation among neighboring East Asian countries, with Japan, South Korea and Taiwan possibly launching countermeasures, and he expressed worry that another wave of the arms race will break out in the East Asian region.

Stressing that the two sides of Taiwan Strait should not return to the era of military confrontation in which both sides invested huge resources to arms, Chien said that Taiwan and China should strengthen mutual understanding and civic exchanges in order to seek solutions acceptable to people of both sides via peaceful negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC SITUATION TO BE BETTER IN SECOND HALF: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Friday that Taiwan's economy will continue to grow and that the economic situation will be better in the second half than in the first half of the year.
Wu made the remarks while attending a congress of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC).

CNAIC President Huang Mao-hsiung noted that Taiwan's economic growth was adjusted upward to 5.71 percent from the original estimate of 4.7 percent last year, but economic growth this year was adjusted downward to 3.63 percent from the original estimate of 4.49 percent.

The downward adjustment has to do with a slower world economy, Huang said, but he also cited a tally by the Ministry of Economic Affairs showing that the ratio of Taiwan manufacturers' overseas production has continued to rise to an average of 38.23 percent, which he said is a sign that Taiwan is losing its competitive edge.

Addressing Huang's concerns, Wu said that world economic growth has been slower this year, dropping to an estimated 3.1 percent from last year's 3.3 percent. In the United States, it dropped to 3.4 percent from an estimated 3.6 percent, and 1.3 percent from an estimated 1.7 percent in the European Union.
The situation is the same in Taiwan, Wu said, adding however that economic growth will continue, and "there is no need to be pessimistic."

Wu said that this year's BOT (build-operate-transfer) projects totaled NT$100 billion (US$3.17 billion) , including underground sewage system works. He noted that currently only 12.5 percent of Taiwan has a sewage pipeline system, so there is a long way to go to match the 90 percent level in some European countries and North America.
He also remarked on the minimum tax system under a tax reform plan and a second phase of financial reforms, saying that a more competitive financial sector will contribute to business development.
Huang for his part suggested that the government ease investment regulations, inquire about the views of businessmen while revisiting regulations, and speed up the pace of liberalization.
The ruling and the opposition parties should also seek reconciliation to speed up the review of bills and the government should attach importance to law and order, he said.

He also suggested that the government engage in trade and economic negotiation with China, saying that if both sides of the Taiwan Strait could sign trade and investment agreements, it would not only bring the benefit of cross-strait economic integration, it would also mitigate hurdles for Taiwan's bid to sign bilateral trade agreements with other nations and avoid the fate of being marginalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO GIVE UNPRECEDENTED NATIONAL SECURITY REPORT: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will issue a national security report this summer following the lead of the heads of state of the United States and other advanced countries, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said Friday.

Chiou said it is the responsibility of the administration to tell the people the threats facing the nation from within and outside the country, the core values of the country's security, the state of the national security and the priority of national security issues.
The national security report, which will be the first in the country's history, will cover the five sections of finance, defense, ties with China, diplomacy and land conservation, Chiou said.

The report will provide feasible guidelines for national policy in the next two to four years but it will not encroach on the authority of the Executive Yuan by dictating any specific measures, the president's chief security aide said.
Chen huddled with his senior security aides earlier Friday to discuss a preliminary report about the nation's finance, Chiou said.

As an advisory group to the president, Chiou said, the National Security Council's opinion will not automatically be translated into policy unless it is approved by the president, and therefore there is no conflict between it and the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORTATION MINISTER TO MEET FRENCH COUNTERPART
DOC.DATELINE: Toulouse, France, June 16 (CNA) (By Liu Teh-chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san confirmed Thursday that he will meet his French counterpart Friday (France time) for talks on issues of mutual interest.
Lin is in Toulouse, headquarters of Airbus, to participate in the delivery ceremony of the fourth of eight A330-300s the China Airlines (CAL) ordered from the airplane giant.

As an advertisement by the Council of Agriculture to promote sales of Taiwan's butterfly orchid, one of its most important agricultural exports, the CAL's fourth A330-300 will carry a huge image of butterfly orchid on its fuselage.

At the invitation of European aviation groups, Lin also attended the Paris Air Show held June 13-16, and traveled by France's high-speed TGV train to compare the high-speed rail systems of Japan and Europe.

He noted that Taiwan boasts a strong industrial foundation and is promoting its aviation industry. With Taiwan's certification on aviation products already recognized by the United States, Taiwan also hopes it can be recognized by the European Union, Lin added.
Lin said the issue will also be the topic of his talks with his French counterpart.

Concerning the air transport charter flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Lin said the government will give precedence to negotiations on charter cargo flights, even though China has proposed that charter passenger flights should come first.
On China's offer to lift restrictions on Chinese people making sightseeing trips to Taiwan, Lin said the issue is complicated and needs to be decided by the proper authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO CALL COORDINATION MEETING IN PREPARATION FOR FISHERY TALKS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will call a coordination meeting next Tuesday to forge a consensus on Taiwan's fishery talks with Japan, due in about two weeks, a ministry spokesman said Friday.

The ministry has invited legislators from all the political parties and representatives of the fishery industry to take part in the Tuesday inter-ministerial meeting with officials from the MOFA, the Ministry of the Interior, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) , the Council of Agriculture and the National Security Bureau, the spokesman said.

Stressing that it is better to deal with the recent fishery disputes between Taiwan and Japan through diplomatic channels, the spokesman said that the government hopes to create a consensus on the issue in preparation for the coming talks with Japan -- the 15th of their kind that will be held in late June or early July.

William C. T. Lai, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP does not favor a proposal of sending military ships to escort Taiwan fishing boats offshore.

Speaking at a news conference, Lai said that deploying military escorts to the scene of the fishery disputes is not a good idea and claimed that it would only create difficulties in bilateral negotiations.

He said that the CGA should send patrol ships to protect Taiwan fishing boats in the disputed overlapping water claimed by both Taiwan and Japan as part of their 200 nautical miles exclusive economic zones before a conclusion is reached after the fishery talks.

Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Lin Yu-fang said that his demand that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) send military vessels to escort Taiwan fishing boats is aimed at "increasing Taiwan's bargaining chips" in negotiations with Japan.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye decided Thursday to send military vessels to escort Taiwan fishing boats that will operate next Tuesday in waters some 60 nautical miles off Suao, Ilan County -- an area near the edge of Taiwan's Air Defense Identification Zone.
Lin told the Central News Agency that it is natural for the MND to dispatch ships to help the CGA protect Taiwan fishermen because the CGA has no enough number of big ships to patrol the vast area.

According to Lin, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen also ascribed Japan's willingness to come to the bargaining table to Taiwan fishermen's protests. He urged the MND to throw its support behind Taiwan's fishermen to underline the government's resolve to seek justice for its people.

Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers Shuai Hua-min, a former military general, and Su Chi, a former chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, called a news conference at the KMT headquarters in which they urged the government to reiterate its traditional sovereignty over the Tiaoyutai Islands, a group of small islets surrounded by the disputed overlapping exclusive economic zones in the East China Sea.
The recent Taiwan-Japan fishery disputes are a consequence of the sovereignty row over the Tiaoyutais and the government must do its utmost to protect what it sees as its territory, they pointed out.

KMT legislators Joanna Lei, Lai Shyh-bao and Tsao Shou-min also voiced their support for the government's moves to claim territorial sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais, claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China.

The fishing squabbles are actually sovereignty disputes, they maintained, suggesting that President Chen Shui-bian hold a national security meeting quickly to ensure Taiwan's fishing, mineral and other development rights in the area.

About 50 fishing vessels from Suao staged a protest last Friday 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that have repeatedly dispersed or arrested Taiwan fishing ships over the past two years in the overlapping waters after Japan claimed sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as just 20 nautical miles off the coast of Ilan.
For the time being, Taiwan fishermen are requested to operate in an area temporarily demarcated by the government to avoid direct confrontation with Japan ahead of the two countries' fishery talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Heart Drug for Blacks Endorsed; Racial Tailoring Would Be a First; Idea Stirs Debate.
Federal health advisers yesterday endorsed the approval of a drug to treat heart failure in African Americans, which would make the controversial pill the first medicine targeted at a specific racial group, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush's support on Major Issues Tumbles in Poll.
Increasingly pessimistic about Iraq and skeptical about President Bush's plan for Social Security, Americans are in a season of political discontent, giving Bush one of the lowest approval ratings of his presidency and even lower marks to Congress, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll. Forty-two percent of the people responding to the poll said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job, a marked decline from his 51 percent rating after of the November election, when he embarked on an ambitious second term agenda led by the overhaul of Social Security. Sixteen months before the midterm elections, Congress fared even worse in the survey, with the approval of just 33 percent of the respondents, and 19 percent saying Congress shared their priorities.
Wall Street Journal: Tensions Split Muslim Gr oups, Posing Big Challenges For Interim Government.
After one of the most violent months in Iraq since the U.S. invasion, a fundamental problem has become even more obvious in Iraq: skyrocketing tensions between Sunni Muslims, like Mr. Hassan, and Shiite Muslims. A recent spate of violence appears to be tit-for-tat killings between Sunni and Shiite Muslims, two of the country's largest groups. Even more alarming, the tension seems to reflect a broader conflict between a Sunni-dominated insurgency and Shiite-dominated government.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL SELF-PAYMENT RATIO HIKE TO BE PUT INTO EFFECT JULY 15

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Friday that a self-payment ratio hike for outpatients and emergency patients will be put into practice July 15.

DOH officials said that the self-payment amount for outpatients for district, regional and national medical center hospitals will be raised to NT$80 (US$2.54), NT$240 and NT$360, respectively, from the present NT$50, NT$140 and NT$210, while the self-payment amounts for emergency patients for regional and national medical center hospitals will be raised to NT$300 and NT$450, respectively, from the current NT$210 and NT$420.
This means that visits to national medical center hospitals will start from NT$510, including the registration fee of NT$150 and self-payment ratio of NT$360.

The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) estimated that most people can get necessary treatment at local community clinics and that only 20 percent of the public will be affected by the hike plan.
The BNHI said that the hike will allow the bureau to cut its expenditure of around NT$4.3 billion a year.

The burden on the underprivileged will not be increased, and the average person will pay between 10 percent and 14 percent of the medical bills after the hikes, health officials said, adding that it will review the hike after six months.
BNHI Vice President Chou Li-fang said the purpose of the hike is not to increase revenues for the national health insurance plan, but to cut expenditure.
She said that around NT$4.3 billion will be saved in the first year, or NT$1.8 billion for the remainder of this year.
At present, the government reimburses around 90 percent to 91 percent of medical bills, with the public shouldering the rest.

After the hike, the self-payment ratio for visits to national medical center hospitals will increase to 13.8 percent, while the ratio will increase to 12.9 percent in regional hospitals and 9.9 percent in district hospitals.

Health officials have listed the following categories for which self-payment will be waived: major disease such as cancer; rare diseases; women giving birth; residents in mountainous areas and outlying islands; low-income households; veterans; and children under three years old.
In addition, sufferers of 97 chronic diseases will be waived from self-payment for medicines and the handicapped will only pay NT$50 in self-payment.
A double hike of health insurance premiums and self-payment ratio was put into effect in September 2003 despite opposition from the national health insurance supervisory committee and the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOINS APEC ENGINEER FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan was formally accepted as a member of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Engineer Framework Friday, an official of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission (PCC) announced, adding that membership will facilitate local engineers to obtain APEC certificates allowing them to work in the region.

As a member of the framework, Taiwan is eligible to certify local engineers' international practice capability in accordance with regulations governing independent authorized bodies for the APEC engineering register, the official noted.

By forging mutual or multilateral recognition ties with other APEC Engineer Framework participants, Taiwan "APEC engineers" can be involved in international practice in APEC markets including the United States, Canada, Japan, South Korea, Australia, New Zealand and Southeast Asian countries.

An APEC engineer should complete accredited programs, gain at least seven years of practical experience, have been in charge of project practice for at least two years, and have maintained a continuous professional career, according to the PCC.

Taiwan's participation in the APEC Engineer Framework was approved in the APEC Engineers meeting, which is part of the biennial International Engineering Meetings taking place June 13-17 in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN PROTEST AT MOFA, JAPANESE MISSION OFFICE

TEXT.P: Scores of Taiwan fishermen and human rights activists protested Friday at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs over the recent fishing disputes between Taiwan and Japan.

Displaying banners blaming the government's inability to handle the disputes and demanding that the officials in charge step down, they also staged a skit to vent their anger over what they called a "useless government" and "cowardly officials."

Claiming that the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea belongs to Taiwan and saying that Taiwan fishermen must not be humiliated by Japanese patrol vessels when operating in surrounding waters, they chanted slogans urging government officials to protect Taiwan fishermen and Taiwan territorial waters by loudly declaring its 200 mile exclusive economic zone.

Chin Chieh-shou, a Taipei county councilor who was present to lend his support to the fishermen, insisted that "Japan must get out of the Tiaoyutais," because the islands, traditional territory of the Republic of China, has been occupied by Japan, which is the root cause of the recent fishery disputes between the two countries.

A fishery rights group issued a statement demanding that President Chen Shui-bian make clear Taiwan's claim that the Tiaoyutais are national territory and support a demand by Taiwan's aborigines to call their ancestors' souls back to Taiwan by demanding Japan remove their names from memorial plaques at Japan's Yasukuni Shrine.

It also demanded that Chen fire Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen, Coast Guard Administration Minister Syu Huei-you and Koh Se-kai, Taiwan's representative to Japan, for their inability to handle the disputes.
Lee Chuang-tung, deputy director-general of the MOFA's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, received a petition from the demonstrators.

The protesters then proceeded to the Taipei office of the Interchange Association, Japan's representative office in Taiwan, where they made a strong protest by tearing down Japan's naval flag and a photo of the Yasukuni Shrine and tossing down a basket of rotten fish.
They demanded that the Japanese government immediately release Taiwan fishermen in its custody.

Fishery disputes between the two countries have escalated in recent years, with Taiwan fishing boats being repeatedly dispersed or detained by Japanese patrol vessels while operating in waters near the Tiaoyutais.
A fishing ship from Suao, in eastern Taiwan's Ilan County, is still being detained by the Japanese authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Su Tseng-chang, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will visit Washington, D.C. later this month.
It will be Su's first visit to the United States since taking the helm of the ruling party early this year.
Su, who is making use of time after the National Assembly election of May 14 and before the year-end city and county chief elections, will visit Washington June 30-July 8.

In addition to calling on the Republican National Committee and the Democratic National Committee, he will also call on government officials, congressmen and think thanks, as well as Taiwanese expatriates who support the DPP.
Su will deliver a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a noted think tank, July 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHERRY FAVORITE NATIVE FLOWER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan cherry has been chosen as the favorite native flower species in national forest parks, according to the results of a poll unveiled Friday.
The Taiwan pleione was second and the Taiwan phalaenopsis was third favorite, the poll also shows.

The Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture conducted the poll in April in the national forest parks to enhance the public understanding of the indigenous flowers of Taiwan. More than 20,000 visitors to the parks and 10,000 Internet surfers took part in the polling.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WISHES TO STRENGTHEN EXCHANGES WITH STOCKHOLM: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei City wishes to strengthen exchanges with the Swedish capital of Stockholm in its bid to develop itself as an international metropolis, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.
Ma made the remarks after talks with Stockholm Mayor Barry Andersson that formed part of the 2005 International Conference Series organized by the Taipei city government.
At the meeting, Ma and Andersson exchanged views on how city residents can participate in urban development.

Andersson briefed Ma about Stockholm's population structure, economic situation and the sources of tax income, stressing that his main policy is to develop Stockholm as an eco-friendly city with sustainable development.
Ma told Andersson that although Taipei and Stockholm are quite different in many aspects, the two mayors have much in common on how to efficiently govern cities.
Recalling his visit to Stockholm in 2000, Ma hailed the city as a highly developed information metropolis with fascinating scenery and unique architecture.
To allow his Swedish guests to have a better understanding of Taipei, Ma talked about the city's cultural, transport, environmental and information development.
Expressing his welcome to Andersson's visit, Ma said Taipei should keep strengthening exchanges with other cities that perform well in cultural, architectural and urban planning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RED CROSS TO HELP 50 STUDENTS FROM INDONESIA STUDY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China will offer financial aid to help 50 students from tsunami affected areas in Aceh, Indonesia, to finish their university education in Taiwan, president of the organization Hau Lung-bin said Friday.
The decision was made after a visit to Aceh in March by Taipei City advisor Lin Cheng-hsiou following the earthquakes and ensuing tsunami in December.
Lin found that many students there still have been unable to continue their education several months after the tsunami, prompting him to solicit the help of the Red Cross.
Hau said that the recipients of the financial aid will not necessarily be ethnic Chinese, but he added that they will be given priority.

A group of 20 students from Aceh visited Jin Wen Institute of Technology and the ROC Red Cross earlier that day. After learning that the ROC Red Cross will offer them NT$15,000 for monthly spending and housing, one girl expressed her deep gratitude.

Wu Hsiao-mei, a 17-year-old girl who lost her mother in the tsunami and whose father still has not recovered from injuries he suffered at that time, said she hopes to study biotechnology in Taiwan after seeing for herself the progress of the country.
Wu said she hopes to help her hometown in Aceh after finishing her university education in Taiwan.
Lin said he will arrange several visits for the Indonesian students to other Taiwan universities in the next few days.

Meanwhile, it was reported that the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has established a cooperation project with an Indonesian Buddhist foundation to help tsunami-affected people reconstruct their hometown and assist their children to have a better learning environment.

After the disaster, Tzu Chi sent many voluntary workers to Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand for post-disaster efforts, offering money for the construction of houses and donating tents, food and clothes to the affected people.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROOF TO SHOW PRESIDENT SET UP ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING: COURT

TEXT.P: Defeated presidential candidate Lien Chan and his running mate James Soong have provided insufficient evidence to back their claim that President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu set up last year's election-eve shooting of themselves, the Supreme Court ruled Friday.

Chen and Lu staging the shooting to give them an advantage in the March 20 election was claimed by Lien and Soong as one of the reasons that their re-election should be nullified. The case was rejected by the Supreme Court.
According to the verdict, the Taiwan High Court has determined that a wound to Chen's abdomen was caused by a gun.

However, as the shooter and weapon have not been found, it remains unknown as to how the president was shot, if one or two shooters were involved, if one gun or two guns were used, or from what angle and distance the shots were fired. Therefore, it is difficult to judge if the wound suffered by Chen was caused by a set-up shooting.

The Supreme Court said a stunt conducted by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Shuai Hua-min lacked credibility because his so-called "test" used a pig in a static state as a target, which was different from the situation in which Chen was shot -- he was standing in a moving jeep and the weapon used in the test was not similar to the type used in Chen's shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODS CLAIM 13 LIVES, CAUSE OVER NT$1.8 BILLION IN LOSSES

TEXT.P: Floods caused by torrential rain over the last six days in southern Taiwan have claimed 13 lives and caused damage worth NT$1.87 billion (US$59.71 million) to the agricultural sector, according to the latest official reports released Friday.
The agricultural losses are the largest since June 1998 when heavy downpours caused NT$1.91 billion in agricultural losses.

The Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center said that as of Friday morning, one person was missing in Pingtung County, while four people were reported dead in Tainan County, another four in Chiayi County, three in Kaohsiung County, and two in Pingtung.

In terms of red alerts over mudslides and landslides, a total of 172 rivers and creeks are listed in the warning, putting at risk over 92 villages in 33 townships. Yunlin County was also pounded heavily by downpours since June 12, according to the latest information of the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture (COA).
COA statistics show that as of Friday afternoon, crop damage had reached NT$1.05 billion, while fishery losses amounted to NT$623.27 million and livestock losses had reached NT$183.83 million.

The council allotted NT$420 million Friday to flood-affected areas, including Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan and Pingtung counties and Tainan City, to support farmers, while offering low-interest loans to flood victims, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER LAUDS PRESIDENT'S PROPOSED REPORT AS LEAP FOR DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker lauded President Chen Shui-bian's proposed national security report Friday as a big leap in the country's democracy.

Hours after a presidential aide announced that Chen will issue the country's first national security report later this summer, DPP Legislator Chen Chin-jun said it is the responsibility of the popularly elected president to give this report to the people.
Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-pao said it is only natural for the president to report to the people on incidents concerning national security.
Instead of giving reports regularly, Lai said, the president should present a report whenever there is an incident of national concern.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Mark M.H. Ho said the president's national security report should cover only issues about territory and sovereignty, with everything else dealt with in the premier's administrative report to the Legislative Yuan.

Opposition People First Party lawmaker Chen Chih-pin said the president should do this earlier, adding that president might as well present his report to the Legislative Yuan, which he said represents the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES OPPOSITION TO SIT IN EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh promised Friday to solve the problem of flooding in Taiwan as long as the legislature sits in an extraordinary session and approves an NT$80 billion (US$2.55 billion) special budget for flood control.
The premier's call was all the more urgent as southern Taiwan was inundated again Friday after a week of torrential rain.

Noting that there is hardly a year goes by without flooding in Taiwan, the premier said the taxpayers' money would be better spent on flood protection than on helping the victims of flooding every year.

The premier said the NT$80 billion to be used to dredge flood-prone rivers, build levees and pumping stations in low-lying areas around the island over eight years will pale in comparison to the NT$70 billion used to tame the Keelung River in northern Taiwan alone.

By sitting for an extra eight to 10 days, the premier said, the legislature will be able to approve the budgets for flood-prevention projects and an arms purchase program, as well as several other bills ungently needed by his administration.

In support of the premier's call, Legislator William Lai, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative whip, announced that his caucus will present a motion June 20 for an extraordinary session.
The motion has already been signed by all 89 DPP lawmakers, far more than the 57 sponsors required for such a motion, Lai said.
In addition to the two budgets mentioned by the premier, Lai said his caucus will ask for action on four other bills during the extra session.

Noting that the main opposition Kuomintang is engrossed in the election of its chairman, Lai said his caucus wanted to call for an extra session after the KMT's July 16 election but was forced to request it sooner because of the flooding.
However, the premier's call was snubbed by the opposition People First Party (PFP).

Branding the premier's call a red herring, PFP legislative whip Lee Yung-ping pointed out that the NT$80 billion budget, even if it is approved now, will not be appropriated until next year and that it makes no sense to ram the budget bill through the legislature in an extraordinary session.
Saying the premier is trying to build public pressure against the opposition, Lee said the PFP will not yield to the threat.

Also, the PFP whip said, the budget for flood-prevention projects should be prepared as part of the government's general budget rather than a special budget, which is free from a legal ceiling on the government's capability to raise loans.

Lee said the legislature has already approved NT$212 billion-worth of special budgets asked by the DPP government in the last five years, and there are still NT$610 billion-worth of special budgets pending in the legislature, which will become a heavy financial burden for the next generation and will inevitably result in a tax hike.

She said the DPP government should incorporate the NT$80 million budget into the government's regular budget and present it to the Legislature Yuan in the next session later this year rather than calling for an extra legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONCERNED OVER CHINA'S MILITARY MODERNIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 16 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: United States Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Thursday that the U.S. has growing concerns over China's military modernization.

Replying to questions raised at a State Department special briefing on an upcoming trip she will make to the Middle East and Europe, Rice said there is a rising concern about military modernization in China.

"While we recognize and believe very strongly that the goal of everyone has to be to integrate China as fully into the international system as possible and to try and create conditions in which China is a positive force, it is also entirely appropriate to be concerned that there is a major military escalation of China's capability," she noted.
She also expressed Washington's concern over Israel's supply of military technology to China and claimed that Israel has the responsibility to be sensitive to these concerns.
The U.S. has a close defense cooperation with Israel, Rice stressed, adding that it also has the primary responsibility for defense in the Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TO PATROL TAIWAN'S EXCLUSIVE ECONOMIC ZONE

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) will allow legislators to board its patrol boats when they patrol the country's 200-mile exclusive economic zone sometime next week, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Joanna Lei said Friday.

After a meeting with CGA chief Shi Hwei-yow, Lei quoted him as promising to offer legislators the opportunity to see in person that the coast guard is pulling its weight in defending the country's economic zone.
However, Shi was cited as saying that the patrol mission will not cover the controversial waters around the Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Japan, China and Taiwan.
The CGA is under great pressure to protect Taiwan fishermen, as Japanese patrol boats have prevented them from operating near the Tiaoyutais.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 18, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1155: Frederick I "Barbarossa" is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Adrian IV.
1812: The U.S. Congress approves a declaration of war on Great Britain over trade restrictions.
1815: British and Prussian forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington and Field Marshall Gerhard von Blucher finally defeat France's Napoleon Bonaparte in a bloody battle at Waterloo, in Belgium. The total number of casualties on both sides is estimated to be 62,000.
1900: With the anti-foreign Boxer Rebellion already under way in China, the Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court orders all foreigners executed.
1927: Chang Tso-lin, head of the separatist Fengtien Army in China's northeast (Manchuria), sets up a military government in Beijing and declares himself marshal.
1928: Amelia Earhart, a 30-year-old American aviator, becomes the first woman to fly across the Atlantic when the tri-engine plane "Friendship," in which she is a passenger, lands at Burny Port.
1940: Charles de Gaulle, founder of the Free French, makes a radio appeal from London urging his fellow countrymen to continue to resist the Germans.
1942: The United States formally begins its Manhattan Project, the manufacturing of the first atomic bomb.
1944: Changsha, capital of China's Hunan Province, falls to invading Japanese troops who violate the Geneva Protocol by using poison gas in battle.
1944: US Vice President Henry Wallace visits China.
1950: Chen Yi, former top administrator of Taiwan province, is executed for sedition.
1960: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrives in Taipei for a state visit.
1965: Typhoon Dinah hits eastern Taiwan, killing more than 100 people and injuring over 200.
1965: Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky vows to militarily defeat the Viet Cong after assuming office as premier of South Vietnam.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Dr. Robert M. Lumiamsky, president, and Dr. Gordon B. Turner, vice president, of the American Council of Learned Societies.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter and Soviet President Leonid Brezhnev sign the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) documents in Vienna.
1980: General Jose Dolores Herrera, El Salvador's ambassador to the ROC, presents his government's Gold Medal of Great Achievements to General Kao Huei-yuan, defense minister, Admiral Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, General Wang Sheng, director of the General Political Warfare Department, and General Wang Yung-shu, director of the National Security Bureau.
1981: The Executive Yuan appoints Dr. Yen Chen-hsing, president of National Taiwan University, as chairman of the Atomic Energy Council.
1982: Republic of China Premier Sun Yun-suan instructs government agencies to study the feasibility of setting up a free trade zone in Taiwan.
1986: Chang Tung-sheng, a noted ROC wrestler known as the "Master of Wrestling," dies of cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Admiral Soong Chang-chih (Sung Chang-chih) as the new ambassador to Panama.
1993: Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa loses a crucial no-confidence vote and dissolves parliament to trigger snap elections in July.
1997: Pol Pot, the fugitive Cambodian Khmer Rouge leader, surrenders to his former comrades.
1999: Florencio Marin, Belize minister of the sugar industry and local government and Latin American affairs, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
2000: The opposition Kuomintang passes a party reform package that includes provisions for the popular election of its party chairman following a nationwide party membership verification and registration process.
2001: The ROC breaks off diplomatic relations with Macedonia after the Balkan state made its intention clear that it would establish formal ties with China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is really a bad situation when a man simply eats his meals without applying his mind to anything at all during the whole day. Are there no such things as gambling and games of skill? To do even one of those things is better than to do nothing at all."

The years 1998 to 2003 saw Singapore reel from one economic shock after another. Yet incomes rose overall by 1.1 percent a year.
Most households were better off at the end of the period, with more living in bigger homes with the latest gadgets. Spending patterns shifted, suggesting a more affluent society willing to fork out more on health care and communications, and papering themselves with more air travel and art and culture classes.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singaporean's incomes and standard of living is up.

The Household Expenditure Survey released yesterday by the Department of Statistics is conducted once every five years to provide data for the compilation of the Consumer Price Index.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY A DEMOCRATIC CHINA CAN ENSURE CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A key question for the development of cross-Taiwan Strait ties is whether China can rise peacefully and become a democratic and rational country, a high-ranking official of the Presidential Office said Saturday.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the office, made the remarks while addressing an academic seminar on "constitutional amendments and cross-strait relations" at National Taiwan University.
Yu said that the constitutional amendments proffered by the Legislature last August and vetted by the now defunct National Assembly on June 7 are significant steps on the road to reform in Taiwan.

Taiwan's future development is closely related to cross-strait relations, he said; however, problems related to this are not the sole arbiter of what the future will bring; rather, whether or not China can meaningfully traverse the path down the road to democracy and rationality in dealing with Taiwan will determine, to a large part, whether Taiwan and China can resolve their political differences in a peaceful and appropriate manner. Taiwan's further democratization will surely be a catalyst for the Chinese to follow, he added.

"So far, economic development in China has not successfully pushed the country forward toward democratization; on the contrary, it has strengthened the leadership's control over the people, " he said.

Touching on China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, Yu said that this sort of non-pacifistic and aggressive behavior not only defies the U.S. principle of resolving cross-strait problems peacefully, but intensifies tensions in the Strait. Moreover, he added, this could be a ticking time bomb threatening regional stability.

Talking about Beijing's recent use of nationalism to stir up anti-Japan sentiments, the official said that although nationalism is not negative, one-party dictatorship and the lack of democratic supervision and freedoms of the press and speech in China result in its people being easily manipulated and can lead to the development of nationalism for an irrational end.

He also commented on media reports that China might send troops to Kyrgyzstan, saying that if this is true, it will be the first time that China will have sent military forces in peacetime to a foreign country, which represents the first step of Chinese military expansion beyond its borders.

"As I said in my speeches delivered in Washington, D.C. and New York while meeting with think tanks last month, as China rises, economic reforms cannot ensure that it will become a responsible superpower, " Yu noted, adding that "I believe that the key point of maintaining peace in East Asia is China's democratization."
"Without a democratic China, there will be no peace in East Asia and there exists now an urgent need to accelerate China's democratic reforms," he said.

Only with more democratization in Taiwan can China's democratic development be helped, he concluded, adding that the emergence of a democratic China will then be able to guarantee the peaceful co-existence of the two sides of the Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CAL CARGO AIRCRAFT WITH ADVERTISEMENT ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The first China Airlines (CAL) A330-300 cargo plane adorned with Taiwan's ubiquitous butterfly orchid on its fuselage arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Saturday.
The new design on the aircraft is part of a cooperative effort between CAL and the Council of Agriculture to promote Taiwan's high-quality agricultural products.
CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-chung and Deputy Council of Agriculture Minister Lee Chiang-chuan presided over a ceremony to welcome the arrival of the plane from France.

Lee said that butterfly orchids are the large flower export from Taiwan. Last year, Taiwan exported US$23.39 million in butterfly orchids mainly to Japan, the United States, the Netherlands, Hong Kong and China, he added.
This A330-300 is the fourth of eight cargo planes ordered from Airbus. It will begin commercial flights to Japan June 24, according to CAL.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ENVOYS INVITED TO ATTEND EUROPEAN CONFERENCE IN POLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 17 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan officials stationed in Poland took part in a two-day conference on international partnerships Friday in Elblag, Poland, at the invitation of the city government.

Over 50 people attended the conference to discuss issues on city-to-city exchanges on economics, culture and tourism. Most participants are from European countries, including Britain, France, Germany, Lithuania, Ukraine, Russia and others. Taiwan was the only country outside Europe invited to attend the meeting, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Poland.
Wang Wan-li, head of the office's business division, delivered a report on Taiwan-Poland relations and Taiwan's current state in economics and trade at the conference that will run through Saturday.
Elblag, with a population of roughly 130,000, is 60 kilometers from Gdansk and is only 50 kilometer from the Russian border. It is the 22nd sister city of Tainan, southern Taiwan.
Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair visited Elblag in April last year to forge the sisterhood relationship.
Elblag Mayor Henryk Slonina, who visited Tainan in February, said he hopes the two cities can continue with existing efforts to expand mutual exchanges between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWIM ACROSS PENGHU BAY KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 2005 Swim Across Penghu Bay kicked off Saturday, attracting 1,084 athletes from around Taiwan, officials of the Penghu County Government said.
The first day of competition was divided into 3,000-meter and 500-meter races, with Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening.
The youngest swimmier was an eight-year-old boy and the oldest was an 84-year-old woman. Several television stars also brought their families to compete in the annual event.
Li Wei won the gold in the 3,000-meter event at 43 minutes, followed by Chen Kuan at 58 minutes, and Wu Wen-bi at 71 minutes.
Sunday's competition will focus on the 6,000-meter race, with 60 athletes competing.
