DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TALKS TO RESPECT GOVERNMENT AUTHORITY: FARMERS' ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association (TPFA) delegates will abide by the country's laws and respect the government's authority while discussing details of fruit exports to China with Chinese representatives next week, TPFA Chairman Liu Chuan-chung said Saturday.
According to Liu, who is also an opposition Kuomintang legislator, neither side will release any statement after the talks.

He was responding to a media report that the TPFA will send delegates to China next week to hold talks with Chinese representatives on details of fruit exports to China and that Taiwan fruits are expected to be granted tariff-free treatment by Beijing by July.

The report said the TPFA, instead of signing an agreement, might release a joint statement with China's Ministry of Commerce after the talks to bypass Taiwan laws that prohibit civic organizations from negotiating or establishing an agreement with Chinese authorities without the government's authorization.

Liu claimed the trip is being arranged at the invitation of the Cross-Strait Association on Trade Exchanges, a non-profit organization set up by China's Ministry of Commerce, and that the talks will be between two civic organizations.
He said the TPFA is only trying to help Taiwan farmers sell their fruits in China, which he called a "purely business activity."
The lawmaker stressed that he is a law-abiding person and will not do anything detrimental to national interests.
However, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) does not approve of the move.

William C.T. Lai, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, pointed out that the government has decided to authorize the Taiwan External Trade Development Council to negotiate with China under the World Trade Organization framework on details concerning the sale of Taiwan agricultural products to China.

But China is trying to deal with the issue as some kind of domestic transaction and to downgrade the status of Taiwan to become a local government under China by opting to hold talks with the TPFA, Lai said, urging the TPFA not to fall into the trap set by Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LINYUAN RESIDENTS PROTEST CHINESE PETROLEUM CORP REFINERY EXPANSION

TEXT.P: Hundreds of residents in Linyuan township, Kaohsiung County, protested Saturday against plans by the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to expand a refinery in the township.
More than 600 people, organized by a local anti-pollution association, gathered in front of the oil refinery.
Police blocked the entrance to prevent protestors from delivering a petition and isolated scuffles broke out.

Linyuan township chief Huang Chau-cheng said since the CPC set up the oil refinery over 30 years ago, it has resulted in many disputes over environmental protection, while pollution it created has caused damage to local fish breeders. Residents can't endure the factory's existence any longer, he added.
The confrontation between protestors and the police ended after a CPC security official took the petition from the protestors.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD CHIEF ON BOARD A PATROL BOAT TO SUPPORT FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Shi Hwei-yow was on board a patrol boat sailing from Suao, Ilan County Saturday to inspect fishing zones off northeastern Taiwan and to symbolically claim the country's exclusive economic zone.

Shi's action came after strong criticism that the government has not duly assumed his responsibility in protecting the country's fishermen, who have been frequently chased, detained or even prosecuted by the Japanese government, with their boats sometimes being impounded, for operating in the overlapped economic zones of the two countries.
Shi said he will also listen to the opinions of fishermen.
The CGA will keep sending patrol boats within the country's economic zone to protect the interests of Taiwanese fishermen in the future, Shi added.

Meanwhile, it was reported that the country's Ministry of National Defense (MND) will also send a patrol ship June 21 to disputed waters to inspect the MND's patrol works there and demonstrate support for the country's fishermen, with Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye and opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang on board.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODING CAUSES RECORD HIGH IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: The recent flooding in southern Taiwan has caused damage worth NT$1.95 billion (US$62 million) to the country's agricultural sector, surpassing the old record posted for a summer downpour in June 1998, in which agricultural damage reached NT$1.91 billion.
According to the latest statistics released by the Council of Agriculture (COA) Saturday, crop losses reached NT$1.08 billion, with 41,505 hectares of farmland affected.

The heavy rains caused damage to the country's livestock industry at NT$183 million, the fishery sector at NT$676 million, and the forestry industry at NT$2.52 million, with losses to equipment and infrastructure totalling NT$10 million, COA officials said.
The COA will offer subsidies and low-interest loans to affected farmers, the officials added.
Meanwhile, the Central Weather Bureau lifted its warning for heavy rains at 4:00 p.m. Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON GETS MARRIED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son, Chih-chung, married his fiancee, Huang Jui-ching, in Taipei Saturday.

The wedding was held in the morning according to Taiwanese tradition, followed by a banquet at noon at the Sheraton Taipei Hotel where around 500 guests including a number of top government officials and business leaders joined the first family in celebrating the marriage.

Addressing the banquet, President Chen said his son is forming his own family at such a young age probably because there is a tradition of early marriage in his family and he told Chih-chung to be responsible for everything he does from now on as getting married means " becoming a grown-up."

The president said the heavy rains that triggered severe flooding in southern Taiwan in the week leading up to the wedding served as a good reminder for the new couple that there are still a lot of unfortunate people who need care and help.
Lastly, the president advised his son not to follow in his footsteps and enter politics, saying his wife, Wu Shu-jen, is bound to a wheelchair for the rest of her life because of his choice.

Chih-chung, 26, obtained a master's degree in law from the University of California at Berkeley in May. The bride is a pianist who holds a master's degree in piano performance from the Taipei National University of the Arts. The couple will travel to the United States to continue their studies after their marriage.
The Presidential Office previously announced that the couple will donate NT$2 million (NT$63,897) in cash to three charitable organizations in the southern city of Tainan to mark their wedding.

According to the Taipei City Police Department, approximately 300 police officers were assigned to maintain order in areas surrounding the president's official residence and Sheraton Taipei Hotel, because several civic groups were planning to take the opportunity of the wedding to stage a demonstration or try to present a petition to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: 174 LICENSED GROUPS OF STREET PERFORMERS TO START BUSINESS JULY 1

TEXT.P: A total of 174 teams and individual street performers have passed the Taipei City Government's first qualification test and review to operate legally, officials of the city bureau of cultural affairs said Saturday.
At the end of June, the recognized street artists will be granted official licenses and they will be able to start performing on the streets of Taipei on July 1, the officials added.

The groups and individuals, include 87 in the field of performing arts, 77 groups in visual arts and 10 in arts and crafts, were selected from 333 hopefuls in the official review, which was conducted in May at the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center.

The review was not only centered on creativity, but also demanded that participants be able to engage in interactions with the audience, officials of the bureau said, noting that most musical performers failed to pass the review because of their reluctance to interact with the public.
The test and review was part of the city government's efforts to raise the artistic level of street performing activities, according to the bureau. (Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAN PARLIAMENTARY SPEAKER TO ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Honduran parliamentary speaker Porfirio Lobo Sosa is slated to arrive in Taiwan Sunday for an official visit at the head of a four-member delegation, according to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
During their stay in Taiwan, they are scheduled to pay visits to President Chen Shui-bian, legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Hwang, the official said.

They are also slated to visit the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Police Department under the Taipei City Government, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, the Taoyuan Irrigation Association, the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and Taipei 101 Tower, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FRUITS COULD BE EXPORTED TO FUJIAN VIA KINMEN AND MATSU

TEXT.P: Taiwan fruits could be shipped to Fujian province via the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, Kaohsiung Customs under the Ministry of Finance said Saturday.

After China's recent announcement that it would be willing to open it's markets to Taiwan fruits, Legislator Wu Chen-tian from Kinmen and Legislator Tsao Erh-chung from Matsu have urged the government to designate the two outlying islands as gateways for export of Taiwan's produce to the mainland, saying that the two already have direct transportation links with Fujian province.

Kaohsiung Customs cited the views of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the nation's top mainland policy planning agency, as saying that if the fruits are for certified Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland, they could go to the mainland through the two outlying islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' ASSOCIATION COULD VIOLATE LAW WITH CHINA TALKS: MAC

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association (TPFA) could violate the law if they talk with China on matters concerning the exercise of public authority without prior authorization, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a news release Saturday.
The MAC was responding to reports that the TPFA, at the invitation of the Cross-Strait Association on Trade Exchange, will go to China to discuss Taiwan fruits being exported to China.

The MAC said that if the TPFA only wants to exchange views with China, the government will not oppose such a move, but if the association, without prior authorization, go to China to consult on matters that need to be conducted via public authorities, then the government will have to deal with the situation according to the law.

The MAC noted that the government has not placed any restrictions on fruits exported to China. But it pointed out that China should take the initiative to improve such problems as high tariffs, poor marketing networks and warehousing facilities.

Premier Frank Hsieh said earlier in the week that the government will commission the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to help with the communications and arrangement of such matters as tariffs, quarantines, inspections and customs clearance with the other side of the Taiwan Strait, the MAC noted.

You Ying-lung, MAC vice chairman and spokesman, said that professionalism is required in negotiating issues regarding agricultural products, and TAITRA could integrate the TPFA and other related agencies to form a strong negotiation team.
"The government has professionalism as its primary concern, " You said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION POLITICIAN PROTESTS COURT RULING ON CLAIM AGAINST CHEN

TEXT.P: Taipei City Councilor Lee Ching-yuan demonstrated in the capital city on Saturday to protest a court ruling on his infidelity claim against then-presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian five years ago.

Lee from the opposition New Party and around 200 supporters -- all wearing surgical masks with a question mark on them -- marched silently around the streets surrounding the Presidential Office in a symbolic move to fight for freedom of speech.
In a book he released in March 2000, Lee claimed that Chen had an extra-marital affair with one of his female assistants.
Chen later sued Lee for attempting to influence the results of the presidential election by making false accusations against him.

Early this month, the Taiwan High Court sentenced Lee to six month behind bars, with his civil rights deprived for two years, for violating the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Law. Lee has decided to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court.
Lee will lose his post as Taipei City councilor if the ruling is upheld by the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAPTAIN OF TAIWANESE FISHING BOAT DETAINED BY JAPANESE COAST GUARD

TEXT.P: The captain of a Taiwanese fishing boat was detained by the Japanese coast guard early Saturday morning for illegally fishing in Japanese waters off Miyako Island, Okinawa, according to Japanese police.

A police officer from Okinawa Prefecture told CNA that the Taiwanese fishing boat "Chinmingtsai No. 11" was spotted by a Japanese patrol ship Friday night in waters 65 kilometers off the east coast of Miyako Island, which is within Japan's exclusive economic zone.

The Taiwanese fishing boat, with a captain and four crew, refused to stop for inspection, and was finally apprehended by a Japanese patrol ship Saturday early morning, which was two hours after it fled, the police said.
The captain, Chen Teh-liang, admitted that he was fishing illegally, according to Japanese police.

Michel Lu, spokesman of the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said the fishing boat was operating in waters 35 nautical miles off the east coast of Miyako Island, which is beyond Taiwan's exclusive economic zone of 200-nautical miles, and was therefore detained by Japanese police.
However, he said that officials of the ROC representative office stationed in Okinawa had contacted Japanese authorities in the hope that the captain can be released on bail as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WANTS TO COOPERATE, NOT TO MERGE WITH DPP: TSU CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union hopes to cooperate with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , but does not want to merge with the ruling party or be wiped out by it, TSU Chairman Shu Chin-chiang said Saturday.

Shu made the remarks when he went to the central Taiwan city of Taichung to attend a congress of the TSU Taichung chapter and speak about the relation between the two ally parties in the year-end elections.
Shu said that the TSU is barely four-year old, and it will not overreach its bounds, adding that the focus now is to lay a solid foundation and to grow step by step.

On the "three-in-one" -- or city and county head, city and county counselor and township and village head -- year-end elections, Shu said the focus will be placed on the city and county councilor elections, although it will also not be absent from the city and county ones, as well as township and village head elections.

The election campaign strategy will be focusing on its advantages and not an across-the-board campaign so as to sabotage the winning chances of the DPP, he said. He stressed that the TSU is an independent party, but will side with its ally the DPP and try to gain a win-win situation through cooperation.
But the cooperation should not take the form of merging with the DPP or being wiped out by it, Shu said, adding that the DPP should give the TSU breathing space or Taiwan people will not accept it.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: MasterCard Says 40 Million Files Are Put at Risk.
MasterCard International reported Saturday that more than 40 million credit card accounts of all brands might have been exposed to fraud through a computer security breach at a payment processing company, perhaps the largest case of stolen consumer data to date. Maste rCard said its analysts and law enforcement officials had identified a pattern of fraudulent charges that were traced to an intrusion at CardSystems Solutions of Tucson, Ariz., which processes more than $15 billion in payments for small to midsize merchants and financial institutions each year. About 20 million Vis a and 13.9 million MasterCard accounts were compromised; the other accounts belonged to American Express or Discover cardholders. The accounts affected included credit cards and certain kinds of debit cards. The F.B.I. said it was investigating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE CONVENES MEETING IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 18 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce of North America (TCCNA) is convening its annual meeting in New Brunswick, New Jersey, from June 17-19, with the participation of more than 650 trade representatives scattering around the region.
The TCCNA, a non-profit organization established in 1987, will choose its new president at the event.

Andrew L.Y. Hsia, representative of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, gave a banquet Friday night in honor of the participants and said his office is willing to better serve the Taiwanese businessmen with operations in the region.

Republic of China Minister of Finance Lin Chuan will be invited to deliver a speech at the TCCNA meeting Saturday, and Minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chang Fu-mei will host a dinner for the participants later that night.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO BOARD FRIGATE TO LEND SUPPORT FOR FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday that he will board a military vessel next Tuesday to sail to Taiwan's exclusive economic zone off northeastern Taiwan to lend support to fishermen.

Wang recently invited the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and related government agencies for a discussion on the fishing disputes triggered by overlapping economic zones between Taiwan and Japan, and the MND decided to send a frigate June 21 to waters near a disputed part of the East China Sea to allow lawmakers to inspect first hand how the administration is protecting Taiwan fishermen there.
Defense Minister Lee Jye invited Wang to board the frigate to show support for the country's fishermen as well as proclaim Republic of China sovereignty over its 200-nautical mile economic zone.
But Wang, considering his capacity as legislative speaker, said he would not board the military vessel.
However, Ilan fishermen, after learning of Wang's decision, urged that he board the ship to deliver his promise to support the fishermen, and Wang changed his mind.

Wang, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and has registered to vie for the July 16 KMT chairman election, will draw lots for the election number next Tuesday.
But Wang said that drawing lots will be his personal matter, and the national interests come first.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P:
In CEP-8, the "cargo aircraft" mentioned in the story should read only "aircraft." A corrected version follows:
FIRST CAL AIRCRAFT WITH ADVERTISEMENT ARRIVES IN TAIWAN
Taipei, June 18 (CNA) The first China Airlines (CAL) A330-300 plane adorned with Taiwan's ubiquitous butterfly orchid on its fuselage arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Saturday.
The new design on the aircraft is part of a cooperative effort between CAL and the Council of Agriculture to promote Taiwan's high-quality agricultural products.
CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-chung and Deputy Council of Agriculture Minister Lee Chiang-chuan presided over a ceremony to welcome the arrival of the plane from France.

Lee said that butterfly orchids are the large flower export from Taiwan. Last year, Taiwan exported US$23.39 million in butterfly orchids mainly to Japan, the United States, the Netherlands, Hong Kong and China, he added.
This A330-300 is the fourth of eight A330-300s ordered from Airbus. It will begin commercial flights to Japan June 24, according to CAL.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL AUTHORITIES REVEAL POSITION ON EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Regarding a report of representatives of a provincial farmers' association to visit China next week for talks on Taiwan fruit exports to China, the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Saturday unveiled its position in dealing with the issue.

The position is made of "one principle, three arrangements, " COA officials explained, stating that the principle is that the council takes all-out efforts to promote agricultural exports, and the sales to China are only a part of the COA's global marketing strategies.

Under the principle, the COA initiated three arrangements for the export drive, which include designating the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to take charge of the sale of Taiwan agricultural products to worldwide markets including China, while allowing local farmers' associations only to serve as suppliers.

The other two arrangements are namely forming a professional team along with the Mainland Affairs Council to conduct negotiations with relevant Chinese authorities on authority problems concerning the exports to China, such as tariffs, quarantines, quality inspections and customs clearance, while asking TAITRA to assist in the arrangement of relevant talks; and promoting the opening of cross-strait talks on "non-stop" cargo charter flights, which will ensure the freshness of high-priced fruits or other fresh agricultural products that Taiwan exports to China during shipment, according to the COA.

The COA underlined that members of farmers' associations around the country should respect existing laws while dealing with issues on cross-strait agricultural exchanges, referring to the reported plan of the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association to hold talks with Chinese representatives on details of fruit exports to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.9 MAGNITUDE EARTHQUAKE RATTLES TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 4.9 magnitude earthquake hit Taiwan at 5: 31 p.m. Saturday, with the epicenter located 10.6 kilometers southwest of Hualien, eastern Taiwan, according to the Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The seismologists said the epicenter was located only 2.5 kilometers under the ground, the quake had an intensity of 5.0 in Hualien, 2.0 in Taichung, Nantou and Ilan.
No casualties or damage was reported, according to the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA HEAD REAFFIRMS RESOLVE TO PROTECT FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Shi Hwei-yow reaffirmed Saturday the administration's resolve to protect fishermen and that it will expand protection areas for fishermen in line with their needs.

Shi made the remarks upon his return to Suao, Ilan, after he led officials and representatives of the fishermen aboard a 1,800-ton vessel on an inspection of waters near a disputed area in which economic zones between Taiwan and Japan overlap.
He stressed that as long as fishermen operate within the legal boundaries, their safety will be guaranteed.
Shi earlier met with representatives of the Suao fishermen's association and listened to their grievances.

Shi's move followed recent criticism that the government has not duly assumed his responsibility in protecting the country's fishermen, who have been frequently chased, detained or even prosecuted by the Japanese government, with their boats sometimes being impounded, for operating in the overlapped economic zones of the two countries.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao protested June 10 in waters 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships from the disputed area.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO TAKE MEASURES TO REDUCE CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS

TEXT.P: The government will take various measures to reduce Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Saturday.

Greenhouse gas emissions have become an important international issue since Feb. 16 when the Kyoto Protocol went into effect, Ho said, adding that her ministry is to organize a national energy conference June 20-21, inviting experts of the industrial sector, scholars and government officials to discuss structural adjustments for the use of energy in Taiwan and policies and measures that should be take to meet the requirements of the Kyoto Protocol.
The government will continue to promote the use of reusable energy and a cleaner liquefied natural gas, while upgrading the conservation and efficiency of energy, she went on.
It is estimated that Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions will increase to 530 million tons in 2025 from 270 million tons recorded last year if the country does nothing from now on, Ho said.
The government hopes that Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions will be reduced by 170 million tons from the estimated figure by improving the use of energy, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER URGES BUSINESSES TO BE INNOVATIVE

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses should take advantage of their ability to quickly upgrade and promote innovative research and development in Taiwan to compete with the rest of the world, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Saturday.

Ho said the government will also work to establish free trade agreements with other countries and take part in international economic and trade organizations to assist local businesses to advance their global market footprint.
The minister made the remarks while giving a speech on Taiwan's economic development and outlook to a group of students at National Taiwan University.
Ho noted that Taiwan, with its exports amounting to US$174 billion in 2004, is the world's 15th-largest trading country.
While 70 percent of the exports by Taiwan are raw materials and parts and components, 25 percent are machinery, and only 5 percent are agricultural products, Ho pointed out.
Therefore, she said, China's policy to open up agricultural imports from Taiwan is not expected to contribute much to the country's economy.
On Taiwan's chipmaking industry, Ho said Taiwan, which is the world's leading contract chipmaker, has 21 foundries for eight-inch wafers, six for 12-inch wafers and four others under construction.

Despite the investments by some Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers in China, the production volume of Taiwan is still far ahead of China, she said, urging the public not to worry that these investment projects will hollow out Taiwan's industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 19 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, June 19:

08: 00, Cabinet Secretary-general Lee Ying-yuan will attend a long-distance swimming activity organized by the Popularized Swimming Association of Taiwan to be held at the Feitsui Bay Beach in Taipei County.
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will inspect an agricultural products distribution center at Shulin, Taipei County.

14: 30, Taiwan Think Tank Chairman Chen Poh-chih will give a lecture at the second student activity center of National Taiwan University.
16: 30, Former President Lee Teng-hui will attend a certificate-granting ceremony for advisors to the National Association of Lee Teng-hui Friends at Ambassador Hotel Taipei.
19: 00, Cabinet Secretary-general Lee Ying-yuan will attend the dinner party of the China Dental Association Congress 2005 at Grand Hotel Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 19, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
2000: Fifty-eight mainland Chinese were found suffocated in a truck container at an English port. They died during the trip from Belgium to Britain.
2001: Formosa Platics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching says that Taiwan should accept mainland China's "one China" principle out of consideration for its mutual benefits at this critical moment of development for the entire Chinese race.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: MasterCard security breach could hit 4 million card holders
The United Daily News: Un-inspected condoms to be unshelved from Monday.
The Liberty Times: Tyco ex-CEO and financial chief found quilty of embezzlement.
The Taiwan Daily: China forbids imports of 'money-making trees' from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY FLOTILLA COMPLETES ROUND-THE-WORLD VOYAGE

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Navy flotilla, which embarked in March on its first round-the-world voyage in a display of long-range sea power, returned to Taiwan Sunday, Navy sources reported.

Navy Commander-in-Chief Chen Pang-chih officiated at a ceremony held at the Tsuoying naval base in southern Taiwan to mark the success of the flotilla's mission and of the commencement of round-the-world navigation training.

The flotilla -- comprised of the French-built Lafayette-class frigate "Kang Ding," the U.S.-built Perry-class frigate "Wu Yi" and a logistical support vessel, with a 700-strong crew -- returned early Sunday morning to the Tsuoying base after having sailed over 55,500 kilometers in 105 days around the globe.
The naval vessels made port calls in seven countries which maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC and made refueling stops in several countries in the Indian Ocean that recognize China.

The flotilla's voyage, dubbed Taiwan's "warship diplomacy, " took it through Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean, around South Africa into the Atlantic Ocean, and then through the Caribbean and the Panama Canal, and across the Pacific Ocean. The flotilla set a ROC Navy record in terms of distance traveled. The Navy began long-distance voyage training in 1953, according to naval officers at Tsuoying.
Adm. Fan Pao-hua, who led the flotilla, said that the voyage was smooth and successful, with morale among the crew being very high.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Oil firms increase prices
With international oil prices rising to record levels, local oil companies Total Petroleum, Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corporation and Caltex Philippines announced respective price adjustments at a uniform P0.50 per liter for gasoline, diesel and kerosene.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: But where's Garcillano?
SO where is former Election Commissioner Virgilio Garcillano -- the man who might hold the answers to intriguing questions raised in allegedly wiretapped conversations between him and President Macapagal-Arroyo?
The Philippine Star: Erap on P2 M: I'm not that cheap
A fuming former President Joseph Estrada sneezed yesterday at police claims that former actress Laarni Enriquez paid P2 million to people involved in an alleged fresh plot to oust President Arroyo.
The Manila Times: UP Physics prof up for Nobel Prize
TWO members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences confirmed in separate messages that Prof. Edgar E. Escultura has been nominated for the 2005 Nobel Prize for Physics.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Hackers Tap 40 Million Credit Cards.
In the largest reported security breach of personal financial information, hackers infiltrated the computers at a Tucson credit card processing center and stole as many as 40 million card numbers, it was disclosed Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' ASSOCIATION'S REPORTED UPCOMING TALKS WITH CHINA CAUSE STORM

TEXT.P: A local farmers' group was at the center of a political storm Sunday after a local newspaper reported that the group will visit China next week to negotiate with Chinese authorities over Taiwan fruit exports to the country.

Legislator William Lai, the whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Legislative Yuan, urged the government to prosecute the leaders of the Farmers' Association of Taiwan Province to the full extent of law if they dare to enter into a pact with China on Taiwan fruit exports to the country.

Noting that the Executive Yuan has authorized the Taiwan External Trade Development Council to talk with Chinese authorities on Taiwan fruit exports, Lai said the association should abide by the government's decision and "not play into Beijing's hands" by dealing on its own with China.

Lai dismissed China's policy of allowing the import of 15 kinds of Taiwan fruits duty-free as "an attempt to alienate fruit farmers from the government, " blaming the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) for cajoling the farmers' association into contacting China.

He claimed that the KMT, whose chairman Lien Chan won the import concessions when he met with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his Chinese tour in April, is pulling strings behind the scenes, adding that the president of the farmers' association, Liu Chuan-chung, is a KMT lawmaker.
By accepting Beijing's invitation to engage in talks, Lai claimed, the farmers' association is allowing Beijing to manipulate Taiwan, which he said is dangerous for the island.

Mark M. H. He, the Taiwan Solidarity Union's legislative convener, agreed with the DPP lawmaker's view, saying that Beijing's concessions on Taiwanese fruit imports is "more of a political charm offense than an economic policy."

In light of the fact that Taiwan is an independent state, Ho said, negotiations on exports of Taiwan agricultural products to China should be held bilaterally under the framework of the World Trade Organization, adding that the farmers' association's contact with Chinese authorities will help Beijing's ploy of sidestepping Taiwan government authorities.

Meanwhile, KMT lawmaker Tseng Yung-chuan said that as a private group aimed at promoting farmers' interests, the farmers' association's efforts to explore overseas markets for local farmers should be encouraged rather than be dissuaded.

Tseng, who is the director of KMT Policy Coordination Committee, said the DPP government should give free rein to the farmers' association within the law to explore overseas markets for the benefit of local farmers.

An official from the farmers' association said his group won't encroach on the power of the government during its pending talks with China, adding that the government really has little role in the deal and can hardly prevent Taiwan fruits from entering the mainland market as long as China allows the imports.

The official, who preferred to remain anonymous, said that Taiwan exported 13,500 tons of fruit to the mainland, Hong Kong and Macau in 2004, accounting for 6 percent of Taiwan's total fruit exports, even without the government's official permission.

If the Council of Agriculture forbids fruit exports to the mainland, the official pointed out, traders can simply sell their product to Hong Kong before re-exporting it to the mainland, a move which he said is beyond the government's control.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CALM OVER FISHERY DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh appealed Sunday for calm over fishery disputes between Taiwan and Japan in their overlapping fishing grounds, saying that these disputes can be resolved via legal professionals, fishermen's associations or private organizations in a peaceful and rational manner.

Hsieh made the call after a spate of incidents in which Taiwanese fishing boats were chased and impounded by Japanese patrol boats, with some Taiwan fishermen even being prosecuted in Japanese courts. In the latest incident, the skipper of the Pingtung-registered fishing boat "Chinmingtsai No. 11" was detained by the Japanese coast guard early Saturday morning for "illegally fishing in Japanese waters off Miyako Island, Okinawa," according to Japanese police.

Hsieh reiterated the government's resolve to protect the rights and interests of Taiwan fishermen, saying that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has been handling the latest dispute via diplomatic channels.

The premier appealed to the fishermen and their families to trust the administration's determination in protecting them, but he added that there are certain limits for Taiwan's law enforcement forces in exercising their authority in the disputed areas.

A police officer from the Okinawa Prefecture told CNA that the Taiwanese fishing boat "Chinmingtsai No. 11" was spotted by a Japanese patrol vessel Friday night in waters 65 kilometers off the east coast of Miyako Island, which is within Japan's exclusive economic zone.

The "Chinmingtsai No. 11" with skipper, identified as Chen Teh-liang, and four crew members, had refused to stop for inspection and was finally apprehended by the Japanese patrol vessel two hours later, the Okinawa police said.
Chen Teh-liang, admitted that he was fishing illegally, according to Japanese police.

Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Saturday that the fishing boat was operating in waters 35 nautical miles off the east coast of Miyako Island, which is beyond Taiwan's exclusive economic zone of 200-nautical miles, and was therefore detained by Japanese police.
However, he said that officials of the ROC representative office stationed in Okinawa have contacted Japanese authorities in the hopes that the skipper can be released on bail as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Hard-Line Figure In Iran Runoff; Candidates Accuse Security Forces of Voter Intimidation.
The hard-line, working-class mayor of Tehran will face former president Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a millionaire cleric, in a runoff election for Iran's presidency next week, according to first-round results announced Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CLOSELY WATCHING JAPANESE COUNCILORS' PLANNED TIAOYUTAIS VISIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is closely watching developments regarding the planned inspection tour of the Tiaoyutai Islands by councilors from Ishigaki Island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Sunday.

The latest news reports from Japan have it that Ishigaki's city council recently passed a resolution stipulating that the Tiaoyutai Islands -- known in Japan as the Senkaku Islands, over which Taiwan, Japan and China each claim sovereignty -- are part of the administrative zone under Ishigaki City, and allowing Ishigaki city councilors to go ashore the disputed islands for inspections.
Commenting on these reports, Lu said that Japan is a democracy and that elected representatives there are free to choose their own ways to express their opinions.

While closely monitoring developments, Lu said, Taiwan's foreign ministry has repeated calls that the two countries hold talks to sort out their fishery disputes arising from overlapping economic zones, such as the area in the East China Sea and south of Okinawa, as well as the issue of sovereignty over the Tiaoyutai Islands.

Meanwhile, Premier Frank Hsieh on Sunday likened the Japanese city councilors' plan to visit the Tiaoyutais to Taiwan legislators' recent push to inspect the Tiaoyutais by frigate, saying that all these "private deeds do not necessarily reflect the ideas or resolutions of the governments."

Lu also noted that skipper Chen Teh-liang of the Pingtung-registered fishing boat "Chinmingtsai No. 11, " who was detained by the Japanese coast guard early Saturday morning for "illegally fishing in Japanese waters off Miyako Island, Okinawa, " is expected to be released along with his vessel Monday or Tuesday.
Lu added that the owners of the "Chinmingtsai No. 11" agreed Sunday to pay for Chen and the fishing vessel's release.

A police officer from the Okinawa Prefecture told CNA that the "Chinmingtsai No. 11" was spotted by a Japanese patrol vessel Friday night in waters 65 kilometers off the east coast of Miyako Island, which is within Japan's exclusive economic zone.

The "Chinmingtsai No. 11" with its skipper and four crew members aboard, had refused to stop for inspection and was finally apprehended by the Japanese patrol vessel two hours later, the Okinawa police said.
Chen Teh-liang, admitted that he was fishing illegally, according to Japanese police.

MOFA spokesman Lu also said Saturday that the fishing boat was operating in waters 35 nautical miles off the east coast of Miyako Island, which is beyond Taiwan's exclusive economic zone of 200-nautical miles, and was therefore detained by Japanese police.
Lu added that officials of the ROC representative office stationed in Okinawa have contacted Japanese authorities in the hopes that the skipper can be released on bail as early as possible.
Taiwan and Japan are expected to hold a 15th round of fishery talks in Tokyo in late June or early July to address the disputes through bilateral negotiations in a peaceful and rational manner.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao, in the eastern Taiwan county of Ilan, protested June 10 in waters 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships from an area in which the 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Taiwan fishing ships have been repeatedly expelled or detained by Japanese patrol vessels over the past two years after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and neighboring Hualien counties.

The Executive Yuan has filed a strong protest against Japan over the controversy via Taiwan's liaison office in Tokyo and has asked that Taiwan and Japan seek to resolve their fishing disputes through dialogue in line with international law.
Ahead of the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, Taiwanese fishermen have been asked by the Coast Guard Administration to operate within the area temporarily demarcated by the government.

Meanwhile, the Suao Fishermen's Association reported recently that a total of 13 Suao fishing boats have been seized by Japan since 2001 while operating in Taiwan's economic zone, and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.

An association official said that overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon are long-standing problems, and if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO DEFEND PEOPLE'S RIGHTS MORE AGGRESSIVELY

TEXT.P: Independent aboriginal lawmaker Kao Chin Su-mei urged the government Sunday to more aggressively defend the interests of the Taiwan people.

Kao Chin made the comments at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon her return from a visit to Japan at the head of a group of Taiwan aborigines, saying that she had originally thought the current government to be more courageous than previous ones but was later disappointed to find that it has failed to properly protect the interests of the people.

Recalling that the government had vowed, in the lead-up to the March 26 demonstration against China, to make Taiwan's voice resonate around the world, Kao Chin said she regrets the fact that the government turned a deaf ear to aborigines' call for help in their dispute with Japan authorities.

Kao Chin and her group appealed three days ago for the government's intervention in Tokyo when they were prohibited by Japanese police from leaving their bus to stage a protest at the Yasukuni Shrine to call for the removal of memorial tablets for Taiwan aboriginal soldiers who died fighting for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II when Taiwan was still a colony of Japan.

Kao Chin and her followers claimed that these Taiwan aboriginal soldiers were forced to serve in the Japanese Imperial Army and would not want to be worshiped in a shrine set up to honor the deceased soldiers of a country that had invaded Taiwan.
Premier Frank Hsieh didn't respond to Kao Chin's call at that time, saying that he respects the Japanese police's handling of the Taiwan protesters.

Kao Chin said her regret has "almost turned to anger" amid reports that Taiwan fishermen have been chased out of one of their traditional fishing grounds to the northeast of Taiwan by Japanese patrol boats in recent weeks.
She urged the government to deliver on its promise to protect the people of Taiwan and to look after their rights and interests "with deeds, and not empty words."

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu, who greeted Kao Chin and her group at the airport, said his ministry will continue negotiating with Tokyo authorities on ways to address the requests of Kao Chin and her group.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP OFFICE IN U.S. TO HAVE NEW CULTURE CENTER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in the United States will have a new culture center to serve Taiwan expatriates in the greater Washington, D.C. area.

The new facility, located in Gaithersburg, Montgomery County, Maryland, will be formally inaugurated at 3 p.m. Sunday. David Ta-wei Lee, the top ROC representative to the United States, and Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, will jointly preside over the inauguration ceremony.

The new culture center, built on a four-acre plot, has a large auditorium capable of accommodating an audience of 500, as well as conference rooms, a library, show rooms, classrooms and other facilities. Construction began in February 2004 and was completed earlier this month.

Yen Ming-yi, director of the new culture center, said a series of cultural and education activities will be staged at the center in the coming months to mark its inauguration. The center's conference and show rooms can be rented for use by Taiwan expatriates in accordance with the center's management regulations, he added.

Gaithersburg Mayor Sidney Katz and representatives from the American Institute in Taiwan, the Maryland State Assembly, the Montgomery County Council and major Taiwan expatriate associations will attend the new culture center's inauguration ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO CALL FOR EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will on Monday propose holding an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan to screen various key bills, DPP caucus whip William C. T. Lai said Sunday.

Lai said that the DPP caucus will present the proposal to the Legislative Yuan to call for a special session to deal with six bills of major concern, including a major arms procurement bill and a bill regarding flood control and prevention which has become more urgent following recent flooding in central and southern Taiwan.

The proposal was signed by 89 DPP lawmakers, more than the minimum level of one-quarter of the 225 legislators required by the Constitution to call a special legislative session, Lai said, urging the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to support the proposal.

According to Chao Yung-ching, another DPP caucus whip, no exact date for the extraordinary session is mentioned in the proposal. He said a date can be decided through inter-party negotiations to be presided over by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng.
Meanwhile, the main opposition KMT said that it refuses to hold an extra legislative session for the sake of the DPP's call to deal with the recent flood damage in central and southern counties.

KMT Central Policy Committee head Tseng Yung-chuan argued that the Executive Yuan still has NT$19.3 billion in a special fund for emergency use that can be put toward flood relief efforts. He said that sending out aid to flood victims is an emergency response and is not related to implementing flood control projects, funding for which he said should be included in the government's regular annual budget.
There is no urgent need to convene an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan, he said, adding that it is inappropriate to hold extra legislative sessions too frequently.
The KMT only called two extra legislative sessions in more than 50 years when it was the ruling party, but the DPP has held five such sessions since it came to power in 2000, he noted.

PFP legislative caucus whip Chen Chih-ping voiced the same opinion, saying that it is unnecessary to convene a special legislative session at the present time as the Executive Yuan still has adequate funds for natural disaster relief.

Flood control projects require lengthy and in-depth study and planning by the government, and the Cabinet should submit such projects in its annual budget for screening by the legislature, he insisted.

Ho Min-hao, a legislative whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , said that his party is in favor of calling a special legislative session to scrutinize significant bills regarding a major military procurement plan and to approve the nomination list of Control Yuan members submitted by the president.

The TSU supports the idea of holding an extraordinary session, but flooding is not the main issue waiting to be handled, Ho pointed out, saying that the government should put forward its flood control projects and budgets for legislative approval in phases, instead of using the issue as a way to pass the buck to others.

Premier Frank Hsieh has several times called for a special legislative session to screen an eight-year flood control project worth NT$80 billion that he proposed soon after assuming the premiership in February this year.
Legislative speaker Wang said that the Legislative Yuan will certainly approve well-crafted flood control projects put forward by the Executive Yuan to improve the livelihood of the people.

But Wang was reserved about the NT$80 billion special budget plan raised by Hsieh for what he called a flood control project, making it clear that such a program must be comprehensively designed in advance and pointing out that the government currently has enough funds to aid the flood victims.

Meanwhile, tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture showed that as of 11: 00 a. m. Sunday, damage to the agricultural sector caused by flooding since last Sunday totaled a record high NT$2.14 billion (US$68 million) . Chiayi, Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Tainan and Yunlin have been the hardest hit counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR OFFICER CALLS FOR COUNTRY'S SUPPORT FOR NATIONAL DEFENSE

TEXT.P: The leader of a Republic of China Navy flotilla which returned from a three-month round-the-world voyage Sunday called for the country to throw its support behind the Navy as well as the development of national defense.

Rear Adm. Fan Pao-hua, who led the flotilla on its 105-day global navigation training mission, said that the voyage was smooth and successful, with morale among the crew being very high, thanks to the support rendered by the nation and the crew's families.

The Navy's first round-the-world mission not only took members of the ROC Navy to every corner of the Earth, it also wrote a new page in ROC history in sea power and diplomacy, Fan said during a press conference held at the Tsuoying naval base in southern Taiwan to mark the success of the flotilla's mission.
Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm.Chen Pang-chih officiated at a ceremony earlier in the day to mark the successful commencement of the Navy's round-the-world navigation training.

According to Fan, the flotilla -- comprised of the French-built Lafayette-class frigate "Kang Ding, " the U.S.-built Perry-class frigate "Wu Yi" and a logistical support vessel, with a 700-strong crew -- departed Tsuoying March 7 and returned to the same naval base early Sunday morning after having sailed over 26,000 nautical miles around the globe.

Fan reported that the naval vessels cruised three major oceans and four major seas around the globe and made port calls in seven countries which maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC, including Panama, Senegal, Kiribatis, Gambia and Palau, adding that the ships also sailed across five channels, capes and canals during the navigation mission.

The flotilla's voyage, dubbed Taiwan's "warship diplomacy, " set a ROC Navy record in terms of distance traveled, during which the Navy officers and cadets spread the word in ROC allies countries about Taiwan's freedom, democracy and diverse society, Fan noted.

The Navy has also examined its long-range combat capabilities in several areas, including night-fighting, electronics warfare and logistical operations on the seas, during the mission, according to Fan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE LOSSES TOP NT$2.1 BILLION

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by torrential rains over the past week have hit NT$2.14 billion (US$68.38 million) as of 11 a.m. Sunday, according to the Council of Agriculture (COA).

Tallies released by the COA show that more than 42,802 hectares of agricultural land, mainly rice paddies and vegetable fields, have been damaged or destroyed in central and southern Taiwan in the downpours which have dumped more than 1,000 millimeters of rainfall on some areas.
Many fisheries in Pingtung, Kaohsiung, Tainan and Chiayi were also heavily damaged or destroyed, while large numbers of livestock have died in the flooding.

The COA said it is providing financial assistance to farmers who have suffered serious damage to their land and crops in areas hit by flooding and is offering soft loans to those who have suffered minor losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT URGENT DUE TO CHINA'S MILITARY THREAT: VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-shian warned over the weekend of China's increased military threat against Taiwan, urging the Legislative Yuan to approve a major arms deal as soon as possible.

Tsai issued the warning Friday while giving a keynote speech on national defense at a roundtable forum held by the Institute of International Relations under National Chengchi University in Taichung City in central Taiwan.

Pointing out that China is engaged in a two-pronged strategy in its dealings with Taiwan, Tsai said that China has never eased its saber rattling aimed at Taiwan despite the fact that it invited main Taiwan opposition leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong -- to visit in late April and early May in a bid to improve bilateral ties.

China has continued with its regular military exercises and has plans of conducting large-scale drills aimed at Taiwan this summer, a situation which Tsai said clearly underscores the urgent need for Taiwan to acquire necessary defensive weapons from the United States.

According to the vice minister of national defense, the military balance across the Taiwan Strait will gradually tilt in China's favor within three to five years, and it is estimated that China will be capable of invading Taiwan after 2012 if it keeps expanding its military at the current pace.

For the sake of the nation's interests and security, the public and the lawmakers should put aside their ideological differences and partisan interests to push for a quick passage of the major arms purchase plan and its budget bill at the Legislative Yuan, he urged.
The major military procurement plan put forward by the Executive Yuan has been stalled in the Legislative Yuan during the past two sessions due to boycotts by the KMT and the PFP.
The plan was originally estimated to cost Taiwan NT$610.8 billion over a 15-year period, but the price has been cut to some NT$480 billion (US$15.2 billion).
Items proposed by the Ministry of National Defense on the procurement list include eight diesel-fueled submarines, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C anti-submarine airplanes.
Minister of National Defense Lee Jye has given assurances at the Legislative Yuan that the weapons will help Taiwan counter China's military threat for the next 30 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAY PERISH IF IT CANNOT RECLAIM PRESIDENCY IN 2008: WANG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who doubles as a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Sunday he is afraid that the nearly 110-year-old KMT may perish if it cannot win back the presidency in 2008.
Wang made the remarks while attending a seminar with a group of KMT die-hards who used to be military service members as part of his campaign activities for the KMT chairmanship.
In his view, Wang said, the most important mission for the next KMT chairman is to integrate the opposition forces and work out a ticket that can win the 2008 presidential-vice presidential election.

Noting that the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years until 2000, has lost two presidential elections in a row, Wang said the next KMT chairman must be able to reinvigorate the party and lead it to reclaim the presidency in 2008.
Nevertheless, Wang said he doesn't think that the next KMT chairman himself should necessarily be the party's candidate for the 2008 presidential election.
Wang, a seasoned Taiwan-born politician, said he believes that he himself is the one who can lead the KMT to weather all the challenges ahead and win the next presidential election.
The July 16 KMT chairmanship election pits Wang against Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a KMT vice chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN RELEASES DETAINED TAIWAN FISHING BOAT, CREW
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 19 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japanese coast guard authorities have agreed to release a detained Taiwan fishing boat and its crew aboard, the Republic of China's representative stationed in Okinawa said Sunday.
The "Chinmingtsai No. 11" trawler from the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung and its four crew members were released at 9 p.m. Sunday, Chen Chih-hung, the ROC's representative in Okinawa said.

The Chinmingtsai and its crew were detained by Japanese coast guard authorities Saturday on charges of poaching in Japan's 200-mile exclusive economic zone some 65 nautical miles east of the Miyako Island, Okinawa.
Chen said Japanese coast guard authorities agreed to allow the detained Taiwan fishing boat and its crew members to leave for home after his office agreed to serve as their guarantor.

According to Chen, the Chinmingtsai's skipper had confessed to having traversed into Japan's exclusive economic waters. The skipper had informed the shipowner of the situation, Chen said. Under the Japanese maritime law, the shipowner will have to pay fine of about 2 million Japanese yen.

The incident came just a few days after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats converged in waters near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, which were claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China, to protest Japanese patrol ships' frequent chasing them away from their traditional fishing grounds. The unusual move was also aimed at pushing the ROC government to adopt more active measures to protect local fishermen's fishing rights in the two countries' overlapping economic zones.

After the unusual protest. Taiwan's Coast Guard Administration has promised to step up patrols and cooperate with the Ministry of National Defense in better protecting local fishermen's safety and legitimate rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET URGES LEGISLATURE TO PASS FLOOD CONTROL BILL ASAP

TEXT.P: Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Sunday the government looks forward to seeing the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan hold an extra session and pass a special budget bill for flood prevention projects as soon as possible.

Cho made the remarks after Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said he would call a cross-party consultative meeting if the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) comes up with a proposal to hold an extra legislative session.

The DPP legislative caucus is scheduled to put forward such a proposal Monday. Previous reports said the DPP caucus is hopeful that an extra legislative session can be held after the opposition Kuomintang's July 16 chairmanship election.
Wang, who is competing with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying for the KMT chairmanship, said he would not neglect his duty as the legislative speaker simply because of his personal bid for the top KMT post.

"So long as the DPP caucus comes up with the proposal, I would certainly call a meeting of legislative whips of various parties to discuss the proposal. With the consent of various party caucuses, an extra legislative session can be held either before or after the KMT chairmanship election. I would faithfully fulfill my duty as legislative speaker," Wang said.

In response, Cho said the Cabinet welcomes Wang's statement. "We hope an extra legislative session can be held soon to screen several urgent bills, including an eight-year, NT$80 billion special budget bill on flood control and prevention around the nation," he added.
Cho stressed that the flood prevention bill, if passed, will be implemented from 2006 with an aim to complete all flood control and prevention projects in eight years.
"The bill is a long-term project and has nothing to do with aid to victims of the recent flooding in several central and southern counties," Cho explained.
Since the government passed a NT$30 billion budget bill in 2001 for cleaning up the Keelung River, Cho said, metropolitan Taipei has not been hit by flash floods.
"We hope Taipei City can share its experience in fighting floods with other cities and counties," Cho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS TO VISIT CHINA FOR FRUIT EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Seven opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers will travel to China Monday to see for themselves customs clearance and implementation of China's open-door policy for Taiwan's fruit exports, legislative sources said Sunday.

The lawmakers, including Legislator Wu Chen-tian from Kinmen and Legislator Tsao Erh-chung from Matsu, will travel to Xiamen in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian from Taiwan-held frontline island of Kinmen via a direct voyage.
Tsao said their visit is mainly aimed at collecting first-hand information to serve as reference for promoting exports of Taiwan fruits to China via the "mini three links" routes.
Taiwan has opened Kinmen and Matsu for direct shipping links with two Chinese port cities -- Xiamen and Mawei -- in Fujian, known locally as the "mini three links" routes.

Since China has agreed to offer Taiwan fruits tariff-free and speedy customs clearance privileges, Tsao said, the Kinmen and Matsu county governments and elected representatives have hoped that Taiwan fruits can be shipped to China via the Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei "mini three links" routes.

Under current Taiwan's rules, Tsao said, Taiwan-funded companies in the Fujian area can legally ship goods, including fruits, from Taiwan to China via Kinmen and Matsu through "mini three links" routes.

"Against this backdrop, we want to visit Fujian to look into its customs clearance operations and its market-opening measures for Taiwan fruits. We hope our fact-finding visit can contribute to future Taiwan fruit exports to China via Kinmen and Matsu through the 'mini three links' routes," Tsao added.
The seven-member group will travel to Xiamen via Kinmen Monday and return to Matsu from Mawei Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 20, or the 14th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation links between Vietnam and China.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
1999: Boris Yeltsin presents U.S. President Bill Clinton with recently declassified Russian reports relating to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
2000: Hans Muench, a German doctor in the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp is given immunity from trial at a French court because of his senility.
2001: The 46th World Conference of the International Council for Small Businesses (ICSB) concludes in Taipei after some 500 participants from 55 countries spent three days to discuss how to cope with the challenges posed by the new era.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position, but if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ENERGY CONFAB SERIOUS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that the administration is getting down to the serious business of working out energy policy and implementation strategy that will not compromise the environment while being acceptable to the industrial and business sectors.

Addressing the opening of the National Energy Conference held at the Taipei International Convention Center, Hsieh assured the country that this two-day meeting would not be just a ceremonial event, but rather a serious brainstorming session aimed at working out good energy and industrial policies.

Hsieh said that economic development sometimes conflicts with environmental protection and conservation efforts. Nevertheless, the premier said, if he had to make a choice between economic development and environmental protection, he would opt for environmental sustainability for the entire country.

At the same time, Hsieh added that as premier, he has no right to ignore efforts to maintain Taiwan's international competitiveness, saying that this is the reason why he has proposed a "golden triangle" formula to enable the country's economic growth, social justice and environmental sustainability to progress in sync.

The premier also admitted that "talking is easier than doing, " pointing out that related issues, such as whether the fifth and the sixth naphtha cracking plants should be built, are extremelly challenging.

Noting that greenhouse gas emissions have become an important international issue since Feb. 16 when the Kyoto Protocol went into effect, Hsieh encouraged participants in the National Energy Conference to fully express their opinions and share their expertise on the issue to assist the administration in crafting workable and pragmatic energy policies.

Hsieh added that related policies on reducing greenhouse gas emissions are already in the administrative pipeline, adding that it has been decided that solar energy will be used at venues of the 2009 World Games to be held in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
