DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA off to Hong Kong today
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo leaves today for a halfday visit to Hong Kong where she is expected to assure its senior business leaders that she remains focused on the efforts to put the Philippine economy in order despite the political controversies hounding her.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Wife says Garcillano still in the country
EMBATTLED former Election Commissioner Virgilio Garcillano is in the country and ready to face any investigation if ordered by the courts, his wife said last night.
The Philippine Star: Palace tags destabilization financiers
Malacanang claimed yesterday it has already identified the supposed financiers of the latest destabilization attempts against the Arroyo administration.
The Manila Times: Investors: GMA foes just making noise
Investors are dismissing the political problems besieging President Arroyo as temporary and ridiculous and expressed confidence that she can overcome them.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Reformers Disputes Iran's Vote Results. Two reform candidates angrily challenged the results of Iran's presidential election Saturday , charging that hard-line factions manipulated the vote in favor of the conservative mayor of Tehran, a former member of the Revolutionary Guards with limited political experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Falling fares fuel short getaways.
Air fares to nearby cities have come down sharply in the last 18 months, prompting Singaporean travellers to make more short getaways.
Ticket prices for some destinations within a five-hour flying radius have fallen by as much as 80 percent, thanks to the arrival of low-cost carriers and fierce competition with full-service airlines.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Lin Boon Heng:To arrange the older person and housewife to get a part time job.
Singapore National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) wants to arrange the older person and housewife to get a part time job in order to increase low-income family's income.
Part time jobs are very potential in development here, said Lim Boon Heng, Secretary-General of NTUC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DELEGATION HOLDS INTRODUCTION PARTY IN TEL AVIV

TEXT.P: Members of a visiting Taiwan trade delegation hosted a cocktail party in Tel Aviv, Israel Sunday to introduce themselves to Israeli politicians and business leaders.

The delegation, made up of representatives of nine Taiwan companies, was organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council to take part in Israel's largest and most prestigious technology exhibition, the International Exhibition for Industrial Technology, which will be held at the Israeli Trade Fair and Convention Center's exhibition hall June 20-23.
Over 480 companies from Germany, Austria, Slovakia, Romania, Taiwan and Israel are participating in the fair, which is expected to attract some 60,000 visitors, according to the fair's organizer.

Republic of China Representative to Israel Charles S.S. Teng said in a speech at the party that he hopes Taiwan's presence in the exhibition will help boost mutual trade between Taiwan and Israel since the two countries maintain close business ties.
Last year, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Israel reached US$1 billion, he added, noting that both countries place a lot of emphasis on technologic development.
Over 100 Israel businesspeople and politicians, including Chaim Chosen, a ranking official of the Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs, attended the cocktail party.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODING CAUSES OVER NT$2 BILLION IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: The recent flooding in southern Taiwan has caused a total of NT$2.15 billion (US$68.74 million) in agricultural losses as of Monday morning, according to the latest Council of Agriculture (COA) statistics.
The figure breaks the old record set in June 1998 when torrential rains caused NT$1.91 billion worth of agricultural losses.
The COA statistics show that crop losses have reached NT$1.2 billion, with 42,808 hectares of farmland being affected by the heavy rains and flooding.
Livestock industry losses have reached NT$199 million, while those in the fishery sector have hit NT$705 million, and those in the forestry industry have reached NT$2.52 million.
Affected farmers can apply for government assistance in the form of subsidies or low-interest loans, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO MEET WITH DPP MAYORS, MAGISTRATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will invite mayors and magistrates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to a tea party Wednesday to listen to their opinions about relief work in the wake of recent flooding in southern Taiwan, an official said Monday.

Chen Wen-tsung, deputy director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, said President Chen is concerned about the recent flooding caused by heavy rains in southern Taiwan, a traditional DPP stronghold.
"President Chen has been kept informed of the latest developments in the flood-affected areas, including the relief and clean-up efforts and the extent of the devastation, the official said.

He added that President Chen is scheduled to meet with DPP mayors and magistrates Wednesday to learn more about the damage caused by the flooding and heavy rains as well as local government chiefs' opinions about post-disaster rehabilitation and future flood control and prevention.

According to the latest Council of Agriculture (COA) statistics, the recent flooding in southern Taiwan has caused a total of NT$2.15 billion (US$68.74 million) in agricultural losses as of Monday morning.
The figure breaks the old record set in June 1998 when torrential rains caused NT$1.91 billion worth of agricultural losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WON'T SAIL TO DISPUTED WATERS: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: An Executive Yuan spokesman on Monday ruled out the possibility of Premier Frank Hsieh sailing aboard a Navy frigate to Taiwan's exclusive economic zone off northeastern Taiwan to inspect the government's efforts in protecting the rights and interests of fishermen operating in the area.

Discounting media reports that Premier Hsieh would probably board a Knox-class frigate Tuesday to inspect the situation in disputed Republic of China economic waters that overlap with those of Japan, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the premier has never had such an idea and there has been no talk on the matter.

Although Hsieh will not board the frigate, which is scheduled to sail to waters near a disputed part of the East China Sea Tuesday to allow lawmakers to view first hand how the administration is protecting Taiwan fishermen operating there, the resolve of the premier and the government to protect the rights and interests of the country's fishermen is unwavering, Cho noted.
The spokesman stressed that it is not necessary to have the premier sail to the disputed area in order to demonstrate the administration's determination in protecting the fishermen.

He added that the premier sailing to the disputed waters would blur the focus of the government's efforts in protecting fishermen in the disputed waters and would raise tensions, which he said the premier wishes to avoid.

The Ministry of National Defense decided last week to send a frigate Tuesday to waters near the overlapping economic zones between Taiwan and Japan under pressure from opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang after a spate of fishing disputes triggered by Japanese patrol boats' expulsion and arrest of several Taiwanese fishing boats.

Nearly 50 fishing boats from Suao, in the eastern Taiwan county of Ilan, protested June 10 in waters 86 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast against Japanese patrol vessels that had expelled Taiwan fishing ships from an area in which the 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Taiwan fishing ships have repeatedly been expelled or detained by Japanese patrol vessels over the past two years after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and neighboring Hualien counties.

The Executive Yuan has filed a strong protest against Japan over the controversy via Taiwan's liaison office in Tokyo and has asked that Taiwan and Japan seek to resolve their fishing disputes through dialogue in line with international law.
Ahead of the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, Taiwanese fishermen have been asked by the Coast Guard Administration to operate within the area temporarily demarcated by the government.

Meanwhile, the Suao Fishermen's Association reported recently that a total of 13 Suao fishing boats have been seized by Japan since 2001 while operating in Taiwan's economic zone, and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.

An association official said that overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon are long-standing problems, and if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 3.33 points to close at 6,296.89.
The bourse opened at 6,311.67 and fluctuated between 6,315.29 and 6,272.97 during trading. A total of 3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.24 billion (US$2.08 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up at 1.3 percent and machinery and electronics shares gaining 0.1 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.7 percent and textile stocks at 0.1 percent.
The remaining two major stock categories -- cement stocks and paper and pulp issues -- remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 455 to 381, with 174 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.004 to close at NT$31.319.
A total of US$823 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$31.323 and fluctuated between NT$31.230 and NT$31.324.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELEASED SKIPPER'S FAMILY WORRYING ABOUT HEAVY JAPANESE FINE
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, June 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The family of the skipper of the Pingtung-based "Chinmingtsai No. 11" trawler, which was detained by Japanese coast guard authorities two days ago for poaching in Japan's exclusive economic zone, are now fretting over how to pay the heavy Japanese fine.

The wife of skipper Chen Teh-liang appealed to the central government for financial assistance to help them raise the 2.36 million Japanese yen (NT$679,276) in two weeks to pay for Chen and the trawler's release.

The "Chinmingtsai No. 11" and its four-member crew were detained by Japanese coast guard authorities Saturday on charges of poaching in Japan's 200-mile exclusive economic zone some 65 nautical miles east of Miyako Island, Okinawa.

The Japanese coast guard authorities released the detained Taiwan fishing boat and its crew around 9 p.m. Sunday after the Republic of China's representative stationed in Okinawa, Chen Chih-hung, promised to serve as their guarantor, promising that the skipper will pay the 2.36 million yen fine in two weeks.

According Rep. Chen, the "Chinmingtsai's" skipper had confessed to having transgressed into Japan's exclusive economic waters, and under Japanese maritime law, the shipowner must pay a fine of about two million Japanese yen for the ship and crew's release.
Skipper Chen is expected to sail back to Pingtung aboard the "Chinmingtsai" Tuesday or Wednesday, according to authorities from the Pingtung Fishermen's Association.

The incident came just a few days after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats converged in waters near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, known in Japan as the Senkaku Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China, to protest Japanese patrol ships' frequently chasing them away from their traditional fishing grounds.
The unusual move was also aimed at pushing the ROC government to adopt more active measures to protect local fishermen's rights in the two countries' overlapping economic zones.

Taiwan fishing ships have repeatedly been expelled or detained by Japanese patrol vessels over the past two years after Japan readjusted and expanded its exclusive economic zone to as close as some 20 nautical miles off the coasts of Ilan and neighboring Hualien counties.

The Executive Yuan has filed a strong protest against Japan over the controversy via Taiwan's liaison office in Tokyo and has asked that Taiwan and Japan seek to resolve their fishing disputes through dialogue in line with international law.

Ahead of the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, probably in early July, Taiwanese fishermen have been asked by the Coast Guard Administration to operate within the area temporarily demarcated by the government.

Meanwhile, the Suao Fishermen's Association reported recently that 13 Suao fishing boats have been seized by Japan since 2001 while operating in Taiwan's economic zone, and the boat owners or families of the fishermen have had to pay for their release.

An association official said that overlapping economic zones and fishing rights being encroached upon are long-standing problems, and if the government is unable to solve them, the fishermen could stage an even bigger protest next time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved down one point to close at 6,188, with 15,910 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August moved down two points to end at 6,128, with 119 contracts traded, while September futures remained unchanged at 6,096, with 117 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,189 for July, 6,130 for August, 6,096 for September, 6,092 for December and 6,097 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

July TE futures moved down 0.3 points to close at 253.8, with 3,078 contracts traded, while August TE futures lost 0.4 points to finish at 251.6, with 14 contract transactions. March TE futures moved down 1.85 points to end at 247, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

July TF futures lost six points to finish at 947.4, with 1,634 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures moved down six points to end at 937, with 22 contracts traded. September TF futures lost 6.4 points to close at 934, with five contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURN EXTRA TEACHERS IN TO POLICE OFFICERS: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: A Cabinet spokesman said Monday that Premier Frank Hsieh has instructed the Ministry of the Interior to map out a plan aimed at expanding the nation's police force by taking advantage of the current resources for recruiting and training teachers.

Cho Jung-tai explained that there is a lack of police officers in the country's law enforcing system. At present, the total number of policemen nationwide is 67,000, fewer than the 72,000 required in the government's budget, he said

Regarding an administrative report released recently by the Ministry of Education that said its current work of recruiting new teachers will be downsized 50 percent in the next three years, the premier therefore thinks that the spare resources in the recruitment can be used to train police officers, Cho noted.
The government is trying to recruit around 5,000 police officers by next year as part of its efforts to maintain public order, he added.

DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Refugees Protest Abductions.
Dagestan -- Residents of a village in eastern Chechnya who have fled into Dagestan to protest what they described as a brutal security raid accused the authorities on Friday of abducting their relatives.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Israel Agrees To Demolish Its Settlers' Gaza Homes.
Israel and the Palestinian Authority have agreed that Jewish settler homes in the Gaza Strip will be demolished as Israeli citizens and soldiers leave the area this summer, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced Sunday after two days of meetings with Israeli and Palestinian officials, the paper said.
(Oliver Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOW OF FORCE CANNOT RESOLVE FISHING RIGHTS DISPUTES: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A show of force cannot resolve international fishing rights disputes, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Monday.

Legislator Lin Cho-shui made the remarks a day before an ROC naval ship will sail to a disputed part of the East China Sea where the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap to accentuate the Republic of China government's determination to protect the nation's fishing and other economic rights in the region.
In his view, Lin said that flexing military muscle is by no means an appropriate way to resolve these sorts of issues.
"International fishing rights disputes must be settled through negotiations and a show of force cannot resolve the matter, " Lin said at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chang Ping-tang, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official, said fishing disputes were better handled by the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) with the MND offering only behind-the-scenes support and assistance.

"As warships coming to the 'first' line could escalate tensions, we should exercise self-restraint, " said Chang, whose official title is assistant deputy chief of the Office of the Deputy Chief of the General Staff for Operations.

The MND agreed to send a Knox-class frigate to the disputed waters northeast of Taiwan under strong pressure from opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ling Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest on the sea earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships' frequently chasing them away from what they call their traditional fishing grounds.

Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng will join Legislator Lin Yu-fang, a co-convener of the Legislature's Defense Committee, and several other members of the committee on the voyage to the disputed waters aboard the Knox-class frigate Tuesday.
Legislator Lin Cho-shui said dispatching a warship to protect fishermen is dangerous and could trigger an unexpected and unwanted conflict.
"It is regrettable that some people have, simply for ideological reasons, forced our military to do what even Chinese warships dare not do, " Lin said.

Stressing that Taiwan should respect international conventions, precedents and customs in resolving fishing disputes, Lin said he is hopeful that Tuesday's voyage will be the last time that a Taiwan warship is mobilized to patrol a disputed maritime region.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited isles known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

Lin said he thinks that the ROC government should shelve the sovereignty dispute over the Tiaoyutais and should instead focus on negotiations on fishing rights in the disputed waters based on international maritime conventions, modern ecological conservation concepts and protection of traditional fishing grounds.

"We should seek co-sharing of fishery resources in disputed waters with relevant countries and adopt appropriate measures to help our fishermen cope with any possible impact to be brought by a new agreement," Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TRANSPORTATION MINISTER MEETS FRENCH COUNTERPART
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, France, June 19 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san has met with his French counterpart and the two have exchanged views favorably for bilateral cooperation in efforts to secure aviation safety.

The visiting Lin, who arrived in France June 12 mainly to witness the delivery of the fourth of eight A330-300s that China Airlines has ordered from the French airplane giant Airbus, met with French Minister of Transportation D. Perben June 17 for talks on issues of mutual interest, particularly the signing of a bilateral aviation safety agreement (BASA) between the two countries.

According to Lin, although Perben is not quite familiar with affairs of his ministry since he has been at the office for only two weeks, the French transportation minister had a sincere and positive attitude toward bilateral cooperation between France and Taiwan.
As the signing of a BASA involves professional and technical affairs, the two ministers agreed that the matter would be referred to civil aeronautics bureaus from the two countries, Lin said.
Lin was in Toulouse, headquarters of Airbus, June 16 to participate in the delivery ceremony of the fourth A330-300 the China Airlines (CAL) ordered from Airbus.

As an advertisement by the Council of Agriculture to promote sales of Taiwan's butterfly orchid, one of its most important agricultural exports, the CAL's fourth A330-300 was painted with a huge image of butterfly orchids on its fuselage.

At the invitation of European aviation groups, Lin also attended the Paris Air Show held June 13-16, and traveled by France's high-speed TGV train to compare the high-speed rail systems of Japan and Europe.

He noted that Taiwan boasts a strong industrial foundation and is promoting its aviation industry. With Taiwan's certification on aviation products already recognized by the United States, Taiwan also hopes it can be recognized by the European Union, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC TO COMMUNICATE WITH SHINKANSEN ON TRAIN CARRIAGE DELIVERY

TEXT.P: Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) stressed Monday that it has not deferred any payments to the Taiwan Shinkansen Corp. (TSC) and the latter has no reason not to deliver the train carriages and core systems.

Arthur Chiang, THSRC vice president, made the remarks after the THSRC received a TSC letter to the effect that it will suspend the delivery of train carriages and core systems. Chiang said the TSC has already delivered 18 train carriages and is scheduled to deliver three more in July. It is expected a total of 30 train carriages will be delivered before the inauguration of the first high-speed rail system in Taiwan.
Chiang said his company has not delayed construction payments to the TSC and can also pay for the July delivery.

Under contract between the THSRC and the TSC, the latter has no reason to suspend delivery, Chiang said. The THSRC will communicate with the TSC according to the contract, but it will not overreact, he added.
He also said the goal is to have the systems become operational on Oct. 31, but the exact time is still under assessment and will be finalized by the end of the August.
If there are any changes, the THRSC will report them, he said.

The 345-kilometer high-speed railway linking Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south will form the backbone of western Taiwan's mass rapid transportation network. It will connect eight metropolitan areas between Taiwan's two largest cities. It will be able to transport at least 300,000 passengers daily when it becomes fully operational.
The multimillion-dollar railway system is Taiwan's first infrastructure project being built under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) model.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' ASSOCIATION RETHINKS STRATEGY ON TRIP TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association (TPFA) said Monday the association will delay its trip to the mainland originally set for this week for talks on Taiwan fruit exports to China to make better preparations.

TPFA Secretary-General Chang Yung-cheng made the remarks after the trip to the mainland by the group resulted in criticism and warnings that the visit could violate the law if it dared to enter an agreement with the mainland.
Chang said that to make fuller preparations for the trip, they have decided to delay the visit, adding that any agreement reached with the other side will not be outside of the law.
He pointed out that the talks with the mainland will not go against government policy, or sidestep the government authorities.
But he also expressed the hope that the government will attach importance to the TPFA's intention to help farmers tap overseas markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FORMALLY REQUESTS SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presented Monday an endorsement signed by 89 lawmakers seeking an extraordinary session of the Legislative Yuan to deal with six key bills.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan, DPP caucus whips Chao Yung-ching and William C. T. Lai urged both the governing and opposition camps to stop bickering and devote their energy on screening the important bills, which include flood control and prevention, a major arms procurement bill and a nomination list of Control Yuan members submitted by the president.

Chao particularly called on the lawmakers to pay special heed to the flood control and prevention draft bill by first approving it and scrutinizing its budget later, because it is an urgent issue now at a time when many townships in central and southern Taiwan are still soaked after several days of heavy torrential downpours last week.

Chao also mentioned that it is necessary to screen the president's nominees for Control Yuan members, since a refusal by the Legislative Yuan to do so has halted the operations of the Taiwan's highest watchdog body for about six months, seriously affecting the people's interests.

In addition, the draft bills on restructuring the organization of the Executive Yuan, reviewing the statute for tobacco and liquor tax and setting up a supervisory board to monitor the laborers' retirement fund are also waiting to be handled quickly, Chao said.

As Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), is now busy in running for the party's chairmanship, it will be no problem for the DPP to wait for Wang to hold the extra legislative session after he completes his campaigning, he said.

Chao noted that other bills viewed as urgent for revision can also be discussed in the session, such as a cross-Taiwan Strait peace promotion bill proposed by the People First Party (PFP) and a truth committee on the 319 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu initiated by the KMT.
The DPP's proposal endorsed by 89 lawmakers asking for an extraordinary session has exceeded a one-quarter of the 225 legislators required by the Constitution for such a gathering.
The Legislative Yuan has been in an adjournment since May 31.
However, KMT Central Policy Committee head Tseng Yung-chuan said that his party is opposed to the DPP's call for opening an extra legislative session under the anti-flood pretext.

It is more important to aid the flood victims now than programming flood control projects, Tseng said, pointing out that the government still has at least NT$19.3 billion (US$612.7 million) in emergency funds for natural disaster aid and relief.

Premier Frank Hsieh's call for an allocation of NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) in an eight-year special budget for flood control projects should be included in the government's regular annual budget or in the five-year NT$500 billion budget for the new 10 major development projects, he said.

There is no urgent need to convene a special legislative session to deal with anti-flood projects now and they must be well digested with sufficient time by the lawmakers, he stressed, adding that it is not appropriate to hold extra sessions so frequently.

The KMT only called two extra legislative sessions in more than 50 years when it was the ruling party, but the DPP has held five such sessions since it came to power in 2000, the KMT official said Sunday.

PFP legislative caucus whip Chen Chih-pin prodded the DPP government to duly carry out its relief operations instead of rushing to call an extra legislative session at present and to get fully prepared for the coming typhoon season.
The legislature must take its time to well screen the six key bills if they are so important as the DPP says and it would be wrong to have them passed rashly in a special meeting, Chen Chih-pin said.

The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) agreed to call an extra legislative session to act on the highly sensitive arms procurement bill and the disputed presidential nomination list for Control Yuan members, but it is opposed to using the occasion to approve the NT$80 billion anti-flood projects.

TSU legislative caucus whip David Huang said that the party is open to including the anti-flood bill for discussion in the extra session, but he maintained that the budgets must not be approved so easily in such a short time on the grounds that such important programs should be carefully crafted after measures have comprehensively and publicly been discussed.

Non-Partisan Solidarity Union legislative caucus whip Yen Chin-piao claimed that his party has no set position regarding a special session. But he added that the flooding in the central and southern Taiwan requires a quick government response.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Anti-Syrian Alliance Claims Victory in Lebanese.
Opponents of Syrian domination claimed a stunning majority victory in the final round of Lebanon's parliamentary elections on Sunday. An anti-Syrian alliance won at least 21 of 28 contested seats in northern Lebanon, giving the alliance a majority in the next 128-seat Parliament. It was a startling change in the way politics have usually been carried out here - along strict clan and religious lines and long under the control of Syria - and perhaps an example of a greater yearning for democracy in the Arab world. The election was the first to be held in nearly 30 years without the presence of Syria n troops, who arrived in 1976 early in Lebanon's civil war and were forced to leave under international pressure in April.
Wall Street Journal: More Than Ever, Businesses Face Risk of Prosecution.
Businesspeople and corporations are at greater risk of criminal liability than ever before. A wave of corporate fraud starting with the 2001 collapse of Enron Corp. has led to potent new weapons for prosecutors such as stiffer financial penalties and prison terms. The Securities and Exchange Commission has more money and manpower to pursue civil-fraud cases. A list of blue-chip American companies have submitted to the threat of criminal indictment of corporations and become more common to accept the deferred-prosecution agreements. Under the arrangements, the government charges the company with criminal behavior but puts the prosecution on hold in exchange for a promise of reform. At an agreed-upon date, the potential charges expire. Since 2003, there have been at least eight such pacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRIAL INSTITUTE OPENS INCUBATION CENTER IN SILICON VALLEY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 19 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) opened a business incubation center in Silicon Valley, California Sunday.

In a ceremony marking the inauguration of the center, ITRI President Johnsee Lee said the center is part of his institute's efforts to help overseas Chinese scientists and technicians to create their own business by finding for them technology, funds and the right personnel.

Touting Taiwan as the gateway to the Asian market for scientists and technicians in Silicon Valley, Lee said the incubation center will help overseas Chinese who are interested in starting their own business in Taiwan to find potential partners, helping them to explore markets in the Asia-Pacific area, and thereby enhancing their possibility of success.

The center will provide ethnic Chinese scientists with consultancy about starting up new ventures, technology and marketing, and backing up their ventures with the ITRI's network in the whole of Asia and its research and development capability, Lee said.

The center will also recruit talented people to work for ITRI in Taiwan. In the next two months, the center will search for a group of scientists and technicians, preferable with five years of working experience in the United States, to work at the ITRI, Lee went on.

Also, the ITRI will hold an internship program for U.S.-educated children of ethnic Chinese parents from June to August this year. This program will offer 20 interns the chance to work at the ITRI this summer with the purpose of preparing them for working in Taiwan in the future.
The center will be operated by ITRI's U.S. subsidiary, the ITRI International, Inc. in San Jose, California, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ENERGY CONFERENCE KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: A national energy conference opened in Taipei Monday with business and environmental groups, think tanks and related government officials attending.

The two-day conference is aimed at charting the nation's energy policy after the Kyoto Protocol went into effect Feb. 16. The protocol committs 38 industrialized countries to cut their emissions of greenhouse gas emissions.

Addressing the opening of the conference at the Taipei International Convention Center, Premier Frank Hsieh said the administration is getting down to the serious business of working out energy policies and implementation strategies that will not compromise the environment while being acceptable to the industrial and business sectors.
He encouraged the participants to express their opinions and share their expertise on the issue to assist the administration in crafting workable and pragmatic energy policies.

Hsieh added that related policies on reducing greenhouse gas emissions are already in the administrative pipeline, adding that it has been decided that solar energy will be used at venues for the 2009 World Games to be held in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, speaking on the challenges and opportunities after the Kyoto Protocol went into effect, said that although Taiwan is not a signatory to the protocol, it realizes the importance of reducing greenhouse gases in pursuing the nation's sustainable development.

The Kyoto Protocol has brought new opportunities, Wu said, noting that it will stimulate the adjustment of the industrial structure, improve energy structure, develop low-carbon energy and new energy technology.
Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said a rudimentary approach after the Kyoto Protocol will be to conserve energy, develop reusable energy and upgrade energy efficiency.
She expressed hope that the conference will help forge national consensus so as to establish guidelines to resolve conflicts between economic development and environmental protection.
Although not many issues are expected to be sorted out in just two days, she expressed hope that common ground will be sought and differences put aside for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: KNOX-CLASS FRIGATE TO PATROL DISPUTED WATERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will send a Knox-class frigate to patrol Taiwan's northeastern economic waters Tuesday, supposedly to demonstrate the government's determination to protect local fishermen's rights and safety, military sources said Monday.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and several members of the Legislative Defense Committee will be on board the ship to inspect the navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the nation's northeastern waters where the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap, the sources said.

The deployment of the Fengyang frigate is part of the MND's response to a legislative demand that the navy more actively assist in protecting local fishermen's rights to operate in the disputed waters, the sources said.

According to the MND schedule, the defense minister and lawmakers will travel to a naval base in Suao in the northeastern county of Ilan early Tuesday. The Fengyang is scheduled to arrive in the disputed economic waters at around noon and to return to Suao that afternoon.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

MND sources said the cruise will be confined to waters some 60 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast. To ensure safety, other naval ships will patrol at distance, while military aircraft will be on routine flight missions in the region.

Military officials said the Knox-class frigates are equipped with sophisticated sonar and anti-submarine helicopters to detect and track submarines. They are mainly responsible for patrolling waters off Taiwan's eastern coast.
The Fengyang has recently been armed with additional air defense weaponry systems, including the Wuchin III air defense system and Standard I air defense missiles, the officials said.

The MND agreed to send a Knox-class frigate to the disputed waters under strong pressure from opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ling Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the area earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships, that frequently chase them away from what they call their traditional fishing grounds.

Besides Lin, several other lawmakers, including Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- who is also a co-convener of the Legislative Defense Committee -- will also take part in the inspection cruise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BANKS REACH OUT TO VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Vietnam has emerged as a red hot market for Taiwan's finance industry, with banks rushing to set up footholds in the Southeast Asian country to cash in on its economic boom, industry sources said Monday.

Statistics compiled by the Financial Supervisory Commission under the Executive Yuan show that eight Taiwan-based banks, including Chingfon Bank, Chinatrust Commercial Bank, Bank SinoPac, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Cathay United Bank and Union Bank of Taiwan, have set up 12 outlets in Vietnam -- five branches, six representative offices and one affiliate.
Eight of the establishments are in Ho Chi Minh City and four in Hanoi.

Taiwan banks are keen to seize a larger slice of the Vietnamese market due to its high flying economy, which has attracted a large number of Taiwan investors, making Taiwan the leading foreign investor in Vietnam, the sources said, pointing out that Vietnam's state-run companies, such as its water and power companies, are also potential good clients.

Although the Taiwan banking industry considers the Vietnam market as very important, the sources pointed out that some development difficulties remain, referring to restrictions set by the Vietnamese government.

The Vietnamese government requires minimum capital investment of US$15 million by a foreign-owned branch and a Taiwan bank in Vietnam is limited to luring deposits that amount no more than two times of its capital, the sources said, forecasting, however, that the "Vietnam fever" in the Taiwan banking industry will not wane in the short term thanks to the country's economic potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFORTS TO CUT GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS MISSING TARGET: EPA

TEXT.P: An environmental protection official said Monday that strategies set at the 1998 National Energy Conference to cut greenhouse gas emissions have proved ineffective and that a target set that year is not expected to be achieved.

The second National Energy Conference was held at the Taipei International Convention Center Monday, a two-day meeting that brings together experts, industry representatives, scholars and government officials to discuss structural adjustments for the use of energy in Taiwan, as well as policies and measures that should be taken to meet the requirements of the Kyoto Protocol.

At the 1998 meeting, a series of strategies were laid down with the goal of maintaining the growth of Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions at the 2000 level through 2020. However, Ho Shun-chin, head of the department of air quality protection and noise control of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said efforts made to achieve the goal have been a waste of time.
Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions have continued to surge since 1999, Ho said, citing the latest EPA statistics.

The official also noted that the average annual growth rate of carbon dioxide emissions among Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) member states reached 0.98 percent, while Taiwan posted an increase rate of over 6 percent. She suggested that Taiwan should learn from the organization, which has helped its members enjoy economic growth without sacrificing the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE ENVOY EXPRESSES STANCE ON FISHING DISPUTES

TEXT.P: The de facto Japanese ambassador to Taipei paid a visit to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Monday to express Japan's stance on Taiwan's plan to send a naval ship to patrol disputed waters where the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Tadashi Ikeda, director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) , was quoted as having told MOFA officials that international fishing disputes should be resolved through negotiations instead of by deploying warships. JIA is a quasi-official body authorized to handle Taiwan-Japan exhcnages in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Ikeda further said the Japanese government considers Taiwan's decision to send a military vessel to the disputed waters for an afternoon -- a stunt dreamed up by opposition lawmakers supposedly to demonstrate determination to protect Taiwan's fishing rights -- to be "inappropriate."

The Japanese envoy was also quoted as having stressed that if Taiwan decides to go ahead with its warship deployment, the vessel should not traverse the middle line of the two countries' overlapping economic zones. Otherwise, Ikeda said, the Japanese government cannot guarantee whether or not it will take action in response.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

Ikeda's message came shortly after the Ministry of National Defense (MND) announced that a Knox-class frigate will be sent to patrol Taiwan's northeastern economic waters Tuesday. According to the MND announcement, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and several members of the Legislative Defense Committee will be on board the ship to inspect the navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the disputed northeastern economic waters.
MOFA officials refused to comment on Ikeda's message from the Japanese government, saying only that the MOFA has informed the defense minister of Japan's stance on the issue.
MOFA officials said they will keep a close watch on whether the frigate patrol will affect the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks scheduled to take place in July.

The MOFA was originally scheduled to call an interministerial meeting Tuesday to work out strategies for the upcoming new round of Taiwan-Japanese fishery talks. But MOFA officials said the meeting will be postponed because Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau, who is to preside over the interministerial meeting, will be otherwise engaged that day.

The deployment of the frigate is part of the MND's response to a legislative demand that the navy more actively assist in protecting local fishermen's rights to operate in the disputed waters, the sources said.

According to the MND schedule, the defense minister and lawmakers will travel to a naval base in Suao in the northeastern county of Ilan early Tuesday. The frigate -- the Fengyang -- is scheduled to arrive in the disputed economic waters at around noon and to return to Suao that afternoon.

MND sources said the cruise will be confined to waters some 60 nautical miles off Taiwan's northeastern coast. To ensure safety, other naval ships will patrol at distance, while military aircraft will be on routine flight missions in the region.

The MND agreed to send the frigate to the disputed waters under strong pressure from opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ling Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the area earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships that frequently chase them away from what they call their traditional fishing grounds.

Besides Lin, several other lawmakers, including Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- who is also a co-convener of the Legislative Defense Committee -- will take part in the inspection cruise.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATIENCE REQUIRED TO BRING ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT LEADERS' MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with China said Monday that it requires patience to bring about a meeting between the presidents on each side of the Taiwan Strait.
Chang Chun-hsiung, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the CNA.

Chang noted that some said after meetings between the leaders of the two largest opposition parties -- Lien Chan of the Kuomintang and James Soong of the People First Party -- with Chinese President Hu Jintao in April and May, respectively, that President Chen Shui-bian might feel an urgent need fo a meeting with Hu. In fact, the president has no such feeling, he added.

Chang said the international community hopes there will be cross-strait government-to-government dialogue, adding that Chen, who is committed to improving cross-strait relations and the people's welfare, also hopes for a meeting with Hu.
However, both sides should start dialogue first and build up mutual trust and understanding before such high-level dialogue can take place, Chang said.
"A hasty Chen-Hu meeting will get us nowhere, " Chang said, adding that such a meeting requires gradual and patient promotion.
Chang added that issues concerning the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will not be decided unilaterally.
He also said that when the time is ripe, he is willing to meet with his counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Exchanges of visits will have positive effects on cross-strait relations, Chang said, adding that he would welcome more exchange and communications between Beijing and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Faced with what he claimed is the more flexible, softer approach of Hu and Premier Wen Jiabao toward Taiwan, he also said Taiwan must re-forge internal consensus.

He said the Taiwan people displayed bravery in the face of China's missile threats, but now Beijing has launched a charm offensive by inviting opposition leaders to visit and by offering zero-tariff treatment for Taiwan's agricultural produce.
"I must admit, Taiwan people are not used to this kind of offensive," Chang added.

He said that he has suggested several times that the DPP adjust its strategy and that the party "must let the people know about the advocacy of the government, " especially the advocacy of "reconciliation and symbiosis" and the "maintaining of the status quo."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO ATTEND WORLD FORUM IN COLORADO

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will travel to the United States Tuesday to attend the 2005 World Forum in Colorado, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Monday.
The officials said Chen will address a seminar to be organized by the World Affairs Council of San Francisco on his way to Colorado.

The foreign minister is expected to explain Taiwan's political and economic development, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular interactions in his speech, they revealed.

The World Forum is an annual conference of government officials, legislators, business and financial leaders and academics that is sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based think tank.

During the annual event, senior U.S. Cabinet officials and lawmakers will provide candid briefings on important policy initiatives, heads of international corporations will discuss business and financial developments and government officials from Europe, Asia and the Americas will debate international strategic and economic issues in a private and informal atmosphere, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRIGATE DEPLOYMENT WILL NOT CAUSE CONFLICT: MND

TEXT.P: Tuesday's deployment of a Knox-class frigate to a disputed part of the East China Sea where the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap will not cause any conflict, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official predicted Monday.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, made the forecast after Tadashi Ikeda, director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), paid a visit to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) earlier in the day to express Japan's stance on Taiwan's plan to send a naval ship to patrol the disputed waters northeast of Taiwan.

Ikeda was quoted as having told MOFA officials that the Japanese government considers Taiwan's decision to send a military vessel to the disputed waters for an afternoon -- a stunt dreamed up by opposition lawmakers supposedly to demonstrate determination to protect Taiwan's fishing rights -- to be "inappropriate."

The de facto Japanese envoy was also quoted as having stressed that if Taiwan decides to go ahead with its warship deployment, the vessel should not traverse the middle line of the two countries' overlapping economic zones. Otherwise, Ikeda said, the Japanese government cannot guarantee whether or not it will take action in response.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

The MND official said the frigate that will be on the patrol mission Tuesday will cruise within the area some 60 nautical miles off Taiwan's east coast. The area is open sea and the vessel will not traverse the "temporary demarcation line" set by the government for the nation's coast guard patrol ships to police.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and several members of the Legislative Defense Committee will be on board the 4,200-ton frigate -- the Fengyang -- to inspect the navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the disputed northeastern economic waters.

The MND agreed to deploy the frigate under strong pressure from opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ling Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the area earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships that frequently chase them away from what they call their traditional fishing grounds.

Besides Lin, several other lawmakers, including Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- who is also a co-convener of the Legislative Defense Committee -- will take part in the inspection cruise.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TO SIGN FTA WITH GUATEMALA IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Guatemalan President Ocar Berger Perdomo has agreed to visit Taiwan in August and that he hopes to sign a Taiwan-Guatemala free trade agreement (FTA) with him by that time.
The president made the remarks when he received Jorge Mendez Herbruger, president of the Guatemalan Congress, at the Presidential Office.

Chen said he invited Berger recently for a visit, and the latter agreed to take part in the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union initiated by Vice President Annette Lu in mid-August and deliver a keynote speech at the event.
Chen said Taiwan and Guatemala have close trade and economic relations, that FTA talks are progressing smoothly and that he is confident the two sides can sign the agreement during Berger's visit.
He expressed appreciation that the Guatemalan Congress has since 1991 had a group friendly to Taiwan and that it has passed resolutions every year to support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.
Chen said he was also gratified to see that the legislatures of the two countries have set up Web sites to provide a platform for bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT 3 YEARS PRIME TIME FOR TALKS WITH CHINA: SEF CHIEF

TEXT.P: From now to 2008 is the prime time for talks between Taiwan and China, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday.

Chang noted in a CNA interview that President Chen Shui-bian's term still has three years to go, that Beijing is gearing up to host the 2008 Olympics and that both Taiwan and China will enjoy a relative stable period conducive to the establishment of a peaceful framework between Taiwan and China through dialogue.

With the mandate of the people, Chen is fully authorized to talk with China and if China wants to improve ties with Taiwan it should talk to the popularly elected president rather than any opposition parties, Chang pointed out.

Although Beijing triggered so-called "China fever" in Taiwan by inviting two opposition leaders to visit in April and May and giving them red-carpet welcomes, the international community still believes Beijing should talk to the president, Chang said.
Any agreement Beijing has concluded with the opposition parties will not necessarily be translated into policy in Taiwan unless it is approved by the government, he pointed out.
Although he is a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Chang said he has always advocated improved ties with Beijing and is therefore a suitable head for the SEF.
He denied that his SEF chairmanship is a sinecure and a form of patronage given to him by President Chen Shui-bian, arguing that he is not being paid for his duties.

He also denied that the SEF, a quasi-official body set up to deal with China on behalf of the government, has been swept to the sidelines after Premier Frank Hsieh asked two private groups this month to negotiate with China over the issues of bilateral charter flights and the trade of fruit, saying that his foundation supports a pragmatic approach toward issues with China and does not care about being passed over for these tasks.

Furthermore, Chang explained, although Beijing has severed contacts with SEF since 1999 for political reasons, the problems of mutual concern cannot wait until a thaw in bilateral relations and if private groups can sort out such issues before the SEF resumes contact with its Beijing counterparts, "then that's all right."
As the chief of the SEF, Chang said, he would like to see a resumption of contact as soon as possible, but he added that it is beyond the ambit of his foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HOPES TO VISIT CHINA IN CAPACITY AS PARTY HEAD

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that if elected chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), he will not rule out the possibility of visiting China in his capacity as the party's head.

In an interview with CNA, he also said that if elected in the July 16 election, he will integrate the KMT's allies -- the New Party and the People First Party (PFP) -- in the "pan-blue alliance" so as to regain power in the 2008 presidential election.

Only by doing so will there be hope for cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he claimed, adding that this is because the KMT advocates the so-called "1992 consensus" -- referring to what it claims was a tacit unwritten agreement to allow different interpretations to the meaning of "one China" in cross-strait talks in Hong Kong in 1992 that led to the first high-level talks the following year after a hiatus of nearly five decades.

In this way, Beijing would be willing to come to the negotiation table and it would be possible to set up direct cross-strait transportation links, establish military buffer zones and sign a cross-strait peace agreement, he claimed.

Wang, who is the convener of a group on cross-strait affairs in the legislature, said that if he visits China in his speakership capacity, he would have to go under the premise of national need, public agreement and legislative resolution, as well as equality and dignity.
The timing for these conditions is not ripe, Wang went on. Comparatively, the condition to travel to China in his capacity as the KMT head is more lax, he added.

On cross-strait policy, Wang said that if elected KMT chairman, he will reactivate the National Unification Guidelines and the National Unification Committee, which have been moribund since President Chen Shui-bian took office for his first term in 2000.

He also claimed that recent visits of China by KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong have brought a positive atmosphere to cross-strait exchanges, but as the opposition parties have no government authority, the momentum for such exchanges cannot continue.
If the "pan-blue alliance" wins the 2008 presidential election, cross-strait relations will naturally warm up, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INVESTMENT IN CHINA DECREASES SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment in China fell sharply in the first five months of this year, decreasing by 28.78 percent to US$1.96 billion from the previous year's level, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The MOEA Investment Commission approved a total of 536 projects for investment in China during the January-May period, the tallies show.
In May alone, the Investment Commission approved 128 investment projects in China worth a combined US$495.4 million.
Also, the commission approved 250 overseas investment projects with a combined value of US$840.7 million from January to May, down 23.22 percent year-on-year.

Meanwhile, the commission gave a green light to 429 foreign and overseas Chinese direct investment projects in Taiwan worth US$973.69 million during the period between January and May, down 29.07 percent from the figure recorded a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN HOPEFUL TOUTS HIMSELF AS BEST CHOICE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng touted himself as the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) best choice for party chief Monday, claiming that only a party chief who doubles as the legislature speaker can solve the thorny problems plaguing the KMT.

In an interview with CNA, the KMT vice chairman who is running for the chairmanship said the two problems facing the party are the handling of its alleged ill-gotten assets and its cooperation with the People First Party (PFP) in the year-end elections of county and city chiefs.
In order to dispose of its assets, Wang claimed, the KMT has to break through what he described as the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's "blockage."

As the legislature speaker, and, if elected, chairman of the KMT -- which controls 80 seats in the Legislative Yuan -- Wang claimed he can unite with other political allies in the legislature to keep the DPP government in check by holding the government's purse-strings tightly and enacting laws.

If he takes the reins of the KMT, Wang claimed, his role and experience as the legislature speaker will stand him in good stead when he searches for party candidates for the year-end elections, and will give KMT the best hope for victory.

Noting that the PFP has floated three prerequisites for a possible merger with KMT, including the retirement of Lien Chan, stopping "patronizing" the PFP and combining the KMT and the PFP into a new party, Wang claimed he can meet all three conditions without problems.
He said Lien has decided to retire and added: "I am not the person who will throw his weight around and I will treat the PFP on an equal footing."
Actually, Wang said, the KMT needs the PFP's support in the legislature while disposing of its controversial assets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 21, or the 15th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: The US Constitution comes into effect.
1900: Battles rage in both Beijing and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: Russian composer Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in Scotland's Orkney Islands are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's General Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He had accepted on June 6 General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1976: A 36-member Republic of China delegation to the 22nd Asian Film Festival returns to Taipei from South Korea after winning nine awards.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan calls on free nations to assume moral responsibility for Indo-Chinese and mainland Chinese refugees and to take effective action immediately.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on the nation's agricultural experts to work out concrete measures to expand agricultural development in the country.
1984: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hwa orders an investigation into the cause of the Haishan coal mine disaster.
1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The ROC Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.
1993: An ROC-US agreement for technical cooperation in the field of environmental protection is signed in Washington, D.C.
1996: Leaders of the European Union reach a deal to end the mad cow crisis with Britain.
1997: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, is invited by the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to attend the ceremony marking the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to mainland China at midnight on June 30.
1999: The ROC formally joins the International Council for Small Business (ICSB), becoming the 11th chapter of the world trade body.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui describes US$300 million-worth of aid pledged to Kosovar refugees as "the chance of a thousand years," and urges the public to have empathy as well as a broader mindset.
2000: US Representative Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, submits Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address for insertion in the congressional record.
2001: New Republic of China representatives to Russia and Germany, Charles King and Hu Wei-chen, respectively, are sworn in Taipei and both men promise to further strengthen the nation's ties with the two countries.
2004: SpaceShipOne safely lands in the Mojave Desert in California after completing the first-ever space flight by a privately built spacecraft.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man after 40 is an object of dislike to men, he will continue to be so to the end of his days."
