DOC.HEADLINE: TRAIN DERAILMENT IN PINGTUNG INJURES 15 PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: A Tzichiang express train from Kaohsiung to Taitung derailed at 12: 25 a.m. Tuesday in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, injuring 15 passengers, Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) officials reported.
The accident, which occurred 8.5 kilometers south of the township of Fangliao, forced the temporary closure of the South Link Line for repairs, the officials said.
A preliminary investigation revealed that several steel rails had been deliberately removed from a section of the rail line, they said, adding that railway police are continuing their investigations.
The rail line is not expected to be reopened until about 5:00 p.m Tuesday, the TRA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD BEAR RESPONSIBILITY FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT DELAY: KMT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 20 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said in a letter sent recently to a group of members of the U.S. House of Representatives that Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party government should bear responsibility for the deadlock that has prevented Taiwan from purchasing U.S. arms.

Thirty U.S. House representatives, including Henry J. Hyde , chairman of the House International Relations Committee, sent a co-signed letter to Lien on May 27, saying that the failure of Taiwan's legislature to pass the special budget for the arms procurement has raised U.S. concerns about Taiwan's ability to defend itself against potential Chinese aggression.
In the letter, they urged Lien and his party to support the U.S. arms procurement plan and help push the Legislative Yuan to pass the relevant bill as soon as possible.

Pointing out in his letter to the U.S. lawmakers that the Kuomintang has always believed in credible defense capabilities while advocating peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Lien said that his party also believes that political prudence should go hand in hand with a strong deterrence, while not trying to unilaterally change the status quo.
"For these reasons, the KMT actively supported military procurements over the past five decades when it was in power, and it will continue to do so in the future," he noted.

Touching on the current arms procurement plan, the KMT head said that although U.S. President George W, Bush approved the arms sales package to Taiwan in April 2001, which includes diesel submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and PAC-3, the current DPP administration in Taiwan procrastinated for three years and did not present a special budget request, for NT$610.8 billion, until June 2, 2004, only nine days before the legislative session was set to end.
"The long delay could only be due to administrative incompetence or lack of political leadership, and certainly not to legislative or partisan obstruction," Lien claimed.

He also said that Taiwan lawmakers were preoccupied with their re-election campaigns after the autumn session began in September last year and therefore, serious debate only began early this year when the new legislature convened. Although Lien admitted that this represented a long delay, he pointed out that the DPP administration was well aware of Taiwan's political calendar.
"To try to squeeze the arms package through the legislature in June 2004, in my view, bespeaks a lack of serious intent on the part of the DPP administration," Lien added.

Regarding the funds needed to purchase the U.S. arms, the Ministry of National Defence first indicated to the Defense Committee of the Legislative Yuan in a closed-door session in May 2002 a figure of NT$280 billion, although no budget request was presented at the time, Lien noted. He added that nobody in the DPP government ever explained to the nation why the price suddenly skyrocketed to NT$610.8 billion in June 2004.

"Now the figure has been reduced to NT$480 billion because of exchange rate fluctuations and the dumping of the so-called 'domestic assembly' plan for the submarines, but there is still a large discrepancy between this figure and the 2002 figure as reported in the press," Lien continued.

According to the KMT head, other important questions on Taiwan's domestic debate on the military procurement issue stand out, including why everything was lumped together in a special budget request and nothing included in the regular annual budget. He said that some legislators believe that the annual budget should be used as much as possible for the arms procurement, and then a special budget could be considered.

To the surprise and dismay of many supporters of the arms package, the DPP administration first presented it in two scanty pages in June 2004, Lien said. Since then, the Ministry of National Defense's explanations have been nothing more than a few sporadic and brief pages and slides, he noted, saying it is no wonder that some political commentators have joked that the DPP administration has been more interested in explaining the plan to Washington than to the Taiwan people.

President Chen Shui-bian himself also committed a serious blunder by insisting on holding a referendum on the same day as the last presidential election on whether or not Taiwan should purchase the PAC-3s, only to see the referendum result nullified as less than half of qualified voters cast their ballots, Lien said. He added that the Legislative Yuan's hands are tied, at least on this issue, by Article 30 of the Referendum Act.
Noting that the Legislative Yuan is now in summer recess, Lien expressed the hope in the letter that the ROC lawmakers will tackle the arms procurement bill in the next session.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 TAIWANESE INJURED IN BUS ACCIDENT IN NORTHEASTERN CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 21 (CNA) (By Chiao Hsing-hua & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Ten members of a Taiwan trade delegation visiting China were injured Monday when the bus they were traveling in slid off the road in heavy rain and slammed into the buttress of a bridge in the northeastern province of Heilongjiang, a provincial official reported Tuesday.
Seven other mainland Chinese passengers were also injured in the accident, according to Wang Limei, deputy director of the provincial office for Taiwan affairs.

The medium-sized bus was one of two that the 22 members of the Taiwan delegation were traveling in on a tour of Taho County to gain a better understanding of the trade and economic development situation in the area. The delegation from Chiayi in southern Taiwan is being headed by Chiayi City Chamber of Commerce Chairman Chen Kuo-hua.
The injured Taiwanese passengers were sent to Taho People's Hospital for medical treatment, Wang said, adding that none of their injuries are life threatening.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN BANK VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN TAIWAN FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) Vice President Fabrizio Saccomanni arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit.
During his stay, Saccomanni, an Italian international finance expert, will visit major financial and banking institutions and deliver a speech on the EBRD's major functions and development projects.

A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Saccomanni will pay visits to the Central Bank of China, the Ministry of Finance, the Financial Supervisory Commission, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the International Cooperation and Development Fund.
Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau will host a dinner in honor of Saccommanni this evening.

Throughout his 35-year career, Saccomanni has held many important posts at the Central Bank of Italy and in regional and international financial organizations, including the International Monetary Fund. He has also written many articles on international monetary problems and has published a book on managing instability in the global financial system, entitled "Global Tigers, National Tamers."

His main areas of responsibility at the EBRD include risk management, treasury risk management, credit/transaction analysis, credit portfolio review, corporate recovery and official co-financing operations, as well as heading the nuclear safety department.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Democrats Block Vote On Bolton; Supporters Press for Recess Appointment.
The Senate yesterday refused for a second time to confirm John R. Bolton as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, prompting his supporters to urge President Bush to bypass Congress and give the controversial nominee a recess appointment, which would last 18 months, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER URGES SAFEGUARDING OF SOVEREIGNTY, FISHERY RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on Tuesday urged a show of resolve to safeguard the Republic of China's sovereignty and local fishermen's rights before he boarded a Knox-class frigate that was to travel to a disputed area northeast of Taiwan.

Wang and several members of the Legislative Defense Committee, accompanied by Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, boarded the 4,200-ton frigate -- the "Fengyang" -- at 9: 30 p.m. to inspect the ROC Navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the disputed northeastern economic waters.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

"From historical, geographical and legal perspectives, it is without question that the Tiaoyutais are Republic of China territory and that they have always been under the jurisdiction of the ROC," he said.
Wang said, "I couldn't disagree more" with the statement in 2002 by former President Lee Teng-hui during an interview in which he said that the islands in question are a part of Japanese territory.
He said that the Tiaoyutais are the territory of the ROC, and it is an unalienable right to safeguard the integrity of the sovereignty of the nation.

The Tiaoyutais, located 120 nautical miles off Taiwan, are under the jurisdiction of Ilan County with a postal code of 290, Wang said, adding that it is "unacceptable" that Japanese patrol boats arrest Taiwan fishermen operating in waters near the Tiaoyutais.

He said that taking a "meek and mild" approach to Japan will not solve the problem, and will only convince local fishermen that they will have to take matters into their own hands. Wang added that without the recent large protest by local fishermen, Japan would most likely not have been interested in coming to the negotiating table for a new round of talks.

He urged the government not to be weak on matters concerning national sovereignty, stressing that it is possible to share marine and mineral resources, and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can jointly tap the Tiaoyutais with Japan, but the government's attitude toward its sovereignty should be unequivocal.
Wang urged the public to show solidarity and protest the unreasonable behavior of the Japanese government.
The "Fengyang" cruised within the areas some 60 nautical miles off Taiwan's east coast and is expected to return to Suao harbor around 5 p.m. after completing its mission.

The Ministry of National Defense agreed to deploy the frigate under strong pressure from opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the area earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships that frequently chase them away from what they call their traditional fishing grounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: 28 Arrested in Spanish Crime Sting.
Spanish police have arrested 28 alleged members of criminal groups from former Soviet countries on suspicion of money laundering in what Spanish authorities have called the largest-ever crackdown on international organized crime in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Terror Camps Scatter, Persist.
U.S. counter-terrorism authorities say that the detention of a Lodi, Calif.-based group of Pakistani men this month underscores a serious problem: the Islamabad government's failure to dismantle hundreds of jihadist training camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Koizumi pledges to consider new war memorial, Roh says.
Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi told South Korean President Roh Moo Hyum on Monday that his government will consider building a new national war memorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Indon, Gambia Presidents arrive.
Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono and Gambian President Yahya A. J. J. Jammeh arrived in the Philippines yesterday to conduct their separate state visits which both aim to strengthen their economic relations with the Philippines and express support for the peace and development programs of the government in Muslim Mindanao.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Fares up; peso down to 55.
JEEPNEY and bus fares are up 33-36 percent, the peso is down to a five-month low, and companies are planning to lay off workers. To top it all, Malacanang warns the economy is in peril due to soaring world crude prices.
The Philippine Star: 'I was the winner, I did not cheat'.
President Arroyo broke her silence yesterday on purported wiretapped conversations, but only to insist that she won the elections last year without fraud, and to say that she would comment on the controversy "at the appropriate time."
The Manila Times: Arroyo: I will talk at appropriate time.
HONG KONG: President Arroyo broke her public silence Monday about allegations she rigged her election in 2004, saying she would comment on the issue at the appropriate time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 18.43 points to close at 6,278.46.
The bourse opened at 6,304.33 and fluctuated between 6,304.88 and 6,265.69 during trading. A total of 3.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.43 billion (US$2.37 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.8 percent, and foodstuff issues and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.2 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.3 percent and textile stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 442 to 402, with 169 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRIGATE DEPLOYMENT NOT TO AFFECT TAIWAN-JAPAN FISHING TALKS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The deployment of a Knox-class frigate on Tuesday to disputed waters in the East China Sea will not lead to conflict between Taiwan and Japan, Michel Lu, the spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said Tuesday.
Lu noted that the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, which is scheduled for July, will not be affected by the deployment.
The two countries are in the process of setting a date for the talks, the official said at a news conference at MOFA headquarters.

MOFA was originally scheduled to call an interministerial meeting Tuesday to work out strategies for the planned fishery talks. But the meeting was postponed after Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau, who was to preside over the event, was busy with other business, and the ministry is also considering inviting scholars and representatives of the judicial sector to attend the meeting.

The upcoming negotiations will be centered on seeking reasonable ways to settle disputes over fishing rights of Taiwan and Japan, both of whose 200-mile exclusive economic zones in the East China Sea overlap, according to MOFA.

The 4,200-ton frigate, "Fengyang, " has been sent to patrol the country's northeastern economic waters, with Minister of National Defense Lee Jye and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, as well as several lawmakers, on board to inspect the navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the disputed waters.

The cruise is considered part of the response of the Ministry of National Defense to a legislative demand for the ROC Navy to be more active in its assistance in protecting fishermen's rights to operate in the waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.071 to close at NT$31.390.
A total of US$628 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.381 and fluctuated between NT$31.335 and NT$31.409.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up nine points to close at 6,197, with 18,478 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August moved up six points to end at 6,134, with 114 contracts traded, while September futures gained 12 points to finish at 6,108, with 177 contracts traded. December futures moved down 16 points to close at 6,075, with three contracts traded, while March futures moved down seven points to close at 6,089, with 10 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,188 for July, 6,128 for August, 6,096 for September, 6,091 for December and 6,096 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
July TE futures moved down 0.6 points to close at 253.2, with 3,275 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 0.35 points to finish at 251.95, with 19 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for September, December and March.

July TF futures lost 2.8 points to finish at 944.6, with 1,879 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures moved down three points to end at 934, with 38 contracts traded. September TF futures lost two points to close at 933, with seven contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T FIRM IN SAFEGUARDING NATION'S SOVEREIGNTY, FISHERMEN'S RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The government is firm in its stance in safeguarding the nation's sovereignty and fishermen's rights, Premier Frank Hsieh reiterated Tuesday.

The premier was responding to questions regarding recent fishery disputes between Taiwan and Japan over overlapping economic zones when he attended an inauguration ceremony of the Taitung Veterans General Hospital in eastern Taiwan.
Hsieh said that the disputes are triggered by overlapping economic zones between Taiwan and Japan, and both sides will re-start negotiation on the matter at the end of this month.
He said that each side can claim sovereignty and focus on the disputed parts. As the Republic of China has no diplomatic relations with Japan, the process may have some twists and turns, he added.

Noting that Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng boarded a military vessel to travel to the disputed waters northeast of Taiwan to support fishermen's rights and to uphold the nation's sovereignty, Hsieh said the move will show the seriousness of the matter and put it in international spotlight, which he said will be favorable for fishery talks with Japan.
But he expressed the hope that the fishermen will not take the matter into their own hands lest they hurt their own interests.
Meanwhile, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said that the government will never flinch on its stance of protecting fishermen's rights and safeguarding of nation's sovereignty.
Cho Jung-tai said the Cabinet welcomes any groups or individuals to show their resolve on the matter based on national interests, but it would also like to see them act rationally.
He also said that Wang and legislators boarding the 4,200-ton Knox-class frigate earlier in the day will help make Taiwan's voice heard in the international community.
According to recent reports by ROC missions overseas, Japan has displayed goodwill toward Taiwan, Cho said.

The Ministry of National Defense agreed to deploy the frigate under pressure from opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protests in the area earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships that frequently chase them away from what they call their traditional fishing ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARCHERS PROTEST AGAINST UNFAIR TREATMENT AT WORLD ARCHERY CONTEST
DOC.DATELINE: Madrid, June 20 (CNA) (By T.L. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's national archery team attending the 43rd World Outdoor Target Archery Championship being held in Madrid June 20-26 lodged a protest against what the team called unfair treatment they received from the organizer of the event.

According to Lee Ching-ping, president of the ROC 's Archery Association, instead of allowing the team to use its "Chinese Taipei" flag decorated with Olympic rings to attend the opening ceremony, the organizer insisted that archers from Taiwan should be present at the ceremony under an ROC national flag.

Although the team told the organizer that it cannot attend any international sport event under the ROC's national flag based on the rules of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and that violating such rules might lead the Chinese archery team to protest, the organizer still wanted the team to follow their instructions, promising that they would bear the responsibility if the Chinese team protested.

Nevertheless, a ranking official of the International Archery Federation (FITA) , requested that the ROC team not use the national flag at the last minute before the opening ceremony began. Such an action immediately led ROC archers to lodge a protest to express their dissatisfaction.

Lee also requested after a discussion on the matter with newly elected FITA President Ugur Erdener that the organizer must give a clear response on how they will deal with flag-hoisting issues if Taiwan wins medals at the event.

With the assistance of James L. Easton, former FITA president and incumbent IOC vice president, the FITA officials eventually promised that the ROC team can attend all the activities of the event under the "Chinese Taipei" flag.
A total of 470 archers from 63 countries are attending the six-day competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER RECEIVES WARM WELCOME IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 20 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen arrived in San Francisco Monday for a layover en route to Colorado to attend the 2005 World Forum.
Chen received a warm welcome from more than 100 Taiwan expatriates while attending a reception in Silicon Valley shortly after his arrival.

Speaking on the occasion, Chen said relations between Taiwan and the United States have become even closer mainly because the Democratic Progressive Party administration has proved that Taiwan is not a troublemaker.

"President Chen Shui-bian has on numerous occasions stressed that Taiwan is an independent sovereign country with its sovereignty resting in its 23 million people and that Taiwan is determined to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and willing to talk with China," the minister said.
In contrast, Chen said, China is actually a troublemaker because its anti-secession legislation codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.
Chen said the main purpose of his current U.S. trip is to attend the 2005 World Forum to be organized by the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), a Washington-based think tank.
The World Forum is an annual conference of government officials, legislators, business and financial leaders and academics from major countries around the world.

During the closed-door meeting, senior U.S. Cabinet officials and lawmakers will provide candid briefings on important policy initiatives, heads of international corporations will discuss business and financial developments and government officials from Europe, Asia and the Americas will debate international strategic and economic issues in a private and informal atmosphere.
Chen said he will take the opportunity to brief conference-goers on the latest political and economic developments in Taiwan and relations across the Taiwan Strait.
On Tuesday, Chen will deliver a speech on Taiwan's progress in human rights protection and democratic reforms at a seminar to be organized by the World Affairs Council in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS ALS/MND DISEASE FIGHTER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian attended a ceremony Tuesday to introduce the third book published by Chen Hung, a patient suffering from a neurological and muscle wasting disease, hailing him as a "fighter for life."
The ceremony was held at the Taipei Municipal Chunghsiao Hospital in Nankang.

Chen Hung began to have trouble walking in 1997, with his muscles gradually atrophying and eventually he could not even swallow food. The early symptoms made doctors think that Chen had had a stroke, and it was not until 1999 that he was confirmed to have ALS/MND (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis and Motor Neurone Disease), a disease that affect some 350,000 people around the world, and kills more than 100,000 each year.
Disease is also commonly called Lou Gehrig's Disease and Maladie de Charcot, after Jean-Martin Charcot, the French neurologist who first described it in 1869.
The disease did not defeat Chen, although now he can only communicate with the outside world by blinking his eyes.
Chen began to "write" books with the help of his wife, blinking his eyes to represent Chinese phonetic symbols.
At the ceremony to introduce his third book, the president said Chen adopted the adage: "Where there is life, there is hope."
The president stressed that Chen has never given up, and no one has given up on him, adding that anyone can see Chen's courage.
Noting that Chen has inspired many people in misery to weather their hardships, the president said he has the highest respect and admiration for Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN AFFAIRS COMMISSION NOT TO BE DISSOLVED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh gave veterans his word Tuesday that the Veterans Affairs Commission (VAC) won't be dissolved; on the contrary, it will be advanced to a higher level to operate as the "Ministry of Veterans."
Hsieh made the promise while attending an inauguration ceremony for the VAC-built Taitung Veterans Hospital in eastern Taiwan.
The hospital, constructed in the Malan Veterans' Home compound in Taitung City, is part of his Cabinet's plans to expand care for aged veterans, the premier said.
It was Hsieh's first VAC activity since he assumed office in February, when he proposed a so-called "six stars" project aimed at upgrading medical care and homes for retired service personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DENIES DELAYING U.S. ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: A Cabinet official denied Tuesday a claim by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government should be held responsible for the deadlock facing the country's latest arms procurement plan from the United States.

In a letter sent recently to a group of members of the U.S. House of Representatives, Lien accused the DPP government of procrastinating for three years before it presented a special budget request for NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) in June 2004 to buy a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and eight diesel-electric submarines.

Although the amount of the procurement was later reduced to NT$480 billion because of exchange rate fluctuations and the exclusion of a plan to assemble the submarines in Taiwan, the Cabinet failed to explain to the nation why the figure skyrocketed from the originally disclosed NT$280 billion, Lien said.
Lien also mentioned that a referendum held last year on whether to purchase more anti-missile armaments was declared invalid because less than half of the eligible voters took part in the poll.
However, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said none of what Lien said is true.
Cho said the government did not delay the budget submission and that it is the KMT that has been blocking the bill from being included in the Legislative Yuan's agenda.
On the amount of the procurement, Cho said legislators can always raised the issue for discussion when they review the budget plan.
Also, the referendum on the anti-missile armaments failed because Lien was asking "pan-blue" supporters to boycott the referendum, Cho noted.
He said the Cabinet hopes that the legislature will call a special session in July to review the proposed budget for the arms procurement package.
Otherwise, the Cabinet expects the legislature to pass the proposed budget as soon as possible during the next legislative session starting in September, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIGHTERS ON COMBAT TRAINING, NOT ESCORTING FRIGATE MISSION

TEXT.P: An official of the Hualien Air Base said Tuesday that several fighters were on combat training flights when a Knox-class frigate set sail carrying Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and several legislators to a disputed area northeast of Taiwan.
Yang Chi-yuan, deputy head of the 401st Tactical Fighter Wing, stressed that whether the fighters were escorting the frigate for safety reasons was secret, and he couldn't comment on it.
But he said that the eight F-16 fighters and one anti-submarine plane from the ROC Navy were in the air at the time for routine combat training flights.

Wang boarded the 4,200-ton frigate -- the "Fengyang" -- earlier in the day to inspect the ROC Navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the disputed northeastern economic waters.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutais in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN FISHERY TALKS TO TAKE PLACE NEXT MONTH: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 21 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The next round of fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan is expected to take place next month, Chen Horng-chi, deputy Republic of China Representative to Japan said Tuesday.
But the exact date of the talks will have to be finalized pending further consultations, he added.

On the government's deployment of a frigate to a disputed area northeast of Taiwan, Chen said that it is only natural for any nation to safeguard a nation's sovereignty, and Japan has no reason to oppose to such a move.
But Chen also said that both Taiwan and Japan should refrain from adopting provocative actions over disputes triggered by overlapping economic zones.
Japanese media prominently reported on the ROC government's deployment of a frigate to the disputed waters, but the Japanese government has responded in a low-profile manner.

Yoshinori Ono, head of the Japan Defense Agency, urged both sides to deal with the issue calmly, adding that his agency will only observe the developments of the matter and that there is no need to take any action.
The Japanese Maritime Safety Agency only said that it has not adopted any special measures Tuesday and is maintaining normal operations.
ROC Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng boarded a Knox-class frigate that traveled to a disputed area northeast of Taiwan earlier in the day.

Wang and several members of the Legislative Defense Committee, accompanied by Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, boarded the 4,200-ton frigate to inspect the ROC Navy's patrol missions off Taiwan's east coast and how it assists in protecting local fishermen operating in the disputed northeastern economic waters.
The area in dispute refers to waters close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Democrats Block a Vote on Bolton for the Second Time.
For the second time in a month, U.S. Senate Democrats blocked a vote on Monday evening on the nomination of John R. Bolton to be ambassador to the United Nations, raising the possibility that President Bush will circumvent the confirmation process and appoint Bolton when Congress recesses. The vote, a setback for both President Bush and Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, came after the White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., made a fruitless attempt to negotiate an end to the impasse with one of Bolton's chief Democratic opponents, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware. With Biden and other Democrats holding firm in their demand for the White House to release information relating to Bolton, his future is unclear.
Wall Street Journal: As Oil Prices Swing, Gas-Station Owners Try Futures Market.
The gas-station business in the United States is in turmoil, largely because of wildly zigzagging energy prices. With oil prices once again hitting record highs, profit margins have been squeezed for operators from mom-and-pop independents to the company-owned stations of Exxon Mobil Corp. A growing number of gas-station owners are now using the futures markets, up from almost nothing two decades ago. That tally doesn't count giant integrated oil companies such as Chevron Corp. or Exxon Mobil, which have been active in the futures markets for decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFORMATION, COMMUNICATIONS EXPORTS DECREASE IN 2004: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The ratio of electronic exports to Taiwan's total exports surged to 23.3 percent last year from the 1995 level of 14.6 percent, while that of exports of information and communications manufacturers dropped to 7.4 percent from 13.2 percent in 2000, according to the latest official statistics released Tuesday.
A report compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that industrial exports took the lion's share of exports in 2004, with a ratio of 98.6 percent.

The report about changes in Taiwan's trade structure in the past 10 years indicates that the drop in exports by the information and communications sector resulted from increasing relocation of the industry overseas.
In terms of imports, agricultural and industrial raw materials increased in both 2003 and 2004, with increases of over 7 percent recorded in each of the two years.
In the capital equipment sector, the ratio of imports posed a slight growth to 21.4 percent last year from the 20.5 percent recorded in the previous year, according to the report.

In its analysis of overseas markets, the DGBAS said China and Hong Kong surpassed the United States to become Taiwan's largest market, accounting for 36.7 percent of the country's exports last year, an increase of 13 percentage points from the 1995 level.
The share of exports to the U.S. market in 2004 dropped to 16.2 percent, while exports to Japan fell to 7.6 percent.
In terms of import sources, Japan was Taiwan's biggest source of imports last year, accounting for 25 percent of the total, followed by the United States with 12.9 percent, the DGBAS report shows.
The report also indicates that imports from China and Hong Kong have been increasing, up 6.4 percentage points from the 1995 level to 11.2 percent for 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SUGGEST JOINT MANAGEMENT OF OVERLAPPING ECONOMIC ZONES

TEXT.P: Taiwan will suggest that Japan shelf their conflicting sovereignty claims to waters where the two countries' 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zone overlap and jointly manage them, Lee Jen-chyuan, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday.

Emerging from a meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Lee told journalists that under the proposal of his office, both Taiwan and Japan should stop enforcing their laws in the overlapping zone to calm the disputes over Taiwan fishermen's right to fish in this area.
Meanwhile, maritime sources in this area should be managed and protected jointly by Taiwan and Japan, and both Japanese and Taiwanese fishermen can operate in this area, Lee said.
This proposal will be raised at the 15th Taiwan-Japan fishing talks, which are expected to begin in July, Lee said.
He refused to say whether or not Japan would accept this suggestion.

The COA's proposal is aimed at addressing local fishermen's complaints that they are chased away or arrested by Japanese coast guard for fishing in these controversial waters between Taiwan and Japan, especially near the Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by both Japan and Taiwan.
The government is under great pressure to deal with the issue after a recent series of news reports about Taiwan fishermen being arrested by Japanese coast guard and being fined heavily in this area.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREENS' URGE KMT TO SUPPORT U.S. ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Tuesday to support their proposal to hold a special legislative session to review the Cabinet-proposed budget for a NT$480 billion (US$15.33 billion) arms procurement package from the United States.

Calling Lien's attention to the continued military buildup by China and its threat to the security of Taiwan and the Asia-Pacific region, William C.T. Lai, a whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, said Lien should be responsible to history.
Lai was responding to Lien's claim that the DPP government should be held responsible for the deadlock facing the arms procurement plan.

In a letter sent recently to a group of members of the U.S. House of Representatives, Lien accused the DPP government of procrastinating for three years before it presented a special budget request for NT$610.8 billion in June 2004 to buy a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and eight diesel-electric submarines.

Although the amount of the procurement was later reduced to NT$480 billion because of exchange rate fluctuations and the exclusion of a plan to assemble the submarines in Taiwan, the Cabinet failed to explain to the nation why the figure skyrocketed from the originally disclosed NT$280 billion, Lien said.
Lien also mentioned that a referendum held last year on whether to purchase more anti-missile armaments was declared invalid because less than half of the eligible voters took part in the poll.
Lai expressed his regret over Lien's allegations, saying it is the KMT that has for the past two legislative sessions been blocking the budget bill from being included in the legislature's agenda.

Lai said there has not been a huge discrepancy in the amount for the procurement as Lien has claimed, with the exception of that which is a result of changes made to reflect exchange rate fluctuations and the exclusion of a plan to assemble the submarines in Taiwan.
Ho Min-hao, convener of the TSU legislative caucus, called Lien a liar for blaming the DPP for the deadlock of the arms procurement plan.
According to Ho, the amount of the procurement skyrocketed mainly because the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party (PFP) insisted that the submarines be assembled in Taiwan.
Also, the KMT and PFP have jointly obstructed the inclusion of the budget bill in the legislature's agenda on as many as 72 occasions, Ho pointed out.

However, PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao, who also serves as director of the party's Policy Research Center, said the PFP strongly opposes holding a special legislative session to review the arms procurement plan and financing the procurement with a special budget.

In addition, the PFP will continue to boycott the procurement unless President Chen Shui-bian apologizes for his unfounded claim that PFP Chairman James Soong had met secretly in the United States with Chen Yunlin, head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, Chang said.

Meanwhile, Chen Chieh-ju, secretary-general of the minority Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, said his party supports the arms procurement but believes adjustments should be made to its amount and items to avoid wasting money.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD NOT ABANDON INDUSTRY FOR GREENHOUSE GAS REDUCTION

TEXT.P: An industrial leader urged the government Tuesday not to abandon any industry in order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Hou Chen-hsiung, chairman of Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, made the remarks at a national conference in Taipei aimed at working out countermeasures in response to the implementation of Kyoto Protocol, which aims to limit the global emission of greenhouse gases.

While urging heavy energy-consuming industries to upgrade their production processes and equipment, Hou also suggested that the government cooperate with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America in the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) under the Kyoto Protocol.
Under the CDM, industrialized countries can invest in greenhouse gas emission reduction projects in developing countries and to buy carbon dioxide credits for reductions achieved in these countries.

According to Hou, Taiwan's energy structure, the ratio of each type of energy, as well as its total energy policy, should be reviewed completely to reach the carbon dioxide emission reduction target set for Taiwan.

Noting that no country has ever abandoned any industry for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, Hou said that by improving equipment and adopting advanced production technology, the country can easily reach its goal of reducing carbon dioxide emissions and industrial upgrading at the same time.
He suggested that the government present a comprehensive industrial development policy to cope with the Kyoto Protocol.

The government should hold constant dialogues with industry representatives, set up greenhouse gas emission reduction targets for the various industries, offer incentives for reductions, create a policy or an environment friendly to the reduction, as well as encourage entrepreneurs to participate in CDM projects, Hou added.

However, environmentalist Chang Tze-chien from Yunlin County expressed a different opinion, describing heavy energy-consuming industries as being like high-calorie junk food and claiming they cannot upgrade their energy use efficiency.

Pointing out that Taiwan has passed the era when heavy energy-consuming industries played a pivotal role in pushing the country's economic growth, Chang urged the government to limit the development of these industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TO LAUNCH SPECIAL OPERATIONS TO PROTECT FISHERMEN

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) will launch special operations during fishing seasons to protect Taiwanese fishermen operating in disputed waters, CGA Director-General Shi Hwei-yow said Tuesday.
Shi said the CGA will also send vessels to escort fishing boats in their main fishing grounds as long as they do not trespass into the territorial waters of other countries.

Shi made the remarks in response to questions from the press after delivering a report on the Taiwan-Japan fishery dispute to the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Shi said there is a clear division of labor between the CGA and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) in the government's efforts to protect fishermen, with the CGA on the frontline and the MND in the rear.
According to Shi, involving the military directly in international fishery disputes could lead to military confrontation and therefore the military will consider carefully when it will step in.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINAL RICE SHIPMENT SENT TO INDONESIA FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The final shipment of rice donated by Taiwan to Indonesian tsunami victims left from the southern port of Kaohsiung Tuesday.

To help the victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster that struck several countries in Southeast and South Asia, Taiwan's representative office in the United States signed a memorandum of cooperation on behalf of the government with the U.S.-based charity organization Feed the Children, under which Taiwan agreed to donate 10,000 metric tons of rice to Indonesia, one of the hardest-hit countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-GUATEMALA TIES UNAFFECTED BY GUATEMALAN MINISTER'S CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Guatemala remain firm despite the current visit to China by Guatemalan Economics Minister Marcio Cuevas, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, the Republic of China embassy in Guatemala was informed beforehand of Cuevas' plan to visit China and the Guatemalan government promised that the trip is aimed solely at seeking business opportunities to narrow Guatemala's trade deficit with China.
MOFA officials said the close interaction between Taiwan and Guatemala shows that bilateral relations have not been affected by Cuevas' visit to China.

For example, Jorge Mendez Herbruger, president of the Guatemalan Congress, is currently on a visit to Taiwan, while Guatemalan President Oscar Berger will visit Taiwan in August for the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union, the officials said.
The two countries are also expected to sign a free trade agreement in August, they added.

With its gross domestic product amounting to US$24.7 billion in 2004, Guatemala is the largest economy in Central America. The trade volume between Guatemala and China totalled US$436 million in 2004, up 41.7 percent over 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS FROM EUROPEAN UNION TO VISIT TAIWAN FOR CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: The 17th Taiwan-E.U. Economic and Trade Consultation Conference will be held in Taipei June 28, with several important officials from the European Commission participating, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.
In addition to E.U. Representative to Taiwan Brian McDonald, several vice ministerial-level officials from the European Commission will also attend the conference, according to the official.

For Taiwan's part, officials from MOFA, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and national security agencies will participate in the meeting, in which both sides will discuss topics of mutual concern, such as the E.U. arms sales embargo on China, Taiwan's participation in international organizations, and trade between Taiwan and the European Union.
The meeting is aimed at working out guidelines and confirming cooperation projects between the two sides, the official added.
As the European officials come from many agencies and spectrums, the meeting is expected to help strengthen mutual understanding and elevate cooperation efficiency, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PANS LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER OVER WARSHIP DEPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng has set a bad example of the legislature encroaching upon the administrative power by demanding that the military send a warship to patrol a disputed part of the East China Sea, a ruling party lawmaker said Tuesday.

Legislator Kao Chih-peng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made the remarks after Wang, accompanied by Minister of National Defense Lee Jye and more than 10 lawmakers, made a rare voyage aboard a Knox-class frigate earlier in the day to the disputed waters northeast of Taiwan where the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap.

Speaking at a weekly meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee, Kao said Wang was using the warship deployment as no more than a campaign gimmick to boost his chances of winning the July 17 chairmanship election of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The Ministry of National Defense (MND) agreed to dispatch the Knox-class frigate -- the Fengyang -- to the disputed waters under strong pressure from Wang and opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ling Yu-fang after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the area earlier this month against Japanese coast guard ships that frequently chase them away from what they call their traditional fishing grounds.
Kao said he is worried that Wang's forcing the military to deploy the Fengyang to the disputed waters could mark the start of the legislature infringing upon administrative powers and functions.

During the DPP meeting, Coast Guard Administration Minister Shi Hwei-you and Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan gave briefings on the fishing ground disputes between Taiwan and Japan.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said after listening to their briefings that the Taiwan-Japan fishery disputes involve a host of complicated problems, including the sovereignty over the Taioyutai Islands, the protection of local fishermen and the demarcation of the nation's 200-mile economic zone.

In addition to taking active steps to protect local fishermen's rights and safety, Su said the government should also work to resolve the fishing ground disputes with Japan through negotiations as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE ENTERPRISES SHOULD BE ECO-FRIENDLY: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday that future large-scale investment projects should present greenhouse gas emission reduction goals for the short, medium and long term.

Ho made the remarks at a two-day national energy conference that opened in Taipei a day earlier aimed at working out countermeasures in response to the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol, aimed at limiting global emissions of greenhouse gases.

Despite disruptions by several environmentalist groups, the participants reached several consensuses on the second day of the meeting, the most important one of which requires future large-scale investment projects to adopt the most efficient production and environmental protection technologies available in the world community and to present their carbon dioxide emission targets.

Ho said two major investment projects of the Formosa Plastics Group and the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corporation to build a steel refinery and a petrochemical complex will also have to be carried out in accordance with the new regulations.

Under the regulations, the investment companies should also help their peripheral plants to upgrade their energy use efficiency and the new heavy energy-consuming industries should promise to abide by the "cap and trade" system of meeting greenhouse gas standards under the Kyoto Protocol.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING DISPUTES WITH JAPAN TO BE SETTLED VIA TALKS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's fishing disputes with Japan as a result of the two countries' overlapping exclusive economic zones will be settled through talks, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

The disputes are more about which country's law should prevail in the overlapping zone than about conflicting territorial claims to the Tiaoyutai Islands and should be sorted out in bilateral fishery talks, the premier said.
He urged local fishermen to avoid conflicts with Japanese patrol boats by fishing within Taiwan's temporary law enforcement line where they will get the government's complete protection.
The premier also recommended that fishermen install global positioning systems on their boats to ascertain their positions and avoid unwittingly trespassing into Japan's exclusive economic zone.

Hsieh's administration has been put on the spot by opposition politicians who called for the defense ministry to protect local fishermen with warships after the fishermen complained that they were chased away from fishing grounds between Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER: FISHERY PROTECTION MISSION NOT NAVY'S JOB

TEXT.P: Fishery protection mission is not the navy's main responsibility, but it would like to show its solidarity with local fishermen in their disputes with Japan over their right to fish in waters northeast of Taiwan, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Tuesday.

After accompanying Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and a dozen lawmakers on a fishery protection mission to the country's territorial waters northeast of Taiwan aboard a navy frigate, the minister said he did not think it is a good idea to assign navy warships exclusively to protect fishermen's rights and interests at sea.
The armed force's primary job is to ensure the country's security and it will protect fishermen's rights only as a sidenote to this, Lee said.
Lee said he agreed to take lawmakers aboard the frigate on a cruise of the country's northeastern territorial waters after a demand by Wang.
He denied the cruise was no more than a political stunt staged at the request of lawmakers, claiming that the mission was to demonstrate the government's determination to protect the fishermen.
He shrugged off a statement by Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Tuesday that the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands are Japanese territory and should be protected at whatever cost, including war.

The Tiaoyutai Islands, known as Senkaku Islands in Japan, lie 102 miles northeast of Taiwan and are claimed by Japan, China and Taiwan. Taiwan fishermen are often chased away from waters near the islands by Japanese patrol boats.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAL TO BECOME TAIWAN'S LARGEST ENERGY SOURCE

TEXT.P: Coal will become Taiwan's largest energy source by 2020, accounting for 40 percent to 42 percent of the country's total energy supply, according to an adjusted national energy structure approved Tuesday by the national energy conference.

At the same time, petroleum will be the country's second-largest energy source at 32 percent, followed by natural gas at 14 percent to 18 percent, nuclear energy at 7 percent and reusable energy at 4 percent to 6 percent, the newly approved national energy structure shows.

In 2025, it continues, energy generated from coal will account for 41 percent to 45 percent of the country's total energy supply, followed by petroleum at 30 percent to 31 percent, natural gas at 16 percent to 19 percent, reusable energy at 5 percent to 7 percent and nuclear energy at 4 percent.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said the conference decided to increase the country's energy reliance on coal given that the existing global coal reserves are estimated to supply the world's consumption for some 200 years, far longer than petroleum reserves.
With respect to carbon dioxide emissions, Ho said Taiwan will adopt a "clean coal" measure to reduce pollution.
Meanwhile, she added, Taiwan will continue to decrease the use of nuclear energy to gradually achieve the nuclear-free goal set by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORCE SHOULD BE LAST RESORT IN DISPUTE-SETTLEMENT: COAST GUARD CHIEF

TEXT.P: The military option is the last resort of settling disputes between countries and should not be used in the country's current fishing disputes with Japan, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Minister Shi Hwei-yow said Tuesday.

In an interview with CNA, Shi said under a 1998 act, the Ministry of National Defense is charged with the defense of the country's territorial waters and exclusive economic zone and the enforcement of the country's laws in these waters, but that was before the establishment of the CGA.

Since the CGA came into place in 2000, a division of labor took place between the CGA and the navy, with the coast guard enforcing the country's law while the navy defends national security on the high seas.

In ironing out the fishing disputes with Japan, Shi suggested the government have recourse to diplomatic negotiations, followed by CGA patrols in controversial areas to turn up the heat on the Tokyo authorities, with the navy as the last option.

He made the comments when a dozen lawmakers led by Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng cruised the controversial waters aboard a navy frigate Tuesday in an attempt to stress the country's territorial claim.
However, Shi said, Taiwan is a democracy and the administration attaches great importance to public opinion. By deploying the warship, the government can restore the fishermen's confidence, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 22, or the 16th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as U.S. ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology with Elie Metchnikov, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: Republic of China Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best-loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai islands.
2000: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the U.S. The alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive.
2001: Oscar Alvarez, Costa Rican ambassador to the Republic of China, hosts a "Latin Night" to mark 60 years of diplomatic relations between Taipei and San Jose.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: EQUIP TAIWAN FISHING BOATS WITH GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEMS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh instructed the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) and Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Wednesday to provide financial assistance to allow Taiwan fisherman to install global positioning system (GPS) equipment on their boats to let them ascertain their positions and avoid unwittingly trespassing into Japan's exclusive economic zone.
Hsieh called for the country to seek to resolve Taiwan's fishing disputes with Japan resulting from the two countries' overlapping exclusive economic zones in a legal and rational manner.
Hsieh, a lawyer-turned-politician, stressed that the Taiwan-Japan fishing disputes should be sorted out through bilateral fishery talks based on the principle of law.

He discounted the idea expressed by some people of seeking "justice" for Taiwan fishermen in an ideological manner, saying that it is unhelpful to take a "stance" while ignoring the facts and evidence in trying to resolve such international disputes.

The premier instructed the COA and the CGA to offer financial assistance to allow Taiwan fisherman to install GPS equipment on their boats, saying that installing GPS equipment on Taiwan fishing boats is the best way to avoid further confrontation in disputed waters, such as the area of the East China Sea near the Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, Japan as well as China.
Hsieh said that South Korea has solved its fishing disputes with Japan since equipping Korean fishing boats with GPS equipment.

He urged local fishermen to avoid confrontation with Japanese patrol boats by not crossing Taiwan's tentative line of demarcation dividing the overlapping economic zones, saying that the fisherman will receive the government's complete protection within this boundary.

Meanwhile, Hsieh said the government's resolve to protect local fishermen's rights and interests and to ensure their safety is beyond question, adding that the administration has continuously made efforts in this regard and that there are concrete statistics providing evidence of these efforts.

Between 2000 and early 2005, Hsieh said, Taiwan law enforcement forces expelled 22,318 mainland Chinese fishing boats from Taiwan's economic zone, as well as 504 fishing boats from other countries, in addition to detaining 4,297 Chinese fishing boats.

Quoting tallies compiled by the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency, Hsieh said that only 11 Taiwan fishing boats have been impounded by Japanese coast guard patrol vessels since 2000, while 38 Chinese fishing boats and 102 South Korean fishing ships have been impounded by Japan during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR RATIONAL REVIEW OF FLOOD-CONTROL PROJECT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Wednesday called for a rational review of the Cabinet's proposed eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-control project and urged that the issue not be politicized.

He noted that recent torrential rains have caused serious flooding in some parts of central and southern Taiwan. During his inspection tour of six cities and counties, Hsieh said, he was impressed to see that some people expressed appreciation for those who pitched in for flood-relief work, while some people who have extracted excessive amounts of groundwater took others to task without reflecting upon their own roles in the flooding.
The premier said that it is the responsibility of the government to deal with natural disasters, adding that the eight-year, NT$80 billion project was not made in haste or on impulse.
He noted that the Ministry of Economic Affairs began to review the nagging problem of flooding two years ago but was unable to work out a substantial plan due to a lack of funds.
The Executive Yuan first put forward the project in early February, he said.
Hsieh has called for an extraordinary legislative session so as to review and pass the flood-control project quickly, although opposition parties have reacted lukewarmly to the call.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FRUITS HOLD GOOD MARKET PROSPECTS IN EUROPE: BUSINESSMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 21 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: High-quality Taiwan fruits hold good market prospects in Europe, a Germany-based businessman from Taiwan said Tuesday.
The businessman, who only revealed his surname as Lan, said Europe is a vast market and has an enormous demand for high-quality farm produce, including fruit.

Lan, who has operated mushroom farms in suburban Berlin for more than 10 years, recently imported a variety of Taiwan fruits to test the market. The fruits included pineapple, papaya, lichee, mango, lemon and guava.
"The deal is experimental in nature. I'll adjust the items to be imported in the future and packaging in terms of market response, " Lan said.

In his view, Lan said, Taiwan fruit farmers interested in exporting their produce to Europe should focus on exploring the high-end market. Taiwan fruit traders can first target upmarket restaurants and hotels as their chefs are more willing to buy high-quality fruits at high prices, he noted.
Lan himself has successfully sold various types of mushrooms in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands. His mushroom farm is one of the largest in Europe.
"So long as we can find reliable distribution channels and ensure good product quality, Taiwan fruits have good market potential in Europe," Lan said confidently.
In addition, Lan said, there is still ample room for increases in Taiwan's butterfly orchid exports to European countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO GIVE SPEECH IN WASHINGTON, D.C.

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Su Tseng-chang, is scheduled to visit the United States in early July to promote "substantive" diplomatic ties between the two countries, sources from the DPP headquarters said Wednesday.

Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , invited Su to visit the United States on behalf of the U.S. authorities. The AIT represents U.S. interests in Taiwan and handles U.S. exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

Su will visit four major cities in the United States during a tour of eight or nine days. The highlight of his trip will be giving a speech at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) think tank, a DPP official said.

Su's itinerary will include a visit to San Francisco, the first leg of his forthcoming U.S. trip, where he will meet with members of Taiwanese clan associations for talks over dinner on a wide range of subjects.
While in New York, Su is expected to meet with DPP members living in the eastern part of the United States and attend a New York Yankees game in which Taiwanese pitcher Wang Chien-ming might start.

Su would like to take the opportunity to cheer on Wang, who has made headlines in Taiwan with his strong performances as a starting pitcher for the Major League club over the past two months, according to the DPP official.
Su and his wife will also travel to Boston, where they have some private matters to handle concerning their two daughters' studies at two local universities.

Intentionally keeping his forthcoming U.S. visit low-profile, Su will only be accompanied by a few DPP officials, including Hsiao Bi-khim, director of the DPP Department of International Affairs, the DPP official said, adding that no members of the local media will be invited to join the tour.
He added that Su will not visit Japan on his way to or from the United States as rumors have said.
