DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. MARKET A GREAT OPPORTUNITY FOR TAIWAN FRUITS, FLOWERS: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 22 (CNA) (By C.C. Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Republic of China official said Tuesday in London that she is confident that various Taiwan-grown flowers and fruits have a great chance of making inroads into the British market.
Kuo Yao-chi, executive director of the 921 Earthquake Post-Disaster Recover Commission under the Executive Yuan, made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency.

Kuo, at the head of a delegation consisting of representatives from the Council of Agriculture (COA) and an agricultural association from Puli, a small town in Nantou County, which was hit hard by the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, is currently visiting the United Kingdom to promote flowers and fruits from Taiwan's earthquake-affected areas.

Pointing out that her commission's current job is to help local industries in earthquake-affected areas to prosper, Kuo said that flowers grown in Puli are very famous all over the world and that Taiwan has gained a reputation of being a "fruit kingdom."

"Taiwan's high-quality flowers and fruits have their own competitive edge, " Kao said, adding that the British importers she met with at a dinner she hosted Tuesday night at the Macdonald Hotel in London were impressed by the eight kinds of fruits and flowers she introduced.

A representative from a renowned local fruit company said after tasting a lichee at the dinner party that it was the best lichee he had ever tasted, promising that he would not only introduce the fruit to British supermarkets, but would also make a visit to Taiwan in October to better his understanding of Taiwan fruits.

During her visit, Kuo has also visited local flower exhibitions and flower markets to promote Taiwan flowers. Kuo said she is encouraged by the positive response to the quality of flowers she has introduced, saying that there is a lot of potential for growth in Taiwan flower exports to the United Kingdom. Currently, Taiwan flower exports to Great Britain stand at only US$200,00 per year, according to COA statistics.
Kuo is scheduled to leave for Manchester Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT PALAU IN LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to make an official visit to Palau June 26-29, officials from the Presidential Office reported Wednesday.
Paluan President Tommy Remengesau renewed his invitation recently to President Chen Shui-bian for a visit to the Pacific island nation.

President Chen, who visited Palau in January this year, asked Lu to make the visit to Palau this month on his behalf due to his tight schedule at the end of June, said Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of Department of Public of Affairs under the Presidential Office.
During her visit to the Republic of China diplomatic ally, Lu is also expected to attend a ceremony marking the grand opening of the Palau Royal Resort Hotel on June 28, Chen Wen-tsung said.
The six-story, 160-room Palau Royal Resort Hotel -- the newest and one of the largest hotels in Palau -- has been built by a group of Taiwanese businesspeople operating in Palau.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER WON'T FLINCH IN SAFEGUARDING ROC SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that he would "not flinch in the righteous pursuit of safeguarding the Republic of China's sovereignty and fishermen's rights and interests" even if he were not running for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship.

Wang made the remarks at a meeting of the opposition KMT Central Standing Committee in response to criticism that he was grandstanding to boost his chances of winning the July 16 KMT chairmanship election by traveling aboard a Knox-class frigate the previous day to the disputed waters northeast of Taiwan where the economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap and which have been the source of a recent spate of fishery disputes.

Wang, who doubles as a KMT vice chairman, said that if the government is turning a blind eye or is not doing enough in declaring the nation's sovereignty and protecting fishermen's operation rights, "we will of course do so, " adding that "if the government is doing so, but is not doing it in a satisfactory way, we will step up our efforts on the matter."

The disputed waters lie close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai Islands in Taiwan and as the Senkakus in Japan. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan. The Tiaoyutais lie 120 nautical miles to the northeast of Taiwan proper.
On whether he might at some point land on the Tiaoyutais, Wang said that he won't "rule out the possibility" if the opportunity arises.
Wang said the previous day that from the historical, geographical and legal perspectives, the Taioyutais are ROC territory.
He noted Wednesday that before the inauguration of the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) in 2000, the Ministry of National Defense had been in charge of assisting the protection of local fishermen.

However, he continued, the CGA has only about 200 vessels, and only 13 of them are over 500 tons, which he said is not sufficient to meet the needs of protecting Taiwan fisherman across the vast expanse of Taiwan's waters.

Wang pointed out that the CGA has only one vessel over 2,000 tons, which he said is "seriously inadequate." If the CGA proposes a budget to build more vessels over 2,000 tons, the legislature will support it, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION ATTENDS BIOTECH CONVENTION IN PHILADELPHIA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 21 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation led by Minister Without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching took part Tuesday in the 2005 annual international convention of the Biotechnology Industry Organization being held in Philadelphia.
Lin said the event, which features the world's largest biotech exhibitions, will facilitate international cooperation between Taiwan and other countries.

The delegation had before this visited various biotech organizations in Philadelphia, New York and Washington, D.C. and exchanged views with U.S. venture capital firms on the trends in biotech development, Lin said.
The delegation will on Wednesday visit the National Institutes of Health and the Federal Drug Administration, he said.

Other members of the delegation include Vice Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang; Johnsee Lee, president of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) ; specialists from the Council of Agriculture, Department of Health, and National Science Council; and executives of several pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies.

The ITRI's Biomedical Engineering Center, which is taking part in the Philadelphia convention for the third year, signed an agreement of cooperation on cartilage restoration research with the Australia-based Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization.
The center also signed an agreement of cooperation on anti-cancer drug development with the U.S.-based Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange surged Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 79.37 points to close at 6,357.83.
The bourse opened at 6,291.91 and fluctuated between 6,381.23 and 6,291.91 during trading. A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97 billion (US$ 3.09 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 1.6 percent, followed by construction shares and machinery and electronics stocks both at 1.5 percent, and textile issues at 1.0 percent.
Cement stocks, plastics and chemicals shares, as well as paper and pulp issues all registered growth of 0.7 percent.
Banking and financial shares dropped 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 656 to 207, with 153 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Republican Rule Makes Lobbying Big Business.
With pro-business officials running executive and legislative branches, lobbyists seek ways to profit from tax breaks, loosened regulations. (by Wennie Chi) ednitem

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY LAUNCHES PUBLICITY DRIVE AGAINST ANIMAL FREEING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior has prepared 20,000 fans printed with messages against freeing animals in the name of religion, which will be handed out to local Buddhist and Taoist temples and organizations, ministry officials said Wednesday.

According to the officials, the practice of releasing captive animals is intended as a charitable act, but the popularity of the practice has also encouraged the commercial breeding and hunting of wildlife.

While the large-scale, commercialized purchase and release of animals means disaster for the animals, which are unequipped to survive in the wild and invariably die slow and agonizing deaths from predation or starvation, the fact that many of the released animals are alien species is bringing about an ecological catastrophe, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES PRESIDENT TO DECLARE TIAOYUTAIS ROC TERRITORY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou urged President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday to declare the Tiaoyutai island group Republic of China territory under the jurisdiction of Toucheng, in northeastern Ilan County.
Ma, who doubles as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, made the remarks at a regular meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee.

Ma agreed with a trip made by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who along with 14 other legislators boarded a Knox-class navy frigate the previous day to travel to disputed waters in the East China Sea where the economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap and which have been the source of a recent spate of fishery disputes.

The disputed waters lie close to a group of uninhabited islets known as the Tiaoyutai in Taiwan and as the Senkakus in Japan. The island group, which lies 120 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan, is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.
Ma claimed that although reactions to Wang's trip were mixed, it was "significant" for the government and the country's fishermen but expressed hope that the stunt was not only a "flash in the pan."

The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) , the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and the navy should cooperate, with the CGA deploying on the frontline, with the navy and the MND right behind the CGA to fully protect the fishermen, he added.

Ma said the government should refuse to recognize Japan's demarcation of its economic zone from the Tiaoyutais, or it will be tantamount to an acquiescence of Japan's sovereignty over the island group.

Noting that the Tiaoyutais are currently controlled by Japan, he said this should not affect Taiwan's sovereignty over the island group, claiming that the "occupation" does not conform with international law and is illegal.
He said that the Tiaoyutai issue involves history, geography, international law and politics, and whether the issue can be put forward in an international court is still questionable.

He also said that the government should not only discuss fishery rights with Japan but also sovereignty in upcoming talks and that if Japan does not agree to discuss sovereignty, then the protection of the fishermen should be conducted more aggressively.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOA REPORT ON MAC CHAIRMAN REMARKS REPUDIATED

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) repudiated Wednesday a report by the Voice of America radio station on the MAC chairman's remarks related to cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the possible arrangement of a meeting between the leaders of the two sides.

The VOA reported Tuesday that MAC Chairman Joseph Wu has urged China to help arrange a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and China's President Hu Jintao by showing more willingness. It also quoted Wu as saying that Taipei and Beijing should use "the interpretation on the results of the 1992 Hong Kong talks " to resume dialogue between the two sides.

According to the report, Wu also claimed that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party government does not exclude an eventual unification with China, saying that it is wrong to be of the opinion that the DPP's only option is Taiwan independence.
Claiming in a press release that the report only picked out part of Wu's remarks, the MAC said that what Wu actually said is that a Chen-Hu meeting can be held when cross-strait tensions are eased.

Wu also said it is impossible for Taiwan to accept the arrangement of such a meeting if Beijing insists on maintaining its "one China" policy, military intimidation and diplomatic obstruction towards the nation, as well as demands that the country should accept certain political preconditions.

Under the current hostile relations between the two sides of the strait, Wu said both sides could have better and closer cooperation if their officials could hold talks on practical matters, including direct charter flights and tourism and agricultural exchanges.

Pointing out that in order to resolve cross-strait disputes, Chen said in March that based on the results achieved in the 1992 Hong Kong talks, he would agree on the resumption of talks with China, Wu further said that if China wants to show willingness, it should take Chen's words as a concept to rebuild a dialogue channel between the Straits Exchange Foundation and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, the quasi-official bodies on either side of the strait set up to handle exchanges in the absence of official ties.

In response to a VOA question on how to eventually resolve the problems related to Taiwan's future, Wu said it is wrong to think that the only option of the DPP after it became the ruling party is to separate Taiwan from China and cut all ties.

Chen said in his second-term inaugural speech delivered in May 20 last year that he does not exclude the possibility of developing any kind of relations with China in the future if the Taiwan people give him the mandate to do so, Wu continued.

"We don't want to pick an option and discuss it before a further debate by the Taiwan people on all the options, or to close the door, " he continued, saying that "the door of Taiwan's future is open."

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY OF ONE INCINERATOR PER CITY OR COUNTY TO BE REVIEWED: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh instructed Wednesday that the policy of having one incinerator per city or county should be reviewed in the hope that several cities or counties can share one incinerator.
Hsieh issued the instruction after listening to reports by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) at an Executive Yuan floor meeting.

EPA officials reported that the campaign to reduce garbage volume has borne fruit, greatly reducing daily transported garbage to a little over 16,000 tons in 2004 from more than 24,000 tons in 1996, representing a reduction in the amount of garbage produced per person per day from 1.143 kg to 0.709 kg.
The officials said that it is estimated that disposal fees will be reduced by around NT$600 million (US$19.04 million) this year from the previous year.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i made the suggestion that the policy of one incinerator per city and county be reviewed and Hsieh said that due to the good results of the garbage reduction campaign, some incinerators under construction may not have enough garbage to dispose of, making them redundant.
The incinerator policy was implemented by the previous Kuomintang government, the premier said.
The premier also suggested the promotion of reducing pollution emissions from vehicles and producing low energy consumption, low-pollution vehicles to help improve air quality.

In addition, the premier noted that at present there are still 12 cities and counties without sewage pipes, an issue that needs to be addressed, as sewage pipes are a major gauge of a nation's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FEARS NO NEGOTIATIONS WITH CHINA: FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 21 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not afraid of negotiating with China and will not rule out opening political talks with Beijing, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.

Chen pointed out that Taiwan has shown goodwill to China on many occasions and that President Chen Shui-bian has offered to reopen cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue based on the foundation of the 1992 talks in Hong Kong.
The minister made the remarks while giving a speech on the cross-strait situation and the triangular U.S.-China-Taiwan relations at the World Affairs Council of Northern California in San Francisco.

Saying Taiwan's resolve to deepen its democratic development remains unchanged, Chen noted that the constitutional reforms accomplished recently in Taiwan are aimed at enhancing government efficiency.
The president has promised that the second phase of reforms will not involve changes to the country's territorial boundaries or official designation, he went on.
He said Taiwan's status as an independent, sovereign state will not change and that Taiwan will stick to its position to maintain the cross-strait status quo.

On the situation in China, Chen said the "peaceful rise" claimed by Beijing has in fact posed a serious challenge to the world, because China has emerged as a superpower in terms of economy, military and nationalism but not democracy.
He urged the international community not to make concessions to China on cross-strait issues and called on Washington to promote constructive U.S.-China-Taiwan relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TO VISIT ST. KITTS AND NEVIS IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed the hope Wednesday that he can visit Saint Kitts and Nevis in early September.
The president made the remarks while receiving St. Kitts and Nevis Prime Minister Denzil Douglas at the Presidential Office.
Chen said that the Republic of China and St. Kitts and Nevis have enjoyed diplomatic relations for 22 years and he expressed hope to become the first ROC president to visit the Caribbean country.

He noted that bilateral relations are close and that various cooperation projects between the two countries are progressing smoothly, including a wharf, a multiple-function cultural center and the redevelopment of a "Warner Park" project.
He expressed appreciation for the long-term support of St. Kitts and Nevis for the ROC's bid to take part in international affairs.
He also extended a welcome to a St. Kitts and Nevis plan to establish an embassy in Taiwan.

Douglas for his part said that China's adoption of its Anti-secession Law in March, which codifies the use of force against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence, has thrown uncertainty upon the peace of the Asia and Pacific region, but he expressed belief that Taiwan should still be able to maintain positive exchanges with the international community and that its people will enjoy peace and stability.

St. Kitts and Nevis will continue to support Taiwan internationally, Douglas said, adding that the purpose of establishing embassy in Taiwan is aimed at promoting bilateral relations and learning from Taiwan's experience.

Douglas also said that his country is undergoing a major transformation, hoping to break from the sugar industry to the service and information industries. As Taiwan underwent a similar transformation, he expressed the hope that Taiwan will provide guidance in this regard.
Chen said Taiwan is happy to help by engaging in personnel training and technical exchange programs with St. Kitts and Nevis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AIRPORT NOT ON TRACK FOR DIRECT LINKS DESPITE TOURIST OPENING

TEXT.P: Despite a government plan to open Taiwan up to Chinese tourists, Taipei's Sung Shan Airport is not suitable for serving direct flights between Taiwan and China at present, a government official said Wednesday.

Lin Hsin-teh, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, made the remarks at a public hearing called by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Ting Shou-chung at the Legislative Yuan in which government officials, academicians and industry executives got together to discuss ways to develop Taipei's tourism.

Responding to Ting's proposal that Sung Shan Airport be allowed to service direct flights from Shanghai's Hongqiao International Airport, Lin said that Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taipei and Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan are more suitable.

Sung Shan Airport is not being considered by the government at present, Lin said, adding however that the domestic airport could be a study case after conditions for direct links across the Taiwan Strait have become ripe.
Appointing an airport for cross-strait direct flights will mainly depend on the situation between Taiwan and China, he explained.

Hsia Chu-jeou, a professor at National Taiwan University, said that the government should open Taiwan to Chinese tourists as soon as possible and should designate Sung Shan Airport to ply direct links with Hongqiao Airport, to help inject economic momentum to both Taipei and Taiwan.
Taiwan Visitors Association Chairman Stanley Yen urged the government to hold substantive talks with China to ward off a possible negative impact of the opening.

Arguing that the government must not pass the responsibility of preventing the absconding en masse of some groups of Chinese tourists to tourist agents, Yen said it is the government's responsibility to negotiate with China on the issue and ask the Chinese side to take measures to stop any re-occurrences.

Nevertheless, Yen called for a standard practice in receiving Chinese tourists, pointing out that there must be no differences in treating visitors from China or elsewhere. This, he said, will help Chinese visitors gain a better understanding of Taiwan and improve Taiwan's international image.
A representative from the Travel Quality Assurance Association suggested that Taiwan hotels treat Chinese tourists fairly because poor treatment will seriously taint Taiwan's image.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOBLESS RATE RISES TO 4.1% IN MAY

TEXT.P: The unemployment rate in Taiwan rose 0.06 percentage point over the previous month to 4.1 percent in May, attributed to a large number of fresh graduates joining the job market, according to a report released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
However, the May figure represented a fall of 0.31 percentage points from that of the same period of last year.
A total of 424,000 people were jobless in May, up 7,000 compared with April, when the unemployment rate hit a new low since May 2001 at 4.04 percent.
First-time job seekers increased by 4,000 in May over the previous month, mainly because of the influx of fresh graduates into the job market, DGBAS officials said.
The job-hunting wave is expected to continue well into August, they said.
Meanwhile, the number of people who quit their jobs increased by 7,000 in May, while those who lost their jobs because of business closures or layoffs decreased by 3,000.
As of May, jobless people had remained unemployed for an average 29.6 weeks, which was 0.9 weeks shorter than the figure registered in April.

By educational background, the employment rate was 4.29 percent among senior high school graduates, 4.08 percent among junior high school graduates and those with lower education, and 3.92 percent among college graduates and those with higher education.

Compared with other Asian countries, Taiwan's unemployment rate was higher than the 3.9 percent of Singapore and the 3.5 percent of South Korea, but lower than the 5.7 percent of Hong Kong and 4.4 percent of Japan, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SKYROCKET ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market surged Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved up 133 points to close at 6,330, with 43,369 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August grew 116 points to end at 6,250, with 1,101 contracts traded, while September futures gained 112 points to finish at 6,220, with 470 contracts traded. December futures moved up 108 points to end at 6,210, with 10 contracts traded, while March futures rose 122 points to end at 6,220, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,197 for July, 6,134 for August, 6,108 for September, 6,102 for December and 6,098 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, all registered growth.

July TE futures increased 6.2 points to close at 259.4, with 6,241 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 5.8 points to finish at 257, with 57 contract transactions. September TE futures rose 4.05 points to end at 253.9, with 10 contracts traded, while December TE futures gained 6.65 points to close at 252, with one contract changing hands.
March TE futures grew 8.25 points to finish at 256.3, with one contract transaction.

July TF futures surged 17.4 points to finish at 962, with 4,576 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures gained 19.2 points to end at 953.2, with 63 contracts traded. September TF futures grew 16.4 points to close at 948, with 25 contract transactions, while December TF futures moved up 15.4 points to end at 939, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Russia, Mexico Talk Up LNG
Russia and Mexico plan to work on boosting cooperation, focusing particularly on energy, President Vladimir Putin and his Mexican counterpart, Vicente Fox, said Tuesday in Moscow. Fox is on the first state visit to Russia by a Mexican president since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN ONLY CANDIDATE IN PARTY HEAD ELECTION

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng registered on behalf of party Chairman James Soong Wednesday, the last day of registration for aspirants for the PFP chairmanship.
Soong, who claimed earlier that he has no intention of running, had yet to announce whether he will run, but as no one else registered, he is the only candidate in the race.
Chin received urgent instructions from PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung and presented the signatures of 92 PFP delegates endorsing Soong to complete the registration process.

Asked whether Soong is willing to continue at the helm of the PFP, party sources said that "this is not a time to ask about his willingness" and claimed that the post is "not about power" but about a mission and responsibility.
The sources also said that although the endorsement had not received prior approval from Soong, he will take up the post with the strong urging of his supporters.
According to PFP regulations, the party will have an election and the result will be announced July 22.

Sources said that Soong "has not been in a good mood recently, " which has affected his willingness to run for the chairmanship. The PFP has seen several key members break ranks over the past two months to rejoin the main opposition Kuomintang because they are dissatisfied with Soong's meetings with President Chen Shui-bian.

PFP Legislator Lee Hung-chun, who said Soong is being plagued constantly with the party's financial problems, said he is considering asking the party's legislators and elected officials to launch a donation drive for the cash-strapped party.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15TH TAIWAN-JAPAN FISHERY MEETING SCHEDULED FOR JULY 29 IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: The 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks has been tentatively scheduled for July 29 in Tokyo, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Wednesday.
The date and venue were proposed by Japanese authorities, the official said, adding that Japan has also proposed that a preparatory meeting be held in mid-July.
According to the official, details regarding the preparatory meeting and the formal round of talks are still in the works.
"We'll make a formal announcement once all technical details are fleshed out," he added.

As to the level of the Japanese chief negotiator for the upcoming talks, the official said, the ministry is still negotiating with Japanese authorities on this matter. The highest-ranking Taiwan official in previous talks was chief secretary of the Fishery Administration under the Council of Agriculture, while the Japanese delegate was an official from its fishery agency.

For the upcoming round of talks, the official said, the Fishery Administration will continue to play the leading role, with MOFA acting as a conduit to help set the stage for negotiators from the two sides.
The official said MOFA has adopted a "double-track" formula for consultations with Japan in arranging the forthcoming fishery talks.

One track is the nation's representative office in Tokyo, which is responsible for consulting with Japanese authorities and the other is MOFA itself which is responsible for discussing with the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA) . JIA is a quasi-official body authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
The official further said MOFA has informed the Cabinet and national security units of the latest progress in preparing for the upcoming fishery talks.
Meanwhile, the official said the most urgent task now is to forge a national consensus on the basic stance for settling fishing rights disputes with Japan.

At the heart of the dispute is the two countries' sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutai Islands -- a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea located some 120 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan proper. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan. The previous 14 rounds of Taiwan-Japanese fishery talks did not make significant headway because Taiwan would not forsake its sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutais which Japan has held since 1972.

Both Tokyo and Taipei claim that the island group fall within their exclusive economic zones. Japan often fines ship owners and impounds Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter waters close to the Tiaoyutais.

The dispute came into the limelight again recently after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the disputed waters over Japanese coast guard ships' frequently chasing them away from the region. Under strong pressure from opposition lawmakers, the military sent a Knox-class frigate to patrol the disputed waters Tuesday to accentuate the government's determination to protect fishermen's rights and safety.
The MOFA official said the ministry will call an interministerial meeting around July 5 to discuss strategies for the new round of talks.
In addition, the official said MOFA plans to invite legislators, scholars and legal experts to a seminar to obtain their opinions about the issue.
MOFA also plans to arrange a meeting between relevant government officials and fishermen or fishing industry representatives, the official said.
"We hope to pool our wisdom through extensive discussions with all parties or groups concerned about the issue," the official said.

At the moment, the official said local people are divided over the sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutais. While some people advocate no compromise on the sovereignty claim, others propose shelving the sovereignty dispute and instead focusing on settling the fishing rights dispute with Japan.

"By holding an interministerial coordination meeting, we hope to seek a national consensus on the bottom line for talks with Japan and a viable package for settling the fishing rights dispute, " the official said.
He said both Taiwan and Japan should exercise flexibility in dealing with the issue.
Perhaps, he said, the sovereignty issue should be shelved for the time being and the priority should be given to fishing rights.

"We hope both sides can reach a consensus on jointly exploring and managing fishery resources in the disputed waters. By so doing, fishermen from both countries will no longer over-fish in the region and a mutually acceptable management mechanism can be established, " the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80% OF WORKERS WILL ACCEPT TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT: POLL

TEXT.P: With temporary staffing becoming a trend among local businesses to cut personnel costs, 83 percent of office workers will accept an offer of temporary employment, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
The survey was conducted by the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank on 1,326 office workers and 570 business owners June 9-21. The margin of error was plus or minus 2.6 percent.

While 96.72 percent of the respondents have "heard of temporary staffing, " 42.92 percent said they lack a full understanding of what it is all about, and 78.48 percent have never had any experience in taking temporary employment.

On the reasons that they would accept temporary employment, 63.98 percent of the respondents said because this would help enrich their work experience; 52.87 percent said because jobs are hard to find; 48.42 percent said because the working hours are flexible; 47.95 percent said because they can do the job part-time and make extra income; and 21.05 percent said because temporary employment enables them to take care of their families.

The main considerations that the respondents have in taking a temporary job include the pay (61.4 percent); benefits (39.65 percent); the opportunity to gain more work experience (37.31 percent); working hours (27.37 percent); and whether they will enjoy a five-day work week (24.21 percent).
Meanwhile, 28.77 percent of the business owners surveyed said they have hired workers through a temporary staffing agency.

While 74.39 percent of these respondents said they have done so to cope with business demand, 29.27 percent said they want to save personnel costs, and 25.61 percent said they wish to reduce administrative chores.
These business respondents hired an average of 8.43 temporary workers, which account for 7.92 percent of their permanent staff, with the duration of employment averaging 5.55 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN BANK TO SET UP OFFICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) will open an office in Taipei to help Taiwan banks reach out to countries in central and eastern Europe, a visiting EBRD executive said Wednesday.

EBRD Vice President Fabrizio Saccomanni, who arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit, said he has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs to pave the way for opening an EBRD office here.
Saccomanni said it will take a few weeks for the EBRD to complete administrative formalities before the bank can formally open an office in Taiwan.

The Italian financial expert said the new EBRD office here will help Taiwan banks forge financial ties with central and eastern European countries by joining the EBRD-funded development projects there.

Saccomanni said Taiwan banks will be welcome to take part in EBRD-backed trade promotion projects and syndicated loan projects aimed at helping EBRD loan recipient countries reinvigorate their economy and completely transform themselves into prosperous liberal democracies.
By so doing, he said, Taiwan banks can spare political and credit risks while earning reasonable profits and forging financial ties in the region.
During his stay, Saccomanni will visit major financial and banking institutions and deliver a speech on the EBRD's major functions and development projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO GOVERNMENT RELOCATION PLANS FOR INUNDATED TOWNSHIPS: CABINET AIDE

TEXT.P: The government is not planning to relocate citizens from several townships affected by recent severe flooding in central and southern Taiwan, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Wednesday.
Speaking at a news conference following the weekly Cabinet meeting presided over by Premier Frank Hsieh, Cho said that neither the Executive Yuan, nor any ministry or individual, has any such plan.
Cho quoted Hsieh as saying that any thought of relocating people is not an issue that can be taken rashly as the opinions of all concerned would have to be taken into consideration first.

According to Cho, the premier asked during the meeting whether the Ministry of Economic Affairs or any individual had put forward such a plan and he claimed that even plans under assessment do not necessarily mean that they would become government policy and be carried out.
The premier reiterated that relevant government agencies will give aid to the people affected by the floods as quickly as possible and help them get back to their normal lives, Cho said.

After heavy torrential downpours inundated central and southern Taiwan a week ago, the economics ministry has done its utmost to repair power and water facilities, while the Council of Agriculture has been dedicated to maintaining the prices of fruits and vegetables, he said, adding that the government will periodically explain to the public its pace in conducting relief operations.
Various townships in central Yunlin and southern Chiayi counties -- Taiwan's major source of farm and aquatic produce - were hardest hit by the weeklong flooding.
Experts have pointed out that the damage is mainly a result of serious land sinkage due to local farmers' and fish growers' heavy use of groundwater over the long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDEN LAUNCHES AID PROGRAM TO HELP FOREIGN SPOUSES KEEP KIDS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Eden Social Welfare Foundation launched an aid program Wednesday to help disadvantaged families with foreign spouses keep their children in the country.
An Eden spokesman said the ultimate goal of the program is to prevent low-income families with foreign wives from sending their young children abroad due to financial difficulties.

According to media reports, many young kids born to Taiwanese fathers and Vietnamese mothers are now living in Vietnam with their maternal grandparents because their parents have had a hard time earning a living in Taiwan.
The Eden spokesman said the charity has recently interviewed 81 families with Vietnamese wives to explore their views on sending their children to Vietnam for financial reasons.
"We found that 70 percent said they would rather not have to send them and would prefer to have their young children live with them in Taiwan, " the spokesman said.
Under Eden's aid program, the charity will offer NT$8,000 in subsidies to each poor family with a foreign spouse every month to help finance living expenses and educational and medical spending.

According to the Eden spokesman, a 25-year-old Vietnamese woman who sent her young daughter to Vietnam a year ago because she has to work to help with the family finances, will soon be able to welcome back her daughter with financial aid from Eden.

The results of a recent Eden survey showed that 60 percent of families with foreign spouses live on a monthly income of less than NT$30,000 and about 20,000 children born to those families cannot attend kindergartens due to financial problems.

Local people are welcome to donate funds for Eden's new aid program, the spokesman said. Donors are encouraged to call (02) 2230-6685 or visit the Web site www.eden.org.tw to obtain more information about the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L STUDENT IDENTITY CARD AND EASYCARD TO BE COMBINED

TEXT.P: The International Student Identity Card (ISIC) , which has been used by more than 400,000 Taiwan students since it was introduced 10 years ago, will be combine with the EasyCard issued by the Taiwan Smart Card Company, according to the card's local issuer Kang Wen Cultural and Education Foundation Wednesday.

The new card, to be launched July 1, will allow holders to use Taipei's Mass Transit System and take city buses just as the EasyCard used in Taipei, in addition to enjoying the original benefits carried by the ISIC.

Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu told a new conference called to announce the launch of the two-in-one card that promoting international exchanges of students has been one of the education ministry's goals, and combining the ISIC with the EasyCard will enable foreign students who visit Taipei to travel easily in the city.

The ISIC, which was established in 1949 by the International Student Travel Confederation to make travel affordable for students, has been used by more than 70 million people around the world. Its holders can enjoy low cost airfares, accommodations, tour packages, rail passes and others advantages in 106 countries.

In order to promote the new card, the Kang Wen Foundation said it will offer a special price of NT$250 for each card in July and August instead of the ordinary price of NT$350. The NT$100 deposit to the Taipei Smart Card Company is refundable when the card is returned. Students of local junior high schools or above may purchase the card.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Former Klansman Guilty of Manslaughter in 1964
A jury at Philadelphia, Miss., pronounced the 80-year-old Edgard Ray Ray Killena, a former member of the the Ku Klux Klan, guilty of manslaughter on Tuesday in the deaths of three young and idealistic civil rights workers who disappeared on a summer night here exactly 41 years ago.
The disappearance of the three men, Andrew Goodman, 20, Michael Schwerner, 24, and James Earl Chaney, 21, on June 21, 1964, drew the national news media and hundreds of searchers to Neshoba County, while Mississippi officials said publicly that the disappearance was a hoax intended to draw attention.
The case, dramatized in the movie "Mississippi Burning, " is one of the biggest in what some have called the South's "atonement trials" revisiting civil-rights-era atrocities.
Wall Street Journal: As Economy Shifts, A New Generation Fights to Keep Up
The gap between poor and rich in the U.S. has widened over the past 30 years. The divergent fates of workers in Milwaukee illustrate why it can be so hard to move up.
In 1957, Wayne Hall started to work at the age of 24. Over the years, he rose from machinery operator to machinery inspector to chief inspector and at age 72, he is retired and can afford to travel with his wife to Disneyland and Tahiti.
In 1971, Hall's stepson, Larson, went to work as a welder in the fabrication shop of a factory across the street from Badger that made rock crushers and other heavy equipment.
By 1981, he was earning roughly as much as his stepfather. But he was lai d off that year. Larson has held many jobs since -- tour-boat operator, trucker, air- conditioning repairman.
Except for one year, he has yet to earn as much as he did at the welding job. Today, he works as a computer support technician, but the contract job runs just six weeks and he doesn't know if he'll still be working after that.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT WILLINGNESS UNAFFECTED BY POLLUTION RULES: MINISTER HO

TEXT.P: As long as Taiwan clearly defines its rules regarding pollution controls, specifically regarding greenhouse gas emissions, the willingness to invest in Taiwan will not be diminished, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Wednesday.

Claiming that Taiwan's emissions of greenhouse gases are not expected to increase too fast given that energy-consuming industries are already saturated at home, Ho said that it would be more damaging if the country fails to meet its target in cutting greenhouse gas emissions.

Citing a study by National Cheng Kung University Professor Chen Chia-jung, Ho said that many of the world's major developed countries have not met their reduction targets; rather, they have in turn showed growth in their emission levels. Germany is the only country that has succeeded in cutting its emissions, she pointed out.

Ho said that it is better to leave room for future discussions at a time when national interests also must be heeded in view of the global efforts to cut pollution, namely the Kyoto Protocol that took effective early this year.

The government will ask investors to put forward their greenhouse gas reduction estimates in both the short and long term when applying for government approval for their new projects and it also will carefully examine the emission levels by old plants, she said, arguing that investment willingness will not be hindered as long as the government sets the rules clearly.

Attendees, including the economics minister and scores of experts, fell short of setting a new reduction target in the country's overall emissions of carbon dioxide at the two-day national energy conference that ended Tuesday.

They also acknowledged that Taiwan will not be able to reach the reduction target set in the 1998 national energy meeting that requires the country's greenhouse gas emissions for 2020 to be lowered to the level registered in 2000.
It also was decided in the meeting that construction of the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant will continue and that nuclear power will be slashed to only 7 percent of Taiwan's energy needs by 2020.
Many environmentalists are disappointed with the outcome of the conference, complaining that the government has broken its promise of building Taiwan into a nuclear-free country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS NEVER WAVERED ON TIAOYUTAI SOVEREIGNTY CLAIM: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday the government has never wavered on its sovereignty claim over the Tiaoyutai Islands, a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea some 120 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan proper.

"Our stance that the Tiaoyutais belong to the Republic of China has never changed," Chen was quoted as having said during an informal meeting with mayors and magistrates of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The Tiaoyutais , which have been held by Japan since 1971, are also claimed by China and Japan. As the 200-mile exclusive economic zones of Taiwan and Japan overlap in waters close to the Tiaoyutais, and bilateral fishing disputes have occurred in the region from time to time.

Chen said the recent dispute with Japan is about fishing rights rather than sovereignty. He further said the Taiwan-Japan dispute over their overlapping economic waters should be resolved through negotiations.
As the top national leader, Chen said he is obligated to defend national dignity, sovereignty, security as well as fishermen's rights and interests.
Noting that a new round of fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan will be held late next month in Tokyo, Chen said all relevant government agencies should make preparations well in advance.

Speaking on the same occasion, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou Yi-jen said the administrative branch should strengthen communications with legislators and fishermen over the fishing problems in the disputed waters.

"Some local fishermen feel that the government has not done enough to protect their rights to operate in waters close to the Tiaoyutais which they regard as their traditional fishing grounds. Until 1945, Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule. Therefore, fishermen could freely operate in waters surrounding the Tiaoyutais. Nowadays, the situation has changed. We must help fishermen adjust their notions. The government will definitely do its utmost to negotiate with Japan. Hopefully, fishermen from both sides should be allowed to operate in the overlapping economic waters," Chiou said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES SWEDISH STATEMENT AGAINST ARMS SALES TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday it "highly approves" of a statement issued by the Swedish parliament earlier this month that expresses opposition to the European Union's plan to lift its 16-year-old ban on arms sales to China.
The Swedish parliament passed the statement June 16 by a vote of 198-102.

The statement said the parliament opposes any proposal to lift the arms embargo against China now because China's human rights conditions have not improved and it worries about the threat to Asia-Pacific regional security.

It further said that if the arms ban were to be lifted now, it would be the worst possible timing given that China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law in March has heightened worries about Asia-Pacific regional stability.
In response, MOFA issued a news release praising the Swedish parliament's statement.
"We highly approve of the Swedish parliament's move, " MOFA said, adding that it hopes that other E.U. countries can listen to mainstream public opinion and deal with the arms ban issue prudently.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH DPP LOCAL GOVERNMENT CHIEFS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with mayors and magistrates from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Wednesday to exchange views on a range of issues, including fishermen protection, post-flooding relief and the year-end three-in-one elections.
Premier Frank Hsieh, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP local chapters chiefs and many other government officials were also present at the informal meeting.

Chen was quoted as having directed all central and local government officials and DPP cadres to work together to support the simultaneous holding of the elections for mayors, magistrates, city and county councilors as well as township chiefs late this year.

Chen also asked Premier Hsieh to personally head a panel to fight vote-buying in the upcoming three-in-one elections. Meanwhile, Chen said he hopes Vice Premier Wu Rong-i can coordinate all relief and aid projects in the wake of the recent flooding disasters in parts of central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS' ASSOCIATION NOT AUTHORIZED TO NEGOTIATE WITH BEIJING: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association is not authorized by the government to negotiate with China, and its leaders will have to face legal consequences if they negotiate with the Beijing regime on anything which falls within the government's purview, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials warned Wednesday.

In a statement issued Wednesday night, MAC officials said the Executive Yuan has asked the MAC and the Council of Agriculture to form a team with the aid of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council to talk with Beijing on the sale of Taiwan fruits to the mainland.
The farmers' association may exchange views with Chinese officials, but is not allowed to enter into any agreement, the MAC statement said.

The statement was prompted by a wire service report that Liu Chuan-chung, president of the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association was in Beijing at the head of a delegation Wednesday to talk with Beijing officials on the export of Taiwan's fruits to China.
The MAC statement said the Council of Agriculture cautioned the farmers' association before its officials left for China to abide by the law or to face the consequences.

According to wire service reports, representatives from Beijing's Association for Economic and Trade Exchange Across the Taiwan Strait (AETEATS) and the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association (TPFA) met to exchange views on technical issues pertaining to Taiwan's fruit exports to China on a duty-free basis.

Noting that the agricultural sectors on each side of the Taiwan Strait are complementary, AETEATS officials said the association will spare no efforts to cooperate with the TPFA to facilitate the import of 15 categories of Taiwan fruits into China duty-free.
The Beijing authorities first proposed Feb. 25 that China should open its doors to agricultural products from Taiwan, AETEATS officials said.

On May 3, Chinese officials in charge of agricultural imports announced that the number of Taiwan fruit categories allowed to be imported into China after passing quarantine checks will be increased to 18 from the current 12, while 15 categories of Taiwan fruits will be allowed to be imported duty-free, according to AETEATS officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING CENTER EXPANDS INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The Biomedical Engineering Center under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in Hsinchu has signed agreements with an Australian and an American research institutes to cooperate in research in cartilage repair and anti-cancer chemotherapy respectively.

Shih-san Su, ITRI vice president and director of the center, reported the center's international cooperation projects at a seminar at the Biotechnology Industry Organization (BIO) 2005 annual international convention in Philadelphia Tuesday.

He said that the ITRI has signed agreement with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) of Australia to cooperate in medical engineering to advance the technology of cartilage repair with the application of polymer. The Biomedical Engineering Center will join hands with a CSIRO spin-off, PolyNovo, in the project.

At BIO 2005, the ITRI has also signed a letter of intent (LOI) with the Samuel Waxman Cancer Research Foundation (SWCRF) in New York to enhance the research in anti-cancer chemotherapy. The ITRI, SWCRF and the Yung Shin Pharmaceutical Industry Co. will cooperate in testing the anti-cancer effectiveness of Benzodithiophene (BDT).

The Hsinchu-based Biomedical Engineering Center is a leading international research organization engaging in applied biomedical research and technical service. Areas of research include genomics, medical engineering, nanobiotechnology, tissue engineering, and pharmaceuticals.

Key research projects under way at the center are related to the research and development of biochips, bioinformatics, biomaterials, human stem cells, tissue repair, molecular devices, nanoparticle labeling, polymetric micelle nanocarriers, biophotonics, targeted drug delivery, and peptide drug development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 23, or the
17th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoza dies at sea on his way
back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and
religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of
Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent
for the saxophone, a wind instrument in various sizes with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube.
1894: British monarch Edward VIII is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, the American zoologist and sociologist best
known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer
expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chinese Revolutionary
Party in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected
director-general.
1922: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Ting-fang,
who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of illness in Canton at the age of 81.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying
that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan on ROC-controlled Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching as governor of Taiwan.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social
Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait, Australia and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival
returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi
and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes
off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law
during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate
membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk dies in
California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The ROC and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation
agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
2000: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao meets with
Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, agreeing to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries. ROC-Macedonia diplomatic ties ended less than a year later when Macedonian pro-Beijing forces gained the upper hand in the nation's coalition government and transferred diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
2001: The Navy General Headquarters says that it has commissioned
a lawyer to protect its legitimate rights in a kickback scandal involving its purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIPOWER CHAIRMAN NAMED

TEXT.P: Outgoing Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp.(TTLC) Chairman Hwang Ing-san will take over the helm of the Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh confirmed Thursday.
Hwang, 64, who holds a doctoral degree in business management from National Chengchi University, assumed the TTLC chairmanship in October 2002.

Ho said that a lot of factors are taken into consideration in choosing the chairman of a state-owned enterprise, adding that Hwang was chosen by the Executive Yuan over other candidates because of his superb management skills and his affable personality.
Ho said that it is hoped that Hwang will make good use of his skills to step up communications with the public on such issues as energy prices, nuclear waste disposal and nuclear safety.
"The personnel arrangement is expected to have a positive effect on Taipower," Ho added.

Ho noted that Taipower is a highly professional company. In the past, except for Lin Neng-pai, who stepped down last month after serving in the post for just 10 months, most of the chairmen came from engineering backgrounds.

Ho said that Hwang faces a daunting task, pointing out that all the issues that he will have to deal with, such as the thorny nuclear disposal and security issues, will require good communication skills on his part.
Taipower President Edward K. M. Chen will be in charge of the professional aspects of running the company, while Hwang will be in charge of the communication aspects, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Russia's WTO Bid Hangs in Balance If Russia fails in its current bid to join the World Trade Organization, the entire accession process could be delayed by several years, a top trade official said Wednesday.
Even as Moscow pushes hard to join the WTO by the end of the year, a number of thorny issues threaten to snarl negotiations. And should Russia stumble now, a growing chorus of experts warns, the quest will only get more difficult, especially if fellow applicant Ukraine succeeds in joining.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-WASHINGTON MUTUAL CONFIDENCE RECOVERING: TAIWAN OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Mutual confidence between Taiwan and the United States has been recovering owing to the assuring policies adopted by Taiwan over the past months, ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Wednesday.
Lee said that the differences and misunderstandings between the leaders of the two countries are also diminishing and that Taipei-Washington relations are now stable.

Lee made the remarks in a press conference for Chinese-language media in Washington, D.C. in response to a question about whether he feels that the United States has leaned toward Taiwan in terms of its cross-Taiwan Strait policy since the start of U.S. President George W. Bush's second term.

The ROC representative said he can sense that communication between the two countries has been getting smoother and smoother over the past 11 months of his term. The two sides have been able to exchange views immediately and candidly on almost all important issues, he said, adding that they are both willing to meet each other halfway to reach consensus on issues over which they have differences.

He pointed out that during a June 8 television interview, President Bush reaffirmed Washington's commitment to defend Taiwan according to the Taiwan Relations Act in the event of China invading Taiwan.
In a recent phone conversation with Chinese President Hu Jintao, Bush also urged Hu to hold dialogue with the duly-elected leader in Taiwan, Lee noted.
According to Lee, Beijing's behavior over the past several months, including its enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, has prompted Washington to adjust its cross-strait policy.

Asked whether this improvement in Taiwan-U.S. ties will be reflected in the arrangements for President Chen Shui-bian's planned transit stop in the United States en route to Central America in September, Lee said the results of the improvement in substantive bilateral relations can be seen in many aspects.

The president's transit stop arrangements are only one aspect, Lee continued, adding that the results may not necessarily be reflected in his stopover arrangements as this is only a superficial aspect and not as important as the substantive improvements in bilateral ties.

On issues concerning the Korean Peninsula, Lee confirmed that Taiwan has actively participated and cooperated in the United States' efforts against nuclear weapons development and organized crime in North Korea. He said that the Taiwan-U.S. cooperation has continued for quite some time and that Washington is very grateful for Taiwan's assistance in the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

New York Times: Chinese Oil Giant in Takeover Bid for U.S. Corporation
The China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) is bidding to buy the American energy giant Unocal. It demonstrates the increasing influence on Asia of Wall Street's bare-knuckled takeover tactics. CNOOC's bid, which comes two months after Unocal agreed to be sold to Chevron, the American energy giant, for US$16.4 billion, is expected to incite a potentially costly bidding war over the California-based Unocal, a large independent oil company. CNOOC said its offer represents a premium of about US$1.5 billion over the value of Unocal's deal with Chevron after a US$500 million breakup fee.
Wall Street Journal: Sudden Death, Doctors Miss Signs Of Heart Defects In Youth Athletes Young Athletes
The cardiac defect which has killed some young athletes killed the boy, known as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, is detectable and treatable. HCM, as it's called for short, is a genetic abnormality that enlarges the left ventricle, leading to sometimes-fatal disturbances of the heart rhythm. Young athletes suffer sudden cardiac death at a rate thought to be two to three times as high as their less-active peers.
