DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN CHOLERA CASE AN ISOLATED INCIDENT: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The cholera case reported recently in southern Tainan has been preliminarily determined to be an isolated incident and involves no danger of triggering an epidemic, Department of Health (DOH) officials said Thursday.

The case, which is the first indigenous case reported in Taiwan in five years, concerns a 72-year-old woman living in Hsinying, Tainan County. She displayed symptoms of diarrhea and vomiting last week soon after eating some food she bought from the market.

According to Chou Chih-hao, deputy director-general of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, none of the 37 family members, neighbors and healthcare workers who have had contact with the patient has come down with similar symptoms.

Chou said local health authorities have collected samples from the market that the patient visited for testing to try to identify the source of contamination and that the test results are expected in five days.

He pointed out that Vibrio cholerae, the bacterium that causes cholera, exists commonly in the environment and is transmissible through the feces of an infected person, contaminated food or drink, flies and cockroaches.
As eating contaminated seafood has been the most common means of infection, people should avoid eating raw seafood, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT STANDS BY TPFA ON TAIWAN FARM EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association (TPFA) has been helping local farmers sell their produce to China for years, and has never infringed on the government's power or violated Taiwan's laws, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Thursday.

Claiming that the government has over the past few years been unable to help Taiwan farmers deal with their overproduction, Chang said that it comes as a boon to them that China is willing to open its door wider to fruits and agricultural imports from Taiwan following a visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan to China from April 26 to May 3.

Based on an existing foundation, the TPFA now is doing its best to help Taiwan farmers sell their produce to China, Chang said, adding that he sees no reason why the government would want to block their efforts instead of giving them a helping hand.

The KMT official's comments came after the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said the previous night that the TPFA has not been authorized by the government to negotiate with China on farm exports and that it will face legal punishment -- up to NT$2 million (US$64,100) in fines or five years in jail -- if it's members engage in talks that involve government authority with China.

A TPFA delegation led by its president, Liu Chuan-chung, is currently holding technical talks in Beijing with representatives of the Association for Economic and Trade Exchange Across the Taiwan Strait about China's promise to provide duty-free treatment to 15 categories of Taiwan fruits and to allow the import of 18 categories of quarantined farm products, which was made to Lien during his visit.
Chang defended the TPFA's efforts in seeking benefits for Taiwan farmers and accused the government of threatening the group in full disregard of local farmers' interests.

The TPFA is only trying to help Taiwan farmers seize a larger share of the Chinese market as it did in the past and there is nothing wrong with that, Chang argued, asking whether the government is actually attempting to limit Taiwan farm exports to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEARCH AND RESCUE VOLUNTEERS TO OBSERVE MAINLAND EXERCISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's world-famous search and rescue volunteers group, known as International Headquarters SAR Taiwan (IHSART) , will be represented when China stages a joint nautical rescue exercise off Shanghai on July 7, the leader of the group said on Thursday.

Lu Cheng-tsung, commander of the group, confirmed in an interview with the Central News Agency that his organization has received an invitation from the Chinese Ministry of Communications to send representatives to observe the exercise.

While saying initially that he wished to maintain a low profile for fear that too much media attention might turn IHSART's presence at the exercise into a political issue, Lu eventually acknowledged that his organization will send a number of representatives to the exercise, including some from Taiwan and a few IHSART members who are employed by Taiwan businessmen in the mainland.
However, he added that nothing has been finalized yet, as he is still considering who should go and under what name.

Lu pointed out that the channels of communication are open between IHSART and relevant mainland organizations, and that IHSART representatives have observed similar mainland operations before. He said that as far as participation in international search and rescue missions is concerned, IHSART has already won worldwide recognition for Taiwan and has not felt any pressure from China to block it from the international arena.

The 70-minute exercise near Shanghai's Yangsan International Port, is said to be the largest of its kind by China, involving 30 vessels, five planes and thousands of people from 24 different units. In addition to Taiwan, the United States, Japan and Russia have also been invited to send observers.

News reports from China said the exercise will be conducted on the pretense that a large cargo ship has collided with a ship carrying dangerous goods in East China Sea, resulting in both ships leaking fuel, with the threat that the dangerous goods could explode. Rescue workers will not only search for sailors who have jumped into the sea but will also try to put out the fires on both ships and clean up the oil spills.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: House GOP Proposes New Social Security Plan.
New approach would add individual accounts, but on a much smaller scale than initially proposed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WEAKER IN GAINING TRADE SURPLUS: CBC

TEXT.P: Taiwan lagged neighboring countries in racking up trade surplus in the first five months of 2005, an indication that there will be no much room for the local currency to further appreciate, according to the newest tallies compiled by the Central Bank of China (CBC).

Statistics made public Wednesday by the CBC show that Taiwan only had a total of US$549 million in trade surplus for the first five months of this year, well behind China, Japan, Singapore and South Korea.

Japan enjoyed a trade surplus of nearly US$34.6 billion in the January to May period, while China followed with about US$30 billion. South Korea and Singapore had US$10.3 billion and US$6.08 billion, respectively.

Taiwan's weaker performance in foreign trade means that the country's supply of U. S. dollars is tight, leaving little room for the new Taiwan dollar to further gain in value against the greenback, CBC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC HOPES TO PASS REVISED LAW TO DEAL WITH BRIBERY MORE HARSHLY

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) on Thursday expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will pass a revised draft Public Officials Election and Recall Law in its next session to deal with bribery offenses more harshly.

The CEC made the call following instructions by President Chen Shui-bian to step up cracking down on bribery in the year-end, three-in-one elections -- meaning city and county chief, city and county councilors, and township and village heads elections.
CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you said that complementary measures for the Dec. 3 elections scheduled are in progress, and graft-fighting is one of the focuses.

Teng noted that the legislature passed the initial review of the revised draft law at the end of May before the close of the first legislative session, and the CEC hopes it can clear the legislature in the next session, which is scheduled to open in September.
Under the revised draft bill, bribery perpetrators will be subject to prison terms between three and 10 years, and will be fined between NT$1 million (US$31,746) and NT$10 million.

For such major elections as the legislative speaker and vice speaker, municipality heads, city and county speaker and vice speaker elections, perpetrators of bribery will be subject to prison terms of between three and 10 years as well as a fine of between NT$2 million and NT$20 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'EVERY POSSIBLE STRATEGY' TO BE USED TO RESOLVE FISHING DISPUTE: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declined Thursday to confirm news reports that Taiwan authorities will delink the sovereignty issue from the fishing rights issue in the forthcoming 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks aimed at sorting out fishing disputes as a result of overlapping economic zones.

Ministry spokesman Michel Lu said that Taiwan negotiators will be allowed to use "every possible strategy" to win the greatest possible benefits for Taiwan and its fishermen in the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, scheduled for July 29 in Tokyo.

It is hoped that both sides will exercise pragmatism and flexibility to solve the disputes caused by the overlapping economic zones since 1996 when the international law of 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zones took effect, Lu noted.
According to Lu, the date and venue were proposed by Japanese authorities, and Japan has also proposed that a preparatory meeting be held in mid-July.

Before July 29, Lu said, the foreign ministry will actively integrate opinions from the government, the academic and the legal sectors, as well as the fishing sector to forge a national consensus on the basic stance of Taiwan for settling fishing rights disputes with Japan.

Ministry officials and relevant representatives will also meet legislators from across the political spectrum in the near future to make the prospective national consensus better representative, Lu added.
Meanwhile, Lu said, Japan's release of the skipper of another Taiwanese fishing boat, the "Tsaiyiyu No. 1," Thursday represented a goodwill gesture toward Taiwan.

For the upcoming round of talks, Lu said, the Fishery Administration will continue to play the leading role, with the foreign ministry acting as a conduit to help set the stage for negotiators from the two sides.

Although there had been a tacit demarcation line, located near the Tiaoyutai Islands -- a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea located some 120 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan proper, to which fishermen from both Taiwan and Japan are supposed to observe -- Taiwanese fishing boats have often been chased away by Japanese patrol boats even from the area only about 30 to 50 nautical miles away from Taiwan.

According to officials from the Fishermen's Association of Suao, northeastern Taiwan, Taiwan fishermen can no longer tolerate the situation with Taiwanese fishing boats now being nabbed even at Taiwan's door.

The only way to escape this kind of Japanese bulling is to flee as soon as the fishermen spot a Japanese patrol boat, from the Taiwanese fishermen's traditional fishing grounds, said the officials from the Suao Fishermen's Association.

The dispute came into the limelight again in early June after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the disputed waters over Japanese coast guard ships' frequently chasing them away from the region.

Under strong pressure from opposition lawmakers, the military sent a Knox-class frigate to patrol the disputed waters June 21 to accentuate the government's determination to protect fishermen's rights and safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER CALLS FOR UNCONDITIONAL CROSS-STRAIT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 22 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue should be conducted using a government-to-government model without any conditions, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said in an interview with a U.S. newspaper.
In the interview published Wednesday in the San Jose Mercury News, Chen rejected Beijing's demand that Taiwan accept eventual unification with China as a condition for cross-strait talks to resume.
Chen said the recent China visit by two of Taiwan's opposition leaders could have been an "icebreaker" in relations between the governments on the two sides of the Strait.
Chen ruled out the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links for now for security reasons, although he said the government continues to welcome investment by Taiwanese businessmen in China.
However, Chen warned that China could use the economic ties to apply political pressure on Taiwan if the island depends too much on the Chinese market.
Meanwhile, Chen expressed confidence in the relations between Taipei and Washington despite the delay of the US$18 billion arms procurement plan from the United States.
Chen said the Cabinet is asking the Legislative Yuan to hold a special session to seek a quick passage of the budget for the procurement in order to show Taiwan's resolve to defend itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TARGETS FOREIGN SPOUSES WHO ABUSE TAIWANESE FAMILY MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the Ministry of the Interior to thoroughly review its immigration policy Thursday after several cases came to light in which foreign brides abused their local family members.

Chiang Yueh-chin, director of the TSU's women's affairs department, accompanied by several TSU officials and representatives of a local association dedicated to the promotion of women's welfare, made the appeal in a news conference.
Chiang expressed her discontentment with remarks by Vice Minister of the Interior Chang Wen-ying who said a recent case in which a foreign spouse abused her mother-in-law was an isolated case.
Chang's claim is an excuse for the ministry's inability to manage the country's immigration policy, Chiang said.

Arguing that this was not a unique situation as there are some 600 cases of physical abuse against family members by foreign spouses around Taiwan, Chiang urged the Ministry of the Interior to hold a census of all Taiwanese families with foreign spouses to better understand the real situation of their marriages as the ministry has allocated NT$3 billion (US$95 million) for the care and consulting services for these foreign spouses.
According to statistics, there are more than 300,000 foreign spouses living in Taiwan.

Tsao Chia-li, who is in charge of the TSU's propaganda arm, noted that her party maintains that legal immigrants should be thoroughly protected, while false marriages and human trafficking should be stopped.
The government's immigration policy should strike a balance among social security, national security and human rights protection, Tsao added.

Liu Ting-mei, executive of a women's welfare association, said both foreign spouses' abuse against their family members or they themselves being abused are not isolated cases. She urged all victims to lodge complaints to the TSU or women's associations for help.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE COUNCIL PUSHES FOR REGULATIONS ON ANIMAL RELEASE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has worked out regulations on the practice of freeing animals for religious purposes that should help conserve Taiwan's ecological system.

After numerous public opinion polls, four public hearings and a final public consensus meeting on the animal release issue, the COA has integrated all the opinions from academic researchers, wildlife conservationists and the religion sector to craft the regulations, paving the way for the country to have a law on the issue.

The COA regulations suggest that correct ways of releasing animals into the wild should be written into textbooks for elementary and junior high schools and that customs authorities step up their crackdown on smuggling of illegal animals from abroad.

The COA regulations also suggest that the Ministry of the Interior coordinate with members of religious circles to work out their own regulations on religious freeing of animals based on the COA version of release.
An estimated more-than 200 million animals are released in religious ceremonies in Taiwan annually, which experts say could be a contributing factor leading to a biological disaster on the island.

Local animal research groups, biological education bodies, wildlife conservationists and scientists have called for the government, particularly the COA, to hammer out measures to stem the practice of releasing animals, which is unregulated.

Chu Tseng-hung, chairman of the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan, said that the buying of captive animals and setting them free by followers of some of Taiwan's religious organizations has become a systematic, commercialized and mass activity of animal cruelty.
Numerous animals -- monkeys, snakes, birds, fish, frogs, turtles and even clams and lobsters -- are dumped in the country's rivers, woods, lakes and even parks and golf courses, Chu said.

Lucia Liu Severinghaus, a researcher with Academia Sinica's Institute of Zoology, said that despite their goodwill, the people who buy and release animals are doing them a grave disservice, as most of the captive-bred animals, unable to survive in the wild, simply die slowly of starvation or predation.

Severinghaus said that the religious freeing of animals also leads to alien invasions of non-native species, which breaks the food chain, leads to hybridism and causes irreversible alteration of the genetic makeup of biological communities.

If the practice continues to be unregulated, she said, invasions of harmful animals, like fire ants and golden apple snails, will continue to occur in Taiwan, undermining the normal development and evolution of the island's ecology and economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GETS GOOD MARKS AT ASIAN PACIFIC MATHEMATICAL OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: Taiwanese junior and senior high school students won one gold, two silvers and four bronzes at the 2005 Asian Pacific Mathematical Olympiad (APMO) held in South Korea, officials of the Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Thursday.

The marks are the best of a group among 175 participants from 19 countries, representing the best performance of Taiwan students at the competition after Taiwanese students participated in the event for the first time in 1991.
Unlike other international mathematical competitions in which the participants have to arrive at the venue of the contests, in the APMO the students can receive the test in their own countries.

After choosing the top 10 semifinalists in March, the local mathematical experts invited by the MOE sent the marks of the students to the international organizer of APMO for the final, with the final results being announced recently.
The gold medallist was Lin Yen-you, a senior high student from the National Experimental High School at the Science-based Industrial Park in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.
In addition to the medals, three other Taiwan students also received honorary prizes.
According to the MOE's regulations, the students with prizes will have privileges in the university or junior high entrance examinations.

The winners of gold, silver and bronze medals will be sent directly to the universities or junior high schools they prefer, with the winners of gold and silver medals being rewarded NT$100,000 (US$3.175) and NT$50,000 each.
Meanwhile, the students with good marks at the APMO will be eligible to participate in the International Mathematical Olympiad to be held in mid-July in Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL GROUP FORMED TO MONITOR CHINA'S RISE: ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The "Congressional China Caucus" formed recently by a group of members of the U.S. House of Representatives is aimed at monitoring issues deriving from the rise of China, which is different from the "Congressional Taiwan Caucus" that is designed to promote friendship with Taiwan, Republic of China representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Wednesday.

Briefing Chinese-language media in Washington, D.C., Lee said he has visited the 15 members of the "China Caucus" and has been told that setting up a sub-group focusing on these issues is necessary because the rise of China has drawn widespread concern in the United States.

Such issues could include China's currency manipulation, U.S. trade deficit with China, intellectual property rights violations in China, dumping of Chinese silk fabrics and China's military buildup, Lee said.
Lee said the caucus members told him that they will monitor if U.S. interests have been damaged as a result of China's rise.
According to Lee, most members of the "China Caucus" are Republican conservatives, with some concurrently being members of the "Taiwan Caucus."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BICYCLES SALES AVERAGE NT$6,709 PER UNIT

TEXT.P: The price of Taiwan bicycles has risen to an average of NT$6,709 (US$213) per unit in the first quarter of this year, statistics released by the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed Thursday.
DGBAS officials also reported bicycle sales of NT$10.1 billion during the first three months of this year.
They noted that Taiwan has developed its bicycle industry for more than 30 years and enjoys a good reputation.

Taiwan produced on average 7.28 million bicycles every year in the 1980s, reaching its zenith at 10.74 million bicycles in 1987. The number started to decline after cheap price competition from China and Vietnam as well as the exodus of manufacturers. The production averaged around eight million units in the 1990s.

Affected by the global recession around 2000 and the 911 terrorist attacks on the United States, Taiwan's largest bicycle importer, the production has continued to drop and only slightly rebounded last year to reach 4.95 million units, although the number still represents a decrease of nearly 40 percent from the 1990s.

With bicycle manufacturers focusing on research and development, and name-brand promotion on high value-added products in recent years to distance themselves from the cheap products in the mainland, the average price per unit has gradually risen, the officials said.
They said that the price of a Taiwan bicycle averaged NT$2,257 in the 1980s, rising to NT$5,815 with a sale of NT$30.2 billion last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPPOSES END TO TOWNSHIP CHIEF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) voiced Thursday its opposition to a proposal to stop holding the elections for township chiefs, calling it a scheme by the ruling party to wipe out democracy among the rank and file.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said that his party is also certainly opposed to the idea that township chiefs be appointed by the central government, because township chiefs are the "representation of Taiwan's grassroots democracy" and also because the KMT enjoys strong support at that level.
Chang called the central government's plan to stop holding the township chief elections an attempt to counter public opinion and suppress democracy at the grassroots level.

Chang's remarks came after President Chen Shui-bian said a day earlier during a gathering with city mayors and county chiefs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that the issue could be put to a referendum late this year for the public to decide.
KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh suggested that the township chief elections be kept in place, but he opined that elections for city mayors and county chiefs should be eliminated.

If the city mayors and county chiefs were removed, the central government would be able to delegate its power and resources directly and effectively to township chiefs who have closer contacts with the local people, Chen Chieh said, insisting that township chiefs must be produced through elections to avoid bureaucracy and to better take care of the people.

As Premier Frank Hsieh has said more than once that the central government is planning to hold elections for city mayors and county magistrates and those for city and county councilors and township chiefs together in December, Chen Chieh urged the DPP not to further complicate the matter by adding another referendum if it really hopes to reduce government spending.
He also called on the DPP not to use the issue as a topic to campaign for itself ahead of the year-end city mayor and county magistrate elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ADJUSTMENT OF FUEL SURCHARGES ON PLANE TICKETS: MOTC

TEXT.P: Although international oil prices have recently hit a new high of US$60 per barrel, the government has said that there will be no adjustment of fuel surcharges by aviation companies on their ticket fees.

Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chang Chia-juch said Wednesday that the ministry will not consider allowing a new hike of fuel surcharges on plane tickets, as the summer peak season is just around the corner.

Neither the government nor the public will accept an additional increase in summer, as airlines usually already raise their ticket prices for peak seasons, Chang said, adding that his ministry will not even assess the possibility before Sept. 14, the expiration date of the current transition period for existing fuel surcharges approved last year by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPELS JAPANESE GANGSTER

TEXT.P: A Japanese gangster was expelled from Taiwan Thursday after he overstayed his visa, according to a report by the Criminal Investigation Bureau.
Police said that Shouichi Fujiwara, 45, is a chapter head of the Yamaguchi Gumi, Japan's largest organized crime group, who took his Taiwanese wife to Taiwan Jan. 22.
But police were tipped off by their Japanese counterparts that Fujiwara was involved in a hit-and-run while under the influence of alcohol in Osaka Jan. 20.
Fujiwara took his wife to Taiwan two days later to try to avoid prosecution. The couple stayed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, and ran a Japanese restaurant.
Although Kaohsiung police did not catch Fujiwara engaging in any shady dealings, his Taiwan visa expired, so the Bureau of Immigration listed him as persona non grata and police expelled him.
Fujiwara was deported from Kaohsiung to Japan via Hong Kong Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER: HEALTHY ECONOMIC SYSTEM CABINET PRIORITY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday that a major task of the Cabinet is to construct a healthy economic system so that Taiwan's vitality can be developed fully.
Speaking at the annual conference of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises in Taipei, Wu described sustained economic development as Taiwan's lifeline.

He said the Cabinet's efforts will be directed at five areas: creating a good investment environment; encouraging the establishment of information-based creative industries; setting up a fair financial and monetary system; making the current economic system more open; and working toward the formation of strategic alliances with other countries.

The vice premier praised Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for their contributions to the nation and said the government values the important role played by these enterprises in the national economy.
He pledged that the government will make more special loans and tariff incentives available to SMEs in addition to helping them with personnel training.

On credit loans for SME businessmen, Wu said that in fiscal year 2004, credit assurance by a special fund had totaled 260,000 cases, with the total amount reaching NT$315.7 billion. This had enabled 126,000 companies to obtain NT$500 billion in loans.
He said an oversight committee of the Cabinet will conduct a study with the view to making it more convenient for SMEs to acquire needed loans.

Speaking on the same occasion, Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh also lauded the contributions by the SMEs, noting that they have hired 77 percent of Taiwan's workforce. She said the credit assurance fund will consider raising the credit limit so that SMEs can get the capital they need more easily.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT NOTIFIES WHO ABOUT ISOLATED CHOLERA CASE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) informed the World Health Organization (WHO) Thursday immediately upon the confirmation of an isolated indigenous cholera case in southern Taiwan earlier that day, according to DOH authorities.

According to Chou Chih-hao, deputy director-general of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC), he notified the WHO Regional Office for the Western Pacific located in Manila about the case -- a toxic-producing vibrio cholerae O1 serotype ogawa, a notifiable disease in the WHO's First Category -- in a 72-year-old woman living in Hsinying, Tainan County.
Since it is an isolated case and the first indigenous case reported in Taiwan in five years, the WHO is not expected to declare Taiwan a cholera affected area immediately, Chou said.

After receiving prompt and adequate treatment, the woman was in stable condition, Chou said, adding that although no further suspected cases were detected by an epidemiological survey, the health authorities would continue to monitor the situation.
None of the woman's 37 family members, neighbors or healthcare workers who have had contact with her have shown symptoms, Chou noted.

Noting that cholera is an acute bacterial enteric disease with an incubation period of up to seven days, Taiwan can be assured that the possibility of a cholera epidemic is zero if no similar cases are reported islandwide by June 30, Chou added.
According to CDC officials, the woman began suffering from diarrhea and vomiting a week earlier after eating food bought from a local market.
Local health authorities collected samples from the market for testing to try to identify the source of contamination, with the test results expected June 26.

CDC officials said that cholera is transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food or water, or through the use of utensils contaminated directly or indirectly with feces, vomitus or by the fingers of infected persons. It can also be transmitted via flies and cockroaches. Contaminated water is the most serious source of infection.
Vibrio cholerae lives in sea water and humans are the only reservoir. Infection often is brought about by eating raw seafood from polluted waters, they said.
They added that vibrio cholerae is susceptible to gastric acid and that infection can only be induced by the intake of a large amount of bacteria.

Although the case is not suspected of being a result of the June 12 flooding in southern Taiwan, the CDC urged the public in flooded areas and elsewhere to eat only well-cooked food and to drink only boiled or bottled water.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOARING OIL PRICES TO AFFECT TAIWAN'S EXPORT ORDERS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports will be affected in the short term by soaring international oil prices and China's moves to cool down its overheated economy, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Thursday.
Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, made the remarks after the ministry announced Taiwan's export performance for May.
According to MOEA statistics, the value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in May reached US$19.52 billion, an increase of 13.14 percent over the same month of last year.
Cumulatively, the value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in the first five months totalled US$95.84 billion, a growth of 17.61 percent over the same period of last year.

The value of export orders for information and telecommunication products reached US$3.55 billion, contributing the most to the growth -- up by US$720 million -- over the same month of last year, while electrical and machinery products registered a US$320 million growth on a year-to-year basis.

Noting that increasing oil prices have slowed down global economic perspectives and that China's economic measures have restrained the supply and demand for steel and petrochemical products in Asia, Chang analyzed that Taiwan's exports will be affected in the short term.
However, the more-than-expected GDP growth in China, Japan and the United States is expected to inject a stabilizing factor to the global economy, Chang added.

According to a recent survey, 23.86 percent of manufacturers polled believe that export orders will increase in June, with 51.49 percent believing that export prospects will remain the same and 24.65 percent predicting that exports orders will decline during the month.

MOEA statistics also show that the industrial production index stood at 129.76 in May, a drop of 1.42 percent over the same month of last year, while the manufacturing production index registered 132.46, a decrease of 1.4 percent on a year-to-year basis.

Cumulatively, the industrial production index in the first five months stood at 123.43, a decrease of 0.35 percent over the same period of last year, while manufacturing production index registered 126.32, a decline of 0.85 percent over the same period of 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER WARNS AGAINST CHINA'S MILITARY BUILDUP

TEXT.P: China's military buildup is increasingly threatening global security, particularly after its recent success in the test firing of newly developed submarine-launched 8,000-mile-range JL-2 missile, according to Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien.

In an interview with the U.S.-based Knight Ridder newspaper group Wednesday, Tsai said that with the success of the JL-2 missile test firing, China has shown hegemonically its ability to deter the United States from meddling should a serious military crisis occur in the Taiwan Strait.
China has been pressing Taiwan ceaselessly through a series of political, economic and military activities, the vice minister noted.

Taiwan is much smaller in comparison with China in terms of military expenditure, territorial extension and population, he went on, adding that Taiwan should develop reliable self-defense forces to ensure national security.
It is necessary for Taiwan to acquire more advanced arms, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION TO IMPROVE IN SECOND HALF OF YEAR: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing production will improve in the second half of this year due to several measures adopted by the government to boost the economy, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Thursday.
Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, made the remarks after the ministry released statistics related to the performance of the manufacturing sector for May.

According to the statistics, Taiwan's manufacturing production index stood at 132.46 in May, a decrease of 1.4 percent on a year-to-year basis, while the manufacturing production index in the first five months registered 126.32, a decline of 0.85 percent over the same period of 2004.

However, Chang predicted that manufacturing production is expected to grow by 5 percent in the second half of this year, as the electronic component sector will bottom out from a stagnant period, while the government's economic measures are expected to boost investment and consumption.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER OF EDUCATION ON VISIT TO U.S., COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng left for New York Thursday on a cultural visit to the United States and Costa Rica, Ministry of Education (MOE) officials said Thursday.
During his U.S. visit from June 23-30, Tu will inspect the MOE's operations in seven cities and hold seminars in New York and Washington to hear the opinions of Taiwan students studying there.
He will proceed July 30 to Costa Rica, where he will exchange opinions with Costa Rican officials on bilateral cultural exchanges.
He will also invite his Costa Rican counterpart, Manuel Bolanos, to visit Taiwan in September.
A specialist in history, Tu will visit various museums in the U.S. and Costa Rica for reference in the promotion of educational and cultural activities in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS WORLD'S SIXTH-BEST SCIENCE EDUCATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan has the sixth-best science education in the world. which is the result of concerted efforts by the private, education and government sectors.

Quoting the 2004 World Competitiveness Yearbook compiled by the Switzerland-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD) , Chen said that science education in Taiwan's schools ranked the sixth in the world in terms of quality and quantity, second only to Singapore among all Asian countries and even better than Japan's.
This indicates that Taiwan's well-established science and technology education is an important asset to the country's strength and a fact not to be taken lightly by the world, according to Chen.
Chen made the remarks during an audience at the Presidential Office with Taiwan winners of the 2005 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair that was recently held in Phoenix, Arizona.
Chen gave the students a thumbs-up for their extraordinary performances in winning awards at the prestigious Intel Fair.

Taiwan students won a total of six Organizational Awards and seven Special Awards at the annual fair, in which more than 1,400 students from over 40 countries competed for US$3 million in scholarships and prizes.

Award-winning works of the Taiwan contestants included Enhanced Cooling of Microelectronic Devices by Using the Thermoacoustic Effect by Hsing Pen-yuan, 18, from Taipei Municipal Lishan Senior High School, and Phylogenetic Analysis of Crickets by Acoustic Behavior and Mitochondrial DNA Sequencing by Wu Jhe-rong, 18, from Taipei Municipal Chien Kuo Senior High School.
Chen told the students that the development of human resources is one of the key factors deciding a country's economic growth, sci-tech progress and international competitiveness.

He also quoted the IMD 2004 World Competitiveness Yearbook as reporting that the interest shown by Taiwanese youth in science and technology ranked seventh among 60 major economic entities around the world, a fact, he said, that is rewarding to all parties concerned.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FREE TRADE ZONE SHOULD BE MODELED ON CEPA

TEXT.P: The establishment of a cross-Taiwan Strait free trade zone should be modeled on the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) , Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research Chairman Vincent Siew was quoted by a Hong Kong daily newspaper as saying Thursday.
Siew said that the CEPA among China, Hong Kong and Macau should be set as a goal for Taiwan and China when the two sides establish a cross-strait free trade zone, according to the Tai Kung Po.

However, both sides would need to make more commitments on customs incentives and reach consensus on currency and taxation issues to allow a CEPA-style cross-strait free trade zone to be established, Siew said.

Noting that a cross-strait free trade zone is not a task that can be achieved overnight, Siew, who is also chairman of the Cross Straits Common Market Foundation, said it should be accomplished step-by-step, with the first phase of the task normalization and institutionalization of trade, postal and transportation relations across the Taiwan Strait, better known as the "three direct links."

Siew said that the "hot points" of the cross-strait economic and trade cooperation should be "direct transportation links" and Taiwanese businesses' moving toward inner provinces around China, according to the Tai Kung Po report.

Siew, who once served as premier when the now-opposition Kuomintang was in power, also said that China's state-run enterprises should cooperate with Taiwanese-financed companies more closely in the future to create "win win" business synergies for both sides, the Hong Kong daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PROPOSES SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION FOR LATE JULY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus will present a new proposal to the Legislative Yuan for convening an extraordinary session in late July, a DPP official said Thursday.

Ker Chien-ming, chief executive of the DPP's policy committee, said after a meeting with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng that the DPP caucus made the decision after considering that the main opposition Kuomintang is holding its chairman election, while the ruling and opposition camps are at odds on various issues.

Ker said that the DPP legislative caucus, which presented June 20 an endorsement signed by 89 lawmakers seeking an extraordinary legislative session to deal with various urgent bills, will present a new proposal for holding the special legislative session in late July.

Relations between the ruling and opposition camps may be improved after the KMT chairman election slated for July 16, Ker predicted, adding that the environment might then become more friendly for holding a special legislative session.

The draft bills that the DPP hopes will be discussed in the special legislative session include a special budget of NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) for flood-control projects, a NT$480 billion arms procurement package from the United States, the confirmation of Control Yuan nominations and proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN APPEARS IN COURT FOR ZANADAU CASE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan appeared in court Friday in person as a witness in the Zanadau Development Corp. corruption trial.

Lien was in court for 50 minutes to answer judges' questions about the financial scandal involving former China Development Holding Corp. Chairman Liu Tai-ying -- the main defendant -- and the private Kaohsiung-based Zanadau Development Corp.
Speaking after the trial session outside the court, Lien said that he feels good about serving as a witness and doing his duty as a citizen.

Lien's appearance at the Taipei District Court Friday was the former ROC vice president's first. In the past, he chose to have his lawyers represent him in court for the various lawsuits that he had filed or that had been filed against him.

Lien responded to accusations made by Liu -- a confidant of former President Lee Teng-hui and the chief of the Kuomintang's (KMT) Business Management Committee between 1993 and 2000 -- that he donated kickback money to Lien's 2000 presidential election campaign.

Formerly the virtual treasurer of the KMT, Liu was indicted in 2003 in at least 12 criminal cases, including corruption, breach of trust and forgery charges, as well as violations of the Securities Transaction Law, the Corporation Law, the Money Laundering Control Law and the Business Accounting Law.
Su Hui-chen, a majority shareholder in Zanadau, accused Liu of accepting a NT$1.06 billion (US$34.2 million) kickback from her in return for a promise to help her secure bank financing in 1995.
The prosecutors also discovered that Liu used KMT assets to make personal investments, including a huge amount of U.S. dollars in his son's banking accounts.

The Taipei District Court decided to lift the overseas travel ban on Liu last June as investigations into Liu's role in most of the 12 cases had already been completed, he had reported to court for every hearing, and he had put up bail of NT$60 million (US$1.79 million) . Furthermore, none of the crimes Liu was alleged to have committed in the 12 cases carries the death penalty, life imprisonment or a minimum penalty of five-year imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTABLISHING TIES WITH CHINA MUST BE DEALT WITH CAREFULLY: VATICAN
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, June 23 (CNA) (By P.C. Fan and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Vatican's foreign minister said Thursday that establishing diplomatic ties between the Vatican and China must be dealt with cautiously, although he himself does not think that any difficulty is "insurmountable."

Archbishop Giovanni Lajolo, who just returned from a trip to four Southeast Asian countries, including Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia and Brunei, made the comments while touching on issues related to the Holy See's relations with China in an interview with Vatican Radio Station.

Saying that establishing diplomatic relations with China has long been studied and examined, the archbishop, however, noted that one should move carefully and asses some premises that cannot be violated by either side.

The Vatican recognizes China despite the fact that it does not maintain official diplomatic relations with Beijing, the minister said, adding that while talking about the recognition of a country, one should first distinguish the fact of recognizing a country and a government and the establishment of diplomatic relations with a nation.

For instance, Lajolo further said, although the Vatican has not established diplomatic relations with Malaysia or Brunei, he was still well received by the foreign ministers of the two countries during his recent trip.
Nevertheless, an observer of Vatican politics predicted the same day that the Vatican faces great difficulties in terms of establishing diplomatic relations with China.

According to the observer, the so-called "premises" mentioned by the archbishop should include the Vatican's insistence on the appointment of a bishop in China and the question of whether the people on the mainland have complete freedom of religion. "They are well aware of the obstacles in the establishment of diplomatic relations between them," he added.

Beijing has insisted for a long time that the Pope's right of appointing bishops in China is an interference in China's internal affairs and that freedom of religion should be subordinate to the political authorities, he also said, adding: "This differs from the Vatican's views, not to mention Beijing's request that the Holy See must first break its official relations with Taiwan as a precondition of establishing ties with China."

Pointing out that the Vatican helps others and has never made enemies, the observer said that it seems that Beijing wants to demand that the Holy See do something against its own will to establish relations with China while breaking ties with Taiwan at the same time.
"How can the Vatican and China establish diplomatic relations within a short period of time after having procrastinated on the issue for some 50 years?" he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES FARMERS' ASSOCIATION TO RESPECT GOVERNMENT AUTHORITY

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official urged the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association (TPFA) Friday to respect the government's authority in dealing with farm exports to China.

The official made the call in the wake of a media report that TPFA Chairman Liu Chuan-chung has reached a consensus with Chinese authorities on matters concerning the certification and quarantine of Taiwan fruit exports. The report said Beijing might recognize the certificates of origin issued by the TPFA to facilitate the import of Taiwan fruits into China.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung pointed out that the issuance of certificates of origin is part of the government's authority and that the TPFA has not been authorized by the government to negotiate with China on issues related to farm exports.
You said the MAC has requested the Council of Agriculture to contact the TPFA to report to the government in one week on the details of its talks with Chinese authorities.

He reminded the TPFA that it could violate the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area for establishing an agreement related to government affairs with China without the government's authorization.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX WORKERS KILLED IN EXPRESS OVERPASS CONSTRUCTION ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Six workers were killed and another injured when part of a balanced cantilever of an overpass under construction along the express road leading to the Yuankang Fishing Port in Hsiping, Miaoli County collapsed Thursday evening, sources from the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported Friday.

CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu proceeded to a local morgue in Tachia, Taichung County, central Taiwan, first thing Friday morning to offer the government's condolences toward the families of the deceased. One of the six workers killed was a Thai national.
The exact causes of the accident was still under investigations.

Chen offered NT$100,000 (US$3,226) to each of the families of the victims. She also promised that the CLA will see to it that the contractor, BES Engineering Corp., and relevant sub-contractors will face the music and pay compensation for the workers who were killed or injured.

After examining the accident scene, prosecutors and labor affairs officials tentatively labeled it as an accident as a result of human error and negligence, adding that the matter should be dealt with according to the law.

The BES authorities promised Friday that the company will help the families take care of all matters regarding the funerals for the victims and will not evade their responsibilities in the wake of the accident.

Meanwhile, CLA officials said that the ill-fated construction site has been checked by local labor affairs officials 31 times since construction began. During the monitoring process, they said, the contractor was ordered to suspend its construction 11 times, with fines totaling NT$1.38 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FINANCIAL DELEGATION ATTENDS SEMINAR IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation made up of government financial officials and representatives from private financial institutions attended a financial seminar held at New York University in New York City Thursday.

Kong Jaw-shong, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) under the Executive Yuan who is heading the delegation, delivered a speech at a luncheon held after the conclusion of the seminar.

The theme of the seminar, which was jointly organized by the Eurasia group, the ROC-USA Business Council and the US-Taiwan Business Council, was "Taiwan Financial Services: Trends, Outlook, and Opportunities."

During the gathering, the participants discussed various topics relating to the current situation, trends and prospects regarding Taiwan's capital market as well as the island's financial reform and its financial service development.

The members of the delegation include Jeffrey Koo, honorable chairman of the ROC-USA Business Council; Wang Chung-Yu, chairman of the council; Lin Chung-cheng, commissioner of the FSC; Chen Mu-tsai, chairman of China Development Financial Holding Corporation; as well as representatives from Fubon Financial and The Cathay Financial Holdings and officials from the Ministry of Finance.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO OIL PRICE HIKE IN JUNE: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh gave her assurance Friday that there will be no oil price hikes in June, even though international oil prices have skyrocketed to over US$60 a barrel.

Ho noted, however, that it cannot be predicted whether there will be a need for price hikes in July by Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), Taiwan's major oil refiner and distributor, given the unpredictable situation on the international oil market.

Meanwhile, CPC President Chen Pao-lang said that CPC will "give thought" to adjusting domestic gasoline prices should oil prices on the international market remain at US$60 per barrel or higher for seven to 10 consecutive days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 33.17 points to close at 6,340.69.
The bourse opened at 6,350.74 and fluctuated between 6,363.88 and 6,324.22 during trading. A total of 3.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$69.54 billion (US$2.21 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.1 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues and construction issues both at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 605 to 238, with 155 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD HAUL OF KETAMINE SEIZED

TEXT.P: Police officers Friday found 100 kg of ketamine worth NT$250 million (US$7.97 million) hidden among more than 2,000 kg of instant coffee imported from Malaysia.
The police officers arrested two Taiwanese men as they were about to claim the shipment from customs at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport.
The main suspect, surnamed Peng, managed to escape.
The two men confessed that Peng established a fake company to import instant coffee from a Malaysian accomplice with ketamine hidden among the goods.
An Investigation Bureau officer noted that it was a record haul of ketamine and the first time the drugs were found hidden among instant coffee.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES MEDIA REPORT ABOUT DRUG ABUSE IN MILITARY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied Friday a media report about widespread drug abuse in the military, claiming that the report is a far cry from the truth.

In a press release issued by the MND, the ministry protested against the report and said that new conscripts that test positive for substance abuse are immediately subject to prosecution as a way to wipe out drugs in the military.

Only seven out of the more than 5,100 new conscripts summoned to the Cheng Kung military base in Taichung county in the first six months of this year tested positive, the ministry said, noting that all of them were sent to law enforcement authorities.
The ministry claimed that the report is untrue and said it has hurt the military's image and has led to misunderstanding.
The MND statement came after local media reported earlier the same day that around two-thirds of some 100 new draftees at the training center in central Taiwan tested positive for drug use.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WORLD'S NO. 1 COUNTERFEIT SOURCE AND MARKET: MAC REPORT

TEXT.P: China is the world's largest source and market for counterfeit goods and the poor-quality products that it makes will seriously hurt its economy and pose a major latent threat to public security, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung claimed Friday.

Citing the finding of a report commissioned by the MAC, You said that due to the Chinese authorities' lax controls, about 70 percent of the world's bootleg products come from China, ranging from brand-name clothing to medicine. Nearly 90 percent of consumers have purchased such fake products, he claimed.

Quoting statistics compiled by China's General Administration of Quality Supervision and Quarantine, You said that counterfeit goods worth a total of 11.1 billion renminbi were seized by Chinese law enforcement authorities from April 2001 to October 2004, posing great losses to consumers and original producers.
According to the report, China's increased counterfeiting has seriously hit many worldwide famous brands and it has become an international issue.

Estimates show that U. S. enterprises suffer as much as US$250 billion in business losses each year due to mainly China-made counterfeit products, according to the report, which added that various upscale brand names have halted plans to enter the Chinese market as a result.

The report ascribed the rampant counterfeiting in China to various factors that include a lack of public respect for intellectual property rights, lax government regulations and punishments and strong local demand. China's vast size has also helped worsen the problem, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA-BOUND PASSENGERS SUBJECTED TO NEW CUSTOMS TARIFFS

TEXT.P: From July 1, all nonresident passengers bound for China will be required to pay tax on any merchandise they carry for personal consumption that exceeds 2,000 renminbi (about NT$8,000) in value, according to the Customs General Administration of China.

The new regulations announced by China's Customs authorities Thursday will also subject in-bound resident passengers to the new tariffs on any goods they carry that exceed 5,000 renminbi in total value.

It was not clear whether Taiwan businessmen and students residing in China will be treated as either residents or nonresidents and officials at the Customs General Administration declined to answer inquiries in this regard.

News reports from China say that the value of goods will be determined by invoices. If a passenger fails to produce such invoices, Customs officials will set the value by consulting a uniform schedule of prices for general merchandise.

All passengers will be required to itemize the goods they carry by filling out a form. Any individuals carrying goods valued at over 50,000 renminbi or company workers with goods exceeding 150,000 renminbi that fail to file claims will be charged with smuggling.

Experts believe the new customs tariffs will affect the shopping habits of certain consumers and they have warned that those who go to Hong Kong or Macau on shopping sprees might find that after paying the tax, the goods they have bought may not necessary be cheaper than those purchased domestically.
