DOC.HEADLINE: TOWNSHIP ELECTIONS TO GO AHEAD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The next elections for township and village heads will be held at year end as scheduled, despite calls by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for them to be abolished, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.
Hsieh pointed out that the Law on Local Government Systems will have to be amended before the elections can be abolished and that the amendment might not be accomplished before the elections are due.
Also, a proposal to hold a referendum on the issue will need to be reviewed by the Legislative Yuan, a process that can take up to six months, Hsieh noted.

The government has decided to hold the next elections for township and village heads Dec. 3 together with two other local elections, namely, those for city and county chiefs as well as city and county councilors.

President Chen Shui-bian has recently suggested that a referendum be held alongside the elections to let the people vote on whether the township and village elections should be abolished and for chiefs at that level to be appointed positions.
According to Hsieh, the Cabinet has already submitted its proposed amendment to the Law on Local Government Systems to the legislature, but the bill failed to win the support of opposition lawmakers.

The Cabinet will submit a similar bill to the legislature during its next session starting in September, Hsieh said, adding that a referendum will be needed if there are problems resolving the partisan differences over the government's plan to abolish the elections.

Also Friday, a group of opposition Kuomintang legislators expressed their objection to Chen's proposal to hold a referendum alongside the elections, calling it a tactic to boost the campaign of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the year-end elections.

Lin Hung-chih said that when holding three elections simultaneously is already a heavy burden for electoral workers, their workload will increase further if a referendum is to be held at the same time.

Lin claimed that abolishing the township and village elections will damage the country's democracy and local self-government system, because the ruling party could offer the appointments of township and village heads as favors to local politicians.
Meanwhile, Wu Yu-sheng urged the DPP not to use referendums as a tool to make political gains disregarding the overall development of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TRIES TO STEER CLEAR OF CAMPAIGN FUNDS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan apparently tried to steer clear of the KMT campaign funds for the 2000 presidential election in court Friday, where he appeared as a witness in the Zanadau Development Corp. corruption trial.

Lien was in court for 50 minutes to answer judges' questions about the financial scandal involving former China Development Holding Corp. Chairman Liu Tai-ying -- the main defendant -- and the private Kaohsiung-based Zanadau Development Corp.

Lien responded to accusations made by Liu -- a confidant of former President Lee Teng-hui and the chief of the KMT's Business Management Committee between 1993 and 2000 -- that he donated kickback money to Lien's 2000 presidential election campaign.
Noting that all campaign funds were handled by a KMT finance committee, Lien claimed to have "no idea" about how the funds were raised or spent and that he had never been shown related account books.

Taipei prosecutors claimed that Liu, formerly the virtual treasurer of the KMT, instructed KMT-run businesses to buy stocks in Typhone Industries, a pineapple cannery that diversified its operations to other fields including building and venture capital businesses, between 1999 and 2000.

In a reciprocal gesture, according to the prosecutors, Typhone owner Huang Tsung-hung handed 17 checks worth a total of NT$160 million (US$5.16 million) to Liu. Of the total, the prosecutors said, Liu stole NT$44 million, which later appeared in the bank accounts of his two sons.
Liu's lawyers denied prosecutors' charges that Liu embezzled the NT$44 million, saying that the amount was channeled into the KMT coffers to be used as the 2000 presidential election campaign funds.

During the court session, Lien also denied that he knew anything about the sources of NT$7 billion in campaign funds that former President Lee Teng-hui, who was KMT chairman in March 2000, once claimed that the KMT had raised for the 2000 presidential election.
The court did not order Lien to confront Liu during Friday's session.

Lien's appearance at the Taipei District Court was the former vice president's first. In the past, he chose to have his lawyers represent him in court for the various lawsuits that he had filed or that had been filed against him.
Prosecutors handling the Zanadau scandal case also subpoenaed Lee to appear in court Nov. 12, 2003.

Liu was indicted in 2003 in at least 12 criminal cases, including corruption, breach of trust and forgery charges, as well as violations of the Securities Transaction Law, the Corporation Law, the Money Laundering Control Law and the Business Accounting Law.
Su Hui-chen, a majority shareholder in Zanadau, accused Liu of accepting a NT$1.06 billion (US$34.2 million) kickback from her in return for a promise to help her secure bank financing in 1995.

The Taipei District Court decided to lift an overseas travel ban on Liu last June as investigations into his role in most of the 12 cases had already been completed. He had reported to court for every hearing and had put up bail of NT$60 million (US$1.79 million) . Furthermore, none of the crimes Liu was alleged to have committed in the 12 cases carries the death penalty, life imprisonment or a minimum penalty of five years' imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN URGED TO DISCARD BUSINESS SUITS DURING SUMMER

TEXT.P: A group of women's rights and environmentally conscious activists called Friday for the country's men to discard business suits in Taiwan's scorching summer and instead wear casual shirts to reduce reliance on air conditioning.

The activists, led by Legislator-at-Large Huang Shu-ying of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, urged the men to get rid of business suits during summer to help save energy, particularly at a time when energy sources have become increasingly expensive.

Noting that air conditioning is the prime reason for surging power consumption in summer, Huang said that one degree higher on air conditioner thermostats around Taiwan in summer means the country could save 300 million kwhs -- an amount of electricity sufficient for residents of Penghu Island to use for an entire year.

Wearing business suits requires a temperature of between 22-23 degrees Celsius to make an office or room comfortable in summer, Huang said, claiming that the room temperature can be higher, which will save some energy, if men were to wear cooler casual shirts.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSING TAIWANESE SEAMEN FOUND

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese seamen on a fishing boat that was reported missing early this week while trying to smuggle a group of Chinese people into Taiwan have been found, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials said Friday.

The CGA has been informed by Chinese authorities that Captain Liu Teng-hsiung and crewman Wang Kuei-lin of the Hsinlienfa No. 23 had been rescued by Chinese fishermen at sea and were being detained in Xiamen for questioning, the officials said.
The whereabouts of the 31 illegal Chinese immigrants they were carrying remains unknown, they said.

The CGA has requested that the Chinese police repatriate the two men and provide Taiwan with related information to facilitate the investigation into a cross-Taiwan Strait human smuggling ring, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREPARATORY MEETING FOR TAIWAN-JAPAN FISHERY TALKS SET FOR JULY 12

TEXT.P: A preparatory meeting for the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks will be held July 12 in Tokyo, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.
Both sides had earlier agreed to hold the fishery talks July 29, also in Tokyo.

According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu, the government will fight for the best interests of the country and seek to resolve the fishery dispute between Taiwan and Japan in a pragmatic and flexible manner.
Before the talks start, ministry officials will visit lawmakers and meet with scholars, legal experts and fishermen's representatives to gather their opinions on the issue, Lu said.

At the heart of the dispute is the disputed sovereignty claim over the Tiaoyutai Islands -- a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea located some 120 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan proper. The island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.
The previous 14 rounds of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks did not make significant headway because Taiwan would not forsake its sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutais, which Japan has held since 1972.

Both Tokyo and Taipei claim that the island group falls within their exclusive economic zones. Japan often fines ship owners and impounds Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter waters close to the Tiaoyutais.

The dispute came into the limelight again recently after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the disputed waters following the latest expulsion of fishermen from the area. Under strong pressure from opposition lawmakers, the military sent a Knox-class frigate to patrol the disputed waters for one afternoon early this week, supposedly to accentuate the government's determination to protect fishermen's rights and safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA CONTINUES MILITARY DEPLOYMENT AGAINST TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: China has continued to step up its military buildup against Taiwan, despite having invited two Taiwan opposition leaders to visit China earlier this year, a senior official said Friday.

Quoting a Chinese government internal circular, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said the Beijing authorities have also directed their overseas diplomatic missions to intensify international publicity to accentuate that the Chinese people are wise enough to resolve their "internal" cross-Taiwan Strait dispute on their own.

According to You, the circular was distributed to Communist Party of China cadres as well as Chinese government officials, overseas staff and military officers in the second half of May after two Taiwan opposition leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- visited China on separate occasions between late April and early May.

"The content of the circular indicates that China, while inviting Taiwan's opposition leaders to open up a new platform for its Taiwan-targeting work and sowing discord in Taiwan society, has continued its military deployment against Taiwan and suppression against Taiwan's international presence," You said.
The circular claims that as the situation in Taiwan remains "grim, " the military must continue to escalate its Taiwan-targeting combat preparedness, You said.

The document also points out that inviting Lien and Soong was a major policy strategy aimed at winning the hearts and minds of the people of Taiwan and at forging ties with various political parties and groups in Taiwan.

It further says the enactment of its anti-secession law will contribute to China's drive to impede the pro-independence force in Taiwan. Nevertheless, it adds that as pro-independence activists have not ceased secessionist activities and anti-Chinese foreign forces have continued to obstruct a solution to the Taiwan issue, the People's Liberation Army must not ease its combat preparedness against Taiwan.

In the meantime, You said, the circular directs Chinese diplomats to strengthen a publicity campaign telling the international community that the Chinese people have the wisdom to resolve their own "internal" disputes.

"Chinese foreign missions are also ordered to take active steps to prevent the United States from developing official ties and military cooperation with Taiwan, foil any U.S. attempts to cooperate with Japan over the Taiwan issue, and strengthen the European Union's and Russia's pro-China stance on the Taiwan issue," You said.

Moreover, You said, the circular demands that Chinese diplomats make every possible effort to impede Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and its affiliates, while appropriately dealing with Taiwan-related affairs in professional international bodies and non-government organizations.

In terms of the content of the circular, You said, China has not shown any flexibility toward the Taiwan Strait issue in the wake of the two opposition leaders' China visits and will continue its all-out efforts to thwart Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations and activities.
For years, You said, China has consistently kept in place a comprehensive package of strategic and tactical measures toward Taiwan.
"The recently obtained Chinese internal circular proves that China will not forsake its two-pronged, carrot-and-stick ploy against Taiwan after the visits by Lien and Soong," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS CLIMATE INDEX OF MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY DROPS IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 24 (CAN) The business climate index of the manufacturing industry stood at 92.34 points in May, with only 9.7 percent of Taiwan manufacturers surveyed believing that the economic prospects were optimistic in that month, according to the results of a survey conducted by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).
The May business climate index, the lowest since July 2001, represented a drop of 4.26 percentage points from the April level, the survey shows.
The survey also found that the ratio of local manufacturers optimistic about the economic prospects in May dropped to 9.7 percent from 21.7 percent in April.

The ratio of manufacturers who believed that the economic prospects remained the same in May increased to 45.9 percent from 41.2 percent in April, while the ratio of firms that believed that the economic situation was bad surged to 44.4 percent from 37 percent in April.
Meanwhile, 21.3 percent of the manufacturers predicted that the economic prospects in the next six months will be better, slightly down from the 22.1 percent registered in April.

The ratio of companies forecasting that the economic situation will go downward stood at 20 percent, down from 29.4 percent registered in April, with 58.8 percent of those surveyed predicting that their operations will remain the same.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS CLIMATE INDEX OF SERVICE INDUSTRY RISES IN MAY

TEXT.P: The business climate index of Taiwan's service industry registered 115.57 points in May, an increase of 1.07 percentage points from the April level, according to a report conducted by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).

The growth in the business climate index of the service industry in May was in contrast to the business climate index of the manufacturing industry in the same month, which stood at 92.34 points, the lowest since July 2001, and represented a drop of 4.26 percentage points from the April level.
It was the first time that TIER announced the business climate index for the service industry, the TIER officials said.

The TIER report surveyed eight main categories of service industry, including retail, restaurants and travel, construction, banking, stocks and securities, insurance, telecommunications and transport.

While only 9.7 percent of Taiwan manufacturers surveyed by TIER believed that the economic prospects were optimistic in May, the business climate index of the service industry demonstrated that domestic consumption can enjoy moderate growth despite soaring prices of merchandise and a moderate unemployment rate.

The report found that almost all companies of the eight categories in the service industry believed that their sales will increase in the next three months, with only the banking sector believing that overdue loans will aggravate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG TRAFFICKERS USING GUANGZHOU AS TRANSIT POINT
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, June 24 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Narcotics traffickers are increasingly using Guangzhou, the capital of China's coastal province of Guangdong, as a transit point for smuggling illicit drugs to Macau, Hong Kong, other parts of China and neighboring countries, customs officials of Guangdong said Thursday.

The officials made the statement following the seizure of more than eight kilograms of ketamine powder from the luggage of two Malaysian passengers at Baiyun Airport in Guangzhou -- the largest quantity of ketamine ever seized at Chinese ports of entry.
Since September last year, customs officials at Baiyun Airport have cracked 10 illicit drug smuggling cases. Eight of these had to do with ketamine; one was for heroin and one for marijuana.

According to Guangdong Customs officials, most of the ketamine powder was found in the luggage of Malaysian passengers who flew from Kuala Lumpur to Guangzhou, but more recently the route has been to go to Singapore by car and then fly from there to Guangzhou so as not to attract the attention of Chinese Customs officials.

A senior customs official said that of those arrested in Guangzhou for narcotics trafficking during the past six months, nine were Malaysians of Chinese origin, three were Singaporeans, one was a resident of Hong Kong, and two were citizens of China. Eighty percent of them were gamblers who had run up large debts.

Ketamine, a non-barbiturate, fast-acting disassociative anesthetic used on both animals and humans, is being abused by an increasing number of young people as a "club drug." The drug can elicit an out-of-body or near-death experience, but can also make the user comatose.

Chinese statistics show that 806 kilograms of ketamine was seized in 2004 at different ports of entry. Such smuggling cases are on the rise because the drug can generate relatively big profits for the traffickers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE GROUP CALLS FOR WIDER OPENING TO CHINESE TOURISTS, INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Opening Taiwan further to Chinese tourists and investors would generate good revenues for Taiwan businesses, the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China said recently.

The business group raised the proposal two days ago in a board meeting, suggesting that the government allow visits by Chinese tourists to Taiwan as soon as possible and permit Chinese investment in the domestic real estate market.
This would help Taiwan's economy, since the flow has been predominately one way -- outward from Taiwan to China, the group said.
Citing estimates by aviation sources, the group said that opening Taiwan to Chinese tourists would help carriers increase their business volumes by about 21 percent.

Given that the government plans to permit 300,000 Chinese people to sightsee in Taiwan each year in the initial stage, this would create at least NT$12 billion (US$385 million) in annual business for the domestic tourist industry based on a per-capita spending of NT$38,000, the group said.

Statistics made public by world tourist organizations show that nearly 22 million tourists visited Hong Kong last year, making Hong Kong one of the top 10 most popular tourist destinations across the world.

The tallies also show that the 2004 figure marks a noticeable growth of more than 40 percent over the 2003 level -- the world's highest increase rate which analysts said was a result of an influx of Chinese tourists.

A total of some 1.1 million foreign tourists traveled to Taiwan in the first four months of this year, a rise of 18.5 percent compared to the previous year's level, the group said, but pointed out that Taiwan must open up to Chinese visitors if the government wants to succeed in its plan of doubling tourist arrivals by 2008.
In addition, the group also asked the government to allow Chinese people to invest in Taiwan's real estate markets in view of the fast-increasing trade and economic links between the two sides.
It said that the government should allow Chinese investors to buy property in Taiwan as there is a growing need for them to do so to set up offices or shops here.
To date, Taiwan investment in China has already surpassed US$100 billion, but the Taiwan market remains intact for Chinese investors, it said.

Despite a government announcement that Taiwan will soon brace for Chinese tourists, no concrete measures have been put in place so far to serve that end amid high expectations from the private sector.

Stanley Yen, chairman of the Taiwan Visitors Association, called Wednesday on the government in a seminar to move as quickly as possible and urged it to hold substantive talks with China to avoid possible negative consequences, such as absconding en masse of some Chinese tourists.
Yen said that it is the government responsibility to talk over the issue with China and ask the Chinese side to take measures to fend off any such re-occurrences.

The famous hotelier also called for a standard practice in receiving Chinese tourists. He maintained that there must be no differences in treating visitors from China, because doing so will help Chinese people better understand Taiwan and improve the country's international image.
Experts in the seminar also suggested the government allow Sung Shan Airport in Taipei to operate direct flights from Shanghai's Hongqiao International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES IMPROVEMENT IN TIES UNDER NEW HONG KONG CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan congratulated new Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang on his swearing in Friday, saying it hopes that bilateral ties under Tsang's tenure will improve.

Tsai Chih-chung, an official in charge of Hong Kong and Macau affairs at the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, told the Central News Agency that Hong Kong is the vital intermediary between Taiwan and the mainland, and constructive Taiwan-Hong Kong ties will not only serve the interests of Taiwan and Hong Kong, but also improve Taiwan's relations with China.

He urged the new Hong Kong chief to break through the old framework of bilateral ties and develop a broad-based relationship with Taiwan; a significant step would be to set up a Hong Kong representative office in Taiwan.

Hong Kong authorities should also understand the role played by the Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong, which is Taiwan's de facto representative office to the former British colony, and treat it accordingly, the official said.
"The interests of both sides will be served if we treat each other amicably," Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Interrogators Cite Doctors' Aid at Guantanamo.
U.S. military doctors at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, have aided interrogators in conducting and refining coercive interrogations of detainees, including providing advice on how to increase stress levels and exploit fears, according to new, detailed accounts given by former interrogators. The accounts shed light on how interrogations were conducted and raise new questions about the boundaries of medical ethics in the nation' s fight against terrorism.
Wall Street Journal: Bid for Power, Oil Battle Sets Showdown Over China.
The US$18.5 billion bid by a Chinese oil company, Cnooc Ltd., to buy the American energy company Unocal Corp. suddenly has raised to the boiling point a long-simmering question: Should the U. S. government move more aggressively to tr y to curb China's rising power? The bold bid plunges Cnooc, which is 70%-owned by the Chinese government, into a takeover battle with Chevron Corp. And it intensifies a wave of urgent debates for the U.S. about a growing economic and geopolitical rival -- as well as a crucial market and source of labor for American business.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAYTHEON WINS CONTRACT TO SUPPLY TAIWAN WITH PHASED ARRAY RADAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 24 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Raytheon Integrated Defense Systems has won a contract to supply Taiwan with an ultra high frequency phased array radar system to upgrade Taiwan's missile and air defense capabilities, the U.S. Department of Defense said Thursday.

The early warning system includes an ultra high frequency phased array radar integrated with Taiwan-furnished identification friend-or-foe beacons, two missile warning centers, communications and interface architecture and protocol to specified Taiwan mission elements via the Taiwan military communications infrastructure.
The Pentagon said the contract carries a price tag of US$752 million and that the new missile and air defense system is scheduled for completion by September 2009.
Military experts said the ultra high frequency phased array radar system will enable Taiwan to detect signals of ballistic missiles and cruise missiles fired by China in a very early stage.
The system to be supplied by Raytheon is one of the two early warning systems that Taiwan proposed to purchase more than a year ago.

The Pentagon notified the Congress of its decision to sell Taiwan two ultra high frequency phased array radar systems and other related facilities in March 2004 in line with U.S. arms export regulations. Before that, Taiwan had passed the budget for the procurement project which will be worth US$1.776 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA PEOPLE VALUE TIES WITH ROC: GUATEMALA CONGRESS LEADER

TEXT.P: The people of Guatemala treasure their country's relations with the Republic of China, and the diplomatic ties between the two countries will not change, Guatemala Congress President Jorge Mendez Herbruger said Friday.
Mendez made the remarks in a news conference prior to his departure after concluding a six-day visit in Taiwan.
He said that the current visit to China by Guatemalan Economics Minister Marcio Cuevas will not affect the diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Guatemala.

During Cuevas's Beijing visit, the Chinese Foreign Ministry has demonstrated its willingness to forge diplomatic ties with Guatemala and other Central American countries, where most of Taiwan's diplomatic allies are.
The Guatemalan government has stated that Cuevas' Beijing visit is aimed at strengthening economic and trade ties with China.

Asked about whether the strengthening of economic and business relations between Guatemala and China will lead to the establishment of diplomatic ties, Mendez said entering the Chinese market is a global trend and Guatemala does not want to be absent from that market.
But Guatemala will not shift its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing as its people value very much its relations with the ROC, he added.

Besides, the economic and trade cooperation between Guatemala and China is still under initial assessment, Mendez said. Citing the example of Taiwan and China, Mendez said, "We have not seen much political changes and contacts between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait even after Taiwanese businessmen have invested so much in China."
Mendez also revealed that Guatemala President Ocar Berger will visit Taiwan in August to attend the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union initiated by Vice President Annette Lu.

At that time, Berger is expected to sign a Taiwan-Guatemala free trade agreement with ROC President Chen Shui-bian to promote the sales of Guatemalan products in Taiwan and to reduce Guatemala's trade deficit with the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO JOINTLY CRACK DOWN ON CROSS-STRAIT CRIMES

TEXT.P: An official from the quasi-official intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Friday urged Chinese authorities to sign an agreement with Taiwan as soon as possible to jointly crack down on cross-Taiwan Strait crimes.
SEF Secretary-General Liu Teh-hsun made the appeal in view of the growing number of cross-strait fraud cases based out of mainland China.
It was reported that the public security agency in Xiamen City uncovered recently a fraud group, detaining 151 suspects, with 28 of them Taiwanese. The targets of the group were all Taiwan people.

Liu said the SEF has sent a letter to its Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- in Beijing, asking it to coordinate with related Chinese agencies so that the latter can offer more information and send back those Taiwanese suspects for further investigation.

Noting that it is difficult for Taiwan law enforcement agencies to uncover cross-strait criminal rings, and the current cooperation between the two sides is limited, Liu urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to sign an agreement as soon as possible in which a regular criminal reporting mechanism can be established for the early settlement of cross-strait criminal cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SEES LITTLE POSSIBILITY OF MEETING WITH CHINESE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday he sees little possibility of meeting with his Chinese counterpart in the foreseeable future because China has set too many conditions.
Hsieh made the remarks in an interview with the Central Broadcasting System of the Republic of China.
Asked whether he is likely to meet with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao, Hsieh said that in terms of past experience and China's present status quo, the possibility of such a meeting is almost nil.
"China has erected too many roadblocks. I would not accept any preconditions that would undermine our national dignity simply for the sake of holding a so-called Hsieh-Wen meeting," Hsieh said.

Noting that Beijing has insisted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resume talks under the premise of "one China, " Hsieh said Taiwan would forfeit its international status if it were to accept such a precondition.

"Beijing has consistently demanded its diplomatic allies recognize that Taiwan is part of China and that the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government of China. If we accept Beijing's 'one China' principle, it is tantamount to forsaking our international personalty simply for resuming cross-strait talks, " Hsieh said, adding that Beijing's "one China" principle is the biggest obstacle to resuming cross-strait dialogue because Taiwan cannot talk with China at the expense of its sovereignty.
So long as China is willing to remove such a precondition or prerequisite, Hsieh said, the two sides can resume talks right now.

Hsieh said the opening of direct cross-strait charter passenger flights earlier this year for the return of Taiwan businessmen from China for the Chinese Lunar New Year celebrations set a good example for the two sides to sit down to talk pragmatically without setting any preconditions.

"We hope the two sides can follow that good example in opening talks on cross-strait charter cargo flights in the near future. The two sides can mutually respect each other's stance, but neither should set a precondition for talks," Hsieh said.

The premier further said the so-called "China fever" fueled by the controversial visits to China by two Taiwan opposition leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong has cooled off as evidenced in the results of the May 14 National Assembly election.

"While Taiwan people generally like to increase civilian exchanges and cultural interactions with China, they are very sensitive to political issues. China has little appeal to most Taiwan people when touching on political systems. The majority of Taiwan people want freedom, democracy and a market economy rather than a totalitarian communist system," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENCY IS CELESTIAL: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday he has not given any thought to the 2008 presidential election because the presidency is not a post that can be won just with wit, schemes or trickery.

"To me, the presidency is celestial. Who wins the post is destined by fate, not just by personal pursuit or efforts, " Hsieh said in an interview with the Central Broadcasting System of the Republic of China.
Asked whether he is likely to run for president, Hsieh said his current preoccupation is how to fulfill his duties and obligations as premier.

"I'm a person who lives in the moment and cares only about the present because it is my belief that one's future is based on one's efforts at present and in the past. If I cannot devote my full energy to my present work, I don't think I can lead anyone anywhere. I must live up to our people's expectations and should not disappoint them," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD SPOTLIGHT ON CHINA DIMS TAIWAN'S GLOBAL PROFILE: SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 24 (CNA) (By Chao Yen and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: China's improved international image is likely to make it more difficult for Taiwan to participate in international organizations, two mainland affairs experts said Friday.

A global poll conducted by the U.S-based Pew Research Center for the People and the Press showed that China is viewed more favorably than the United States in many of the 16 countries surveyed, especially in Europe and Asia, although there is still considerable wariness about its growing economic and military strength.

Dr. Kenneth K. Wang, director of the Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies at Tamkang University, told the Central News Agency in an interview that compared with U.S. President George W. Bush's "iron-fist" policy, China's soft approach of seeking economic cooperation with other countries is definitely more appealing.

Wang expressed the fear that China's improved image in the world may enable Beijing to persuade more countries to accept its "one China" policy, thus blocking Taiwan from participating in world organizations.

In his view, Taiwan should make more efforts to let other countries see more clearly the benefits they may have in expanding economic cooperation with Taiwan. He suggested that Taiwan should also let the world know its democratic achievements and make them see Taiwan as a peace-loving country, rather than a destabilizing factor.

Lin Wen-cheng, professor at the Institute of Mainland China Studies of National Sun Yat-sen University, pointed out that the Iraq War that led to Saddam Hussein's removal was the main reason for America's poor image, as shown by results of the poll.

Lin warned that China's "peaceful rise" should not be taken lightly, as it has already produced far-reaching effects in many countries. As a consequence, Taiwan's interests may be sacrificed, with Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization being a prominent example.
In his opinion, Taiwan should step up its publicity campaign internationally and make timely responses to any issue taken by China so as to allow the world to understand Taiwan's position.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 JET FIGHTER VEERS OFF RUNWAY IN CHIAYI, NO ONE HURT

TEXT.P: An F-16 jet fighter veered off the runway while landing at the Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan Friday. No one was hurt in the mishap although the airport which is shared by civilian airplanes was forced to close, according to a statement issued by the Air Force Friday.
The statement said the twin-seat F-16 was returning from a regular training mission at 10: 12 a.m. when it veered off the runway after taxiing about 4,000 feet on the tarmac.

The Air Force commander on the base ordered the jet fighter towed away from the runway and the airport closed during the towing operation, a normal procedure, although the pilot and the plane were fine.

The Air Force said the cause of the incident was under investigation, adding that it apologized for any inconvenience caused to civilian flights by the accident and promised to do its utmost to prevent further accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 25 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, June 25:
09: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend an academic seminar on the sovereignty, the ROC Constitution and the future of Taiwan at the Law School of National Taiwan University.
09:00, The NGOs Association for International Affairs will share its experiences of participation in the United Nations Human Rights Commission meetings at Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
09: 40, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will give a keynote speech at an academic seminar on the globalization and the economic development at Shih Chien University in Taipei.
10: 30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a Mass in memory of the victims during the martial law era in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
11:00, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will attend the opening ceremony of the 2005 Career Jobs Expo for Youth at the Taipei World Trade Center.
17: 30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a national demonstration for religious rituals in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan.
18:00, The opening ceremony of the 2005 Taipei Film Festival will be held at the Chungshan Hall in downtown Taipei.
18:30, Vice President Annette Lu will address the dinner party of Taiwan's Bar Association at Tayih Landis Hotel in Tainan City, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SAUDI ARABIA ECONOMIC COOPERATION MEETING HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The first Taiwan-Saudi Arabia joint economic cooperation meeting was held Friday in Taipei with the participation of some 60 government officials and business leaders from the two countries.

The meeting was jointly chaired by Kuo Chin-tsai, head of the Saudi Arabia Committee of the Taipei-based Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association (CIECA) , and Hussein A. Al-Athel, secretary-general of the Riyadh Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
During the meeting, the two sides discussed bilateral cooperation opportunities and other matters of mutual concern, while introducing the economic situations of the two nations.

The Riyadh Chamber of Commerce and Industry also signed memorandums of understanding with the CIECA and the Small and Medium Business Association on bilateral cooperation to further promote Taiwan-Saudi Arabia economic and trade relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DRUG CAMPAIGN CRITICAL TO NATIONAL SECURITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday drug abuse is not just a personal moral issue but has become an issue crucial to public order, social stability, public health and national security.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with individuals and social groups that have made outstanding contributions to the anti-drug campaign over the past year.

With drug abuse becoming ever more serious, new ecstasy pills continuing to appear and the number of repeat drug abusers and traffickers continuing to rise, Chen said many criminal cases now are related to drugs. Worse still, he said, drug abuse has also become a major cause behind a fast rise in the number of local HIV carriers.
Chen encouraged his guests to continue their efforts in assisting the government in eradicating drug trafficking and abuse and in curbing a further spread of AIDS.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BE REDIVIDED INTO EIGHT SPECIAL MUNICIPALITIES: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have eight special municipalities, or provinces or counties, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Friday.
The minister said that his ministry is drafting a bill for redistricting the administrative areas based on population and the people's livelihood.
Under the bill, the country will be divided into eight areas, called either special municipalities, counties or provinces, each with a population of between 2.5 million and three million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURN FLOOD-PRONE TOWNSHIPS INTO HONEYMOON VILLAGES: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested turning low-lying coastal area in central and southern Taiwan, which are plagued by flooding, into villages for honeymooners.
Huddling with chiefs of these flood-prone townships, the vice president said honeymoon villages could attract tourists with their rich natural resources of wetlands and culture.

Noting that the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corporation owns a wetland farm in Tungshi township of Chiayi, Lu said the honeymoon villages could start from this farm, called Aogu, in light of the fact that the company is prepared to try this idea out.
Lu floated the idea in an attempt to help residents in these townships to turn disasters into opportunities.
Warning that the world is entering a disastrous era, Lu urged residents living in low-lying areas to brace for natural disasters prompted by people's unchecked exploitation of nature.
These townships were subject to frequent flooding owing to the subsidence of land caused by excessive groundwater pumping in the last decades for fish farming.
Hardly a year goes by without these areas being inundated in waist-deep water brought by either typhoons or torrential rain.

Lu was obviously inspired by Lee Hung-yuan, a professor at National Taiwan University who recommended at Friday's meeting to change the way the land in the area is used which is no longer suitable for farming because of the increasing ground salinity.
He suggested converting these flood-prone areas into tourist attractions as a series of wetland parks.
No decision was taken in Friday's meeting as the vice president said she needs time to round out her idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 25, or the 19th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th U.S. state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Co. turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was the supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia during World War II, the last viceroy of India, then the commander in chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration, and other elements.
1942: Maj. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of U.S. forces in Europe and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the U.N. Charter. The ROC, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain are made members of the U.N. Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second-place finish.
1975: Mozambique gains independence, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as U.S. secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news-gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua-lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
2000: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh is elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
2001: The Council for Economic Planning and Development announces that the government will encourage the formation of 50 private venture capital funds, totaling NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), to boost the development of the local bio-tech industry.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: News challenge for PSA: Wave of shipping alliances.
The consolidation of shipping lines will pose a new challenge for PAS Corp which it must meet head-on, said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.
In May, Danish shipping giant AP Moeller-Maersk made a bid to buy Anglo-Dutch rival P&O Nedlloyd. Other shipping lines will respond by forming similar alliances or mergers, sparking a wave of consolidation similar to that of airlines and banks, predicted Mr Lee.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PSA can keep the competition by low cost: MM Lee
The wave of huge shipping alliance or mergers brings the pressure of competition to PSA Corp. So PSA needs to keep low cost, including low salaries for employees, to against the pressure from the huge shipping group.
Speaking at the port workers union's dinner on Friday, Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew explained PSA Corp could not afford to stand still, and that it would face keener competition ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Greenspan slams tariffs against China
Trade sanctions against China won't protect U.S. jobs, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said Thursday, and he joined with Treasury Sceretary John Snow in saying sanctions might backfire.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: No permit, no rally - PNP
Director General Arturo C. Lomibao, chief of the Philippine National Police (PNP), yesterday warned rallyists from both pro- and anti-government camps that the PNP will strictly enforce the "no permit, no rally" policy in anticipation of more mass actions in the coming days in Metro Manila.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Demos fail to move Arroyo
MORE than 5,000 protesters comprising a broad political spectrum yesterday demanded the resignation of President Macapagal-Arroyo but the Chief Executive flatly rejected their call saying she has a mandate to rule.
The Philippine Star: GMA allies to stop tape probe
President Arroyo's allies in the House of Representatives want the five committees looking into the controversial "Gloriagate" recordings to stop their investigation. They are invoking the Constitution -- and even the name of the late Manila Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin -- to abort the inquiry that was conducted for three days this week.
The Manila Times: Cory gives Gloria a lift
former President Corazon Aquino on Friday urged the people to give President Arroyo the"maximum benefit of the doubt"in the face of the political turmoil besieging her administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-MADE RADAR SYSTEM WILL BOOST DEFENSE CAPABILITY: MND

TEXT.P: An early warning surveillance radar system to be sold to Taiwan by the United States will boost the country's defense capability significantly, the Ministry of National Defense said Saturday.

In a statement issued a day after the U.S. Defense Department announced in Washington that it had awarded defense contractor Raytheon Co. a US$752 million contract to build the radar system for Taiwan, the ministry said Taiwan's ability to defend itself against missiles is insufficient.

Although Taiwan has already acquired the U.S.-made Patriot Advanced Capability-II anti-missile system and is anticipating purchasing the more advanced PAC-III system, their effects are limited without the early warning radar system.

The ministry said the radar system will allow Taiwan's air force to detect and track long- and short-range ballistic missiles, cruise missiles, enemy aircraft and surface ships, giving it more time to respond with its anti-missile missiles.
The delivery date for the system is set for September 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REIMPOSES BAN ON U.S. BEEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced Saturday a reimposition of a ban on imports of U.S. beef after the U.S. Agriculture Department confirmed a second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) in a U.S. animal, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Saturday.

Cho Jung-tai quoted the premier as saying that the safety of domestic consumers was the only factor in his decision. However, the premier said U.S. beef already on the local market will not be taken off store shelves.

Citing expert opinions, Hsieh claimed that U.S. beef already brought into Taiwan came from animals aged less than 30 months, raised after a ruminant-to-ruminant feed ban in the United States and believed to be free from BSE.
Cho cited the premier as urging the public to trust his administration's decision and not to panic.
U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns said in Washington Friday that a sample taken from the suspect animal in November 2004 had conclusively tested positive for BSE.
The premier said the Executive Yuan will review the ban if other evidence proves the test result to be incorrect.

DOC.HEADLINE: `GOODWILL TAIWAN AMBASSADORS' TO VISIT U.S. CONGRESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 24 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Thirty Taiwanese young people participating in a series of training courses organized by the Formosa Foundation will begin visiting U.S. congressmen next week, foundation officials said Saturday.

Over the last week, the group, 10 of which are university students and the remaining 20 of whom live in the United States, have taken courses on communication techniques, crisis management, the Asia-Pacific situation, Taiwan history and culture, as well as U.S.-Taiwan relations, in preparation for their roles as "goodwill ambassadors."
Starting from next week, they will visit U.S. congressmen, government officials in charge of foreign policy and experts from various think tanks.

The participants in two previous training courses have visited more than 200 senators and members of the U.S. House of Representatives to exchange opinions with them and present issues in which Taiwanese-Americans are concerned.

The Los Angeles-based Formosa Foundation, a non-profit organization established in 2001, is aimed at promoting the understanding of and support for Taiwan by American society, encouraging and offering opportunities for Taiwanese young people to participate in U.S. politics, as well as promoting friendship among people in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONFIDENT NEW CONSTITUTION WILL BE READY BY 2008

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed confidence Saturday that he will give Taiwan a new constitution that is timely, relevant and viable by the time he steps down in 2008.
With the establishment of a new discourse on national sovereignty and the fading of old ideology, Taiwan is now ready to promote across-the-board reforms to the Constitution, Chen said.

Chen said he believes the second phase of constitutional reforms will be no more difficult than the first and that he is willing to act as the midwife who will assist with the birth of the new constitution.
The president made the remarks while addressing a symposium on sovereignty, constitution and the future of Taiwan held by the Taiwan Law Society.

Chen said that what he called "an illusionary and stiff greater China ideology" has seriously confused the national status and identity of Taiwan over the past five decades and has led to procrastination and hampering of the development of democracy and constitutional government in Taiwan.
"It will be impossible for Taiwan to become a normal country enjoying independent sovereignty, freedom and democracy unless it frees itself from this unrealistic political dogma," Chen said.
According to Chen, sovereignty not only means the right to be one own's master but also means the will to be one own's master.

With the democratization of the country, the wish of the Taiwanese people to be their own master has been realized and a clear and specific national sovereignty consciousness has taken shape, Chen claimed.

"The Republic of China is an independent, sovereign state. Its sovereignty belongs to all the people in Taiwan. Only the 23 million people in Taiwan have the right to determine the future of Taiwan, " he said.
"Such discourse is not only consistent with the democratic principles of sovereignty of the people and self-determination, but it also honestly reflects the status quo in reality, " he claimed.

By replacing the old sovereignty concept dominated by a "greater China consciousness" with this practical discourse, it will be helpful to the unity and ethnic harmony of Taiwan and will facilitate subsequent constitutional reforms, he said.

He noted that Taiwan has conducted seven rounds of constitutional reforms in the past decade because the "greater China consciousness" has prevented the country from making comprehensive changes to the Constitution.

Chen has pledged to promote a second phase of constitutional reforms following amendments passed early this month under which the National Assembly was abolished to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional reforms.
He has promised that the second phase of reforms will not involve sensitive issues such as changes to the country's sovereignty, territorial boundaries or official designation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SEF HEAD VOWS TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT WELFARE

TEXT.P: The newly appointed chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has vowed to promote the welfare of the people on either side of the Taiwan Strait, a local reporter said Saturday.

Chang Chun-hsiung, former premier and former secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was recently appointed by President Chen Shui-bian to lead the SEF, the quasi-official body set up to deal with cross-strait relations in the absence of official ties between the two sides of the strait, after former SEF President Koo Chen-fu died in January this year.

Chang, who has also served as Presidential Office secretary-general and as a legislator for seven consecutive terms, has long been a close partner and political heavyweight trusted by the president, according to the reporter.
Chen hopes Chang can help him open a window of opportunity for the strained cross-strait relations.

Taiwan and China experienced a period of harmonious interaction and exchanges since historic talks between Koo and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) in 1993, the reporter said.
Unfortunately, the cross-strait consultation channels broke down in 1999 and the death of Koo interrupted the experience accumulated by the SEF and ARATS.
The new SEF head has been described, even by some opposition party members, as an honest, modest and respectable politician capable of resolving disputes.

Within the DPP, Chang is a pragmatic advocate of strengthening cross-strait exchanges. He worked on pushing the passage of the DPP's 1999 resolution on Taiwan's future, saying that Taiwan and China should improve their mutual understanding and economic and trade cooperation through wide-ranging dialogue in order to establish a peaceful framework and durable stability between the two sides.

To put into practice the resolution, Chang as premier not only loosened the restrictions set by former President Lee Teng-hui on cross-strait economic and trade exchanges, but also adopted a policy to help promote economic and trade exchanges between the two sides of the strait. Throughout his tenure as premier, Chang also urged both sides to engage in dialogue without preconditions.

He was also the first DPP member to suggest that the president ameliorate and normalize cross-strait relations after last year's legislative elections. His pushing for better ties between the two sides was an important factor the president's selection of him to fill the vacancy left by Koo.

Chen has reiterated several times since he became president that he would honor his "five noes" commitment. He has also said that he did not change the principles for dealing with China during his first term and that such principles and commitments will remain unchanged in his second term.

In addition, Chen took the further step earlier this year of pushing for an agreement on direct cross-strait charter flights, expressing the hope that by doing so, Taiwan and China can jointly create a new era of consultation.
According to Chang, there will be relative cross-strait stability from now until 2008 as in Taiwan, Chen is seen as someone who will not betray the nation's interests in any talks with China.

Besides, by reaching an agreement with opposition PFP Chairman James Soong in a meeting in February, Chen also promised that he will not declare independence, will not change the designation of the nation and will not push for a unification vs. independence referendum that will change the status quo, Chang said.

This is the most important common factor reached by the ruling DPP and the opposition after they encountered pressure from the public, he went on, adding that this also shows certain similarities to the spirit of the four points set by Chinese President Hu Jintao in dealing with cross-strait relations.

Claiming that China's Anti-Secession Law sees anti-independence as more important than reunification, Chang said that this, along with the DPP's main idea of maintaining the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and seeking cross-strait peace, have actually created room for reconciliation and coexistence between the two sides.

Therefore, the coming three years will be a golden opportunity for building a peaceful framework between Taiwan and China, according to Chang. " If we miss these precious three years, nobody can predict the future development in the strait," he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FILM FESTIVAL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The seventh Taipei Film Festival kicked off Saturday at the Chungshan Hall in downtown Taipei, with the premiere of "Three Times, " a film directed by world-acclaimed Taiwan director Hou Hsiao-hsien.

The venue was very "Russian" Saturday, with a series of live dance and music performances at the Chungshan Hall square as part of the festival's "City-Vision" section, which focuses this year on two Russian cities with rich cultural traditions and complex histories -- Moscow and Saint Petersburg.

The festival has another new section -- the New Talent Competition -- aimed at encouraging young and talented filmmakers. A total of 14 films from around the world have been nominated and the winner will be awarded NT$650,000 (US$20,700) at a presentation slated for July 1, according to the organizer.
The competition jury is made up of Wang Toon, Clara Law, Fruit Chan, Lin Cheng-shen and Jia Zhanke, directors from Taiwan, Hong Kong and China.

A total of 138 international and local films will be screened in the two-week festival. The festival's general director, Edmond Wong, said that as of Friday, around NT$4.5 million had been taken in advanced ticket sales, surpassing the total box office record of the 2004 film fair.
The festival will close July 9 after an award presentation ceremony for the annual "Taipei Film Award" and "Taipei Theme Award."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Justices Back Forced Sale of Property.
The Supreme Court gave cities broad power to buildoze homes and small stores to make way for business development, a ruling the dissenters said put shopkeepers and homeowners at the mercy of revenue-hungry governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Hard-Line Tehran Mayor Wins Iranian Presidency; Victory Could Complicate Relations With West.
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the hard-line mayor of Tehran who has invoked Iran's 1979 revolution and expressed doubts about rapprochement with the United States, won a runoff election Friday and was elected president of the Islamic republic in a landslide, the Interior Ministry announced early Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES OPPOSITION TO SUPPORT 2ND-PHASE CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: A senior ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker called on opposition parties Saturday to support President Chen Shui-bian's bid to promote a second phase of constitutional reforms.

According to Chen Chin-jun, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, making Taiwan a "normal country" is one of the president's top concerns and the country needs a timely, relevant and viable constitution in order to achieve that goal.
Chen said the passage of a constitutional amendment package through the National Assembly early this month was a show of the power of the people.

Therefore, the president hopes to continue this momentum to promote a second phase of reforms to address issues such as whether to change the country's political system to a presidential system or parliamentary system; whether the Taiwan provincial government should be abolished; lowering the voting age from 20 to 18; and adopting a voluntary military service system, Chen said.
Earlier in the day, President Chen expressed confidence that he will give Taiwan a new constitution that is timely, relevant and viable by the time he steps down in 2008.

The president said Taiwan is now ready to promote across-the-board reforms to the Constitution following the establishment of a new discourse on national sovereignty and that he believes the second phase of constitutional reforms will be no more difficult than the first.
Ho Min-hao, convener of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus, said his party supports the promotion of a second phase of constitutional reforms.
However, Ho said he is pessimistic about the prospects of success of the reforms in light of the high threshold required for the passage of constitutional amendments.

According to the amendment package passed early this month, popular referendums will be held on future constitutional amendments. It requires the approval of at least three-quarters of the eligible voters, or more than 8 million people, before the amendments can be considered passed.
Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers expressed objections to the president's plan to make further changes to the Constitution.

KMT Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, who also heads the party's Policy Committee, claimed that the country "needs some rest" after the last constitutional reforms and he urged the president to use the rest of his term to implement political reforms and improve the economy.
Agreeing with Tseng, PFP legislative caucus convener Chen Chih-pin said the DPP should prioritize domestic and economic issues instead of focusing on constitutional reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKET VALUE OF LISTED COMPANIES UP NT$143.96 BILLION

TEXT.P: In anticipation of prosperous times for the electronics industry in Taiwan, foreign institutional investors have continued to increase their purchases of Taiwan stocks, which has boosted the market value of Taiwan listed companies by NT$143.96 billion (US$4.59 billion) this week.
Taiwan Stock Exchange statistics show that the combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan reached NT$410.73 billion this week.

The statistics also show that gainers outnumbered losers in the 20 top major industries, with the market value of listed companies in the automobile, tourism and wholesale and retail industries showing an increase of over 2 percent.
The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, ended at 6,340.69 Friday, a surge of 47.13 points from last week.
There have been 116 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a daily average turnover of NT$68.94 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTENDS CHURCH SERVICE FOR VICTIMS OF IMPROPER VERDICTS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh attended a church service in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan Saturday for victims of improper verdicts handed down between 1949 and 1987 when the island was ruled by martial law.

Speaking at the service, the premier extended his sympathy for victims of improper verdicts and their families, and urged them to rise beyond their personal suffering and look forward to harmony between different ethnic groups.

The church service, which brought together hundreds of attendants, was the latest of a series of activities organized by the Compensation Foundation for Improper Verdicts to heal the rift caused by the rule of martial law.
The private foundation was set up with funds donated by the government to compensate victims of improper verdicts.
Since its formation in 1999, the foundation has received 7,378 applications for compensation, 83 percent of which have been approved.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS TO PROMOTE TAIWAN FRUIT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) headed Saturday for Wuhan, in central China's Hubei Province, to promote Taiwan fruit.

KMT Legislator Her Jyh-huei, president of the Association for Economic and Trade Relations across the Straits, said the delegation of his association, headed by KMT Legislator Kuo Su-chun, will take part in the Taiwan Week in Wuhan and inspect the potential market for Taiwan fruit.
Her said his association would like to serve as an intermediary between the Taiwan authorities and China in exploring the Chinese market for Taiwan fruit.

The KMT lawmaker said the Executive Yuan has asked the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) to negotiate on its behalf with the Beijing authorities on exports of Taiwan fruit to China, while Beijing said it prefers to deal with the Taiwan Provincial Farmer's Association.

Her said the Executive Yuan will not empower the Taiwan Provincial Farmer's Association because it is a local civic group, while Beijing is reluctant to talk with TAITRA because of its strong association with the DPP administration. Her said his association can help both sides to break through the impasse by serving as a go-between.

Boasting about his group's good connections with the Beijing authorities and rich experience in associating with China, Her said Beijing has always accepted certificates of origin issued by his group for Taiwan goods.
For the benefit of Taiwan farmers, Her urged the government not to try to stop his group's efforts from serving local farmers to promote their produce in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC CONSUMPTION TO PLAY IMPORTANT ROLE IN ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: An official from the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) predicted Saturday that domestic consumption will play a pivotal role in the country's economic growth.
The official made the remarks in consideration of the gradual but stable growth in Taiwan's exports.
According to statistics from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the value of Taiwan's exports reached US$16.32 billion in May, an increase of 4.0 percent over the same month of last year.
Cumulatively, the value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in the first five months totalled US$74.81 billion, a growth of 7.6 percent over the same period of last year.
Analyzing Taiwan's export performance in the second half of this year, the TIER official predicted that exports will maintain a certain level of growth.
However, due to soaring prices of oil and other raw materials, the growth in value of imports will surpass that of exports, gradually reducing the island's trade surplus, the official added.

Although orders received by Taiwanese manufacturers have usually set new records, the manufacturing production index has not risen in accordance with the growth pace of export orders, due largely to the fact that a growing number of these export goods are made in Taiwan companies' overseas plants.

According to the MOEA statistics, the manufacturing production index stood at 132.46 in May, a decrease of 1.4 percent on a year-to-year basis, while the manufacturing production index in the first five months registered 126.32, a decline of 0.85 percent over the same period of 2004.

Forecasting that exports will see a growth at a slower pace in the next six months due to stable economic growth in the United States and China, the official predicted that domestic consumption will play a greater contribution to the country's economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER VISITS NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 24 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng called at the headquarters of the United States College Board Friday on the first day of a visit to New York.

During his stay, board officials expressed their gratitude over a Ministry of Education (MOE) offer of US$300,000 to support the board's new plan concerning its Advanced Placement Program, according to MOE officials stationed in New York.
The college board is scheduled to introduce Chinese-language courses in U.S. high schools next autumn.

Tu arrived in New York Thursday. He was scheduled to attend a conference Saturday along with nearly 30 Taiwanese scholars living in the United States. Later in the day, he will head for New Jersey to take part in the annual meeting of the New York chapter of the North American Taiwanese Medical Association (NATMA).
Tu has been invited to deliver a speech at the NATMA meeting, while the group will award the minister in recognition of his educational and cultural contributions, the officials said.

On Monday, he will preside over a meeting of MOE officials stationed in the United States to review their work. The minister will visit Washington, D.C. before taking a flight to Costa Rica, an ally of the Republic of China in Central America, Thursday for an official visit. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan July 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO RECONSIDER U.S. BEEF BAN UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: The government will reconsider its ban on U.S. beef under certain conditions, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Saturday.

These conditions include the release of pathological information concerning the second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) found in the United States, the implementation of a feed ban and beef slaughtering standards, as well as the establishment of a BSE surveillance system, according to Chen Lu-hung, head of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation.

Chen noted that the information made known so far shows that the latest case involves an eight-year-old non-ambulatory "downer" cow, but there has not been any other pathological data such as where exactly the animal was raised and the whereabouts of its siblings.

While the United States already imposed in 1997 a feed ban that prohibits feeding to cattle and other ruminants most mammalian protein, including meat-and-bone meal, it has also adopted beef slaughtering standards that require the removal of risky BSE-transmissible tissue such as brains, spinal cords and bones from the cattle, Chen pointed out.
Meanwhile, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) is also reviewing its BSE surveillance program, Chen said.
Earlier in the day, Premier Frank Hsieh announced a reimposition of a ban on U.S. beef imports after the USDA confirmed the second BSE case.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE SECURITY CHECKS TO BE CONDUCTED ON INFORMATION PRODUCTS: BSMI

TEXT.P: In an effort to protect the public from electromagnetic hazards, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will perform stricter checks on information products from July 1.
Besides the existing security checks, products will have to pass an additional electric security check before entering the market, BSMI officials said Saturday.

The upgraded security checks are adopted in accordance with international security standards, while each item that passes the checks will be clearly labeled so that consumers can identify them, the BSMI said.
Detailed information on the label can be acquired by calling 0800-231-623.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY ON U.S. BEEF IMPORTS `WRONG': CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Several members of the Consumers' Foundation Saturday harshly criticized the Department of Health (DOH) 's decision to reopen the Taiwan market to U.S. beef in mid-April.
The officials made the criticism after a second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, was confirmed in the United States.

Although the government reimposed the ban on imports of U.S. beef from Saturday, it decided, following advice from experts in the field, that U.S. beef already on store shelves in Taiwan is safe and does not need to be removed.

However, the Consumers' Foundation urged the government to recall all U.S. beef already on store shelves "in consideration of local consumers' health, " adding that it might mobilize consumers to boycott U.S. beef if the government does not react to its call.

Consumers' Foundation Vice Chairman Cheng Hung-jen said that nobody is sure how long the incubation period of mad cow disease is and he claimed that the lifting of the ban on imports of U.S. beef in mid-April was made out of "political considerations."
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case.
The island lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16.
According to Cheng, the DOH decided to reopen the market despite concern expressed by the Council of Agriculture.

After the second case of mad cow disease was confirmed, the DOH still did not react quickly to demands that all U.S. beef already on local store shelves be recalled, Cheng said, claiming that the DOH's policy is "absurdly wrong" and saying that the foundation will hold DOH officials responsible if any local people are affected by the disease.

The foundation's secretary-general, Huang Yi-teng, said that if there are cases in which the health of local people is affected by the disease, the foundation will help consumers claim compensation from the government.
Taiwan was a major outlet for U.S. beef before the import ban was imposed in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD PAY MORE HEED TO CHILDREN BORN TO FOREIGN BRIDES

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng said in a recent interview with the CNA that allowing Taiwanese children born to foreign spouses to receive education is the responsibility of the government.
Tu made the remarks amid reports that some 3,000 Taiwanese children born to Vietnamese spouses do not receive education due to economic and several other factors.

It was reported that these children were first taken by their mothers to Vietnam because of the relatively high living costs in Taiwan. However, Vietnam does not recognize dual nationality, making the children unable to attend schools in Vietnam either.

Tu noted that the government has paid great attention to the education problems faced by these new "sons of Taiwan " and he stressed that allowing them to enjoy educational resources as ordinary children in Taiwan is the responsibility of the government.

In much the same way, Tu added, the government also has the responsibility to allow children of Taiwanese businessmen living in Southeast Asian countries to enjoy the same educational resources as other Taiwan citizens.
Liu Teh-sheng, the Ministry of Education official in charge of the education of overseas Taiwanese, noted that the issue needs to be resolved via cooperation among various ministries.

Liu suggested that the government allow the children to come back to Taiwan for education or that they attend schools operated by Taiwanese businessmen living abroad. He mentioned that there is one such school in Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Thirteen With the C.I.A. Sought by Italy in a Kidnapping.
An Italian judge has ordered the arrest of 13 officers and operatives of the United States Central Intelligence Agency on charges that they seized an Egyptian cleric on a Milan street two years ago and flew him to Egypt for questioning, Italian prosecutors and investigators said Friday. Judge Guido Salvini said in May that it was "certain" that Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, had been seized by "people belonging to foreign intelligence networks interested in interrogating him and neutralizing him, to then hand him over to Egyptian authorities."

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC COMMUNICATION KEY TO SUCCESS OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: Public communication is key to the success of constitutitonal reforms, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen said Saturday.

In an interview with the CNA, Yao said that the constitutional reforms should be made in three steps: making the public aware of the needs for the reforms through public communication; mapping out strategies to be taken; and elaborating on the content of the reforms.

Yao revealed that he had suggested President Chen Shui-bian to pay more attention to public communication recently when Chen invited he himself, senior advisors to the president Peng Ming-min and Wu Li-pei and former legislator Chang Chun-hsiung to discuss his bid to promote a second phase of constitutional reforms.

During the meeting, Yao continued, Chen told them that a second phase of constitutional reforms would address issues such as whether to change the country's political system to a presidential system or a parliamentary system; whether to change the existing five-branch central government organization to a three-branch one; and whether the Taiwan privincial government should be abolished.

Yao said that he had no opinion on the content and timetable of the reforms but suggesting the president pay more attention to strategies, ways and means to be taken to promote constitutional amendments.
It is necessary to increase public communication to raise public concern about the issue, Yao proposed.

Addressing a symposium on sovereignty, constitution and the future of Taiwan held by the Taiwan Law Society earlier in the day, President Chen expressed confidence that he will give Taiwan a new constitution that is timely, relevant and viable by the time he steps down in 2008.
