DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 26, or the 20th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The U.S. Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the U.N. founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter would become effective Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to U.S. President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Student leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the Republic of China.
1992: A peoples' court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: U.S. forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former U.S. President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton begins a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
2001: ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi signs an agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart, Marco A. Ventura, to help train youth from the Central American nation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS GRILL HEALTH DEPARTMENT OVER BEEF IMPORT ISSUE

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the opposition People First Party (PFP) threatened Sunday to boycott the budget for the Department of Health (DOH) should the top governmental health affairs agency continue to be negligent in not overseeing safety of imported beef from the United States.

A second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cow disease, in the United States was confirmed by a British laboratory Friday, prompting the government to reimpose a ban on imports of U.S. beef from Saturday.
The DOH decided at the same time that U.S. beef already on store shelves in Taiwan is safe and does not need to be removed.

The Consumers' Foundation criticized the DOH harshly Saturday for the department's decision to reopen the Taiwan market to U.S. beef in mid-April despite concerns expressed by the Council of Agriculture while Japan and South Korea did not do the same thing.

Consumers' Foundation Vice Chairman Cheng Hung-jen also said that after the second case of mad cow disease was confirmed, the DOH still did not react quickly to demand that all U.S. beef already on local store shelves be recalled. Claiming that the DOH's policy is "absurdly wrong, " Cheng said that the foundation will hold DOH officials responsible if any local people are affected by the disease.

In a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan Sunday, PFP legislators Tsai Sheng-chia and Lin Teh-fu noted that nobody is sure how long the incubation period of mad cow disease is and lashed out at the DOH's lifting of the ban on imports of U.S. beef in mid-April as a decision made out of "political considerations."
Tsai questioned the DOH's motive and wisdom of reopening Taiwan's doors to U.S. beef two months ago when Japan and South Korea were keeping their bans in place.

Noting that the DOH still decided to reopen Taiwan to U.S. beef imports in April despite Council of Agriculture officials' concerns, Tsai said that DOH officials should take the full responsibility now that a second U.S. case of mad cow disease has been confirmed.

If Taiwan consumers were to come down with mad cow disease after eating imported U.S. beef, they should be entitled to national compensation since this would be a repercussion caused by wrong government policies, Tsai continued to say.

Lin ridiculed the DOH officials for quoting U.S. beef exporters, even liaison officials, as having guaranteed that U.S. beef is safe despite that a second U.S. case of mad cow disease was still under investigation, asking whether or not it was only a question of what the Americans said.

Chin Hui-chu, a PFP whip at the Legislative Yuan, claimed that the Executive Yuan decided to reopen U.S. beef imports soon after President Chen Shui-bian said that U.S. beef was safe and Taiwan should re-introduce U.S. beef into the domestic market.
Chin wanted a disclosure of the administration's decision-making process concerning the beef reopening to find out who was the real decision-maker.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case, the first U.S. case of mad cow disease.
The country lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG'S ELECTION COMMENTS REFERRED TO CHAIRMAN, NOT PRESIDENT: PFP

TEXT.P: When PFP Chairman James Soong said on Saturday night that he was physically fit to participate in the next election, he was referring to the election of party chairman, not the 2008 presidential election, a People First Party (PFP) spokeswoman clarified Sunday.

Soong was at a banquet for the wedding of the son of PFP official Lai Hung-min when he mentioned that he had just undergone a physical and that doctors had pronounced him quite healthy -- fit enough to run in another election.
He also said he wanted to "make some people nervous" and that they ought to realize that "none of them can take advantage of James Soong."
Acting apparently on the spur of the moment, Lai made light of the moment and called on PFP faithfuls to "send Soong to the Presidential Office" in 2008.

Stressing that she was present at the wedding banquet, Chin Huei-chu, director of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that she could sense that Soong's remarks meant that he could continue to lead the party and serve the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO STAY WITH KMT LINE IF ELECTED PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng stressed Sunday that he will stick to the Kuomintang's (KMT) party line as he always has to protect the Republic of China, if elected party chairman.
Wang made the remarks at a campaign stop marking the establishment of a local chapter of his supporters in Tainan city, southern Taiwan.

Emphasizing that he will stand by the party line that promotes democracy, freedom and reform, Wang, one of the party's five vice chairmen, said that he will fully devote his energy to serving the party to help make the ROC a more democratic, prosperous, securer and free country should he win the chairmanship.

A KMT chairman must know how to use the majority advantage of the "pan blue alliance" in the Legislative Yuan to implement the party's policies and help the party win back power, he said, reiterating that the KMT must engage in reform and reach out to the people if it wants to defeat the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the 2008 presidential election.

Wang is set to face Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, also a KMT vice chairman, in the main opposition party's chairmanship election set for July 16. Incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to leave the post in August.
Ma also has launched his own campaign for the party's top post, claiming that the race is critical for the KMT's chances in the 2008 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC LIKELY TO RAISE INTEREST RATES TO AVERT LOOMING INFLATION

TEXT.P: The rising price of crude oil will force the hand of Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) to raise interest rates soon to arrest market speculation about possible inflation, analysts predict.
The CBC is likely to raise interest rates by 0.125 percentage points June 30 when its board of directors and supervisors meet for a quarterly meeting, financial market sources said Sunday.

According to CBC authorities, the CBC has cut interest rates 15 consecutive times since December 2000, and only raised them by 0.25 percentage points in September 2004, followed by another rise again last December of 0.125 percentage points and then again in March of this year by 0.125 percentage points.
Currently, the country's discount rate, guaranteed loan rate and short-term loan rate stands at 1.875 percent, 2.25 percent and 4.125 percent, respectively, according to CBC authorities.

Commenting on the possibility of raising interest rates, Kung Ming-hsing, a senior researcher with the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research -- a think tank -- said that if domestic commodity prices continue to soar as a result of spiraling oil prices, which surged past the US$60 per barrel mark for the first time Thursday, the CBC will have to do something to prevent inflation from jumping.
The 0.125 percent rise in interest rates expected to be announced June 30 could be the first of a series of similar rises in the future should oil prices continued to surge, Kung speculated.

Continuously rising interest rates, however, will probably deal a blow to the domestic real estate market, which has gained steam in recent months despite the fact that the country's economy has suffered from sluggish growth since the first quarter of this year, Kung pointed out.

There have been two rival voices from within the CBC on the "to raise or not to raise issue, " with one side hoping that the current interest rates will remain unchanged because of the sluggish growth, and the other side arguing that raising interest rates is unavoidable amid looming inflation, a CBC official said.

The local banker noted that reviewing past experiences, the CBC tends to raise interest rates before inflation begins and it has proved to be an effective method to maintain a healthy monetary policy.
As a result, he said, a rise of 0.125 percentage points in Taiwan's interest rates on June 30 is very possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER CALLS FOR INTENSIFIED CRACKDOWN ON DRUG-RELATED CRIMES

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Sunday law enforcement officers should do more to crack down on drug trafficking and abuse because such offenses have been closely associated with other criminal activities.
Shih made the remarks while attending a "drug-free homeland" activity organized by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office to mark the June 26 International Anti-Drug Day.

In 2003 and 2004, Shih said, more than 8,400 kilograms of contraband drugs were seized around the country. Worse still, he said, 30-plus amphetamine producing facilities were discovered during the same period, indicating that amphetamine production has gradually been moved back to Taiwan from China.

"Official tallies also show that the number of repeat drug abusers and traffickers has been steadily rising, " Shih said, adding that law enforcement agencies should strengthen cooperation in cracking down on drug-related crimes.

In addition, Shih said he is hopeful that community volunteers, school teachers and administrators as well as media outlets can launch a joint publicity campaign to help the public understand drug hazards to human health, social order and even national security.

Since many Taiwan drug dealers and traffickers are believed to be hiding in China, Shih urged Beijing to intensify investigations into its domestic drug trade and cooperate with Taiwan to thwart drug trafficking across the Taiwan Strait.
"China should forsake its political ideology and cooperate with Taiwan to stamp out drug-related crime for the sake of protecting public health and social order," he added.

Shih's appeal for reinforced crackdown on drug crime came two days after President Chen Shui-bian said drug abuse is not just a personal moral issue but has become an issue crucial to public order, social stability, public health and national security.

During his meeting with individual volunteers and social groups that have made outstanding contributions to the anti-drug campaign over the past year, Chen said many criminal cases now are related to drugs.

"With drug abuse becoming ever more serious, new ecstasy pills continuing to appear and the number of repeat drug abusers and traffickers rising steadily, drug-related crime has become rampant," Chen said, adding that drug abuse has also become a major cause behind afast rise in the number of local HIV carriers.

Against this backdrop, Chen said he hopes individual volunteers and public interest groups can continue their efforts in assisting the government in eradicating drug trafficking and abuse and in curbing a further spread of AIDS.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP VOWS TO SERVE AS BRIDGE IN SELLING TAIWAN PRODUCE TO CHINA

TEXT.P: A civic group led by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Her Jyh-huei urged the government Sunday to allow it to act as a platform between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to help Taiwan farmers sell their produce in China.

Her, who serves as chairman of the Association for Economic and Trade Relations Across the Strait (AETRAS) , said that the group is prepared to act as a private-sector communications bridge to step up two-way business and cultural exchanges since systematic talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait have been cut since mid-1999.

To help Taiwan farmers capture a larger portion of the Chinese market, the group is planning to kick off a series of agricultural exchanges in the near term, such as a Taiwan Week being held in Wuhan, Hubei province to promote Taiwan fruit, he said, noting that KMT lawmakers -- Kuo Su-chuan, Chu Fong-chi, Chi Kuo-tung and Liao Wan-ju -- also took part in the activity.

Commenting on a just-concluded low-key visit to China by the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association, which was headed by Liu Chuan-chung, also a KMT legislator, Her claimed that his group exceeds Liu's group in holding talks with China and that if the government is willing to grant its approval, the AETRAS is very willing to serve as a civilian platform between Taiwan and China.

Although China offered greater market access to Taiwan farm exports to visiting KMT Chairman Lien Chan during a trip from April 26 to May 3, Her pointed out that no progress has been made in this regard and called on the government to come up with a resolution as quickly as possible.

China promised to provide duty-free treatment to 15 categories of Taiwan fruits and to allow the import of 18 categories of quarantined farm products during Lien's visit in a goodwill gesture to improve its strained relations with Taiwan.

However, China has so far been reluctant to talk over technical details regarding the opening with the semiofficial Taiwan External Trade Development Council appointed by the Republic of China government, making it harder for Taiwan farmers to provide quarantine and product origin certifications, he said, adding that all these problems need to be handled by the government.
At present, farm produce from Taiwan must go through a third area or country, such as Hong Kong, to be quarantined and certified, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN FISHING DISPUTES SHOULD BE SOLVED DIPLOMATICALLY: YAO

TEXT.P: Taiwan-Japan fishing disputes should be settled diplomatically via rational bilateral negotiations, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, an expert in South China Sea issues, said Sunday.
Yao said that the last thing he would like to see is that Taiwan comes into conflict with Japan as the result of fishing disputes between the two countries.

As the 15th round of fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan is scheduled to be held in Tokyo July 29, mainly aimed at solving the disputes caused by overlapping economic zones, Yao said that the country could use some debates on whether the sovereignty issue should be delinked from the fishing rights issue during the forthcoming fishery meeting to make the talks more pragmatic.

Yao made the remarks after a Taiwan fishing boat, the "Chinruifeng No. 168, " reportedly was given notice by a Japanese patrol boat Sunday "to leave the Japanese exclusive economic zone" at an area near the "temporary demarcation line" that has been zoned tacitly between the two countries regarding fishing operations.

The Suao Fishermen's Association complained the same day that since Taiwan and Japan are preparing to meet for a new round of fishery talks to address the overlapped economic zones issue, Japan should not take radical moves now to declare its sovereignty over the area that is Taiwan fishermen's traditional fishing grounds and is zoned clearly by the "temporary demarcation line."

Yao did not advocate the ROC Navy sending military vessels to "protect the interests of fishermen, " saying that if fishing disputes arise because of unclear economic zones, the disputes should be tackled via diplomatic means.

As to the territorial disputes involving the Tiaoyutai Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan, to which Taiwan, Japan and China claim sovereignty, Yao said that as far as he knew, China has been using a "syllogism" strategy, claiming that the Tiaoyutai Islands belongs to Taiwan and since Taiwan is part of China, the Tiaoyutai Islands are China's.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S NEW REGULATIONS ON RELIGIOUS AFFAIRS MEAN STRICT CONTROL: MAC

TEXT.P: China's new Regulations on Religious Affairs have done more in strengthening Beijing's control and governance of religions than safeguarding the people's religious freedom, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan said in a newly released report.

The research report for June, written by the cultural division of the MAC, noted that although the regulations, which came into effect in March, reaffirm that all Chinese citizens enjoy freedom of religious belief, they may actually still impose many restrictions on religious faiths, making these standards of freedom quite different from those in democratic countries.

The report said it is clear from the new regulations that religious affairs in China are not ruled by law, but are still ruled by government officials. For example, Article 3 says the state protects "normal religious activities." Yet the legal definition of "normal" is never clearly defined, and the government has the right to interpret it freely.

In another example, Article 3 and Article 4 emphasize that all religious groups and activities must be in line with national unity, consolidation among different ethnic groups and social stability, and free from foreign control. This means that religions are still subject to the highest guiding principles of the Communist Party of China.

The report further noted that, according to the regulations, people in China can believe in any religion, but are not allowed to preach freely. Religious workers are not allowed to preach outside their places registered with the government, and they can only preach in designated time periods.

The Appendix of the regulations says China will undertake religious exchanges with Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau in accordance with laws, administrative regulations and relevant rules of the nation. The MAC report viewed this as largely ambiguous and wants to wait and see what might develop from it.

The regulations, announced by China's State Council, took six years to draft. They cover six areas: general principles of religious freedom, expectations of religious organizations, places of worship, specifics for religious personnel, issues concerning religious property and legal liabilities. Altogether there are 48 articles.

Religious leaders worldwide have noted that the Chinese government, officially atheist, cares less about what religious people actually believe than about its official policies not being undermined. Many observers have agreed that the success of the regulations will depend on how they are interpreted and implemented at the grassroots level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION WANTS U. S. BEEF TO BE DESTROYED PUBLICLY

TEXT.P: Out of concern that public fears over U. S. beef might flare again in Taiwan following a second confirmation of mad cow disease in the United States, the Consumers' Foundation (CF) demanded the government Sunday publicly destroy all U. S. beef that has been imported to Taiwan.

CF Vice Chairman Chen Hung-jen, who visited various hypermarkets earlier the same day, said that his foundation can help retailers ask for compensation from the Department of Health (DOH) if they are willing to take these products off the shelves.

The DOH immediately reimposed a ban on U. S. beef imports Saturday after a second mad cow disease case in the United States was confirmed. The DOH removed the restriction in April this year following a 14-month ban after the first case in the United States was reported in late 2003.

CF Secretary General-Huang Yi-teng said that the government must fully assume responsibility for the two-month legal loophole that it created and insisted that the government should come up with specific measures to deal with risky beef from the United States by asking retailers to recall their products and compensate them for their losses for the sake of public health.

The government must respond to the U. S. beef in question because it is very difficult for the general public to trace the origin of the meat they eat if they were said to be from other countries, he said.

Meanwhile, local hypermarket managers said that the sale of U. S. beef in their shops have not been affected despite the news of a second mad cow disease case in the United States, a sharp contrast to a general assumption that U. S. beef will be rejected by Taiwan consumers.
However, the managers said that they will replace U. S. beef with beef from Australia and New Zealand after the current stock from the United States is used up in late July at the earliest.

They pointed out that they will increase supplies of Australian and New Zealand beef in the near future given that Taiwan consumers have been gradually getting used to products from the two countries over the past two years.

Before the first mad cow disease case in the United States, U. S. beef enjoyed about a 70 precent share in the domestic market, well ahead of some 30 percent taken by beef from Australia and New Zealand, they said, adding, however, that the ratio had dropped to around 50 percent after the initial ban.
They predicted that the follow-up effects in the domestic market will not surface until next week despite the fact that the Taiwan market remains little affected for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COAST GUARD URGES JAPAN TO EXERCISE SELF-RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan and Japan should exercise self-restraint before the two countries work out a solution to their fishing rights dispute through negotiations, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Sunday.

The CGA made the call after a Japanese coast guard ship issued a warning to a Taiwan fishing boat operating near the middle line of the two countries' overlapping economic waters, also known locally as the "tentative demarcation line," earlier in the day.

The "Chinjuifeng No. 168" from Suao in the northeastern county of Ilan was operating in waters some 60 nautical miles east of the Tiaoyutai Islands -- a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China -- when it was served a Japanese notice asking it to leave the region.

CGA officials said that as the Chinjuifeng was operating within the "tentative demarcation line" that has been zoned tacitly between the two countries regarding fishing operations, the CGA immediately ordered its "Keelung" patrol vessel to sail to the disputed region to protect the Taiwan fishing boat's safety.
The "Keelung" patrol vessel was on a North Pacific patrol mission at the time. In addition, the CGA sent two other ships from Taiwan to the region.
According to CGA officials, the three patrol ships have arrived at the disputed waters by Sunday evening. The officials said the CGA will do its utmost to protect local fishermen's safety.

The officials said the CGA has also informed the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Fishery Administration under the council of Agriculture of the latest incident and asked for their assistance in dealing with the issue.

Since the two countries have agreed to hold a new round of talks to resolve their fishing rights dispute in Tokyo July 29, the CGA officials said they hope Japan can exercise self-restraint to avoid complicating the issue.

The incident came after the Ministry of National Defense, under strong pressure from opposition lawmakers, sent a Knox-class frigate to patrol the disputed waters Tuesday to accentuate Taiwan's determination to protect its fishermen's rights and safety. Some 15 lawmakers from across the party spectrum, led by Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, took the cruise aboard the warship in the company of Defense Minister Lee Jye.

At the heart of the dispute is the two countries' sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutai Islands. Both Tokyo and Taipei claim that the island group falls within their 200-mile exclusive economic zones. Japan often fines ship owners and impounds Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter waters close to the Tiaoyutais.
The previous 14 rounds of Taiwan-Japanese fishery talks did not make significant headway because Taiwan would not forsake its sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutais which Japan has held since 1971.

The dispute came into the limelight again recently after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the disputed waters over Japanese coast guard ships' frequently chasing them away from the region.

A spokeswoman for the Suao Fishermen's Association said Japan should refrain from sending coast guard ships to patrol waters close to the "tentative demarcation line" now that the two countries will meet in July to discuss measures for joint exploration for and management of resources in their overlapping economic waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BEEF ON LOCAL STORE SHELVES PERFECTLY SAFE: DOH

TEXT.P: U.S. beef on local store shelves and on way to Taiwan is perfectly safe, a Department of Health (DOH) official said Sunday.

Chen Lu-hung, director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, said the government's decision to reinstate a U.S. beef import ban the previous day was more of "procedural" in nature rather than out of food safety concern.

"When the DOH lifted the ban on imports of U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16 this year, it made a promise that the door will be shut down again if a new case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) or mad cow disease is confirmed in the United States," Chen said.

Taiwan first banned U.S. beef imports in December 2003 after the United States reported its first case of BSE, which has been linked to a variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, a disease that has claimed more than 140 lives worldwide, mostly in Britain.

On Saturday, Premier Frank Hsieh ordered a reinstatement of the U.S. beef import ban after the U.S. Department of Agriculture confirmed the discovery of a second BSE case. Nevertheless, the DOH said U.S. beef on local market shelves and delivered before June 25 can still be sold here.

The decision immediately drew scathing criticism from consumers groups and some opposition lawmakers. They demanded that the government recall all U.S. beef from local market shelves and destroy the produce in public for health concern.
In response, Chen said the newly discovered BSE case involved an eight-year-old non-ambulatory "downer" cow which had never entered the market nor been made into animal feeds.

Moreover, Chen said, the U.S. beef allowed to enter Taiwan in the past two months was from young cattle under 30 months of age which is free of any risk of BSE infection. Therefore, he said, the DOH will not ask stores to remove U.S. beef from their shelves.
As to when the government would lift the import ban again, Chen said the issue will be considered only after certain conditions are met.

"The conditions that the United States must meet will include the release of pathological information concerning the second BSE case, the birth certificate of the sick cattle, the implementation of a feed ban and beef slaughtering standards, as well as the establishment of a BSE surveillance system," Chen said.

He noted that the information made known so far shows that the latest case involves an eight-year-old non-ambulatory "downer" cow, but there has not been any other pathological data such as where exactly the animal was raised and the whereabouts of its siblings.

While the United States already imposed in 1997 a feed ban that prohibits feeding to cattle and other ruminants most mammalian protein, including meat-and-bone meal, it has also adopted beef slaughtering standards that require the removal of risky BSE-transmissible tissue such as brains, spinal cords and bones from the cattle, Chen pointed out.
Meanwhile, the U.S. Department of Agriculture is also reviewing its BSE surveillance program, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM REQUIRES COMPLEMENTARY MEASURES: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan must craft comprehensive complementary measures no matter which government system it would adopt in the future, a scholar in constitutional theory and principles said Sunday.

Lee Hung-hsi, president of the Ketagalan Institute and a mentor of President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks while delivering in a speech in the eastern city of Hualien on the pursuit of an ideal constitutional system for Taiwan.

Describing the present ROC Constitution as a Draconian statute, Lee said the government system laid out in the Constitution is cobbled together from various political systems. As a result, he said, the system set forth in the present Constitution is hard to implement.
In the next stage of constitutional reform, Lee said, Taiwan should flesh out all-inclusive complementary measures once it make a final decision on its future government system.

"There has been a debate in local society on whether Taiwan should adopt a presidential system or a parliamentary system. Either of them has its own special features, merits and deficiencies. No matter which system we may choose in the future, the most important thing is that we should draw up complementary measures to make our new system viable and fitting to our national situation," Lee said.
Lee's remarks came a day after President Chen reaffirmed his commitment to acting as a "midwife" who will help with the delivery of a new Constitution for Taiwan by the time he steps down in 2008.
The Ketagalan Institute is an independent, non-partisan educational institution founded by President Chen in March 2003 for promoting civic values through policy research.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 3RD PLACE IN ASIAN WOMEN'S BASKETBALL CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team beat its Japanese counterpart Sunday to win a third place in the 21st Asian Women's Basketball Championship.
The Taiwan team won the game held in Qinhuangdao in the northern Chinese province of Hebei with a score of 73:62.
By defeating the Japanese team, Taiwan secured a berth to play in the World Women's Basketball Championship to be held in Brazil in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD JOIN U.N. CONSULTATIVE PROCESS OVER FISHING DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Taiwan should strive to join the United Nations' Open-ended, Informal Consultative Process on Oceans and the Law of the Sea to facilitate solution to its longstanding fishing disputes with Japan, local international law experts said Sunday.

According to the experts, the Open-ended Informal Consultative Process on Oceans and the Law of the Sea is a U.N.-recognized non-government organization which offers a platform for countries around the world to discuss issues regarding oceans and the law of the sea.

Tsai Tseng-chia, a research fellow at National Chengchi University's International Relations Institute, said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Coast Guard Administration should cooperate to solicit international support for Taiwan's participation in this non-government organization which would provide a useful channel for Taiwan to resolve its dispute over fishing rights in waters close to the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Victory by Hard-Liner in Iran Could Widen Rift With U.S.
Almost no one in Washington expected the landslide victory of the conservative mayor of Tehran, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, as Iran's next president. Ahmadinejad has made little secret of his determination that Iran is going to become a nuclear nation, though he has been careful to deny that Iran's ultimate goal is to build a weapon. Facing a populist, the Bush administration is bracing for a long, hot summer of confrontation with Iran.

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team defeated Japan 73-62 Sunday evening to finish third at the 21st Asia Women's Basketball Championship held in Qinhuangdao, northern China June 19-26.
The victory also gave Chinese Taipei the last spot in next year's Women's Basketball World Championship to be held in Brazil.
China defeated South Korea 73-67 to win the tournament, the third of its kind since 2001, Xinhua News Agency reported.
A total of 13 teams participated in the tournament, with Chinese Taipei, China, Japan, South Korea and Thailand competing in the Class 1 division of the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 27, or the 21st day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads had gone out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
2000: The Legislative Yuan adopts a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.
2001: A total of 175 illegal mainland Chinese immigrats are repatrated from Fu Su Port on the frontline island of Matsu through arrangement by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DEPARTS FOR PALAU FOR OFFICIAL VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu departed for Palau Monday morning for a three-day official visit to the southwestern Pacific island nation.

Speaking at the airport prior to her departure, Lu said that Palau is the ROC diplomatic ally located nearest to Taiwan and that the heads of state of the two countries frequently visit each other's country.

An island nation with rich ocean tourism resources, Palau has been a popular place for Asian tourists, particularly Taiwanese, Lu said, adding that she is going to meet with Palauan officials in charge of tourism and with local hoteliers to gain a better understanding of the travel facts of the island country for reference for Taiwan tourists.
Lu is expected to meet with Palauan President Tommy Remengesau and the speakers of the Palauan Senate and House of Representatives during her stay.

She is scheduled to attend a ceremony Tuesday marking the grand opening of the six-story, 160-room Palau Royal Resort Hotel -- the newest and one of the largest five-star hotels in Palau -- which was built by a group of Taiwanese businesspeople operating in Palau.
Additionally, Lu will also visit other tourism attractions and environmental facilities around Palau.
Palauan President Tommy Remengesau renewed his invitation recently to President Chen Shui-bian for a visit to his country.
President Chen, who visited Palau in January this year, asked Lu to make the visit to Palau this month on his behalf due to his tight schedule in late June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO RELEASE REPORT ON CHINA'S MILITARY POWER: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 26 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Defense is expected to release a report on China's military buildup around the July 4 U.S. Independence Day, the Republic of China's top representative to the United States said in Los Angeles Sunday.
David Ta-wei Lee, who is currently on a brief visit in the southern California city, made the remarks while meeting with a group of Chinese-language media correspondents.

In line with the principles of a Taiwan-U.S. mutual trust mechanism, Lee said, U.S. authorities will brief the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C. before the report on China's military power is released.

The report is expected to include an in-depth assessment of China's military power and strategy and a detailed analysis of its missile and naval force buildup across the Taiwan Strait, China affairs experts said, adding that the report is expected to raise concerns over China's ever growing military threat to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKERS GRILL ADMINISTRATION OVER U.S. BEEF IMPORT ISSUE

TEXT.P: A group of opposition legislators grilled the administration again Monday over the U.S. beef imports issue amid concerns of mad cow disease.

Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, a deputy convener of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said he wants administration officials, including Premier Frank Hsieh, to apologize to the country for "wrong policies" which he claimed have ignored the people's health and compromised Taiwan's national dignity.

A second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cow disease, in the United States was confirmed by a British laboratory Friday, prompting the government to reimpose a ban on imports of U.S. beef from Saturday.
The Department of Health (DOH) decided at the same time that U.S. beef already on store shelves in Taiwan is safe and does not need to be removed.

Lai criticized the government for putting political considerations ahead the people's health. He said that beef from the ROC-held outlying island of Kinmen has been banned from being imported into Taiwan proper since 1999 following a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak there. The ban still stands today even though no new cases of foot-and-mouth disease have been reported since then, he said.

The lawmaker ridiculed the administration for "flattering" the United States by reopening Taiwan's doors to U.S. beef even though the mad cow disease threat in the United States has not disappeared as evidenced by Friday's confirmation of a second case.

Lai said that companies which have sustained losses due to the government's wrong policies regarding U.S. beef imports should be entitled to national compensation, adding that if anyone comes down with mad cow disease after ingesting imported U.S. beef, the government should foot their medical bills in addition to paying them compensation.
KMT Legislator Joanna Lei urged the administration to end its "beef diplomacy" and refrain from "trading people's lives for Taiwan's diplomatic space."

Meanwhile, opposition People First Party (PFP) Lin Teh-fu said that the administration owes the country explanations on many matters, including why Taiwan reopened its doors to U.S. beef in April despite concerns expressed by the Council of Agriculture and why imported U.S. beef is allowed to remain on store shelves around Taiwan after the DOH called a halt to imports of U.S. beef Saturday.

Lin noted that nobody is sure how long the incubation period of mad cow disease is and lashed out at the DOH's lifting of the ban on imports of U.S. beef in mid-April as a decision made out of "political considerations."

PFP Legislator Lee Hung-chun asked why Taiwan reopened its doors to U.S. beef in April while more than 50 countries around the world, including Japan and South Korea, kept their bans on U.S. beef imports in place.

PFP lawmakers threatened Sunday to block the budget for the Department of Health should the top government health affairs agency continue to be negligent in overseeing safety of imported beef from the United States.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case, the first U.S. case of mad cow disease.
The country lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAN ON POULTRY IMPORTS FROM JAPAN REMAINS IN FORCE: COA

TEXT.P: The ban on poultry imports from Japan has remained in force since January 2004, a Council of Agriculture official in charge of animal quarantine and inspection affairs said Monday.

The official made the remarks after the Japanese government announced over the weekend that bird flu has been detected in chickens at a farm in northeastern Japan and that restrictions have been imposed on shipments of poultry and eggs from the area.

"We have imposed a ban on imports of poultry and related products from Japan since the H5N1 bird flu infections were confirmed in that country in January 2004, " the official said, adding that the ban has not been lifted since that time.

Amid reports of new bird flu infections in Japan, the official said, the COA will heighten its alert and step up inspection and quarantine measures to avert any avian flu-infected poultry from entering Taiwan.

The Japanese government said Sunday that more than 800 chickens at a farm in Mitsukaido City in Ibaraki Prefecture, located just northeast of Tokyo, have died since April, and recent tests on some found they were infected with the H5N2 strain of bird flu.

H5N2 is regarded as less dangerous strain of the bird flu virus than H5N1, which has led to the death and slaughter of tens of millions of birds across Asia since late 2003. H5N1 has also crossed over to humans, killing 38 people in Vietnam, 12 in Thailand and four in Cambodia in the past couple of years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR BLOOD DONATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for people Monday not to be reluctant to donate blood, especially in the summer when a lack of blood is expected because the regular blood donation operations in schools will be stopped during summer vacation.

Chen made the appeal while receiving over 30 acclaimed blood donors at the Presidential Office. Each of the donors have donated blood more than 140 times, while one of the five female donors among the remarkable citizens, Jao Chiu-yun, has donated blood 506 times.
The president expressed his admiration and gratitude to the donors for their "life-saving deed, " saying that generously donating blood for needy people is a "valuable life-caring action."

After 31 years of efforts to promote a blood-donation campaign around the country, Taiwan has seen success, with the "donation-supply balance" reaching 7.9 percent, well above the internationally recognized standard of 5 percent, Chen noted.
Last year, a total of 2.33 million units of blood was donated nationwide, for a total of 5.3 million units for use in medical treatment following processing of the donated blood.
More remarkably, Chen noted, since 1991, 100 percent of Taiwan's domestic supply of blood for medical treatment has come from voluntary donors.

However, he reminded people that blood donation operations have been affected by the mid-June floods caused by torrential rains in southern Taiwan, and that the major source of blood donations -- schools around the country -- will soon close for summer vacation.
To ensure sufficient blood supplies during the long summer vacation, Chen urged people to answer his call to donate blood.
Minister of the Department of Health Hou Sheng-mao and Taiwan Blood Donation Foundation Chairman Lin Kuo-hsin were also at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARSHIP WINNERS URGED TO HELP LIFT ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui exhorted a group of excellent aboriginal students Monday to return to their home villages after graduation to help lift the development of aboriginal communities.

Lee, one of the key donors to the Aboriginal Scholarship established by the Lee Lien Educational Foundation, conferred scholarships on aboriginal students who were selected by the foundation this year. The scholarships total NT$1.02 million (US$32,903).

Addressing the ceremony held at National Taipei Teachers' College, Lee said he wants the aboriginal student elite to return to their home towns after graduation to serve or teach there, taking up their historical responsibilities by playing roles as "enlighteners."

Noting that most of the country's aboriginal villages suffer not only from poor living conditions but also from a lack of confidence spiritually, Lee exhorted the aboriginal top-scorers to help boost the indigenous people's psychological rehabilitation and in turn rebuild their confidence in themselves.
Development of aboriginal society will be accelerated only when environments there are noticeably improved and the people regain their confidence in themselves, Lee reiterated.

A total of 80 indigenous students received the 2005 Aboriginal Scholarship, the third of its kind, with scholarship amounts ranging from NT$20,000 (for graduate students) , to NT$15,000 (for college students) and NT$10,000 (for senior high school and vocational school students).

According to Huang Kun-hui, chairman of the Lee Lien Educational Foundation, President Lee donated all of the governmental subsidies from campaign funds to enable the establishment of the foundation in 1996 after Lee won Taiwan's first popular presidential election.

With savings interest rates continuing to fall in recent years, Huang said, the foundation has found it increasingly difficult to maintain the same levels of scholarship amounts every year. He urged all sectors of the country to contribute to this great project aimed at helping aboriginal young men and women.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for August moved down 50 points to end at 6,180, with 478 contracts traded, while September futures lost 50 points to finish at 6,158, with 183 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and March.

No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ANNOUNCES PERIODIC BAN ON FISHING OFF LANYU

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced a ban Monday on commercial fishing within six nautical miles off the coast of Orchid Island, or Lanyu, from March to June every year to preserve marine sources for the people living on the island.
The three-month period is the traditional fishing season of the Tao people on Lanyu, which lies off the southeastern coast of Taiwan, when schools of flying fish gather.
From next year, fishing boats with a displacement of over 10 tons will not be allowed to fish in the area, while drift nets, explosive and toxic substance are prohibited.

Hsieh also instructed the Coast Guard Administration to implement the policy and enforce the law concerning the ban in a strict manner, saying that he hopes flying fish will be left to Lanyu residents.
The premier made the announcement while attending Lanyu Flying Fish Festival activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

The bourse opened at 6,307.61 and fluctuated between 6,342.45 and 6,279.39 during trading. A total of 3.16 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$69.05 billion (US$2.2 billion).
