DOC.HEADLINE: U. S. BEEF SOLD IN TAIWAN SAFE: AIT OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: U. S. liaison officials stationed in Taiwan gave their assurances Monday of the safety of beef imports from the United States to Taiwan and called on Taiwan to reopen its market to U. S. imports based on scientific review, not politics.

Dana Shell Smith, spokeswoman for the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , and Eric Trachtenberg, AIT deputy section chief in charge of farm trade, made the remarks while answering questions from reporters during a meeting with local media.

Stressing that U. S. beef imported to Taiwan is completely safe despite the fact that a second case of BSE (bovine spongiform encephalopathy) , or mad cow disease, in the United States was confirmed over the weekend, Trachtenberg urged Taiwan authorities to use its scientific c judgment, not politics, to decide whether U. S. beef should continue to be imported into Taiwan.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) immediately reimposed a ban on beef imports from the United States Saturday, only two months after it lifted a ban in April. Taiwan initially put the ban in place in late 2003 soon after the first case of mad cow disease was discovered.
The Consumers' Foundation has asked the DOH to publicly destroy all U. S. beef sold to Taiwan, which would include that on shelves and in storage out of grave concern over public health.
According to Trachtenberg, the second case of BSE is not a new case, or a new animal, but a re-test of an old sample taken during an extensive cattle herd surveillance program before Dec. 2004.

Citing the newest guidelines published by the World Animal Health Organization May 27, Trachtenberg said that boneless beef from cattle under 30 months can be freely traded without risk to consumers regardless of the exporting country's BSE status, provided that the animals are inspected before and after slaughter, specified risk materials are removed, and approved slaughter methods are used, he noted.

The United States follows all of these guidelines for beef sold to Taiwan, he said, emphasizing that there are major differences in the cow whose test just came back and the cattle used in U. S. beef exports. This cow was born before the U. S. government put into place stringent new measures, including the prohibition of feeding rendered cattle products back to other cattle.

In addition to being born before the feed ban, the animal in question did not and never would have entered the food supply or feed supply chain, he explained, noting that Taiwan's decision to reopen its market to U. S. beef April 16 was based on a thorough, objective and scientific review of safety over 15 months, involving 18 outside experts.
Taiwan's decision to resume U. S. beef imports in April was made without political considerations, Smith said.
AIT is responsible for Washington's dealings with Taiwan now that the two countries maintain no formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING RIGHTS AND SOVEREIGNTY INEXORABLY LINKED: TAIWAN ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Fishing rights are an extension of sovereignty and the sovereignty issue is by no means a matter concerning only fishermen, according to a group of Taiwan academics Monday.

They called for the administration to harden its resolve to protect the country's fishermen by seriously reiterating the Republic of China on Taiwan's sovereignty claim over the Tiaoyutai Islands -- the heart of fishing disputes between Taiwan and Japan, which have been brought into the limelight recently.

At a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Prof. Kuo Chung-yi with Soochow University said that because Japan claims the Tiaoyutai Islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan, the Japanese government has demarcated its 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zone to an area reaching Taiwan's doorstep, leading to the recurrence of a spate of fishing disputes between the two countries in recent years.

Prof. Liu Yuan-chun, a former president of Soochow University, expressed indignation with the administration's recent announcement, prior to the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, that discussions on fishing rights would have nothing to do with the sovereignty issue.

Noting that fishing rights are absolutely an extension of sovereignty, Liu lashed out at the administration, calling it "a bunch of irresponsible liars" who say that the issue of sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais will not be brought up at the forthcoming Taiwan-Japan fishery talks.

Prof. Hsia Chu-chiu with National Taiwan University noted that Japan does not have fishing disputes with Taiwan alone. Japan has had similar disputes with South Korea over the island chain of Takashima, known as "Dokdo" in South Korea. Because the South Korean government firmly supported private actions to defend the disputed island chain, Japan did not make headway with their claim over the islands, Hsia added.

The three professors said that they already have acquired signatures of nearly 50 academics and intellectuals in the country, including Academia Sinica Vice President Ovid Tzeng, supporting the launch of a campaign called the "global Chinese intellectuals protecting Taiwan fishermen" in the hopes that more intellectuals and people with greater influence will exert pressure on the government so that Taiwan will not lose ground in the upcoming fishery talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ENVOY REASSURES SAFETY OF BEEF

TEXT.P: The de facto U.S. ambassador to Taipei reassured Taiwan consumers of the safety of U.S. beef Monday.

Douglas Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office, made the remarks following Taiwan's reimposition of a ban on imports of U.S. beef Saturday, one day after a second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, in the United States was confirmed by a British laboratory.
The Department of Health (DOH) decided at the same time that U.S. beef already on store shelves in Taiwan is safe and does not need to be removed.
Paal said that the second case of BSE is not a new case, or a new animal, but a re-test of an old sample taken during an extensive cattle herd surveillance program before December 2004.

"There is no reason to question the safety of the U.S. beef supply. This cow never entered the food supply or feed supply chain," Paal said. In fact, because the animal was older than 30 months of age when slaughtered, the stringent screening measures now in place would never allow such an animal to be utilized for food or feed, he added.
He said that there is no reason "to compare this long-deceased cow with cattle that are now being used for U.S. beef exports."
He also said that the stringent screening measures in place to protect consumers and contain the spread of BSE succeeded in identifying, isolating and disposing of this disease animal.
The recently confirmed BSE case has no public or animal health implications, he maintained, adding that "this test has absolutely no bearing on U.S. beef imported to Taiwan."
He expressed the hope that Taiwan will move swiftly to re-open the beef market after AIT shares detailed information on the recent BSE detection.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case, the first U.S. case of mad cow disease.
The country lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million-worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before Taiwan imposed the ban. Since then, Australian and New Zealand beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, banned U.S. beef in the aftermath of the mad cow disease scare, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year. (By Lilian Wu) 334

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bombing Attacks on Iraqi Forces Kill 38 in North.
Four suicide bomb attacks struck Iraqi police and an army base in a 16-hour wave of insurgent violence in the northern city of Mosul on Saturday and Sunday, killing 38 people and wounding scores more. One American commander said the violence continued a trend in the past few weeks of insurgent attacks intensely focused on Iraqi security forces.
Wall Street Journal: After Earlier Fumbles, Cn ooc Uses Wall Street Tactics in Unocal Bid.
Six years ago, the state-owned Chinese oil company Cnooc Ltd. attempted an initial public offering in New York and Hong Kong, and the result was utter failure due to poor timing and a lack of interest by investors. Six years la ter, Cnooc is trying to make itself understood again -- and the world is paying attention this time. The oil and natural-gas producer is pursuing the biggest overseas acquisition in Chinese history: an $18.5 billion rival bid against Chevron Corp. for control of California-based Unocal Corp. The bid, and the preparations that led to it, illustrate just how far Cnooc has come in schooling itself in the arts of Wall Street corporate finance and in the sensitive politics of Sino-U.S. relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIOU'S U.S. VISIT IRRELEVANT TO ARMS PROCUREMENT PROJECT: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 26 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The top ROC representative to the United States confirmed Sunday that Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of Taiwan's National Security Council, is currently on a visit in the United States.
Nevertheless, David Ta-wei Lee said he doesn't think that Chiou's ongoing U.S. visit has anything to do with issues related to Taiwan's long-stalled arms procurement project.

According to local media reports, Chiou arrived at Los Angeles International Airport Friday evening. He was escorted from the airport by an unidentified American upon his arrival. Since then, no local journalists have been able to trace his whereabouts.

Lee, who came to Los Angeles from Washington, D.C. over the weekend to address a meeting of executives of major Taiwanese expatriate associations in southern California, told Chinese-language media correspondents during a news briefing Sunday that Chiou would have traveled to Washington, D.C. first if he were to discuss the arms procurement project during his current visit.
"Chiou would also have contacted me if the main purpose of his visit were to tackle the arms procurement project as some media reports speculated," Lee said.

The United States agreed to sell Taiwan a robust package of weapons in 2001. While Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party administration has come up with a special budget proposal for the procurement package, its opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has so far not approved the bill.

Lee said the ROC government's stance on arms procurement has been very consistent. In his view, Lee said, the pending procurement project forms an extremely important part of Taiwan-U.S. military cooperation.
"It is my hope that our legislature can pass the budget bill for the procurement project as soon as possible," Lee said.
The NT$480 billion arms procurement package includes eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$205 MILLION TO BE SPENT IN PROMOTING LANYU COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The government will spend US$205 million (US$6.54 million) in efforts to rebuild six tribal communities on Orchid Island, or Lanyu, an offshore island which lies off the southeastern coast of Taiwan, Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday.
The money was donated by Taiwan Power Company in return for Lanyu serving as a dumping ground for nuclear waste produced by nuclear-generated power plants on the main island of Taiwan.

Hsieh made the announcement while attending the Lanyu Flying Fish Festival's opening. Ministers without Portfolio Fu Li-yeh, Kuo Yao-chi and Cho Jung-tai; Walis Pelin, minister of the Council of Indigenous Peoples; and Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Chin-yuan were also at the ceremony.

A planned overall community rebuilding program will be implemented under goals including promoting industrial development, upgrading social welfare and medical treatment systems, improving community security, promoting cultural education, and preserving the natural environment of the small island, home of the indigenous tribe of Tao, or Yamei, the premier said.

Besides the program, a limited ban on commercial fishing within six nautical miles off the coast of Lanyu will also be implemented from March to June every year to preserve marine sources -- mainly flying fish -- for the island people, Hsieh noted
The three-month period is the Tao's traditional fishing season for flying fish, which is the source of the indigenous people's diet and cultural development.
From next year, fishing boats with a displacement of over 10 tons will not be allowed to fish in the area, while drift nets, explosive and toxic substance are prohibited.
Meanwhile, a suspended employment project will also be resumed to assist Lanyu residents to find jobs, the premier added

DOC.HEADLINE: LI AO SUING ENTIRE LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: : Independent Legislator Li Ao, a noted writer who is also known for having filed numerous lawsuits in the past four decades, is setting a new national record by suing all his colleagues in the Legislative Yuan -- 224 of them in all -- for "abusing their rights" and "failure to perform their duties."
The Taipei District Court will begin hearing the case July 1.
Li reportedly told his friends that he enjoys suing people and is not afraid of incurring the anger of his fellow legislators. He said he was "proud" of his new record.

What prompted Li to file the suit was the resolution adopted by the Legislative Yuan March 4 in reaction to the anti-secession law being considered at that time by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament.

The resolution says the Republic of China, since its founding in 1912, has been a "sovereign, independent country" and that any move to unilaterally change the status quo or try to denigrate the sovereignty of the nation will run counter to the common will of the Taiwan people and the international community.
Li claimed that in adopting the resolution, the lawmakers acted beyond their power and in violation of the Constitution.

He also claimed that despite being a member of the Legislative Yuan, he was never consulted during the process of drawing up the resolution, while his colleagues claimed that the resolution was passed following party negotiations and represented Taiwan public opinion.
Believing that his rights have been violated, Li is demanding that the court rule that each of his 224 colleagues should pay him NT$1 (about US$0.03) in compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BEEF ALREADY IN TAIWAN SAFE, NO NEED FOR RECALL: HEALTH DEPT.

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 27 (CAN) U.S. beef is safe and there is no need to take it off the market or mark it with a warning, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.

Chen Lu-hung, director of DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks at a news conference following Taiwan's reimposition of a ban on imports of U.S. beef Saturday, one day after a second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, in the United States was confirmed by a British laboratory.

Grilled by media over whether the decision was politically motivated -- the previous ban was just lifted two months ago -- and whether Taiwan has followed strict screening procedures in importing U.S. beef, Chen stressed that the DOH's policy is based on professional considerations, and there has been no political pressure.

He said that mad cow disease is caused by feed containing an abnormal form of a protein called prion, and that the U.S. imposed a ban on such feed in 1997. The World Organization for Animal Health said trade of U.S. boneless beef for cattle 30 months of age or under can be allowed regardless of any other considerations.

Addressing some legislators' concerns that Japan has not reopened its markets to U.S. beef imports, while Taiwan has, Chen said that when Taiwan decided to lift the U.S. beef ban in April, there was a condition; namely, that if a subsequent case surfaced, U.S. beef imports would be immediately suspended. Given this second case, the DOH banned U.S. beef; however, the meat that is currently in Taiwan is safe, he said.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case, the first U.S. case of mad cow disease.
Taiwan lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Plans New Tool to Halt Spread of Weapons.
Administration plans to target assets of anyone tied to Syrian, Iranian and N. Korean firms believed to be involved in missile programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN PALAU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu arrived in Palau Monday for a three-day official visit.
Lu was warmly welcomed by Minister of State Affairs Temmy L. Shumull and Taiwanese expatriates in the Pacific island nation at the Palau international airport.
Soon after her arrival, Lu called on President Tommy Remengesau at his office and presented him with a photo of a remote sensing image of Palau taken by the Taiwan-owned FORMOSAT-2 satellite.
In their 20-minute talks, Lu and Remengesau expressed commitment to boosting friendly relations between Taiwan and Palau. Lu later delivered a speech at the Palau Senate.

Palau, famous for its coral reefs, attracts many tourists from around the world every year. Accompanied by local people, Lu made a sightseeing cruise by boat to a coral reef preservation area and other tourist attractions later in the day.

Referring to Palau's well-developed tourist industry, Lu said as an island surrounded by sea like Palau, Taiwan should make more efforts to promote oceanic tourism on its offshore islets such as Penghu and Green Island.
The main purpose of Lu's visit was to meet with Palauan officials in charge of tourism and with local hoteliers to gain a better understanding of the country for reference for Taiwan tourists.
Palau, the Republic of China's closest diplomatic ally in geographic terms, is a popular destination for Taiwanese tourists.
Lu is also expected to meet with the speakers of the Palauan Senate and House of Representatives during her stay.

She is scheduled to attend a ceremony Tuesday marking the grand opening of the six-story, 160-room Palau Royal Resort Hotel -- the newest and one of the largest five-star hotels in Palau -- which was built by a group of Taiwanese businessmen.
President Chen Shui-bian, who visited Palau in January and promised to return for the opening, asked Lu to make the visit this month on his behalf due to his tight schedule.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY, FREEDOM CORNERSTONES OF TAIWAN-U. S. TIES: DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 26 (CNA) (By Laurence Chu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Democracy and freedom are the cornerstones of Taiwan-U. S. relations, upon which both countries are in the best position to build mutually beneficial ties, Republic of China's top envoy to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Sunday in Los Angeles.

Giving a 30-minute speech at a dinner party with more than 200 local Chinese community representatives, Lee said that Taiwan's democracy and freedom have made the country's existence so important that this cannot be underestimated by the American people, both those friendly to Taiwan and those who are not.
In turn, the lack of democracy and freedom in China is the leading barrier for the Beijing regime in terms of developing ties with the United States.
He noted that U.S. President George W. Bush mentioned democracy and freedom 27 times when giving his second inaugural speech in January this year.

According to the de facto ambassador from Taiwan to the United States, Taiwan- U. S. relations reached a high-point in April 2001. Bilateral links began to improve again this spring after Beijing came up with an Anti-Secession Law in mid-March to contain Taiwan independence, he pointed out.

Taiwan's rational and peaceful response toward the Anti-Secession Law has again brought Taiwan and the United States closer thanks to common ground regarding respective understanding and positions, he said.

Lee said that he strongly believes that his No. 1 priority while serving in the post is to mend and heal mutual trust and forge an unfettered communication channel between the two countries. He added that he was able to exchange views and opinions with U.S. officials very cordially and frankly.
Lee took over the post as Taiwan's top liaison official to the United States last year after President Chen Shui-bian was sworn in for a second term in May last year.
It was Lee's first visit to Los Angeles since assuming the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER WARNS OF ETHNIC ISSUE IN KMT CHAIRMANSHIP RACE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng reiterated Monday his hope for a gentleman's race for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship, saying that the contestants should not play with the sensitive ethnic issue to win support.
Wang made the call at a seminar held at the Taichung City Council with more than 40 scholars while elaborating on his vision of how to lead the KMT if he is elected party chairman.

Pointing out that under the governing Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan is facing four major crises --- financial hollowing-out, economic margionalization, ethnic conflict and insecurity across the Taiwan Strait -- Wang claimed that only a second power transfer can help the country surmount these problems.

However, he went on, the complex and sensitive ethnic issue has been brought into the contest by his sole rival in the race and he called for his competitor to avoid collision for the sake of the KMT's future. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is Wang's only rival in the race for the chairmanship.

Wang also said he is confident of building a new future for the KMT on the grounds that he is the right person to consolidate public support for the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party and use the "pan blue" majority advantage at the Legislative Yuan to help the alliance win back power in the 2008 presidential election.

Wang and Ma, both of whom are KMT vice chairmen, will compete in a showdown to win the party chairmanship through a direct vote among party members set for July 16. Incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan is slated to leave the post in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS POLICY ON U.S. BEEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh defended his administration's policy on U.S. beef Monday, arguing there was nothing wrong with a decision two months ago allowing the import of U.S. beef from cattle younger than 30 months old, although all imports were banned again Saturday.

Answering questions from journalists while on an inspection tour of Orchid Island off the eastern coast of Taiwan, the premier said safety was the only concern behind the government's decision to ban U.S. beef Dec. 31, 2003, when America's first bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) case was confirmed. The ban was lifted conditionally April 16 but reimposed Saturday following confirmation of a second U.S. case.

Hsieh said U.S. cattle raised after 1997 -- when a ban of meat and bone meal in feed went into effect -- are believed to be free from BSE, which is why his administration decided in April to allow imports of U.S. beef from cattle less than 30 months old and why it will allow beef already imported to remain on the market.

Just as locally produced pork is suitable for consumption in Taiwan despite it being banned from the U.S. because of foot-and-mouth disease in Taiwan, U.S. beef is suitable for consumption in the United States despite the occurrence of BSE there, Hsieh argued, claiming that all the U.S. beef already in Taiwan is safe.

The premier said banning imports of U.S. beef is the easiest way out, but the government has to take into consideration the interests of local businessmen who sell U.S. beef and Washington's possible reactions, the premier said.

He dismissed as groundless critics' claims that he is trying to play up to Washington, arguing that there is no point for him to curry favor with a country that will not even allow him to set foot on its territory.

In a related development Monday, four opposition lawmakers from the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union logged a charge of "manslaughter" with the prosecutors' office against Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou, claiming that Hou's office is risking the lives of the public by "zigzagging" on policy concerning U.S. beef.

The four lawmakers, led by Legislator Lai Hsin-yuan noted in their complaint that Hou's office lifted the ban April 16 and that a health official claimed at that time that U.S. beef was safe. "If that were true, why was the ban reinstated on Saturday?" they asked.

"If the beef is dangerous and should be banned, why allow meat already in the country to remain on the market without being recalled? There is no explanation other than an unspecified intent to kill people," they claimed in their complaint, urging the prosecutor to initiate a probe.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY TO IMPROVE IN SECOND HALF OF YEAR: CEPD

TEXT.P: A yellow-blue light was recorded for Taiwan's economy in May, meaning that the economy was "sluggish, " although it will rebound in the second half of this year, an official of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) predicted Wednesday.

According to the five-color rating system devised by the CEPD to gauge Taiwan's economy, red means an overheated economy, yellow-red represents a heating-up economy, green reflects stability, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue points to recession.
Hung Juei-ping, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said the composite economic index in May dropped to 18 points, setting a new low since June 2003.

But he pointed out that the leading index climbed 0.8 percent in May from April, the bigger recent single-month increase. In addition, the economy of the high-tech industry has rebounded, which will be favorable to the economy in the next half of the year, he said.

Of the nine items to gauge the economy in May, stock prices and new manufacturing orders added one point each, while the money supply MIb, exports, industrial production and non-agricultural employment were cut by one point each, making the composite economic index drop from the 20 points in April.
The continued slip was due mainly to sluggish industrial production. The third consecutive month of a yellow-blue light also showed that the domestic economy was still not in good shape.

The resurgence of domestic energy prices has added uncertainty to the economic prospects, but the domestic leading index has begun to climb and the number of manufacturers who think the economy in the next three months will decline has dropped to 17 percent, with a gradual rebound of the high-tech industry, creating a favorable forecast for the economy in the second half of the year, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE IMMIGRANTS TO BE FINGERPRINTED SOON: MAC

TEXT.P: Chinese citizens who come to Taiwan for family reunions, long-term stays and settlement will be required to be fingerprinted in the near future, a senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.
MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has drawn up a comprehensive package of regulations for taking the fingerprints of such Chinese citizens.

The fingerprinting requirement will be implemented in line with a new article added to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which has been approved by the Legislative Yuan, Liu said.

In addition to drafting detailed enforcement rules, Liu said, the MOI has also already purchased the equipment needed to implement the new requirement and facilities will be in place for use by mid-July.
With Taiwan opening its doors ever wider to people from China, Liu said, the number of Chinese people using false identity papers has become an increasingly serious problem for the authorities.

"Many mainland citizens have visited Taiwan several times, using a different identity each time. As the situation has become worse and worse, administrative agencies have had to spend a lot of administrative resources verifying the identity of prospective visitors," Liu said, adding that the false identity issue is expected to be minimized after the fingerprinting regulations come into force.

The new enforcement rules, crafted by the Exit and Entry Bureau under the MOI's National Police Administration, clearly singles out targets to be subject to fingerprinting, the venue for fingerprinting, the establishment of a fingerprint databank and safeguards of the databank, Liu said.

Noting that the new fingerprinting requirement is part of the measures to substantitate the policy of "proactive liberalization with effective management" toward cross-strait exchanges, Liu said the new measure will facilitate the security management of Chinese immigrants.

As to whether the fingerprinting measure will be expanded to all Chinese visitors, Liu said the MAC -- the nation's top China policy planner -- will call an interministerial meeting in the near future to discuss whether the existing statute should be further revised to fingerprint all incoming citizens from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLID MILITARY FORCE, STRONG WILL KEY TO VICTORY: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: National Defense Minister Lee Jye said Monday that a solid military force and strong will to fight are key to victory.
Lee made the remarks during a pep-speech to graduating cadets of five military academies at Fu Hsing Kang College in Taipei.

He said the military has in recent years dedicated itself to the buildup of a modern military force. It has continued to streamline military personnel, hoping to build a solid force with strong combat ability.

Faced with the military threat of China, Lee urged the nation not to hinge its hopes on the goodwill of the enemy and not to rely on assistance from the international community, but to rely on the country's own strength.
He also urged the cadets to accept challenges and understand that a crisis can also be a turning point so that they can move with the times and form the backbone of a modern force.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PROFESSIONALS URGED TO ABIDE BY RULES DURING TAIWAN VISITS

TEXT.P: A total of 110 visiting Chinese professionals have been repatriated in the past three months for engaging in activities incompatible with the stated purposes of their visits, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.
"We feel regret that the visiting professionals have failed to faithfully abide by our regulations, " MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said.

With the number of visiting Chinese professionals who have engaged in such activities increasing steadily, Liu said, the government has demanded their local hosts assume more responsibility in identity verification, swift reporting of major events involving visiting Chinese professionals, and spot checks.

Besides repatriating rule-breaking Chinese visitors, Liu said their local hosts will also be fined and disciplined in accordance with the law for the sake of maintaining orderly exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Earlier this month, Liu went on, a delegation from a temple dedicated to the Chinese Goddess of the Sea in Meizhou in the southeastern Chinese Province of Fujian was repatriated because it changed its itinerary to engage in a "united front" publicity campaign.

In May, an electronic trade delegation from Guangdong Province came to Taiwan in the name of visiting the annual Taipei computer trade fair. However, the delegation exhibited their own products at the show without permission. All delegation members were repatriated for violating the rules, Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CONVEYS PRESIDENT'S GREETINGS TO PALAU PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, who arrived here Monday, conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's greetings to Palau people at a dinner hosted by Palau President Tommy Remengesau, Jr.
Lu also told her host that Chen felt sorry at not being able to accept Remengesau's invitation to attend the inauguration of the Hotel Royal in Palau, which was financed by Taiwan businessmen.

Remengesau invited Chen to preside at the opening of the hotel slated for Tuesday when Chen toured the island state in January, but Chen's busy schedule precluded him from making the trip and he sent Lu on his behalf.

Speaking at the dinner, Lu boasted that ties between the two countries have become closer and closer, with Taiwan's president and vice president visiting Koror within six months and Taiwan tourists accounting for 50 percent of the 90,000 visitors that descend on the island state every year.
She also praised Remengesau for his leadership.
Lu is expected to return to Taiwan Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: U.S. ASSESSMENT OF CHINA'S THREAT MAY NOT BE ACCURATE

TEXT.P: An assessment by U.S. defense and intelligence officials that China might attack Taiwan in two years is not accurate because it does not take into consideration the recent lowering of tension across the Taiwan Strait, a China expert said Monday.

Commenting on a Washington Times report that Pentagon officials fear that Beijing "will attack Taiwan in the next two years, " Chang Jung-kung, spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang, noted that the analysis was made purely from a military point of view.

The Washington Times report Sunday said China is building its military forces faster than U.S. intelligence and military analysts expected, which has prompted fears that Beijing will attack Taiwan in two years and then be forced to go to war with the United States, which has vowed to defend Taiwan against a Chinese attack.

Chang noted that the Pentagon assessment does not take into consideration what he claimed is the latest development that the relationship between Taiwan and China has entered a new phase since KMT Chairman Lien Chan's journey of peace to China in late April and early May.

"As long as President Chen Shui-bian does not push for de jure independence of Taiwan during the rest of his term, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be out of the shadow of war until the next presidential election in March 2008," he said.

Chang quoted various Chinese think tanks as claiming that Lien's visit to China has "defused" the crisis of war in the Taiwan Strait. In his view, the assumption that China might attack Taiwan in two years will not happen, unless Chen uses a second stage of constitutional reforms to seek de jure independence.

He pointed out that after Lien's visit to China, Beijing's policy toward Taiwan began to stress cross-strait exchanges once again. This, he said, has reduced the pressure faced by Taiwan from China's military buildup.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC TO BE IN CHARGE OF REDRAWING CONSTITUENCY BORDERS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will form a screening committee to redraw the country's constituency borders, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.

DPP whips William Lai and Jao Yung-ching made the remarks after CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung reported on the timetable for redrawing constituency lines at a coordination meeting of government and DPP officials at the Executive Yuan.
CEC officials said the redrawing of the borders should be promulgated one year before the term of the incumbent legislators expires, which means it should be announced by Jan. 31, 2007 at the latest.

According to the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, the redrawing will be decided by the CEC and the CEC will form a screening committee on the issue, taking into consideration views provided by local election commissions.
Jao said that the CEC is responsible for the task and that credible figures recommended by the public will be asked to sit on the screening committee.

The Legislative Yuan should not form a screening committee with its members formed in proportion of the ratio of each political party, because it would lead to a political struggle and "gerrymandering," Jao continued.

Chen Chin-chun, another DPP whip, said the redistricting of constituencies does not require prior approval from the Legislative Yuan and he added that legislative power must not supersede executive power.
Chen said the CEC should listen to public views on the matter and redraw the boundaries based on the principles of population, structure, region and culture.

On an opposition Kuomintang proposal that the redistricting of the constituencies should need the approval of the Legislative Yuan, Chen said that such a political struggle would render the electoral reform of "single seat, two votes" meaningless.

The National Assembly passed early this month a constitutional amendment package, one of the major items of which was to change the electoral system from multiple seats in a constituency into the "single seat, two votes" system.

Starting from the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, the Legislative Yuan will have only 113 seats and will be elected every four years. While 73 seats will be elected from regional districts, there will be six seats for aboriginal representatives and 34 seats for at-large and overseas expatriate representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERY ADMINISTRATION PROTESTS JAPANESE COAST GUARD DISTURBANCE

TEXT.P: The Fishery Administration has demanded that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) lodge a protest with Japan over Japanese coast guard ships that interfered with the operations of a Taiwan fishing boat the previous day, an official said Monday.

The official was referring to the Chinjuifeng No. 168 -- a Suao-based fishing boat that was served a notice by Japanese coast guard ships while operating in waters close to the middle line of the two countries' overlapping exclusive economic zones, also known locally as the "tentative demarcation line," on Sunday.

The Japanese coast guard demanded that the Chinjuifeng leave the waters, which lie some 60 nautical miles east of the Tiaoyutai Islands -- a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China.
The Fishery Administration official said the Japanese move was unacceptable because the Chinjuifeng did not cross the "tentative demarcation line."

"Acting on the Chinjuifeng's emergency request for help, we immediately asked the Coast Guard Administration to send patrol ships to the waters in question to protect our fishermen's legitimate fishing rights and safety," the official said.
Three Taiwan coast guard patrol vessels swiftly went to the disputed region to ensure the Chinjuifa's safety and smooth operations, the official said.
In addition, he said, the Fishery Administration has demanded that the MOFA convey its protest over the Japanese coast guard's disturbance of the Taiwan fishing boat's operations.

In the future, the official said, local fishermen should use fishery radio stations or the CGA's 118 hotline to inform relevant government agencies whenever they are disturbed by Japanese coast guard patrol ships while operating within Taiwan's exclusive economic waters.
"We are determined to make every possible effort to protect our fishermen's rights and safety," he added.

The incident came after the Ministry of National Defense, under strong pressure from opposition lawmakers, sent a Knox-class frigate on a visit to the disputed waters last Tuesday, supposedly to accentuate Taiwan's determination to protect its fishermen's rights and safety. Some 15 lawmakers from across the party spectrum, led by Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, took the cruise aboard the warship in the company of Defense Minister Lee Jye.

At the heart of the dispute is the two countries' sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutai Islands. Both Tokyo and Taipei claim that the island group falls within their 200-mile exclusive economic zones. Japan often fines ship owners and impounds Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter waters close to the Tiaoyutais.
The previous 14 rounds of Taiwan-Japanese fishery talks did not make significant headway because Taiwan would not forsake its sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutais, which Japan has held since 1971.

The dispute came into the limelight again recently after some 50 Taiwan fishing boats staged a rare protest in the disputed waters over Japanese coast guard ships that frequently chase them away from the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: 66% OF TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS SEE BUSINESS CLIMATE EVEN IN 3 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Two-thirds of Taiwan manufacturers see the country's business climate even in the coming three months, according to the results of a survey released Monday by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The survey, conducted in May, shows that 66 percent of the respondents believe the business climate will remain unchanged in the next three months, while 17 percent predict it will be improved and another 17 percent have a negative outlook.

The manufacturing sector's sales decreased in May by 2.9 percent from the previous month's level and by 1.2 percent year-on-year, while new orders received by the manufacturers fell by 2.3 percent from the April but rose by 2.6 percent from the previous year's level.
The utilization ratio of installed facilities stood in May at the same mark of 79.8 percent posted in the previous month and 0.5 percentage points less than the figure recorded a year ago.

At the same time, the profit earned from their sales was at an average of 4.9 percent, down 0.1 percentage points from the previous month's level and 0.3 percentage points less than that of the last year.
The CEPD rated Taiwan's economy in May with a yellow-blue light, meaning that the economy was sluggish.

According to the five-color rating system devised by the CEPD to gauge Taiwan's economy, red means an overheated economy, yellow-red represents a heating-up economy, green reflects stability, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue points to recession.
However, the leading index climbed 0.8 percent in May, a sign that the economy will rebound in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SKELETON FLOOD-CONTROL PLAN APPROVED BY GOVERNMENT PLANNER

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), a government planning agency, approved Monday a skeleton program drawn up by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to prevent flooding.
The program, brought up by the MOEA earlier this year, will spend NT$80 billion (US$25.51 billion) over eight years to fix flood problems that have plagued central and southern Taiwan.

The program is all the more urgent when more than 500 square kilometers of land was inundated early this month after days of torrential rain. Specialists blamed ground subsidence caused by over-pumping of groundwater from aquifers for the disaster.
In approving the program, the CEPD noted that the country suffers damage of NT$12.8 billion on average every year from flooding triggered by typhoons and heavy rain.
It noted that nine typhoons hit Taiwan in 2004 and one of them, Mindulle, which barrelled across the country from June 28 to July 3, inundated 659 square kilometers of land.
In order to reduce the damage caused by floods, the CEPD said the flood-control program should focus on the areas hardest-hit.
The program approved by the CEPD is only a skeleton and still has to be fleshed out by specific plans put forth by local governments and approved by the MOEA.
After being approved by the CEPD, the program will be presented to the Cabinet for a final decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENDORSES PREMIER'S DECISION ON BEEF BAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stepped into the controversy surrounding the Executive Yuan's decision to ban U.S. beef Monday, saying the administration did not contradict itself by dropping a ban on imports and reinstating it Saturday.

In an interview with a local TV station, the president said his administration reinstated the ban not because of the danger of U.S. beef after the confirmation of the second mad cow disease in the United States, but because the original ban was withdrawn on the condition that there should be no more mad cow disease cases in the American cattle population.

He said he has directed Premier Frank Hsieh to do whatever it takes to ensure that the economy will grow by 4 percent this year despite the slowdown of the international economy and he urged the public to be confident in Taiwan's economy, promising that the stock market will boom.
As to the possibility of a meeting between himself and Chinese President Hu Jintao, Chen said it would have to take place in a third country and without any conditions other than his one.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 28, or the 22nd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1776: British forces are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: A peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the victorious allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Treat of Versailles because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against the Chinese communists.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from Cominform at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the U.S. government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the ROC Navy and Air Force.
1950: Gen. Douglas McArthur, commander of the Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of the 17-year-old soccer player Pele, whose real name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.
1970: U.S. troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1976: Fifty-one American scholars, researchers, teachers and students arrive in Taipei for a five-week Seminar on China Studies.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives H.A.E. Scheels, permanent honorary vice president of the International Badminton Federation.
1977: Ma Chi-chuang, board chairman of the China Steel Corp., puts a torch to the blast furnace of the company's new Kaohsiung steel plant to signify the start of steel making at the plant.
1979: The ROC government approves two new appointments proposed by the Kuomintang's Central Committee, naming H.K. Yang, political vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Africa, and Ding Mou-shih, administrative vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Korea.
1981: To promote cultural communication and economic relations, the Sino-Nigerian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus becomes the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
1999: The 1999 International Seminar on the Protection of Clean Coasts opens in Kaohsiung with more than 100 experts from home and abroad attending.
2000: Just as scientists from around the world have finished the first big step toward mapping the human genome, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces that Taiwan will establish its own genetic research center within one year.
2001: The National Policy Foundation, an opposition Kuomintang think tank, unveils new policy guidelines featuring a "confederation" with Beijing and a "double economic triangle" covering Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention -- that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER MAKES LOW-PROFILE STOPOVER IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 27 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen is scheduled to depart New York Monday night following a one-day stopover in the city during his U.S. visit, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York reported.

The ROC mission in New York said that Tan has not met with any U.S. officials during his low-profile visit to the city. The mission also did not confirm whether the minister has met with any officials from U.S. think tanks.

Amid media reports that Chen could visit Central or South America or Europe after winding up his U.S. trip, the mission only said that it is unaware of the reports, declining to elaborate on where Tan will head to next.

Chen attended the 2005 World Forum in Colorado June 23-24. ROC Representative to the U.S. David Ta-wei Lee and several leading Taiwan entrepreneurs, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Chairman Morris Chang and the Far Eastern Group Chairman Douglas Hsu, also attended.

The World Forum is an annual conference of government officials, legislators, business and financial leaders and academics that is sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based think tank.
Before the World Forum, Chen delivered a speech on Taiwan's progress in human rights protection and democratic reforms at a seminar organized by the World Affairs Council in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-TECH INDUSTRIES INCREASINGLY SHIFTING TO CHINA: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said late Monday that Taiwan high-technology industries have increasingly tilted to China, making it imperative for the administration to exert tighter controls for national security as well as for the industries' own survival.
In an interview with a local TV station, Chen noted that relaxing the policy on cross-strait exchanges can only be done when there is an effective management mechanism in place.

Noting that even liberal governments like that of the United States maintain controls on high-technology exports, Chen said that it is "right and necessary" for the government to impose some controls on China-bound Taiwan companies, particularly those in the high-tech industry.

Chen expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will pass a science and technology protection bill as soon as possible so that there will be "clear rules of the game" in place for the business sector to follow and for the administration to enforce.

Stressing that China is not "any foreign country, " particularly to Taiwan, Chen said that investing in China "is not simply a matter of mutual benefit." While the government should do its part to maintain Taiwan industries' international competitiveness and national security, all the Taiwan companies maintaining business operations in China should "keep the political risks in mind, " he added.

Taking Chi Mei Optoelectronics as an example, Chen said that when the company first entered China, the chairman of the company at the time, Hsu Wen-lung, was given all sorts of special treatment. But after the company settled there, the Chinese communists "changed their face" and "the conveniences enjoyed by the company turned into illegalities," the president said.

Chen said that in 2001, his administration changed the former "no haste, be patient" policy, aimed at reining in Taiwan investment in China, into a new "active opening, effective management" policy in the hopes that Taiwan industries and businesses could "plow deep locally and position themselves globally" in the 21st century.

The president urged the Taiwan businesspeople operating in China to keep their core business base and research and development in Taiwan while making money overseas, noting that China is not "the only or last market in the world." He also reminded them to "send some money back" as few of the China-based Taiwanese companies have repaid their investment funds that were sourced from Taiwan.

New York Times: Justices Allow a Commandments Display, Bar Others.
A fractured Supreme Court on Monday upheld a six-foot-high Ten Commandments monument on the grounds of the Texas Capitol while ruling that framed copies of the Commandments on the walls of two Kentucky courthouses were unconstitutional. The question was whether either display violated the First Amendment's prohibition against an official "establishment" of religion. It appeared to be that religious symbols that have been on display for many years, with little controversy, are likely to be upheld, while newer displays intended to advance a modern religious agenda will be met with suspicion and disfavor from the court.
Wall Street Journal: Breaking Taboos, Japan Redefines Its Role With China.
Relations between Japan and China are at their tensest level in decades. One cause has been Chinese outrage over visits by Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to a religious shrine that commemorates Japan's war dead, including people convicted of war crimes against China and other Allied countries. In Japan, there has been rising anxiety about China's growing economic and political strength. But behind the scenes in Tokyo, another factor has also altered ties between Asia's two biggest powers: the emergence of a new generation of leaders with new notions about Japan's role in the world.
