DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DESIGNATION IN WTO DIRECTORY UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 28 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has successfully retained the designation of its permanent mission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the new WTO Directory which was printed recently,

As WTO Director-General Supachai Panitchpakdi and other officials of the Secretariat of the organization could not resolve a dispute between Taiwan and China on the name of the island's representation to the organization, the world trade body has been unable to revise the contents of the directory since it was issued in October 2002.
In February 2003, Beijing requested a change of the designation of Taiwan's delegation to the WTO and the official titles of its members.

The procrastination of renewing the directory has caused inconvenience in the operations and communications of the WTO and many WTO members have requested the Secretariat of the organization to tackle the matter as soon as possible. Normally, WTO issues the directory twice a year in April and October.

Supachai, who is set to leave office in August this year and does not want to hand over the so-called "hot potato issue" to his successor, eventually decided last week to issue a new WTO directory after thoroughly taking cross-strait and other relevant situations into consideration. In the new edition of the WTO Directory, Taiwan still has the designation " Permanent Mission of the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen, Matsu to the World Trade Organization, " demonstrating that China's attempt to downgrade the name of Taiwan's delegation to the WTO from "permanent mission" to "economic and trade office" or "permanent representative office" was unsuccessful.

Nevertheless, instead of using official diplomatic titles to address the members of the mission as it did before, the WTO only allows the Taiwan officials to use honorifics such as Mr., Mrs. Or Miss in the new WTO Directory. Except for the ROC's permanent representative to the WTO, who has never used "ambassador" as his official diplomatic title, all other members of the Taiwan delegation to the WTO have always been addressed using their respective official titles, including minister, councilor, first secretary, second secretary and third secretary, in the directory.

Although Taiwan was flexible in dealing with the matter, it fiercely opposed the WTO changing the official title of the members of the Taiwan permanent mission. Lin Yi-fu, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, immediately made a written and an oral protest to Supachai after received a copy of the new WTO directory, saying that he cannot accept the new directory and requested that the WTO reprint it.

Noting that he fully understands Taiwan's stance and concern about the matter, the WTO executive head said that he himself and the WTO Secretariat spared no effort over the past two years to make everyone happy.

Section 8 of the new directory contains a note by Supachai emphasizing that the WTO's director-general has the authority and responsibility to prepare and issue the directory and that the directory can only be used between the WTO Secretariat and the WTO members. The note also said that all the information included in the directory is purely for the use of strengthening contact between the delegations of WTO member states and the WTO Secretariat, adding that nothing in the directory will affect any delegation's legal rights or obligations.

According to Article XII of the "Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization, " Supachai also said in his note that "any state or separate customs territory possessing full autonomy in the conduct of its external commercial relations and of the other matters provided for in this agreement and the Multilateral Trade Agreements may accede to this agreement." All the terms used in the article to describe the name provided by a customs territory delegation and the note of the WTO Secretariat bear no "sovereignty meanings."

Part of the contents of Supachai's note were made under the request of Taiwan while some contents of the note were formed to help the WTO Secretariat avoid facing the complicated and sensitive problem of sovereignty.

A source close to the WTO said that since the problem relating to the name of the Taiwan delegation to the WTO and its members' official diplomatic titles are political problems between the two WTO member states, which do not fall within the jurisdiction of the WTO authorities, Supachai and the WTO Secretariat, in order to let the world trade body run smoothly, cannot but assume the responsibility to solve the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU DEMANDS LOW PRICES FOR OIL, WATER AND ELECTRICITY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Tuesday demanded that the government maintain its original policy of low rates for oil, water and electricity even thought public utilities are pushing to raise prices.

Executives of TSU's legislative caucus made the appeal at a meeting where officials from state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC), Taiwan Water Corp., Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), as well as the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) were invited to explain their future policies.

Chang Hung-chiang, deputy general manager of CPC, noted that international oil prices have exceeded US$60 per barrel, but the CPC only increased oil prices for the first time this year in March, resulting in a loss of NT$10 billion so far this year.
Chang admitted that there is price hike pressure for oil, but "prices are decided by the market, " and the CPC has not set any readjustment scale in advance.
Chiang Ching-san, a Taipower executive, said the company has not increased its electricity prices since 1983. On the contrary, it has readjusted downward the prices 11 times, he added.

However, due to the soaring prices for oil and coal in international markets in the last few years, Taipower suffered additional spending of NT$47 billion in 2003, Chang stressed, saying that the company cannot afford more losses.

TSU lawmakers estimated that if all these prices are increased at the same time in the second half of this year, every family will have to spend several thousand NT dollars more each month. They urged the government to supply these basic daily necessities at low prices.
Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the government should keep its promise in previous election campaigns of not increasing water and electricity rates.

Wang made the appeal following the remarks made by Premier Frank Hsieh Monday that the government will not exclude the possibility of increasing electricity rates this fall or winter, and is expected to readjust upward oil prices if its international price exceed US$60 per barrel.

Wang stressed that this was not an opportune time for the government to increase rates for daily necessities as many people are living in poverty, urging the government to keep its promises made in election campaigns.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BEHIND WTO DIRECTORY CHANGES TO TAIWAN: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Monday accused China of plotting to change the titles of the Republic of China's World Trade Organization (WTO) officials in the WTO directory, although China ultimately failed to force Taiwan to give up its "permanent mission" title.
Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said this indicates that China is not interested in having mutually beneficial interactions with Taiwan in the WTO.

In the latest edition of the WTO members' directory, published in June, 2005, the titles of all Taiwan officials except for those of the permanent representative and his deputy, were deleted -- such titles as counselor, first secretary and second secretary no longer appear before the names of Taiwan officials bearing those titles. Only their names and their main lines of business were printed.

Lu said the government has asked its mission in the WTO to lodge a protest with the WTO Secretariat for unilaterally changing the contents of the data presented by the mission and to demand that the directory be reprinted.

He said the WTO Secretariat was under pressure from China, and this incident once again shows that China has been doing all it can to shrink Taiwan's international space, contradicting its own promise to develop good interactive relations with Taiwan.

If the trend continues, he pointed out, mutual trust between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will all but disappear and the possibility of improving bilateral ties will become even slimmer, Lu said.

As a matter of fact, he noted, the WTO directory is not an official document with any legal status; it's but an address book for internal use, and therefore will in no way affect Taiwan's legal rights and privileges in the WTO and in the country where it is located.

Ever since Taiwan became the WTO's 114th member in Jan. 2002, China has tried repeatedly to change the title of Taiwan's mission into something like Hong Kong or Macau's Economic and Trade Office that does not imply sovereignty of a state, according to Lu.
He added that under endless pressure from China, the secretary-general of the WTO has suggested that Taiwan change its title into the Office of the Permanent Representative.

As Taiwan has a solid legal basis for using "permanent mission" as its official title in the WTO as well as support from friendly countries, China's attempts to change that title have not been successful, he said.

Lu urged the WTO Secretariat to remain neutral and not to be threatened by any member into damaging another member's legal rights in the WTO, in accordance with the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization.

By caving in to China and deleting the titles of Taiwan's WTO officials in the directory, the WTO Secretariat has violated its role as a neutral entity and the member-driven principle of the organization, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD CONVENES SYMPOSIUM ON FISHING RIGHTS DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Reacting to a spate of fishing disputes with Japan and ensuing controversies surrounding the sovereignty issue over the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, the Ocean Business Research Committee, an Executive Yuan ad hoc group, sponsored a symposium on the situation of Taiwan's ocean waters and government policies Tuesday.

The symposium, presided over by Coast Guard Administration Minister Shi Hwei-yow, focused its discussions on three areas, namely the situation of Taiwan's waters and strategies on related developments; the Chunxiao oil field and the Tiaoyutai Islands disputes; and the Nansha (Spratlys) Islands issue and the situation of the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands.
Participants of the symposium included officials from the Ministry of the Interior, international law specialists, academics, legislators and government security advisers.
It is hoped that opinions will be sought and national consensus reached during the symposium. The 15th round of fishery talks between Taiwan and Japan will take place July 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS OPT FOR STERN ATTITUDE OVER FISHING DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Taiwan will have to get tough with Japanese fishermen intruding on the Republic of China's economic zone to protect its own fishermen, authorities from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Tuesday.

Speaking at a symposium titled: The Situation of Taiwan's Peripheral Seas and Relevant Policies, sponsored by the Ocean Business Research Committee, Chang Yuan-hsu, director of the MOI Department of Land Administration, said that the central government is resolutely determined to address Taiwan's fishing disputes with Japan even though it is a thorny issue.

On the prospects of the forthcoming 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks, which is expected mainly to tackle the problems of overlapped exclusive economic zones, Chang said that Japan is not expected to yield much or make its position known in the meeting for fear of agitating China, under whose "one China" policy, Taiwan is part of China.
Chang continued to say that even if Taiwan-related affairs are brought to the negotiating table, the Taiwan negotiating team is at a disadvantage due to the country's attenuated diplomatic status.
However, Chang said that if Japanese fishermen experienced the same miserable treatment that has been suffered by Taiwan fishermen, Japan would have a different attitude at the fishery talks.

Chang said Taiwan taking tougher measures against Japanese fishing boats, such as impounding their vessels and fining the boat owners, for trespassing on Taiwan's exclusive economic zone, may be a viable strategy for Taiwan not to lose too much ground at the forthcoming meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER VOWS TO PROMOTE INTERNATIONAL JUDICIAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Tuesday local prosecutors should enhance exchanges with their foreign counterparts to help deepen Taiwan's judicial assistance and cooperation with other countries.
Shih made the call in a keynote speech delivered at the opening a seminar on international judicial assistance in criminal investigations.

Noting that Taiwan has forged various kinds of judicial aid mechanisms with the United States, Canada, Singapore, Thailand, Australia and Malaysia, Shih said local prosecutors should take even more active steps in developing contacts and exchanges with their counterparts in major countries around the world to help upgrade Taiwan's profile in the international judicial community.
"If we can forge judicial aid agreements with more countries with which we do not have diplomatic ties, it will contribute to our diplomatic work," Shih said.

Meanwhile, Shih said, Taiwan should continue judicial reform to live up to public expectations of judicial functions. In his view, he said, the role of prosecutors should be diversified and prosecutors should play a more active role in criminal indictment, crime prevention and legal education.

The seminar, with a theme of "Taiwan as a member of the global society, " was organized by major local prosecutors associations with an aim of forging judicial aid channels with countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Scores of prosecutors and other judicial personnel from the Netherlands, Britain, Thailand, Japan and South Korea have traveled to Taipei to attend the seminar to offer counseling on steps to promote international judicial aid based on their respective countries' experiences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU'S DECISION TO HAVE CONTACTS WITH CHINA DRAWS MIXED REACTION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday would not make comment after its ally, the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) announced that it will adopt a pragmatic approach on cross-strait issues and start to have exchanges with China, but the opposition parties expressed welcome to such a move.

The legislative caucus of the TSU said Tuesday that private exchanges between Taiwan and China are indeed frequent, and the time to review the "no haste, be patient" policy, which was initiated by former President Lee Teng-hui in 1996, has come.
"To let China know the true voice of Taiwan's private sector, the TSU will not be absent from cross-strait exchanges that will enhance bilateral understanding," the TSU legislative caucus said.

Ho Ming-hao, TSU whip in the legislature, said that Lee Hsien-nian, director of TSU's Policy Committee, broached the new pragmatic approach in a party central executive committee meeting Monday, which was received positively by a majority of members of the central executive committee although the party will still solicit views from all quarters.
"Former President Lee didn't have prior knowledge of the matter," Ho said. Lee is the spiritual leader of the four-year-old party.

Ho said that the TSU's stance that cross-strait exchanges should be based on a state-to-state basis and on equal footing, that direct cargo cross-strait transportation links should come first before those of personnel exchanges, and that direct cross-strait air links should be considered as international flights remains unchanged.

"But if the TSU consistently refuses to have dialogues with China, the latter will have no way of understanding the real needs of the Taiwan people, " he said, and this is why the party's central executive committee has decided to make contact with China.

He said that the TSU will actively participate in a cross-strait peace committee initiated by President Chen Shui-bian, which he said will enhance cross-strait understanding so that "the local Taiwan people will have a say" in cross-strait issues.
A DPP spokesman said that it will have no comment on the adjustment of the TSU's attitude regarding contact with China.

Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, noted that the DPP central standing committee passed aresolution on political parties visiting China in April to the effect that Taiwan, as a pluralistic and democratic society, political parties might have different views on cross-strait development, but they will safeguard Taiwan's democracy, sovereignty, and express Taiwan's free will to choose and its determination to pursue peace.

He said that the development of cross-strait relations will be a long, winding road, and that the recent visits to China by two major opposition leaders -- Chairman Lien Chan of the Kuomintang and Chairman James Soong of the People First Party -- had tilted too much toward China, which he said has somewhat distorted Taiwan's image.

Chen Chin-chun, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said the TSU's announcement caught the DPP by surprise, and the party urged the TSU to explain clearly its U-turn as the TSU has consistently exhorted that one must not think of the enemy as the "motherland."
However, both the KMT and the PFP welcomed the TSU's attitude shift.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said that Lien suggested cross-strait party-to-party exchanges five years ago, and that the KMT is happy to see that the DPP and the TSU have begun to toe the KMT's line on cross-strait issues.

Chang also said that the first step for the TSU to have exchanges with China is for the party to forego its Taiwan-independence advocacy, saying that party-to-party exchanges will be based on goodwill, and if the party continues to advocate Taiwan independence and the nation's official name rectification as well as writing a new constitution, he couldn't see any basis for bilateral exchanges.

Chen Chih-ping, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that TSU's pragmatic approach in attempting to visit Hong Kong, and taking part in a cross-strait peace committee will help reduce Taiwan independence sentiments and cross-strait animosity.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER CONDEMNS CHINA OVER CHANGES TO TAIWAN'S WTO INFORMATION

TEXT.P: A senior ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker condemned China Tuesday over what he called Beijing's extreme oppression of Taiwan for pressuring the World Trade Organization (WTO) to change the island's information in its new directory.
Under pressure from China, Taiwan's officials to the WTO are being addressed as "Mr." and "Miss" instead of their official titles in the WTO directory renewed last week.
Chen Chin-jun, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said China is being two-faced by welcoming Taiwan farm exports on the one hand and isolating Taiwan internationally on the other.

However, Chen Chih-pin, convener of the opposition People First Party legislative caucus, said the government should examine the way it deals with the matter because it failed to take any precautions beforehand or any countermeasures afterwards.

Sharing a similar view, Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lai Hsin-yuan said the matter shows that the country's permanent mission to the WTO has failed to fulfill its duty to defend Taiwan's sovereignty.
Lai demanded that the WTO mission fight for Taiwan's right and ask the WTO Secretariat to restore the titles of the Taiwan officials.
Lai pointed out that the titles of the officials have been recognized by the Swiss government and that the WTO Secretariat has no right to change the information provided by its member nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PRC PRESIDENT MEETING IN THIRD COUNTRY UNLIKELY: BEIJING SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 28 (CNA) (By Chiao Hsin-hua and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he is willing to meet with his Chinese counterpart Hu Jintao in a third country, but while Beijing has not yet made any official response, a Beijing scholar claimed Tuesday that such a meeting is unlikely.

Chen told a TV station in Taipei that he is ready to meet with Hu in a third country provided there are no additional prior conditions attached, including the "one-China" principle and the so-called 1992 consensus on a tacit agreement that there is one China and that either side of the Taiwan Strait can make its own interpretation of what "one China" means.
Chen explained that the reason why his proposed meeting with Hu should be in a third country is that he would refuse to go to China, while Hu is also unlikely to come to Taiwan.
Xu Bodong, director of the Taiwan Research Institute at Beijing University, said that a meeting between Hu and Chen in a third country would signify a meeting between two chiefs of state.
He said Beijing cannot possibly give up its "one-China" policy, which he said is Beijing's "bottom line."
Xu noted that the one-China principle was not something imposed by Beijing upon Taiwan, because the ROC Constitution is based on the one-China framework.
In China, scholars of important think tanks usually simply parrot the official line of the government in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES LEGISLATURE TO SUPPORT FLOOD CONTROL BUDGET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the Legislative Yuan Tuesday to review as soon as possible an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control budget.
Chen made the appeal at a meeting with group chiefs of irrigation associations around Taiwan.
Citing as an example the flood control project for the Keelung River, Chen said the NT$31.6 billion inundation-prevention plan faced strong opposition at that time.
However, those opposing the project have been proved wrong, as the Keelung River flood-control program has resolved the inundation problem in the areas around the river, Chen noted.

Due to the heavy losses caused by recent flooding in central and southern Taiwan, the Cabinet has decided to allocate NT$80 billion to resolve the inundation problems in these areas within eight years, a task that was originally estimated to take 80 years.
Chen urged the legislature to "do the right thing no matter how much it costs, " and solicited public support for the project.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITIZENS WORRY SUICIDE REPORTS COULD BRING IMITATIONS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A survey has found that the public mostly thinks media reports on suicide cases will fan a suicide epidemic and imitations, and hopes the media carries such reports with restraint.

The survey was conducted by associate professor Lyu Shu-yu of the Department of Public Health of Taipei Medical University and the TVBS poll center in May under the commission of the Department of Health.

Lyu said on Tuesday that 93.5 percent of the respondents believed the media has dealt with cases suicide in a manner of repetition and overload, while 67 percent said the way that media reported news concerning suicides was very sensational and detailed.

Citing examples of the suicides of actor Leslie Cheung and comedian Ni Min-jan, the researcher said that media conspicuously and graphically exposed how they took their own lives, then beautified and glorified the apparent reasons.
In comparison, information on suicide control and prevention appears poor, she noted.
The survey also showed that 59.8 percent of the people answering the poll expressed their concern that media reports on suicide cases could encourage copycat deaths.

About 20 percent of the respondents said they were often stricken by panic or with psychological pressure after reading, watching or hearing reports on someone's suicide, while the number of those polled who indicated suicide news could prevent similar tragedies from happening registered only less than 1 percent.

In general, Lyu said over 90 percent of the respondents believed media should not conduct live reports concerning a suicide, while 87 percent thought the media coverage of a suicide should be reduced.
Television footage the audience does not like to see is the body of the dead person and how the suicide happened, she noted.

Lyu said that in a two-week period right after Ni hanged himself in late April, she and other researchers visited four hospitals, finding that at three of the medical facilities, the number of attempted suicide patients had doubled during the period.

One of the three hospitals even told them that in the first two weeks of May, when countrywide media was crazy about reporting Ni's suicide, the number of attempted suicide patients sent to their emergency rooms was about the same as the number of such patients admitted in the hospital from January to April, she indicated.

Professor Chang Chin-hua of National Taiwan University said that since the media craze about Ni's hanging hit the screens, statistics have been rising daily about the number of people killing themselves. She suspected that the media might have become a "murderer."

To prevent the media from turning into a "murderer," Lyu advised three "noes" regarding suicide reportage, including no front page coverage, no repeating and overloading reports, and no live reports or sensational photos.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT, PALAU PRESIDENT PRESIDE OVER OPENING OF HOTEL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu and Palauan President Tommy Remengesau jointly presided Tuesday over the opening of the Palau Royal Resort Hotel, built with funding from Taiwanese businessmen.
Lu said at the opening that Taiwan-Palau relations will be even more solid because of the close cooperation between President Chen Shui-bian and Remengesau.
Remengesau said the opening of the hotel represents closer relations between the two countries and that Lu's visit to his country is an indication of that close friendship.

The Royal Resort, a six-story, 158-room hotel, is the newest and one of the largest five-star hotels in Palau, an island nation with rich ocean tourism resources that is a popular destination for tourists, particularly Taiwanese.
Of the more-than 90,000 tourists who visited Palau last year, Taiwan tourists accounted for more than 40,000.

Lu suggested to the Far East Air Transport Corp., which operates a direct Taiwan-Palau route, that it should arrange Friday flights to Palau and Sunday return flights so as to attract more Taiwan tourists.

In the evening, Lu attended a banquet that was also attended by Palau dignitaries and members of her Taiwan delegation, including James Huang, vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office and Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Ouyang Jui-hsiung.
Remengesau recently renewed an invitation to Chen to make a visit to his country.
Chen, who visited Palau in January, asked Lu to make the visit to Palau this month on his behalf due to his tight schedule and Lu departed Monday for a three-day official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO HOLD CROSS-STRAIT CRISIS SEMINAR EXERCISE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will hold a cross-Taiwan Strait crisis seminar and exercise July 8 in Taipei, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang announced Tuesday.
Lee said 90 post-graduate students will take part in the three-day event, which he claimed will be "more exciting than the movie Thirteen Days," about the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.

According to Lee, the exercise will be aimed at enhancing the knowledge of local students in cross-strait relations and national security and training personnel dealing with cross-strait affairs through the crisis management simulation.

Lee said there will never be lasting peace across the strait if cross-strait relations are not normalized, because a bad neighbor that refuses to renounce the use of force is living next door to Taiwan.

Tung Li-wen, head of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, said the participants will be divided into three groups representing policy-makers of Taiwan, China and the United States in the exercise, with the scenario set in 2010.
The students in politics, diplomacy and international relations, who include several foreign students studying in Taiwan, are from 29 universities nationwide, DPP officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HOPEFULS FOR CHAIRMANSHIP WARNED AGAINST PLAYING PFP CARD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) hopefuls for the party chairmanship should refrain from playing People First Party (PFP) card in their campaign, a PFP official warned Tuesday.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP Policy Center, said it would be inappropriate for either of the KMT candidates to separate PFP authorities from the PFP rank-and-file in an attempt to boost their campaigns.

Chang said his party wishes luck to both Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- the two candidates in the race -- but said the PFP will not show preference for either candidate.

Although Chang did not mention any names, his comment was believed to refer to Ma, who was quoted in Tuesday's United Daily News as saying that while PFP Chairman James Soong might be on better terms with Wang than with him, many of the PFP rank and file -- who he said are the ones who really matter in any elections -- favor him.

Ma made the remarks after being asked to comment on speculation carried in the China Times the previous day that Soong and PFP lawmakers are helping Wang in the race "secretly," in the belief that Wang will allow them to save face by letting them incorporate into the KMT "with dignity."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHILIN PRESIDENTIAL RESIDENCE MADE NATIONAL HISTORIC MONUMENT

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government is preparing to take over the management of the Chiang Kai-shek Shilin Residence from the Presidential Office after it was raised to the level of a state-designated historic site, Department of Cultural Affairs officials said Tuesday.
The presidential residence has already been listed as a city-designated historic monument and has being partly opened to the public.

Under the city's management, the old presidential residence, along with cultural and historical relics concerning the late President Chiang and his wife, will be entirely opened to the public, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY ACADEMY ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: The Intellectual Property Academy (IPC) established by the Ministry of Economic Affairs began operations Tuesday with the aim of cultivating 1,000 professionals annually to help corporations create, protect and use the fruits of intellectual property.

The academy began operations after a plaque-unveiling ceremony at the academy's office on the National Taiwan University campus. The ceremony was presided over by Tsai Lien-sheng, director-general of the MOEA's Intellectual Property Office and NTU President Lee Szu-tsen.
Tsai noted that Taiwan spent US$13.4 billion in high-tech research in 2003, accounting for 2.46 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP), the ninth-highest level in the world.
Taiwan saw 72,000 patent applications filed last year, with the number of patents approved in the United States ranked third in that country, according to Tsai.

The academy will establish strategic alliances with various universities around the country and will coordinate the efforts of NTU and domestic enterprises to promote the cultivation of intellectual property experts, a MOEA official said.

The IPC will also nurture patent agents and judges and will strengthen intellectual property knowledge to allow the judicial authorities to create an environment favorable to intellectual property rights protection, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA LIFTS PHUKET TRAVEL ALERT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) lifted an "orange" travel alert on the Thai resort island of Phuket Tuesday as the post-tsunami rehabilitation work there has been completed.
The ministry imposed the orange alert over travel to Phuket after it was hit by tsunamis caused by a devastating earthquake beneath the Indian Ocean last Dec. 26.

According to a report by the Republic of China representative office in Thailand, tourism facilities and traffic networks on Phuket have all been repaired and reconstructed, daily life has returned to normal and social order has stabilized. Moreover, the report said, a large number of American and European tourists are returning to the resort island.
MOFA officials said the United States has lifted its travel advisory against Phuket, while Singapore and Japan never issued a travel alert at all.

After a careful evaluation of the situation, the officials said MOFA decided to lift the travel advisory from Tuesday. Nevertheless, the officials said local citizens should always stay alert while traveling abroad and keep in touch with the nation's overseas missions and their families at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: AD HOC TEAM SHOULD BE SET UP TO NEGOTIATE WITH JAPAN: MOI

TEXT.P: As a fishing dispute between Taiwan and Japan has again become a hot topic, an official suggested Tuesday that the government prepare an ad hoc team to negotiate with Japan to settle the dispute.

Chang Yuan-hsu, director of the Land Administration Department of the Ministry of the Interior, put forward a five-point strategy when he delivered a report on drawing the border of the country's exclusive economic zone (EEZ).

"Some territorial sea issues can be settled simply by making domestic laws, while others must be handled in accordance with international law or precedent, " he told a seminar discussing Taiwan's surrounding waters and related issues.

The first point of his strategy is to legislate more domestic laws, as existing ones are inadequate, including assigning a government agency to take care of law-breaking seamen and ships, and designating another to mete out fines.
He suggested that the government take reference from the U.S. coast guard or Japan's maritime authorities, which have rules for implementing laws.

Secondly, he suggested that the government speed up a survey of the country's territorial waters and then establish an information-exchange platform that will eventually expand into a national databank on the nation's territorial waters.

His third proposal is to beef up sea patrols. He noted that after Taiwan published an EEZ temporary borderline in 2003 -- a move meant to show Japan Taiwan's determination to maintain its EEZ -- both law enforcement officials and fishermen have had a "rule" to follow.
Fourthly, Chang proposed that the government gather comprehensive information on international law and precedent that can be used to help reach a deal with Japan.
Fifth, he said, a competent negotiation team that has legal, geographic, geological, historical, topographic and other experts as members must soon be organized to talk with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER EXPLAINS DRAWING OF PROVISIONAL LEGAL BOUNDARY

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-Chyuan said Tuesday at a seminar on Taiwan's surrounding waters that a provisional legal boundary in the overlapping economic zones of Taiwan and Japan in waters northeast of Taiwan has taken into consideration many factors.

The seminar was held at the Executive Yuan in the wake of a recent protest by about 60 Taiwanese trawlers in waters 80 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan against Japanese coast guard ships that chase them from what they claim are their traditional fishing grounds on many occasions.

The waters near a number of small uninhabited islands known as the Tiaoyutais, which are claimed by Taiwan, Japan and China, are claimed by Taiwan as traditional fishing grounds. However, Japan demarcated the area as part of its 200-mile economic zone in 1996 and has since often impounded Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter the region, fining their owners.

The Ministry of the Interior at the end of 2003 drew a provisional line within the Republic of China's 200-mile exclusive economic zone at the mid-point between the overlapping zones and the government has urged Taiwan fishermen to operate within the provisional line so as to avoid fishery disputes.

Grilled by some scholars as to whether the provisional legal boundary is too timid, Su pointed out that the boundary was not demarcated by his ministry but was drawn after taking into consideration geographic and historical factors, as well as the views of scholars.

He said that drawing the economic zone involves not only demarcation but also sovereignty issues, especially since the Tiaoyutai island group is claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan, and has to be solved through diplomatic procedures.
Taiwan and Japan are scheduled to hold fishery talks next month to discuss issues resulted from their overlapping 200-mile exclusive economic zones.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SAID TO BEGIN BUILDING FIRST AIRCRAFT CARRIER IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: China will begin to build its first aircraft carrier in August at a cost of 30 billion yuan (about US$362 million), according to a report by China's www.Boxun.com.

The report said the carrier, which the web site claims will have a displacement of 78,000 tons, will be built by the Jiangnan Shipyard in Shanghai although this has been denied by Zhan Guangqin, deputy chief of China's Commission of Science Technology and Industry for National Defense.

The unconfirmed report quoted an unnamed engineer at the shipyard as saying that Russian experts will help with the fitting of a steam-turbine propeller that will give the giant vessel a top speed of 32 knots.

It claimed that the carrier will go into service in 2006 at the earliest and that it will take two more years to combine the operations of the vessel with those of jet fighters to form a combative force.
Weapons experts, however, pointed out that it seems "too optimistic" to build an aircraft carrier in just one year and to develop a battle group in three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS CIVIL SERVANTS TO DEFEND GOVERNMENT POLICIES

TEXT.P: Civil servants should defend the government's policies to avoid "public misunderstandings, " Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

Hsieh made the remarks in support of a recent decision by Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao that GIO officials of certain ranks should contribute an article on current affairs to the opinion pages of local newspapers every day. The decision has triggered widespread anger within the GIO.
Hsieh said the decision is mainly aimed at encouraging civil servants to defend the government's policies, which he claimed is often "misunderstood" by the public.
He said contributing articles to the opinion pages should not be considered improper and that the media will still have the right to decide whether they will publish the articles or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL EDUCATION SPENDING OF EACH HOUSEHOLD REACHES NT$47,000

TEXT.P: The average annual spending of each household on education in Taiwan reached NT$47,056 (US$1,498) in 2003, accounting for 5.3 percent of total household income, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The expenditure included tuition and books, which accounted for 58.3 percent of total educational costs, as well as spending on supplementary schools or private tutoring, the statistics show.
The statistics were part of a DGBAS report about higher education received by the population aged between 18 and 23 years.

In 2003, Taiwan's population aged between 18 and 23 years reached 2.14 million. Among them, more than 60 percent received higher education in college or university, in comparison with the 18.4 percent registered in 1976.

If divided by family income into five groups, 45 percent of young people between 18 and 23 in the lowest income groups received advanced education in 2003, while the ratio in the highest income groups reached 69.2 percent, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA CHIEF CALLS FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF OCEAN AFFAIRS MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan should set up an Ocean Affairs Ministry to more efficiently protect its territorial waters and marine resources, the nation's coast guard chief said Tuesday.
Coast Guard Administration Minister Shi Hwei-yow made the remarks while addressing the opening of a symposium on the situation regarding the seas surrounding Taiwan and relevant policies.
Shi pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian clearly outlined an "ocean state" development blueprint when he took over the nation's helm in 2000.
"It is regrettable that the Executive Yuan, while drafting an administration restructuring plan, dropped the proposal of creating an ocean affairs ministry," Shi said.

Given the fact that Taiwan's territorial waters cover a vast expanse of 548,000 square kilometers, Shi said, Taiwan badly needs to set up an ocean affairs ministry to handle issues related to its territorial waters and its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.
In his view, Shi said, the recent fishing dispute with Japan has made more urgent the necessity of creating an ocean affairs ministry to more efficiently deal with relevant affairs.

"At the moment, ocean-related affairs, including fishing disputes, are handled by a number of different government ministries and agencies. None of those agencies give priority to ocean-related affairs and as a result, we have been unable to tackle relevant issues efficiently," Shi said.

In addition to the sovereignty dispute with Japan over the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea, Shi said Taiwan also faces many other ocean-related challenges, including the Chunxiao oil field exploration disputes, the sovereignty dispute over the Nansha (Spratly) Islands and Chinese research ships' frequent encroachment upon waters surrounding the Taiwan-held Tungsha (Pratas) Islands in the South China Sea.

Shi said he hopes the Executive Yuan will reconsider its internal restructuring plan and revive the plan to set up an ocean affairs ministry to facilitate the development of Taiwan into an "ocean state."

The symposium was organized by the Ocean Business Research Committee, an Executive Yuan ad hoc group, with the participation of more than 200 government officials, international law experts, academics and legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PRODDED TO RESPECT U.S. PRESENCE, POWER IN ASIA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 27 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. does not fear China and has no intention of competing against China strategically, but it does hope China will respect America's power and presence in Asia, U.S. Under Secretary of State R. Nicholas Burns said in an interview Saturday with a New Delhi newspaper.

According to the pretext of the interview released by the State Department Monday, Burns told India's Star News that China should understand that the Asia-Pacific region has been secure, balanced and peaceful for the better part of the last 50 years, partly because of the positive influence of the United States and its military deployments in the region.

"There is no question that the great majority of Asian countries want to see a continuation of American power and presence in the region because we are a force for stability and for peace," Burns said.
The United States does compete with China economically, but is otherwise seeking a peaceful relationship, Burns went on.

He shrugged off the question of whether Indian and Japan could be a counterbalance to China, saying that he cannot speak for the Indian government, but adding that the United Sates and India have emerged from a period when they held different views of the world and now they have a greater confluence of interests, which makes it possible for the emergence of a strategic partnership between them.
Burns visited New Delhi to work out the details of a forthcoming visit to Washington by Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO FALLS TO 2.71% IN MAY

TEXT.P: The overdue loan ratio of domestic banks stood at 2.71 percent as of the end of May, down 0.04 percentage points compared with the previous month's level, according to a report released Tuesday by the Financial Supervision Commission (FSC).
FSC officials said the overdue loan ratio is decreasing owing to efforts by domestic banks to dispose of their non-performing loans.
The combined overdue loans of domestic banks amounted to NT$431.2 billion (US$13.73 billion) as of the end of May, which was NT$700 million less than the level at the end of April.
Domestic banks posted a broadly defined overdue loan ratio of 3.64 percent as of the end of May, down 0.03 percentage points from that of the previous month.
Among the 47 domestic banks, 32 registered a broadly defined overdue loan ratio of under 5 percent.
A total of NT$1.42 trillion in non-performing loans was written off during the period between January 1999 and May 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 29 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 29:
09: 00, The Central Standing Committee of the opposition Kuomintang will hold its weekly meeting at the party's Taipei headquarters.
09: 20, Defense Minister Lee Jye will commission a group of generals at the Tri-service Officers' Club in Taipei.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the commission of a group of generals at the Tri-service Officers' Club in Taipei.
10:00, The opposition New Party will unveil the itinerary of its delegation's China tour at the party's Taipei headquarters.
12: 45, Vice President Annette Lu will return from a visit to Palau.
14: 00, The Taiwan-Hong Kong Industrial and Commerce Council will pay a call at the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
16: 20, The Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT SUGGESTS COOPERATION WITH CHINA IN UNDERSEA OIL DRILLING

TEXT.P: The government might authorize the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to cooperate with China in exploring for undersea oil in the East China Sea, providing it does not provoke a dispute over sovereign rights, a CPC official said Tuesday.

In an symposium organized by the Ocean Business Research Committee under the Executive Yuan to discuss the government's strategy in managing the waters around Taiwan, Kung Hsiang-pang, director of the CPC's undersea exploration department, said China is contemplating exploring oil fields west of the median line of the Taiwan Strait, either by itself or in collaboration with foreign oil companies.

In order to ensure its claim to at least a part of any possible oil reserves in this area, Kung suggested that the government should empower CPC -- which has accumulated a lot of experience in undersea exploration -- to cooperate with China in exploring.
Kung said the possibility for Taiwan to cooperate with Japan in exploring oil fields in the East China Sea is slim in light of their conflicting claims of exclusive economic zones.

Noting that Japan has rejected Taiwan's claims by cooperating with China in exploring oil in an area within Taiwan's exclusive economic zone, Kung said Taiwan would compromise its claims if it were to cooperate with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 29, or the 23rd day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thais revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai-shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by the Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1974: The ROC government announces the suspension of diplomatic relations with Venezuela, which recognized the Chinese communist regime.
1974: The 6th National Little League Baseball Tournament ends with the Li Teh team from Kaohsiung City designated to represent the ROC in the Asian playoffs.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship-carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates the new Commissioned and Noncommissioned Statute of the Armed Forces and the new Entertainment Tax Law.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1982: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives Richard Allen, senior counselor for foreign policy to the Republican National Committee of the United States.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law, or Eugenics Bill, after a third reading.
1986: Argentina wins the World Cup soccer title again in Mexico, thanks to Diego Maradona, 25, who was directly or indirectly responsible for all the goals in the championship game.
1992: Mohamed Boudiaf, president of Algeria, is assassinated as he opens a cultural center in Annaba.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
1999: The ROC wins the right to host the annual global Information Technology conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000.
2000: Taiwan-based China Airlines signs an agreement with eight other regional airlines to establish a Pan-Asia Travel Portal website by the end of this year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."
