DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS VISIT GERMANY TO STRENGTHEN EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, June 28 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislator said in Berlin Tuesday that a delegation of Legislative Yuan members has gained fruitful results during its visit to Germany on the strengthening of exchanges between the legislatures of the two countries.

You Ching, president of the Taiwan-Europe Parliamentarians' Exchange Association who is heading the delegation, said while meeting with members of the local media at a press conference that during their stay in the German capital, the members of the delegation have met with leading members of the German ruling and opposition parties and exchanged views with them on cross-Taiwan Strait relations and relations between Taiwan and Germany.
The nine-member delegation also called for members of the German political parties to help Taiwan join international organizations, You said.

During their stay in Germany, the legislators also paid a courtesy visit to Dr. Hermann Otto Solms, vice president of the German National Parliament, to express their gratitude for the resolution passed by the parliament last October requesting that the European Union maintain its ban on arms sales to China.

According to You, Germany is expected to hold general elections in September, and the delegation's current visit is also aimed at collecting the latest information related to the elections and their possible impact on Germany's future foreign policy.

Touching on economic and trade relations between the two countries, DPP Legislator Wang To-far, also a member of the delegation, said that a bill regarding the development of recycled energy is expected to be vetted in the next session of the Legislative Yuan.

"As Taiwan has set the goal of 12 percent of its total electricity consumption being from recycled energy by 2020, and as Germany is a leader in relevant sectors, German firms will definitely take notice of the business opportunities in Taiwan," he added.
The legislators have also visited Austria, Belgium and France during their 12-day tour in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO PRESIDE OVER MEETING ON NATIONAL SECURITY REPORT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a high-level meeting this afternoon to discuss the content of a national security report to be released this summer, a Presidential Office spokesman said Wednesday.

Many senior officials, including Vice President Annette Lu, who just returned from a three-day visit to Palau at noon, Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, will attend the meeting, the spokesman said
President Chen said earlier this year that he would set a precedent in Taiwan by issuing a national security report for the first time this summer.

The national security report will cover five major categories of national affairs -- finance and economy, national defense, relations across the Taiwan Strait, diplomacy, and national land conservation, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG SAYS IT'S LOGICAL TO QUIT AS VICE CHAIRMAN IF HE LOSES ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that it is logical to conclude that he would step down as opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice chairman if he were to lose the KMT chairmanship election next month.

Wang was responding to questions on remarks a day earlier by Mu Ming-chu, a former legislator who is serving as Wang's campaign aide, while he was soliciting support in the southern county of Pingtung for his bid for the KMT's top post.

Mu said that if Wang is not elected party chairman, the KMT will be "plunged into crisis" because Wang will no longer serve as a party vice chairman and such issues as "pan-blue alliance" integration, the party's controversial assets and party staff salaries will become problems.
Wang said that he has not yet thought about the issue of quitting as vice chairman and still has to assess the matter, stressing however that "Mu's speculation is reasonable."
Wang noted that Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, another KMT vice chairman and his rival in the July 16 chairmanship election, has spoken about the generational transfer of power in the party leadership.
Wang said that a man of his age should leave the party leadership if he loses the election. Wang is 64 years old, and Ma is 55.
Wang's campaign headquarters said, however, that Wang has a broad mind and that he will work with Ma in whatever post he holds.

KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu set the tone for Wang's camp at a press conference held at Wang's campaign headquarters in Taipei. Hung said that Mu's views are her "personal views, " adding that Wang has served in the KMT for over 30 years and that he will continue to work for the maximum interests of the party in whatever post he holds.
"Both Wang and Ma are indispensable assets of the KMT, " Hung said, adding that they should value each other's contribution to the party.
Hung said that Wang has every confidence in winning the election and that he will continue to rely heavily on Ma to create a win-win situation for the KMT and the nation.
Meanwhile, Ma said he is sure that Wang loves the party and that he won't quit as vice chairman even if he loses the election.
Ma also said that he will quit along with incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan after election.

Ma said that if Wang wins the chairmanship election, "I will support him in the interests of the party, " adding that "this is a gentlemen's battle" and that both are comrades before the election and should be so after the election. The mayor added that both he and Wang agreed that the party can't afford to be split apart.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WATER RATE HIKE IN THE NEAR TERM: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh promised Wednesday there will not be water rate hike in the near term.
Hsieh said during a weekly Cabinet meeting that the Cabinet will first put forth a pricing formula and submit it to the Legislative Yuan for approval before raising water rates.
The Cabinet will also review the basic minimum charge for water consumption to encourage people to cherish water resources.
According to Hsieh, the burden of many consumers will decrease if the minimum charge is lowered as the amount of water consumed by approximately 75 percent of users is lower than the minimum level.
Hsieh said he will request the water company to present an analysis of its financial structure and review its pipe replacement program, both of which he said will affect the water pricing.
On energy rates, the premier said the government will respect the market mechanism and take the country's economic and energy policies into consideration before hiking energy rates.
It will be unnecessary for the government to develop more energy resources and generate more energy if people can conserve energy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR SUPPORT FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT, VOLUNTEER MILITARY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan is now at a critical juncture of metamorphosis on many fronts, including constitutional reform, detente across the Taiwan Strait, diplomatic development and upgrading of national defense.
Chen made the remarks while addressing a commissioning ceremony for 55 newly promoted generals and admirals.
"Over the years of development, Taiwan has become a liberal democracy. But it is now facing many new challenges, " Chen said.

At this historical moment, the president went on, Taiwan must establish an elite military force to guarantee a safe and stable environment for constitutional reform, cross-strait detente, civic participation in diplomatic affairs and refinement of defense capabilities.

As commander-in-chief of the armed forces, Chen said he wants to join all service members in fulfilling the military's core values of "sacrifice, unity and accountability" with "courage, conviction and trust."

Noting that the ultimate goal of Taiwan's military buildup is to maintain a balance of military power with China, Chen said Taiwan must establish an elite military force strong enough to deter any invasion and fight back any possible attack from China.

In recent years, Chen said, senior U.S. officials have on many occasions expressed worries about China's rapid military expansion and missile deployment. The soon-to-be-released Pentagon annual defense white paper is also expected to mention U.S. concern about China's growing military power.

Chen said three weaponry systems his administration has proposed to purchase from the United States -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- have been chosen after a comprehensive professional assessment and extensive public debate.

"We regret that the procurement plan has been excessively politicized. With the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan refusing even to put the procurement package into its work agenda, our national defense network may have a loophole that could eventually upset the military balance in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region," Chen said.
Chen expressed hope that all military service personnel can stand even more united and redouble their efforts to hone their combat prowess to safeguard national security and cross-strait stability.

With the evolution of modern warfare, he continued, Taiwan must establish an all-volunteer military service system to upgrade the quality of service members, enhance combat prowess and boost military operational efficiency.

Noting that ever-more sophisticated weapons require trained professionals to operate them, Chen said the military must step up recruitment of volunteers so that these advanced weapons can be operated appropriately and the weapons' efficacy reaches their fullest potential. A volunteer service system is also expected to increase job opportunities for young people, he added.

While congratulating the new generals and admirals, Chen also demanded that all senior officers further improve management mechanisms and risk-reduction measures to minimize accidents and casualties in military training programs and enhance safety in military barracks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIAOYUTAIS BELONG TO ROC: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The Tiaoyutai island group is the territory of the Republic of China no matter whether from the viewpoints of geography, geology, history or international law, an official of a local think tank claimed Wednesday.

Stephen S.F. Chen, convener of a national security group of the National Policy Foundation, made the remarks when he reported on the dispute surrounding the Tiaoyutais and protection of local fishermen's rights to a regular meeting of the opposition Kuomintang Central Standing Committee.

The former representative to the United States claimed that since the first generational transfer of power in Taiwan politics in 2000, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, confined by its ideology and election considerations, has had no comprehensive plan for the nation and has failed to see the basic interests of the nation.

Whether it is from the viewpoints of geography, geology, history and international law, the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to Taiwan and the government should insist on the sovereignty of the island group, according to Chen.

The Tiaoyutais, known in Japan as the Senkakus, comprise eight islets located northeast of Taiwan, about 102 nautical miles from the northern port of Keelung. The islands, claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan, are about 90 nautical miles from the nearest Taiwanese and Japanese territory.
Waters near the Tiaoyutais have been the source of a long-running dispute between Taiwan and Japan, as they are located in the overlapping exclusive economic zones of the two countries.
Japan agreed to a new round of fishery talk July 29 after a mass protest by Taiwan fishing vessels near the controversial waters in northeastern Taiwan early this month.
Chen claimed that without sovereignty there can be no fishing rights.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor and KMT Vice Chairman Ma Ying-jeou echoed Chen's views, saying that the government should insist that fishing rights and sovereignty are inseparable.
Ma said that if the government shelves the dispute on sovereignty and only talks about fishing rights in the upcoming fishery talks, it will be detrimental to Taiwan.

He said Taiwan should not unilaterally shelve the dispute on sovereignty, pointing out that the island group has already been occupied by Japan and that Taiwan's unilateral shelving would be tantamount to giving up its sovereignty claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 85.19 points to close at 6,231.65.
The bourse opened at 6,370.14 and fluctuated between 6,375.68 and 6,231.65 during trading. A total of 3.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$90.8 billion (US$2.89 billion).

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.6 percent, construction issues at 1.5 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, paper and pulp issues, as well as banking and financial shares both at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 650 to 206, with 149 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TO BLAME FOR CHANGES IN TAIWAN'S WTO INFORMATION: DPP

TEXT.P: A senior ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker claimed Wednesday that China's pressure was behind a World Trade Organization (WTO) move to change Taiwan's information in its new directory and he urged the opposition not to blame the government.
In the WTO directory renewed last week, Taiwan's WTO officials are addressed as "Mr" and "Miss" instead of their official titles.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lai Hsin-yuan, who is a former advisor to the National Security Council, accused Taiwan's permanent mission to the WTO of failing to defend Taiwan's sovereignty.

She claimed Wednesday that the changes were the result of a concession made by the permanent mission and she demanded that the Cabinet punish the officials responsible and demand that the WTO republish the directory.
However, William C.T. Lai, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said the allegation is totally untrue and will upset the morale of Taiwan's WTO mission.

He also called the opposition Kuomintang's and People First Party's attention to the fact that China has not stopped oppressing Taiwan internationally despite the recent visit to China by the two parties' leaders, and urged the two parties to condemn China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Green Light for Deripaska Power Bid.

Billionaire Oleg Deripaska's Basic Element on Tuesday won approval from the Federal Anti-Monopoly Service to buy an 80 percent stake in turbine maker Siloviye Mashiny, or Power Machines. The decision in favor of Basic Element was widely anticipated after the anti-monopoly service in April turned down a similar bid by German engineering giant Siemens.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN SUPPORTS PROBE INTO FSC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan supports a probe by prosecutors of an alleged insider trading of an official of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), an Executive Yuan spokesman said Thursday.

Cho Jung-tai made the remarks one day after prosecutors searched the office of the FSC and questioned Lee Chin-cheng, head of the commission's Examination Bureau, for several hours in a probe into alleged insider trading of stocks of a high-tech company.
Cho said the Executive Yuan supports the probe and has confidence in the findings. If any officials were involved in the case, the Executive Yuan will not be lenient, he said.

Legislator Chang Hsien-yao of the opposition People First Party said the FSC should check whether its officials are involved in insider trading, as well as investigate the worst blunder in the stock market when a local securities dealer unfamiliar with the system keyed in the wrong numbers and made a purchase of NT$8 billion (US$255.5 million) for Merrill Lynch, which wanted to buy around NT$80 million-worth of stocks.
Chang said that relevant officials should be disciplined so as to stabilize the stock market and assuage local misgivings.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July moved down 85 points to close at 6,199, with 54,328 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August dropped 87 points to end at 6,120, with 1,296 contracts traded, while September futures lost 86 points to finish at 6,099, with 369 contracts traded.
December futures moved down 92 points to close at 6,090, with 12 contracts traded, while March futures lost 82 points to close at 6,089, with 11 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,284 for July, 6,207 for August, 6,185 for September, 6,182 for December and 6,171 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
July TE futures moved down 3.8 points to close at 252.1, with 6,016 contracts traded, while August TE futures lost 3.65 points to finish at 250, with 155 contract transactions.
September TE futures dropped 2.35 points to close at 250.8, with 14 contract transactions, while December TE futures gained one point to finish at 249.5, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures lost 11.6 points to finish at 961.4, with 4,951 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures moved down 12.6 points to close at 948, with 273 contracts traded.
September TF futures dropped 7.6 points to close at 950, with 16 contract transactions, while December TF futures moved down 6.0 points to close at 946.4, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CONCLUDES PALAU VISIT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu returned to Taiwan Wednesday after concluding a visit to Palau that began Monday, describing it as "a short but rich and fruitful trip."

Although Lu said that her trip to the diplomatic ally in the South Pacific was short -- a little more than 50 hours in total, about one-third of which was spent at sea, she hailed it as "a lean but beautiful diplomatic tour."

Stating that she was deeply impressed by Palau's beautiful scenery, Lu called on Taiwan tourists to pay more visits to the island nation, which is an ideal destination for a wide variety of water-based leisure activities.

Taiwan has a very similar natural environment to Palau and the people in Taiwan should pay more attention to the sea that surrounds the country as it wishes to become an ocean power, Lu said, pointing out that long-term negligence by the government has made Taiwan lose its oceanic characteristics.

The recent fishery dispute between Taiwan and Japan is a clear reflection of the importance for Taiwan to acknowledge itself as an ocean country in order to protect the country's vital interests, she said.

Traveling at the head of an official delegation, the vice president departed for Palau Monday for a three-day visit, during which she met Palauan President Tommy Remengesau, Jr. and upper and lower house speakers Johnny Reklai and Augustine Mesebeluu, respectively.

The major purpose of Lu's visit was to take part in the inauguration of a Taiwan-funded upscale hotel -- the Palau Royal Resort Hotel, which is expected to create many job opportunities for local people and bring in more foreign tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.176 to close at NT$31.610.
A total of US$1.25 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.465 and closed at the day's high of NT$31.610.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET REJECTS PFP REQUEST TO FREEZE CONSUMER PRICES

TEXT.P: A Cabinet official turned down Wednesday a proposal by opposition lawmakers that the government freeze all consumer prices.

Calling the proposal unfeasible, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said that while such a proposal might have worked during Taiwan's authoritarian rule, it is impossible for the government to impose such a policy today.
Cho said consumer prices should be guided by the market mechanism and that the Cabinet can only deal with prices according to the law.
For example, Cho said, oil prices are calculated according to a formula, while any adjustment in the pricing formula for water rates requires the approval of the Legislative Yuan.
He pointed out that one ton of water cost only NT$10.5 (US$0.33) in Taiwan now, which he said is cheaper than most other countries.

A group of opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators have demanded that the Cabinet work out a plan to freeze consumer prices within a week and said they will block the Cabinet's budget proposal otherwise.

Also Wednesday, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said electricity rates will not be hiked this summer and that it will depend on international coal prices as to whether electricity rates will be raised in the fall.
Ho said the Ministry of Economic Affairs will promote a campaign to conserve energy and will then consider the burden on consumers before hiking electricity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASSOCIATION OF CIVIL SOCIETY AIMS TO UPGRADE DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Taiwan Association of Civil Society (TACS) founder Wilson Chen said Wednesday that his group has been acting as a platform for discussing all sorts of issues rationally in the hope that Taiwan will become "a real democracy" at an early date.

Chen was speaking to a group of journalists and academics celebrating the second anniversary of the society's founding. Presidential advisor Chen Tien-fu was invited to present a "thank you plaque" to journalist Chuang Feng-chia for his contribution in helping to promote the cause of TACS.

TACS was established in 2003 in response to the way Taiwan lawmakers do not discuss major policy issues but simply engage in partisan struggles, and the way the media do not do their jobs professionally but rather just stage talks shows that serve only to advance the interests of political hot-heads.
"What the parliament and the media were doing did not help to solve problems. Rather, they created factors for social division and turmoil and making the public more and more uneasy," Chen said.
TACS is aimed at building a civil society by elevating people's sense of citizenship and building an infrastructure for promoting social harmony, he said.
He described Taiwan as a multi-cultural society in which aboriginals and old and new immigrants should respect and help each other so they can jointly create a democratic civilization.
TACS has worked to recruit graduate school students who have the ability to write reports and complete a project. It now has over 60 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-PARTY MEETINGS URGED TO FORGE CONSENSUS ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: A scholar urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition parties Wednesday to meet regularly on national affairs and forge consensus on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Professor Chao Chien-min of National Chengchi University made the remarks when he attended a seminar on the roles and functions of Taiwan's political parties in promoting cross-strait exchanges. The seminar was sponsored by the College of Social Sciences of National Taiwan University.

Professor Lin Cheng-yi of the same university said that with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) heads traveling to China over the past two months to have exchanges with the Communist Party of China, there should be due division of work and a notification mechanism so as "to assuage misgivings."

Lin noted that a cross-strait peace alliance promoted by several civic groups, such as the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, the Taiwan Labor Front and the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, has called on the government to convene national meetings on cross-strait issues.
Judging from Chinese President Hu Jintao's policy toward Taiwan, Lin said that China would focus on trade and economy, culture and education, as well as sports and tourism exchanges.
All civic groups relevant to the above fields are China's possible targets, Lin said, adding that the government should integrate information and make it transparent.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian has announced that he will invite opposition parties and representatives from all quarters to convene a cross-strait peace development committee, Lin urged the president to deliver on his promise or explain why he has failed to deliver.
He suggested that the government supply information so that Taiwan civic groups, when conducting exchanges with China, will have a standard operating procedure or set of guidelines to follow.
The government should also notify the opposition parties when announcing major policies and step up communication beforehand so as to form a unified team to negotiate with China, Lin said.

NTU Professor Wu Yu-shan said that the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union should reflect upon themselves after Taiwan people "had not shown strong disapproval" after the China visits by the KMT and PFP heads.

This, he claimed, seems to show that seeking reconciliation with Beijing has gained some legitimacy in Taiwan. He added that if the trend continues, there might be an appeal for the "pan-green camp" to become more hawkish and for the opposition "pan-blue alliance" to become more dovish in dealing with cross-strait relations.
But he also warned the "pan-blue alliance" not to be too optimistic, saying that it could harm itself if it overplays cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWANESE DREAM OF BEING THEIR OWN BOSS AND SOME SUCCEED: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Around 90 percent of people in Taiwan say they have considered starting their own business, and more than a quarter of these have, an Internet poll showed Wednesday.
The poll, conducted jointly by Cheers magazine and www.104boss.com.tw, said that among those who have the experience of starting their own business, 60 percent began when they were between 20 and 29.

The survey also found that among entrepreneurs, 69 percent failed, but only 3.5 percent of them said they had given up the hope of being their own boss, while 81 percent said they would look for another job and build up momentum for a fresh start. Another 13 percent said that they would persist until they succeed.

Asked about problems starting their own business, 74 percent said a lack of start-up money, 53 percent said they couldn't grasp the direction of the business and which business to set up, while 25 percent said that they couldn't find suitable partners.

The biggest hurdles in starting a new business, in order, are: business direction, wrong business formula or wrong business (40.5 percent), unstable financial support (36.9 percent), and hard to find clients (32 percent).
The survey also found that the service sector has become the mainstream of starting new businesses, while eateries are the favorite among new businesses.

The best timing of starting a business is five years after work, while a starting fund of NT$500,000 (US$15,870) is most common, and the daily needs of average people provide the optimal opportunity for business starters.
The survey was conducted June 7-15, receiving 3,075 effective samples.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHINA FEVER' AIMED AT ISOLATING TAIWAN GOVERNMENT: DPP

TEXT.P: The seemingly friendly "China fever" created recently by Beijing is aimed at dividing the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan and isolating the government of Taiwan, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Wednesday.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin said that China has never stopped its international oppression of Taiwan or made concessions on basic issues despite the friendly atmosphere shown in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

Yen was referring to the visits to China by members of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang and People First Party at Beijing's invitation over the past two months, which the media and politicians claim has created what they describe as "China fever" in Taiwan.

In what the DPP has called the latest example of China's oppression of Taiwan, Beijing reportedly has pressured the World Trade Organization (WTO) to omit the official titles of Taiwan officials to the WTO in its new directory, giving them the honorifics of simply "Mr." or "Ms."

Yen said Beijing should open dialogue with the government if it is truly friendly toward Taiwan and he urged the opposition parties to meet with the ruling party to seek a consensus on divisive issues before holding any talks with Beijing.
He made the remarks during a seminar on the role and function of opposition parties in promoting cross-strait exchanges.

Also at the seminar, Chen Ming-tong, a professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of National Development, claimed that the problem of cross-strait exchanges always lies with the Beijing side.

Chen pointed out that the recent "China fever" is built upon a framework in which the opposition leaders who have visited China recognize the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" principle and that this framework will become even firmer as such exchanges increase.
Under these circumstances, members of the opposition parties should prioritize the overall interests of Taiwan over partisan interests while engaging in exchange activities with China, Chen said.
He called on the opposition parties to avoid distorting the government's policies in exchange for partisan gains.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED REVISIONS TO THE REFERENDUM LAW APPROVED BY EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: A proposal to revise the Referendum Law to make it easier for the people to call for referendums and approve them was approved by the Executive Yuan Wednesday.
Under the proposal, the scope of issues that can be put to a referendum would be expanded to cover the sensitive issue of changing the nation's territorial boundaries.
Also, the number of voters needed to initiate a request for a referendum would be lowered from 0.5 percent of the total eligible voters in the last presidential election to 0.03 percent.
The number of sponsors needed to second such a request would be lowered from 5 percent of eligible voters in the last presidential election to 1.5 percent.

Except for the proposition to change the nation's boundaries, which would have to be approved by half of all eligible voters, other issues would need only one-quarter of eligible voters' approval, according to the proposal.

The Legislative Yuan's right to initiate referendums under the current law will be shifted to the Executive Yuan; what is left for the legislature is only the right to approve the Executive Yuan's request for a referendum.

The Central Election Commission (CEC) will substitute for the Executive Yuan as the government agency in charge of referendums, and the commission provided for in the current law to review people's request for a referendum will be replaced by the CEC too.
The proposed revisions will be presented to the legislature for enactment in the next legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI SETS UP INCUBATION CENTER IN CALIFORNIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) recently opened a talent incubation center in Silicon Valley, California, via its North American base -- ITRI International Inc. -- to offer comprehensive services to people interested in starting a new business.

With abundant researchers and brilliant technical services to corporations, ITRI's business incubation center in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, has been chosen as the best center of its kind in Asia by the Asian Association of Business Incubation (AABI) this year.

ITRI President Johnsee Lee said on his recent visit to the United States that Taiwan can become a springboard for talented people in Silicon Valley to enter the Asian market, and the newly established North American incubation center can help such efforts.

ITRI's incubation center in Silicon Valley will offer knowledge on how to open a business, technical support and trade consulting services to potential clients and help them promote the sales of their products to the Asian and Pacific region.
In addition to offering technical support to corporations, the ITRI also badly needs high-tech experts from abroad.

ITRI's talent-search program from abroad last year received a warm response, and the organization will continue the program in search of high-tech experts with more than five years' work experience in North America.
To strengthen Taiwan's competitiveness, Lee said he hoped that ITRI International, Inc. can forge cooperative relations with noted U.S. universities, research organizations and corporations.

Currently, ITRI has long-term cooperative projects with Rockwell Scientific, Co., Stanford University, the University of California at Los Angeles, Corning and Dow Chemical, and has established strategic alliances with SRI International, UC Berkeley, and Carnegie Mellon University.

In 2004, ITRI successfully introduced 211 U.S. patents related to digital imaging ICs to Taiwan, ushering in an era of digital television, LCD television and the digital imaging industry in Taiwan, and the company will keep securing U.S. patents for Taiwan to upgrade the technical level of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNAL CONSENSUS CRITICAL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: EX-MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan must first forge a domestic consensus on the nature and direction of cross-strait relations if it hopes to have adequate room to deal with China, a former top mainland policy-planner said Wednesday.

Legislator Tsai Ing-wen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who once served as Mainland Affairs Council chairwoman, made the remarks in a keynote speech delivered at a seminar on the role and functions of domestic political parties in promoting cross-strait exchanges.

The seminar was organized by National Taiwan University's Social Science College as the role of political parties in cross-strait ties has come to the forefront after the controversial visits to China by two opposition leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- between late April and early May.

Noting that local politicians like to treat cross-strait ties as a stage for grandstanding based on their own ideologies and sense of mission, Tsai said their political calculations have often hindered them from addressing cross-strait issues squarely and logically.

As a result, she said, politics has mingled with legal matters, with politicians indulging themselves in seeking legal solutions to intrinsically political events. At stake in such practices have been the impartially and objectivity of the law.

Tsai said Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties should think how to integrate law and politics by laying out a comprehensive framework within a legal basis for both camps to cooperate in cross-strait policy formulation while leaving room for them to compete among themselves. Only by so doing, Tsai said, can Taiwan present a unified front in dealing with China or tackling external affairs.
As far as cross-strait affairs are concerned, Tsai said the government and all local political parties must take into account two key points.

First, Tsai said, local political parties must keep in mind that the 23 million Taiwan people share a common destiny and therefore should create a priority list for engagements with China, with the common interests of all domestic parties superseding the common interests of their own party and the Chinese Communist government in Beijing.

For the sake of maintaining national identity, Tsai went on, the government should be given room to exercise its public authority in cross-strait engagements, while local political parties and the public should also have a say in cross-strait affairs.

Tsai outlined key obligations for political parties in engaging China, including abiding by the law; being subject to a certain degree of supervision; showing transparency in their engagements with China; informing the public of the goals of their contacts and exchange programs; and consulting and communicating with the government on the conduct of their engagements.

As the government monopolizes administrative power in cross-strait affairs, Tsai said, it should also fulfill some obligations, including professionalism, impartiality, non-partisan thinking, avoiding arrogance, avoiding the abuse of power, taking the initiative to consult and communicate with opposition parties and expounding on its major policy goals and their legality to opposition parties and the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PREPARING FOR TALKS WITH CHINA ON FRUIT SALES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is preparing for talks with relevant Chinese organizations about supplying Taiwanese fruits to the Chinese market after a Beijing official indicated flexibility Wednesday on which organization should represent Taiwan in this regard.

At a news conference held by the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council in Beijing, Tang Wei, deputy chief of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs of the Ministry of Commerce, said that China is willing to discuss the importation of Taiwanese fruits with any non-governmental organization that can truly represent the interests of Taiwanese farmers and is familiar with Taiwan's fruit trade.

This is seen by Taiwan officials as the first indication that Beijing is no longer opposed to Premier Frank Hsieh's suggestion that Taiwan be represented by the unofficial foreign trade arm, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Tang's remarks are seen as having demonstrated considerable flexibility, compared with those made by Li Weiyi, spokesman for the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office at a news conference on June 15. Although Li did not comment directly on Hsieh's proposal, he said that Beijing has always considered trade and economic cooperation with Taiwan an "internal affair" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Last week a delegation of the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association visited China and discussed technical problems concerning the sale of Taiwan fruits with the Cross-Strait Association of Economy and Trade under the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. At the time, Beijing appeared to prefer to deal with the association directly.

Senior officials of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Wednesday termed Beijing's recent statement a "positive response" and called on both sides to begin talks as soon as possible. They also said the MAC will consult with TAITRA and the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association on the next steps in the negotiation process with the mainland.

Meanwhile, TAITRA Secretary-General Chao Yung-chuan said the TAITRA representative in Beijing was trying to find out more about Beijing's new gesture. He also said he expects TAITRA to be designated by the MAC to be the organization responsible for sales of top-quality Taiwan fruits to the Chinese market.
China announced on May 3 that it would increase the number of Taiwan fruit categories allowed for import to China from 12 to 18, and grant tariff-free treatment for 15 categories.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSAL TO TALK WITH CHINA COSTS TSU OFFICIAL HIS PARTY MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: A key official of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) resigned Wednesday for touting the idea that the party should engage in talks with China, contradicting the party line of never making contact with China unless it recognizes Taiwan's sovereignty.

Lee Hsien-jen, chief executive officer of the TSU's Policy Council, tendered his resignation after his proposal to begin discussions with China backfired. His resignation was accepted by the party's Central Committee, TSU Secretary-General Cheng Chen-lung said.
In a statement, the party said it has never changed its policy of insisting on and safeguarding Taiwan's independent sovereignty.

It compared recent visits to China by major opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong to "kowtowing to Beijing." It said it will never fall into the trap of China's united front that Lien and Soong had helped to set up.

It also admonished party members not to go against the party's "Taiwan identity above all" policy and contact China, and threatened to discipline or expel those who violate the policy. However, it is acceptable for party members to visit China as tourists.
Cheng said the latest information shows that none of the TSU's 12 legislators has invested in China, adding that anyone found to have done so will be disciplined.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGER YU'S BROTHER HAS NOT BEEN EXECUTED FOR DRUG OFFENSE: BEIJING

TEXT.P: News reports that Taiwanese singer Yu Tien's adopted younger brother has been executed in China on charges of narcotics trafficking are incorrect, a spokesman for the Chinese government said Wednesday.

Li Weiyi, spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, told a regular news conference that Yu Fu-hsing, charged with smuggling heroin into Xiamen, is still awaiting trial at the highest People's Court in Fujian.

Li said court trials are very serious matters. He deplored the fact that incorrect news reports have misled people and caused distress to the family members of the defendant. However, he declined to disclose the whereabouts of the accused and his present condition.

Over the past few days, news media in Taiwan has widely reported that popular singer Yu Tien's 49-year-old younger brother, Yu Fu-hsing, who moved to Xiamen 12 years ago, had been executed with a number of other drug traffickers by lethal injection on June 26 by Chinese authorities for smuggling heroin into China from Thailand.

The news originated from reports in Hong Kong newspapers, which said that Yu Fu-hsiung had been sentenced to death in March for carrying 10 bricks of heroin totaling 3.8 kilograms worth about NT$100 million in street value.
Yu Tien was visibly shaken and in tears in TV interviews when told his younger brother had been executed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY DELEGATION TO VISIT CHINA NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: A New Party delegation is slated to embark on an eight-day visit to China July 6, New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming announced Wednesday.

Speaking at the New Party headquarters in Taipei, Yok said that he will personally lead the 30-member mission to China via Hong Kong, where they will make stops in Guangzhou, Nanjing, Dalian and Beijing through a stay until July 13.
The New Party is a small party with only a single legislator in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

The main purpose of the visit is to step up bilateral exchanges and mutual communication between Taiwan and China, seeing as both places are members of the global Chinese society, and to mark the 60th anniversary of China's victory over the Japanese in 1945 at the end of World War Two, Yok said.

The New Party delegation's visit to China will be the third by a political party from Taiwan since April this year following a "journey of peace" by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and a "bridge-building" trip by People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.
The New Party delegation will be accorded with the same protocol by the Chinese side as is accorded by China to the KMT and the PFP, Yok added.

The KMT, the PFP and the New Party form the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" to counter the pro-independence "pan green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Meanwhile, PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng told a seminar on the roles of political parties in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges held at National Taiwan University that Taiwan-China interactions are unstoppable trends and he urged the government to go with the flow created by opposition parties instead of just sitting idly by.

The governing DPP must forswear ideological strife and lean toward moderation for the sake of the people's benefit, Chin said, stressing that PFP Chairman Soong goodwill visit to China in early May helped lay the foundation for the two sides to improve their strained ties on a wide range of fronts.

A capable and visionary government should have the wisdom and courage to use Taiwan's links with China to its advantage to pursue benefits for the country, rather than viewing them as threats, he said, calling on the government to seize all available opportunities to mend relations and forge rapport with China.

Kao Koong-lian, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, suggested that the government bravely take on the challenges from China with effective strategies to counter what it calls the "united fronts" of the Chinese Communists.

Speaking at the same seminar, Chang Wu-ueh, a professor of China studies at Tamkang University, warned that Beijing is attempting to extend its clout into Taiwan's political spectrum by pushing for party-to-party contacts with Taiwan's opposition parties.

He urged both the ruling and opposition camps to ponder in depth through dialogue how to face Beijing's offensive at a time when the Chinese Communist regime crowds out the ruling DPP in bilateral contacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SHOULD INVITE ROC LEADERS TO VISIT WASHINGTON, D.C.: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said in a recent interview with a U.S. press group that the United States should invite President Chen Shui-bian and herself to visit Washington, D.C.

Lu gave the interview with Tim Johnson, Beijing bureau chief of the Knight Ridder press group, at the Presidential Office June 24. The San Jose Mercury News, a Knight Ridder newspaper based in California, published the interview in its June 28 issue.

Noting that both the late Palestinian Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama had been invited to visit the White House, Lu said in the interview that President Chen and she are even more qualified to be invited to visit the U.S. capital because they have dedicated themselves to promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and peace for many years.

The San Jose Mercury News published the interview with Lu Tuesday under the title "Vice President Defends Taiwan." The article, carried on the paper's Asian news page, had a photo of Lu sitting in her office before her life-size portrait.

Lu said in the interview that she doesn't see any chance or reason for Taiwan to become a part of the People's Republic of China in the foreseeable future. She further said she thinks Chinese leaders do not want to have a war with Taiwan before 2008 because they must focus efforts on preparing for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games.

Over the past decade, Lu said Taiwan business people have set up thousands of factories in southern and central China to cash in on cheap labor there. Lu said she is worried about the situation. In her view, Lu said China has to some extent succeeded in enticing Taiwanese business people to invest and settle on the Chinese mainland.

Lu said she earnestly hopes that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan can pass as soon as possible a bill aimed at punishing Taiwan business people who leak highly sensitive technical expertise to China.

Asked if she would seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination for the 2008 presidential election, Lu didn't give a direct reply. She instead said more and more people like her because of her straightforward, frank and principled character.

The Knight Ridder group, the second-largest newspaper publisher in the United States, operates 31 dailies, with 14 ranking among the top 100 newspapers in the United States, including the San Jose Mercury News, which is the most influential paper in the San Francisco area.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH HAS NEW DEPUTY MINISTER

TEXT.P: One of President Chen Shui-bian's advisers, Chen Shih-chung, was named deputy minister of the Department of Health Wednesday, the department announced.
Chen Shih-chung, who will also keep his job as a presidential adviser, is expected to be in charge of national health insurance affairs.

Chen Shih-chung graduated from the dentistry department of Taipei Medical College, the predecessor of Taipei Medical University, and served as the chairman of the Taipei Dental Association and was board chairman of Taipei Medical University.
He was to fill the vacancy left by Hou Sheng-mou, who became minister of the health department in February.

Noting that his main job in the health department will be planning the second-generation national health insurance program, and strengthening relations with the legislature, Chen Shih-chung said the task will be tough but he will try his best.

As the self-payment fees for outpatients and emergency patients in regional and national medical center hospitals will be increased starting from next month, Chen Shih-chung said health department officials are communicating with various hospitals to better understand whether their supplementary measures will be sufficient to cope with the change.

Chen Shih-chung said he hopes that this will help reduce the financial burden on the national health insurance program and encourage the public to go to big hospitals for treatment only when they have big health problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY REFUTES REPORT ON NUMBER OF ABUSED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The number of abused children and teenagers in Taiwan has fallen, in contrast to a media report that claimed that the number has jumped by almost 1.5-fold in just a year, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Wednesday.

The spokesman asked the China Time Express to make a correction of its report printed earlier the same day that says the number of abused children in Taiwan rose quickly to 7,837 for 2004 from the 2003 level of 5,349 -- a 1.47-fold increase.

The numbers cited by the newspaper are wrong and it should correct the report to reflect the facts, the MOI official said, elaborating that the 2004 number was 7,837 -- 5,796 abused children and 2,041 teenagers -- in comparison to the 2003 figure of 8,013 -- 5,349 children and 2,664 teenaged youths.

To prevent such cases from happening in society, local governments, law enforcement authorities and private sector groups have set up round-the-clock telephone lines to provide necessary aid, assistance and shelter to abused children -- mainly victims of domestic violence, the official said, pointing out that parents, adoptive fathers and mothers, relatives and family friends are the most frequent abusers.
Unemployment, drug abuse, alcohol addiction and broken marriages are the major reasons driving adults to abuse children, experts say.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION NEEDED TO TACKLE NEW SITUATION: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties must reconcile and dialogue with each other and forge a consensus on how to cope with China's ever more adroit strategies toward Taiwan, a scholar said Wednesday.

Chang Wu-yueh, a Tamkang University associate professor, made the suggestion at a seminar on the role and functions of domestic political parties in promoting exchanges across the Taiwan Strait. The issue has come to the forefront after two Taiwan opposition leaders -- Kuomintang (DPP) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (FPF) Chairman James Soong -- made controversial visits to China between late April and early May.

Noting that increasing interaction between Taiwan's opposition parties and the Communist Party of China (CPC) will enable Beijing authorities to directly influence Taiwan's domestic affairs and electoral results, Chang said local ruling and opposition parties must seek reconciliation and work out viable strategies to cope with this new situation.

"Ruling and opposition parties must consider how they can work together to avert Chinese influence in domestic affairs while competing among themselves for popular support in political elections. If ruling and opposition camps cannot cooperate, they would be unable to present a unified front to pursue national and popular interests," Chang said.
With party-to-party exchanges across the Taiwan Strait continuing gaining momentum, Chang said domestic inter-party reconciliation has become ever more urgent.
Chang said he sees no reason for the KMT to refuse to reconcile with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) now that it has forsaken its 80-year feud to reconcile with the CPC.
"As to the DPP, if it cannot reconcile with the KMT, how can it convince us that it can promote reconciliation and dialogue with China?" Chang said.

He further said Beijing should develop contact and dialogue with the DPP administration after it forged ties with the KMT and the PFP. "Otherwise, how can it promote peaceful development in bilateral ties?" he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 30 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, June 30:

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HUDDLES WITH AIDES OVER NATIONAL SECURITY REPORT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian huddled with his security aides over his forthcoming national security report to the public earlier the day, Chiou I-jen, secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), said Wednesday.
The meeting brought together Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, the president's chief of staff Yu Shyi-kun, and Chiou.
The preliminary draft of the report covers the five topics of finance, defense, ties with China, diplomacy and the conservation of land, Chiou said.
The president's security aides have met weekly over the report, which will be the first in the country's history.

Noting that part of the preliminary report has been published in newspapers, Chiou said the full report has not been finalized, and that the NSC will look into who leaked the contents of the preliminary report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO STOP BLOCKING WEB SITES OF TAIWAN NEWSPAPERS

TEXT.P: China should first allow its people to access Web sites of Taiwan's newspapers before the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) allows Beijing People's Daily and Xinhua news agency to post correspondents to Taiwan again, MAC chief Jaushieh Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

Wu said his council withdrew permission to People's Daily and Xinhua to station correspondents in Taiwan in April because they contradicted the purpose of their correspondents' presence in Taiwan by publishing misleading stories about Taiwan on purpose.

He said Beijing should show goodwill toward Taiwan before the MAC reinstates the permission to the People's Daily and Xinhua; for example, by allowing mainland Chinese people to access Web sites of Taiwan's newspapers, not least the Web sites of the United Daily News and the China Times, the two most outspoken critics of the DPP government.
"What is Beijing afraid of?" Wu asked, given that the two papers are known for their watchful surveillance of the DPP government, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CHINA TRADE INCREASES

TEXT.P: Two-way trade between Taiwan and China amounted to US$21.79 billion in the first four months of this year, up 18.9 percent from the previous year's level, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Taiwan exported goods worth US$15.66 billion to China during the period between January and April, while importing US$6.129 billion in goods from China, up 15 percent and 30.2 percent year-on-year, respectively.
Taiwan enjoyed a surplus of US$9.538 billion in its trade with China during the January to April period, an increase of 7 percent from the figure recorded a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION CRITICIZES GOVERNMENT'S PROPOSAL TO REVISE REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's proposal to revise the Referendum Law was welcomed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) but drew brickbats from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) on whose ideas the current law was crafted.

Speaking for the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Huang Teh-fu said the DPP government is trying to cut the legislature's power by doing away with its right to initiate referendums because the DPP failed to win a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

By taking away from the Legislative Yuan the right to initiate referendums and giving it to the Executive Yuan, the proposal runs against the basic principle that referendums are a device created to address problems caused by the executive branch's failure to enact proper laws and thereby should reside with the legislature.

He blamed the Executive Yuan for wanting to lower the minimum number of voters needed to make a request for a referendum, to second the request and to approve issues via for referendum simply because President Chen Shui-bian's 2004 referendum was a failure.
However, by making it easier to have recourse to referendums, Huang argued, the Executive Yuan is opening the door to political disturbance and compromising stability.

PFP lawmaker Chen Chih-pin shared the KMT's view, claiming that referendums are supposed to be a right of the people, but the proposed revision would turn them into the right of the government by giving the Executive Yuan rather than the legislature the power to initiate them.

Furthermore, Chen Chih-pin said, the Central Election Commission is responsible for the organization of elections for public officials, which is quite different from referendums, and can't replace the referendum reviewing commission that would be established to review whether the request for a referendum is legal.
Chen Chih-pin said his party doesn't agree with the Executive Yuan's proposal to eliminate the referendum reviewing commission provided for in the current law.
On the other end of the political spectrum, the ruling DPP and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , lauded the proposal as a step in the right direction.
DPP Legislator William Lai, who is the whip of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the existing Referendum Law is riddled with so many restrictions that it is almost impractical.
Instead of giving people the right to referendums, Lai claimed the law has virtually denied people the right.
TSU convener at the legislature Mark Ho said his party welcomes the Executive Yuan's proposal.
As an inherent right of the people, the fewer restrictions that are imposed on bringing about a referendum the better, Ho said.
He urged the KMT and PFP to uphold the proposal, which he said will solidify the country's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 30, or the 24th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of the Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: U.S. President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian cosmonauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record-breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.
1983: Hsu Shih-hsien, mayor of Chiayi and Taiwan's first female mayor, dies of liver cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Sten A. Akestam, president of the International Association of Lions Clubs, and six other top-ranking Lions officials.
1987: The construction of Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County, with a price-tag of NT$14 billion, is completed.
1989: ROC Interior Minister Hsu Shui-teh and Vice Defense Minister Kuo Tsung-chin jointly preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a national boundary stone tablet inscribed with the words "Shield of the South China Sea" on Tungsha Chuntao (the Pratas Islands) in the South China Sea.
1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The U.S. government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1997: Britain hands Hong Kong back to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
1999: The U.S. ratings agency Standard and Poor's gives the ROC's long-term foreign currency credit a rating of AA+, indicating its belief that the country has a high level of capability in fulfilling its financial commitments.
2000: A total of 251 sinologists from around the world meet at Taiwan's Academia Sinica to discuss the digital preservation of traditional Chinese literature and language archives.
2001: Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, accompanied by a high-profile delegation, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit to the ROC at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAND JUSTICES REVIEW FINGERPRINTING CONSTITUTIONALITY REQUEST

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices convened a meeting Thursday to review a constitutional interpretation request filed by the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to have the fingerprinting provision in the Household Registration Law invalidated.
Article 8 of the law stipulates that people claiming new national identification cards must be fingerprinted, which critics say encroaches upon their basic human rights.

DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng spoke of the gist of the request shortly after the meeting started at 9 a.m. Hsieh Ai-ling, head of the Population Administration of the Ministry of the Interior, officials from related government agencies, as well as experts and scholars also attended the meeting which lasted until noon.
The Council of Grand Justices will continue to review the matter Friday.
Gao said after reporting to the Council of Grand Justices that a majority of people support fingerprinting, which he said reflects "a failure of human rights education."
He equated fingerprinting to strip searches, saying that the policy is akin to treating everyone like a crime suspect. He added that fingerprinting violates the people's inalienable right to privacy.

The lawmaker also said that if the government is allowed to use social order as an excuse to strip the people of their rights, then there is nothing stopping it from using other national security reasons to encroach upon the people's rights.
The government originally planned to require people to be fingerprinted when they apply for the new national identification card which is set to be issued from July 1.
On May 30, the DPP filed the constitutional interpretation request after human rights groups expressed concerns with the fingerprinting policy.
In view of the limited time available, the council on June 10 ordered a moratorium on the policy until it releases its interpretation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA PERFORMS IN PARIS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 29 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Sinfonietta Philharmonic Orchestra performed classic works by J.S. Bach and Ludwig van Beethoven as well as a piece by Taiwanese composer Huang Fou-tong in Paris Wednesday.

Performing at the 18th-century Saint Roch Church near the Louvre Museum, the orchestra delighted listeners with Bach's "a minor Sonata for Violin, "Beethoven's "seventh Symphony, " and Huang's "Variations on the Theme by Chen Chu-suei."
The sinfonietta, headed by violinist Su Shien-ta, is currently on a European tour which will also take it to Slovakia in early July.

On Tuesday, the group gave a highly acclaimed performance at the Auvers-sur-Oise Music Festival. Auvers-sur-Oise, located around 40 kilometers northwest of the French capital, is the small town where Vincent van Gogh took his own life in 1890.
Five members of the sinfonietta, including a harpist and four violinists, are scheduled to head to Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, to give a chamber concert Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROTESTS TO WTO OVER OMISSION OF OFFICIALS' TITLES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) Lin Yi-fu has protested to the organization over the omission of Taiwan officials' official titles in its new directory and demanded that the directory be republished, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Taiwan's permanent mission to the WTO will also provide a list of its members, including their official titles, to the WTO missions of other countries for their reference, according to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu.

In the new WTO directory published recently, the official titles of all officials at Taiwan's permanent mission are omitted with the exception of those for the permanent representative and deputy permanent representative. The WTO reportedly made the omission due to pressure from China.
Condemning China for its "suppression of Taiwan, " Lu said Taiwan must fight for its due dignity and appeal to the international community over this "unreasonable treatment."
Lu said Taiwan has maintained smooth communication with the WTO Secretariat despite the dispute, which he said is mainly the result of the WTO's succumbing to Chinese pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: WESTERN NATIONS RETHINKING STANCES ON FINGERPRINTING: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan pointed out Thursday that even Western countries which champion human rights have begun to reconsider their stance on fingerprinting.

Su made the remarks on the sidelines of an award presentation ceremony as the Council of Grand Justices began earlier in the day to review a constitutional interpretation request filed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to have the fingerprinting provision in the Household Registration Law invalidated because of concerns that it violates human rights.

The ministry had planned to require that people be fingerprinted when claiming the new version of the national identification card originally set to begin to be issued from the start of July. However, after the legislative caucus of the DPP requested an interpretation May 30, the Council of Grand Justices on June 10 placed a moratorium on the policy until it reviews the request and releases its interpretation.
Noting that a majority of people support the fingerprinting policy, Su said, the ministry hopes the grand justices will give a ruling as soon as possible.

He pointed out that in the United Kingdom, an ID card bill which includes a fingerprinting requirement recently passed its second reading in the House of Commons. He noted that even Britain, a country noted for championing human rights, is rethinking its policy on fingerprinting.

In addition, the United States now requires arriving visitors to be fingerprinted, Su said, adding that many people who oppose fingerprinting in Taiwan comply with the fingerprinting regulation when traveling to the United States. These people are adopting a "double standard," he said.

As many industrial countries are now changing their policies on fingerprinting to protect the security of the people and the nation, Su urged the Taiwan people think about whether Taiwan, faced with a growing number of mainland Chinese and Southeast Asian immigrants, should maintain the fingerprint requirement.
"The concept of human rights changes, and we need to carefully consider whether sticking to the old human rights standards will lead to social disorder," Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 10.29 points to close at 6,241.94.
The bourse opened at 6,278.75 and fluctuated between 6,280.53 and 6,240.84 during trading. A total of 2.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.47 billion (US$1.78 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.5 percent and cement stocks and plastics and chemicals shares both gaining 0.3 percent.

Five other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent, construction issues at 0.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 558 to 282, with 174 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC DISCUSSIONS CAN BRIDGE CROSS-STRAIT GULF: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait could consult more with each other over economic matters, a move that would increase mutual trust and create conditions for political reconciliation.

"Insisting on cross-strait rapprochement" was one of three "insistences" that he said were his government's top priorities. The other two were insisting on constitutional reform and insisting on fairness and justice.
Chen made the statements while speaking at the opening ceremony of an Executive Yuan training session attended by officials groomed for future promotions. One session was dedicated to training women.

He said there is little likelihood of a breakthrough in cross-strait political relations. However, improvements can be made in economic affairs such as direct flights of cargo airplanes, opening up Taiwan's tourism market to Chinese visitors, and fishery and agricultural cooperation, he added.

If the governments on the two sides of the Strait can talk about expanding current exchanges and thereby accumulate mutual trust, it will create favorable conditions for eventual political reconciliation, he said.

The president pointed out that exchanges between people on both sides of the Strait have developed into "extremely close" ties that will be "highly valuable and significant" for the development of bilateral relations.
He hoped efforts will be made to resume cross-strait dialogue because, he said, only through dialogue can both side narrow their gap and lay a solid foundation for building mutual confidence.

While seeking dialogue and rapprochement with China, he stressed that the government will never change its "pragmatic and rational" policy of upholding Taiwan's national sovereignty and insisting on Taiwan's national identity.

Chen went on to say that since the first-phase of constitutional reform has been completed, the second phase will deal with such critical issues as adopting a three-branch or five-branch government, and choosing a presidential or cabinet system.
Elaborating on his idea of reform, he said the country should insist on rectifying all political, judicial, educational, financial, social and media abnormalities.

"This is what the people have been expecting, and this will enable our next generation to live in a 'fair and just new Taiwan' where social justice, economic justice, judicial justice, sexual justice and international justice will prevail," he said.
He vowed that the government will not forget to assist the less privileged while it seeks economic development and works to enhance national competitiveness.

The people are also eagerly expecting Taiwan to shed political polarization that has seen their society divided along the "blue" and "green" lines as ruling and opposition politicians waste their energies in endless confrontation, said the president.

He suggested that the ruling and opposition parties engage in "fair competition featuring cooperation, not confrontation," and work to "monitor each other in a check and balance that brings unity, not a war of attrition."
Taiwan must stop wasting its energy and sapping its vitality through social polarization and political confrontation; it must forge ahead for justice and democracy, he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mixed Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July remained unchanged at 6,199, with 20,191 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for August remained unchanged at 6,120, with 420 contracts traded, while September futures lost seven points to finish at 6,092, with 107 contracts traded. December futures moved up 20 points to close at 6,110, with three contracts traded, while March futures moved up 10 points to close at 6,099, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,199 for July, 6,120 for August, 6,099 for September, 6,090 for December and 6,089 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
