DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUPS TO HOLD CROSS-STRAIT WORKSHOPS

TEXT.P: Several local civic groups led by the Peacetime Foundation will hold workshops on July 30-31 and Aug. 6 to allow the public to share their views on the future of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, officials said Thursday.
The other two co-organizers of the events are the Chinatimes Cultural and Educational Foundation and the Public Television Service.
The organizers said the workshops, which they said are similar to citizen conferences, are aimed at providing a space for rational dialogue and exchanges between different voices in society.
All people above 18 years of age are welcome to take part to help the creation of a cross-strait vision from the people's perspective, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S REQUEST TO DISBAND MEDIA MONITORING GROUP 'OUTRAGEOUS': DPP

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Thursday termed a request by the legislative caucus of the Kuomintang (KMT) to disband a media monitoring group as "outrageous."

DPP Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim was responding to the opposition party's request that the government should disband such groups as the Taiwan Advertisers' Association and another alliance to monitor the media, calling them "hitmen" for the ruling party. The KMT also urged the DPP to keep its hand out of the media.
Hsiao said that the KMT had the media firmly in its grip through its party-run enterprises while in power, and that it thinks the DPP is doing the same.
She said that the civic groups are offering their views on media direction out of their free will and it is "unfair" that they be accused of being "unfair" by the KMT.
The legislative caucus of the KMT said the number and size of the media should be decided by free competition of market forces and political forces shouldn't meddle with media development.

The KMT caucus said the "cutting electronic media by half" drive launched by some civic groups is an attempt to stifle freedom of speech under the name of media reform, noting that Lin Yu-huei, chief executive officer of the media monitoring alliance served as the vice director of the DPP's department on ethnic affairs before and the alliance has long been regarded as a pro-DPP group.

The media monitoring group as well as other groups called on the Government Information Office (GIO) Wednesday, asking it to show its resolve and be stringent in renewing the licenses of cable TV stations to "phase out" media of lower quality.

The legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a DPP ally, said that it supports news freedom, but the media should also possess self-discipline. Mark Ho, TSU whip in the legislature, said that it is a fact that media lately has been awash with sensational and violent news. The party understands the worries by some civic groups, but this still should not warrant an "exit of the media."
He suggested that the media and the GIO meet to thrash out self-disciple guidelines to facilitate regulations by the GIO.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH REPS TO JOIN GOVERNMENT POLICY-MAKING PROCESS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's commission on the promotion of youth affairs decided Thursday to invite youth aged between 12 and 24 to form a "youth consultative team" in order to allow young people to directly take part in the government's policy-making process.
Minister-without-Portfolio Fu Li-yeh, who doubles as the convener of the commission, announced the decision after the commission's sixth plenary meeting.

The commission also decided to request that relevant authorities map out action plans to implement the guiding principles of the government's "Youth Policy White Book, " which was released in January, Fu said.
The white book's guidelines are based on the view that "investing in the country's youths is investing in the country's future development," Fu said.
Based on this principle, efforts will be made to provide resources for youths in their development, Fu said, adding that the commission hopes to cultivate internationally competitive youth.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Chinese President to Talk Energy.
Chinese President Hu Jintao was set to arrive in Moscow to meet President Vladimir Putin on Thursday as part of a global mission to secure energy supplies for his country's booming economy. Trade will lead the agenda of Hu's four-day visit to Russia, with oil and electricity as top priorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TV STATION FOR ABORIGINES IN ASIA TO BE SET UP JULY 1

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Thursday that the first television station for aborigines in Taiwan and in Asia will be opened Friday in Taiwan.
According to Chen, the station will represent the voices of Taiwan's more than 800 aboriginal villages from 12 tribes.

In the newest edition of the president's electronic paper, Chen recalled that on July 1, 2003 he attended the opening ceremony of the country's first television station broadcast entirely in the Hakka dialect, and on July 1, 2005, the first television station in Asia for Taiwan's indigenous people will be presented to the public.

Chen said the television station represents an opportunity for the people living on the island to know each other better, and help people interested in aboriginal culture have more knowledge about this culture.

Noting that aboriginal people excel in sports, arts and cultural aspects, Chen hailed the achievements by aboriginal people, such as the world-renowned athlete C.K. Yang, musician Kuo Ying-nan, and pop singer Chang Hue-mei, better known as A-Mei.
Chen encouraged aboriginal people to present their talents via this television station and make Taiwan more culturally diverse.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES PEOPLE TO 'SWITCH OFF AND SAVE'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Thursday called on the people to "switch off and save, " saying that if each citizen saves one unit of electricity a day, Taiwan could save NT$21 billion (US$670 million) in electricity spending every year.

Facing public concerns over possible hikes in the rates of water and electricity due to surging international crude oil prices, Chen said that he has ordered the Presidential Office management unit to map out energy-saving measures, while he and his family will also economize.

Chen made the remarks in the latest issue of his "A-Bian e-news." He said he supports an energy-saving campaign, called "switching off on the summer solstice, " which was recently launched by two private non-profit organizations, the Society of Wildness and the Delta Electronics Foundation, at Taipei's Da-an Forest Park.
The president said that the campaign is not about how much time a household turns off the lights a day, but is aimed to convince people to really implement the idea of environmental protection.

Saving energy can be achieved anywhere and anytime if people adopt good habits, Chen said, noting that under the current global consumption of energy, the world's crude oil reserves can only supply 41 years of worldwide demand, while it is expected that the Earth's environment will be further damaged under the greenhouse effect caused by fuel burning and air pollution.
It's especially important for Taiwan to lower its consumption of energy, given the fact that over 97 percent of Taiwan's energy is imported from foreign markets, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA UNLIKELY TO INVADE TAIWAN IN NEAR TERM: CHINA EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 29 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Ambassador to China James Lilley expressed his disapproval Wednesday of a Washington Times report that Beijing might take military action against Taiwan in two years.

Lilley, who is now director of Asian Studies at the American Enterprise Institute, said China's military buildup over recent years does not necessarily mean Beijing has a military ambition in the near term.

In addition, the U.S. military deployment in the Asia-Pacific region and the security cooperation between the United States and its regional allies will deter China from making an impetuous move, Lilley said.
The close economic relations between Taiwan and China, marked by investments worth US$150 billion in China by Taiwanese businesses, also makes a war unlikely across the Taiwan Strait, he said.

He said he does not think China will attack Taiwan in the near term because cross-strait tensions have tempered following the recent visits to China by two of Taiwan's opposition leaders and softening of the pro-independence stand of the Taiwan government.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 OLYMPIC GAMES SLOGAN SHOULD HIGHLIGHT PEACE, FREEDOM: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday he believes that Beijing would gain more esteem and recognition if it could give more emphasis on the spirit of "peace and freedom" in its slogan for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a delegation from the Hong Kong-based Taiwan Commerce and Industry Association,

Beijing's Olympics organizing committee announced last Sunday that the slogan for the 2008 Summer Olympic Games will be "One World, One Dream" which the committee said "embodies the common aspirations of the 1.3 billion Chinese people in establishing a world of peace and a better future."
Chen said China's desire for securing a clear break with the past by hosting a successful Olympic Games is understandable.

"China looks forward to joining the ranks of world superpowers through hosting the 2008 Olympic Games. However, a big power may not necessarily win respect and acclaim in the international community, " Chen said.
If Beijing could change its slogan to "One Peaceful World, One Free Dream, " Chen said he believes that Beijing would receive even more world recognition and esteem.
Noting that the basic Olympic spirit lies in freedom, unity, peace, friendship and progress, Chen said China should highlight those themes in its slogan.
"I'm convinced that China would win even more veneration and credit if it could change its slogan to 'One Peaceful World, One Free Dream' to embody a broader vision and deeper insight," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT INVITED TO ENDORSE SAFETY OF U.S. BEEF) The U.S. Meat Export Federation invited anexpert to endorse the safety of U.S. beef in the wake of localmisgivings about its consumption after a recent confirmation of asecond case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cowdisease, in the United States.

TEXT.P: Mel Kramer, an epidemiologist who served in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services before, said that mad cow disease is caused and spread by an abnormal form of a protein called a "prion."
Experiments in Britain showed that meat from animals under 30 months of age has yet to develop fully, and that there is no possibility of people being infected after eating it, Kramer said.

He stressed that only by eating infected issue, particularly brain, of a sick cow, can a person get infected. The beef itself will have no abnormal protein, and there is no safety concerns for U.S. beef currently sold in Taiwan.
Taiwan reimposed a ban on imports of U.S. beef last week. although the Department of Health said that the beef on local store shelves and there is no need to recall the beef.
Taiwan first banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case, the first U.S. case of mad cow disease.
Taiwan lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age April 16.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million-worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before Taiwan imposed the ban in December 2003. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, banned U.S. beef in the aftermath of the mad cow disease scare, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP STANDS BY REVISING REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's approval to amend the Referendum Law will greatly improve the government's policy-making quality and its competitiveness, an official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang made the remarks at the party's headquarters in a display of support for the Executive Yuan's proposed amendments to the Referendum Law that must be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for final approval.

In a bid to dispel outside misgivings that a more liberal Referendum Law will invite moves from the ruling DPP to initiate public referendums on sensitive national sovereignty issues, such as changes to the country's territory or official title, Lee gave his assurance that no politically delicate issues will be included in a second round of constitutional revisions.

Responding to the opposition camp's accusation that a less rigid Referendum Law will help create political unrest at home, Lee called such rhetoric a mistrust of the people of Taiwan and the country's democratic system.

As a full-fledged democracy, Taiwan is capable of holding public referendums to allow its people to exercise their mandate -- an important step to implement public mandate in a democratic country, Lee said.
The current Referendum Law, which was passed by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, is a "bird cage" law which strictly restricts the public's power regarding referendums.

The Executive Yuan gave the green light Wednesday to a Referendum Law amendment draft bill, which proposes to significantly lower the threshold for calling, endorsing and approving a referendum by the public and scrapping the rule requesting the establishment of a referendum reviewing commission at the Legislative Yuan.

Caucus members of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called a news conference earlier the same day to voice their disagreement of the Executive Yuan's Public Referendum revisions proposal, attacking the governing DPP for plotting to shift public attention from its failure in reviving the economy to boost its chances in December's city mayor and county magistrate elections by throwing out the issue.

According to KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, President Chen Shui-bian and the Executive Yuan raised the issue during the current adjournment of the Legislative Yuan mainly to campaign for the DPP in the year-end elections.

Lai claimed that the DPP wants to hollow out the power of the Legislative Yuan with the proposal, which, if approved, would permit a small number of the public to call referendums to give a final say on issues that fail to pass the legislature.

Such a situation would fan Taiwan's political wrangling polarized by pro-unification "pan blue" and pro-independence "pan green" backers, Lai predicted, warning that political instability will scare away foreign investors and lead to an economic downfall.
KMT lawmaker Fei Hrong-tai said that the Cabinet's proposal to amend the Public Referendum Law is just a DPP campaign scheme.

It would create a fresh spat of crisis across the Taiwan Strait if the DPP attempts to alter the country's territory and official designation stipulated in the Republic of China Constitution, Fei added, asserting that KMT lawmakers will undoubtedly do their best to kill the Executive Yuan's draft bill at the legislature.
In the face of strong criticism from the opposition camp, Premier Frank Hsieh claimed that the Cabinet's proposal to revise the existing Referendum Law is solely to respond to public expectations.

Although everyone has a different view of the issue, Hsieh said that an amended law will serve both the ruling and opposition parties in the future, as it also will be easier for an opposition party to initiate a referendum.
The Referendum Law is meaningless should it impose thresholds that are too high for a public referendum to be passed, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP AFRICAN ALLIES IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICES

TEXT.P: The medical aid provided by Taiwan to its African allies is gradually shifting towards the improvement of public health services and enhancement of academic research, the Department of Health's representative to Africa Chen Chih-cheng said Thursday.

Chen, who is in charge of integrating the operations of the four Taiwan medical missions in Africa, made the remarks while giving a speech at the health department. He is currently back in Taiwan on vacation.
Chen pointed out that Taiwan's medical aid to Africa was originally conducting mainly via the dispatch of medical teams to provide medical services to local people.
However, the focus of the aid is gradually shifting toward training local medical personnel and offering suggestions to improve public health policies of the African nations, Chen said.
For example, Chen said, every year, Taiwan helps train five medical doctors in Malawi and provide scholarships to five to 10 Malawian doctors to study in Taiwan.
Also, Taiwan has since last July provided free out-patient services to HIV/AIDS patients in Malawi, where an estimated 8 percent of the population have contracted the disease, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP TO PROMOTE AMITY OF CROSS-STRAIT PARLIAMENTARIANS INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A group to promote amity of parliamentarians between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait was formally inaugurated Thursday.
Former vice speaker of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi is president of the group, which is scheduled to organize a delegation to visit China in July to enhance bilateral understanding.

Yao said the amity group was formed after long-term efforts and communications over the past 30 months, and that China will also have vice chairman-level officials of the National People's Congress to launch a counterpart group to establish a platform for exchanges between parliamentarians across the Taiwan Strait and promote the wellbeing of peoples on both sides.

Incumbent Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Vice Legislative Speaker David J. C. Chung, former National Assembly President Chen Ching-jang and Yao served as the co-conveners of the group, which gathers nearly 100 incumbent and former legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS PREVENTION IS FACING CHALLENGES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will present what it considers as more effective measures to prevent the spread of AIDS Saturday, as the fatal disease is spreading rapidly in Taiwan.
The plan will be presented in accordance with the convening of the 7th International Congress on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific in Kobe, Japan, July 1-5.

According to Tsai Shu-feng, section chief of the health department in charge of AIDS prevention, the plan will focus on needle-exchange program, and replacing drug addiction by other less toxic medicines.

Chen Cheng-hue, a nurse from National Cheng Kung University Hospital, noted in her report that intravenous injection has become a factor in the rapid spread of AIDS during the last few years, citing the example of Nepal, in which the ratio of AIDS patients among drug addicts has risen from less than 2 percent in 1990 to 68 percent in 2003.
"The situation is more evident in southern Taiwan, and no one knows why," Chen added.

According to statistics from the health department's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , the ratio of AIDS transmissions among intravenous drug users in Taiwan surged to 16 percent in May this year from 2 percent in the past.

Hsieh Szu-min, a doctor from National Taiwan University Hospital, noted that a campaign focusing on "preventing AIDS with condoms" promoted by the government in the past has been so successful that drug addicts practice safe sex, but are careless with their drug habits.
In addition to the health department's prevention measures, the CDC also urged non-governmental organizations to promote AIDS prevention education among the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CLOSELY WATCHING GUATEMALA-CHINA EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taipei will closely watch trade exchanges between Guatemala and China, although Guatemala's president and foreign minister promised that Taiwan-Guatemala diplomatic ties will remain unchanged, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

According to Lu, Guatemala has been seeking to expand its exports to China to offset its long-term trade imbalance, which is the main reason the Central American country wants to open a trade office in China, which has responded positively to Guatemala's proposal.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will continue to monitor expansion in bilateral ties between China and Guatemala, despite the fact that they are economic oriented for the time being, Lu stressed.
China is very interested in Guatemala's petroleum and natural gas, while Guatemala hopes to export sugar, bananas and coffee to China, the Guatemalan Economic Ministry said recently.
Guatemala is one of the two dozen countries that maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taipei.
Beijing has in recent years been trying hard to lure away Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central and South America in a diplomatic tug of war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Morgan Stanley Plans to Rehire Its Former President.
The board of Morgan Stanley is expected to meet Thursday and elect John J. Mack, a former president of the firm, as its chairman and chief executive, succeeding Philip J. Purcell, the man who forced him out in a bitter power struggle in 2001. For Mack, 60, who drove the 1997 merger with Purcell and Dean Witter, his return is also a resounding victory for the Morgan Stanley bankers and traders whose revolt against Purcell's leadership this spring forced a recalcitrant Morgan Stanley board to abandon its longstanding support of Purcell. While a last-minute reversal is always possible, it is widely expected that the board will support Mack four years after his unceremonious departure.
Wall Street Journal: Boeing to Name 3M's McNerney as Its New Chief.
Boeing Co. is expected Thursday to name 3M Co. Chairman and Chief Executive W. James McNerney Jr. as its new CEO, tapping an outside leader with aviation-industry experience to help repair the company's reputation in the wake of a series of scandals. McNerney, who earlier ran General Electric Co.'s jet-engine unit and has s erved on the Boeing board since 2001, becomes the aerospace giant's third top official in the past year and a half. Widely respected in the aerospace industry, the 55-year-old McNerney has been pursued by Boeing's board off and on for much of that time. He knows both the commercial aircraft and military businesses, and has been known as an adept turnaround artist in previous posts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES NEW HK CHIEF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian congratulated new Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang Thursday, saying he hopes Tsang can continue to promote Hong Kong-Taiwan exchanges in addition to boosting the well-being of Hong Kong's 6.8 million residents.
Chen extended his congratulations while meeting with a delegation from the Hong Kong-based Taiwan Commerce and Industry Association.

Noting that Hong Kong is an extremely important entrepot in trade and personnel exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said forging a constructive relationship will benefit not only Taiwan and Hong Kong but will also help promote normalization of cross-strait relations.

Besides expecting Tsang to deliver on his promise to defend the basic rights and interests of the 6.8 million Hong Kong citizens, Chen said he looks forward to see Tsang take steps to increase engagements with Taiwan, promote constructive Taiwan-Hong Kong-China interaction and ensure peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

On the eve of the eighth anniversary of Hong Kong's return to Chinese rule, Chen lamented that Hong Kong is one of the few areas in the world to have seen a serious retreat in protection of personal freedom and rule of law.

"Since the former British colony returned to Chinese rule in 1997, Beijing has played a big role in Hong Kong affairs, despite its promise to allow Hong Kong to enjoy a wide-degree of autonomy under a 'one country, two systems' formula," Chen said.
At least 163 cases involving Chinese government's encroachment upon Hong Kong's autonomy, judicial independence and freedom of speech have been reported over the past eight years, Chen said.

In the past year alone, Chen said, the Chinese government has repeatedly vetoed Hong Kong people's appeal for direct election of their chief executive and legislators, dictated the schedule for Hong Kong's political reform and grossly intervened in the Hong Kong legislative council elections and the by-election of its chief executive.

Chen recalled that a Hong Kong talk show host was forced to stop comments on political events under Beijing's pressure and that a Hong Kong-born correspondent of a Singaporean newspaper was arrested in Beijing earlier this year on charges of spying. All these incidents have caused concern in the world community, he added.

Tsang, a popular career civil servant who last week assumed the title of chief executive -- Hong Kong's highest political post -- in a ceremony held in Beijing, will serve out the tenure left vacant by Tung Chee-hwa, who quit in March this year citing fatigue and failing health, although it is widely believed that was just an excuse and that the unpopular Tung was simply dumped by his puppet masters in Beijing.
Thanks to Beijing's gross intervention, only Tsang registered for the chief executive by-election and consequently, there was no vote by the 800-member electoral college.

"In the process of the by-election, the 6.8 million Hong Kong residents were deprived of their most basic political rights. It is sad and regrettable that an ultra-modern and prosperous society like Hong Kong has been handcuffed with a medieval despotic political system," Chen said.

In the past, Tung took his oath of office in Hong Kong. This time around, Tsang was sworn in inside the People's Great Hall in Beijing. "The change is yet another sign of the decline in Hong Kong's autonomy and separate identity," Chen said.

If China cannot embrace freedom and democracy and accelerate its political reform, Chen said, Hong Kong's development will definitely be restricted. Whether China can maintain its current pace of economic growth will also be in doubt, he added.

Given Hong Kong's important intermediary role in cross-strait relations, Chen went on, his administration will continue keeping a close watch on its democratic development and expanding services to Taiwan expatriates there.
Judging from Hong Kong's fate in the past eight years, Chen said Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula is mere hot air.

"My observation is that 'one county' is real, but 'two systems' is false. Hong Kong's example can serve as a reminder to peace- and democracy-loving people around the world. Taiwan must learn a lesson from it. We must make every possible effort to avert such a sad experience for the 23 million Taiwan people," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DAY CELEBRATION TO BE STAGED IN TAICHUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 30 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) kicked off a series of activities in Taichung Thursday with a lobster festival to celebrate Canada's 138th birthday, which falls on July 1.
The CTOT is hosting the events in partnership with the Taichung city government and various partners around the country.

On Canada Day, the CTOT will offer information and services on-site in Taichung to "strengthen Canada's relationship in central Taiwan with the public, the business community and Canadian citizens," according to a CTOT official.

"We have in recent years developed a tradition of celebrating Canada Day outside of Taipei. Dubbed the 'Canada Day Road Show', we've found it's an effective way to reach out to Taiwanese people around the island, " said Gordon Houlden, executive director of the CTOT.
Houlden said the CTOT received an enthusiastic welcome from Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and the business community, and added that "we wish to recognize the Canadian community in central Taiwan."

He will host a Canada Day gala luncheon and Canadian Ginseng Festival featuring North American ginseng, of which Canada is the world's largest supplier, producing about 60 percent of the global supply.

The CTOT will also host the Canadian Technology and Investment Seminar: Go North! The seminar is co-hosted by the Central Taiwan Science Park and the Economic Bureau of the Taichung city government, aiming to provide Taiwan companies with information they need to evaluate business collaboration opportunities outside of Taiwan.

As Canada is the 3rd-largest car exporter in the world after the United States and Japan and has one of the fastest-growing automotive research, development and testing sectors in the global automotive sector, the seminar is expected to draw quite a number of interested investors.

A seminar on Canadian Design Excellence in Green Building will also be held, featuring experts from Canadian companies, the CTOT and the Chinese Architecture and Building Center (CABC) . The seminar, supported by the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, will profile Canadian capability in sustainable development initiatives, green building techniques and compliance with mandatory green building design criteria introduced in Taiwan in 2002.

Special to the 2005 Canada Day celebration is an expanded gathering of Canadian studies scholars from around Taiwan, coinciding with the establishment of the Canadian Studies Association and the annual Canadian Studies 2005 Scholarship Award Reception.

On July 2, there will be a charity premiere of the Canadian film "The Blue Butterfly, " to which some 200 minority children, those suffering from rare diseases and young cancer patients have been invited.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VATICAN TIES STABLE: MOFA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the Vatican are stable and reports of the possibility of official ties between China and the Holy See are just a Chinese plot to ruin ROC-Vatican ties, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official claimed Thursday.
MOFA Spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks following reports that China's newly appointed auxiliary bishop for Shanghai has gained recognition from the Vatican.

Officials from Chinese churches said this is an "active signal" for a step forward in China-Vatican relations, as it is the first time that both the Chinese communist government and the Holy See have tacitly agreed the appointment of the country's top church post.

Although Liu Bonian, an official at the state-approved Chinese Catholic Patriotic Association, admitted that the appointment has been made in accordance with Chinese procedure, he claimed that the recognition from the Vatican represents "a step forward."
Some Chinese church leaders have expressed hope that the appointment can help achieve reconciliation between the Chinese government and the Holy See.
China has no diplomatic relations with the Holy See and has rejected the pope's authority to appoint bishops.
Lu said official ties between the ROC and the Vatican have had many complications during the last three decades. However, the ties have remained stable despite Chinese interference.
China has demanded that the Vatican sever its formal relations with Taiwan in exchange for the setting up of officials ties.

"We don't think China will allow religious freedom in the foreseeable future and we believe that the Vatican is chiefly concerned with religious freedom and the numerous Catholics in China, " Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO DEPART FOR 9-DAY U.S. VISIT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang will depart Taipei Friday for a nine-day visit to the United States aimed at promoting bilateral exchanges, DPP sources said Thursday.

Su's first stop will be San Francisco, where he will address a meeting of an ethnic Taiwanese medical doctor's association Saturday. Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, is also expected to attend that meeting.

DPP sources said Su will keep a low profile during his visit, the ultimate goal of which will be achieving substantive results. He will be accompanied by several DPP officials, including Legislator Hsiao Bu-khim, who concurrently heads the DPP's international affairs department.

Following his San Francisco visit, Su will travel to Washington, D.C., where he will deliver a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a noted think tank. He will also meet with U.S. congressional leaders and other political figures. The full itinerary, however, was not disclosed.

Su will also visit Boston and New York to meet with think tank scholars and Taiwanese community leaders, as well as taking care of some private affairs, including his eldest daughter's enrollment in a graduate school in Boston, DPP sources said.
During his stay in New York, the sources said, Su may watch a New York Yankees baseball game with Taiwan-born pitcher Wang Chien-ming as starter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA MARINE CAPABILITY STILL INADEQUATE: ROC DEFENSE OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The People's Liberation Army's sea combat capability is still inadequate but if it wages "psychological, media and legal warfare" against Taiwan, the country will be under a great threat, a defense official claimed Thursday.
Gen. Hu Chen-pu, director-general of the General Political Warfare Bureau of the Ministry of National Defense, made the remarks while speaking to graduating cadets of five military academies.
In order to counter China's possible "soft-strike" strategy, Hu said Taiwan's political warfare units will have to remodel themselves into an effective, professional and integrated force.
His bureau will shed unrelated business and focus on psychological warfare and counseling, cultural promotion, civilian services and military news releases -- all non-military jobs, he went on.

Accordingly, he said, political warfare officers will have to sharpen their skills in boosting morale, serving military families and communicating with the media and elected representatives of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-RUSSIA TIES CAN BE FURTHER IMPROVED

TEXT.P: There is room for improvement in Taiwan-Russia relations, although bilateral trade between the two countries has been rapidly increasing in recent years, the Taiwan-Russia Association president said Thursday.

Chang Chun-hsiung, who doubles as chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a semi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties, made the remarks in a meeting with a visiting Russian parliamentary delegation headed by Vladimir Smolensky.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Russia increased to US$3 billion in last year, Chang said, noting however that the figure is far lower than that of cross-Taiwan Strait trade.

Chang, a former premier, expressed hope that Taiwan and Russia will continue to increase bilateral exchanges based on the existing cooperation relations. He also encouraged Taiwan businessmen to invest in Russia.

Smolensky, who arrived in Taiwan at the head of a six-member delegation a day earlier, said the Russian government has presented a draft bill on the establishment of special economic zones to its parliament for screening.
He said that he and his delegation are expected to find out about Taiwan's experiences in this field during the visit for Moscow's reference, while promoting bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
Smolensky also pledged to do his best to promote the opening of direct Taiwan-Russia air links.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SIGNS ANTI-MONEY LAUNDERING PACT WITH PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: Officials of Taiwan and Paraguay signed an agreement Thursday to jointly combat money laundering and information-exchange by terrorists, at an annual plenary meeting of the Egmont Group held in Washington, according to officials of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice (MOJ).
The pact was signed by Yiia Shan-mao, director of the Investigation Bureau, and Carlos Yegros, director-general of Paraguay's Financial Intelligence Unit.
MOJ officials said the pact is expected to help strengthen the two countries' capability in combating cross-border crimes and terrorist activities.

In addition to exchanging views with related anti-crime agencies of other participant countries at the Egmont Group meeting, Yiia was also seeking the possibility of forging anti-crime cooperation with other countries.

The major anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist organizations in the world, such as the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and the Egmont Group, have said that information exchange among countries is the most important way to fight money laundering and terrorism.

According to MOJ officials, the anti-money laundering center under the Investigation Bureau is Taiwan's financial intelligence data center, which serves as Taiwan's communication channel with such centers of other countries, and its signing of an anti-crime agreement with Paraguay represents a step forward in international judicial cooperation, following similar agreements signed with Albania and Palau.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN PLAN TO STAGE PROTESTS AT JIA OFFICE

TEXT.P: Fishermen in the northeastern county of Ilan plan to organize a protest at Japan's de facto embassy in Taipei July 7 over the Japanese coast guard's frequent disturbance of their operations in waters off northeastern Taiwan, fishery sources said Thursday.

Suao fishermen said they will invite their counterparts in other parts of the country to join the protest at the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), a quasi-official organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Following their planned protest at the JIA, the fishermen also plan to file a petition with the Executive Yuan pushing it not to compromise their rights during a new round of fishery talks with Japan scheduled for July 29 in Tokyo.

Over the past year, Japanese coast guard ships have often chased Taiwan fishermen away from the two countries' overlapping economic zones near the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea. Japan has even impounded more than 10 Taiwan fishing boats over the past year.

Japanese coast guard ships temporarily suspended patrols in the disputed waters after some 50 Suao-based fishing boats staged a rare protest in the waters early this month and a naval warship made a brief visit to the sensitive zone, supposedly to accentuate Taiwan's determination to protect its fishermen's rights and safety. Some 15 lawmakers from across the party spectrum, led by Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, took the cruise aboard the warship in the company of Defense Minister Lee Jye.

Nevertheless, Japanese patrol ships returned to the area again last weekend and served notice to a Suao-based fishing boat warning it to leave the region even though the boat was operating within the middle line of the two countries' overlapping economic zones, known locally as the "tentative demarcation line."

A Suao Fishermen's Association spokesman said local fishermen plan to demonstrate at the JIA office in Taipei next Thursday in protest over the latest action. The planned protest is also aimed at reminding the government not to sacrifice fishermen's rights in the upcoming 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks.

At the heart of the dispute is the two countries' sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutai Islands. Both Tokyo and Taipei claim that the island group falls within their 200-mile exclusive economic zones. Japan often fines ship owners and impounds Taiwanese fishing vessels that enter waters close to the Tiaoyutais.
The previous 14 rounds of Taiwan-Japanese fishery talks did not make significant headway because Taiwan would not forsake its sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutais, which Japan has held since 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL NOT ATTACK TAIWAN BEFORE 2010: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The likelihood of a military conflict between Taiwan and China before 2010 is slim, thanks partly to the visits to China by two opposition party leaders, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official claimed Thursday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of KMT Culture and Communication Committee, disputed speculation that Beijing is likely to invade Taiwan in the forseeable future, claiming that Chinese President Hu Jintao will not address the "Taiwan problem" before 2010 because his regime will be obsessed with preparations for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, the 2010 Shanghai Expo and the 2010 Guangzhou Asian Games.
At the same time, Chang said, Beijing will keep an eye on the outcome of the 2008 presidential election in Taiwan, which he predicted will hold sway on Beijing's approach toward Taiwan.

However, Chang claimed that President Chen Shui-bian's attempts to revamp the Constitution by 2008 and his administration's proposal to revise the Referendum Law might force Hu to change "his plan of waiting until 2010 to deal with Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SHOWCASES WORK DONE BY ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh Thursday showcased the work done by his administration this month.

In a news conference called for the first monthly showing of his administration's work, the premier touted 37 "distinguished tasks" chosen from 138 jobs done by ministries and agencies under the Executive Yuan in June.

Notable among them was work to help conserve flying fish around Orchid Island, a cultural exhibition of the Shao aboriginal tribe, the opening of the 2005 Tung Blossom Hakka Festival, the creation of a"Taiwan Images" blog and the staging of the 2005 National Exhibition of Performing Arts, the inking of a contract with a private constructor to build a sewage system for Tanshui in Taipei County.

Others include the resumption of diplomatic relations with Nauru, helping the Public Television Station to broadcast live 28 U.S. Big league matches featuring Taiwanese pitcher Wang Chien-ming, exports of Taiwan papayas to Japan for the first time and testing duck eggs for dioxin.

Speaking at the news conference, Hsieh said he asked the government agencies last month to report to the Executive Yuan their remarkable achievements every month and to show them off at a news conference so the public can see what the government is doing for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIDS QUILT ASSOCIATION FORMALLY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: After many twists and turns, the Taiwan AIDS Quilts Association was formally launched Thursday to help enhance public awareness of AIDS, promote AIDS victims' rights and assist in AIDS prevention.
The association is one of the world's 33 similar organizations dedicated to promoting international exchanges in AIDS prevention.

The non-profit organization will send a delegation to the 7th International Conference on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific to be held in Kobe, Japan July 1-5 to report on Taiwan's efforts in AIDS education, prevention and control.

10:00, President Chen Shui-bian will address the opening ceremony of the 2005 Science Fair at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL SUPERVISORY COMMISSION TO SET UP OFFICE IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved the establishment of a representative office of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) in New York, FSC officials said Thursday.
FSC representative Weng Wen-chi and his deputy, Tseng Mei-shin, are scheduled to take over their new posts in New York in the near future, the officials said.

The establishment of the FSC's New York office, which will be located at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, is aimed at increasing cooperation and exchanges with the main international financial supervisory agencies and organizations, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NOT HINDER CHINA'S PEACEFUL RISE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not be an obstacle to China's emergence, providing its emergence is peaceful and not with an eye toward Taiwan's extermination, Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday.

In an interview with the Voice of America (VOA) , Hsieh said the basic principle for his administration to develop ties with China is that it should not compromise the country's status quo and should serve the interest of the people.
Taiwan will not be interested in improving ties with China if China poses a threat to its existence, Hsieh said.
He ruled out the possibility of his visiting China in the foreseeable future because of concern that it might give rise to public mistrust in his government.

As to China's "one China policy, " the premier said Beijing defines it in lenient terms while dealing with Taiwan but requests other countries to follow a strict "one China policy" that recognizes Beijing as the sole legitimate regime of China.

Noting that he offered June 13 to negotiate with China on the exporting of Taiwan fruit to China, visits to Taiwan by Chinese tourists and the opening of direct chartered flights across the Taiwan Strait, the premier said Beijing has responded positively to the first two issues.
He passed over the question of whether he will run in the 2008 presidential election on the Democratic Progressive Party ticket, saying that it is too early to say.
The interview was broadcast Thursday by VOA and its pretext will be posted on the VOA Web site.
